Author’s Note 作者的话
------------------

during the year i wrote this book, every day I woke up and deliberately chose faith over fear. 在我写这本书的那一年里，每天醒来我都刻意选择信仰而不是恐惧。

I had recently come off a lucrative venture where I co-founded a cryptocurrency. I quit that venture in not the most pleasant fashion. My friends and family expected me to start a newer, bigger, and better cryptocurrency. The stage was set for me to “get back” at my old business partners who I had a falling out with… 我最近结束了一项有利可图的投资，在那里我共同创立了一种加密货币。我以一种不太愉快的方式退出了那项事业。我的朋友和家人希望我开始一种更新、更大、更好的加密货币。这个舞台是为我 “报复” 与我吵架的老商业伙伴准备的……

And there I was, assembling boxes of notecards and writing about it. There I was, dedicating my life to a thing that flies over the heads of most people. There was no clear path to recouping my time spent exploring the system you’re about to learn in this book. Yet, I chose faith. There’s something here, I told myself. There’s something that is bigger than a mere box of notecards. After reading this book, I know you’ll find this to be true. 我就在那里，组装成箱的记事卡并写下来。我在那里，将我的生命献给了大多数人都无法理解的事情。没有明确的途径可以收回我花在探索你将在本书中学习的系统上的时间。然而，我选择了信仰。这里有东西，我告诉自己。有些东西比一盒记事本还要大。读完这本书，我知道你会发现这是真的。

This book is for those who value the intellectual pursuit in life. It’s for those who wish to unlock their inner-genius so that they can contribute something to the world. It’s for those committed to growth and learning. 本书适合那些重视生活中的知识追求的人。它适合那些希望释放内在天赋的人，以便他们可以为世界做出贡献。它适用于那些致力于成长和学习的人。

Thank you for joining me on this journey. 感谢您加入我的旅程。

Just remember one thing—actually two: First, always choose faith over fear. And second: always remember…to stay crispy, my friend.[1](#footnote-011) 只要记住一件事——实际上是两件事：第一，永远选择信仰而不是恐惧。第二：永远记住…… 保持酥脆，我的朋友。 1

Preface (Do Not Skip) 前言（请勿跳过）
------------------------------

the subject of this book concerns itself with a knowledge development system created entirely out of notecards. I call this system the Antinet Zettelkasten (or simply, the “Antinet”). 本书的主题涉及一个完全由记事卡创建的知识开发系统。我称这个系统为 Antinet Zettelkasten（或简称为 “Antinet”）。

**The Triple-entendre of The Antinet 安提内特的三重联结**
------------------------------------------------

The Antinet is a triple-entendre.Antinet 是一个三重关系。

First off, it’s a tongue-in-cheek jab at the digitally obsessed world we live in. There’s no debating that digital technologies have changed our world, mostly for the better. Digital technologies are better than their analog counterparts for many things: navigation, an open encyclopedia, information sharing, and so on. However, the one thing I contend that digital is not great for is this: thinking. Deep, deliberate thinking. Both short-term development of thought and long-term development of thought are best procured using analog tools. 首先，这是对我们生活的数字化世界的一种半开玩笑的嘲讽。毫无疑问，数字技术已经改变了我们的世界，主要是为了变得更好。数字技术在很多方面都优于模拟技术：导航、开放式百科全书、信息共享等。然而，我认为数字化不擅长的一件事是：思考。深思熟虑，深思熟虑。思想的短期发展和思想的长期发展都最好使用模拟工具来获得。

This being the case, the Antinet doesn’t mean “anti-internet.” In fact, in this book, I introduce an option for using a digital reference manager. Therefore, the Antinet is not purely analog in nature. After all, digital reference managers require the internet. 既然如此，Antinet 并不意味着 “反互联网”。事实上，在本书中，我介绍了使用数字参考管理器的选项。因此，Antinet 在本质上并不是纯粹的模拟。毕竟，数字参考管理器需要互联网。

The second meaning behind the term Antinet refers to its use as an acronym. The Antinet is an acronym that maps to four principles (detailed later on). The four principles the acronym maps to are the same four principles employed by Niklas Luhmann, the main originator of the Antinet. I’ll introduce you to the acronym of the Antinet later in this book. And I’ll introduce you to Luhmann shortly. But first, let me tell you about the third entendre.Antinet 一词背后的第二个含义是指它作为首字母缩写词的使用。 Antinet 是映射到四个原则的首字母缩写词（稍后详述）。首字母缩略词映射到的四项原则与 Antinet 的主要创始人尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 采用的四项原则相同。我将在本书后面向您介绍 Antinet 的首字母缩写词。我很快就会把你介绍给卢曼。但首先，让我告诉你第三个共鸣。

The third meaning behind Antinet refers to Antonin Sertillanges. This Catholic intellectual and writer built his own Antinet-like system and wrote about it in his book The Intellectual Life. I talk about Sertillanges throughout this book. The “Ant” in Antinet also serves as an ode to Antonin.Antinet 背后的第三个含义是指 Antonin Sertillanges。这位天主教知识分子和作家建立了他自己的 Antinet-like 系统，并在他的著作《知识分子生活》中对此进行了描述。我在整本书中都在谈论 Sertillanges。 Antinet 中的 “Ant” 也是对 Antonin 的颂歌。

**Antinet vs. ZettelkastenAntinet vs. Zettelkasten**
----------------------------------------------------

The Antinet most directly originated from the work of a German scholar named Niklas Luhmann, a man who gained popularity for his genius-level theoretical work in the field of sociology. Luhmann referred to his Antinet as a Zettelkasten, which in American English means notebox, and in European English translates to slip box. Throughout the rest of this book, I’ll use the terms Antinet, Zettelkasten, analog Zettelkasten, and Luhmann’s notebox, interchangeably. And for any grammarians out there: I use the German singular form of Zettelkasten as both singular and plural in English, rather than trying to work in the German plural form of Zettelkästen. The Chicago Manual of Style, on which this book’s format relies, dictates one should not pluralize foreign words as though they were English.Antinet 最直接的起源是德国学者尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的著作，此人以其在社会学领域的天才级理论工作而声名远播。 Luhmann 将他的 Antinet 称为 Zettelkasten，在美式英语中意为记事本，在欧洲英语中翻译为滑箱。在本书的其余部分，我将交替使用术语 Antinet、Zettelkasten、模拟 Zettelkasten 和卢曼的笔记本。对于那里的任何语法学家：我使用 Zettelkasten 的德语单数形式作为英语的单数和复数形式，而不是尝试使用 Zettelkästen 的德语复数形式。本书格式所依据的《芝加哥文体手册》规定，不应将外来词复数化，就好像它们是英语一样。

I must caution you that outside of this book, the term Zettelkasten does not refer to the same concept I’m referring to. When I use the term Zettelkasten, I’m referring to the version of the Zettelkasten that Niklas Luhmann himself used: an analog one. I am not referring to the abstracted interpretations that the term has found itself cloaked in today. This so-called “cloaked” version stems from the metamorphosis of a physical thinking system into a metaphysical one. The embodiment of this new version is akin to that of digital notetaking apps with note-linking capabilities. Such apps (which are themselves digital Zettelkasten systems) merely link notes. I consider such apps to operate in an entirely different realm altogether. Get ready to enter the world of the Antinet. It’s a trip. 我必须提醒您，在本书之外，术语 Zettelkasten 所指的概念与我所指的不同。当我使用 Zettelkasten 一词时，我指的是 Niklas Luhmann 自己使用的 Zettelkasten 版本：模拟版本。我指的不是这个词在今天隐藏起来的抽象解释。这种所谓的 “隐形” 版本源于物理思维系统向形而上学系统的变形。这个新版本的体现类似于具有笔记链接功能的数字笔记应用程序。此类应用程序（它们本身就是数字 Zettelkasten 系统）仅链接笔记。我认为此类应用程序在完全不同的领域中运行。准备好进入 Antinet 的世界。这是一次旅行。

**A Note on the Subtitle of This Book 关于本书副标题的注释**
--------------------------------------------------

The initial subtitle for this book was, The Secret Knowledge Development System Evolved by History’s Greatest Minds. After I finished writing this book, I decided to change its subtitle to the one you find on its cover: Uncovering the True Magic of the Notebox System That Will Turn You into a Research and Writing Machine. I believe this new version better emphasizes two “core aspects” of the book, which I will detail now: 这本书最初的副标题是，历史上最伟大的头脑进化的秘密知识发展系统。写完这本书后，我决定将其副标题更改为封面上的副标题：揭开笔记本系统的真正魔力，它将把你变成研究和写作机器。我相信这个新版本更好地强调了本书的两个 “核心方面”，我现在将详细介绍：

The first core aspect of this book centers around uncovering the true magic of Niklas Luhmann’s notebox system (the Zettelkasten). You will learn how the modern (digital) interpretations of Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten are quite different from its true (original) nature. These modern interpretations of Zettelkasten lack the most important principles of the system. As a result, the modern interpretations are far less effective when it comes to achieving its main goal (genius-level creative output).[2](#footnote-010) In this book, we will uncover the true magic of Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten so that you can experience its fullness (and avoid wasting your time with the modern, less-effective digital interpretations). 本书的第一个核心方面围绕揭开尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 笔记本系统 (Zettelkasten) 的真正魔力展开。您将了解 Niklas Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的现代（数字）解释与其真实（原始）性质有何不同。 Zettelkasten 的这些现代解释缺乏该系统最重要的原则。因此，在实现其主要目标（天才级创意输出）时，现代诠释的效果要差得多。2 在本书中，我们将揭开尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的 Zettelkasten 的真正魔力，让您体验它的完整性 (并避免将时间浪费在现代、低效的数字解释上）。

The second core aspect of this book centers around directing us towards the end goal. What is the end goal? The end goal is to become a research and writing machine. You see, a common misconception regarding Zettelkasten is that it is a subfield of Personal Knowledge Management (“PKM”). PKM has largely come to refer to digital notetaking apps for storing information. With each passing year, new digital notetaking apps emerge with more and more features (linking notes, tagging notes, creating pre-built templates for notes, metadata conventions for notes, etc.). The one thing digital notetaking apps seemingly do not focus on is…helping you develop knowledge! Luhmann’s sole purpose for building his Zettelkasten centered on helping him become a research and writing machine. It was a system that helped him develop knowledge. It was a system that helped him evolve the many thoughts that emerged from his readings (over four decades). All of this was done with a sole focus on becoming a prolific research and writing machine (which is what he became). In brief, the true nature of Zettelkasten is not an information storage system; it’s a Knowledge Development System—more specifically, it’s an Analog Knowledge Development system (an “AKD”).[3](#footnote-009) 本书的第二个核心方面围绕着引导我们走向最终目标。最终目标是什么？最终目标是成为一个研究和写作机器。你看，关于 Zettelkasten 的一个常见误解是它是个人知识管理（“PKM”）的一个子领域。 PKM 在很大程度上指的是用于存储信息的数字笔记应用程序。随着时间的推移，新的数字笔记应用程序出现了越来越多的功能（链接笔记、标记笔记、创建笔记的预建模板、笔记的元数据约定等）。数字笔记应用程序似乎不关注的一件事是…… 帮助您发展知识！ Luhmann 建立 Zettelkasten 的唯一目的是帮助他成为研究和写作机器。这是一个帮助他发展知识的系统。这是一个帮助他发展从他的阅读（超过四个十年）中出现的许多想法的系统。所有这一切都是为了成为一个多产的研究和写作机器（他就是这样）。简而言之，Zettelkasten 的真正本质不是信息存储系统；它是一个知识开发系统——更具体地说，它是一个模拟知识开发系统（“AKD”）。 3

Am I saying that the Zettelkasten is only for those interested in becoming a research machine or a writing machine? Not quite. Even if you’re interested in becoming a reading machine (i.e., learning machine), an Antinet Zettelkasten can help you. However, it is important to adopt the mindset of approaching the books you read as if you’ll be writing a book about the material. Paradoxically, adopting this mindset (as if you were going to teach the material), helps you learn the material.[4](#footnote-008) In brief, by adopting the writing machine mindset, you will become a better learning machine. 我是说 Zettelkasten 只适合那些有兴趣成为研究机器或写作机器的人吗？不完全的。即使您有兴趣成为阅读机器（即学习机器），Antinet Zettelkasten 也可以帮助您。然而，重要的是要采用一种心态，将你阅读的书籍当作你要写一本关于这些材料的书。矛盾的是，采用这种思维方式（就好像您要教材料一样）可以帮助您学习材料。4 简而言之，通过采用写作机器的思维方式，您将成为更好的学习机器。

After I determined this was the better subtitle, I let things sit for a week or so. To recap, the subtitle I was left with was, Uncovering the True Magic of the Notebox System That Will Turn You into a Research and Writing Machine. However, when looking at the length of the subtitle, I found it to be too wordy. Therefore, I decided to condense it to what you find on the cover: A Knowledge System That Will Turn You Into a Prolific Reader, Researcher and Writer. That cuts straight to the heart of the matter (even though uncovering the true nature of Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten remains a core theme of this book). 在我确定这是更好的副标题后，我让事情搁置了一个星期左右。回顾一下，我留下的副标题是，揭开笔记本系统的真正魔力，它将把你变成一个研究和写作机器。然而，当我看到字幕的长度时，我发现它太罗嗦了。因此，我决定将其浓缩为您在封面上找到的内容：一个知识体系，它将使您成为多产的读者、研究人员和作家。这直接切入了问题的核心（尽管揭示尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的 Zettelkasten 的真实本质仍然是本书的核心主题）。

While the new subtitle better encompasses the two core aspects of this book, I think the very first subtitle is also worth diving into (aka, the “legacy subtitle”). The reason why is that much of this book touches on the rich history of the Zettelkasten. This adds important seasoning to the book. Let’s dive into this now. 虽然新副标题更好地涵盖了本书的两个核心方面，但我认为第一个副标题也值得深入研究（又名 “旧版副标题”）。原因是本书的大部分内容都涉及 Zettelkasten 丰富的历史。这为本书增添了重要的调味料。现在让我们深入探讨一下。

**The Rich History of ZettelkastenZettelkasten 丰富的历史**
------------------------------------------------------

The legacy subtitle of this book is The Secret Knowledge Development System Evolved by History’s Greatest Minds. Please take note of a few things: 这本书的旧副标题是历史上最伟大的头脑进化的秘密知识发展系统。请注意以下几点：

First, note the phrase History’s Greatest Minds. This touches on the idea that it was not Luhmann alone who produced the Antinet Zettelkasten. After all, in 1786, Johann Friedrich Blumenbach described the usage of slip boxes (Zettelkästchen).[5](#footnote-007) Indeed, some of history’s greatest minds used systems closely resembling the Antinet. Luhmann was intimately familiar with many of these scholars[6](#footnote-006). In turn, they have had a hand in evolving the Antinet as we know it. 首先，请注意历史上最伟大的思想这个短语。这涉及到制作 Antinet Zettelkasten 的并非卢曼一人。毕竟，在 1786 年，Johann Friedrich Blumenbach 描述了滑箱 (Zettelkästchen) 的用法。5 事实上，历史上一些最伟大的思想家使用的系统与 Antinet 非常相似。卢曼与这些学者中的许多人都非常熟悉 6。反过来，他们也参与了我们所知的 Antinet 的发展。

Those who evolved the Antinet include the following individuals:[7](#footnote-005) 那些进化了 Antinet 的人包括以下个人：7

Second, note the phrase Evolved by. The historical genealogy of the Antinet was “perhaps first mentioned in 1548 by Conrad Gessner.” It was then expanded by Georg Philipp Harsdöffer (1607–1658), Joachim Jungius (1587–1657), and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646–1716). The Catholic intellectual and philosopher Antonin Sertillanges outlines a similar system to the Antinet. His book, The Intellectual Life, published in 1921, contains the instructions in explicit detail.[8](#footnote-004) 其次，请注意 “Evolved by” 这个短语。 Antinet 的历史谱系“可能在 1548 年由 Conrad Gessner 首次提及”。随后，Georg Philipp Harsdöffer (1607–1658)、Joachim Jungius (1587–1657) 和 Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646–1716) 对其进行了扩展。天主教知识分子和哲学家 Antonin Sertillanges 概述了一个与 Antinet 类似的系统。他在 1921 年出版的著作《知识分子生活》中包含了详细的说明。 8

The Antinet was developed by the likes of many learned scholars throughout time. Yet, the Antinet’s “non-electronic completion” is viewed by scholars as stamped by Niklas Luhmann.[9](#footnote-003)Antinet 是由许多博学的学者开发的。然而，Antinet 的 “非电子完成” 被学者们视为尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的印记。 9

In the early 1950s, when Luhmann began building his Zettelkasten, he was working at the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court. It was there that he spent his time “organizing a reference system for administrative court decisions.”[10](#footnote-002) When asked by an interviewer what he did after getting off work at five o’clock in the evening, Luhmann replied that he read a lot and, “above all I started to work with a Zettelkasten.”[11](#footnote-001) From this, one infers that whatever Luhmann learned while organizing the reference system for the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court ended up helping him evolve the Zettelkasten into what it is today.1950 年代初期，当卢曼开始建造他的 Zettelkasten 时，他正在吕讷堡高等行政法院工作。正是在那里，他花了很多时间 “为行政法院判决组织一个参考系统。”10 当一位采访者问及他晚上五点下班后做了什么时，卢曼回答说他读了很多书，而且， “最重要的是，我开始与 Zettelkasten 一起工作。”11 由此可以推断，无论卢曼在为 Lüneburg 高等行政法院组织参考系统时学到了什么，最终都帮助他将 Zettelkasten 发展成了今天的样子。

For this reason, the Antinet is not a secret knowledge development system created by one individual; rather, it’s a secret knowledge development system evolved by history’s greatest minds. The overhyped digital notetaking systems of today have rendered the old way of developing knowledge almost completely lost. Analog knowledge development has become a secret. Its methods are a secret known only to a small collection of people. For instance, scholars who study the evolution of notetaking in Early Modern Europe.[12](#footnote-000) Even though the legacy subtitle is admittedly sensationalistic, I hold that there is at least sensational substance to support its sensationalism. 因此，Antinet 不是一个人创造的秘密知识开发系统；相反，它是由历史上最伟大的头脑进化而来的秘密知识开发系统。当今过度宣传的数字笔记系统已经使旧的知识增长方式几乎完全消失了。模拟知识开发已成为秘密。它的方法是一个秘密，只有一小部分人知道。例如，研究早期现代欧洲笔记演变的学者。12 尽管遗留副标题公认是耸人听闻的，但我认为至少有耸人听闻的物质来支持它的耸人听闻。

In summary, you can see by the depth of both subtitles how robust this book is. It touches on many aspects of the Zettelkasten: its true nature, its modern misconceptions, its key principles, its history, its magic, its scientific underpinnings, and more. This additional context gives you a greater respect for the journey you’re about to embark on in reading this book. But before you do, let’s talk about the goal of this book. 总而言之，你可以从这两个字幕的深度看出这本书的强大程度。它涉及 Zettelkasten 的许多方面：它的真实性质、它的现代误解、它的主要原则、它的历史、它的魔力、它的科学基础等等。这个额外的背景让你更加尊重你即将踏上阅读本书的旅程。但在此之前，让我们谈谈本书的目标。

**The Goal of This Book 本书的目标**
-------------------------------

The goal of this book is both simple and complex. My goal is to help people who are committed to growth and learning to create genius-level work. I hope the genius-level work created lasts for two hundred years or more. The reason any piece of work might last for two hundred years or more is related to the contribution it makes to other people. 本书的目标既简单又复杂。我的目标是帮助致力于成长和学习的人创造出天才级别的作品。我希望创造的天才级别的作品能持续两百年或更长时间。一件作品之所以能流传两百多年，与它对他人的贡献有关。

That is my why. 这就是我的原因。

My what is this system: the Antinet. The Antinet is a knowledge development system. It’s a tool that enables one to develop thoughts. I also contend that it develops thoughts better than its digital imitators. The Antinet enables one to unlock brilliant insights. It’s built on fundamental principles that help develop one’s mind. It’s built on both order and chaos. In turn, it reveals accidental associations and unconventional interactions between ideas. There are other properties of the system I will introduce in the book as well. 我的这个系统是什么：Antinet。 Antinet 是一个知识开发系统。它是一种使人能够发展思想的工具。我还认为它比它的数字模仿者更能发展思想。 Antinet 使人能够解锁绝妙的见解。它建立在有助于发展思想的基本原则之上。它建立在秩序和混乱之上。反过来，它揭示了想法之间的偶然联系和非常规互动。我还将在本书中介绍该系统的其他属性。

My how is the way that I preach this system. Spoiler alert: I’m not an academic. 我宣讲这个系统的方式是怎样的。剧透警告：我不是学者。

I couldn’t care less about ascribing to academic conventions (i.e., aca- demic jargon). 我一点也不在乎归因于学术惯例（即学术术语）。

Anyway, I intend to write using my own voice. I intend to speak in a way that discusses complex ideas in an as simple manner as possible, without being simplistic. That is how I intend to deliver the message of the Antinet Zettelkasten to you. 不管怎样，我打算用我自己的声音来写作。我打算以尽可能简单的方式讨论复杂的想法，而不是简单化。这就是我打算如何向您传达 Antinet Zettelkasten 的信息。

My why, my what and my how are both simple and complex. An Antinet is a system founded on simple laws yet morphs into something quite complex. The theory behind why it works is also simple yet has very deep implications in the field of knowledge. Get ready for a fun ride. 我的原因、我的内容和我的方式既简单又复杂。 Antinet 是一个建立在简单法则之上的系统，但会演变成相当复杂的东西。它为何起作用背后的理论也很简单，但在知识领域具有非常深刻的含义。准备好享受有趣的旅程。

A curious thing happens when one develops knowledge using the techniques you’re about to learn. In-depth context often accompanies each thought. Other thoughts oftentimes inspire each paragraph. I have written this book using my own Antinet. As such, I have been quite judicious in attaching comments and sources in the form of footnotes. This text is ripe with footnotes. The Journey That Led Me To Publish A Book On The Antinet 促使我在 Antinet 上出版一本书的旅程
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There i was, lying on my couch one weekday afternoon during the pandemic of 2020. I had just finished a three-hour binge of the show Billions. 在 2020 年大流行期间的一个工作日下午，我躺在沙发上。我刚刚结束了节目 Billions 的三个小时狂欢。

It’s a weekday, I said to myself. I should be doing something productive. Look at me, I’m a single 34-year-old with nothing to live for besides my cat (a ragdoll named Brodus Maximus). I felt like a complete slouch, a freaking loser. I was empty and unfulfilled. 今天是工作日，我对自己说。我应该做一些富有成效的事情。看看我，我是一个 34 岁的单身男人，除了我的猫（一只名叫 Brodus Maximus 的布娃娃）之外，没有什么可以活下去的。我觉得自己像个彻头彻尾的懒汉，一个该死的失败者。我是空虚和不满足的。

Roughly a year prior, I had left the cryptocurrency company I had co-founded. For two years, I worked eight days a week to launch the company. In record- breaking time, I helped take the company from $2.14 million in debt to be- coming one of the most exciting high-growth companies out there.[13](#footnote-021) We raised roughly $10 million via what is known as an ICO (Initial Coin Offering). We then raised over $14.1 million in equity during the next six months.[14](#footnote-020) 大约一年前，我离开了我共同创立的加密货币公司。两年来，我每周工作八天来创办公司。在创纪录的时间内，我帮助公司摆脱了 214 万美元的债务，成为最令人兴奋的高增长公司之一。 13 我们通过所谓的 ICO（首次代币发行）筹集了大约 1000 万美元. 然后，我们在接下来的六个月内筹集了超过 1410 万美元的股权。 14

Things were looking great. I was helping people, is what I thought. I was raising money to build ground-breaking technology that would re-shape the way GPS works, using cryptocurrency to incentivize individuals. We then held an exciting conference in downtown San Diego, and I spoke to over a thousand excited investors and customers who were diehard fans. 事情看起来很棒。我是在帮助别人，这就是我的想法。我正在筹集资金以构建突破性的技术，该技术将重塑 GPS 的工作方式，使用加密货币来激励个人。然后我们在圣地亚哥市中心举行了一场激动人心的会议，我与一千多名兴奋的投资者和客户进行了交谈，他们都是铁杆粉丝。

Over the next year, however, the market proceeded down a slow death march. Cryptocurrency prices across the entire industry dropped significantly. My investment and investments made by my family and friends who trusted me were down over 95%. The thousands of customers and investors who had once declared their love for the company were disgruntled. They were now practically threatening to bring pitchforks to our offices! 然而，在接下来的一年里，市场开始了缓慢的死亡行军。整个行业的加密货币价格大幅下跌。我的投资以及信任我的家人和朋友的投资下降了 95% 以上。数以千计曾表态热爱公司的客户和投资者心存不满。他们现在几乎是在威胁要把干草叉带到我们的办公室！

Since I was the face of the company, I took the brunt of it. It felt awful; I was called a scammer and every other awful thing you can think of. Things got even worse. We had to lay off almost half our company in a day (totaling over forty people).[15](#footnote-019) 因为我是公司的门面，所以我首当其冲。感觉糟透了；我被称为骗子和其他你能想到的可怕的事情。事情变得更糟了。我们不得不在一天之内解雇几乎一半的公司（总共四十多人）。 15

On the day of the layoff, I observed my relationships with now-former employees transform from some of my closest to my most contentious ones. I felt depleted, yet I couldn’t show it because I still needed to lead the rest of the team out of the mess. I pressed on for another six months. When we got the company to a stable point, I knew deep down that I needed to take a break, and I had to step away for personal reasons. I was empty inside. On top of this, the technology really hadn’t panned out; it needed more time to develop. Meanwhile, the vision was redirected into something I wasn’t proud of. Yet, because I was not the majority partner or shareholder, I didn’t have the legal control required to do anything about it. Nor did I possess the energy to fight it. I was physically, emotionally, and mentally burnt out. 在裁员那天，我观察到我与现在的离职员工的关系从一些最亲密的关系转变为最有争议的关系。我感到筋疲力尽，但我无法表现出来，因为我仍然需要带领团队的其他成员走出困境。我又坚持了六个月。当我们把公司稳定下来的时候，我内心深处知道我需要休息一下，因为个人原因我不得不离开。我内心是空的。最重要的是，这项技术确实没有成功。它需要更多的时间来发展。与此同时，愿景被重定向到我并不引以为豪的事情上。然而，因为我不是主要合伙人或股东，所以我没有采取任何行动所需的法律控制权。我也没有精力与之抗争。我在身体上、情感上和精神上都筋疲力尽。

Fast-forward a year later, and there I was, on my couch, lying down in a vegetative coma of indolence, watching Billions. I wasn’t necessarily suicidal, but I was sad; I had thoroughly lost my excitement for life. Plus, on top of this, my other ragdoll cat, Mr. Bigglesworth (Brodus’s brother), passed away from stomach cancer. He was only two years old. After watching him suffer for months, I decided to pull the plug. It may seem ridiculous writing about this; there are definitely more severe travesties in life. But I was single at the time, with only two cats for company. Yet there I found myself, holding one of them in my arms as the veterinarian injected him with something to make his breathing stop forever. 快进一年后，我躺在沙发上，懒洋洋地躺在植物人昏迷中，看着 Billions。我不一定有自杀倾向，但我很伤心；我已经彻底失去了对生活的热情。另外，最重要的是，我的另一只布偶猫 Bigglesworth 先生（布罗杜斯的兄弟）死于胃癌。他只有两岁。看着他受苦几个月后，我决定拔掉插头。写这个似乎很荒谬；生活中肯定有更严重的悲剧。但当时我单身，只有两只猫作伴。然而我发现自己在那里，当兽医给他注射某种东西让他的呼吸永远停止时，我将其中一只抱在怀里。

I was depressed; I came down with a major case of black ass, as Samuel Johnson would call it (his phrase for melancholy). On the surface, I wished to create even more significant success than what I had engineered at the cryptocurrency company. This time, however, I wanted more control over the product and the company’s direction so that, in my mind, we wouldn’t compromise on the vision. 我很沮丧；我遇到了一个严重的黑屁股案例，正如塞缪尔约翰逊所说的那样（他对忧郁的用语）。从表面上看，我希望创造比我在加密货币公司设计的更大的成功。然而，这一次，我想要更多地控制产品和公司的方向，这样在我看来，我们就不会在愿景上妥协。

Yet what I really desired was to serve people worth serving. Sure, there were some excellent people I got to serve at the cryptocurrency company; but, let’s face it, the vast majority of those involved were in it to make money without having to do anything. The people interested in cryptocurrency were there for one thing, and one thing only: to get rich doing nothing. When the market is up, you’re Jesus Christ himself; when the market is down, you’re the reason for all their problems. 然而，我真正想要的是为值得服务的人服务。当然，我在加密货币公司服务过一些优秀的人；但是，让我们面对现实吧，绝大多数参与其中的人都是为了赚钱而不必做任何事情。对加密货币感兴趣的人只为一件事而存在：无所事事致富。当市场上涨时，你就是耶稣基督本人；当市场低迷时，你就是他们所有问题的原因。

I would rather not serve people who were get-rich-quickers, and I wanted to avoid being in the business of wasting my energy with wasteful products. Sure, I wanted to have a significant impact, but I also wanted to provide a product that actually leaves future generations with something useful. 我宁愿不为那些一夜暴富的人服务，我也不想从事浪费我的精力在无用的产品上的生意。当然，我想产生重大影响，但我也想提供一种真正能给后代留下有用东西的产品。

After finishing the entire season of Billions, I decided to sell my 72-inch big screen TV and spend time brainstorming my next venture. I was still fascinated with cryptocurrency, and I was intrigued by decentralized finance. I saw innovation coming out of that space. But I was leaning toward creating something in my craft of marketing and copywriting. Specifically, I was intrigued by the idea of creating a newsletter, and it would be in a format inspired by my mentor, the late, great copywriter Gary Halbert. The project entailed digitizing Luhmann’s entire Zettelkasten (roughly ninety thousand notecards) and uploading it online for all to view.[20](#footnote-014) 然而，Ahrens 对模拟 Zettelkasten 工作原理的描述相当欠缺。它缺少大量细节，并且在几个段落中给出了模糊的概述。 19 但值得称赞的是 Ahrens，他模糊的描述可能是模拟 Zettelkasten 工作原理的最好描述。为了弥补 Ahrens 描述的模糊性，我开始在网上进行研究。很快，我发现了一些有趣的事情：德国比勒费尔德大学启动了一个特别项目，卢曼是同一所大学。该项目需要将 Luhmann 的整个 Zettelkasten（大约九万张记事卡）数字化并上传到网上供所有人查看。 20

I began to scan Luhmann’s Online Archive and even started writing out the translated versions of his notes by hand. Using Luhmann’s actual Zettelkasten as a guide, I began building out my analog Zettelkasten over the following months. 我开始浏览卢曼的在线档案，甚至开始手写他笔记的翻译版本。以 Luhmann 的实际 Zettelkasten 作为指导，我在接下来的几个月里开始构建我的模拟 Zettelkasten。

I also began porting over the notecards I had taken for the previous fifteen years. I had been building out a notecard box off and on over the previous fifteen years. These cards were not addressed, but just free-floating notecards. The thing I was missing was the infinite internal branching brought forth by the Antinet’s tree structure. 我也开始移植过去 15 年的笔记卡。在过去的十五年里，我一直在断断续续地制作一个记事卡盒。这些卡片没有地址，只是自由浮动的记事卡。我缺少的是 Antinet 树结构带来的无限内部分支。

I started installing the old cards into my analog Zettelkasten by giving them numeric-alpha addresses in the top-right corner, and then branching them with similar cards. I began to observe how the notecards I had created for over a decade began to reveal patterns I would have otherwise not seen if they’d remained organized by book title. It was very exciting to observe the power of such a system. 我开始将旧卡安装到我的模拟 Zettelkasten 中，方法是在右上角为它们提供数字字母地址，然后用类似的卡对它们进行分支。我开始观察我创建了十多年的记事卡如何开始揭示如果它们仍然按书名组织的话我将看不到的模式。观察这样一个系统的力量是非常令人兴奋的。

The experience and the journey I went through helped me realize that the magic of a Zettelkasten—and indeed the magic of knowledge management—rests not in the idea of creating notes; just as important is the medium one uses to create the notes. The magic of Zettelkasten does not come from taking atomic notes and linking them together using sexy software. Rather, the magic rests in the analog thinking system Luhmann created. One built of a pen, paper, and…a brain. 我经历的经历和旅程帮助我意识到 Zettelkasten 的魔力——实际上是知识管理的魔力——不在于创建笔记的想法；同样重要的是人们用来创建笔记的媒介。 Zettelkasten 的魔力并非来自记录原子笔记并使用性感软件将它们链接在一起。相反，魔力在于卢曼创造的模拟思维系统。一个由笔、纸和…… 大脑构成的。

Over the following months, I began to see some encouraging results using the analog Zettelkasten. From studying Luhmann’s archives, I discovered there were four key principles that serve as the foundation of Luhmann’s system. These four principles comprise the acronym “ANTI.” From there on, I began using the term “Antinet” to describe the system. 在接下来的几个月里，我开始看到使用模拟 Zettelkasten 的一些令人鼓舞的结果。通过研究卢曼的档案，我发现有四个关键原则作为卢曼体系的基础。这四项原则构成了首字母缩略词 “ANTI”。从那时起，我开始使用“Antinet” 这个词来描述这个系统。

Meanwhile, I was progressing on the project related to marketing, copywriting, and cryptocurrency. I began to see my knowledge compounding, and this helped me produce content. 与此同时，我正在推进与营销、文案和加密货币相关的项目。我开始看到我的知识复合，这帮助我制作内容。

I was gaining a ton of momentum and making progress. I also began using an analog weekly planner to manage my to-do’s and my goals. I found my productivity skyrocketing during this period. These practices also helped me detach myself from the digital distractions brought forth by phone and laptop. 我获得了巨大的动力并取得了进步。我还开始使用模拟每周计划器来管理我的待办事项和目标。在此期间，我发现我的工作效率直线上升。这些做法还帮助我摆脱了电话和笔记本电脑带来的数字干扰。

More importantly, my mind felt like it was actually being stretched, and like it was growing again. If I’m not learning and growing, I’m not the happiest person to be around. This system started bringing me happiness and joy again. 更重要的是，我的头脑感觉它真的被拉伸了，又好像又在生长。如果我不学习和成长，我就不是周围最快乐的人。这个系统又开始给我带来幸福和快乐了。

I’ve since introduced the magic of the Antinet to my Little Brother, who I mentor (initially, we met through the Big Brothers Big Sisters mentorship program, and I’ve continued mentoring him beyond). After discovering the power of the analog Zettelkasten (aka, the Antinet), I began sharing my material online with people. I’ve met some incredible people through my website, and through Reddit, YouTube, and Twitter. I’ve started to see the transformation of others who use analog thinking systems. There are some fascinating people out there who are having success with this tool. The Antinet helped me achieve what I was missing—a system that possessed the power of thinking on paper. To hell with taking the safe route and creating some crypto project to serve entitled speculators (who want to get rich without lifting a finger)! 让我们明确一点，对模拟 Zettelkasten 充满热情是非常荒谬的。这是一个看似过时的记事卡系统，由一些已故的学者设计，他们的书几乎无法阅读！然而我无法抗拒。我觉得很想分享我的发现。我记得在我参加的关于黑曜石的在线课程中与我互动的那些迷人的人。我权衡了这些感受，然后做出了决定。走安全路线并创建一些加密项目来服务有资格的投机者（想不费吹灰之力就发财的人）见鬼去吧！

I am energized writing about something that I know can help driven people, academics, and knowledge workers develop their minds. It hasn’t been easy. Somehow I ended up doing what I wanted to do all along—and I found it in quite an odd vehicle. I decided to do something that was missing in my previous ventures, and that is this: helping people worth helping. 我充满活力地写一些我知道可以帮助有动力的人、学者和知识工作者发展思想的东西。这并不容易。我一直靠我的投资和积蓄为生，没有从这项工作中赚到一分钱。但我不在乎；我知道我没有出卖自己的灵魂，也没有用浪费的、投机的产品浪费人们的生命，让其他人失去金钱，所以我晚上睡得很香。不知何故，我最终做了我一直想做的事——我发现它是在一辆很奇怪的车里。我决定做一些我以前的冒险中缺失的事情，那就是：帮助值得帮助的人。

The Who And Why Of The AntinetAntinet 的人物和原因
--------------------------------------------

In the early days of writing this book, I recorded a podcast every day.[23](#footnote-074) In the podcast, I mainly discussed items related to what I was discovering about the Antinet. 在写这本书的初期，我每天录制一个播客。23 在播客中，我主要讨论与我对 Antinet 的发现有关的项目。

One day, my father, who has served his community as a mortgage broker for over thirty-five years, visited me in San Diego, California. I learned that he had listened to a lengthy episode about the Antinet recorded the previous day. Yet instead of feeling grateful, I felt a bit uneasy. This prompted me to clarify who should bother investing their finite life energy into learning about the Antinet. Sure, my dad probably listened to the podcast because he loves me. But should he really invest his time learning about the Antinet? 一天，作为抵押贷款经纪人为社区服务超过 35 年的父亲到加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥拜访我。我了解到他听了前一天录制的关于 Antinet 的一长集。然而，我没有感激，反而感到有点不安。这促使我澄清谁应该费心投入他们有限的生命能量来学习 Antinet。当然，我爸爸听播客可能是因为他爱我。但他真的应该花时间学习 Antinet 吗？

Attention is the most valuable asset you have. You must not waste it learning something that you really shouldn’t bother with. I love my dad and would hate to think he’d waste his time learning about the Antinet when he really should be spending it on his craft. Even though I don’t know you, I’d hate for you to waste your time as well. For this reason, before you even begin getting too deep into this book, I would like to provide some context and reasons for why you should or shouldn’t read this book. 注意力是您拥有的最宝贵的资产。你一定不要浪费时间学习一些你真的不应该费心的事情。我爱我的父亲，不想认为他会浪费时间学习 Antinet，而实际上他应该把时间花在他的手艺上。虽然我不认识你，但我也不想让你浪费你的时间。出于这个原因，在你开始深入阅读本书之前，我想提供一些你应该或不应该阅读本书的背景和原因。

**Why You Should Bother Reading This Book 为什么你应该读这本书**
------------------------------------------------------

Here are three reasons why you should read this book: 以下是您应该阅读本书的三个理由：

1. You’re a writer, author, or person who wants to create genius-level work in your field—the type of work that will last for over two hundred years.1. 你是一位作家、作家或想在你的领域创造天才级作品的人——这种作品将持续 200 多年。

2. You already have experience writing by hand, and you’re aware of its power—yet you ran into the same wall I once ran into stemming from notecard systems organized by category.2. 你已经有手写的经验，你也知道它的力量——但你遇到了我曾经遇到过的同一堵墙，它源于按类别组织的记事卡系统。

3. You wish to use a system that develops the two most essential skills you’ll need for thriving in the future: (1) the skill of getting to know your mind (self-awareness) and (2) the skill of developing your mind’s flexibility.[24](#footnote-073)3. 您希望使用的系统能够培养您在未来蓬勃发展所需的两项最基本技能：(1) 了解您的思想（自我意识）的技能和 (2) 培养您的能力的技能头脑的灵活性. 24

**Who Should Even Bother Reading This Book 谁应该读这本书**
----------------------------------------------------

As mentioned in the preface, Niklas Luhmann was the originator of the Antinet, and you will be learning more about him in this book. Luhmann himself held that the Antinet was a “universal tool.” A tool that could capture any thought and potentially provide value to anyone, as long the thought could be written on a notecard.[25](#footnote-072) 正如前言所述，尼克拉斯 · 卢曼是反网络的鼻祖，您将在本书中更多地了解他。卢曼本人认为 Antinet 是一种 “通用工具”。一种可以捕捉任何想法并可能为任何人提供价值的工具，只要可以将想法写在记事卡上即可。 25

Although Luhmann held that one “can place almost everything in [the notebox],” so long as it can be “noted down,” I hold a closer view to that of several scholars, that an Antinet is primarily beneficial for researchers and writers who wish to notate thoughts and ideas from their readings.[26](#footnote-071) It’s mainly useful for non-fiction writers who do much reading, thinking, and processing of ideas. The Antinet develops thoughts both in the short term and long term. Thoughts serve as the raw material for non-fiction writers, and thoughts stand as the raw material for the Antinet. 虽然卢曼认为一个人 “几乎可以把所有东西都放在[记事本] 里”，但只要它能被“记下来”，我更接近一些学者的观点，即 Antinet 主要对研究人员和作家有益，他们希望从他们的阅读中记下想法和想法。26 它主要对阅读、思考和处理想法的非小说类作家有用。 Antinet 在短期和长期发展思想。思想是非小说作家的原材料，而思想是安提内特的原材料。

The purpose of the Antinet is to develop your thoughts so that they are more thoroughly evolved and supported by the time they make their way to your manuscript.Antinet 的目的是发展你的思想，以便在它们进入你的手稿时得到更彻底的发展和支持。

The Antinet is primarily a tool for researchers and writers. However, do note the use of the term primarily. The Antinet is primarily useful for non-fiction writers; yet, it’s not exclusively useful for such individuals.Antinet 主要是研究人员和作家的工具。但是，请注意主要使用该术语。 Antinet 主要对非小说作家有用；然而，它并不只对这些人有用。

**A More Pessimistic Answer 一个更悲观的答案**

A pessimistic answer to the question of who should bother learning the Antinet is this: most people shouldn’t bother with this book. 对于谁应该费心学习 Antinet 的问题，一个悲观的答案是：大多数人不应该费心阅读这本书。

Here’s why—there are 1.65 million writers in the world.[27](#footnote-070) There are at least 7.8 million researchers in the world.[28](#footnote-069) For good measure, let’s throw in an extra twenty million more individuals who are aspiring writers, professional researchers, graduate students, and independent intellectuals. That’s 29.45 million people. Divide that into 7.9 billion people on earth, and you get 0.37%. In other words, there’s a 0.37% chance that an Antinet is helpful for any given person. Therefore, there’s only a small chance that you should bother with this book. However, you’re not an average person. Being that you found yourself here and are reading this right now, perhaps I’ve already filtered out the other 99.63% of people. And, in that case, I’m honored to have you here! 原因如下——世界上有 165 万作家。27 世界上至少有 780 万研究人员。28 另外，让我们再投入 2000 万个人，他们是有抱负的作家、专业研究人员、研究生，以及独立的知识分子。那是 2945 万人。将其除以地球上的 79 亿人，得到 0.37%。换句话说，Antinet 对任何给定的人都有帮助的可能性为 0.37%。因此，你应该费心阅读这本书的可能性很小。但是，您不是普通人。既然你发现自己在这里并且正在阅读这篇文章，也许我已经过滤掉了其他 99.63% 的人。而且，在那种情况下，我很荣幸有你在这里！

**A More Optimistic Answer to Who Should Even Bother with Learning about the Antinet 一个更乐观的答案，谁应该甚至费心去了解 Antinet**

The Antinet is a system that serves as a ruminant for your thoughts. The idea that only non-fiction writers can benefit from such a system is somewhat limiting and probably inaccurate. Indeed, mathematicians who construct proofs that require rumination over months (or perhaps years) would most certainly find value in a system such as an Antinet.Antinet 是一个可以反刍你的想法的系统。只有非小说作家才能从这样的系统中受益的想法有些局限，而且可能不准确。事实上，构建需要数月（或可能数年）反思的证明的数学家肯定会在像 Antinet 这样的系统中找到价值。

Richard Feynman and many physicists would find their success watered down if it were not for their analog devices that serve as a form of short-term thought development and long-term rumination. 理查德 · 费曼 (Richard Feynman) 和许多物理学家会发现，如果不是因为他们的模拟设备充当了短期思想发展和长期反思的一种形式，他们的成功就会大打折扣。

It appears that non-fiction writers and deep researchers are primarily those who will benefit from thinking systems such as an Antinet. 看起来，非小说类作家和深度研究人员将主要受益于 Antinet 等思维系统。

If you’re an entrepreneur, an artist, a software engineer, a business professional, etc., here’s the cold hard truth: an Antinet will likely be less helpful to you—unless you intend to publish and ship content. This goes for any Zettelkasten system (even the digital knockoffs). 如果您是企业家、艺术家、软件工程师、商业专家等，那么冷酷的事实是：Antinet 对您的帮助可能不大——除非您打算发布和传送内容。这适用于任何 Zettelkasten 系统（甚至是数字仿冒品）。

Regardless of what camp you fall into, there’s one thing you cannot forego. And that is, a commitment over the long term to developing your knowledge using an Antinet. Think decades, not years. 无论您属于哪个阵营，都有一件事是您不能放弃的。也就是说，长期致力于使用 Antinet 发展您的知识。想想几十年，而不是几年。

**Why Notetaking Is Important to Learn in the First Place 为什么记笔记对于学习很重要**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

It’s been put forth by scholars that “reading without noting” yields “superficial knowledge.” This is because reading, as an act alone, is “not accompanied by the attention and thought required to make a well-considered note.”[29](#footnote-068) 有学者提出 “读书不留神” 是“肤浅的知识”。这是因为阅读，作为一种单独的行为，“没有伴随着做一个经过深思熟虑的笔记所需的注意力和思考。”29

Notetaking serves as the mechanism that enables a contradictory paradox. One initially considers notetaking to be a memory replacement tool. That is, you don’t have to memorize anything because you can just dump it all in an archive of notes; in other words, you can replace the need to memorize. However, something else occurs entirely. Notetaking, if done via writing by hand, acts as a memory enhancement tool. 记笔记是导致矛盾悖论的机制。人们最初认为记笔记是一种记忆替代工具。也就是说，你不必记住任何东西，因为你可以将它们全部转储到笔记档案中；换句话说，你可以取代记忆的需要。但是，完全发生了其他事情。记笔记，如果通过手写来完成，可以作为一种记忆增强工具。

Notetaking was thought to aid memory in two different ways, observes Ann Blair in her work on the subject. First, it creates a written record to return to. Second, and more interestingly, by forcing the mind to dwell on the material, the act of writing excerpts and the thoughts they generate enables one to retain better what was read or heard.[30](#footnote-067) 记笔记被认为以两种不同的方式帮助记忆，安布莱尔在她关于这个主题的工作中观察到。首先，它创建一个要返回的书面记录。其次，更有趣的是，通过强迫大脑专注于材料，写摘录的行为和它们产生的想法使人们能够更好地记住读过或听到的内容。 30

Jeremias Drexel (1581—1638) observes that if one takes notes, their memory becomes far from being neglected; in fact, their memory becomes “substantially more effective.” As the scholar Alberto Cevolini reflects, notetaking promotes better understanding of material. The reason why centers around the time and attention devoted to the reading. “The reader,” observes Cevolini, “reflects longer on what he is reading, and the matter becomes more clearly understood.”[31](#footnote-066)Jeremias Drexel (1581—1638) 观察到如果一个人做笔记，他们的记忆就不会被忽视；事实上，他们的记忆变得 “更加有效”。正如学者阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 所反映的那样，记笔记有助于更好地理解材料。之所以集中在阅读上的时间和注意力上。 “读者”，Cevolini 观察到，“对他正在阅读的内容进行更长时间的反思，并且对问题的理解也更加清晰。”31

In addition, notetaking procures long-term knowledge storage by setting up the required material for maintenance rehearsal and elaborative rehearsal—critical components of human memory that will be covered later in the book. 此外，笔记通过为维护复述和精细复述设置所需的材料来获得长期的知识存储——人类记忆的关键组成部分将在本书后面介绍。

Simply stated, if developing deep, long-term non-superficial knowledge from the books you read is of essential value to you, then notetaking is the most critical skill you must master. 简单地说，如果从你阅读的书籍中发展深刻的、长期的、非表面的知识对你来说是必不可少的价值，那么记笔记是你必须掌握的最关键的技能。

**Why a Notetaking System Is Important 为什么笔记系统很重要**
---------------------------------------------------

One reason to build a notetaking system centers on the simple idea that one should follow in the footsteps of history’s greatest scholars and thinkers: “In light of [notetaking’s] (literally) rich tradition, one would be well-advised to mind the recommendations of the scholars, and set about the construction of [a notetaking system] as soon as possible.”[32](#footnote-065) 建立笔记系统的一个原因在于一个简单的想法，即人们应该追随历史上最伟大的学者和思想家的脚步：“鉴于 [notetaking]（字面上）丰富的传统，最好注意以下建议学者，并尽快着手构建 [笔记系统]。”32

Another reason is that a notetaking system allows one to offload the cognitive processing work that memory requires for later recall. Cognitive processing can then be used to think, develop, and reflect on ideas instead of developing mnemonic memorization tricks, such as the method of loci used by ancient Greek thinkers. 另一个原因是，笔记系统允许人们卸载记忆所需的认知处理工作，以便以后回忆。然后可以使用认知处理来思考、发展和反思想法，而不是开发助记记忆技巧，例如古希腊思想家使用的轨迹法。

Yet, as previously touched upon, a notetaking system is primarily best suited for writers and researchers who “ingest” and produce much content. Scholars agree that a notetaking system is a valuable tool for those who mainly wish to “work with information gleaned from reading.”[33](#footnote-064) 然而，如前所述，笔记系统主要最适合 “摄取” 和产生大量内容的作家和研究人员。学者们一致认为，对于那些主要希望 “利用从阅读中收集的信息进行工作” 的人来说，笔记系统是一种有价值的工具。 33

**Why Use an Antinet 为什么使用 Antinet**
------------------------------------

An Antinet is a strict interpretation of the already niche field of Zettelkasten, which many believe to exist within the niche field of personal knowledge management (PKM).[34](#footnote-063) PKM is a niche field within knowledge management, which stands already as a rather niche field itself. In brief, the Antinet is believed to reside in the deep alcoves of an already very niche field.Antinet 是对 Zettelkasten 已经利基领域的严格解释，许多人认为它存在于个人知识管理 (PKM) 的利基领域内。34 PKM 是知识管理中的一个利基领域，它本身已经是一个相当利基的领域. 简而言之，Antinet 被认为位于一个已经非常小众领域的深处。

Chances are, you’re a nerd like me who geeks out over learning, growth, reading, and the development of your mind. If that’s not you, then you’re in the wrong place. If this describes you, then carry on reading. 很有可能，你是像我这样的书呆子，对学习、成长、阅读和思维发展非常感兴趣。如果那不是你，那你来错地方了。如果这描述了您，请继续阅读。

The question then becomes, why should you invest your time learning about the Antinet in the first place? 那么问题就变成了，为什么要首先花时间学习 Antinet？

There are several reasons, which I’ll outline throughout the book; however, the short answer is this: it’s the purest, hardest, most-time-intensive, but most rewarding way to develop your knowledge. Digital apps and other new tools cut corners that produce stunted thoughts. Life’s too short. If you’re going to produce work, do it the hard way. The result will show signs of your commitment to this. 有几个原因，我将在整本书中概述；然而，简短的回答是：这是最纯粹、最困难、最耗时但最有益的增长知识的方式。数字应用程序和其他新工具偷工减料会产生发育迟缓的想法。生命太短暂。如果你要完成工作，那就用艰难的方式去做。结果将显示您对此承诺的迹象。

The Antinet is for those who aim to produce thought-provoking content, even if it’s at the expense of being easy. Digital tools, I contend, are easier and more convenient than building an analog knowledge system; however, the output digital systems produce is of lesser quality than systems that force one to think on paper.Antinet 适用于那些旨在制作发人深省的内容的人，即使是以牺牲简单为代价。我认为，数字工具比建立模拟知识系统更容易、更方便；然而，数字系统产生的输出质量不如强迫人们在纸上思考的系统。

**The Antinet Evolves Your MindAntinet 进化你的思想**

Another reason one ought to adopt and learn the Antinet centers around evolution. If you wish to evolve as a person and evolve your mind, an Antinet is the most full-bodied tool for doing such. 人们应该采用和学习 Antinet 的另一个原因是围绕进化展开的。如果你想作为一个人进化并进化你的思想，Antinet 是最完整的工具。

Akin to the concept of human evolution happening by way of externalization (i.e., creating tools like axes, spears, vehicles for transport), a theory “that was very successful in the second half of the twentieth century states that evolution implies an increasing ‘exteriorization’ of individual memories.”[35](#footnote-062) This means that to evolve, we must externalize our memories and move from the structural coupling of communication from consciousness to communication with machines. 类似于通过外化发生的人类进化的概念（即创造工具，如斧头、长矛、运输工具），一种 “在二十世纪下半叶非常成功的理论指出，进化意味着越来越多的‘外化’ ' 个人记忆。”35 这意味着要进化，我们必须外化我们的记忆，并从意识交流的结构耦合转向与机器的交流。

Yet, there’s a problem with this evolutionary leap. The issue is that when one moves toward communication with machines (such as using digital notes to interact with one’s own internally-sourced thoughts), one’s consciousness becomes watered down and stripped of its individualism. 然而，这种进化飞跃存在一个问题。问题在于，当一个人开始与机器交流时（例如使用数字笔记与自己的内部思想进行互动），一个人的意识就会淡化并剥夺其个人主义。

**The Antinet Preserves One’s Consciousness Better Than Digital Tools Because of Its Analog Nature 由于其模拟性质，Antinet 比数字工具更能保护一个人的意识**

Your handwriting is a mighty powerful thing. Something covered later in 你的笔迹是一个强大的东西。稍后介绍的内容

this book is the concept of an internal ghost, internal monologue, and internal dialogue. Niklas Luhmann referenced this concept as well. The idea of the internal ghost has been observed and studied by scholars as the interaction between (1) external memory systems like the Antinet and (2) internal memory (which is the so-called wetware memory that resides inside your skull). 这本书的概念是内心幽灵、内心独白和内心对话。 Niklas Luhmann 也引用了这个概念。内部幽灵的概念已被学者们观察和研究为 (1) 外部记忆系统如 Antinet 和 (2) 内部记忆（即位于您头骨内的所谓湿件记忆）之间的相互作用。

After studying John Boyle, John Locke, and Robert Hooke, one researcher found that “annotations that are stored in the external memory can function only in tandem with internal memory, so excerpts and notes prompt recollection of more than what they actually contain.”[36](#footnote-061) The magic that’s happening here is that when one interacts with notes written in one’s own handwriting and with other external contextual details attached to it (like the color and shape of the notecards), one’s consciousness and memory fills in the details and other thoughts that serve as a cue for one’s consciousness. 在研究了约翰 · 博伊尔、约翰 · 洛克和罗伯特 · 胡克之后，一位研究人员发现 “存储在外部记忆中的注释只能与内部记忆协同工作，因此摘录和笔记会促使人们回忆起比它们实际包含的内容更多的东西。”36 这里发生的神奇之处在于，当一个人与自己手写的笔记以及附加在上面的其他外部上下文细节（如记事卡的颜色和形状）进行交互时，一个人的意识和记忆会填充这些细节和其他想法作为一个人的意识的线索。

In other words, the notes in your Antinet set off a chain reaction—a conversation, internally, that becomes an internal dialogue (not an internal monologue). This experience is a powerful phenomenon generated in analog knowledge systems such as the Antinet. 换句话说，你的 Antinet 中的笔记引发了连锁反应——一种内部对话，变成了内部对话（而不是内部独白）。这种体验是 Antinet 等模拟知识系统中产生的一种强大现象。

Unlike digital notes, which can multiply endlessly due to virtually unlimited storage-space limits, notes in an Antinet serve as a cue for generating the recall process in your mind. Digital notes take a different form; they tend to be all-encompassing and thorough, which gets overwhelming. Your notes should be a communication experience that takes place when you use them to write your book, essay, blog post, or paper. 与由于几乎无限的存储空间限制而可以无限增加的数字笔记不同，Antinet 中的笔记可以作为在您的脑海中产生回忆过程的提示。数字笔记采用不同的形式；它们往往是包罗万象和彻底的，这让人不知所措。你的笔记应该是一种交流体验，当你用它们来写你的书、论文、博客文章或论文时，就会发生这种情况。

**Evolution via Communication and Artificial Consciousness 通过交流和人工意识进化**

Evolution and human progress will emerge from the transition of the structural coupling of communication and consciousness to the structural coupling of communication and artificial consciousness (by way of externalization). 进化和人类进步将从通信和意识的结构耦合过渡到通信和人工意识的结构耦合（通过外化）。

The best tools are the ones that lead to artificial consciousness—by which I mean a communication partner that seems to have its own externalized personality.[37](#footnote-060) 最好的工具是那些导致人工意识的工具——我指的是一个似乎有自己外化个性的沟通伙伴。 37

Thus far, digital notetaking apps have proven useful as information storage systems, not as artificial consciousness storage systems. The Antinet is a better artificial consciousness storage system, and it serves as a better cue for the internal mental dialogue when it comes time to write. Moreover, I contend that an Antinet is, paradoxically, closer to enabling human evolution than digital tools even though digital tools are perceived as being more evolved. 到目前为止，数字笔记应用程序已被证明可用作信息存储系统，而不是人工意识存储系统。 Antinet 是一个更好的人工意识存储系统，它可以在写作时为内部心理对话提供更好的提示。此外，我认为，自相矛盾的是，Antinet 比数字工具更接近于实现人类进化，尽管数字工具被认为是更进化的。

**Why You Should Even Care About Learning a System That Strictly Adheres to Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten 为什么你甚至应该关心学习一个严格遵守 Niklas Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的系统**

Among scholars—and one in particular who has surveyed nearly all knowledge development systems used throughout history—Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten system is decidedly one that “stands out.” Alberto Cevolini points out that Luhmann’s paper outlining his Zettelkasten can be regarded as modern society’s most advanced result of a long-lasting reflection performed on knowledge management.[38](#footnote-059) 在学者中——特别是那些调查过几乎所有历史上使用的知识发展系统的人——尼古拉斯 · 卢曼的 Zettelkasten 系统无疑是 “脱颖而出” 的系统。 Alberto Cevolini 指出，Luhmann 概述他的 Zettelkasten 的论文可以被视为现代社会对知识管理进行长期反思的最先进成果。 38

I contend that history’s physical analog thinking systems evolved to their most advanced level with Luhmann’s Zettelkasten system. Instead of being carried forth and developed from there, it has essentially been replaced with digital notetaking tools, which I suggest are worse in many ways. The popularity of analog thinking tools has dwindled as a consequence, and their popularity has been supplanted with the usage of digital tools. Additionally, the actual evolution of analog thinking systems has seemingly stopped. I can only hope that my book will bring back some innovation in this space. 我认为历史上的物理模拟思维系统随着卢曼的 Zettelkasten 系统发展到最先进的水平。它并没有从那里得到发展，而是基本上被数字笔记工具所取代，我认为这些工具在很多方面都更糟糕。模拟思维工具的流行度因此下降，它们的流行度已被数字工具的使用所取代。此外，模拟思维系统的实际进化似乎已经停止。我只希望我的书能在这个领域带来一些创新。

**Each Component of Luhmann’s Principles is Unique and They Combine to Create a Whole Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts 卢曼原则的每个组成部分都是独一无二的，它们结合起来创造出一个大于其部分之和的整体**

In this book, I’ll detail the four principles that make Luhmann’s system unique. The four principles combine to create the Antinet. When you interpret Luhmann’s system loosely, it loses its luster and impact. One of its key impacts is its proclivity to transform from a memory replacement tool to a system that actually ends up enhancing memory—a so-called memory aid. 在本书中，我将详细介绍使卢曼系统独一无二的四项原则。这四个原则结合起来创建了 Antinet。当你松散地解释卢曼的体系时，它就失去了光彩和影响力。它的一个关键影响是它倾向于从记忆替代工具转变为实际上最终会增强记忆力的系统——即所谓的记忆辅助工具。

The four principles of the Antinet force something called neuro-associative recall. Together, each aspect of the Antinet transforms it from a memory-storage system to a memory-supercharging system.Antinet 的四个原则迫使一种叫做神经联想回忆的东西。总之，Antinet 的每个方面都将其从内存存储系统转变为内存增压系统。

Luhmann echoes this notion. He suggests that the Antinet forces one to file thoughts (“placing of the notes”). While it “takes time,” according to Luhmann, it also does two things: (1) it helps enliven the “sheer monotony of reading,” and (2) it “incidentally trains the memory.”[39](#footnote-058) 卢曼呼应了这一观点。他建议 Antinet 迫使人们记录思想（“放置笔记”）。根据卢曼的说法，虽然它 “需要时间”，但它也有两件事：(1) 它有助于使“阅读的单调乏味” 变得活跃起来，(2) 它“顺便训练了记忆力。”39

**Why You Should Not Bother Reading This Book 为什么你不应该读这本书**
-----------------------------------------------------------

Luhmann’s notebox system has become surprisingly popular recently with the publication of several books, and it’s also become popularized through online communities.[40](#footnote-057) Myths about Luhmann’s system have also emerged. One such myth is that Luhmann’s system produces prolific amounts of writing—without the process of writing being difficult. 随着几本书的出版，卢曼的记事本系统最近变得出奇地流行，它也通过在线社区得到普及。40 关于卢曼系统的神话也已经出现。一个这样的神话是，卢曼的系统产生了大量的写作——而写作的过程并不困难。

The author of perhaps the most popular book on Luhmann’s Zettelkasten writes that Luhmann’s productivity is impressive, yet even more amazing is that “[Luhmann] seemed to achieve all this with almost no real effort.”[41](#footnote-056) This is a false notion that will be explored later in the book, but the result of its proliferation is that the Zettelkasten finds itself presented as a system that causes many people to overlook the actual realities of using it: the truth is that Luhmann worked night and day, and his writing and theoretical work were his life. To a large degree, he produced so much because his wife passed away, and he had a caretaker who cooked his meals and helped him raise his children. This allowed Luhmann to focus almost exclusively on writing. In brief, the Zettelkasten does not replace hard work; rather, it greatly enhances the depth of thought in one’s work output; however, there’s one caveat. Those who wish to use such a system must not shy away from the prospect of hard work. 关于卢曼的 Zettelkasten 的也许是最受欢迎的一本书的作者写道，卢曼的生产力令人印象深刻，但更令人惊讶的是，“[卢曼] 似乎几乎没有付出任何努力就实现了这一切。”41 这是一个错误的观念，我们将对其进行探讨在本书的后面，但它激增的结果是 Zettelkasten 发现自己呈现为一个系统，导致许多人忽视了使用它的实际情况：事实是卢曼日以继夜地工作，他的写作和理论工作是他的生活。在很大程度上，他之所以能生产这么多，是因为他的妻子去世了，他有一个看门人为他做饭，帮助他抚养孩子。这让卢曼几乎可以完全专注于写作。简而言之，Zettelkasten 并不能取代辛勤工作；相反，它极大地增强了一个人的工作产出中的思想深度；但是，有一个警告。那些希望使用这样一个系统的人一定不要回避艰苦工作的前景。

Another thing that must be considered is that an Antinet is something you should investigate if, and only if, you have adequate time. If you’re under constant deadlines, for instance—daily deadlines, such as those experienced by a newspaper writer—an Antinet is probably not for you. Paradoxically, unlimited time is also not ideal either. You must have short-term projects as milestones. Luhmann had this in the form of peer-reviewed articles. While the number of books Luhmann published is impressive (seventy), just as impressive is that he published 550 articles.[42](#footnote-055) These served as short-term projects which helped him develop his thirty-year undertaking to devise a theory of everything in the field of sociology. 另一件必须考虑的事情是，当且仅当您有足够的时间时，您才应该研究 Antinet。例如，如果您经常面临截止日期——每天的截止日期，例如报纸作家所经历的那样——Antinet 可能不适合您。矛盾的是，无限时间也不理想。您必须将短期项目作为里程碑。卢曼以同行评审文章的形式提出了这一点。虽然卢曼出版的书籍数量令人印象深刻（70 本），但同样令人印象深刻的是他发表了 550 篇文章。 42 这些都是短期项目，帮助他发展了 30 年的事业，即在社会学。

After Luhmann passed away, two hundred more unpublished manuscripts were found among his possessions.[43](#footnote-054) The sheer volume of Luhmann’s output stands as one of the main selling points for the Zettelkasten system. It’s a big part of what has attracted many people to the concept. Further, Luhmann continued to be productive even after he passed away with a half-dozen of his books published posthumously. Sönke Ahrens writes that he knows more than a few colleagues who would give a lot to be as productive as Luhmann—even as productive as Luhmann was after he died![44](#footnote-053) 卢曼去世后，在他的财产中发现了 200 多份未发表的手稿。 43 卢曼作品的绝对数量是 Zettelkasten 系统的主要卖点之一。这是吸引许多人接受这个概念的重要原因。此外，即使在他去世后，卢曼仍继续保持高产，并出版了他的六本书。 Sönke Ahrens 写道，他认识的同事中有不少愿意为像卢曼一样多产而付出很多——甚至像卢曼死后那样多产！44

However, here’s the reality: Luhmann’s books were poorly written (due to academic German conventions still practiced today). Luhmann’s writings are packed with very deep ideas, yet, reading Luhmann’s work is a sleep-inducing experience. His books are extremely and unapologetically challenging to understand. They’re convoluted with academic jargon and unnecessarily large words. Even Luhmann himself acknowledged the issues with his writing style that caused him to have difficulty getting his work translated. From observing beginners and translators who tried reading his texts, Luhmann once remarked, “I have noticed how haphazardly I write—despite considerable care in preserving and refining theoretical coherences.”[45](#footnote-052) 然而，现实是这样的：卢曼的书写得不好（由于今天仍在实行的学术德国惯例）。卢曼的作品充满了非常深刻的思想，然而，阅读卢曼的作品是一种催眠的体验。他的书极富挑战性，而且毫无歉意地难以理解。他们被学术术语和不必要的大词所困扰。甚至卢曼本人也承认，他的写作风格存在问题，导致他的作品难以被翻译。通过观察尝试阅读他的文本的初学者和译者，卢曼曾经评论说：“我注意到我写作是多么随意——尽管在保持和完善理论连贯性方面付出了相当大的努力。”45

Hans-Georg Moeller considers Luhmann’s social theory to be the best analysis of contemporary society presently available. Yet, he observes that Luhmann’s work remains “far less prominent” than it ought to be. The reason? Luhmann’s books were so difficult to read.[46](#footnote-051) This same scholar wrote an entire book dedicated to exploring Niklas Luhmann’s theoretical work. Before even beginning the book, he allocates a section dedicated to how and why Luhmann produced books that were so challenging. Luhmann’s word selection, style, and tone were that of an academic who gave lectures so dense that you left feeling like you didn’t understand a thing. This gives you a glimpse of what reading Luhmann’s work feels like. Luhmann’s writing style is so thickly drenched in doctrinaire academic-prose that the scholar who wrote a book on Luhmann refers to his writing style as soporific.[47](#footnote-050)Hans-Georg Moeller 认为卢曼的社会理论是目前对当代社会最好的分析。然而，他观察到卢曼的作品仍然 “远没有其应有的突出”。原因？卢曼的书很难读。 46 同一位学者写了一整本书来探索尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的理论工作。在开始这本书之前，他分配了一个部分专门介绍卢曼如何以及为何创作出如此具有挑战性的书。卢曼的用词、风格和语气就像一位讲课的学者，他的演讲如此密集，以至于你离开时会觉得自己什么都不懂。这让你瞥见阅读卢曼作品的感觉。卢曼的写作风格充满教条主义的学术散文，以至于写过一本关于卢曼的书的学者称他的写作风格令人昏昏欲睡。 47

**Why Luhmann’s Books Were So Bad 为什么卢曼的书如此糟糕**

The reason Niklas Luhmann’s books were so bad centers around the following aspects: 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的书之所以如此糟糕，主要集中在以下几个方面：

**Academic Pretentiousness Described the German Academic Climate of His Time 学术自命不凡描述了他那个时代的德国学术风气**

Luhmann’s dense academic writing style was almost a requirement in his field if he wished to be taken seriously. It was an “environment of academically pretentious soporific authors.”[48](#footnote-049) The greatness of one’s work correlated directly with how inaccessible and difficult it was to penetrate.[49](#footnote-048) In other words, the more ridiculously challenging it was to read a person’s work, the more respect the one who wrote it received—assuming the ideas weren’t pure gibberish. Luhmann’s work most certainly was not gibberish; it was deep, brilliant, unconventional, cross-disciplinary, and, astoundingly, quite valid. 如果卢曼希望受到重视，他浓厚​​的学术写作风格几乎是他所在领域的必备条件。这是一个 “充斥着学术上自命不凡的催眠作者的环境”。48 一个人的作品的伟大与它的难以接近和深入了解直接相关。 49 换句话说，阅读一个人的作品越是荒谬的挑战，就越受尊重写它的人收到了——假设这些想法不是纯粹的胡言乱语。卢曼的作品绝对不是胡言乱语。它深刻、精彩、非传统、跨学科，而且令人惊讶的是，它非常有效。

Luhmann operated within the academically pretentious standard of Germany’s academic environment. As a result, his books reflect his environment. One scholar states, “Luhmann (or rather, his writing) suffered from being too closely associated with the German academic elite at the time.”[50](#footnote-047) 卢曼在德国学术环境的学术自命不凡的标准下运作。因此，他的书反映了他的环境。一位学者指出，“卢曼（或者更确切地说，他的作品）因与当时的德国学术精英联系过于紧密而受到影响。”50

**Luhmann Barely Edited His Work 卢曼几乎没有编辑他的作品**

“Once I’ve written [a manuscript],” Luhmann stated in an interview, “I don’t usually revise it.”[51](#footnote-046) In brief, he was not a perfectionist. He did not have a writing process like F. Scott Fitzgerald, wherein he would write books in longhand using a pencil in a notebook before typing the manuscript using a typewriter. Luhmann wrote his texts by hand on notecards, but he put little effort into making them cohesive and flow naturally. Luhmann was more concerned with just getting his work shipped, as imperfect as it was. “I don’t have any notion of perfection when it comes to books and essays,” Luhmann said, “like some people who think they have to write a definitive work with their first book.”[52](#footnote-045) Luhmann considered nearly all of his roughly seventy books, 550 articles, and two hundred unpublished manuscripts as “version zero.” The only book he did not hold as “version zero” was his Theory of Society (which took him some thirty years to write).[53](#footnote-044) He created major versions of this book every decade: one each in the 1960s, 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s.[54](#footnote-043)“一旦我写了 [手稿]，”卢曼在接受采访时说，“我通常不会修改它。”51 简而言之，他不是一个完美主义者。他没有像 F. Scott Fitzgerald 这样的写作过程，在用打字机打字之前，他会先用铅笔在笔记本上手写书籍。卢曼在记事卡上手写他的文本，但他很少努力使它们连贯自然。 Luhmann 更关心的是让他的工作顺利进行，尽管它并不完美。 “当谈到书籍和论文时，我没有任何完美的概念，”卢曼说，“就像一些人认为他们必须用他们的第一本书写出一部权威的作品。”52 卢曼几乎考虑了他大约 70 年代的所有经历书籍、550 篇文章和 200 篇未发表的手稿作为 “零版本”。他唯一没有作为“零版本” 持有的书是他的《社会理论》（他花了大约 30 年的时间才写成）。53 他每十年创建这本书的主要版本：1960 年代、1970 年代、1980 年代和 1990s.54

It may be overstating things to insinuate Luhmann never revised his manuscripts. In fact, he did insert new pages between existing pages of his drafts, similar to how he made his notes branch in his Zettelkasten. For instance, one finds manuscripts with pages 1, 2, 2a, 2b, 3. The pages 2a and 2b were inserted as an afterthought.[55](#footnote-042) Therefore, clearly, Luhmann did some editing after writing a manuscript. 暗示卢曼从未修改过他的手稿可能是言过其实了。事实上，他确实在他的草稿的现有页面之间插入了新页面，类似于他在他的 Zettelkasten 中将笔记分支的方式。例如，人们发现第 1、2、2a、2b、3 页的手稿。第 2a 和 2b 页是事后插入的。55 因此，很明显，卢曼在写完手稿后做了一些编辑。

**Luhmann Desired to Be Impenetrable by the General Public in Fear of His Career Being Threatened 卢曼因害怕他的职业生涯受到威胁而希望公众无法理解**

There’s a dark secret in Luhmann’s life that isn’t talked about much.[56](#footnote-041) I will cover it later in this book; however, it provides a perfectly understandable reason why Luhmann would want to remain impenetrable to the general public. Because his positions in sociology are so complex, it is conceivable that the public would have placed him in an ideologically dangerous category, thereby threatening his career. To mitigate such a risk, one can suppose Luhmann erred on the side of being highbrow so that only well-read intellectuals could decipher what he was saying. This risked fewer opportunities of mischaracterization from untrained readers in the social sciences. 卢曼的生活中有一个不为人知的秘密。 5​​6 我将在本书的后面部分介绍它；然而，它提供了一个完全可以理解的理由，说明为什么卢曼希望对公众保持不可理解的状态。由于他在社会学中的立场如此复杂，可以想象公众会把他置于意识形态上危险的一类，从而威胁到他的职业生涯。为了减轻这种风险，我们可以假设卢曼犯了一个错误，即他的文采太高明了，以至于只有博览群书的知识分子才能理解他在说什么。这减少了未受过社会科学训练的读者错误描述的机会。

Luhmann’s writing style helped ensure that only academics proficient and trained in such a style would be capable of even attempting to understand his work. To illustrate this point, we can refer to an interview with Luhmann from 1973. The interviewer asks Luhmann what critics he fears most, and his reply is classic: “The stupid ones.”[57](#footnote-040) Luhmann’s writing style prevented the stupid ones from reading his work, and it’s continued to do so long after he’s passed. 卢曼的写作风格有助于确保只有精通这种风格并接受过这种风格训练的学者才有能力尝试理解他的作品。为了说明这一点，我们可以参考 1973 年对卢曼的采访。采访者问卢曼他最害怕的评论家是什么，他的回答很经典：“愚蠢的人。”57 卢曼的写作风格阻止了愚蠢的人阅读他的作品，并且在他过世后很长一段时间内仍然如此。

**Luhmann’s Zettelkasten System Created a Deep Spider-Like Network That Was Hard to Disentangle Using a TypewriterLuhmann 的 Zettelkasten 系统创建了一个类似蜘蛛的深度网络，很难用打字机解开**

Even academics trained in reading dense prose have found themselves challenged by Luhmann’s writing style, stemming from the complex, multidisciplinary webs of thought Luhmann’s books dump onto the page. Luhmann proclaimed, in a seemingly proud manner, that “there’s no linearity, but a spider-web-like system that can be started anywhere.”[58](#footnote-039) Such a non-linear structure makes Luhmann’s work something that is “not reader-friendly,” according to one scholar.[59](#footnote-038) Luhmann asserts that the non-linear nature of his work is a feature, not a bug. It enables one to pick up one of his books and start reading anywhere–such as the beginning or end of the book. Yet this assumes some familiarity with Luhmann’s work. As Moeller points out, anyone can indeed begin reading anywhere, but they can’t start understanding anywhere.[60](#footnote-037) One can begin reading anywhere, assuming they’re already well-versed in Luhmann’s work. Becoming well-versed in Luhmann is hard to achieve if you start with Luhmann’s books, though it’s been said that his lectures were easier to comprehend.[61](#footnote-036) 即使是受过阅读密集散文训练的学者也发现自己受到了卢曼写作风格的挑战，这源于卢曼的书倾倒在页面上的复杂的、多学科的思想网络。卢曼以一种看似自豪的方式宣称，“没有线性，而是一个可以从任何地方开始的类似蜘蛛网的系统。”58 这种非线性结构使卢曼的作品 “对读者不友好”，根据一位学者的说法。59 Luhmann 断言他工作的非线性性质是一个特征，而不是一个错误。它使人能够拿起他的一本书并开始阅读任何地方——例如书的开头或结尾。然而，这是假设对卢曼的作品有一定的了解。正如默勒所指出的，任何人确实可以从任何地方开始阅读，但他们无法从任何地方开始理解。60 一个人可以从任何地方开始阅读，前提是他们已经精通卢曼的作品。如果你从卢曼的书开始，很难精通卢曼，尽管据说他的演讲更容易理解。 61

There’s no friendly initiation when you begin trying to read Luhmann’s work. You’re quickly confronted with unconventional, intimidating terminology. This terminology is packed with sudden, chaotic shifts between ideas.[62](#footnote-035) Want to know the best part about all this? Luhmann doesn’t even bother to explain the unconventional terminology he introduces. He leaves you to embark on a mental journey down the complex jungle of intellectual self-discovery. One thing is certain: you’d better be prepared to bring your own map. 当你开始尝试阅读卢曼的作品时，并没有友好的启蒙。您很快就会遇到非常规的、令人生畏的术语。这个术语充满了思想之间突然、混乱的转变。62 想知道这一切的精华部分吗？卢曼甚至懒得解释他引入的非常规术语。他让你踏上一段智力自我发现的复杂丛林的精神之旅。有一件事是肯定的：您最好准备好自己的地图。

Judging the books that contained such complex webs of ideas, one may be quick to blame Luhmann’s Zettelkasten; however, that’s jumping to conclusions too quickly. Luhmann’s environment certainly influenced the complex style Luhmann strived for in his texts, but there are a few other reasons Luhmann’s work is web-like: one is out of principle, and the other is that Luhmann perhaps enjoyed being a troll. Let’s cover such aspects now. 判断包含如此复杂思想网络的书籍，人们可能很快就会责怪卢曼的 Zettelkasten；但是，这太快下结论了。卢曼的环境当然影响了卢曼在他的文本中力求的复杂风格，但卢曼的作品像网络一样还有其他一些原因：一个是不符合原则的，另一个是卢曼可能喜欢做一个巨魔。现在让我们涵盖这些方面。

**Luhmann Desired to Be Impenetrable for The Sake of Principle 卢曼希望为了原则而坚不可摧**

Luhmann brings forth the idea that not everything ought to be easy to understand. He once posed the question: “Should everything that is said be equally forced under the rod of comprehensibility?… Comprehensibility without effort? Understandable without any preparation, without any time thinking and deciphering?”[63](#footnote-034) From this, Luhmann implied that one shouldn’t expect all knowledge to be in a format that could be spoon-fed to those who are not committed to the work involved in understanding advanced thought. Advanced knowledge is something that must be earned, in other words. It does one an injustice to make such knowledge so easily digestible; doing such a thing waters down the impact knowledge can have on one’s mind. 卢曼提出了这样一种观点，即并非所有事物都应该易于理解。他曾经提出这样一个问题：“所有所说的一切都应该被同样地强加在可理解性的棒下吗？…… 不费吹灰之力的可理解性？” 无需任何准备，无需任何时间思考和破译就可以理解？”63 卢曼由此暗示，人们不应期望所有知识都采用一种形式，可以用勺子喂给那些不致力于理解工作的人思想先进。换句话说，高级知识是必须获得的东西。让这样的知识如此容易消化是不公平的；做这样的事情会削弱知识对一个人思想的影响。

Perhaps this is just a cop-out by Luhmann. After all, it’s easier to offload the cognitive work involved in simplifying ideas. But maybe Luhmann does have a point. It would degrade some of the world’s magic if all knowledge were trivial to ingest. Perhaps Luhmann’s right in this respect. 也许这只是卢曼的一个逃避。毕竟，卸载涉及简化想法的认知工作更容易。但也许卢曼确实有道理。如果所有的知识都微不足道，它会降低世界的一些魔力。也许卢曼在这方面是对的。

Indeed, the more complex and impenetrable a subject is, the more attractive it can become for those with a thirst for knowledge. The difficulty of deciphering Luhmann stands as the very thing that initially attracted Johannes Schmidt (the scholar heading up the digitization of Luhmann’s literary estate). When Schmidt first came across Luhmann’s work, he did not understand a word of it. 事实上，一门学科越复杂、越难理解，它对那些求知若渴的人就越有吸引力。破译卢曼的困难正是最初吸引约翰内斯 · 施密特（领导卢曼文学遗产数字化的学者）的原因。当施密特第一次看到卢曼的作品时，他一个字也不懂。

In making his texts challenging to decipher, Luhmann essentially filtered out and disqualified those he could not care less about—that is, people who weren’t serious and committed to putting in the work required to engage with theoretical sociology. 在使他的文本难以破译的过程中，卢曼基本上过滤掉了那些他不太关心的人，也就是那些不认真和不致力于投入理论社会学所需工作的人。

For those serious about social theory, the complexity of Luhmann counter-intuitively seemed to serve as the key attraction. From there, his writing sucked people into The Matrix of Sociology, if you will. 对于那些认真对待社会理论的人来说，卢曼的复杂性似乎反直觉地成为了关键的吸引力。从那里开始，他的作品吸引了人们进入社会学矩阵，如果你愿意的话。

In an interview with Johannes Schmidt conducted by a man who runs a podcast covering complex philosophical and social concepts, they both shared the same experience upon first encountering Luhmann: “When you first read Luhmann, on the one hand, you don’t understand at all, but on the other hand that makes you want to!”[64](#footnote-033) 在一位经营涵盖复杂哲学和社会概念的播客的人对 Johannes Schmidt 的采访中，他们在第一次遇到卢曼时分享了相同的经历：“当你第一次阅读卢曼时，一方面，你不明白所有，但另一方面，这让你想要！”64

We could refer to this as the phenomenon of complexity attraction—referring to the event wherein complexity serves as an attraction mechanism for those passionate about a field. 我们可以将此称为复杂性吸引现象——指的是复杂性作为对某个领域充满热情的人的吸引机制的事件。

Another example of complexity attraction is illustrated by the author of the book, The Radical Luhmann. He recounts a story in which an academic friend of his missed a talk by a guest lecturer in philosophy. When the friend asked another academic who attended the conference how it was, the person replied in all seriousness, “It was awesome—I did not understand a word!”[65](#footnote-032) 复杂性吸引的另一个例子是本书作者激进的卢曼 (The Radical Luhmann) 的例子。他讲述了一个故事，在这个故事中，他的一位学术朋友错过了一位哲学客座讲师的演讲。当这位朋友问另一位参加会议的学者时，那人一本正经地回答说：“太棒了——我一个字都听不懂！”65

**Luhmann Desired to Be Impenetrable for The Sake of Being an Irreverent Troll 卢曼希望成为一个无礼的巨魔而变得坚不可摧**

Luhmann’s character is described as an obscure, ironic, radical thinker.[66](#footnote-031) Perhaps today we’d consider him a bit of a troll. Luhmann has some trollish tendencies, covered later in the book. His theories were often quite paradoxical and, after long explanations, pointed back to themselves and the beginning of where they started. He was fascinated with self-referential systems wherein the beginning is the end, and the end is the beginning. His Zettelkasten system reflected such ideas, which is somewhat unsurprising. 卢曼的性格被描述为一个晦涩、讽刺、激进的思想家。 66 也许今天我们会认为他有点像巨魔。 Luhmann 有一些 trollish 倾向，这将在本书后面介绍。他的理论常常是自相矛盾的，并且在经过长时间的解释之后，又回到了它们自己和它们开始的地方。他着迷于自我参照系统，其中开始即结束，结束即开始。他的 Zettelkasten 系统反映了这样的想法，这有点不足为奇。

In brief, one should not get caught up in the idea that the Zettelkasten will magically enable you to spit out a massive number of books or papers that are instant classics and perfect. It can undoubtedly produce excellent work; however, the sizable amount of work Luhmann produced largely also came from the fact that he only lightly edited his work. Furthermore, his work was tangled in a spider-like web. Some of this is due to his Zettelkasten, which is due to the aforementioned variables. 简而言之，人们不应该相信 Zettelkasten 会神奇地让你吐出大量即时经典和完美的书籍或论文。它无疑可以产生出色的作品；然而，卢曼创作的大量作品很大程度上也来自于他只对作品进行了轻微的编辑。此外，他的工作纠缠在一张蜘蛛网中。其中一些是由于他的 Zettelkasten，这是由于上述变量。

In my opinion, there’s a healthy balance for how to use a Zettelkasten system. It centers around the age-old balance of quality vs. quantity. The Antinet’s main benefit is its ability to develop thoughts thoroughly. It truly does help create profound ideas; however, you must also be prepared to take the time to edit your work and make it readable for your audience—if, that is, you wish to appeal to general readers. Instead of publishing seventy books, if Luhmann had instead focused on making, say, ten books (and thus had taken the additional time to make his ideas easier to digest) perhaps his theoretical work would be much more popular than it remains today. 在我看来，如何使用 Zettelkasten 系统存在一个健康的平衡。它以质量与数量的古老平衡为中心。 Antinet 的主要好处是它能够彻底发展思想。它确实有助于创造深刻的想法；但是，您还必须准备好花时间编辑您的作品并使其对您的观众具有可读性——也就是说，如果您希望吸引普通读者。如果卢曼不是出版 70 本书，而是专注于制作，比如说，10 本书（并因此花更多的时间让他的思想更容易被消化），也许他的理论著作会比今天更受欢迎。

Using an Antinet will enable you to develop and put all the crazy, otherworldly thoughts from your mind into a rumination system that allows it to grow. From there, their complexity will grow. You can certainly decide to forego simplifying your text for the general reader. Or, you can use such a system to enable you to offload the complexity that usually lives in your mind so that you can then create a more reader-friendly, more straightforward version for your audience. It’s entirely up to you. 使用 Antinet 将使您能够开发并将所有疯狂的、超凡脱俗的想法从您的脑海中放入一个允许它成长的反刍系统。从那里开始，它们的复杂性将会增加。您当然可以决定放弃为普通读者简化您的文本。或者，您可以使用这样的系统来卸载通常存在于您脑海中的复杂性，以便您可以为您的受众创建一个更易于阅读、更直接的版本。这完全取决于你。

It’s essential to keep all of this in mind when deciding whether you wish to build your own Antinet. When using an Antinet, your ideas and thoughts will indeed be developed to a greater degree than they otherwise would. Yet, it also means that the complexity and entanglements of your ideas will also grow, thus requiring much editing to make your work digestible. 在决定是否要构建自己的 Antinet 时，务必牢记所有这些。使用 Antinet 时，您的想法和思想确实会比其他情况下得到更大程度的发展。然而，这也意味着您的想法的复杂性和纠缠性也会增加，因此需要进行大量编辑才能使您的工作易于理解。

In brief, Luhmann’s pedantic, and overly-complex writing style can be attributed to several things. Primarily it stems from the German academic climate of his day. It also stems from his carnivalesque and trollish nature. He purposely sought to be impenetrable by “stupid” critics. Yet, the Antinet itself isn’t to blame for Luhmann’s writing voice. 简而言之，卢曼迂腐、过于复杂的写作风格可以归因于几个原因。这主要源于他那个时代的德国学术氛围。这也源于他狂欢和巨魔的天性。他故意试图让 “愚蠢的” 批评家无法理解。然而，Antinet 本身并不是卢曼写作声音的罪魁祸首。

On the opposite end of the spectrum, we find Umberto Eco, an Italian scholar who used his own Antinet-like system. Eco’s notecard system, like the Antinet, possessed web-like cross-references. However, Eco wrote in a way that both entertained and informed his readers at the same time.[67](#footnote-030) Just because one uses a web-like analog system doesn’t mean their writing style magically becomes arrogant. 在频谱的另一端，我们找到了意大利学者 Umberto Eco，他使用了自己的类似 Antinet 的系统。 Eco 的记事本系统与 Antinet 一样，拥有类似网络的交叉引用。然而，Eco 的写作方式既让他的读者感到愉悦，又让他的读者知晓信息。67 仅仅因为一个人使用了类似网络的模拟系统，并不意味着他们的写作风格神奇地变得傲慢自大。

Now, should you write in the trollishly pedantic academic style of Luhmann? Or, should you opt for the entertaining and informative style of Umberto Eco? My opinion is to follow the advice of Hemingway: write the truth. Write the truest sentence you can. Write with your 100% authentic voice. Your readers can smell it on you. People are more perceptive than you think. If writing like a trollish academic pleases you, and if it is you, then by all means write that way! Otherwise, err on the side of writing to communicate, instead of writing to confuse. 现在，你应该用卢曼那种古怪迂腐的学术风格写作吗？或者，您应该选择 Umberto Eco 的娱乐性和信息性风格吗？我的意见是听从海明威的建议：写真话。尽可能写出最真实的句子。用您 100% 真实的声音写作。你的读者可以从你身上闻到。人们比你想象的更敏锐。如果像一个 trollish academic 那样写作让你高兴，如果是你，那么一定要那样写！否则，宁愿写作是为了交流，而不是写作是为了混淆。

Assuming I haven’t scared you away at this point, let’s now move on to why one would opt for an Antinet in the first place. Let’s talk about where the Antinet shines. 假设我在这一点上没有吓跑你，现在让我们继续讨论为什么人们会首先选择 Antinet。让我们谈谈 Antinet 的闪光点。

**Where the Antinet Truly ShinesAntinet 真正闪耀的地方**
-------------------------------------------------

The entire point of using an Antinet centers around producing unconventional, deeply evolved thoughts. Certain aspects of an Antinet ensure unconventional, deeply evolved thoughts emerge from the system, and these areas are where it shines in comparison to other knowledge systems. 使用 Antinet 的全部意义在于产生非常规的、深度进化的思想。 Antinet 的某些方面确保系统中出现非常规的、深度进化的思想，与其他知识系统相比，这些领域是它的闪光点。

**Producing Genius-Level Work through Creative Insights and Unconventional Interactions 通过创造性的洞察力和非常规的互动产生天才级的作品**

Let’s start from the end result of what an Antinet aims to produce, and then work backward from there. 让我们从 Antinet 旨在产生的最终结果开始，然后从那里开始倒推。

An Antinet aims to produce genius-level work. Plain and simple.Antinet 旨在产生天才级别的作品。干净利落。

To produce genius-level work, one must unlock creative insights that otherwise would remain disconnected in disparate fields. As a thinker, your goal centers not on hitting targets that others find difficult to hit, but to hit targets that others can’t even see. This comes about by unlocking creative insights. 要想创作出天才级别的作品，就必须释放出创造性的洞察力，否则这些洞察力在不同的领域会保持脱节。作为一个思考者，你的目标不是要达到别人难以达到的目标，而是要达到别人甚至看不到的目标。这是通过释放创造性的洞察力来实现的。

Nassim Nicholas Taleb observes that the primary reason for America’s dominance in the global economy (with companies like Apple, Amazon, Nike, Google, Facebook, etc.) all stems from one key strength: creativity.[68](#footnote-029) 纳西姆 · 尼古拉斯 · 塔勒布 (Nassim Nicholas Taleb) 观察到，美国在全球经济中占据主导地位的主要原因（苹果、亚马逊、耐克、谷歌、Facebook 等公司）都源于一个关键优势：创造力。 68

The question then becomes: how does one unlock creative insights? 那么问题就变成了：一个人如何解锁创造性的洞察力？

Unlocking creative insights stem from one thing: unconventional interactions. For something to be unconventional requires some degree of randomness and the paradoxical quality of being true, with the insight often inspiring a sense of awe and wonder. The requirement for interactions is comparison. That is, one must be able to relate and associate concepts. This primes similar ideas to be nested and neighbored around one another so that when an unconventional link is connected to a “neighborhood” in the Zettelkasten, it creates unexpected ideas that emerge from viewing it in context with its neighboring cards. 释放创造性的洞察力源于一件事：非常规的互动。一些非常规的东西需要一定程度的随机性和真实的矛盾品质，而洞察力往往会激发敬畏和惊奇的感觉。交互的要求是比较。也就是说，一个人必须能够关联和联想概念。这引发了相似的想法相互嵌套和相邻，这样当一个非常规的链接连接到 Zettelkasten 中的 “邻居” 时，它会产生意想不到的想法，这些想法是在与相邻卡片的上下文中查看它时产生的。

At the center of innovation rest two seemingly different concepts, from two seemingly different contexts, that interact to create something greater than either of those two concepts individually. This is a central idea of communication theory—a field Luhmann’s work was deeply rooted in and that he understood quite well. Innovation and breakthroughs in thinking happen when two different ideas, with different goals and perspectives, communicate and create new meaning.[69](#footnote-028) This is related to the concept of emergence in systems theory, in which new properties and behaviors emerge when individual parts interact in a broader whole. 创新的核心在于两个看似不同的概念，来自两个看似不同的背景，它们相互作用创造出比这两个概念中的任何一个更伟大的东西。这是传播理论的一个中心思想——卢曼的工作深深植根于这个领域，他对此非常了解。当具有不同目标和观点的两种不同想法进行交流并创造新的意义时，思维上的创新和突破就会发生。 69 这与系统理论中的出现概念有关，其中当各个部分在更广泛的环境中相互作用时，新的属性和行为就会出现所有的。

Such phenomena appear to occur more profoundly within a system such as an Antinet. Unlike digital systems (which have the tendency of being flooded with too much information), an analog thinking system seems to generate fewer yet much more meaningful interactions, which, in turn, generate creative insights that are not replicable by the system’s digital cousins. 这种现象似乎更深刻地发生在像 Antinet 这样的系统中。与数字系统（有被过多信息淹没的趋势）不同，模拟思维系统似乎产生更少但更有意义的交互，反过来，产生创造性的见解，这是系统的数字表亲无法复制的。

**The Antinet Shines When One Desires to Develop a Long-Term Thesis or Series of Works in an Area (Such as a Thirty-Year Thesis) 当一个人希望在一个地区发展长期论文或系列作品（例如三十年论文）时，Antinet 就会发光**

The reason Luhmann created his Zettelkasten in the first place is two-fold. 卢曼首先创建他的 Zettelkasten 的原因有两个。

First, Luhmann set out to create a system for retrieving things forgotten by memory.
