Yet after a certain point, as early as 1981, he discovered its true power—his Zettelkasten became a thinking tool and communication partner that emerged almost as if it were its own mind, a ghost in the box. More on this will be covered later. More pertinent right now, however, is the second reason Luhmann started his Antinet. 首先，卢曼着手创建一个系统来检索被记忆遗忘的事物。然而在某一时刻之后，早在 1981 年，他就发现了它的真正力量——他的 Zettelkasten 变成了一种思考工具和沟通伙伴，它几乎就像是自己的思想，盒子里的幽灵。稍后将对此进行更多介绍。然而，现在更相关的是卢曼开始他的 Antinet 的第二个原因。

The second reason relates to his main objective: to embark upon a thirty-year-long quest to excavate a theory of everything as it relates to human society. 第二个原因与他的主要目标有关：开始长达三十年的探索，挖掘与人类社会相关的万物理论。

Authors like Robert Greene and Ryan Holiday have publicly shared their notecard systems, yet their systems are quite trivial compared to an Antinet. They’re organized by topic or book title. They were created primarily for writing one book, which are projects lasting one to several years. Their notebox systems were not architected for projects with a time span of three decades. A short-term project is more straightforward in scope than a thirty-year theory of everything. This likely explains why Greene’s and Holiday’s notebox systems don’t seem to restrict them. However, when you’re trying to categorize and prepare for a project that will last thirty years, you must embrace chaos. You cannot hope to have the categories you start out with be perfectly ordered and arranged by topic forever. You can’t expect to have the notebox adhere to the original set of organized sections over the long term. The thoughts and ideas must emerge as your research grows. Knowledge will emerge from the trees and branches of thought in unconventional places. 像 Robert Greene 和 Ryan Holiday 这样的作者已经公开分享了他们的记事卡系统，但与 Antinet 相比，他们的系统非常微不足道。它们按主题或书名组织。它们主要是为了写一本书而创建的，这些项目会持续一到几年。他们的记事本系统不是为时间跨度为 30 年的项目设计的。短期项目在范围上比 30 年的万物理论更直接。这可能解释了为什么 Greene 和 Holiday 的笔记本系统似乎没有限制它们。然而，当你试图对一个将持续三十年的项目进行分类和准备时，你必须拥抱混乱。您不能希望让您开始使用的类别永远按主题完美排序和排列。从长远来看，您不能指望让笔记箱坚持原来的一组有组织的部分。随着研究的发展，想法和想法必须出现。知识将从非常规地方的思想树和树枝中涌现。

This raises some problems with category-based notebox systems, however. Each time you finish a book, the cards live only in the silo of that project. A great wall is seemingly hoisted around the project, preventing future work from smoothly referencing its parts. It’s forever walled off from the other future projects you embark upon. Its fruitful and potent ideas are blocked off from colliding with ideas related to any future work you create. As a result, you cannot experience the cumulative compounding miracle the Antinet seems innately built for. 然而，这给基于类别的记事本系统带来了一些问题。每次你完成一本书时，卡片只存在于该项目的筒仓中。项目周围似乎竖起了一堵长城，阻止未来的工作顺利引用其部分。它永远与你开始的其他未来项目隔离开来。它富有成效和有力的想法被阻止与与您创建的任何未来工作相关的想法发生冲突。因此，您无法体验 Antinet 似乎与生俱来的累积复利奇迹。

The compounding miracle cannot be unleashed if you have to start over from scratch every time you start a new project, as evidence suggests Holiday does each time he starts a new book.[70](#footnote-027) 如果你每次开始一个新项目都必须从头开始，复合奇迹就无法释放，正如证据表明霍利迪每次开始一本新书时所做的那样。 70

Luhmann recognized this, which is one reason he architected his Antinet in such a way. “I started the index card file,” Luhmann explained, “because it was obvious to me I would have to plan for a lifetime not for a book.”[71](#footnote-026)Luhmann 认识到了这一点，这也是他以这种方式构建 Antinet 的原因之一。 “我开始制作索引卡文件，” 卢曼解释说，“因为对我来说很明显，我必须为一生而不是一本书做计划。”71

In brief, the Antinet is best for long-term projects and also if you intend to leverage the miracle of compounding your ideas over a thirty-year-plus timeframe. That doesn’t mean you must commit to working on one project for thirty years; instead, it means you must commit to having your work compound and interact with itself over thirty years (this is made possible by way of the Antinet’s structure). 简而言之，Antinet 最适合长期项目，如果你打算在三十多年的时间框架内利用复合你的想法的奇迹。这并不意味着您必须致力于一个项目 30 年；相反，这意味着你必须承诺让你的作品在三十年内与自己进行复合和互动（这是通过 Antinet 的结构实现的）。

Other problems with categorical-based notebox systems will be outlined later on in the book. 本书稍后将概述基于分类的记事本系统的其他问题。

**The Antinet Shines in Revealing Structured AccidentsAntinet 在揭示结构性事故方面大放异彩**

The Antinet enables users to slow down their minds and develop their thoughts. It also excels in stimulating one to think of associated ideas and then link to those ideas in the note. Some confuse this (the concept of linking) as the unique benefit of Luhmann’s system; however, this is not the case.Antinet 使用户能够放慢他们的思维并发展他们的思想。它还擅长激发人们思考相关的想法，然后将这些想法链接到笔记中。有些人将此（链接的概念）混淆为卢曼系统的独特优势；然而，这种情况并非如此。

The practice of reading something and writing the idea immediately into a digital markdown file, and then linking that file to some other idea is not what is meant by unconventional interactions. For something to be an unconventional interaction, it must genuinely be unconventional. Nearly anyone can search their digital notes to find keywords related to the current idea they just wrote down and link that idea. The idea of simply linking your notes in this way is a misinterpretation that plagues countless numbers of people in the digital Zettelkasten world. 阅读一些东西并将想法立即写入数字降价文件，然后将该文件链接到其他想法的做法并不是非常规交互的意思。对于非常规的互动，它必须真正是非常规的。几乎任何人都可以搜索他们的数字笔记，找到与他们刚刚写下的当前想法相关的关键字，并将该想法链接起来。以这种方式简单地链接你的笔记的想法是一种误解，困扰着数字 Zettelkasten 世界中无数人。

For instance, David Kadavy’s book about digital Zettelkästen outlines the advantage of the system, stating that you activate your mind’s “associative” machine when you think of a related concept in your mind, which “collides” with another related idea.[72](#footnote-025) While this is true to a degree, it largely misses the mark. Here’s why: 例如，David Kadavy 关于数字 Zettelkästen 的书概述了该系统的优势，指出当您在脑海中想到一个相关概念时，您会激活大脑的 “联想” 机器，与另一个相关想法“碰撞”。 72 虽然这是在某种程度上是正确的，它在很大程度上没有达到目标。原因如下：

The point of the Antinet is its ability to serve as a thinking machine, as a knowledge development system, and as an extended memory. The system forces the user to think of the keyterm they would use to describe a concept. Only after this critical step do you look up the concept and go through your notes and compare and remind yourself of the things you’ve forgotten in the process. The magic of an Antinet does not center on one’s ability to think about what a new concept you’ve read relates to (as that’s a conventional interaction, not an unconventional interaction). Rather, as Luhmann puts it, its magic stems from “interactions that were never planned, never preconceived, or conceived” by your current way of thinking.[73](#footnote-024)Antinet 的要点在于它能够充当思维机器、知识开发系统和扩展记忆。该系统强制用户考虑他们将用来描述概念的关键词。只有在这个关键步骤之后，你才能查找概念并浏览你的笔记并比较并提醒自己在此过程中忘记的事情。 Antinet 的魔力并不在于一个人思考你所阅读的新概念与之相关的能力（因为这是一种传统的互动，而不是非常规的互动）。相反，正如卢曼所说，它的魔力源于您当前思维方式 “从未计划、从未先入为主或设想的互动”。 73

The magic of innovation and of unlocking creativity stems from the possibility of (1) making relations using the term you’re currently thinking of, but more importantly (2) the analog nature of the system with its tree-structure (which you’ll learn about later in the book), ends up inducing structured accidents that are otherwise impossible to replicate.[74](#footnote-023) 创新和释放创造力的魔力源于以下可能性：(1) 使用您当前正在考虑的术语建立关系，但更重要的是 (2) 系统的模拟性质及其树结构（您将在本书的后面部分了解），最终会引发结构性事故，否则这些事故是无法复制的。 74

This is why it’s critical, in Luhmann’s words, that your “selection and comparisons are not identical with the schema of searching for them.”[75](#footnote-022) Why is this the case? Because simply searching for a keyword, digitally, robs the potential for innovation to occur not through seeing what you felt was related in that moment, but through the ingenious, unconventional discoveries you make along the way navigating to the nearby cards, and nearby branches of thought that have emerged and evolved around the cards you’re looking for. This tree-like structure, of which the Antinet is comprised, is what helps unlock truly unconventional interactions. The concept of the tree-like structure is something to be covered in detail later in this book. 这就是为什么用卢曼的话来说，你的 “选择和比较与搜索它们的模式不同” 是至关重要的。 75 为什么会这样？因为简单地以数字方式搜索关键字，会剥夺创新的潜力，而不是通过看到你当时觉得相关的东西，而是通过你在导航到附近的卡片和附近的分支机构的过程中所做的巧妙的、非常规的发现。围绕您正在寻找的卡片出现和发展的想法。构成 Antinet 的这种树状结构有助于解锁真正非常规的交互。树状结构的概念将在本书后面详细介绍。

CHAPTER THREE 第三章
-----------------

The Current Zettelkasten Landscape 当前的 Zettelkasten 景观
------------------------------------------------------

Why I Decided to Write This Book 为什么我决定写这本书
-------------------------------------------

Let’s first start with why i am not writing a book about the Antinet  (i.e., an analog Zettelkasten). 让我们首先从为什么我不写一本关于 Antinet（即模拟 Zettelkasten）的书开始。

I am not writing a book on the Antinet to sell a massive number of books. As mentioned, I started out working with an Antinet because I desired to write about my interests in other fields (specifically: marketing, copywriting, philosophy, and psychology). While working on a book in these fields, I decided to use an analog Zettelkasten to help me. In doing this, I discovered how wrong the conventional wisdom is about Zettelkasten. I had to learn this the hard way. In order to figure out the truth, I went straight to the original source: Luhmann’s online archive. I spent many months reverse-engineering Luhmann’s Zettelkasten. I wrote out many of his notecards by hand to understand how it truly works. I discovered that the Zettelkasten is much different than how it’s described everywhere else. 我在 Antinet 上写书不是为了销售大量书籍。如前所述，我开始使用 Antinet 是因为我想写下我在其他领域的兴趣（特别是：市场营销、文案写作、哲学和心理学）。在写这些领域的书时，我决定使用模拟 Zettelkasten 来帮助我。在这样做的过程中，我发现了关于 Zettelkasten 的传统观点是多么错误。我不得不以艰难的方式学习这一点。为了弄清楚真相，我直接找到了原始资料来源：卢曼的在线档案。我花了几个月的时间对 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 进行逆向工程。我手写了他的许多记事卡，以了解它是如何真正起作用的。我发现 Zettelkasten 与其他地方的描述大不相同。

I think it’s important to publish this book on the Antinet because there’s already a wealth of wonderful books in the field of marketing, copywriting, and psychology. Within the realm of Zettelkasten, there’s really only one dominant book out there right now: How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens. 我认为将这本书出版在 Antinet 上很重要，因为在营销、文案和心理学领域已经有大量精彩的书籍。在 Zettelkasten 的领域内，目前真的只有一本占主导地位的书：Sönke Ahrens 的《如何做智能笔记》。

This would be fine if the book was excellent; however, there are two issues with the book. First, it contains information that gets the most critical pieces of the Zettelkasten wrong. And second, many people don’t even realize Ahrens’s book exists. This becomes problematic because the online environment for gaining an accurate understanding of a Zettelkasten is even worse. I surveyed the top nine search engine results for the term “Zettelkasten.” In brief, every one of them contains flaws in their description of what a Zettelkasten is. 如果这本书很棒，那会很好；但是，这本书有两个问题。首先，它包含的信息使 Zettelkasten 的最关键部分出错。其次，许多人甚至不知道阿伦斯的书的存在。这变得有问题，因为用于准确了解 Zettelkasten 的在线环境甚至更糟。我调查了 “Zettelkasten” 一词的前九个搜索引擎结果。简而言之，他们每个人在描述什么是 Zettelkasten 时都存在缺陷。

When searching for the term “Zettelkasten” on Google, the first result is Wikipedia’s entry for Zettelkasten. This entry gets it wrong in several ways. First, it describes the Zettelkasten as a hierarchical structure.[76](#footnote-124) This is wrong. A Zettelkasten is a tree-like structure wherein each leaf is of the same importance as any other. Each leaf, like each note, just lives in a different location on a tree. Second, Wikipedia posits a Zettelkasten as something built in digital format using “specialist knowledge management software.” The entry then reluctantly admits that it “can be done on paper using index cards.”[77](#footnote-123) In reality, the true power of Zettelkasten revolves around the fact that it is—in its very essence—an actual notebox! 在 Google 上搜索术语 “Zettelkasten” 时，第一个结果是维基百科关于 Zettelkasten 的条目。这个条目在几个方面弄错了。首先，它将 Zettelkasten 描述为一个等级结构。76 这是错误的。 Zettelkasten 是一种树状结构，其中每片叶子都与其他叶子具有相同的重要性。每片叶子，就像每个音符，只是生活在树上的不同位置。其次，维基百科将 Zettelkasten 定位为使用 “专业知识管理软件” 以数字格式构建的东西。然后条目不情愿地承认它“可以使用索引卡在纸上完成。”77 事实上，Zettelkasten 的真正力量在于它是——本质上——一个真正的笔记本！

The second result I was given was the website [zettelkasten.de](http://zettelkasten.de/).[78](#footnote-122) When I first began surveying the top search results for Zettelkasten, I landed on a “Lessons Learned” post on the home page of [zettelkasten.de](http://zettelkasten.de/). The post was written by a machine-learning researcher who shared his journey using a Zettelkasten. This researcher mentioned the frustration using tags. The site owners responded, sharing their frustrations with tags, saying that the “mess” it creates resonated with them. Yet as a solution, they referenced a post that discusses a distinction between good and bad tags.[79](#footnote-121) To me, this just seems like complexity built on unnecessary complexity. Remember, I was very new to the field of Zettelkasten at the time. I soon discovered that the creator of Zettelkasten, Niklas Luhmann, never used tags. This illustrates what I believe happens to many people who are new to Zettelkasten. They end up stumbling across these types of online posts and find themselves unnecessarily confused. 我得到的第二个结果是网站 zettelkasten.de.78 当我第一次开始调查 Zettelkasten 的热门搜索结果时，我看到了 zettelkasten.de 主页上的 “经验教训” 帖子。这篇文章是由一位机器学习研究人员撰写的，他分享了他使用 Zettelkasten 的旅程。这位研究人员提到了使用标签的挫败感。网站所有者回应说，他们对标签感到沮丧，称标签造成的 “混乱” 引起了他们的共鸣。然而，作为解决方案，他们引用了一篇讨论区分好标签和坏标签的帖子。79 对我来说，这似乎是建立在不必要的复杂性之上的复杂性。请记住，当时我对 Zettelkasten 领域还很陌生。我很快发现 Zettelkasten 的创建者 Niklas Luhmann 从未使用过标签。这说明了我认为许多刚接触 Zettelkasten 的人会遇到的情况。他们最终无意中发现了这些类型的在线帖子，并发现自己陷入了不必要的困惑。

The search engine’s third result on the term “Zettelkasten” also came from [zettelkasten.de](http://zettelkasten.de/). It was the Getting Started Overview page where one finds advice such as “Don’t use categories. Use tags instead.”[80](#footnote-120) The problem here is twofold. First, as stated previously, Luhmann never used tags (as the concept was not yet invented). And second, Luhmann didn’t even subscribe to this notion in spirit. Luhmann used categories and top-level sections for his Zettelkasten. They weren’t strict categories like the Dewey Decimal system. They were more like rough starting points. Nonetheless, they were indeed categories. In Luhmann’s first Zettelkasten, he had 108 categories. His second Zettelkasten was more narrowly focused on his sociological work, yet it still contained 11 top-level categories.[81](#footnote-119) 该搜索引擎关于 “Zettelkasten” 一词的第三个结果也来自 zettelkasten.de。这是入门概述页面，人们可以在其中找到诸如 “不要使用类别” 之类的建议。请改用标签。”80 这里的问题是双重的。首先，如前所述，卢曼从未使用过标签（因为当时还没有发明这个概念）。其次，卢曼在精神上什至不认同这个观点。 Luhmann 在他的 Zettelkasten 中使用了类别和顶级部分。它们不像杜威十进制系统那样严格分类。它们更像是粗略的起点。尽管如此，它们确实是类别。在卢曼的第一个 Zettelkasten 中，他有 108 个类别。他的第二个 Zettelkasten 更侧重于他的社会学工作，但它仍然包含 11 个顶级类别。 81

The next handful of search engine results suffers similar inaccuracies. They contain material overly focused on the digitized—and in my opinion, compromised—version of the Zettelkasten. They also include complete inventions first devised by Sönke Ahrens. They also confuse Luhmann’s numeric-alpha notecard address system by telling readers to use dates for their notecard IDs.[82](#footnote-118) The best information source on the Zettelkasten doesn’t even make it into the first five pages of the search results.[83](#footnote-117) 接下来的一些搜索引擎结果也存在类似的错误。它们包含的材料过于关注 Zettelkasten 的数字化版本——在我看来，是折衷的版本。它们还包括由 Sönke Ahrens 首次设计的完整发明。他们还通过告诉读者使用日期作为他们的记事卡 ID 来混淆 Luhmann 的数字字母记事卡地址系统。 82 Zettelkasten 上最好的信息来源甚至没有出现在搜索结果的前五页中。 83

Simply stated, learning what a Zettelkasten is by searching the term online is like walking into a minefield of misinformation. 简而言之，通过在线搜索术语了解什么是 Zettelkasten 就像走进错误信息的雷区。

I believe there are only a handful of sources the inquisitive are left with if they wish to gain an accurate understanding of Zettelkasten in its purest form (the analog form). Those sources are (1) the online archive of Niklas Luhmann’s actual Zettelkasten, (2) the paper outlining Zettelkasten written by Niklas Luhmann himself, titled, Communication with Noteboxes, (3) the works of Johannes Schmidt, a scholar at Bielefeld University who heads up Luhmann’s archive project, and who has studied Luhmann’s materials closest.[84](#footnote-116) 我相信，如果好奇者希望以最纯粹的形式（模拟形式）准确了解 Zettelkasten，那么他们只剩下少数资源了。这些来源是 (1) 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的实际 Zettelkasten 的在线档案，(2) 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 本人撰写的概述 Zettelkasten 的论文，标题为 “与记事本交流”，(3) 比勒费尔德大学的学者约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 的作品 Luhmann 的档案项目，谁研究过 Luhmann 的材料最近。 84

These three sources are difficult to penetrate and understand. With pen and notecards in hand, I spent one month reading Luhmann’s paper, Communication with Noteboxes. When printed out, this paper totals a mere four pages. It’s so densely written it requires very careful reading in order to grasp what is being said. I spent over a month reading this paper! Yet, my careful review was worth it; there is so much to learn by reading the paper. I spent about six weeks doing the same thing with Johannes Schmidt’s in-depth article on Luhmann’s Zettelkasten.[85](#footnote-115) This, too, was a very dense read. 这三个来源是很难渗透和理解的。我拿着笔和记事卡，花了一个月的时间阅读了卢曼的论文《与记事本的交流》。打印出来时，这篇论文总共只有四页。它写得如此密集，需要非常仔细地阅读才能理解所说的内容。我花了一个多月的时间阅读这篇论文！然而，我的仔细审查是值得的；阅读这篇论文可以学到很多东西。我花了大约六个星期的时间对 Johannes Schmidt 关于 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的深度文章做同样的事情。 85 这也是一篇非常密集的阅读。

I tell you all of this not necessarily to encourage you to do the same. Instead, I tell you this in case you’re curious and want to venture down the rabbit-hole of Zettelkasten knowledge yourself. These are the primary sources. They’re difficult. Thankfully, however, you don’t have to spend weeks trying to piece together a Zettelkasten from those few articles. That’s why I’m here— to introduce to you the world of the real Zettelkasten (without boring the heck out of you with dense academic prose). Even if I do bore the heck out of you in some parts, just know that it could be worse, much worse. If you doubt that, just try reading Luhmann’s paper! 我告诉你所有这一切并不一定是为了鼓励你也这样做。相反，我告诉你这个是为了防止你好奇并想自己探索 Zettelkasten 知识的兔子洞。这些是主要来源。他们很难。不过值得庆幸的是，您不必花费数周时间尝试从那几篇文章中拼凑出一个 Zettelkasten。这就是我来这里的原因——向您介绍真正的 Zettelkasten 世界（不会让您厌倦密集的学术散文）。即使我确实在某些部分让你厌烦，但要知道情况可能会更糟，更糟。如果您对此表示怀疑，请尝试阅读 Luhmann 的论文！

Before moving on, let me first outline my intent in describing the misinterpretations others hold in regards to Zettelkasten. I am not doing this because I’m motivated by some sadistic pleasure gained from criticizing the well-intentioned work of others.[86](#footnote-114) In fact, I feel bad about calling to light what I see as the errors and misinterpretations of such people. Every individual I’ve come across in the personal knowledge management and Zettelkasten fields are well-intentioned. Granted these people often sell online courses, or online consulting, and have agendas related to those sales; yet it’s not disguised. It’s quite apparent what the catch is. Every one of them believes he or she is teaching material that will help people produce better knowledge. Moreover, much of the proselytizers of Zettelkasten knowledge come close to getting things right. Indeed, some authors share useful principles that even Luhmann himself did not bother mentioning.[87](#footnote-113) 在继续之前，让我首先概述一下我描述其他人对 Zettelkasten 的误解的意图。我这样做并不是因为我受到批评他人善意工作所带来的施虐快感的驱使。86 事实上，我对呼吁揭露我所看到的这些人的错误和误解感到难过。我在个人知识管理和 Zettelkasten 领域遇到的每个人都是善意的。当然，这些人经常销售在线课程或在线咨询，并且有与这些销售相关的议程；但它没有伪装。很明显，问题是什么。他们每个人都相信自己是教材，可以帮助人们产生更好的知识。此外，许多 Zettelkasten 知识的传播者都接近于把事情做好。事实上，一些作者分享了一些有用的原则，甚至连卢曼本人也懒得提及。 87

As I was learning Luhmann’s Zettelkasten myself, I observed something that reminded me of a cognitive error called the availability cascade. Even if you’re unfamiliar with the term, you’re undoubtedly familiar with its concept. An availability cascade describes the phenomenon of an idea spreading rapidly and creating a self-reinforcing cascade of information. It occurs as the result of encapsulating a novel and complex concept into a simplified version—and here’s the key part—the simplified version is slightly less accurate. This creates a waterfall of incorrect information that re-circulates itself and spreads rapidly. Why? Because simpler ideas spread more easily. 当我自己学习 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 时，我观察到一些让我想起称为可用性级联的认知错误的东西。即使您不熟悉这个术语，您无疑也熟悉它的概念。可用性级联描述了一种想法迅速传播并创建自我强化的信息级联的现象。它的出现是将一个新颖而复杂的概念封装到一个简化版本中的结果——这是关键部分——简化版本的准确性稍差。这会产生大量不正确的信息，这些信息会自行重新传播并迅速传播。为什么？因为更简单的想法更容易传播。

Recently, a study at UC San Diego was published showcasing the availability cascade. The study found that research that is less likely to be true is cited 153 times more if the material is interesting. Implicit in this is the following idea: research spreads more if it’s simplified enough to be interesting in the first place (regardless of its accuracy). 最近，加州大学圣地亚哥分校发表了一项研究，展示了可用性级联。该研究发现，如果材料有趣，则不太可能是真实的研究被引用的次数增加 153 倍。这其中隐含了以下想法：如果研究足够简化以首先引起人们的兴趣（无论其准确性如何），它就会传播得更多。

The phenomenon of the availability cascade finds itself ever-so-present within the land of Zettelkasten. It’s negatively affecting every well-intentioned knowledge worker who becomes hopeful and excited about Zettelkasten. Here’s why: a second wave of teachers of the Zettelkasten finds itself emerging right now. Most of them do not use the primary sources as their material for teaching others about what a Zettelkasten is. Instead, this new wave of Zettelkasten evangelists use Sönke Ahrens’s work, namely his book How to Take Smart Notes, as the primary material on which they rely.[88](#footnote-112) The problem with these new Zettelkasten evangelists is not just their misunderstanding of how the Zettelkasten truly works, but also the contradictions they introduce.[89](#footnote-111) 可用性级联的现象发现自己在 Zettelkasten 的土地上一直存在。它对每一位对 Zettelkasten 充满希望和兴奋的善意知识工作者产生了负面影响。原因如下：Zettelkasten 的第二波教师发现自己正在涌现。他们中的大多数人不使用主要来源作为他们的材料来教别人什么是 Zettelkasten。相反，新一波的 Zettelkasten 布道者使用 Sönke Ahrens 的著作，即他的书《如何做聪明的笔记》，作为他们所依赖的主要材料。 88 这些新的 Zettelkasten 布道者的问题不仅仅是他们对 Zettelkasten 真正运作方式的误解，还有他们引入的矛盾。 89

For instance, one self-declared bestselling author published a book recently on how the Zettelkasten works.[90](#footnote-110) His book not only preaches Ahrens’s work, it appends new inventions onto it. As a result, one is left with inventions built on top of an already sizable list of inventions. I will introduce you to these inventions shortly. They derive from a new quasi-religion that has developed a rather malignant growth inside the world of Zettelkasten. I call this quasi-religion, Ahrensianity. 例如，一位自称为畅销书的作家最近出版了一本关于 Zettelkasten 工作原理的书。90 他的书不仅宣扬了 Ahrens 的作品，还在其上附加了新发明。结果，留下了建立在已经相当大的发明清单之上的发明。我将很快向您介绍这些发明。它们源自一种新的准宗教，这种准宗教在 Zettelkasten 的世界中发展得相当恶性。我称这种准宗教为 Ahrensianity。

**Ahrensianity 阿伦斯性**
---------------------

Mark Twain once wrote to himself privately in his notebook, “If Christ were here there is one thing he would not be—a Christian.”[91](#footnote-109) This indeed may be true. After all, Jesus referred to himself as Jewish and never called himself a “Christian,” for one. Second, he was a poor Galilean who was illiterate and didn’t speak Greek (the language the New Testament was written in). Where did “Christian” come from then? From the early Hellenic-Jewish Apostle named Paul—a man who never met nor knew Jesus, yet who served as a forceful voice in the formative decades after the death of Jesus. Paul’s teachings and writings formed the core beliefs and doctrines of Christianity. In brief, his interpretations of a remote Jew he didn’t even know are what ended up giving birth to Christianity as we know it.[92](#footnote-108) 马克 · 吐温曾在他的笔记本中私下给自己写道：“如果基督在这里，那么他就不会成为基督徒。”91 这确实可能是真的。毕竟，耶稣称自己为犹太人，从未称自己为 “基督徒”。其次，他是一个贫穷的加利利人，不识字，不会说希腊语（新约圣经就是用这种语言写成的）。那么“基督教” 从何而来？来自早期的希腊犹太使徒保罗——一个从未见过也不认识耶稣的人，但在耶稣死后的几十年里，他是一个强有力的声音。保罗的教导和著作构成了基督教的核心信仰和教义。简而言之，他对一个他甚至不认识的偏远犹太人的解释最终催生了我们所知道的基督教。 92

Since the 1700s, scholars have been publishing arguments that show how Paul’s teachings differ from and contradict Jesus’s teachings. Furthermore, Paul’s teachings add inventions to Jesus’s preachings that were never held by Jesus. This has given rise to the term “Pauline Christianity,” or “Paulism,” which the world today knows as Christianity. Yet, again, this body of teachings finds itself profoundly different from that of the founder—Jesus of Nazareth.[93](#footnote-107) I don’t know about you, but I’m a much bigger fan of Jesus of Nazareth and his teachings, than I am of religious dogma. 自 1700 年代以来，学者们一直在发表论据，表明保罗的教导与耶稣的教导有何不同和矛盾。此外，保罗的教导在耶稣的讲道中添加了耶稣从未持有过的发明。这导致了 “保罗基督教” 或“保禄主义”一词的产生，即当今世界所熟知的基督教。然而，再一次，这套教义发现自己与创始人——拿撒勒人耶稣的教义截然不同。93 我不知道你怎么想，但我比我更喜欢拿撒勒人耶稣和他的教义的宗教教条。

It may seem absurd, but the phenomenon of Paul learning of Jesus and then inventing the notion of Christianity is similar to that of Sönke Ahrens learning of Niklas Luhmann and inventing the notion of Zettelkasten. Yet what Ahrens teaches is not the Zettelkasten system as Luhmann conceived of it; rather it contains its own flavor and spin. Yet, with Ahrens’s insistence on the idea that the power of the Zettelkasten revolves around the mere linking of notes (in digital form), it’s perhaps been taken even further away from the original form than what Paul did to Jesus’s teachings. 这可能看起来很荒谬，但保罗学习耶稣然后发明基督教概念的现象类似于 Sönke Ahrens 学习尼克拉斯卢曼并发明 Zettelkasten 的概念。然而，阿伦斯所教导的并不是卢曼设想的 Zettelkasten 系统；相反，它包含自己的风味和旋转。然而，由于 Ahrens 坚持认为 Zettelkasten 的力量仅围绕音符的链接（以数字形式），因此它可能比保罗对耶稣的教义所做的更远离原始形式。

In brief, Ahrens’s interpretations of Zettelkasten should not be called Zettelkasten. It should be called Ahrenskasten, or perhaps…Ahrensianity! 简而言之，阿伦斯对 Zettelkasten 的解释不应该被称为 Zettelkasten。它应该被称为 Ahrenskasten，或者……Ahrensianity！

The doctrine of Ahrensianity is composed, primarily, of three types of notes: (1) fleeting notes, (2) literature notes, and (3) permanent notes. All three of these notes stand as an invention and were never terms Niklas Luhmann used. Of the three, perhaps literature notes are closest to what Luhmann actually did; however, there are even issues with the description of such notes in Ahrens’s book. 阿伦斯学说主要由三种类型的笔记组成：(1) 短暂的笔记，(2) 文学笔记，和 (3) 永久的笔记。所有这三个音符都是一项发明，从来都不是尼克拉斯 · 卢曼使用的术语。在这三者中，也许文学笔记最接近卢曼的实际所作；然而，阿伦斯书中对此类笔记的描述甚至存在问题。

**The Latter-Day Ahrensians 后期阿伦斯派**

In a newly released book with Zettelkasten in its title, David Kadavy proceeds to illustrate the doctrine of Ahrensianity in his chapter, “Anatomy of a Zettelkasten.”[94](#footnote-106) He then adds his own inventions by adding three more components to the mix: “inbox,” “someday/maybe,” and “raw.” This leaves us with even more complexity built on top of something not even based entirely on Zettelkasten in the first place (but rather based on the interpretations of Sönke Ahrens).[95](#footnote-105) This is an example of interpretations piling on top of interpretations. Meet the latter-day Ahrensians. 在一本新出版的以 Zettelkasten 为书名的书中，David Kadavy 在他的章节 “Zettelkasten 的解剖学” 中继续说明 Ahrensianity 的学说。94 然后他通过添加另外三个组件来添加自己的发明：“收件箱， ”“有一天 / 也许”和“原始”。这给我们留下了更多的复杂性，建立在最初甚至不完全基于 Zettelkasten 的东西之上（而是基于 Sönke Ahrens 的解释）。95 这是一个解释叠加在解释之上的例子。认识近代的阿伦斯人。

As mentioned briefly, there exist confusion and contradictions within this new wave of Zettelkasten interpretation. After exposure to the lessons of Sönke Ahrens and observing confusing and contradictory reasoning brought forth by the new wave of Ahrensian devotees, it becomes clear why it’s so crucial to properly understand Zettelkasten. 正如简要提到的，Zettelkasten 解释的新一波浪潮中存在着混乱和矛盾。在接触了 Sönke Ahrens 的课程并观察了新一波 Ahrensian 信徒带来的令人困惑和矛盾的推理之后，很清楚为什么正确理解 Zettelkasten 如此重要。

For instance, one finds authors both touting the benefits of digital notes for enabling search functionality, and devaluing the analog method. Kadavy does this by stating that because an analog Zettelkasten possesses a “slow rate” of exposing users to information while using it, it consequently “reduces your focus.”[96](#footnote-104) In brief, this notion is absurd. It even conflicts with what Ahrens would admit as a primary benefit of analog. 例如，人们发现作者既吹捧数字笔记在启用搜索功能方面的好处，又贬低模拟方法。 Kadavy 这样做是说，因为模拟 Zettelkasten 在使用它时向用户展示信息的速度 “很慢”，因此它会 “降低你的注意力”。96 简而言之，这个想法是荒谬的。它甚至与 Ahrens 承认的模拟技术的主要优势相冲突。

This demonstrates something that is happening at a more rapid pace within the field of Zettelkasten. We have Kadavy, an Ahrensian follower, providing an example of why digital-based thinking and notetaking may be better because of search functionality. We also have him adding his own spin on top of the Ahrensian spin and advocating for digital search functionality of a notetaking system because, he asserts, more exposure to information will increase one’s focus.[97](#footnote-103) Again, this is absurd. But the contradictions get worse: ten pages after asserting this, Kadavy advises readers to not worry about being “efficient.”[98](#footnote-102) He goes on to declare that the “bottleneck” of great ideas does not stem from the speed and quantity of writing and thinking, but from slow, consistent, hard, and deliberate thought.[99](#footnote-101) 这证明了 Zettelkasten 领域内正在以更快的速度发生的事情。我们有 Kadavy，Ahrensian 的追随者，提供了一个例子，说明为什么基于数字的思维和笔记可能会因为搜索功能而变得更好。我们还让他在 Ahrensian spin 之上添加自己的 spin，并提倡笔记系统的数字搜索功能，因为他断言，更多地接触信息会增加一个人的注意力。97 这又是荒谬的。但矛盾变得更糟：在断言这一点后十页，Kadavy 建议读者不要担心 “效率”。98 他继续宣称伟大思想的“瓶颈” 并不源于写作和思考的速度和数量，而是来自缓慢、一致、艰苦和深思熟虑的思考。 99

In essence, an author who wrote a book on digital Zettelkasten finds himself really an advocate of the analog Zettelkasten—yet perhaps he’s too blind to see its power. He’s blinded by the digital age we live in, and seems so convinced of the technologies it’s yielded. Yet he discounts the technology of the organ that resides inside one’s skull. This technology, the human brain, seems to do better in environments where its allowed to slow down and think on paper (when it comes to writing, at least). 本质上，写了一本关于数字 Zettelkasten 的书的作者发现自己确实是模拟 Zettelkasten 的拥护者——但也许他太盲目了，看不到它的力量。他对我们生活的数字时代视而不见，而且似乎对它所产生的技术深信不疑。然而，他对位于人头骨内的器官的技术打了折扣。这种技术，即人脑，似乎在允许放慢速度并在纸上思考（至少在写作方面）的环境中表现更好。

**A Lesson from Robert Caro 罗伯特卡罗的教训**

Where does slow, consistent, hard, and deliberate thought come from? Let’s ask two-time Pulitzer Prize winning author, Robert Caro. In an interview, Caro was asked why he wrote out all of his books long-hand first, and then by typewriter. Caro responded, “It’s to slow myself down.” He concludes, “If I write by hand it’s a little bit slower and I think things through.”[100](#footnote-100) 缓慢、一致、艰苦和深思熟虑的思想从何而来？让我们问问两次获得普利策奖的作家罗伯特卡罗。在一次采访中，卡罗被问到为什么他先手写所有的书，然后再用打字机写出来。卡罗回答说：“这是为了让自己慢下来。” 他总结道，“如果我手写，速度会慢一点，我会仔细考虑。”100

How did Caro learn the power of such a method? He learned it early in his writing career. One of Caro’s writing professors once imparted advice to him. The advice ended up exposing Caro’s writing methods at the time. As Caro recounts of the experience: “You know, sometimes you know when someone has seen right through you.” Right then and there Caro knew his professor had seen through him. What Caro was referring to was the advice he received from his professor: “Mr. Caro, you’re never going to achieve what you want to achieve unless you learn to stop thinking with your fingers.” By this, Caro’s professor meant that Caro must stop just writing papers directly using his typewriter. Instead Caro ought to slow down and think on paper, with a pen. When Caro wrote his first book, he changed up his process. At the time he was still not heeding his professor’s advice. Why? Because he was “a newspaper man” and time was of the essence. Yet, when he set out to write his book, he switched. When he set out to write his book, he first wrote the draft in longhand, and then he wrote it out via typewriter.[101](#footnote-099) 卡罗是如何学会这种方法的力量的？他在写作生涯的早期就学会了这一点。卡罗的一位写作教授曾给他提过建议。该建议最终暴露了卡罗当时的写作方法。正如卡罗对这段经历的回忆：“你知道，有时候你知道什么时候有人看穿了你。” 就在那一刻，卡罗知道他的教授已经看穿了他。卡罗指的是他从教授那里得到的建议：“先生。卡罗，除非你学会停止用手指思考，否则你永远无法实现你想要实现的目标。” Caro 的教授由此意味着 Caro 必须停止直接使用他的打字机写论文。相反，卡罗应该放慢脚步，用笔在纸上思考。当卡罗写他的第一本书时，他改变了他的过程。当时他还没有听从教授的建议。为什么？因为他是 “报人”，时间紧迫。然而，当他开始写他的书时，他改变了。当他着手写书时，他先是手写草稿，然后用打字机打出来。 101

In summary, slow, consistent, deliberate thought comes from the world of analog. Specifically, it comes from writing by hand. This is something built into the Antinet. Trust me, it will transform the way in which you think. It will transform your research. And it will transform your writing. 总之，缓慢、一致、深思熟虑的思想来自模拟世界。具体来说，它来自手写。这是 Antinet 中内置的东西。相信我，它会改变你的思维方式。它将改变您的研究。它会改变你的写作。

**Those Who Teach Zettelkasten Don’t Even Know What a Zettelkasten Truly Is 那些教 Zettelkasten 的人甚至不知道 Zettelkasten 的真正含义**

Unless you’re a careful and scrutinizing reader, these seemingly contradictory positions may go unnoticed. However, since you’re now privy to Ahrensianity, you are better equipped for two things. First, you’ll find it easier to spot such contradictions when you read an article about Zettelkasten that, in reality, is teaching the Ahrensian interpretation of Luhmann’s Zettelkasten (and not the real authentic Zettelkasten); and second, you will understand why the author is confused in the first place. The reason the author is confused about what a Zettelkasten is, is simply this: a Zettelkasten isn’t merely a notetaking methodology. A Zettelkasten is a method to build your own person—a second version of yourself with whom you can communicate— a second mind. More on this will be explored in detail later in the book. 除非你是一个细心和仔细审查的读者，否则这些看似矛盾的立场可能会被忽视。但是，由于您现在了解 Ahrensianity，您可以更好地应对两件事。首先，当你阅读一篇关于 Zettelkasten 的文章时，你会发现更容易发现这些矛盾，实际上，这篇文章正在教授卢曼的 Zettelkasten 的阿伦斯式解释（而不是真正的 Zettelkasten）；其次，您首先会明白为什么作者会感到困惑。作者对 Zettelkasten 是什么感到困惑的原因很简单：Zettelkasten 不仅仅是一种记笔记的方法。 Zettelkasten 是一种建立你自己的人的方法——你可以与之交流的第二个版本——第二个头脑。本书后面将详细探讨这方面的更多内容。

**An Example Contradiction: Dynamically Updating Links 一个矛盾的例子：动态更新链接**

A key feature of digital Zettelkasten apps is the dynamic updating of links across all files when you update the filename. In other words, when you edit a note’s filename, all other notes that link to that filename dynamically update as well (so that the links don’t break). This is an important feature because the majority of digital “Zettelkasten” are not truly Zettelkasten. A true Zettelkasten system has numeric-alpha filenames (e.g. 2701/1A). Apps without the dynamic-updating function instead utilize filenames that are typically a human-readable concept name. For instance, a note that outlines confirmation bias would typically be named confirmation [bias.md](http://bias.md/). If one were to, for instance, change the filename from confirmation [bias.md](http://bias.md/) to confirmation [fallacy.md](http://fallacy.md/), then all of the links pointing to the original would break. One would have to use the find-and-replace-all text feature to fix the broken links. This is not the case with the dynamic updating feature in certain notetaking apps. As a result, much time is saved with the valuable dynamic updating feature. 数字 Zettelkasten 应用程序的一个关键功能是在您更新文件名时动态更新所有文件之间的链接。换句话说，当您编辑笔记的文件名时，链接到该文件名的所有其他笔记也会动态更新（这样链接就不会中断）。这是一个重要的特征，因为大多数数字 “Zettelkasten” 并不是真正的 Zettelkasten。真正的 Zettelkasten 系统具有数字字母文件名（例如 2701/1A）。没有动态更新功能的应用程序会使用通常是人类可读概念名称的文件名。例如，概述确认偏差的注释通常被命名为 confirmation bias.md。例如，如果将文件名从 confirmation bias.md 更改为 confirmation fallacy.md，那么所有指向原始链接的链接都会中断。必须使用查找并替换所有文本功能来修复损坏的链接。某些笔记应用程序中的动态更新功能并非如此。结果，宝贵的动态更新功能节省了大量时间。

In essence, the ability to dynamically update links is quite useful for those who use digital Zettelkasten. Yet, one finds authors writing about these apps contradicting the value of such a feature. Kadavy flat out states that it is an “overrated feature” for digital Zettelkasten.[102](#footnote-098) I don’t even use a digital Zettelkasten, nor do I wish to, yet even I can see how poorly informed this opinion is! Such an assertion could be understandable if one were using numeric-alpha addresses (that is, is using Zettelkasten in its truer form), as there would be no reason for the filenames to ever change in the first place. 从本质上讲，动态更新链接的能力对于那些使用数字 Zettelkasten 的人来说非常有用。然而，人们发现作者撰写的有关这些应用程序的文章与此类功能的价值相矛盾。 Kadavy 直言不讳地说这是数字 Zettelkasten 的 “高估功能”。102 我什至不使用数字 Zettelkasten，我也不希望使用，但即使我也能看出这种观点是多么缺乏见识！如果使用数字字母地址（即以更真实的形式使用 Zettelkasten），这样的断言是可以理解的，因为文件名一开始就没有理由改变。

The numeric-alpha naming convention Luhmann devised enables one to infinitely internally branch thoughts and link all entries anywhere. In fact, the reason one ought never to update filenames is that mistakes or odd conventions (and old naming of concepts) prove quite valuable. Moreover, they form odd clusters that order themselves in unique ways allowing one to observe the evolution of one’s thinking. This is invaluable for the knowledge development system that a Zettelkasten is.Luhmann 设计的数字字母命名约定使人们能够在内部无限地分支思想并将所有条目链接到任何地方。事实上，一个人不应该更新文件名的原因是错误或奇怪的约定（以及概念的旧命名）被证明是非常有价值的。此外，它们形成奇怪的集群，以独特的方式排列自己，让人们能够观察到一个人思维的演变。这对于 Zettelkasten 的知识开发系统来说是无价的。

**Another Contradiction: Linking Notes vs. Rewriting Ideas 另一个矛盾：链接笔记与重写想法**

The very same author who undermines the value of dynamic links in a digital Zettelkasten makes an even more absurd statement that introduces confusion for those wishing to become more effective knowledge creators. Kadavy states that linking is overrated and he supports rewriting instead of linking. Why? He reasons that it’s easier to just rewrite things by typing.[103](#footnote-097) I find this rather absurd because it diminishes the major premise of a digital Zettelkasten: the attractiveness of a digital Zettelkasten, in comparison with a digital note database, centers on the benefit of linking thoughts. One rationale for this is that by linking, users need not constantly rewrite everything. Instead, they can revise and develop the thought that they link to. Many first-generation Ahrensian followers base their biggest idea around that of linking thoughts.[104](#footnote-096) For this reason, it becomes a bit of a mess when one digital Zettelkasten follower promotes one idea and the other promotes the exact opposite notion. At the center of this mess rests the core of it all: basing one’s teachings on someone other than the system’s creator (Niklas Luhmann). Instead, when you base your opinion on an early Zettelkasten apostle (Sönke Ahrens), you’re left with contradictions. You’ll find one digital Zettelkasten teacher advocating for one thing, and a different digital Zettelkasten teacher advocating for the exact opposite. The key lesson here? Start with Luhmann, start with the original source, and then work backwards from there. 破坏数字 Zettelkasten 中动态链接价值的同一位作者发表了一个更加荒谬的声明，给那些希望成为更有效的知识创造者的人带来了困惑。 Kadavy 指出链接被高估了，他支持重写而不是链接。为什么？他认为通过打字重写东西更容易。103 我觉得这很荒谬，因为它削弱了数字 Zettelkasten 的主要前提：与数字笔记数据库相比，数字 Zettelkasten 的吸引力集中在链接的好处上想法。这样做的一个理由是，通过链接，用户不需要不断地重写所有内容。相反，他们可以修改和发展他们所链接的思想。许多第一代 Ahrensian 追随者将他们最大的想法建立在联系思想的基础上。104 因此，当一个数字 Zettelkasten 追随者推广一个想法而另一个推广完全相反的概念时，它会变得有点混乱。在这个混乱的中心是这一切的核心：将一个人的教义建立在系统创造者（尼克拉斯卢曼）以外的人身上。相反，当你的观点基于早期的 Zettelkasten 使徒（Sönke Ahrens）时，你就会陷入矛盾。你会发现一位数字 Zettelkasten 老师提倡一件事，而另一位数字 Zettelkasten 老师提倡完全相反的事情。这里的关键教训？从卢曼开始，从原始资料开始，然后从那里开始倒推。

**Another Contradiction: Highlighting Books 另一个矛盾：突出书籍**

Advising readers to highlight books while reading is something Luhmann never did. Yet we find such advice from Kadavy, the teacher of digital Zettelkasten methods. This author advises readers to highlight text in their e-readers.[105](#footnote-095) This goes against even Sönke Ahrens’s advice. Further, Kadavy then advises readers to “highlight the highlights.”[106](#footnote-094) 建议读者在阅读时突出显示书籍是卢曼从未做过的事情。然而，我们从数字 Zettelkasten 方法的老师 Kadavy 那里找到了这样的建议。这位作者建议读者在电子阅读器中突出显示文本。105 这甚至违背了 Sönke Ahrens 的建议。此外，Kadavy 随后建议读者 “突出亮点”。 106

On the matter of highlighting texts, I will say this: highlighting is not advisable. It is not a good method for focused reading of challenging and complex information. For challenging material, it’s best to invest the time required to reformulate it, and reflect on it in the form of notes. There are no shortcuts. 关于突出显示文本的问题，我会这样说：突出显示是不可取的。这不是集中阅读具有挑战性和复杂信息的好方法。对于具有挑战性的材料，最好投入所需的时间重新制定它，并以笔记的形式进行反思。没有捷径。

While highlighting does not possess the cognitive-development power of reformulating and reflecting on information, it is not “completely pointless,” as one cognitive scientist, Fiona McPherson, points out. The reason it’s not completely pointless is that highlighting books can have the helpful effect of forcing one to actually read the words.[107](#footnote-093) 虽然突出显示不具备重新表述和反思信息的认知发展能力，但正如一位认知科学家菲奥娜 · 麦克弗森 (Fiona McPherson) 指出的那样，它并非 “完全没有意义”。它并非完全没有意义的原因是突出显示书籍可以起到迫使人们真正阅读文字的有益效果。 107

But look at what the cognitive scientist is really admitting here. Her main point is that highlighting is not completely pointless; it’s just barely above completely pointless. In other words, it’s mostly pointless. 但是看看认知科学家在这里真正承认的是什么。她的主要观点是突出显示并非完全没有意义；它只是勉强高于完全没有意义。换句话说，它几乎毫无意义。

I’d advise you to stay away from the practice of highlighting. If the material is familiar to you, and especially if it’s complicated, highlighting won’t help much. Furthermore, research shows that highlighting may even “harm” your ability to recall information in certain scenarios.[108](#footnote-092) 我建议你远离突出显示的做法。如果材料对你来说很熟悉，特别是如果它很复杂，突出显示不会有太大帮助。此外，研究表明，突出显示甚至可能会 “损害” 您在某些情况下回忆信息的能力。 108

As McPherson observes, the main value of highlighting does not intrinsically add much value to your understanding of the material. Its main benefit centers on its ability to motivate one to spend more time with the material.[109](#footnote-091) This effect caused by spending more time with material will resurface throughout this book. Perhaps not so ironically, the reason the analog Zettelkasten outweighs the effectiveness of digital Zettelkasten is because the analog form forces users to spend more time developing thoughts. 正如 McPherson 所观察到的，突出显示的主要价值本质上并没有为您对材料的理解增加太多价值。它的主要好处在于它能够激励人们花更多时间阅读材料。109 这种因花更多时间阅读材料而产生的影响将在本书中再次出现。也许不那么讽刺，模拟 Zettelkasten 胜过数字 Zettelkasten 的有效性的原因是因为模拟形式迫使用户花更多的时间来发展思想。

**Direct Contradictions of Luhmann’s Teachings 卢曼教义的直接矛盾**

I’ve laid out several contradictions that have emerged within recent digital Zettelkasten teachings. Unfortunately, many more continue to rise to the surface. Some contradictions are even more severe than others. 我列出了最近数字 Zettelkasten 教学中出现的几个矛盾。不幸的是，还有更多的问题继续浮出水面。有些矛盾甚至比其他矛盾更严重。

There are also direct contradictions of Luhmann’s teachings. For instance, Luhmann calls the Zettelkasten a “universal instrument” which accepts any keyterm one wishes to create in the index.[110](#footnote-090) Even the simple, isolated basic keyterm of “Picasso” is fine, as Luhmann says, because it may unlock accidental insights.[111](#footnote-089) According to Luhmann, it’s more fruitful to create keyterms that generalize different things, and relate heterogeneous things to a larger theme or observation. More on this will be explained later in this book. However, we find Kadavy citing Ahrens on how one ought to select keyterms for tagging.[112](#footnote-088) Note that he cites Ahrens instead of the creator of the Zettelkasten, Niklas Luhmann. He then prescribes to the reader the following directive: “avoid generic keywords, such as ‘psychology’.” [113](#footnote-087) This directly conflicts with Luhmann describing the Zettelkasten as a “universal instrument” into which one can place almost any keyterm and get back unconventional insights. 卢曼的教义也有直接的矛盾。例如，Luhmann 将 Zettelkasten 称为 “通用工具”，它接受人们希望在索引中创建的任何关键词。110 即使是“Picasso” 这样简单、孤立的基本关键词也很好，正如 Luhmann 所说，因为它可能会解锁意外的见解。 111 根据 Luhmann 的说法，创建概括不同事物并将异质事物与更大的主题或观察联系起来的关键词会更有成效。本书稍后将对此进行更多解释。然而，我们发现 Kadavy 引用了 Ahrens 来说明人们应该如何选择用于标记的关键词。112 请注意，他引用了 Ahrens 而不是 Zettelkasten 的创建者 Niklas Luhmann。然后，他向读者规定了以下指示：“避免使用通用关键字，例如‘心理学’。” 113 这与卢曼将 Zettelkasten 描述为一种 “通用工具” 直接冲突，人们可以在其中放置几乎任何关键词并获得非常规的见解。

Unfortunately, those who accept such advice may never experience the magic and accidental insights generated by working with an analog thinking system. While the analog route may seem difficult at first, the alternative isn’t that nice and pretty. Furthermore, it’s rather vague. For instance, toward the end of Kadavy’s book on digital Zettelkasten, there’s a section that debates “linking vs. tagging vs. both.”[114](#footnote-086) Luhmann never found himself bothered with such drivel because, as I’ve already stated, the concept of tagging notes didn’t exist. Kadavy’s solution to this topic remains to be decided by the reader as he concludes, “there’s no right answer.” [115](#footnote-085) Actually, there is a right answer. Do what Luhmann did, and use an analog thinking system and stop worrying about such irrelevant things! 不幸的是，那些接受此类建议的人可能永远不会体验到使用模拟思维系统工作所产生的神奇和意外的见解。虽然模拟路线一开始可能看起来很困难，但替代方案并不是那么好。此外，它相当模糊。例如，在 Kadavy 关于数字 Zettelkasten 的书的结尾处，有一节讨论 “链接与标记还是两者兼而有之”。114 Luhmann 从来没有发现自己被这样的胡言乱语所困扰，因为正如我已经说过的那样，标记的概念笔记不存在。 Kadavy 对这个话题的解决方案仍有待读者决定，他总结道，“没有正确的答案。” 115 事实上，有一个正确的答案。做卢曼所做的，使用模拟思维系统，不要再担心这些无关紧要的事情了！

**Stripping Away The Importance of The Numeric-Alpha Card Addresses 剥离数字字母卡地址的重要性**

Within the Latter-day Ahrensian Zettelkasten school, there exists a more pernicious contradiction of the original form that promotes downplaying the importance of numeric-alpha card addresses. 在现代 Ahrensian Zettelkasten 学校中，存在一种与原始形式更有害的矛盾，这种矛盾促使人们淡化数字字母卡地址的重要性。

If you wish to take Luhmann seriously, then you must accept his notion that an alter ego arises out of an analog Zettelkasten. A ghost in the box arises in the form of a second mind (if you structure your analog Zettelkasten properly). This creates an entity that allows you to communicate with it in the first place. 如果你想认真对待卢曼，那么你必须接受他的观点，即另一个自我从模拟的 Zettelkasten 中产生。盒子里的鬼魂以第二个头脑的形式出现（如果你正确地构建你的模拟 Zettelkasten）。这将创建一个允许您首先与其通信的实体。

As Luhmann makes clear, the numeric-alpha card addresses are a key component that “makes possible its ability to communicate in the first place.”[116](#footnote-084) 正如 Luhmann 明确指出的那样，数字字母卡地址是 “首先使其能够进行通信的能力” 的关键组成部分。 116

It becomes, therefore, quite confusing when digital Zettelkasten proponents take a nonchalant approach to this concept—if they even decide to mention it at all, that is![117](#footnote-083) 因此，当数字 Zettelkasten 的支持者对这个概念采取漠不关心的态度时，它变得非常混乱——如果他们甚至决定完全提及它，那就是！ 117

For instance, Kadavy’s book that supposedly teaches digital Zettelkasten starts off the chapter on file identification with, “A big debate among Zettelkasten practitioners is file-naming convention.”[118](#footnote-082) In reality, there is no debate if one is to subscribe to the Zettelkasten in its truest form. Yet the author of this book carries on and lists out four options to choose from. 例如，据称教授数字 Zettelkasten 的 Kadavy 的书在文件识别一章的开头写道：“Zettelkasten 从业者之间的一场大辩论是文件命名约定。”118 实际上，如果一个人要在它最真实的形式。然而，本书的作者继续并列出了四个选项供您选择。

Here are the recommendations described by the author: 以下是作者描述的建议：

The first option this author lists is to use “phrases” in the filename. This practice is precisely what Luhmann says one should not do! Luhmann explicitly advises that the Zettelkasten must not rely on a structure that uses content-based order.[119](#footnote-081) 这位作者列出的第一个选项是在文件名中使用 “短语”。这种做法正是卢曼所说的不应该做的！ Luhmann 明确建议 Zettelkasten 不得依赖使用基于内容的顺序的结构。 119

The second option Kadavy lays out for IDs is that of an ugly date-timestamp number.[120](#footnote-080) This makes very little sense, as the magic of Zettelkasten revolves around the idea that you branch internally, in an infinite manner based on the idea—not the time and date in which that idea formed. Date-time IDs destroy the beauty of the numeric-alpha convention Luhmann used. It adds complicated bloat to something that is otherwise so simple.Kadavy 为 ID 设计的第二个选项是一个丑陋的日期时间戳数字。120 这没有什么意义，因为 Zettelkasten 的魔力围绕着你在内部分支的想法，以无限的方式基于这个想法——而不是该想法形成的时间和日期。日期时间 ID 破坏了 Luhmann 使用的数字字母约定的美感。它给本来很简单的东西增加了复杂的膨胀。

The third option for IDs Kadavy mentions is, in his words, “the most complicated naming convention.”[121](#footnote-079) He references the naming convention called Folgezettel. This is a term that has, for some odd reason, gained popularity amongst the new digital Zettelkasten school (note: Luhmann actually never used the term). What this term means is essentially an address affixed to each card that is numeric-alpha and that can be branched, and internally evolved (e.g. 2412/1A/1). I will not go into detail on this now, as it’s a core component of the Antinet and will be discussed in great length later on. The author goes on to declare it as “unnecessary” for building a digital Zettelkasten. But something that is even more unnecessary in a digital Zettelkasten is…the digital part!Kadavy 提到的 ID 的第三个选项，用他的话说，是 “最复杂的命名约定”。121 他提到了名为 Folgezettel 的命名约定。出于某种奇怪的原因，这个术语在新的数字 Zettelkasten 学校中流行起来（注意：卢曼实际上从未使用过该术语）。这个术语的意思本质上是贴在每张卡片上的地址，它是数字字母，可以分支，并且可以在内部进化（例如 2412/1A/1）。我现在不会详细介绍这个，因为它是 Antinet 的核心组件，稍后将详细讨论。作者继续宣称它对于构建数字 Zettelkasten 是 “不必要的”。但在数字 Zettelkasten 中更不需要的是…… 数字部分！

Where Kadavy goes from bad to worse, however, is in his misunderstanding of what numeric-alpha card addresses actually are. He states that it forces a “hierarchical arrangement of notes in a system supposed to be non-hierarchical.”[122](#footnote-078) This notion is absurd. Each note in the Antinet is like a leaf on a tree. Every leaf on a tree is of the same class as other leaves; they just live in a different location on the tree. As Johannes Schmidt points out “the position of a special subject or card says nothing of the theoretical importance of the card.” As far as hierarchy, “there’s no bottom and there’s no top.”[123](#footnote-077) Secondly, who stated that the Zettelkasten is “supposed to be non-hierarchical?” Even though an analog Zettelkasten (and its numeric-alpha card addresses) is not hierarchical (which the author gets wrong), the notion that a Zettelkasten is “supposed to be non-hierarchical” stands as a myth. 然而，Kadavy 变得越来越糟的地方在于他对数字字母卡地址的实际含义的误解。他指出，它强制 “在一个本应是非等级制度的系统中对笔记进行等级制度安排。”122 这个想法是荒谬的。 Antinet 中的每个音符就像树上的一片叶子。树上的每一片叶子都与其他叶子属于同一类；他们只是住在树上的不同位置。正如 Johannes Schmidt 指出的那样，“特殊主题或卡片的位置并不能说明卡片的理论重要性。” 就等级而言，“没有底部，也没有顶部。”123 其次，谁说 Zettelkasten “应该是无等级的？”尽管模拟 Zettelkasten（及其数字字母卡地址）不是分层的（作者弄错了），但 Zettelkasten“应该是非分层的”的概念仍然是一个神话。

Kadavy outlines the final option for how to identify one’s notes: use a combination of mixing up all three of these options.[124](#footnote-076) This is fine advice if you wish to spend your days reading and spinning your wheels in the mud trying to make use of what you’ve just read.Kadavy 概述了如何识别一个人的笔记的最后一个选项：使用混合所有这三个选项的组合。 124 如果你想花时间阅读和在泥泞中转动你的轮子试图利用什么，这是一个很好的建议你刚读过。

From this one starts to get a glimpse of how much of a mess the current landscape is for English-speaking people who dare do an internet search for the term “Zettelkasten.” Just as an illustration, if you end up searching for “Zettelkasten,” you end up with an 80% or greater chance of selecting an article that does not teach the ID system Luhmann used for his Zettelkasten (the numeric-alpha address version). 从这里开始，对于敢于在互联网上搜索 “Zettelkasten” 一词的讲英语的人来说，当前的情况是多么混乱。举个例子，如果你最终搜索“Zettelkasten”，你最终有 80% 或更高的机会选择一篇没有教授 Luhmann 用于他的 Zettelkasten 的 ID 系统（数字字母地址版本）的文章。

This misinformation continues to spread at a rapid pace. The availability cascade of inaccurate but simplistic Zettelkasten information exacerbates the issue, and it’s getting harder for potential users to grasp what the Zettelkasten system actually was, and is. 这种错误信息继续快速传播。不准确但简单的 Zettelkasten 信息的可用性级联加剧了这个问题，潜在用户越来越难以掌握 Zettelkasten 系统的实际情况。

**The Problem with Latter-Day Ahrensian Teachings 现代阿伦斯教义的问题**

The problem with the teachings of those basing their source material off of Sönke Ahrens’s publications is the fact that all of the subtleties and magic of the Zettelkasten are discarded. There exists a magic in building a pen-and-paper-based system, a communication partner, an alter-ego, a second mind. This type of system creates accidents and randomness that are invaluable. Its essence is watered down, if not altogether nuked by its digital, inbred, cousins. 那些以 Sönke Ahrens 的出版物为基础的原始资料的教义的问题在于，Zettelkasten 的所有微妙之处和魔力都被丢弃了。建立基于笔和纸的系统、沟通伙伴、另一个自我、第二个头脑是有魔力的。这种类型的系统会产生非常宝贵的事故和随机性。它的本质被淡化了，如果不是完全被它的数字、近亲繁殖的表兄弟所破坏的话。

It’s unfortunate that those who teach the Zettelkasten system have missed out on the true underlying magic of Luhmann’s system in its purest form. Going in search of the magic requires a person to be rather crazy (like yours truly). You must take a risk and purchase the materials required and go through the long slog of creating your own analog Zettelkasten (using only pen and notecards). Furthermore, it’s a lonely journey as there’s not much information out there about how to build an analog Zettelkasten (though hopefully I’ll help make the road less lonely). It’s also one that may be filled with missteps that are hard to correct given the fact that there’s no find-and-replace-all functionality. Yet it’s worth the investment. Sure, it’s unfortunate that these digital Zettelkasten teachers never discovered the true magic of Zettelkasten. But it’s more unfortunate that they end up unintentionally misleading others who may have otherwise put in the work to build a true Zettelkasten (if they had only known how it really works and what is to be gained by it). 不幸的是，那些教授 Zettelkasten 系统的人错过了卢曼系统最纯粹形式的真正潜在魔力。寻找魔法需要一个相当疯狂的人（就像你一样）。您必须冒险购买所需的材料，并经历创建您自己的模拟 Zettelkasten 的漫长过程（仅使用笔和记事卡）。此外，这是一个孤独的旅程，因为没有太多关于如何构建模拟 Zettelkasten 的信息（尽管希望我能帮助让这条路不那么孤独）。考虑到没有查找并替换所有功能，它也可能充满了难以纠正的失误。然而，这是值得的投资。当然，不幸的是，这些数字 Zettelkasten 教师从未发现 Zettelkasten 的真正魔力。但更不幸的是，他们最终无意中误导了其他人，这些人可能已经投入了建设真正的 Zettelkasten 的工作（如果他们只知道它的真正运作方式以及它能带来什么）。

**Why I Decided To Write a Book About the Zettelkasten 为什么我决定写一本关于 Zettelkasten 的书**
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Even though the information landscape pertaining to Zettelkasten is riddled with inaccurate information, it’s not the reason I decided to publish a book on the Zettelkasten. I mean, there’s a massive amount of misinformation in many other fields. The field I spent much time in several years ago was that of cryptocurrency. There are massive sums of inaccurate information in that field. Yet, this didn’t drive me to publish a book on cryptocurrency. Why? It’s simple. Because that audience is primarily filled with speculators who want to make money without lifting a finger. 尽管与 Zettelkasten 相关的信息领域充斥着不准确的信息，但这并不是我决定出版一本关于 Zettelkasten 的书的原因。我的意思是，在许多其他领域存在大量错误信息。几年前我花了大量时间的领域是加密货币。该领域存在大量不准确的信息。然而，这并没有促使我出版一本关于加密货币的书。为什么？这很简单。因为观众主要是想不费吹灰之力就能赚钱的投机者。

The reason I decided to publish my views and findings related to the Zettelkasten system stems from the following: 我决定发表与 Zettelkasten 系统相关的观点和发现的原因在于：

First, the misinformation connected with Luhmann’s Zettelkasten is multiplying due to the availability cascade phenomenon. 首先，由于可用性级联现象，与 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 相关的错误信息正在成倍增加。

Second, if I don’t write about what I’ve learned about Zettelkasten now (while my passion for it is still fresh), then I probably never will. 其次，如果我现在不写下我对 Zettelkasten 的了解（虽然我对它的热情还很新鲜），那么我可能永远不会写。

Third, and most importantly, I actually care about sharing this information because I care about the people who would potentially waste their lives learning the wrong methods and techniques to build a Zettelkasten. I believe that many people have, are, and will waste their precious life energy learning the ins-and-outs of digital apps instead of creating the genius-level work they’re capable of. 第三，也是最重要的一点，我实际上很关心分享这些信息，因为我关心那些可能会浪费生命学习错误的方法和技术来建造 Zettelkasten 的人。我相信很多人已经、正在并将浪费他们宝贵的生命能量来学习数字应用程序的来龙去脉，而不是创造他们能够完成的天才级工作。

Why do I care to publish my findings on the Zettelkasten? I’d like to think it’s because I’m a saint, and that it’s simply just the right thing to do. But seriously, I think the reason why I care about such people like yourself is because I was once in your shoes. 为什么我要在 Zettelkasten 上发表我的发现？我想这是因为我是圣人，而这只是正确的做法。但说真的，我想我之所以关心像你这样的人是因为我曾经站在你的立场上。

I very clearly recall the confusion I experienced and even the suffering I experienced from not knowing how to organize all the thoughts floating around in my head. 我非常清楚地记得我经历过的困惑，甚至是不知道如何组织脑海中飘荡的思绪所经历的痛苦。

I care to share with you what I’ve learned because I’ve seen the faces of those in the community of people who are eager to learn. When I took an online course on personal knowledge management, I interacted with people like you—people who are committed to growth and learning. That course humanized the need for the information I learned, and so too has interacting with people like yourself on my YouTube channel.[125](#footnote-075) 我愿意与您分享我所学到的东西，因为我看到了社区中那些渴望学习的人的面孔。当我参加关于个人知识管理的在线课程时，我与像你这样的人互动——他们致力于成长和学习。该课程使我对所学信息的需求变得人性化，在我的 YouTube 频道上与像您这样的人互动也是如此。 125

In brief, I’m publishing this book because as I’ve demonstrated, I believe the landscape of accurate information pertaining to the Zettelkasten system is bad and it’s getting worse, and it’s worth sharing my views with this community because the people it’s comprised of are people worth serving. 简而言之，我出版这本书是因为正如我所展示的那样，我相信与 Zettelkasten 系统有关的准确信息的情况很糟糕，而且情况越来越糟，值得与这个社区分享我的观点，因为它的组成人员是值得服务的人。

Now, before we get into the core of the Antinet, let’s first dive into the mind of its creator: Niklas Luhmann. Understanding the mind of its creator provides tremendous value in understanding the nature of what we’ll be building together: the Antinet Zettelkasten. 现在，在我们进入 Antinet 的核心之前，让我们先深入了解它的创造者：尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的思想。了解其创造者的思想对于理解我们将共同建造的东西的本质具有巨大的价值：Antinet Zettelkasten。

CHAPTER FOUR 第四回
----------------

Niklas Luhmann, The Man 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼，男人
------------------------------------

Before we begin diving into Niklas Luhmann’s notebox system, there’s one area worth first exploring: Niklas Luhmann, the man. That is, Luhmann’s background, his theories, his beliefs, and his attitudes. 在我们开始深入研究尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的笔记本系统之前，有一个领域值得首先探索：尼克拉斯 · 卢曼这个人。也就是卢曼的背景，他的理论，他的信仰，他的态度。

**Why It’s Important to Gain Familiarity with Niklas Luhmann 为什么熟悉尼克拉斯 · 卢曼很重要**
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The structure, spirit and personality of the Antinet carries imprints of its biggest contributor, Niklas Luhmann.Antinet 的结构、精神和个性带有其最大贡献者尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的印记。

The Antinet enables one to be “light of mind” amidst the complexity of knowledge. This type of state reflects Niklas Luhmann’s tendency toward being abstract, vague, trollishly carnivalesque and—at the same time— brilliant. The Antinet carries with it such a demeanor. It is one of order, disorder, absurdisms, and brilliance—yet the Antinet also contains imperfections. Its order is not perfect either. A system of perfect order is seen in the digital realm—with its deterministic, orderly execution of programs that subscribe to a uniform, predictable protocol. For a glimpse of imperfections and chaos, one need only review the archive of Luhmann’s notebox, or view his private home office.[126](#footnote-168) In brief, Luhmann’s theoretical work was not developed in an environment of pure order.Antinet 使一个人在知识的复杂性中成为 “思想之光”。这种状态反映了尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的抽象、模糊、狂欢狂欢的倾向，同时又很聪明。 Antinet 带有这样的风度。它是秩序、混乱、荒谬和辉煌的其中之一——然而 Antinet 也包含不完美之处。它的顺序也不完美。在数字领域可以看到一个完美秩序的系统——它确定性地、有序地执行订阅了统一、可预测协议的程序。要一窥不完美和混乱，人们只需查看卢曼笔记本的档案，或查看他的私人家庭办公室。 126 简而言之，卢曼的理论工作并不是在纯粹有序的环境中发展起来的。

Simply stated, the Antinet is not for OCD-individuals who can’t sleep at night unless their workflow follows some made-up atomic protocol.[127](#footnote-167) 简而言之，Antinet 不适用于那些晚上无法入睡的强迫症患者，除非他们的工作流程遵循某种虚构的原子协议。 127

Because Luhmann’s writing was so dry and complex, it leads to confusion and misinterpretations of what his system actually is. This confusion of what a Zettelkasten actually is continues to spread to this day. 由于卢曼的写作是如此枯燥和复杂，这导致了对他的系统实际上是什么的混淆和误解。这种对 Zettelkasten 究竟是什么的困惑一直持续到今天。

Up until now, those who desired to understand Luhmann’s Zettelkasten in its purest form were faced with disentangling the prose of Luhmann’s paper “Communication with Noteboxes.” This paper took me about three weeks to read and extract into my own Antinet. I spent almost six days a week doing this; I then spent another month doing the same with Johannes Schmidt’s paper on Luhmann’s Zettelkasten, and another month perusing the digital Zettelkasten archives. 直到现在，那些想要以最纯粹的形式理解卢曼的 Zettelkasten 的人都面临着解开卢曼论文 “与记事本的交流” 的散文。这篇论文花了我大约三个星期的时间阅读并提取到我自己的 Antinet 中。我几乎每周花六天时间做这件事；然后我又花了一个月的时间对 Johannes Schmidt 关于 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的论文进行了同样的处理，又花了一个月的时间仔细阅读 Zettelkasten 的数字档案。

Like Luhmann’s books and papers, he left his Zettelkasten system to be understood only by those who invest the time and energy into disentangling his prose. Most people have not done this. As a result they’ve been left with a surface-level understanding of what he built. However, if you venture deeper and dig into what Luhmann really said, one discovers the system to be quite profound.[128](#footnote-166) 就像卢曼的书籍和论文一样，他留下了他的 Zettelkasten 系统，只有那些投入时间和精力来解开他的散文的人才能理解。大多数人没有这样做过。结果，他们对他建造的东西只剩下了表面的了解。然而，如果你更深入地探究卢曼真正说过的话，就会发现这个系统非常深奥。 128

**A Brief Background of Niklas Luhmann 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的简要背景**
-------------------------------------------------------

Niklas Luhmann was born in Lüneburg, Germany on December 8, 1927. He was the son of a brewer, though Luhmann himself was disinterested in drinking.[129](#footnote-165)Drinking beer at festivals and the local Biergarten was (and still is) seen as “a social virtue” in Germany.[130](#footnote-164) Abstaining from such events, which offered invaluable networking opportunities, likely contributed to Luhmann becoming an outsider. This also created a barrier to his advancement in his early career as a civil servant, working for the government. 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 于 1927 年 12 月 8 日出生于德国吕讷堡。他是酿酒师的儿子，尽管卢曼本人对饮酒不感兴趣。129 在节日和当地的啤酒花园里喝啤酒曾（现在仍然）被视为 “一种社会美德” ” 在德国。 130 此类活动提供了宝贵的交流机会，但不参加这些活动可能导致卢曼成为局外人。这也阻碍了他作为公务员在政府工作的早期职业生涯的晋升。

According to Luhmann’s youngest son, Clemens, Luhmann avoided drinking alcohol throughout his life. Yet, on very, very rare occasions, Luhmann would drink alcohol. When he did it was one glass of red wine. According to Clemens, the reason his father avoided alcohol was simply this: he didn’t want to appear stupid![131](#footnote-163) 据卢曼的小儿子克莱门斯说，卢曼一生都在戒酒。然而，在非常非常罕见的情况下，卢曼会喝酒。当他这样做时，是一杯红酒。根据克莱门斯的说法，他父亲不喝酒的原因很简单：他不想显得愚蠢！131

Back to young Luhmann: After a year working at the Lüneburg Higher Administration Court, Luhmann took another bureaucratic job in Hanover, Germany. After a year there, and after “problems had arisen, especially in the area of Nazi reparations,” Luhmann took a different job at the Lower Saxony Ministry of Culture.[132](#footnote-162) 回到年轻的卢曼：在吕讷堡高级行政法院工作一年后，卢曼在德国汉诺威从事另一份官僚工作。在那里待了一年之后，在 “出现了问题，尤其是在纳粹赔偿领域” 之后，卢曼在下萨克森文化部找到了一份不同的工作。 132

It soon became clear Luhmann did not wish to be a mere government employee. He desired an easy job where he could immediately go home at five o’clock sharp. He desired this type of work-life balance so that he could pursue his true passions in the evenings. When asked by an interviewer what those true passions were, Luhmann replied that his interests at night revolved around two things: first, reading books, and second, his notebox system (that is, his Antinet). 很快就清楚了，卢曼不希望仅仅成为一名政府雇员。他想要一份轻松的工作，他可以​​在五点整立即回家。他渴望这种工作与生活的平衡，这样他就可以在晚上追求他真正的激情。当一位采访者问及那些真正的激情是什么时，卢曼回答说他晚上的兴趣围绕着两件事：第一，读书，第二，他的记事本系统（即他的 Antinet）。

During this time Luhmann recalls that he “read a lot.”[133](#footnote-161) He read sociology and philosophy—mainly Descartes and Husserl. In sociology, he was absorbed by a concept that would stand as a core component of his social theoretical work. The concept is called functionalism. One can browse the notes from those readings in Luhmann’s online archive.[134](#footnote-160) 卢曼回忆说，在这段时间里，他 “读了很多书”。133 他读了社会学和哲学——主要是笛卡尔和胡塞尔。在社会学中，他被一个概念所吸引，这个概念将成为他社会理论工作的核心组成部分。这个概念被称为功能主义。人们可以在卢曼的在线档案中浏览这些阅读材料中的笔记。 134

Yet Luhmann spent most of his time in the evenings working with his Antinet. He did this “above all” other activities.[135](#footnote-159) 然而，卢曼大部分时间都在晚上用他的 Antinet 工作。他做这 “高于一切” 其他活动。 135

Luhmann’s paradise was reading and conversing with the greatest minds of humanity. He would read philosophy and sociology, and then reformulate and reflect on the readings by expressing them on paper via writing by hand with a pen. After this he would install into his Antinet the thoughts from these conversations between him and the author he was reading. 卢曼的天堂是阅读和与人类最伟大的思想交谈。他会阅读哲学和社会学，然后通过用笔手写在纸上表达来重新表述和反思阅读材料。在此之后，他会将他和他正在阅读的作者之间的这些对话中的想法安装到他的 Antinet 中。

Yet one day, early in his career, Luhmann’s paradise would come under attack. His job became more demanding. Nights spent with his books and his Antinet were “no longer possible with growing tasks.”[136](#footnote-158) 然而有一天，在他职业生涯的早期，卢曼的天堂会受到攻击。他的工作变得更加苛刻。与他的书和他的 Antinet 一起度过的夜晚 “随着任务的增加而不再可能。”136

One day a senior member of his company sat Luhmann down. Hoping to advise Luhmann and help advance Luhmann’s career as a civil servant, he proffered some advice. “You should look into doing some extracurricular volunteering, and work in a district.” Luhmann replied that he wouldn’t. “Why?” the senior employee asked. Luhmann replied, “I am reading Hölderlin.”[137](#footnote-157) Luhmann was referring to Friedrich Hölderlin, a German philosopher and poet. It was a higher priority for Luhmann to expand his mind than to expand his career prospects playing the conventional games of bureaucratic advancement. A short while later, Luhmann would leave the government job and attend Harvard University. 一天，他公司的一位高级成员让卢曼坐下来。希望为卢曼提供建议并帮助推进卢曼的公务员职业生涯，他提供了一些建议。 “你应该考虑做一些课外志愿服务，并在一个地区工作。” 卢曼回答说他不会。 “为什么？” 老员工问道。卢曼回答说：“我在读荷尔德林。”137 卢曼指的是德国哲学家和诗人弗里德里希荷尔德林。对于卢曼来说，开阔视野比玩传统的官僚晋升游戏来扩大职业前景更为重要。不久之后，卢曼将辞去政府工作并进入哈佛大学就读。

A brief lesson can be learned from this important point: Luhmann’s vocation 从这一重要观点可以得出一个简短的教训：卢曼的职业

was reading, thinking, and writing. He turned his vocation into his vacation. The Antinet did not serve Luhmann as a tool to replace this line of work; instead, it was a tool to aid and enhance it. 是阅读、思考和写作。他把他的职业变成了他的假期。 Antinet 并没有成为卢曼取代这一行的工具；相反，它是一种帮助和增强它的工具。

Later on in life, when Luhmann did finally get his dream job working as a professor at Bielefeld University, he was able to spend his time doing what he loved: reading, thinking, and writing. At that point Luhmann didn’t desire fame from his work. He didn’t desire wealth or riches so that he could spend days bronzing on Caribbean beaches. He instead desired one thing: “more time.”[138](#footnote-156) 在后来的生活中，当卢曼终于在比勒费尔德大学找到了他梦想中的教授职位时，他能够把时间花在做他喜欢做的事情上：阅读、思考和写作。那时，卢曼并不希望从他的作品中获得名声。他不渴望财富或财富，这样他就可以在加勒比海滩上度过数天的古铜色。相反，他想要一件事：“更多时间。”138

Luhmann desired more time so he could spend it doing more of what he loved: reading, writing, and working. When asked of his ultimate Utopia, Luhmann replied, “I could imagine that for me, the day has thirty hours.”[139](#footnote-155) He wanted thirty-hour-long days spent mostly reading, writing, and thinking. 卢曼想要更多的时间，这样他就可以花更多的时间做他喜欢做的事情：阅读、写作和工作。当被问及他的终极乌托邦时，卢曼回答说：“我可以想象，对我来说，一天有三十个小时。”139 他想要三十个小时的日子主要用于阅读、写作和思考。

As for Luhmann’s family life, in 1960 at the age of thirty three, Luhmann married his wife, Ursula. They had three children together and a nice life. Sadly, she died in 1977, when Luhmann was fifty years old. After she died, Luhmann never married again. He had a caretaker cook meals and help him take care of his three children. This enabled Luhmann to focus and continue spending time on his true passions: reading and his Antinet. 至于卢曼的家庭生活，1960 年，33 岁的卢曼与妻子厄休拉结婚。他们一起生了三个孩子，过着美好的生活。遗憾的是，她于 1977 年去世，当时卢曼 50 岁。她死后，卢曼再也没有结婚。他有一个看门人做饭，帮助他照顾他的三个孩子。这使卢曼能够专注并继续花时间在他真正的激情上：阅读和他的 Antinet。

Luhmann’s professional life was a successful one—albeit a rather quiet one. He is referred to as “the most important German sociologist in the twentieth century.”[140](#footnote-154) Yet he lived a rather simple lifestyle. His routine and workflow will be covered later in the book. His life revolved around his intellectual pursuits. His life was dedicated to his grand theory of everything as it pertains to society. 卢曼的职业生涯是成功的——尽管相当平静。他被称为 “二十世纪最重要的德国社会学家”。140 然而，他过着相当简单的生活方式。他的例程和工作流程将在本书后面介绍。他的生活围绕着他的知识追求。他的一生致力于他关于与社会有关的一切事物的宏大理论。

Luhmann’s publication footprint is sizable and impressive. The “sheer number [of publications] is unprecedented,” writes one scholar.[141](#footnote-153) Luhmann produced 550 academic papers and seventy books in approximately forty years.[142](#footnote-152) In his literary estate, Johannes Schmidt uncovered three thousand manuscripts, two hundred of which were previously unpublished.[143](#footnote-151) As Schmidt puts it, Luhmann was (with the help of his Antinet) “a publication machine.”[144](#footnote-150) 卢曼的出版足迹相当庞大且令人印象深刻。一位学者写道：“[出版物] 的绝对数量是前所未有的。”141 卢曼在大约四十年的时间里发表了 550 篇学术论文和 70 本书。142 在他的文学庄园中，约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 发现了三千份手稿，其中两百份以前未出版. 143 正如施密特所说，卢曼（在他的 Antinet 的帮助下）是 “一台出版机器”。 144

**Luhmann’s Philosophical and Political Views 卢曼的哲学和政治观点**
----------------------------------------------------------

Luhmann was misconceived to be a conservative, right-wing thinker because he debated Jürgen Habermas, a popular left-wing liberal ideologue. Those who attended the event say Luhmann dismantled Habermas’s positions, which resulted in Luhmann becoming “rather famous” in Germany.[145](#footnote-149) 卢曼被误认为是一名保守的右翼思想家，因为他与广受欢迎的左翼自由主义理论家于尔根 · 哈贝马斯 (Jürgen Habermas) 进行了辩论。参加此次活动的人说，卢曼推翻了哈贝马斯的立场，这导致卢曼在德国变得 “相当有名”。 145

Yet Luhmann was not a right-wing conservative. His views could be likened to a laissez faire approach to politics and the economy. He could more be likened to a Libertarian (to use American political terminology). Luhmann was an ironic character with a stoic demeanor. So too were his political positions. Perhaps a better description of Luhmann’s political position could be that of absurdism, with a trend toward being carnivalesque. Luhmann’s philosophical views were a unique blend of stoicism, Spinozism, and Daoism.[146](#footnote-148) He was always careful to not fall into the trap of moralizing issues, and practiced being one step removed from established positions on matters. He desired to avoid the trap of dogmatism, which first starts with a strong belief in one side being good, and the other side being bad. Luhmann spent a lot of time disciplining his mind so that it could always remain one thing: detached. 然而，卢曼并不是右翼保守派。他的观点可以比作对政治和经济的自由放任态度。他更像是一个自由主义者（使用美国政治术语）。卢曼是一个具有讽刺意味的人物，有着坚忍的风度。他的政治立场也是如此。也许对卢曼的政治立场更好的描述是荒诞主义，有一种狂欢的倾向。卢曼的哲学观点是斯多葛主义、斯宾诺莎主义和道家主义的独特结合。 146 他总是小心翼翼地避免陷入道德化问题的陷阱，并实践了在事情上远离既定立场的一步。他希望避免教条主义的陷阱，教条主义首先是坚信一方是好的，另一方是坏的。卢曼花了很多时间训练自己的思想，让它始终保持一件事：超然。

photo credit: “Carnivalesque Luhmann,” accessed January 25, 2022 [https://miro.medium.com/max/940/0*eMW-vEwe5E56raEs.jpg](https://miro.medium.com/max/940/0*eMW-vEwe5E56raEs.jpg) 照片来源：“Carnivalesque Luhmann”，2022 年 1 月 25 日访问 https://miro.medium.com/max/940/0*eMW-vEwe5E56raEs.jpg

As one author puts it, “[Luhmann was] quite disturbed by ideological attempts at taking democracy too seriously and thought that such attempts may paradoxically pose a danger for its existence.”[147](#footnote-147) 正如一位作者所说，“[卢曼] 对过于认真对待民主的意识形态尝试感到非常不安，并认为这种尝试可能自相矛盾地对其存在构成危险。”147

The same could be said of Luhmann’s views toward nationalism (or “love for one’s country,” as some would deem it). In his opinion, passion could turn into dogma, which then could turn into storming the United States Capitol. Having learned from a childhood experience (which will be revealed shortly), Luhmann was quite reticent about allowing dogma to influence his thinking. Thus, he remained disciplined in a rational, detached thinking style. This is worth noting because it would have been quite easy for him to have gone a different route. One of Luhmann’s greatest influences, Georg Hegel, was quite an enthusiastic ideologue.[148](#footnote-146) It would be easy to conceive of Luhmann trying to further the ideologies of his mentor; yet, he did not do such a thing. 卢曼对民族主义（或某些人认为的 “爱国”）的看法也是如此。在他看来，激情可能会变成教条，然后可能会变成冲击美国国会大厦。从童年经历中吸取教训（很快就会揭晓），卢曼对让教条影响他的思想非常谨慎。因此，他保持着理性、超然的思维方式。这一点值得注意，因为他很容易走另一条路。对卢曼影响最大的人之一，格奥尔格 · 黑格尔 (Georg Hegel) 是一位相当热情的理论家。148 很容易想象卢曼试图进一步推进他导师的意识形态；然而，他并没有这样做。

Of what can be said of Luhmann’s religious views remains rather brief: he was not very religious.[149](#footnote-145) 关于卢曼的宗教观点，可以说的内容仍然相当简短：他不是很虔诚。 149

**Luhmann’s Theoretical Concepts 卢曼的理论概念**
------------------------------------------

There are a series of concepts that continually resurface in Luhmann’s writings. These concepts were of great importance to his work, and they will be covered in further detail throughout the book. 卢曼的著作中不断出现一系列概念。这些概念对他的工作非常重要，将在整本书中进一步详细介绍。

One of Luhmann’s cornerstone concepts revolves around communication. One of his more frequently quoted statements suggests that “Humans cannot communicate; not even their brains can communicate; not even their conscious minds can communicate. Only communication can communicate.”[150](#footnote-144) 卢曼的基石概念之一围绕沟通展开。他更常被引用的陈述之一表明 “人类无法交流；甚至他们的大脑也无法交流；甚至他们的意识也无法交流。只有沟通才能沟通。”150

In light of this, it’s worth considering that the Antinet revolves around communication. Ideas communicate through being stored in contextual branches and stems of thoughts. The ideas also communicate with one another through remote linking to other leaves of thought in the internally-constructed tree of knowledge. 鉴于此，值得考虑的是 Antinet 围绕通信展开。想法通过存储在上下文分支和思想干中进行交流。这些想法还通过远程链接到内部构建的知识树中的其他思想叶子来相互交流。

Communication was not only a pillar of Luhmann’s theoretical work; it also stands as a pillar of his Antinet. This is why Luhmann titled his paper, “Communication with Noteboxes” [emphasis mine]. 传播不仅是卢曼理论工作的支柱，也是卢曼理论工作的支柱。它也是他的 Antinet 的支柱。这就是为什么卢曼将他的论文命名为 “与记事本通信”[强调我的]。

Another cornerstone of Luhmann’s theoretical work is systems theory. This relates to the field of cybernetics and self-referential systems, which houses itself in the term autopoeiesis.[151](#footnote-143) This concept is a very interesting one. It’s a biological concept that Luhmann applied to social sciences. Later on in the book, I’ll unpack these concepts and explain them in further detail. 卢曼理论工作的另一个基石是系统论。这与控制论和自我参照系统领域有关，它们属于自创生一词。151 这个概念非常有趣。这是卢曼应用于社会科学的生物学概念。在本书的后面，我将解开这些概念并进行更详细的解释。

**Systems Theory 2.0 系统理论 2.0**

Luhmann’s take on systems theory was not conventional. It could be better likened to systems theory 2.0. 卢曼对系统理论的看法并不传统。它可以更好地比作系统理论 2.0。

Systems theory 1.0 revolves around the mereological notion of whole-parttheory. In this model, the system equals the whole. The parts are like organs in a body yet are thought of as more modular and static in nature. When you think of systems theory 1.0, think simple input-output machines (like a vending machine). You put a dollar in, and it spits out a snack (assuming it doesn’t get stuck)! 系统理论 1.0 围绕整体 - 部分理论的分体概念展开。在这个模型中，系统等于整体。这些部分就像身体中的器官，但在本质上被认为更加模块化和静态。当您想到系统理论 1.0 时，请想到简单的输入输出机器（如自动售货机）。你投入一美元，它会吐出零食（假设它没有卡住）！

Systems theory 2.0 finds itself in a world of complex interdependent subsystems. Complexity serves as a cornerstone of Luhmann’s theoretical work and as such it strongly influenced his notion of systems. The ‘system’, in Luhmann’s systems theory 2.0, consists of an internal environment that houses subsystems. The ‘parts’ are actually subsystems, each with their own complex processes and interactions with their environment. Whereas the parts in systems theory 1.0 are thought of as modular and static organs, the parts in systems theory 2.0 are themselves systems, like the cardiovascular system and immune system in a human body. The parts are essentially their own complex systems, which are comprised of their own complex systems, which are comprised of their own complex systems, and on and on. It’s essentially one big complex fractal of systems and subsystems. 系统理论 2.0 发现自己处于一个复杂的相互依赖的子系统世界中。复杂性是卢曼理论工作的基石，因此它强烈影响了他的系统概念。在卢曼的系统理论 2.0 中，“系统” 由容纳子系统的内部环境组成。 “部分” 实际上是子系统，每个子系统都有自己的复杂过程以及与环境的交互。系统论 1.0 中的部分被认为是模块化和静态的器官，而系统论 2.0 中的部分本身就是系统，例如人体的心血管系统和免疫系统。这些部分本质上是它们自己的复杂系统，它们由它们自己的复杂系统组成，而这些复杂系统又由它们自己的复杂系统组成，等等。它本质上是系统和子系统的一个大的复杂分形。

Systems theory 2.0 suggests that the environment of the subsystems is provided by other systems: “Within a complex system, such as the human body, there are a large number of subsystems that mutually provide the environment for one another.”[152](#footnote-142) One scholar observes that Luhmann’s work in systems theory raises the question of whether it should be more appropriately named, “system-environment theory.”[153](#footnote-141) 系统理论 2.0 表明子系统的环境由其他系统提供：“在一个复杂的系统中，例如人体，有大量的子系统相互提供环境。”152 一位学者指出，卢曼在系统理论方面的工作提出了一个问题，即是否应该将其命名为 “系统 - 环境理论” 更为恰当。 153

In the world of the Antinet, the subsystems are essentially contextual stems of thought that form around notes. Each of these subsystems cluster together to form themselves as a subsystem. They also can link to and connect with other subsystems in remote parts of the Antinet. These clusters of subsystems create an internal environment in the Antinet that mirrors the chain-linked structure of how human memory works. 在 Antinet 的世界中，子系统本质上是围绕音符形成的上下文思想主干。这些子系统中的每一个都聚集在一起，形成一个子系统。它们还可以链接到 Antinet 远程部分的其他子系统。这些子系统集群在 Antinet 中创建了一个内部环境，该环境反映了人类记忆如何工作的链式结构。

Luhmann devised radical theories that were not conventional and that were not based on classic sociological concepts. As mentioned previously, Luhmann’s intellectual rival, Jürgen Habermas, aimed for his theoretical work to “improve society by making it communicate more rationally.”[154](#footnote-140) Habermas subscribed to Karl Marx’s famous dictum that philosophy and theory must not merely analyze the world; it must set out to change it.[155](#footnote-139) 卢曼设计了一些激进的理论，这些理论不是传统的，也不是基于经典的社会学概念。如前所述，卢曼的知识分子竞争对手于尔根 · 哈贝马斯 (Jürgen Habermas) 的理论工作旨在 “通过使社会更理性地交流来改善社会”。154 哈贝马斯赞同卡尔 · 马克思的著名格言，即哲学和理论不仅要分析世界，而且要分析世界。它必须着手改变它。 155

Luhmann thought such notions futile. In his opinion, ideology packed into theory and science result in bad science—namely, confirmation bias. His opinion was colored by the social unrest of the time (1968), and the tendency of packing ideological political agendas into sociological theories. 卢曼认为这样的想法是徒劳的。在他看来，将意识形态塞进理论和科学会导致糟糕的科学——即确认偏差。他的观点受到当时（1968 年）社会动荡的影响，以及将意识形态政治议程纳入社会学理论的趋势。

Luhmann sought to de-anthropocentrize sociology by exploring what the field would look like if it did not revolve around people. Rather, he conceived a social system centered on concepts and systems. Luhmann called his theoretical work “radically anti-humanist,” and “radically anti-regionalist.”[156](#footnote-138) 卢曼试图通过探索如果社会学不以人为中心的领域会是什么样子，从而使社会学去人类中心化。相反，他构想了一个以概念和系统为中心的社会系统。卢曼称他的理论著作为 “彻底的反人道主义者” 和“彻底的反区域主义者”。 156

By anti-humanist, Luhmann was not implying that he was against human beings. Rather, he held that anthropocentric models of reality are “unfit to theoretically describe and analyze communication.”[157](#footnote-137) By anti-regionalist, Luhmann desired for his theoretical work to be like mathematics; i.e., a science that works across cultures. For example, math works in Japan, and it works just the same in America. 卢曼所说的反人道主义者并不意味着他反对人类。相反，他认为以人类为中心的现实模型 “不适合从理论上描述和分析交流”。157 作为反区域主义者，卢曼希望他的理论工作像数学一样；即，一门跨文化的科学。例如，数学在日本行得通，在美国也行得通。

These terms, anti-humanism and anti-regionalist provide a nice summary of Luhmann’s thought.[158](#footnote-136) The terms are rather alarming at first; yet, when you peel away the layers and truly understand what they mean, they’re rather concise and quite profound. 反人道主义和反区域主义这些术语很好地总结了卢曼的思想。158 这些术语起初相当令人震惊；然而，当你剥开层层，真正理解它们的意思时，它们是相当简洁和深刻的。

After conducting a comprehensive analysis of Luhmann’s work, one scholar labeled his theories as metabiological. “Just as Greek metaphysics explained the world beyond the physical by applying physical concepts,” one scholar writes, “Luhmann applied biological concepts for a descriptive analysis of the nonbiological world and, in particular, society and communication.”[159](#footnote-135) In sum, Luhmann’s theoretical work was deep, radical, and widely researched, spanning many disciplinary fields. By understanding this, one begins to understand why he structured the Antinet the way he did. It allowed him to link together and pull from many sources to illustrate his ideas in great depth. 在对卢曼的工作进行了全面分析之后，一位学者将他的理论标记为元生物学。 “正如希腊形而上学通过应用物理概念解释物理之外的世界，” 一位学者写道，“卢曼应用生物学概念对非生物世界，特别是社会和交流进行描述性分析。”159 总之，卢曼的理论工作深入，激进，研究广泛，跨越许多学科领域。通过理解这一点，人们开始理解他为什么按照他的方式构建 Antinet。它使他能够将许多资源联系在一起并从中汲取灵感，以深入说明他的想法。
