Understanding this provides ideas for how you yourself may wish to apply such a methodology to your own disciplinary field. You are undoubtedly unique in the way you think, and in your understanding of the material from which you pull ideas together. The Antinet serves as a fantastic system to assemble this wide-ranging material in such a way to make it more straightforward so as to communicate thoughts from your own uniquely genius ways of thinking. 理解这一点可以为您自己如何将这种方法应用于您自己的学科领域提供想法。毫无疑问，您在思考方式以及对从中汲取灵感的材料的理解方面是独一无二的。 Antinet 是一个奇妙的系统，可以将这些范围广泛的材料以一种更直接的方式组合起来，以便从您自己独特的天才思维方式中交流思想。

**Luhmann, The Troll 卢曼，巨魔**
----------------------------

Luhmann was polite, respectful, and sharp; yet he was also a trollish, ironical character. 卢曼彬彬有礼、恭敬而且敏锐。但他也是一个古怪的、讽刺的角色。

One scholar describes Luhmann’s writing style as using “dry, technical, and conceptual language frequently interspersed with bits of sarcasm, satire, and parody.”[160](#footnote-134) 一位学者将卢曼的写作风格描述为使用 “枯燥的、技术性的和概念性的语言，经常夹杂着讽刺、讽刺和戏仿。”160

**Instances of Luhmann’s Trollishness 卢曼的 Trollishness 实例**

Luhmann’s work tends to provoke others and give off a trollish air; yet upon closer review, it packs wisdom and poses very good points. 卢曼的作品往往会激怒他人，散发出一种古怪的气息；然而，经过仔细审查，它包含了智慧并提出了非常好的观点。

As mentioned, Luhmann held that society is composed of internal subsystems that can affect one another (as they’re related)—like the way a human body includes the cardiovascular system and immune system. He likens these to the economic system and political system. 如前所述，卢曼认为社会由内部子系统组成，这些子系统可以相互影响（因为它们是相关的）——就像人体包括心血管系统和免疫系统一样。他把这些比作经济制度和政治制度。

However, Luhmann also held that the subsystems themselves cannot control one another. Therefore, organizations like the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the G8 Summit, which deem themselves to have influence and control over the economic system function, in Luhmann’s view, in a similar way to the members of tribal groups who do rain dance rituals. This, according to Luhmann, helps the tribe “spread the impression that something is being done rather than merely waiting until things change by themselves.”[161](#footnote-133) 然而，卢曼也认为子系统本身不能相互控制。因此，在卢曼看来，国际货币基金组织 (IMF) 和 G8 峰会等自认为对经济体系具有影响力和控制权的组织的运作方式类似于进行雨舞仪式的部落成员. Luhmann 认为，这有助于部落 “传播正在做某事的印象，而不是仅仅等待事情自行改变。”161

That Luhmann posed such an idea was quite the controversial thing to do. The notion is quite unsettling, especially for the members of the IMF and G8 Summit who might come across this assertion. 卢曼提出这样一个想法是一件很有争议的事情。这个概念相当令人不安，特别是对于可能会遇到这种说法的国际货币基金组织和八国集团峰会的成员而言。

Luhmann, however, was not presenting this notion to divide and humiliate the people and members of the IMF and G8 Summit (or the tribal members who dance for rain). He is not claiming they’re irrational or silly, or that such things should be abolished. Rather, what Luhmann asserted is that such organizations serve a function in modern society, just as they did in tribal society. They provide optimism and hope to its members. Even if the organizations cannot control the future, they give its citizens the impression they do, which provides optimism for people to press forward.[162](#footnote-132) 然而，卢曼提出这一概念并不是为了分裂和羞辱国际货币基金组织和八国集团峰会的人民和成员（或为雨而舞的部落成员）。他并不是说他们不合理或愚蠢，或者应该废除这些事情。相反，卢曼所断言的是，这些组织在现代社会中发挥着作用，就像它们在部落社会中所做的那样。他们为其成员提供乐观和希望。即使这些组织无法控制未来，它们也会给公民留下他们可以控制未来的印象，这为人们提供了向前推进的乐观情绪。 162

Although Luhmann introduced radical notions (even at the expense of offending established institutions), he was described as distanced, but “extremely polite.”[163](#footnote-131) 尽管卢曼引入了激进的观念（甚至以冒犯既有机构为代价），但他被描述为与世隔绝，但 “非常有礼貌。”163

Luhmann would politely wait for people to finish making their point, no matter how confused or absurd the question was. Instead of flatly telling a person that they were wrong, Luhmann’s replies were softer in manner: “Of course you can do it that way,” Luhmann would start, “but I would prefer to start with a different distinction.” Luhmann was very polite in delivering his message, yet he was also very clear and precise. 卢曼会礼貌地等待人们说完他们的观点，无论这个问题多么令人困惑或荒谬。卢曼没有直截了当地告诉一个人他们错了，而是以更温和的方式回答：“当然你可以那样做，” 卢曼会开始说，“但我更愿意从不同的区别开始。” 卢曼在传达信息时非常有礼貌，但也非常清晰准确。

**The Ironic, Carnivalesque Side of Luhmann 卢曼讽刺的、狂欢的一面**

The philosophy underneath the foundation of Luhmann’s troll-like ironic and smirky demeanor can be described as something I mentioned earlier: he tended toward the absurdist and carnivalesque. 卢曼巨魔般的讽刺和坏笑的举止背后的哲学可以描述为我之前提到的东西：他倾向于荒诞主义和狂欢。

Yet the result of being an absurdist does not connote becoming filled with despair (after accepting the notion that life and reality are absurd, even pointless). Rather, the reasonable reaction is to be filled with a lightness, knowing that the world’s complexity is something uncontrollable and unknowable. One may even feel a sense of joy in knowing this. 然而，成为荒诞主义者的结果并不意味着充满绝望（在接受生活和现实荒谬甚至毫无意义的观念之后）。相反，合理的反应是充满轻松，知道世界的复杂性是无法控制和不可知的。知道这一点，人们甚至会感到一种喜悦。

Enlightenment thinkers were not of the type to accept such notions. They possessed comparatively serious dispositions—“Cartesian scientific ‘certainty’”—with regard to their beliefs in right and wrong. Yet when one adopts a more open, curious, and awe-filled view of the absurd complexities that compose reality, one can achieve a lightness of being.[164](#footnote-130) 启蒙思想家不是那种接受这种观念的人。他们在对与错的信念方面具有相对严肃的倾向——“笛卡尔式的科学‘确定性’”。然而，当一个人对构成现实的荒谬复杂性采取更加开放、好奇和充满敬畏的观点时，就可以实现一种轻松的存在。 164

Irony is the art and science of paradoxes, that is, dichotomies that arise in our perceptions of truth. Irony is when something is, at the same time, and to the same extent, both serious and not serious—both valid and invalid. It’s when something makes sense, and at the same time, it also “makes nonsense.”[165](#footnote-129) Luhmann’s theories, and even the Antinet itself, can be reflected in this notion. Here rests a system that enables one to be a publication machine by slowing down. It rapidly produces large amounts of well-formed text by undertaking the comparatively non-rapid process of writing thoughts by hand. Like Luhmann’s theories, the Antinet is rather ironic and paradoxical in nature. 反讽是悖论的艺术和科学，即我们对真理的看法中出现的二分法。具有讽刺意味的是，当某事在同一时间并在同一程度上既严肃又不严肃——既有效又无效。它是当某件事有意义的时候，同时，它也 “胡说八道”。165 卢曼的理论，甚至 Antinet 本身，都可以在这个概念中得到体现。这里有一个系统，可以通过放慢速度使人成为出版机器。它通过进行相对非快速的手写思想过程来快速生成大量格式正确的文本。与卢曼的理论一样，Antinet 具有讽刺意味和自相矛盾的性质。

**Luhmann, The Beatles Fan? 卢曼，披头士乐队的粉丝？**

Luhmann wasn’t just a pedantic academic with a certain trollish predisposition. He was plugged in and ‘in-touch’ with popular culture. 卢曼不仅仅是一个带有某种古怪倾向的迂腐学者。他被插入并 “接触” 了流行文化。

For instance, he would use lyrics from The Beatles to illustrate his points (citing “Everybody’s got something to hide, except me and my monkey” and “Your inside is out, and your outside is in”). He used such quotes to illustrate the social unrest movement of 1968.[166](#footnote-128) 例如，他会用甲壳虫乐队的歌词来说明他的观点（引用 “每个人都有隐藏的东西，除了我和我的猴子” 和“你的内心在外面，你的外面在里面”）。他用这样的引语来说明 1968.166 的社会动荡运动

Although Luhmann mentioned Beatles lyrics every now and then, according to Luhmann’s youngest son, Luhmann wasn’t a fan. Luhmann primarily listened to Louis Armstrong and classical music.[167](#footnote-127) For Luhmann, a large part of being in-touch with popular culture is thanks to the fact that he lived with his children after his wife passed. “My children are an essential part of my life,” Luhmann said. “I live here with them and the whole youth culture around them.”[168](#footnote-126) 尽管卢曼时不时地提到甲壳虫乐队的歌词，但据卢曼的小儿子说，卢曼并不是乐队的粉丝。卢曼主要听路易斯 · 阿姆斯特朗 (Louis Armstrong) 和古典音乐。167 对卢曼来说，接触流行文化在很大程度上要归功于他在妻子过世后与孩子们住在一起。 “我的孩子是我生命中不可或缺的一部分，” 卢曼说。 “我和他们以及他们周围的整个青年文化住在这里。”168

**Luhmann, The Joker 卢曼，小丑**

A final example of Luhmann’s character can be found in his own Antinet. On one of his cards, one finds the following note: 卢曼性格的最后一个例子可以在他自己的 Antinet 中找到。在他的一张卡片上，人们发现了以下注释：

In the notebox is a note containing the argument that refutes the claims on all the other notes. But this note disappears as soon as you open the notebox. I.e., he assumes a different number, disguises himself and then cannot be found. A joker.[169](#footnote-125) 在笔记箱中有一张笔记，其中包含反驳所有其他笔记的主张的论据。但是一旦你打开记事本，这张便条就会消失。也就是说，他假设了一个不同的数字，伪装自己然后就找不到了。一个小丑. 169

I haven’t been able to figure out this riddle. Perhaps the card Luhmann is talking about is his own internal monologue; his own inner voice, Luhmann himself—a joker. 我一直无法弄清楚这个谜语。也许卢曼所说的这张牌是他自己的内心独白；他自己内心的声音，卢曼本人——一个爱开玩笑的人。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

You now have a taste of the type of character Niklas Luhmann was. You also have a sense for the theories underlying Luhmann’s research. These are important aspects to understand. As you’ll soon find out, these properties are felt within the architecture and nature of the Antinet Zettelkasten. 您现在已经了解了尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的性格类型。你也对卢曼研究背后的理论有所了解。这些都是需要理解的重要方面。您很快就会发现，这些属性体现在 Antinet Zettelkasten 的建筑和自然环境中。

CHAPTER FIVE 第五章
----------------

What Is An Antinet? 什么是反网？
--------------------------

“hey boy!” a soldier shouted at 17-year-old Niklas Luhmann, “stick out your arm!”“嗨男孩！” 一名士兵对 17 岁的尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 大喊：“伸出你的手臂！”

Young Luhmann complied. He stuck out his arm. 年轻的卢曼顺从了。他伸出手臂。

Luhmann stood as a prisoner captured along with his friends. They ranged from fifteen to eighteen years old. One expects they were scared. Yet, instead of being frightened, Luhmann was one thing: he was hopeful. 卢曼像一个和他的朋友一起被俘的囚犯一样站在那里。他们的年龄从十五岁到十八岁不等。人们预计他们会害怕。然而，卢曼并没有害怕，而是一回事：他充满希望。

“Finally,” one imagines Luhmann thinking to himself, “I’ll be freed of the glorified slave labor I’ve been forced into for the past several years!”“终于，” 人们想象卢曼自言自语，“我将摆脱过去几年被迫从事的美化奴隶劳动！”

What happened next would be stamped onto Niklas Luhmann’s psyche— and also stamped onto his body—for the rest of his life. 接下来发生的事情将烙印在尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的心灵上——也烙印在他的身体上——直到他的余生。

The soldier who shouted at Luhmann approached him and got into Luhmann’s face. Next, the soldier ripped away Luhmann’s wristwatch from his arm. He then threw Luhmann to the ground. Luhmann was kicked and beaten for what felt like hours—viciously beaten by the soldier—an American soldier—who had just hauled in his latest herd of Nazi captives, which included Luhmann. 冲着卢曼大喊大叫的士兵走近他，撞到了卢曼的脸上。接下来，士兵从他的胳膊上扯下了卢曼的手表。然后他把卢曼扔在地上。卢曼被拳打脚踢了好几个小时——被士兵狠狠地殴打了——一名美国士兵——他刚刚把他的最新一批纳粹俘虏拖了过来，其中包括卢曼。

A detail not often mentioned of Niklas Luhmann, the godfather of the Zettelkasten notetaking system, is the following fact: Niklas Luhmann was, technically, a Nazi.Zettelkasten 笔记系统的教父尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 不常提及的一个细节是：从技术上讲，尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 是一名纳粹分子。

Yet before wishing upon him Inglorious Basterds forehead-carving treatment, I ought provide you with an additional bit of information: serving in the Nazi ranks was not Luhmann’s choice. 然而，在为他祈愿无耻混蛋的额头雕刻治疗之前，我应该向你提供一些额外的信息：在纳粹队伍中服役并不是卢曼的选择。

On January 22, 1943, following the implementation of a decree, the Nazis enacted an order. The order called for drafting entire school classes of male students born in 1926 and 1927 into military units. Supervising this program were two institutions: the Hitler Youth organization and the infamous Nazi air force, the Luftwaffe. Because of this order, fifteen-year-old Niklas Luhmann (born on December 8, 1927) was forced to join the Nazi ranks of the Luftwaffenhelfer. These were assistants to the infamous air force of the Nazis.[170](#footnote-290) However, at the desperate end of World War II, Luhmann was sent to the front lines of the war. Shortly after this assignment, he and his comrades were captured by American soldiers.1943 年 1 月 22 日，在执行一项法令后，纳粹颁布了一项命令。该命令要求将 1926 年和 1927 年出生的男学生全部编入军队。监督该计划的是两个机构：希特勒青年组织和臭名昭著的纳粹空军德国空军。由于这项命令，15 岁的尼克拉斯 · 卢曼（Niklas Luhmann，生于 1927 年 12 月 8 日）被迫加入纳粹德国空军空军。这些人是臭名昭著的纳粹空军的助手。170 然而，在二战末期，卢曼被派往战争前线。执行此任务后不久，他和他的战友被美国士兵俘虏。

Note that Luhmann was conscripted into Nazi service. The word, conscripted, basically means one is given the so-called “early honor” to serve their country, for free, and without pay. It was a government order. They had no say in this matter. 请注意，卢曼被征召入伍。应征入伍这个词基本上意味着一个人被赋予所谓的 “早期荣誉”，可以免费、无偿地为他们的国家服务。这是政府命令。在这件事上他们没有发言权。

Toward the end of World War II, the Nazis realized things looked bleak for them. For this reason, they forced their citizen’s children into slave labor for their ‘just’ cause. These children were supposed to have been between the ages of fifteen to eighteen years. Yet American soldiers reported capturing Nazi children as young as eight years old carrying guns.[171](#footnote-289) 在第二次世界大战快结束时，纳粹意识到他们的处境看起来很凄凉。出于这个原因，他们为了他们的 “正义” 事业，强迫他们公民的孩子从事奴隶劳动。这些孩子的年龄应该在十五到十八岁之间。然而，美国士兵报告说，他们抓获了年仅 8 岁的纳粹儿童携带枪支。 171

Luhmann did not elect to serve the Nazi cause, and he was not a fan of the Nazi ideology; however, that didn’t matter. Luhmann had no choice but to serve the Nazis. 卢曼没有选择为纳粹事业服务，他也不是纳粹意识形态的拥护者；但是，那没关系。卢曼别无选择，只能为纳粹服务。

When the American soldiers captured Luhmann, he was beaten as if he were a Third Reich soldier of the highest-rank. 当美国大兵俘虏卢曼时，他被打得像第三帝国的最高军衔士兵一样。

Yet this most unfortunate experience transformed Luhmann’s thinking process in an invaluable way. You see, what made Luhmann such a profound thinker stems from one thing, perspective. 然而，这一最不幸的经历以一种无价的方式改变了卢曼的思维过程。你看，是什么让卢曼成为如此深刻的思想家，源于一件事，观点。

As we’ll discuss more in a later chapter, perspective derives from the Latin roots, per, meaning “thoroughly and fully,” and specere, meaning “to observe, and see, and spectate.” Combined, perspective means thoroughly observing, seeing, and spectating. 正如我们将在后面的章节中详细讨论的，perspective 源自拉丁语词根 per，意思是 “彻底和完全”，而 specere 意思是 “观察、观看和旁观”。结合起来，透视意味着彻底观察、观察和观察。

Luhmann’s theories encompass some of the most radical perspectives in the social sciences. His perspectives were shaped by his experience of being tortured at the hands of American soldiers. 卢曼的理论包含了社会科学中一些最激进的观点。他的观点是由他在美国士兵手中遭受酷刑的经历塑​​造的。

Many people, including myself, tend towards the simplicity of dualistic philosophies. We prefer the simplicity of good vs. evil. We love Hero’s Journeys—stories like Star Wars and the light side vs. the dark side. Yet, as Luhmann learned very early and painfully, reality is not so simple. Reality is often quite complex. 许多人，包括我自己，都倾向于二元论哲学的简单性。我们更喜欢善与恶的简单性。我们喜欢英雄之旅——星球大战和光明面与黑暗面之类的故事。然而，正如卢曼很早就痛苦地了解到的那样，现实并非如此简单。现实往往相当复杂。

Luhmann discovered this when the Americans captured him and beat him during the final moments of World War II. On that day, Luhmann (and his fellow glorified slave-laborers) found themselves hopeful. They were hopeful that the “coercive apparatus”—the Nazi regime—would wither away once the Nazis were defeated.[172](#footnote-288) Luhmann believed the world reflected that of good vs. evil. Even though Luhmann was working for the Nazi party, he believed the Nazis to be the evil side. After all, they coercively enslaved him into service, and the Allied powers were thought to be the good side. 当美国人在第二次世界大战的最后时刻俘虏并殴打他时，卢曼发现了这一点。那天，卢曼（和他的同胞荣耀的奴隶劳工）发现自己充满希望。他们希望一旦纳粹被击败，“强制机器”——纳粹政权——就会消亡。172 卢曼相信世界反映了善与恶的对比。尽管卢曼为纳粹党工作，但他认为纳粹是邪恶的一面。毕竟，他们强迫他服役，盟军被认为是好的一面。

Luhmann and his colleagues were quite elated when they were captured. They were now captured by the good side, soon freed of the Nazi evil they had found themselves chained to. Once Luhmann and his colleagues were captured, however, they were ushered like cattle into a room. When the soldier shouted at Luhmann to hold his arm out, Luhmann extended his arm as if to embrace his American savior. Luhmann wished to clasp hands and thank the soldier for rescuing him from the Nazi’s forced labor. 卢曼和他的同事们在被捕时非常高兴。他们现在被好的一面俘虏了，很快就摆脱了他们发现自己被束缚的纳粹邪恶。然而，一旦卢曼和他的同事被捕，他们就会像牛群一样被带进房间。当士兵大喊卢曼伸出手臂时，卢曼伸出手臂，仿佛要拥抱他的美国救星。卢曼真想握手感谢士兵把他从纳粹的强制劳动中解救出来。

Yet, instead of being embraced with the clasping of hands, the American soldier ripped off Luhmann’s watch, threw Luhmann to the ground, and proceeded to beat him viciously. Luhmann’s friends looked on in dismay. 然而，这名美国士兵并没有被双手合十拥抱，而是扯下卢曼的手表，将卢曼扔在地上，然后开始恶毒地殴打他。卢曼的朋友们沮丧地看着。

“What the hell’s happening?!” we can imagine Luhmann asking himself in a state of distress. “I thought the Americans were here to rescue me and to free me!” Luhmann thought Americans—aka, the good guys—were rescuing him. “这到底是怎么回事？！” 我们可以想象卢曼在苦恼中自问。 “我以为美国人是来救我、解救我的！” 卢曼认为美国人——也就是好人——正在拯救他。

It’s rather heartbreaking to imagine the young 17-year-old Luhmann in such a state. Imagine the painful thoughts racing through Luhmann’s mind. It’s sad to think of other children like him who experienced the same; children scared for their lives, suddenly being thrown to the ground and beaten. Luhmann’s experience was not isolated, either. It happened to many POWs—children and adults. 想象年仅 17 岁的卢曼就处于这样的状态，真是令人心碎。想象一下卢曼脑海中闪过的痛苦念头。想到其他像他一样经历过同样经历的孩子，我很难过；孩子们害怕他们的生命，突然被扔在地上并被殴打。卢曼的经历也不是孤立的。它发生在许多战俘身上——儿童和成人。

Luhmann realized the world was not as simple as the paradigm of good vs. evil during this moment. The world was complex, and the world was sometimes rather sad. 在这一刻，卢曼意识到世界并不像善与恶的范式那么简单。世界是复杂的，世界有时是相当悲伤的。

This life experience led Luhmann to realize that political regimes “could not run along the axis of “good/evil, but rather that one must judge the figures in their limited reality.”[173](#footnote-287) To be clear, the beatings of Luhmann and his friends were not permitted by the Allied powers. The preventative mechanism for such abuse was supposed to be the Geneva Convention. The Geneva Convention outlined provisions for properly treating prisoners of war (“POWs”). Its goal centered on protocols designed to treat POWs with honor and respect.[174](#footnote-286) Apparently, the terms honor and respect were loosely interpreted by the American soldiers. These soldiers were presumably emotionally exhausted by the war. Seeing friends suffer and die (in physical form) weighed more heavily than the Geneva Convention’s rules (which were of metaphysical form). The Geneva Convention’s metaphysical rules seemed purely imaginary compared to physical death. 这种生活经历让卢曼意识到，政治体制 “不能沿着‘善 / 恶’的轴线运行，而是必须在有限的现实中判断人物。”173 需要明确的是，卢曼和他的朋友的殴打是盟军不允许。这种滥用的预防机制应该是日内瓦公约。 《日内瓦公约》概述了妥善对待战俘（“战俘”）的规定。它的目标集中在旨在以荣誉和尊重对待战俘的协议上。174 显然，美国士兵对荣誉和尊重这两个词的解释很笼统。这些士兵大概在战争中情绪疲惫。看到朋友受苦和死亡（以肉体形式）比日内瓦公约的规则（形而上学形式）​​更重要。与肉体死亡相比，日内瓦公约的形而上学规则似乎纯粹是虚构的。

From the abuse and violence inflicted on Luhmann and his fellow Nazi-slave-children, Luhmann saw reality as the murky picture it is, perhaps for the first time in his life. 从卢曼和他的纳粹奴隶儿童同伴遭受的虐待和暴力中，卢曼将现实视为阴暗的画面，这也许是他一生中的第一次。

The lesson in all of this? Simply this: no system is impenetrable to evil acts. 所有这一切的教训？简单地说：没有任何系统是无法渗透邪恶行为的。

Luhmann viewed Americans as the lesser evil, saying, “The American system, for example, seems to me the most good.” Nevertheless, Luhmann was not blind to the systematic problems ingrained in any political system. 卢曼认为美国人是较小的邪恶，他说，“例如，美国制度在我看来是最好的。” 尽管如此，卢曼并没有对任何政治体系中根深蒂固的系统性问题视而不见。

Luhmann recognized reality as a complex system mixed with a lot of good and a lot of bad. He later declared that non-Nazi systems of governance possess “more positive features and more negative features than any previous society. So today is both better and worse.”[175](#footnote-285) 卢曼认为现实是一个复杂的系统，混合了很多好事和坏事。他后来宣称，非纳粹治理体系 “比以往任何社会都具有更多积极的特征和更多的消极特征。所以今天既好又坏。”175

The experience shaped Luhmann so profoundly that he devised a thinking system for himself, and made sure to architect it in such a way as to challenge others’ perennial tendency of drifting back into an overly simplistic view of the world. He needed a system to deter the common tendency of drifting into simple dualistic suppositions of good vs. evil. 这段经历对卢曼的影响如此深刻，以至于他为自己设计了一个思维体系，并确保以这样一种方式构建它，以挑战其他人长期倾向于回归过于简单的世界观的趋势。他需要一个系统来阻止陷入简单的善恶二元假设的普遍趋势。

It’s “increasingly rare,” Luhmann said, that thoughts or disagreements can be developed in a useful way if you “moralize” them.[176](#footnote-284) Luhmann needed a system to constantly adapt his perspective in such a way as to filter out the tendencies and biases conducive to falling into the simplicity fallacy— that of oversimplifying reality.Luhmann 说，“越来越少见”，如果你 “道德化” 它们，想法或分歧可以以有用的方式发展。 176 Luhmann 需要一个系统来不断调整他的观点，以过滤掉有益的倾向和偏见陷入简单性谬误——将现实过于简单化。

**The Zettelkasten as an Adaptive Optic System for Raw and Distorted ThoughtsZettelkasten 作为原始和扭曲思想的自适应光学系统**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Luhmann needed a tool similar to something called an adaptive optic system (in the world of astronomy). This technology is built into telescopes, and it converts blurry, distorted pictures of the universe into crisp and clear images. It achieves this by sending the initial light waves it receives, which are raw and distorted, into a self-correcting feedback loop that measures the distortions. Next, a critical step happens: the system generates an inverse wavefront to compensate for the initial distorted light waves. 卢曼需要一种类似于自适应光学系统（在天文学领域）的工具。这项技术内置于望远镜中，它将模糊、扭曲的宇宙图片转换为清晰的图像。它通过将接收到的原始和失真的初始光波发送到测量失真的自校正反馈回路来实现这一点。接下来，一个关键的步骤发生了：系统产生一个反波前来补偿初始扭曲的光波。

The Zettelkasten system works much like an adaptive optic system. Except instead of crystallizing raw and distorted light waves, raw and distorted thoughts serve as the materials crystallized.Zettelkasten 系统的工作原理很像自适应光学系统。除了不是结晶原始和扭曲的光波，原始和扭曲的思想作为结晶的材料。

Now, back to Luhmann’s experience of being tortured by American soldiers. Let’s wrap up this part of the story. 现在，回到卢曼被美国大兵折磨的经历。让我们结束这部分的故事。

Shortly after being held in captivity, Luhmann was released. He was one of the luckier ones simply because he was still seventeen years old. He was not technically an adult yet. However, the nightmare of American captivity was not yet over for his friends who had recently turned eighteen. They were sent to French mines and forced into slave labor and even more beatings.[177](#footnote-283) 在被关押后不久，卢曼被释放。他是比较幸运的人之一，因为他还只有十七岁。他在技术上还不是成年人。然而，对于他刚满 18 岁的朋友们来说，美国囚禁的噩梦还没有结束。他们被送到法国的矿山，被迫从事奴隶劳动，甚至遭受更多的殴打。 177

In his later adult life, Luhmann held these memories in his mind. His theory of society proposes radical notions—such as sociology not necessarily being about people, but of environmental factors. That is, society is more ecological than sociological. Also, he held that polar extremes in society are necessary. These radical views are but one reason Luhmann’s writings were so complicated and hard to understand. I cover this in more detail at another point in the book, but in sum, Luhmann’s antithetical ideas were at risk of triggering uproar; therefore, he was incentivized to package his complex views with difficult prose. He did this to shield himself from being read by casual readers. 在他成年后的生活中，卢曼将这些记忆牢记在心。他的社会理论提出了激进的概念——比如社会学不一定是关于人的，而是关于环境因素的。也就是说，社会比社会学更具生态性。此外，他认为社会中的极端是必要的。这些激进的观点只是卢曼的著作如此复杂和难以理解的原因之一。我在书中的另一处对此进行了更详细的介绍，但总而言之，卢曼的对立思想有可能引发轩然大波；因此，他被激励用难懂的散文来包装他复杂的观点。他这样做是为了保护自己不被临时读者阅读。

Luhmann’s Zettelkasten served a critical function in doing this (among many other things), and would later assist his ideas in gaining notoriety. Eventually Luhmann became one of the greatest modern social theory thinkers of our time. His system for managing his theories—the Zettelkasten—informs and inspires knowledge workers to this day.Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 在这方面发挥了关键作用（除其他外），后来帮助他的想法声名狼藉。最终，卢曼成为我们这个时代最伟大的现代社会理论思想家之一。他管理理论的系统——Zettelkasten——至今仍在启发和启发着知识工作者。

Yet there’s one issue emerging today which risks watering down the impact of the Zettelkasten system Luhmann devised. That’s what we shall talk about next. 然而，今天出现的一个问题可能会削弱卢曼设计的 Zettelkasten 系统的影响。这就是我们接下来要讲的。

**Specific Principles vs. General Principles 具体原则与一般原则**
--------------------------------------------------------

It is my belief that there is a risk to Luhmann’s Zettelkasten system becoming misinterpreted and thereby morphed into something it is not. 我相信卢曼的 Zettelkasten 系统存在被误解的风险，从而演变成它不是的东西。

A principle is defined as a fundamental truth that serves as the foundation for a system.[178](#footnote-282) Seems straightforward, right? The problem today is that the specific principles of the Zettelkasten system that Luhmann himself specified in his own paper are being cast as general principles.[179](#footnote-281) The specific principles of Luhmann’s Zettelkasten system were cast aside and written off as unnecessary and archaic. Luhmann’s system is built entirely of physical, not digital, parts. With those parts of Luhmann’s system stripped away, deleted, and morphed from physical form to metaphysical form, the critical essence of the Zettelkasten system has been demoted. The parts have been deleted and replaced with analogous abstractions, with the belief that the original parts were non-critical. In reality, these substituted parts are indeed very critical to the whole! 原则被定义为作为系统基础的基本真理。178 看起来很简单，对吧？今天的问题是，卢曼自己在他自己的论文中指定的 Zettelkasten 系统的具体原则被当作一般原则。 179 卢曼的 Zettelkasten 系统的具体原则被抛弃并被认为是不必要的和过时的。 Luhmann 的系统完全由物理部件而非数字部件构建。随着卢曼系统的那些部分被剥离、删除并从物理形式转变为形而上学形式，Zettelkasten 系统的关键本质已经被降级。这些部分已被删除并替换为类似的抽象，相信原始部分是非关键的。实际上，这些被替代的部分对于整体来说确实是非常关键的！

This entirely different system I’m alluding to is that of digital notetaking apps. These apps possess functionality enabling one to link notes. Even though such apps are thought of as a Zettelkasten, the magic that Luhmann built into his system is lost. Or at the very least, much of the Zettelkasten magic is replaced by something else entirely. 我指的这个完全不同的系统是数字笔记应用程序。这些应用程序具有使人们能够链接笔记的功能。尽管此类应用程序被认为是 Zettelkasten，但卢曼在其系统中植入的魔力已经消失。或者至少，Zettelkasten 的大部分魔法完全被其他东西所取代。

Digital notetaking apps with note-linking capability are often thought of as Zettelkasten systems. This is not the case. As a result, people who are newly curious about Zettelkasten end up hopelessly lost and confused. Or people end up thinking they understand what a Zettelkasten is. They proceed to take thousands of digital notes before they realize they’re lost and confused. They’re left with a mess of digital information, and they have no idea why they even began to take notes in the first place. 具有笔记链接功能的数字笔记应用程序通常被认为是 Zettelkasten 系统。不是这种情况。结果，刚开始对 Zettelkasten 产生好奇的人们最终陷入了无可救药的迷茫和迷茫。或者人们最终认为他们了解 Zettelkasten 是什么。在他们意识到自己迷路和困惑之前，他们开始记下数以千计的数字笔记。他们留下了一堆数字信息，他们甚至不知道为什么他们一开始就开始做笔记。

I’m not against progress; however, it becomes confusing when a new concept (i.e. digital notetaking apps with linking capabilities) ensconces itself in a term used by an entirely different concept (i.e. Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten). 我不反对进步；然而，当一个新概念（即具有链接功能的数字笔记应用程序）将自己置于一个完全不同的概念（即 Niklas Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten）所使用的术语中时，它就会变得混乱。

At the core of this situation rests the delineation of specific vs. general principles. 这种情况的核心在于具体原则与一般原则的划分。

Let’s first discuss general principles. 让我们首先讨论一般原则。

I am not a fan of creating your own instantiation of a system and then referring to it as if it’s identical to that which it was inspired by. 我不喜欢创建你自己的系统实例，然后引用它，就好像它与它的灵感来源是一样的。

Take a deep breath, and reread that paragraph. 深吸一口气，重新阅读那段话。

OK, now let me give you an example of this. Let’s start with a wiki. A wiki is an information source developed collaboratively by a community of users. It allows any user to add and edit content.[180](#footnote-280) If I were to create my own version of a wiki in physical form, and if, as a result of the different medium, I were forced to alter and change the essence of how it works, I would hope that I wouldn’t do one thing—and that is this: I hope I wouldn’t call it a wiki! Doing so would confuse everyone; I would term the new system (inspired by a wiki) differently, since it’s new. It is (only) inspired by the concept of wiki. I also would not force those who still use digital wiki systems to forever specify that they use digital wikis (as opposed to my new analog wiki). Yet this rather absurd illustration is precisely what has taken place with regards to the Zettelkasten. If you use a physical Zettelkasten system today, with the same principles that Luhmann used, one is forced to specify that they’re using an analog Zettelkasten, or a Luhmannian Zettelkasten (as opposed to a Zettelkasten—that is, a digital notetaking app with linking functionality). 好的，现在让我给你举个例子。让我们从维基开始。 wiki 是由用户社区协作开发的信息源。它允许任何用户添加和编辑内容。180 如果我要以物理形式创建我自己的 wiki 版本，并且如果由于不同的媒介，我被迫改变和改变其工作方式的本质，我希望我不会做一件事——那就是：我希望我不会称它为 wiki！这样做会使每个人都感到困惑；我会用不同的方式命名新系统（受维基启发），因为它是新的。它（仅）受到 wiki 概念的启发。我也不会强迫那些仍然使用数字维基系统的人永远指定他们使用数字维基（与我的新模拟维基相反）。然而，这个相当荒谬的例子正是发生在 Zettelkasten 身上的事情。如果你今天使用物理 Zettelkasten 系统，使用与 Luhmann 使用的相同的原理，那么人们被迫指定他们使用的是模拟 Zettelkasten 或 Luhmannian Zettelkasten（与 Zettelkasten 相反，即，数字笔记应用程序与链接功能）。

Look, I am not against identifying general principles and adapting such principles into more convenient forms in support of your own personal preferences and goals. Research in knowledge science espouses the view that “general principles should be adapted by individuals.” Even ancient learned scholars believed this to be necessary. Early modern Europe produced strict doctrinaire thinkers. One such thinker was the Jesuit pedagogue, Jeremias Drexel (1570–1625). Drexel once asserted, “If [the] precepts and rules of notetaking do not please you, draw up other precepts for yourself, fewer in number, shorter, suited to your studies, just as long as you take notes.”[181](#footnote-279) 你看，我并不反对确定一般原则并将这些原则调整为更方便的形式以支持你自己的个人偏好和目标。知识科学研究支持 “一般原则应因人而异” 的观点。甚至古代博学的学者也认为这是必要的。近代早期的欧洲产生了严格的教条主义思想家。一位这样的思想家是耶稣会教育家 Jeremias Drexel（1570-1625）。德雷克塞尔曾经断言，“如果 [the] 笔记的戒律和规则不喜欢你，为自己制定其他戒律，数量更少，更短，适合你的学习，只要你做笔记。”181

The question then becomes: in Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten, what stands as a general principle and what stands as a specific principle? That is, what could be altered and eliminated in the name of inspiration, and what is a specific principle that must be strictly adhered to if one were to strive to use the same system Luhmann used when he used the term Zettelkasten? 那么问题就变成了：在尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的 Zettelkasten 中，什么是一般原则，什么是特定原则？也就是说，如果要努力使用卢曼在使用 Zettelkasten 一词时使用的相同系统，那么可以以灵感的名义改变和消除什么，以及必须严格遵守的具体原则是什么？

On this matter, I have two beliefs: 在这件事上，我有两个信念：

First, I believe that general principles in a Zettelkasten system are processes—such as how one takes notes from the materials one reads. So-called literature notes are an example of a general principle in a Zettelkasten. Relatedly, the term literature notes is suboptimal. Literature notes was a term never used by Niklas Luhmann, but was popularized by modern authors who loosely interpret Luhmann’s system. Furthermore, the term literature note renders the types of notes Luhmann took as ambiguous.[182](#footnote-278) 首先，我认为 Zettelkasten 系统中的一般原则是过程——例如人们如何从阅读的材料中做笔记。所谓的文献注释是 Zettelkasten 中一般原则的一个例子。相关地，术语文学笔记是次优的。文学笔记是尼克拉斯 · 卢曼从未使用过的一个术语，但被松散地解释卢曼系统的现代作家所普及。此外，文学笔记一词使卢曼认为模棱两可的笔记类型。 182

The bottom line is that the manner in which you take notes while reading is an example of adhering to a general principle. Reason being, the process of taking notes while reading is a highly personalized activity. The content you select while reading, and the manner and style in which you choose to extract that selection is highly personalized. How you do it must be adapted by you. As the scholar, Alberto Cevolini, puts it, “what attracts attention and is deemed memorable in a book may not be the same for all readers. By definition, information retrieval is a selective performance; in turn, selection is a highly personalized activity.”[183](#footnote-277) 最重要的是，你在阅读时做笔记的方式是遵守一般原则的一个例子。原因是，阅读时做笔记的过程是一项高度个性化的活动。您在阅读时选择的内容，以及您选择提取该选择的方式和风格是高度个性化的。你如何做必须由你来调整。正如学者阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 所说，“一本书中吸引注意力和被认为令人难忘的内容可能对所有读者来说都是不一样的。根据定义，信息检索是一种选择性表现；反过来，选择是一种高度个性化的活动。”183

My second belief concerns itself with what constitutes specific principles in a Zettelkasten system. 我的第二个信念与什么构成了 Zettelkasten 系统中的具体原则有关。

I suggest that there are four principles which are specific principles in a Zettelkasten. 我建议有四个原则，它们是 Zettelkasten 中的具体原则。

I am not the first to propose that a Zettelkasten consists of four principles. The first person to do so was Niklas Luhmann himself. He referred to the principles as requirements. The second individual to outline its four principles was Johannes Schmidt, the scholar who perhaps knows Luhmann’s work best.[184](#footnote-276) 我不是第一个提出 Zettelkasten 由四个原则组成的人。第一个这样做的人是尼克拉斯 · 卢曼本人。他将原则称为要求。第二个概述其四项原则的人是约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt)，他可能是最了解卢曼著作的学者。 184

The principles I’m presenting are mapped onto Luhmann’s four principles; however, in my perfectly biased opinion, they are more simple and useful in understanding the Zettelkasten. Plus, they form a cool acronym! 我提出的原则映射到卢曼的四项原则；然而，在我完全有偏见的观点中，它们在理解 Zettelkasten 方面更加简单和有用。另外，它们形成了一个很酷的首字母缩写词！

Three of the four principles I introduce are referred to by Luhmann as internal requirements. One of the four principles he specified was referred to as an external requirement.[185](#footnote-275) 我介绍的四个原则中的三个被卢曼称为内部要求。他指定的四项原则之一被称为外部要求。 185

It’s worth noting that my views on what stands as a general principle vs. specific principle remain an area in which I hold different opinions than others. Sascha Fast, a leading educator of the Zettelkasten system and who operates perhaps the most visited website pertaining to the Zettelkasten ([https://zettelkasten.de](https://zettelkasten.de/)), quotes the Israeli fitness trainer, Ido Portal who says, “Principles are higher than techniques. Principles produce techniques in an instant.”[186](#footnote-274) This quote implies that the four specific principles outlined by Niklas Luhmann are merely techniques that could be adapted and adjusted freely without worry of compromising the whole. 值得注意的是，我对一般原则与具体原则的看法仍然是我与其他人持有不同意见的领域。 Sascha Fast 是 Zettelkasten 系统的领先教育者，他经营着可能是与 Zettelkasten 相关的访问量最大的网站 (https://zettelkasten.de)，他引用以色列健身教练 Ido Portal 的话说：“原则高于技术。原则瞬间产生技术。”186 这句话暗示尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 概述的四个具体原则只是可以自由调整和调整的技术，而不用担心损害整体。

Fast goes on to outline several principles, such as the “Principle of Atomicity” which pertains to the idea that one should “put things that belong together into a single note, give it an ID, but limit its content to that single topic.” [187](#footnote-273) Fast’s second principle, labeled the “Principle of Connectivity,” argues for alternative techniques for implementing two of the principles Luhmann specifies as internal requirements for a Zettelkasten system, that of (1) “the possibility of arbitrary internal branching,” and (2) “possibility of linking” via the numeric-alpha addressing scheme used by Luhmann.[188](#footnote-272)Fast 继续概述了几个原则，例如 “原子性原则”，它与“将属于一起的东西放在一个笔记中，给它一个 ID，但将其内容限制在那个单一主题” 的想法有关。 187 Fast 的第二个原则，标记为“连通性原则”，主张采用替代技术来实施 Luhmann 指定为 Zettelkasten 系统内部要求的两个原则，即 (1)“任意内部分支的可能性”，以及 (2 ) 通过 Luhmann 使用的数字字母寻址方案“链接的可能性”。 188

I do not hold the first principle (the “Principle of Atomicity”) as a general principle because Luhmann generally did not abide by such a principle. One idea per note is a convenient idea espoused by many people, but it is largely a myth as it pertains to Luhmann’s system.[189](#footnote-271) Yet, for digital Zettelkasten, I agree with Fast in that it’s probably a useful practice. 我不认为第一原则（“原子性原则”）是一般原则，因为卢曼一般不遵守这样的原则。每个音符一个想法是许多人拥护的一个方便的想法，但它在很大程度上是一个神话，因为它与 Luhmann 的系统有关。 189 然而，对于数字 Zettelkasten，我同意 Fast 的观点，因为它可能是一种有用的做法。

The same applies to Fast’s “Principle of Connectivity.” Perhaps it’s a useful practice for digital Zettelkasten; however, it essentially demotes two of Luhmann’s core principles (the “internal branching” tree-like structure of notes, and the numeric-alpha addressing of notes) and passes them off as mere “techniques.” 这同样适用于 Fast 的 “连通性原则”。也许这对数字 Zettelkasten 来说是一种有用的做法；然而，它实质上贬低了卢曼的两个核心原则（音符的“内部分支” 树状结构，以及音符的数字字母寻址）并将它们作为纯粹的 “技术” 传递出去。

The reason this is important to know, and why it’s worthy of your time, centers on the fact that when too many aspects of a system are relegated to abstractions, you generalize it so severely that it transforms the original system into something it is not. It strips away a system’s unique, rough personality and smooths it down into a watered-down, blurry image of what it once was. The image you see when you squint your eyes at the Mona Lisa: is it the Mona Lisa you’re seeing? Or a blurred-out version? More directly, if you define the principles of a Zettelkasten as something that is founded on atomicity, and connectivity, then thousands of systems could qualify as a Zettelkasten. Wikipedia could be considered a Zettelkasten by these principles (even though it’s not). A website could be regarded as a Zettelkasten in that case. A thesaurus (with its See also references) could be considered a Zettelkasten. Or, as most people believe, a digital notetaking app with note-linking functionality (via something popularized with the term wikilinks), yes definitely this, could even be considered a Zettelkasten. In the considerable amount of time I’ve spent working with an analog Zettelkasten—one which adheres to Luhmann’s four principles—I can say that such a system operates much differently than any of these things. In other words, Luhmann’s Zettelkasten system stands apart as an entirely different entity compared with Wikipedia, websites, thesauri, and digital “Zettelkasten.” 知道这一点很重要，为什么值得你花时间，原因在于当一个系统的太多方面被抽象化时，你将它概括得如此严重，以至于它把原来的系统变成了它不是的东西。它剥离了一个系统独特、粗糙的个性，并将其平滑化为一个淡化的、模糊的过去形象。当你眯着眼睛看蒙娜丽莎时你看到的图像：你看到的是蒙娜丽莎吗？还是模糊版？更直接地说，如果您将 Zettelkasten 的原则定义为基于原子性和连通性的东西，那么成千上万的系统都可以成为 Zettelkasten。根据这些原则，维基百科可以被视为 Zettelkasten（尽管它不是）。在这种情况下，网站可以被视为 Zettelkasten。同义词库（及其参见参考文献）可以被视为 Zettelkasten。或者，正如大多数人所相信的那样，一个具有笔记链接功能的数字笔记应用程序（通过术语 wikilinks 流行起来的东西），是的，绝对是这个，甚至可以被认为是 Zettelkasten。在相当多的时间里，我一直在使用模拟 Zettelkasten——它遵循卢曼的四个原则——我可以说这样一个系统的运行方式与这些东西有很大不同。换句话说，与维基百科、网站、词库和数字 “Zettelkasten” 相比，Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 系统是一个完全不同的实体。

These are but philosophical views; however, I consider it essential to present the idea that one ought to take seriously the requirements that Luhmann himself specified. One should take these requirements seriously enough to at least try them out. I’ve found the four principles to be pivotal in my experience working with a Zettelkasten. 这些只是哲学观点；然而，我认为有必要提出这样一种观点，即人们应该认真对待卢曼自己指定的要求。人们应该认真对待这些要求，至少要尝试一下。在我与 Zettelkasten 合作的过程中，我发现这四项原则至关重要。

For the time being, I’ll continue referring to the analog Zettelkasten as a Zettelkasten; however, in a little bit I’ll introduce the four specific principles adopted by Niklas Luhmann. After I do this, I’ll be introducing a new term that I believe encompasses Luhmann’s system more accurately. In the meantime, the term Zettelkasten shall suffice. 目前，我将继续将模拟 Zettelkasten 称为 Zettelkasten；但是，稍后我将介绍尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 采用的四个具体原则。在我这样做之后，我将引入一个新术语，我认为它更准确地包含了卢曼的系统。与此同时，Zettelkasten 一词就足够了。

In brief, a Zettelkasten possesses four specific principles. These four principles define what a Zettelkasten is. However, before I share these principles with you, I’d like to turn to what a Zettelkasten is not. Why? Because it helps demystify the essence of a Zettelkasten in preparation for being introduced to what it actually is. 简而言之，Zettelkasten 拥有四个具体原则。这四项原则定义了 Zettelkasten 是什么。但是，在与您分享这些原则之前，我想先谈谈 Zettelkasten 不是什么。为什么？因为它有助于揭开 Zettelkasten 的本质的神秘面纱，为了解它的实际情况做准备。

Let’s dive into this now. 现在让我们深入探讨一下。

I lied. Before I tell you what a Zettelkasten is not, let’s hone in on the term Zettelkasten itself. 我撒了谎。在我告诉你 Zettelkasten 不是什么之前，让我们仔细研究一下 Zettelkasten 这个词本身。

The term Zettelkasten in American English translates to notebox. The term notebox is the shortened form of a “notecard box.” Zettel is the German word for note, and kasten is the German word for box. 美式英语中的术语 Zettelkasten 翻译为记事本。 notebox 一词是 “notecard box” 的缩写形式。 Zettel 是德语单词的音符，kasten 是德语单词的盒子。

The reason this is worthy of mention is because of the widespread misinterpretation of the term Zettelkasten. When searching the web, one finds references of it as a “slipbox.” 之所以值得一提，是因为对 Zettelkasten 一词的广泛误解。在网络上搜索时，人们会发现它被称为 “滑箱”。

The reason slip is translated from zettel stems from a translation defining it as a slip of paper. In popular English-German translation dictionaries, slip of paper remains listed but is no longer used as the preferred definition.[190](#footnote-270) The most widely used and arguably the “best among all” translation sources is one that does not hold slip as the most correct term for zettel.[191](#footnote-269) It holds that the most correct translation for the term zettel is simply a note.slip 之所以从 zettel 翻译过来，源于一种将其定义为 slip of paper 的翻译。在流行的英德翻译词典中，slip of paper 仍然被列出，但不再被用作首选定义。 190 使用最广泛且可以说是 “最好的” 翻译来源是不将 slip 视为最正确的术语的一种对于 zettel.191 它认为术语 zettel 最正确的翻译只是一个注释。

The mix-up with slip vs. note stems from specifications provided by the American National Standards Institute (“ANSI”) and the European paper standards, International Organization for Standardization (“ISO”).[192](#footnote-268) 将滑票与票据混为一谈源于美国国家标准协会 (“ANSI”) 和欧洲纸张标准、国际标准化组织 (“ISO”) 提供的规范。 192

The type of paper used by Luhmann is not commonly found in the US. I know this, of course, because it’s the first thing I tried getting my hands on after learning what type of paper Luhmann used. It’s tricky to find, but more tricky is finding cabinets with drawers that can properly store such paper. The paper size used by Luhmann is ISO’s paper size, A6, which is 4.1 inches by 5.8 inches. According to ISO standard 2784, the American equivalent of A6 paper is paper sized 4 inches by 6 inches, which are notecards (or blank index cards).[193](#footnote-267) 卢曼使用的纸张类型在美国并不常见。我当然知道这一点，因为这是我在了解卢曼使用的纸张类型后尝试着手做的第一件事。很难找到，但更棘手的是找到带抽屉的柜子，可以妥善存放这种纸张。 Luhmann 使用的纸张尺寸是 ISO 的纸张尺寸 A6，即 4.1 英寸乘 5.8 英寸。根据 ISO 标准 2784，美国相当于 A6 纸的纸张尺寸为 4 英寸 x 6 英寸，即记事卡（或空白索引卡）。 193

In brief, Luhmann used zettel (i.e. note) to refer to a notecard. In other words, a zettel is a notecard; Luhmann never used zettel in the manner in which people use it today—which is to connote a digital document containing text, usually in markdown format. 简而言之，卢曼使用 zettel（即笔记）来指代记事卡。换句话说，zettel 是记事卡； Luhmann 从来没有像今天人们使用它的方式那样使用 zettel——这是指包含文本的数字文档，通常是 markdown 格式。

In Luhmann’s formative article on his Zettelkasten system, “Communication with Noteboxes,” Luhmann meant notebox as in notecard box; he did not refer to a note as some metaphysical instantiation of a notecard; he would otherwise refer to that as a thought. 在 Luhmann 关于他的 Zettelkasten 系统的形成性文章 “Communication with Noteboxes” 中，Luhmann 将 notebox 理解为 notecard box；他没有将笔记称为记事卡的某种形而上学实例；否则他会将其称为思想。

From this one ought not to discount the importance of notecards—with their physical properties that include having a static fixed place in space, and limitations on character-length which they strictly enforce by their size. One also must not discount the effect these properties had in shaping and forming Luhmann’s thoughts. Why? Because the medium one uses not only is the message, it develops the message.[194](#footnote-266) 由此不应低估记事卡的重要性——它们的物理特性包括在空间中有一个静态的固定位置，以及字符长度的限制，它们严格按照大小执行。人们也不能低估这些特性在塑造和形成卢曼思想方面的影响。为什么？因为人们使用的媒介不仅是信息，它还发展了信息。 194

This may seem like dry material, but I assure you, it’s necessary knowledge if you wish to properly adopt and use a Zettelkasten system and avoid the landmines you’ll face the second you begin exploring the concept of Zettelkasten outside this clear canvas I’m about to paint for you. It’s straightforward that Zettelkasten means notebox if you’ve read what I’ve written here. Be forewarned, however; as soon as you begin surfing the web or watching YouTube videos, you’ll begin to come upon descriptions of Zettelkasten that are outdated, misguided, or flat-out wrong (unless you’ve stumbled onto my YouTube videos, of course)! 这可能看起来像枯燥的材料，但我向你保证，如果你想正确采用和使用 Zettelkasten 系统并避免地雷，那么当你开始探索 Zettelkasten 的概念时，你将在这块透明的画布外探索 Zettelkasten 的概念，这是必要的知识我是即将为你画画。如果您已经阅读了我在这里写的内容，那么 Zettelkasten 的意思很简单。但是请注意；一旦您开始上网或观看 YouTube 视频，您就会开始发现对 Zettelkasten 的描述已经过时、被误导或完全错误（当然，除非您偶然发现了我的 YouTube 视频）！

Now that you know that Zettelkasten translates to notebox, it’s time to belabor this matter further by exploring the next topic: what a Zettelkasten is not. 现在您知道 Zettelkasten 翻译成记事本，是时候通过探索下一个主题进一步讨论这个问题了：Zettelkasten 不是什么。

**What a Zettelkasten Is NotZettelkasten 不是什么**
-----------------------------------------------

Zettelkasten does not refer to any notebox system. For instance it does not connote a notebox organized by human-readable top-level concepts or names, such as the system described by the author Ryan Holiday (which he adapted from the author Robert Greene).[195](#footnote-265)Zettelkasten 不涉及任何记事本系统。例如，它并不表示由人类可读的顶级概念或名称组织的记事本，例如作者 Ryan Holiday 描述的系统（他改编自作者 Robert Greene）。 195

Luhmann makes it clear that what he means by the term notebox is not a “mere container from which we can retrieve what we put in.”[196](#footnote-264) When Luhmann writes of “communication with noteboxes,” he’s not really communicating with noteboxes but with what the notebox becomes. What he’s communicating with, he says, is a system that can “communicate” in the first place. The benefit of a communication partner is the learning that comes through not only new information, but through accidents and surprises. We’ll cover these in detail later on in this book. Accidents and surprises emerge not via dynamically-structured notecards ordered by topic; rather, the magic Luhmann writes about emerges from the interplay of four specific principles he outlines. This is but one reason why just any notebox system does not connote a Luhmannian notebox system.Luhmann 清楚地表明，他所说的 notebox 一词并不是 “我们可以从中检索我们放入的东西的容器”。196 当 Luhmann 写到“与 noteboxes 的交流” 时，他并不是真正与 noteboxes 交流，而是与记事本变成了。他说，他正在与之交流的是一个首先可以 “交流” 的系统。沟通伙伴的好处是学习不仅来自新信息，还来自意外和惊喜。我们将在本书后面详细介绍这些内容。意外和惊喜不是通过按主题排序的动态结构记事卡出现的；相反，卢曼所写的魔法是从他概述的四个具体原则的相互作用中产生的。这只是为什么任何笔记本系统都不意味着卢曼笔记本系统的原因之一。

In brief, a Ryan Holiday notebox system is not a Zettelkasten. 简而言之，Ryan Holiday 笔记本系统不是 Zettelkasten。

A Zettelkasten is also not the equivalent of a commonplace book, which is essentially a notebook organized by topic. The limitations of commonplace books centers around the following: they only enable short-term knowledge development. They do not cater to allowing thoughts to evolve over time, infinitely. They do not allow for the infinite internal branching and expansion of ideas. One of the four principles of the Zettelkasten (the true Zettelkasten) enables this expansion. This sets the Zettelkasten system apart from all others.Zettelkasten 也不等同于普通书，普通书本质上是按主题组织的笔记本。普通书籍的局限性主要集中在以下几点：它们只能促进短期知识的发展。他们不迎合允许思想随时间无限进化。它们不允许思想的无限内部分支和扩展。 Zettelkasten（真正的 Zettelkasten）的四项原则之一使这种扩展成为可能。这使 Zettelkasten 系统与众不同。

Let’s hone in for a moment on commonplace books. 让我们仔细研究一下普通书籍。

I find the people who prefer analog thinking systems are oftentimes those who greatly value commonplace books. Actually, I think commonplace books are fantastic thinking systems; yet they pale in comparison to the Antinet over the long haul. 我发现喜欢模拟思维系统的人往往是那些非常看重平庸书籍的人。实际上，我认为平凡的书是奇妙的思维系统；但从长远来看，与 Antinet 相比，它们显得苍白无力。

Commonplace books are closely related to florilegia. These were notebooks containing religious verses and excerpts grouped by theme. When I refer to this type of knowledge system I refer to commonplace books. These types of tools were incredible tools for advancing science and knowledge—especially during the Renaissance. One scholar refers to these tools as “the person-plus-notebook-system.”[197](#footnote-263) 平凡的书籍与花语密切相关。这些是包含按主题分组的宗教经文和摘录的笔记本。当我提到这类知识体系时，我指的是普通书籍。这些类型的工具是推动科学和知识发展的不可思议的工具——尤其是在文艺复兴时期。一位学者将这些工具称为 “人加笔记本系统”。 197

There are many great thinkers throughout history who used commonplace books. Thomas Jefferson was an avid user of commonplace books. Dutch humanist, Desiderius Erasmus (1446-1536) was an ardent advocate of commonplace books.[198](#footnote-262) Sigmund Freud used a “new kind of notebook, the ‘wunderblock’ or (magic notepad).”[199](#footnote-261) Behind the cool name is the same thing: a commonplace book. 历史上有许多伟大的思想家都使用过平凡的书籍。托马斯 · 杰斐逊 (Thomas Jefferson) 热衷于阅读通俗书籍。荷兰人文主义者 Desiderius Erasmus（1446-1536 年）是通俗书籍的热心倡导者。198 西格蒙德 · 弗洛伊德使用了一种 “新型笔记本，'wunderblock' 或（魔法记事本）。”199 这个很酷的名字背后是同一件事：一本普通的书

An image of one of Thomas Jefferson’s commonplace books. 托马斯 · 杰斐逊的一本平凡书籍的图片。

photo credit: “Image 36 of Thomas Jefferson, 1758-1772, Literary Commonplace Book,” image, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA, accessed May 4, 2022. 照片来源：“托马斯 · 杰斐逊 Image 36, 1758-1772, Literary Commonplace Book” 图片，美国国会图书馆，华盛顿特区 20540，2022 年 5 月 4 日访问。

Yet, there are shortcomings of commonplace books. They embody that of a “subsidiary memory,” whereas the Antinet is more than this. The Antinet is a second mind, an equal. In fact, you’ll oftentimes find yourself humbled by the knowledge the Antinet surfaces. The idea of the Antinet as something greater than a subsidiary memory, does not come from myself. It actually originates from scholars who analyzed both commonplace books and Antinet Zettelkasten systems. “The florilegium was a type of ‘double memory’ to which scholars could resort anytime their personal memory failed, the filing cabinet behaves as a true communication partner with its own idiosyncrasies and its own opinions.”[200](#footnote-260) 然而，普通书籍也有缺点。它们体现了 “附属记忆”，而 Antinet 不止于此。 Antinet 是第二个头脑，一个平等的。事实上，您经常会发现自己对 Antinet 表面的知识感到谦卑。 Antinet 比附属记忆更伟大的想法并不是来自我自己。它实际上起源于分析普通书籍和 Antinet Zettelkasten 系统的学者。 “florilegium 是一种‘双重记忆’，学者们可以在个人记忆失败时求助于它，文件柜是一个真正的沟通伙伴，有自己的特质和自己的观点。”200

As one scholar observes, florilegium and commonplace books act as just another ego, whereas an Antinet behaves as an alter ego. It’s no surprise to learn that Luhmann referred to his own Antinet as an alter ego.[201](#footnote-259) 正如一位学者所观察到的，florilegium 和普通书籍只是另一个自我，而 Antinet 则是另一个自我。得知卢曼将自己的 Antinet 称为另一个自我也就不足为奇了。 201

An ego is the conscious sense of self. It’s what you think of when you use the word ‘I’.[202](#footnote-258) 自我是有意识的自我意识。当你使用 “我” 这个词时，它就是你的想法。202

When you write down your thoughts in commonplace book or Moleskine notebook, you see yourself in them. It’s a linear version of yourself. It’s less chaotic in nature usually because each page is closely related in time. 当您在平凡的书或 Moleskine 笔记本上写下您的想法时，您会在其中看到自己。这是你自己的线性版本。它本质上不那么混乱，通常是因为每个页面在时间上都密切相关。

An alter ego is a second identity. It’s a second mind that exists metaphorically.[203](#footnote-257) The alter ego exists either as a substitute or a representative of your mind, yet it possesses unique characteristics. It possesses its own unique personality. Think of Superman, compared with his alter ego, Clark Kent. 改变自我是第二身份。它是隐喻存在的第二心智。 203 另一个自我作为你心智的替代品或代表而存在，但它具有独特的特征。它拥有自己独特的个性。想想超人，与他的另一个自我克拉克肯特相比。

The Antinet is more of an alter ego. It develops its own unique personality whom you communicate with.Antinet 更像是一个改变自我。它会发展出自己独特的个性，与您交流。

An Antinet is not a collection of excerpts, quotes, kindle highlights, or florilegia. It’s something more complex than these types of devices. The Antinet is not a subsidiary memory; it’s a second mind.Antinet 不是摘录、引述、kindle 亮点或 florilegia 的集合。它比这些类型的设备更复杂。 Antinet 不是附属记忆；这是第二个想法。

In brief, if you’ve ever kept a notebook containing your thoughts and readings, and organized them by category, that’s not a Zettelkasten system, nor is it something which I believe you’ll ever want to go back to once you begin using a Zettelkasten. 简而言之，如果您曾经保留一个包含您的想法和阅读的笔记本，并按类别组织它们，那不是 Zettelkasten 系统，我相信一旦您开始使用 Zettelkasten。

I won’t cover the advantages and disadvantages of such systems here; just for now, know that they’re quite different from a Zettelkasten system. 我不会在这里介绍此类系统的优点和缺点；就目前而言，要知道它们与 Zettelkasten 系统完全不同。

**What a Zettelkasten System Is 什么是 Zettelkasten 系统**
-----------------------------------------------------

I hold, like Niklas Luhmann held, that his notebox system is built on four specific principles. One of the principles (or requirements) is external according to Luhmann, which means it lives in physical reality. The other three principles are internal concepts, which means that they are more metaphysical in nature—though they are present within the physical principle. 我认为，就像尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 所认为的那样，他的笔记本系统是建立在四个具体原则之上的。根据卢曼的说法，其中一项原则（或要求）是外在的，这意味着它存在于物理现实中。其他三个原理是内部概念，这意味着它们本质上更形而上学——尽管它们存在于物理原理中。

**The Four Principles of a (True) Zettelkasten（真正的）Zettelkasten 的四项原则**

**Principle #1: Analog 原则 #1：模拟**

The first principle is what Luhmann referred to as an external requirement for a Zettelkasten. By external, Luhmann meant it’s something that is physical in nature: “Wooden boxes, which have drawers that can be pulled open, and pieces of paper.”[204](#footnote-256) 第一个原则是 Luhmann 所说的 Zettelkasten 的外部要求。对于外部，卢曼的意思是本质上是物理的东西：“木箱，里面有可以拉开的抽屉，还有几张纸。”204

Luhmann referred to this principle as a mere externality; however, he referred to it as mere for good reason. At the time there was no metaphysical, internal way of memorizing knowledge other than resorting to the mnemonic techniques. Such techniques were used by ancient Greek thinkers like Socrates. This involved mapping metaphysical thoughts onto physical items present in either a literal or an imagined room or space. The physical objects acted as cues allowing one to better recall any thought stored in memory. 卢曼将这一原则称为纯粹的外部性；但是，他称其为有充分理由的。当时除了求助于助记术之外，没有任何形而上学的、内在的记忆知识的方法。苏格拉底等古希腊思想家使用了这种技术。这涉及将形而上学思想映射到实际或想象的房间或空间中存在的物理项目上。物理对象充当提示，允许人们更好地回忆存储在内存中的任何想法。

Believe it or not, at the time when learned scholars and thinkers began to transition from such mnemonic techniques (which are metaphysical in nature) to notes stored in physical materials (such as was tablets, and later on, paper), it was met with much resistance—even Socrates himself, we learn by way of his followers, derided the emerging popularity of taking physical notes.[205](#footnote-255) Plato echoed the same sentiment as Socrates: “According to Plato, the true learned man should rather be autonomous. He should not ask for help coming from the outside; instead, he should be able to help himself, especially in face-to-face interactions.”[206](#footnote-254) Yet Plato also began adopting the idea of storing thoughts in physical materials. His tool of choice was the wax tablet.[207](#footnote-253) 信不信由你，当博学的学者和思想家开始从这种助记技术（本质上是形而上学的）过渡到存储在物理材料（例如平板电脑，后来是纸）中的笔记时，它遇到了很多阻力——我们从他的追随者那里了解到，即使是苏格拉底本人，也嘲笑记录物理笔记的新兴流行。 205 柏拉图回应了与苏格拉底相同的观点：“根据柏拉图的说法，真正有学问的人应该是自主的。他不应该向外界寻求帮助；相反，他应该能够帮助自己，尤其是在面对面的互动中。”206 然而，柏拉图也开始采用将思想存储在物理材料中的想法。他选择的工具是蜡片。 207

In my opinion, using physical materials to work with knowledge unlocks some of the most powerful results. Later in the book, I detail why I believe the analog component to be so important. I will also share research and specific illustrations showing why physical materials are so critical to developing knowledge. To that end, Luhmann did not need to specify analog as a requirement over digital. Why? Because digital tools were not an option when he started building his Zettelkasten. I have reason to believe that if Niklas Luhmann were alive today he would continue using his analog Zettelkasten. There’s magic within the analog medium incapable of being reproduced in digital tools. I will share why I believe this to be the case later on in this book. 在我看来，使用物理材料来处理知识可以解锁一些最强大的结果。在本书的后面，我详细说明了为什么我认为模拟组件如此重要。我还将分享研究和具体插图，说明为什么物理材料对发展知识如此重要。为此，Luhmann 不需要将模拟指定为对数字的要求。为什么？因为当他开始建造他的 Zettelkasten 时，数字工具不是一个选择。我有理由相信，如果尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 今天还活着，他会继续使用他的模拟 Zettelkasten。模拟媒体中存在无法在数字工具中复制的魔力。我将在本书后面分享为什么我相信情况会如此。

**Principle #2: Numeric-alpha Notecard Addresses 原则 #2：数字字母记事卡地址**

Perhaps the most important principle in Luhmann’s notebox system is that of the numeric-alpha notecard addresses. Numeric-alpha refers to card addresses which start with a number and then are combined with alphabetical characters to branch down and internally expand to an infinite degree. This simple practice creates a self-referential object for every single one of your thoughts. This enables what Luhmann phrased, “the possibility of linking.”[208](#footnote-252) Linking thoughts is the very thing which enables the system to become self-referential in nature, a cybernetic network as Luhmann thought of it.[209](#footnote-251) 也许卢曼的记事本系统中最重要的原则是数字字母记事卡地址。数字字母是指以数字开头，然后与字母字符组合向下分支并在内部无限扩展的卡地址。这个简单的练习为你的每一个想法创造了一个自我参照的对象。这使得 Luhmann 所说的 “链接的可能性” 成为可能。 208 链接思想正是使系统在本质上成为自我参照的东西，正如 Luhmann 所认为的那样，这是一个控制论网络。 209

What is meant by addresses should also not be overlooked. In the first Zettelkasten Luhmann created in the 1950’s, he used a convention that employed commas for separating his different branches of thought in his Antinet. For instance, his notecard “5,1A” contained an excerpted quote by an author.[210](#footnote-250) In Luhmann’s second Zettelkasten, which was built specifically to help him with his thirty-year-long undertaking to create a unified theory of everything as it applies to society, he used a mix of slashes and periods and commas. For instance: ‘21/1,1’.[211](#footnote-249) I simply use the numeric-alpha scheme combined with slashes (I do not use commas or periods as separators). For instance: ‘27/2a/12’. I’ve yet to find it necessary or natural to use periods or commas. Regardless, we’ll explore in detail the specific schemes and practices of building your own Antinet later in the book. The beauty of the system is that there’s not a strict computer science protocol. There’s no scheme you must adhere to in order to work with the system. You can mold it and work with it in the way your brain most prefers (as long as you operate within the framework of the four principles I’m introducing now)! 地址的含义也不应被忽视。在 1950 年代创建的第一个 Zettelkasten Luhmann 中，他使用了一种约定，即在他的 Antinet 中使用逗号分隔他的不同思想分支。例如，他的记事卡 “5,1A” 包含一位作者的摘录。 210 在卢曼的第二个 Zettelkasten 中，它专门用于帮助他完成长达 30 年的工作，即创建适用于所有事物的统一理论在社会上，他混合使用了斜杠、句号和逗号。例如：‘21/1,1’.211 我只是使用数字字母方案和斜线组合（我不使用逗号或句点作为分隔符）。例如：“27/2a/12”。我还没有发现使用句号或逗号是必要的或自然的。无论如何，我们将在本书后面详细探讨构建您自己的 Antinet 的具体方案和实践。该系统的优点在于没有严格的计算机科学协议。没有您必须遵守的方案才能使用该系统。您可以按照您的大脑最喜欢的方式塑造它并使用它（只要您在我现在介绍的四个原则的框架内操作）！

Now back to the concept of card addresses for a moment. When people first see a card address like, ‘27/2a/12’ they immediately think it adheres to a hierarchical structure. The address does not indicate a hierarchy, however. It’s merely the location of where the leaf lives on a branch of your tree. Think of it more like a geographic coordinate system, like latitude and longitude (for instance ‘-77.0364,38.8951’). The periods do not connote a hierarchy; the address ‘27/2A/12’ could simply be represented as ‘27.2A.12’, and that would be just fine. It’s a matter of personal preference. 现在回到卡地址的概念。当人们第一次看到诸如 “27/2a/12” 之类的卡地址时，他们会立即认为它遵循层次结构。但是，该地址并不表示层次结构。它只是叶子在树枝上的位置。把它想象成一个地理坐标系，比如纬度和经度（例如‘-77.0364,38.8951’）。这些句点并不意味着等级制度。地址 “27/2A/12” 可以简单地表示为“27.2A.12”，这样就可以了。这是个人喜好的问题。

Anyway, we’re in the weeds here. Much about numeric-alpha addresses will be covered later on in this book. For now, just know that this is perhaps the most important principle of Luhmann’s four principles. It also happens to be the principle that people overthink the most, too! Assigning a numeric-alpha address to a notecard paralyzes people. It can be the thing that kills your progress. This all stems from one’s internal tendency towards perfectionism. Digital notetaking tools have trained many to be perfectionists (even at the expense of being productive). This tendency is something we’ll be fixing. With the Antinet you’ll learn to focus on what really matters: developing knowledge (not cutesy bubble graphs displaying connected digital notes). I’ll be teaching you to major in the major (instead of majoring in the minor). Don’t worry, I’m here to help in your recovery. 无论如何，我们在这里杂草丛生。本书稍后将详细介绍数字字母地址。现在，只知道这可能是卢曼四项原则中最重要的原则。这也恰好是人们最常想的原则！将数字字母地址分配给记事卡会使人瘫痪。它可能会扼杀你的进步。这一切都源于一个人内在的完美主义倾向。数字笔记工具已将许多人训练成完美主义者（甚至以牺牲生产力为代价）。这种趋势是我们要解决的问题。使用 Antinet，您将学会专注于真正重要的事情：发展知识（而不是显示连接数字笔记的可爱气泡图）。我会教你主修专业（而不是主修辅修）。别担心，我是来帮助你康复的。

Again, the importance of numeric-alpha addresses cannot be emphasized enough. It not only enables linking, it enables the self-referential composition of the Zettelkasten which gives it a unique personality. Luhmann holds this as one of the most important aspects of the system. The unique personality stands as the raw material which will help the Zettelkasten morph into an unexpected structure allowing you to communicate with the second mind, the doppelgänger, the ghost (or spirit, or mind) in the box, as Luhmann referred to it.[212](#footnote-248) This is the entity Luhmann was suggesting would communicate when he titled his paper, “Communication with Noteboxes.” Numeric-alpha addresses make this possible. 同样，数字字母地址的重要性怎么强调都不为过。它不仅可以实现链接，还可以实现 Zettelkasten 的自我参照组合，赋予其独特的个性。卢曼认为这是该系统最重要的方面之一。独特的个性作为原材料，将帮助 Zettelkasten 变成一个意想不到的结构，让你与第二个思想、二重身、盒子里的幽灵（或精神，或思想）交流，正如卢曼所说。 212 Luhmann 在将他的论文命名为 “与记事本交流” 时，建议使用这种实体进行交流。数字字母地址使这成为可能。

**Principle #3: Tree 原则 #3：树**

The third principle Luhmann specifies is a structure that allows for “the possibility of arbitrary internal branching.”[213](#footnote-247)Luhmann 指定的第三个原则是允许 “任意内部分支的可能性” 的结构。 213

Luhmann realized early on in life—thanks partly to his experiences being tortured by the so-called good guys at the end of World War II—that the world is not so simple. It’s quite complex. Reality resolves to nature, which resolves to chaos. If scientists seek to discover and publish the truth, then it’s necessary to accept chaos. Life is not a simple dualistic affair, as Luhmann discovered. It’s not always one of good vs. evil. The world is complex, and so is the human mind. 卢曼很早就意识到——部分归功于他在二战结束时被所谓的好人折磨的经历——世界并不是那么简单。这很复杂。现实归于自然，自然归于混沌。如果科学家试图发现并公布真相，那么就必须接受混乱。正如卢曼所发现的那样，生活并不是简单的二元对立的事情。它并不总是善与恶之一。世界是复杂的，人的思想也是如此。

With this understood, the question then becomes: how can one devise a system built on that which best models reality? Reality is chaos, yet it also emerges from ordered and simplistic rules (think the laws of thermodynamics). Reality (chaos) also emerges from simplistic parts (for instance, the atomic theory posits that matter is composed of particles called atoms). Reality is chaos built out of simple laws of order, and units of order. These simple laws and units of order bind the system together, allowing one to navigate complexity. It was with this in mind that Luhmann crafted his notebox system. 理解了这一点，问题就变成了：如何设计一个建立在最能模拟现实的系统之上的系统？现实是混乱的，但它也来自有序和简单的规则（想想热力学定律）。现实（混沌）也来自简单化的部分（例如，原子理论假定物质由称为原子的粒子组成）。现实是由简单的秩序法则和秩序单元构成的混乱。这些简单的法则和秩序单位将系统结合在一起，允许人们驾驭复杂性。考虑到这一点，Luhmann 设计了他的笔记本系统。

Within the current popularity of communities forming around Personal Knowledge Management (“PKM”) systems, it’s become a popular idea to embrace so-called dynamic systems—ones that are fluid and are built on things like wikilinks, and tags. An idea taught in the popular PKM course, Linking Your Thinking, preaches this idea in dogmatic fashion: “Folders are rigid and exclusionary by their nature. Whatever is in a folder lives separated from the main collection. It’s a rigid hierarchy that imposes order.”[214](#footnote-246) This notion, however, is mere pop-productivity opinion. Luhmann’s Zettelkasten was not dynamic, nor was it fluid. It could be argued that it was built entirely of folders (in the digital computer directory sense). The reason why a dynamic, fluid structure is one you ought not to strive for centers on the following fact: such a structure would be lacking in rough, unique conventions. It would lack a unique personality, which is what Luhmann’s system optimized for. In brief, it would not mirror the systems found in nature. 在当前流行的围绕个人知识管理 (“PKM”) 系统形成的社区中，拥抱所谓的动态系统已成为一种流行的想法——动态系统是流动的，建立在维基链接和标签等事物之上。流行的 PKM 课程 Linking Your Thinking 中教授的一个想法以教条的方式宣扬了这个想法：“文件夹本质上是僵化和排他性的。文件夹中的任何内容都与主要收藏分开。这是强加秩序的严格等级制度。”214 然而，这个概念仅仅是流行生产力的观点。 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 既不动态，也不流畅。可以说它完全是由文件夹构建的（在数字计算机目录意义上）。为什么动态的、流动的结构是你不应该追求的，原因在于以下事实：这样的结构将缺乏粗糙、独特的惯例。它会缺乏独特的个性，而这正是卢曼系统优化的目的。简而言之，它不会反映自然界中发现的系统。

Simply stated, Luhmann’s Zettelkasten structure was not dynamic or fluid in nature. Yet, it was not rigid, either. Examples of a rigid structure are classification systems like the Dewey Decimal System, or Paul Otlet’s massive notecard world museum known as The Mundaneum. These types of systems are useful for interpersonal knowledge systems; however, they’re not illustrative of what Niklas Luhmann’s system was: an intrapersonal knowledge system. Luhmann’s notebox system was not logically or neatly organized in a way that allowed for convenient public access. It was pure chaos to anyone (other than its creator) who perused its contents. In other words, Luhmann’s Zettelkasten was not a structure that could be characterized as one of order. 简单地说，卢曼的 Zettelkasten 结构本质上不是动态的或流动的。然而，它也不是严格的。严格结构的示例是杜威十进制系统之类的分类系统，或保罗 · 奥特莱特 (Paul Otlet) 的大型记事卡世界博物馆，即世界博物馆 (The Mundaneum)。这些类型的系统对于人际知识系统很有用；然而，它们并不能说明尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的系统是什么：一个内省知识系统。 Luhmann 的记事本系统在逻辑上或组织上都不够整齐，无法方便公众访问。对于仔细阅读其内容的任何人（除了它的创建者）来说，这都是纯粹的混乱。换句话说，卢曼的 Zettelkasten 不是一种可以被描述为秩序的结构。

In brief, Luhmann’s notebox system was not dynamic and fluid. Yet it was not one of order, either. 简而言之，卢曼的笔记系统不是动态的和流畅的。然而，这也不是秩序之一。

So what are we to think of Luhmann’s notebox system? In my experience using it, I find it to be more organic in nature. Like nature, it has laws and rules by which it operates; yet, it’s also subject to complete and total random choice. We know this because in describing it, Luhmann uses the word arbitrary to describe its arbitrary internal branching. Defined, arbitrary, means something that is decided randomly on personal whim.[215](#footnote-245) This arbitrary, random structure contributes to one of its greatest aspects—the aspect of surprises. Even though I’d call it an organic structure, that term seems rather trite. Other ways you can think of it is as a molecular structure, or an atomic structure. Yet, in recent time, concepts like atomicity, as I’ve touched on, have been overused and abstracted unnecessarily. Sure, atomicity could be considered a property of the Zettelkasten, but it could be argued atomicity is a property of nearly everything that is composed of matter! 那么我们应该如何看待卢曼的笔记系统呢？根据我使用它的经验，我发现它本质上更有机。就像大自然一样，它有运作的规律和规则；然而，它也受到完全和完全随机选择的影响。我们知道这一点是因为在描述它时，卢曼使用任意一词来描述其任意内部分支。定义的、任意的，是指根据个人心血来潮随机决定的事情。215 这种任意、随机的结构造就了它最重要的方面之一——惊喜方面。尽管我将其称为有机结构，但该术语似乎相当老套。您可以将其视为分子结构或原子结构的其他方式。然而，最近一段时间，像我提到的原子性这样的概念被过度使用和不必要地抽象化了。当然，原子性可以被认为是 Zettelkasten 的一个属性，但可以说原子性是几乎所有由物质组成的东西的属性！

Let’s not get carried away, however. Let’s jump back to the question: how are we to think of Luhmann’s notebox system? 但是，我们不要得意忘形。让我们回到这个问题：我们如何看待卢曼的笔记系统？

It’s actually quite simple, and I’ll share with you precisely how you should think of the Zettelkasten in just a moment. Until then, it’s important to close the loop on the characteristic which describes it. 其实很简单，稍后我将准确地与您分享您对 Zettelkasten 的看法。在此之前，关闭描述它的特征的循环很重要。

One of the scholars who studied Luhmann’s Zettelkasten closest is the researcher Johannes Schmidt from Bielefeld University in Germany. Bielefeld is the same university Luhmann worked at, and where he used his Zettelkasten to devise his impressive social theoretical work. It’s no coincidence that Schmidt knows Luhmann’s system so well. Schmidt has spent countless hours sifting through Luhmann’s notebox card-by-card in person. He’s currently the scientific coordinator of the project to digitize Luhmann’s notebox and publish its contents online for all to explore.[216](#footnote-244) According to Schmidt, Luhmann’s notebox system is “a rough structure.”[217](#footnote-243) It’s organized “by subject areas, which is reflected in the first number assigned to the card.”[218](#footnote-242) The characteristic which describes a Zettelkasten is simply this: it’s a rough structure that consists of both “order and disorder.”[219](#footnote-241) 对卢曼的 Zettelkasten 研究最密切的学者之一是德国比勒费尔德大学的研究员 Johannes Schmidt。比勒费尔德是卢曼工作过的同一所大学，他在那里使用他的 Zettelkasten 设计了他令人印象深刻的社会理论著作。施密特如此了解卢曼的体系并非巧合。施密特花了无数个小时亲自逐张筛选卢曼的笔记本。他目前是将卢曼笔记箱数字化并在线发布其内容供所有人探索的项目的科学协调员。216 根据施密特的说法，卢曼的笔记箱系统是 “一个粗略的结构”。217 它是“按学科领域组织的，这反映在分配给卡片的第一个数字。”218 描述 Zettelkasten 的特征很简单：它是一个由“有序和无序” 组成的粗略结构。”219

Now that we know the characteristic of a Zettelkasten not as a dynamic, fluid structure, nor a structure of complete order, we can think of it as a rough structure. Yet, knowing this gets us only so far. Knowing the abstract characteristic of a system is nice, yes, but not really that useful in practice. For this reason, I’ll share with you what I’ve found to be the best illustration of what type of structure a Zettelkasten is. 既然我们知道 Zettelkasten 的特征不是动态的、流动的结构，也不是完全有序的结构，我们可以将其视为粗略的结构。然而，知道这一点只能让我们走到这一步。了解系统的抽象特征很好，是的，但在实践中并不是那么有用。出于这个原因，我将与您分享我发现的最能说明 Zettelkasten 结构类型的内容。

Think of a Zettelkasten as a tree. A real tree. Not a tree that is platonic in nature. Not a diagram of a tree. Not a tree directory structure that you think of in computer science. Rather think of the Zettelkasten as an actual tree. What does an actual tree contain? It contains a trunk, branches, stems, vines, and leaves. We’ll go into detail on this later on in the book; but for now, think of each individual leaf as a notecard. With a Zettelkasten, you’ll be building trees of knowledge, one that has different trunks, different branches, different stems of thoughts, and even vines that link to other branches, allowing you to explore and swing between branches and trees. 将 Zettelkasten 想象成一棵树。一棵真正的树。不是柏拉图式的树。不是树图。不是您在计算机科学中想到的树目录结构。而是将 Zettelkasten 视为一棵真正的树。一棵真正的树包含什么？它包含树干、树枝、茎、藤蔓和叶子。我们稍后会在本书中对此进行详细介绍；但现在，将每一片叶子想象成一张记事卡。使用 Zettelkasten，您将构建知识之树，它有不同的树干、不同的树枝、不同的思想主干，甚至还有与其他树枝相连的藤蔓，让您可以探索并在树枝和树木之间摇摆。

The importance of the Zettelkasten’s tree-like structure should not be overlooked. Human memory works in a way that closely models tree-like structures. Even physically, the human brain, neurons, and neural networks follow branching structures. Some of the most beautiful tree-like images are the networks of the human brain: “If each nerve cell enlarged a thousand fold looks like a tree, then a small region of the nervous system at the same magnified scale resembles a gigantic, fantastic forest.”[220](#footnote-240)Zettelkasten 树状结构的重要性不容忽视。人类记忆的工作方式与树状结构密切相关。即使在物理上，人脑、神经元和神经网络也遵循分支结构。一些最美丽的树状图像是人脑的网络：“如果每个放大一千倍的神经细胞看起来像一棵树，那么同样放大的神经系统的一个小区域就像一个巨大的、奇妙的森林”220

The structure of your second mind (which is what a Zettelkasten, if built properly, will create) is critically important. It’s not just about storing information and creating cool bubble graphs of notes that link together (that’s what digital tools focus on); rather, it’s about exploration, as one scholar put it. The tree structure of the Zettelkasten enables meaningful exploration, as Alberto Cevolini points out: “secondary memories themselves have an inner order that allows for exploration.”[221](#footnote-239) 你的第二思维的结构（这是 Zettelkasten 的结构，如果构建得当，将会创建）是至关重要的。这不仅仅是关于存储信息和创建链接在一起的很酷的笔记气泡图（这是数字工具的重点）；相反，正如一位学者所说，它是关于探索的。 Zettelkasten 的树状结构使探索成为可能，正如 Alberto Cevolini 指出的那样：“次级记忆本身具有允许探索的内在秩序。”221

Later we’ll be exploring the tree structure of Luhmann’s Zettelkasten in more detail. We’ll be exploring how to think of it. More practically, we’ll be exploring how to leverage it to help you develop and evolve your knowledge over time. 稍后我们将更详细地探索 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的树结构。我们将探索如何思考它。更实际的是，我们将探索如何利用它来帮助您随着时间的推移发展和发展您的知识。

**Principle #4: Index 原则 #4：索引**

The last principle in Luhmann’s notebox system is the index. Luhmann calls this concept a “Register.”[222](#footnote-238) I prefer index, but you’re welcome to use whatever terminology you like best. You can think of the index as a map. It’s your map for exploring your own tree of knowledge. 卢曼笔记箱系统的最后一个原则是索引。 Luhmann 将此概念称为 “寄存器”。222 我更喜欢索引，但欢迎您使用您最喜欢的任何术语。您可以将索引视为地图。这是您探索自己的知识树的地图。

Say you’re traveling, staying in a new location and suddenly you realize you haven’t eaten all day. You’re starving. You think to yourself, I’m really craving In-N-Out Burger right now. You recall seeing an In-N-Out Burger the previous day, but since you’re traveling, you’re not sure how to get there. You pull out your phone, open your maps app, and then what do you do? Do you type in the latitude-longitude coordinates ‘32.7794303,-117.242262’? Or, instead, do you type in the human-memorable name known as ‘In-N-Out Burger’? Chances are you opt for the human-memorable name. This is precisely how to think of the index for your Zettelkasten. The index is a key-value associative array. They keyterm is the human-readable name, and the value is the location of the leaf on a tree in your Zettelkasten. For instance, here’s an example taken directly from my Zettelkasten: “Truth”: ‘5455/1’. 假设您正在旅行，住在一个新地方，突然发现您一整天都没有吃东西。你饿死了。你自己想想，我现在真的很想吃 In-N-Out 汉堡。您记得前一天看到了一个 In-N-Out 汉堡，但由于您正在旅行，您不确定如何到达那里。你拿出你的手机，打开你的地图应用程序，然后你做了什么？您是否输入经纬度坐标 “32.7794303,-117.242262”？或者，相反，您是否输入了被称为“In-N-Out Burger” 的人类记忆名称？您可能会选择易于记忆的名称。这正是您的 Zettelkasten 指数的思考方式。索引是一个键值关联数组。它们的关键字是人类可读的名称，值是 Zettelkasten 中树叶的位置。例如，这里有一个直接取自我的 Zettelkasten 的例子：“Truth”：‘5455/1’。

If you’re a software developer or programmer, and you’re familiar with data structures like JSON, or Python dictionaries, or YAML arrays, you can get pretty advanced with your index. You can create nested items of key-value pairs. If you’re not a nerd (or a wannabe nerd, like me), then don’t worry about this stuff. We’ll cover keyterms and the index in detail later on (and you won’t have to be a computer nerd to understand it). 如果您是一名软件开发人员或程序员，并且您熟悉 JSON、Python 字典或 YAML 数组等数据结构，那么您可以在索引方面取得相当高的水平。您可以创建键值对的嵌套项。如果你不是书呆子（或者像我一样想成为书呆子），那么不要担心这些东西。稍后我们将详细介绍关键字和索引（您不必是计算机呆子也能理解它）。

The bottom line is this: think of the index as your own map that enables you to swing onto a certain leaf, on a certain branch of a certain tree. From there, you can then continue exploring by reviewing the nearby stems of thoughts and the individual cards which, themselves, contain remote links. These remote links enable you to swing around to other leaves on other branches of your tree of knowledge. More on this will be revealed later in the book. But for now, you’re ready to be introduced to what an Antinet is composed of. 底线是：将索引视为您自己的地图，使您能够摆动到特定树叶、特定树的特定分支上。从那里，您可以通过查看附近的思想干和本身包含远程链接的个人卡片来继续探索。这些远程链接使您能够切换到知识树其他分支上的其他叶子。关于这一点的更多信息将在本书后面揭示。但现在，您已经准备好了解 Antinet 的组成部分。

**Introducing “The Antinet” 介绍 “Antinet”**

To summarize, these are the four principles of a Luhmannian Zettelkasten: 总而言之，这些是 Luhmannian Zettelkasten 的四个原则：

1. it is Analog;1. 它是模拟的；

2. it uses Numeric-alpha Addresses;2. 它使用数字字母地址；

3. it has a Tree Structure;3. 它有一个树结构；

4. and an Index.4. 和索引。

The first letters of each of those four things (“A”, “N”, “T”, “I”) are what make it an Antinet. 这四个东西的第一个字母（“A”、“N”、“T”、“I”）使它成为 Antinet。

Many people, when first coming across the term Antinet, may mistake it for being anti-digital, or anti-technology. This misinterpretation is something I understand, and frankly, something I take delight in. I snicker at the idea of ruffling people’s feathers because there’s a part of me that is a troll, just as Niklas Luhmann himself was. 许多人在第一次看到 Antinet 这个词时，可能会误以为它是反数字或反技术的。这种误解是我理解的，坦率地说，也是我喜欢的事情。我对激怒人们羽毛的想法嗤之以鼻，因为我的一部分是一个巨魔，就像尼克拉斯 · 卢曼本人一样。

The consequences of this aren’t the most pleasant, however. In my very early days sharing this knowledge, I was met with much resistance. In online forums whenever I answered Zettelkasten questions (from an analog perspective), I received polarized reactions. That is, I tended to receive a healthy supply of upvotes, and a heavy supply of downvotes. That’s fine with me. I deserved it; however, if you spent some time reading what I actually said, I was not as anti-digital as one would think. 然而，这样做的结果并不是最令人愉快的。在我分享这些知识的早期，我遇到了很多阻力。每当我回答 Zettelkasten 的问题时（从模拟的角度），我都会在在线论坛上收到两极化的反应。也就是说，我往往会收到大量的赞成票和大量的反对票。这对我来说没问题。我活该；然而，如果你花一些时间阅读我实际所说的话，我并不像人们想象的那样反对数字化。

To be clear, I am anti-digital when it comes to a knowledge development system such as the Antinet; but within reason. I understand that some people may operate and think better with digital tools. That’s fine. In my book you’ll find a section for those who refuse to give up digital media for working with knowledge. It’s a compromised version—I strongly believe that—but it may be useful for some. However after you read the science and rationale for an analog knowledge development system, I’m confident you’ll at least give such a system your best shot first. 需要明确的是，当涉及到像 Antinet 这样的知识开发系统时，我是反对数字化的；但在合理范围内。我了解有些人可能会使用数字工具更好地操作和思考。没关系。在我的书中，您会找到一个专为那些拒绝放弃数字媒体来处理知识的人准备的部分。这是一个妥协的版本——我坚信这一点——但它可能对某些人有用。然而，在你阅读了模拟知识开发系统的科学原理和基本原理之后，我相信你至少会首先尝试这样一个系统。

Now that I’ve explained what Antinet stands for, I will be using the term Antinet as the primary term through the remainder of this book (instead of Zettelkasten). Here and there I’ll drop in the term Zettelkasten; but my preferred term is Antinet. I choose to do this because today the term Zettelkasten connotes digital notetaking apps with linking capabilities. Also, the reason I don’t just use the term notebox system is because it’s already used for systems that simply store notecards categorically.[223](#footnote-237) 现在我已经解释了 Antinet 代表什么，我将在本书的其余部分使用术语 Antinet 作为主要术语（而不是 Zettelkasten）。在这里和那里，我会提到 Zettelkasten 这个词；但我更喜欢的术语是 Antinet。我选择这样做是因为今天 Zettelkasten 一词意味着具有链接功能的数字笔记应用程序。此外，我不只使用术语记事本系统的原因是因为它已经用于简单地分类存储记事卡的系统。 223

Before we move on, there’s one last thing you should know. It pertains to the net in Antinet. 在我们继续之前，还有最后一件事你应该知道。它与 Antinet 中的网络有关。

**The “Net” in “Antinet”“反网” 中的 “网”**

The net in Antinet refers to network. To Luhmann, the system he built was a cybernetic network. It was self-referential in nature because of its ability to cross-reference its contents through the numeric-alpha addresses.[224](#footnote-236)Antinet 中的 net 指网络。对卢曼来说，他建立的系统是一个控制论网络。它本质上是自引用的，因为它能够通过数字字母地址交叉引用其内容。 224

Luhmann, familiar with how human memory worked, understood how the brain is structured—as a network, just as we know it today—a network that possesses approximately 100 billion neurons and 200 trillion connections.[225](#footnote-235)Luhmann 熟悉人类记忆的工作原理，了解大脑的结构——就像我们今天所知道的那样——一个拥有大约 1000 亿个神经元和 200 万亿个连接的网络。 225

Now that you know the four principles of the notebox network Luhmann designed, you’re closer to understanding it. But there’s only one problem: you now know what an Antinet is, but you still have no idea what an Antinet really is. The four principles describe the parts of Luhmann’s system. They describe its fundamental raw “atomic” material. They do not describe the whole it creates—and trust me, the four parts do combine to create a whole greater than the sum of its parts. 了解了 Luhmann 设计的笔记本网络的四大原则后，就更接近理解它了。但只有一个问题：你现在知道 Antinet 是什么，但你仍然不知道 Antinet 到底是什么。这四个原则描述了卢曼系统的各个部分。他们描述了其基本的原始 “原子” 材料。他们没有描述它所创造的整体——相信我，这四个部分确实结合在一起创造了一个大于其部分之和的整体。

When the four principles are combined into a system, the Antinet becomes a thinking tool, a communication partner, and a second mind. They combine to produce many other novel phenomena, such as insightful surprises by way of ordered randomness. The Antinet becomes a system where thought is developed—both in the short term (by way of writing by hand, and thinking on paper) as well as the long term (by its branched architecture that stamps things in time that are most useful later on: this includes mistakes in your own thinking that are stamped in time, which will prove valuable). Also stamped in time is your own mind, and its own context, with its own links (that one thinks of at the time of writing and developing thought). In brief, there’s a temporal context which is stamped and installed into your Antinet. This context, this inner voice, if you will, then develops into a second mind enabling you to communicate with it, and in Luhmann’s terms, to ask it questions. It is the combination of all four principles which transform the Antinet from a mere notebox into a second mind.[226](#footnote-234) 当四大原则组合成一个系统时，Antinet 就成为了思维工具、沟通伙伴、第二思维。它们结合起来会产生许多其他新奇现象，例如通过有序随机性带来的富有洞察力的惊喜。 Antinet 成为一个思想发展的系统——无论是短期的（通过手写和纸上思考）还是长期的（通过它的分支架构及时标记事物，这些事物在以后最有用：这包括你自己思维中的错误，这些错误会被及时标记，这将证明是有价值的）。你自己的思想和它自己的上下文，以及它自己的链接（在写作和发展思想时想到的）也被及时打上了烙印。简而言之，有一个时间上下文被标记并安装到您的 Antinet 中。这个语境，这个内心的声音，如果你愿意的话，会发展成第二个头脑，使你能够与之交流，用卢曼的话来说，就是向它提问。正是所有四项原则的结合，将 Antinet 从单纯的笔记本变成了第二个头脑。 226

Magic takes place when the four principles interact in the Antinet.
