Johannes Schmidt observes that, when the four principles of an Antinet are combined, “all of them together create a complex cognitive system.”[227](#footnote-233) This is accomplished, through the four principles, in several ways: 当四个原则在 Antinet 中相互作用时，魔法就会发生。约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 观察到，当 Antinet 的四项原则结合在一起时，“所有这些原则共同创造了一个复杂的认知系统。”227 这是通过四项原则以多种方式实现的：

1. The neuroimprinting on the mind via its analog medium of writing by hand.1. 通过手写的模拟媒介在脑海中留下神经印记。

2. The “(selective) relations” between notes enabled via the numeric-alpha addresses.[228](#footnote-232)2. 通过数字字母地址启用音符之间的 “（选择性）关系”。 228

3. The “special filing technique”, with its infinite internal branching via the tree structure.[229](#footnote-231)3. “特殊归档技术”，通过树形结构进行无限的内部分支。 229

4. The index, which enables you to neuro-imprint ideas and cues in human- memorable language.4. 索引，它使您能够以人类容易记忆的语言在神经中烙印想法和线索。

All of these four elements interact and create unexpected effects, including reverberation—as it’s called in the science of human memory—allowing you to retain more knowledge and connections than you ever thought possible. You’ll begin to notice yourself reading differently. Certain index keyterms arise while reading; all you have to do is write the keyterm down on a notecard (called a “bibcard”). This is what Luhmann did. 所有这四个元素相互作用并产生意想不到的效果，包括混响——正如人类记忆科学中所说的那样——让你记住比你想象的更多的知识和联系。你会开始注意到自己的阅读方式有所不同。阅读时会出现某些索引关键词；您所要做的就是将关键字写在记事卡（称为 “bibcard”）上。这就是卢曼所做的。

As it relates to the four principles, this structure, as Johannes Schmidt observes, demonstrates how quickly the Antinet sets you on a path away from what one would deem ordered (and taxonomically sound). Although seemingly nonsensical, to the creator—that is, to you—the Antinet becomes perfectly natural to understand. One is led away from the original topic and to a variety of other subjects—ones that would not have initially been associated with one another.[230](#footnote-230) All of these incommunicable experiences are formed by the structure of the Antinet’s four principles. 正如 Johannes Schmidt 观察到的那样，由于与四项原则相关，这种结构展示了 Antinet 如何快速地让你走上一条远离人们认为有序（和分类合理）的道路。尽管看似荒谬，但对创作者（即对您）来说，Antinet 变得非常容易理解。一个人被带离了最初的主题，转向了各种其他主题——这些主题最初不会相互关联。230 所有这些不可交流的体验都是由 Antinet 的四项原则的结构形成的。

The whole of an Antinet is incommunicable—meaning, you’ll need to understand it yourself by experiencing it yourself. Don’t worry, though. I’ll be showing you precisely how to build your own Antinet a few chapters from now. Until then, I’d like to share with you a little bit more about what an Antinet really is.Antinet 的整体是不可沟通的——也就是说，你需要自己去体验它来理解它。不过别担心。从现在开始的几章中，我将准确地向您展示如何构建您自己的 Antinet。在那之前，我想与您分享更多有关 Antinet 到底是什么的信息。

**What an Antinet Really IsAntinet 到底是什么**
------------------------------------------

An Antinet, defined, is composed of four principles which form a knowledge system (as well as other systems) which in turn, transforms itself into a second mind.Antinet 被定义为由四个原则组成，这些原则形成了一个知识系统（以及其他系统），而该知识系统又将自身转变为第二思维。

From this definition, it may not seem like much, but there’s a lot to unpack here. Unpacking this definition is what I’ll be doing in this section. My goal centers on two things: first, to give you a glimpse of the metaphysical experience in working with an Antinet; and second, to do so in a way that isn’t boring as hell. Sound good? Let’s get started. 从这个定义来看，它可能看起来不多，但这里有很多东西要解压。解开这个定义是我将在本节中做的事情。我的目标集中在两件事上：首先，让您瞥见使用 Antinet 工作时的形而上学体验；其次，以一种不那么无聊的方式这样做。听起来不错？让我们开始吧。

**The Fundamentals of Knowledge Development 知识发展的基础**

We’ll be discussing the concept of knowledge development later. First, though, we need to understand the fundamental raw material of what we’re even working with as knowledge developers. The best place to start is merely with the question, What is a thought? 稍后我们将讨论知识发展的概念。不过，首先，我们需要了解我们作为知识开发人员正在使用的基本原材料。最好的起点只是问一个问题，什么是思想？

**What Is a “Thought”? 什么是 “思想”？**

The best way to understand what an Antinet really comes from asking what it contains. 了解 Antinet 的真正含义的最好方法是询问它包含什么。

What does an Antinet actually contain? Notes, yes. But what does a note contain? There are many types of notes, yes. But for all intents and purposes, a note contains one thing: a thought.Antinet 实际上包含什么？注释，是的。但是笔记包含什么？有很多种笔记，是的。但就所有意图和目的而言，一张纸条包含一件事：一个想法。

The latest research in cognitive neuroscience shows that the average person experiences 6,200 thoughts per day.[231](#footnote-229) Many of these thoughts are useful, yet they need some time to develop. They need what Luhmann referred to as rumination in order to sprout and grow. Unfortunately, most thoughts never have the chance to ruminate. Even if captured digitally, thinkers rarely undertake the practices necessary to sort and make use of all the information they encounter. Why? Simply because they quickly find themselves drowning in too much information (and as a result, too many thoughts). In other words, we experience thought overload—and this is especially the case for thoughts enmeshed in digital workflows. 认知神经科学的最新研究表明，普通人每天会经历 6,200 个想法。231 其中许多想法很有用，但需要一些时间来培养。他们需要卢曼所说的反刍才能发芽和成长。不幸的是，大多数想法从来没有机会反省。即使以数字方式捕获，思考者也很少进行必要的实践来分类和利用他们遇到的所有信息。为什么？仅仅是因为他们很快发现自己淹没在太多的信息中（结果是太多的想法）。换句话说，我们会经历思想过载——尤其是在数字工作流程中的思想中。

The problem of thought overload, however, is the very thing Luhmann figured out how to solve. By way of metaphor, Luhmann’s Antinet transforms one’s mind into a persistent, supercharged version of itself. Luhmann devised a knowledge structure for his thoughts which transformed his mind—and he admitted he was not naturally very proficient at remembering thoughts. 然而，思想超载的问题正是卢曼想出的解决方法。通过比喻，卢曼的 Antinet 将一个人的思想转变为一个持久的、增压的自我。卢曼为他的思想设计了一种知识结构，这改变了他的思想——他承认他天生就不太擅长记住思想。

Luhmann desired to create a marcescent tree of knowledge. A marcescent tree is one which never loses any of its leaves. It’s a phenomenon in nature. Like the leaves of a marcescent tree, Luhmann created a mind that never loses thoughts. Indeed, the Antinet is a mind that never loses its thoughts. It’s a marcescent tree. The only risk is if it catches on fire or is destroyed (which is something I’ll address later in this book).Luhmann 希望创造一棵有毒的知识树。落叶树是一种从不落叶的树。这是一种自然现象。卢曼就像一棵有毒的树的叶子，创造了一个永不失去思想的头脑。的确，Antinet 是一颗永远不会失去思想的头脑。这是一棵有毒的树。唯一的风险是它着火或被毁坏（这是我将在本书后面讨论的问题）。

OK, let’s now address the question: What actually is a thought in the first place?! For this answer, let’s turn to the dictionary for help. 好吧，现在让我们来解决这个问题：首先，思想到底是什么？！对于这个答案，让我们转向字典寻求帮助。

Perhaps the world’s biggest trolls are those working at Merriam-Webster who devised the definition for the word thought. By their definition, a thought is something that comes from thinking.[232](#footnote-228) How profound. If you look up the word thinking, you’ll learn that it’s something a mind does to produce thoughts.[233](#footnote-227) What we’re left with is a circular reference that doesn’t tell us very much. 也许世界上最大的巨魔是那些在 Merriam-Webster 工作的人，他们为思想这个词设计了定义。根据他们的定义，思想是来自思考的东西。232 多么深刻。如果你查找 “思考” 这个词，你会发现它是一种思想产生思想的行为。233 我们剩下的是一个循环引用，它并没有告诉我们太多信息。

Thankfully from the land of psychology emerges a definition of thought that is of more use: a thought is simply a representation of reality.[234](#footnote-226) In other words, a thought is a reflection or observation of reality. Such things are what you write down on a notecard. Its aim is to represent some aspect of reality (physical or metaphysical reality). 值得庆幸的是，从心理学领域出现了一个更有用的思想定义：思想只是现实的一种表现。234 换句话说，思想是对现实的反映或观察。这些事情就是你写在记事卡上的东西。它的目的是代表现实的某些方面（物理或形而上学的现实）。

Your thoughts do not live in an isolated universe. They’re shaped by several dimensions, which are constantly changing over the course of your life. Thoughts are a product of self, space, time, reverberation (recent behaviors and interests), and content (current context). These five dimensions stand essentially as a container which shapes a thought. More on this will be written about later in the book. For now it’s worth knowing that one of the core strengths of an Antinet is its ability to preserve not just the thought itself, but the container of dimensions in which a thought is formed. 你的思想并不生活在一个孤立的宇宙中。它们由多个维度塑造，这些维度在您的生活过程中不断变化。思想是自我、空间、时间、回响（最近的行为和兴趣）和内容（当前环境）的产物。这五个维度本质上是一个塑造思想的容器。本书稍后会详细介绍这一点。现在值得知道的是，Antinet 的核心优势之一是它不仅能够保存思想本身，而且能够保存形成思想的维度容器。

**What Is a “Memory”? 什么是 “记忆”？**

Great, now you know that a thought is. It’s your mind’s representation of reality. You also know that it’s shaped by several dimensions. 太好了，现在你知道念头是什么了。这是你的思想对现实的表现。你也知道它是由几个维度塑造的。

The next question is, what’s a memory? 下一个问题是，什么是记忆？

Before answering this question, one must delineate between a memory, and memory (as in human memory). We’ll start with what a memory is. 在回答这个问题之前，必须在记忆和记忆（如人类记忆）之间划清界限。我们将从什么是记忆开始。

Put simply, a memory is a stored representation of a thought. Like a thought, your memories are also a function of several dimensions which shape it. Scientific experiments in the study of human memory show that different brain regions process different dimensions attributed to a memory. This model of memory is called the attribute model of memory. To reiterate, the attribute model of memory asserts a view in which different brain regions process different dimensions of a memory. Like the dimensions of thought, the dimensions attributed to a memory include variables like space, time, sensory perceptions, and emotional aspects.[235](#footnote-225) 简而言之，记忆是思想的存储表示。就像一个想法，你的记忆也是塑造它的几个维度的函数。人类记忆研究中的科学实验表明，不同的大脑区域处理归因于记忆的不同维度。这种记忆模型称为记忆的属性模型。重申一下，记忆的属性模型断言不同的大脑区域处理不同维度的记忆。与思维维度一样，归因于记忆的维度包括空间、时间、感官知觉和情感方面等变量。 235

**What Is “Human Memory”? 什么是 “人类记忆”？**

Now we know what a thought is, and what a memory is. There’s only one more thing we ought to get on the same page about before trying to understand what an Antinet really is. 现在我们知道什么是思想，什么是记忆。在试图理解 Antinet 的真正含义之前，我们只需要再了解一件事。

But first, now is a good time to take a step back for a moment. Let’s answer the question of why it’s even important to understand what an Antinet really is. 但首先，现在是退后一步的好时机。让我们来回答为什么了解 Antinet 的真正含义如此重要的问题。

The reason it’s important is that by learning how knowledge development works, your own thinking, researching, and publishing output will be greatly enhanced. Even if you decide that building an Antinet is not for you, you can still greatly benefit from learning these concepts. Got it? Good. Let’s jump back into the fundamentals of knowledge development (thought, a memory, and human memory). 之所以重要，是因为通过了解知识开发的工作原理，您自己的思考、研究和发表成果将得到极大提高。即使您认为构建 Antinet 不适合您，您仍然可以从学习这些概念中受益匪浅。知道了？好的。让我们回到知识发展的基础（思想、记忆和人类记忆）。

The last thing you ought to know centers around what human memory is. 你应该知道的最后一件事围绕着人类记忆是什么。

The reason memory can be a confusing concept centers on the fact that a memory is different from plain ol’ memory. The term memory refers to the collective process of encoding, storing, and retrieving a memory. 记忆可能是一个令人困惑的概念的原因在于记忆与普通记忆不同这一事实。术语记忆是指编码、存储和检索记忆的集体过程。

Now that we know that a memory is a stored representation of a thought, and a thought is your mind’s representation of reality, effectively, human memory is your mind’s ability to encode, store, and retrieve representations of reality. 既然我们知道记忆是一种思想的存储表征，而思想是你的大脑对现实的表征，那么实际上，人类记忆是你的大脑编码、存储和检索现实表征的能力。

This is a greatly simplified conceptualization of human memory. Why? Simply because human memory is one of the last major unknowns in the field of neuroscience. Human memory is still a mystery.[236](#footnote-224) In my opinion, this is very exciting. Richard Feynman, the revered American theoretical physicist, observed it as “a very important problem which has not been solved at all.”[237](#footnote-223) 这是人类记忆的一个大大简化的概念化。为什么？仅仅是因为人类记忆是神经科学领域最后的主要未知数之一。人类的记忆仍然是一个谜。236 在我看来，这是非常令人兴奋的。受人尊敬的美国理论物理学家理查德 · 费曼 (Richard Feynman) 认为这是 “一个非常重要的问题，但根本没有解决。”237

Luhmann was familiar with how human memory works. He understood it not as something composed of one thing; rather, he knew it as something composed of trillions of connections built on association. The concept of association shall be discussed later in the book. According to Richard Yeo, memory isn’t something that happens in the brain alone. It’s more complex than that. Memory is “often distributed across heterogenous systems combining neural, bodily, social, and technological resources.”[238](#footnote-222) 卢曼熟悉人类记忆的工作原理。他不把它理解为由一个东西组成的东西；相反，他认为它是由建立在关联基础上的数万亿个连接组成的。关联的概念将在本书后面讨论。根据 Richard Yeo 的说法，记忆不仅仅发生在大脑中。它比那更复杂。记忆 “通常分布在结合了神经、身体、社会和技术资源的异构系统中。”238

There are different lenses and models scholars use to study human memory. I won’t get into them now, nor will I get into the pros and cons of each. The tendency to overcomplicate things plagues the disciplinary field of human memory studies (and, let’s be honest, many academic fields as well). Often, scholars fall prey to the complexity cognitive fallacy. They overcomplicate ideas, filling them with unnecessary technobabble when trying to explain something even they don’t understand yet.[239](#footnote-221) This is why, for now, and for our purposes, the simple definition of human memory I laid out previously will more than suffice in aiding our understanding of what an Antinet really is. 学者们使用不同的镜头和模型来研究人类记忆。我现在不会讨论它们，也不会讨论每种方法的优缺点。将事物过于复杂化的趋势困扰着人类记忆研究的学科领域（老实说，许多学术领域也是如此）。通常，学者们会陷入复杂性认知谬误。他们使想法过于复杂，在试图解释一些甚至他们还不理解的事情时给他们灌输不必要的技术术语。 239 这就是为什么，就目前而言，为了我们的目的，我之前提出的人类记忆的简单定义将足以满足帮助我们理解 Antinet 的真正含义。

Before moving on, here’s a summary of the three fundamental components of knowledge development we’ve just learned: 在继续之前，这里是我们刚刚学到的知识发展的三个基本组成部分的总结：

● A thought is your mind’s representation of reality.● 思想是你头脑对现实的表现。

● A memory is a stored representation of a thought.● 记忆是思想的存储表征。

● Human memory is the collective process of encoding, storing, and retriev  ing a memory.● 人类记忆是编码、存储和检索记忆的集体过程。

**What Is “Reality”? 什么是 “现实”？**

For the sake of moving forward, I’m tempted to dive right into addressing what an Antinet really is; however, I simply can’t. 为了继续前进，我很想直接讨论 Antinet 的真正含义；但是，我就是做不到。

Here’s why: if you review the definitions of the three concepts I’ve laid out previously, there’s one concept I haven’t properly addressed yet. That concept is, reality. 原因如下：如果您回顾一下我之前列出的三个概念的定义，就会发现有一个概念我还没有正确解决。这个概念就是现实。

I bet you didn’t think you’d be faced with the question what is reality? when you began reading about something called an ‘Antinet’; but alas, here we are. I’m not going to dive too deeply into the solving of the question of reality right now, but I’ll give you a better understanding than you might otherwise have had. In brief, no two people share the same reality (it’s, like, relative, man). In all seriousness, Einstein proved reality is not one fixed state. Reality is really an infinite number of unique realities that depend on where you are, and how fast you’re moving in spacetime.[240](#footnote-220) More pragmatically, there are three types of reality: (1) objective reality, which are things like gravity that we all experience, (2) subjective reality, such as pain or another sensation one might experience, and (3) inter-subjective reality, which include shared beliefs and sociological concepts (like money, politics, and power).[241](#footnote-219) 我打赌你不认为你会面临什么是现实的问题？当您开始阅读有关 “Antinet” 的内容时；但是，唉，我们到了。我现在不打算深入探讨现实问题的解决方案，但我会给你一个比其他人更好的理解。简而言之，没有两个人共享相同的现实（就像亲戚一样）。严肃地说，爱因斯坦证明了现实不是一种固定状态。现实实际上是无限数量的独特现实，这取决于你在哪里，以及你在时空中移动的速度。240 更实用地说，现实分为三种类型：(1) 客观现实，就像引力一样，我们所有经验，(2) 主观现实，例如疼痛或一个人可能经历的另一种感觉，以及 (3) 主体间现实，包括共同的信仰和社会学概念（如金钱、政治和权力）。 241

From a philosophical perspective, the concept of reality has been debated for aeons. There are different ontological positions describing reality. These positions include monism, dualism, pluralism, and my favorite—dialectical monism. I’m not going to continue any further down the philosophical discussion of reality, but for now, think of reality as any physical or metaphysical truth you experience. By physical truth, this refers to that which your sensory system detects in your environment (sight, smell, taste, touch, sound). By metaphysical truth, this refers to that which your mind (or body—via intuition) detects, experiences, and believes to be true. These sensations and insights are your reality, and they’re represented in thought. 从哲学的角度来看，现实的概念已经争论了很久。存在描述现实的不同本体论立场。这些立场包括一元论、二元论、多元论和我最喜欢的辩证一元论。我不打算继续对现实进行哲学讨论，但现在，将现实视为您体验到的任何物理或形而上学的真理。就物理事实而言，这是指您的感官系统在您的环境中检测到的（视觉、嗅觉、味觉、触觉、声音）。通过形而上学的真理，这是指你的思想（或身体——通过直觉）检测、体验并相信是真实的。这些感觉和洞察力就是你的现实，它们在思想中得到了体现。

OK, whew! We’ve now successfully gone down the metaphysical and theoretical rabbit-hole. We’ve addressed what thought is, what a memory is, what human memory is, and what reality is. Here’s a full summary of four fundamental components involved in knowledge development: 好的，哇！我们现在已经成功地进入了形而上学和理论的兔子洞。我们已经解决了什么是思想，什么是记忆，什么是人类记忆，什么是现实。以下是知识开发所涉及的四个基本组成部分的完整摘要：

● A thought is your mind’s representation of reality.● 思想是你头脑对现实的表现。

● A memory is a stored representation of a thought.● 记忆是思想的存储表征。

● Human memory is the collective process of encoding, storing, and retrieving a memory.● 人类记忆是编码、存储和检索记忆的集体过程。

● Reality is any physical or metaphysical truth you experience.● 实相是你体验到的任何物理或形而上学的真理。

**Your Ultimate Task When Working with an Antinet 使用 Antinet 时的终极任务**

What we could technically do next is chase down the definition and our understanding of truth. Ultimately this exercise is never-ending. Like the Antinet, the truth of the cosmos is a self-referential, recursive beast. It’s filled with seemingly never-ending paradoxes that point back to its self.[242](#footnote-218) For an example of what I mean by self-referential, let’s take the dictionary’s definition of truth. The Oxford English Dictionary defines truth as “the quality or state of being true.”[243](#footnote-217) That’s as self-referential as it gets right there, and that’s the truth (I couldn’t help it). In brief, we can define truth simply as that which we believe as true. From there we can explore the concept of belief, but I’m going to stop now before someone gets hurt. 从技术上讲，我们接下来可以做的是追查定义和我们对真理的理解。最终，这个练习是永无止境的。就像 Antinet 一样，宇宙的真相是一种自我参照、递归的野兽。它充满了看似永无止境的悖论，这些悖论指向它的自我。 242 为了说明我所说的自我参照的一个例子，让我们以字典对真理的定义为例。牛津英语词典将真理定义为 “真实的品质或状态”。243 这就是自我指涉，这就是真理（我情不自禁）。简而言之，我们可以简单地将真理定义为我们相信为真的事物。从那里我们可以探索信念的概念，但我现在要在有人受伤之前停下来。

Ultimately, as knowledge developers, and knowledge creators, we’re all in the business of truth. When using an Antinet and writing down your thoughts in the form of notes, the ultimate goal is to write down your truth—and to do it honestly. This directive is deathly serious. One of the most critical factors that will make your time building an Antinet worthwhile is to write down as honestly as possible, your truth. For example, “The author mentions rumination and surprise, but I fail to see the significance of such things.” Or, “I honestly have no idea what my goal is with learning an Antinet at this point, and the reason why is x.” Or, “What the author says makes a lot of sense; however, I’ve already invested so much time building thousands of digital notes using tool x. If I switch now, who’s to say I won’t just switch again to a new knowledge tool three months from now!”[244](#footnote-216) 归根结底，作为知识开发者和知识创造者，我们都在从事真理的工作。当使用 Antinet 并以笔记的形式写下你的想法时，最终目标是写下你的真相——并且诚实地去做。这个指令非常严重。让你花时间构建 Antinet 的最关键因素之一是尽可能诚实地写下你的真相。例如，“作者提到了反省和惊奇，但我看不到这些东西的意义。” 或者，“老实说，我现在不知道我学习 Antinet 的目标是什么，以及为什么是 x 的原因。” 或者，“作者说的很有道理；但是，我已经投入大量时间使用工具 x 构建了数千个数字笔记。如果我现在切换，谁能保证我不会在三个月后再次切换到新的知识工具！”244

Writing your honest truth results in you taking your Antinet seriously. It will mitigate the risk of ever abandoning it. Perhaps most importantly, it will result in creating and publishing genius-level work built to inspire others for centuries. 写下你诚实的真相会让你认真对待你的 Antinet。它将降低永远放弃它的风险。也许最重要的是，它将创造和出版天才级的作品，这些作品几个世纪以来一直激励着其他人。

We humans have a very keen sense of bullshit. People are better than you think at detecting bullshit. We can tell when someone’s writing the truth, and when someone’s writing something just to sell books. The way to sell books is, paradoxically, to not try to sell books! The way to sell books is to write the truth—your truth. And that starts by writing the truth in the form of notes. This doesn’t only apply to writing books, it applies to any form of creative output (e.g. music, plays, songwriting, etc.). The bottom line is that, with the Antinet, the name of the game is writing your truth, as honestly as possible. 我们人类对废话有一种非常敏锐的感觉。人们比你想象的更善于发现废话。我们可以分辨出什么时候有人在写真话，什么时候有人只是为了卖书而写东西。矛盾的是，卖书的方法就是不要试图卖书！卖书的方法就是写出真相——你的真相。这首先要以笔记的形式写下真相。这不仅适用于写书，它适用于任何形式的创意输出（例如音乐、戏剧、歌曲创作等）。最重要的是，对于 Antinet，游戏的名称是尽可能诚实地写下你的真相。

In Ernest Hemingway’s fantastic non-fiction book, Death in the Afternoon, he takes the reader through the world of bullfighting. While it’s a seemingly grotesque sport—especially in modern times—it is a book I highly recommend reading if one wishes to observe what I mean by writing the truth. It’s a master-course for what good writing is. In the book he writes of bullfighting, “I should not try to defend it now, only to tell honestly the things I have found true about it.”[245](#footnote-215) Like Hemingway, your ultimate task when developing your thoughts in the Antinet concerns itself with one thing: it’s to tell honestly the things you find to be true. 在欧内斯特 · 海明威 (Ernest Hemingway) 精彩的非小说类书籍《午后之死》(Death in the Afternoon) 中，他带领读者穿越了斗牛的世界。虽然这是一项看似怪诞的运动——尤其是在现代——如果有人想观察我写下真相的意思，我强烈推荐阅读这本书。这是一门关于什么是好的写作的大师课程。在他写的关于斗牛的书中，“我现在不应该试图为它辩护，而只是诚实地讲述我所发现的关于斗牛的真实情况。”245 就像海明威一样，在 Antinet 中发展你的思想时，你的最终任务与一个事情：诚实地说出你认为是真的事情。

**Why an Antinet Is Not About Storing Notes 为什么 Antinet 与存储笔记无关**

An Antinet is not an analog note database. It’s not even about storing notes. The Antinet concerns itself with the dualistic emergence of a second mind. A second mind is formed by properly integrating the four principles of the Antinet, and implementing an effective workflow enabling it to operate as a thinking system.Antinet 不是模拟笔记数据库。它甚至与存储笔记无关。 Antinet 关注第二思想的二元性出现。通过适当整合反网络的四项原则，并实施有效的工作流程，使其能够作为思维系统运作，从而形成第二思维。

An Antinet is not a notetaking system; it’s not a notetaking app based on the functionality of linking notes (that is, wikilinks). To its creator (Niklas Luhmann), the Antinet was not “just an analog database,” writes Johannes Schmidt.[246](#footnote-214) It was not a container for storing notes; it was not chaotic for its creator either. The Antinet “was not a maze but a thinking tool, a communication partner, and a publication machine.”[247](#footnote-213)Antinet 不是笔记系统；它不是基于链接笔记（即维基链接）功能的笔记应用程序。 Johannes Schmidt 写道，对于它的创建者（Niklas Luhmann）来说，Antinet 不仅仅是 “一个模拟数据库”。246 它不是存储笔记的容器；它的创造者也并不混乱。 Antinet“不是迷宫，而是思维工具、通信伙伴和出版机器。”247

The problem with thinking of the Antinet as a notetaking system is that, well, it’s not a notetaking system! The term notetaking connotes the idea that you’re writing down facts or thoughts that are already formed. Luhmann’s Antinet was not a notetaking system. Hell, even the principles of an Antinet are not that important if the only thing they yield is the better taking of notes. The reason why an Antinet is important centers on the benefits it yields for one’s mind and thoughts. The Antinet is a thinking system because it transforms the way one thinks. It also is a thought system because it develops thought, both in the short term and the long term. 将 Antinet 视为笔记系统的问题在于，好吧，它不是笔记系统！记笔记一词意味着您正在写下已经形成的事实或想法。卢曼的 Antinet 不是一个笔记系统。地狱，如果 Antinet 的唯一原则是更好地记笔记，那么它们也不是那么重要。 Antinet 重要的原因在于它对人的思想和思想产生的好处。 Antinet 是一种思维系统，因为它改变了一个人的思维方式。它也是一个思想系统，因为它在短期和长期发展思想。

The key differentiator between an Antinet and a digital notetaking app is precisely that the Antinet is a thinking system.Antinet 和数字笔记应用程序之间的关键区别恰恰在于 Antinet 是一个思维系统。

The Antinet, when used properly, and when its four principles are involved, results in one’s thinking being transformed. The way you read books and recall thoughts changes in the course of using the Antinet. It’s an incommunicable experience, and something I’ll be touching on throughout the book.Antinet 如果使用得当，当涉及到它的四个原则时，就会导致一个人的思想发生转变。在使用 Antinet 的过程中，您阅读书籍和回忆想法的方式会发生变化。这是一种不可言传的体验，我将在整本书中谈到这一点。

Digital notetaking apps, on the other hand, can perhaps be employed to develop thought. Even then, a digital notetaking app’s effectiveness is watered down because it naturally omits the first principle of the Antinet (analog). 另一方面，数字笔记应用程序或许可以用来发展思维。在这方面，它们可以被认为是思想系统；然而，它们不能被描述为一个思维系统（除非它们是通过 Antinet 的四项原则正确构建的）。即便如此，数字笔记应用程序的有效性也会被削弱，因为它自然而然地忽略了 Antinet（模拟）的第一原则。

The analog principle is critical because it involves writing by hand. From using the Antinet, it could be postulated that Luhmann’s mind grew in two areas: (1) memory span of thought (or thought-span), and (2) neuro-associative recall. 通过使用 Antinet，可以假设卢曼的思维在两个方面得到了发展：(1) 思维的记忆广度（或思想广度），以及 (2) 神经联想回忆。

Let’s explore both of these concepts now. 现在让我们探讨这两个概念。

**The Antinet’s Effect on the “Memory Span” of Thoughts (“Thought-Span”)Antinet 对思想 “记忆广度”（“Thought-Span”）的影响**

Within the field of memory research, scientists use the term memory span to refer to the minimum number of items one can recall. 在记忆研究领域，科学家使用术语记忆广度来指代一个人可以回忆的最少项目数。

Related experiments traditionally focus on more rudimentary recall tasks. They entail asking participants to recall a list of words, letters, or digits.[248](#footnote-212) The goal with an Antinet is to develop your memory span not for words, letters, or digits; but to develop your memory span for thought. That is, the goal is to develop the mind to instantly recall thoughts, and to recall as many thoughts as possible. This is what is meant by thought-span.[249](#footnote-211) 相关实验传统上侧重于更基本的回忆任务。它们需要要求参与者回忆单词、字母或数字的列表。248 Antinet 的目标是扩展您的记忆范围，而不是单词、字母或数字；但要发展你的记忆跨度。也就是说，我们的目标是培养大脑立即回忆起想法，并尽可能多地回忆起想法。这就是思想跨度的意思。 249

How is it possible to develop the memory span of thoughts? This is achieved through neuroimprinting thoughts on your mind via something called elaborative rehearsal in the field of human memory. Also involved is maintenance rehearsal. Both of these processes are procured by a feature innate to the Antinet by way of its first principle (analog). Before moving on, let’s take a moment to address what is meant by the term neuroimprinting. 如何发展思维的记忆广度？这是通过在人类记忆领域中称为精心排练的东西在你的脑海中留下神经印记的想法来实现的。还涉及维护排练。这两个过程都是通过 Antinet 的第一原理（模拟）与生俱来的特性实现的。在继续之前，让我们花点时间了解一下神经印记一词的含义。

By trade, I was a copywriter in my previous professional life. Today, I am more generally, a writer. I was a good copywriter—scratch that—I was really good. My experience as a copywriter provided me with the greatest gift one could ask for: a lime green Lamborghini. 通过贸易，我在以前的职业生涯中是一名撰稿人。今天，我更普遍地是一名作家。我是一个很好的撰稿人——从头开始——我真的很棒。我作为文案撰稿人的经历为我提供了一个人可能会要求的最好的礼物：一辆柠檬绿兰博基尼。

Here’s the point: I’ve had a lot of success as a copywriter, which has gifted me with the time of writing right now, to you. If you write out a great poem by keyboard, it will be imprinted on your screen. If you write out a great poem by hand, it will be imprinted on your soul. 如果你用键盘写出一首伟大的诗，它就会印在你的屏幕上。如果你亲手写出一首伟大的诗，它就会烙印在你的灵魂上。

**the deep roots of neuroimprinting 神经印记的深层根源**

It can be argued that neuroimprinting is a biological term observed to occur in infant birds, such as geese, ducks, and chickens.[252](#footnote-208) However I believe the concept to be less formal in nature (scientifically). Regardless, I hold the concept of neuroimprinting to be true because of empirical evidence. 可以争辩说，神经印记是观察到的一个生物学术语，出现在幼鸟身上，例如鹅、鸭子和鸡。252 然而，我认为这个概念在自然界（科学上）不太正式。无论如何，由于经验证据，我认为神经印记的概念是正确的。

The concept of neuroimprinting has rich and deep roots in scholarship. The scholar Francesco Sacchini (1570–1625) cites ancients who copied down texts. He explains they did such a practice not in order to have copies of them, but in order to better retain the knowledge.[253](#footnote-207) 神经印记的概念在学术界有着丰富而深刻的根源。学者弗朗切斯科 · 萨基尼（Francesco Sacchini，1570-1625 年）引用古人抄录的文字。他解释说，他们这样做不是为了复制，而是为了更好地保留知识。 253

Sacchini recounts a story of Demosthenes copying down Thucydides eight times in order to understand the ideas more thoroughly. Sacchini also asserts that Saint Jerome (342–420 ad) wrote many volumes by hand, “not due to the weakness of his library but out of desire to profit from the exercise.”[254](#footnote-206)Sacchini 讲述了德摩斯梯尼 (Demosthenes) 八次抄袭修昔底德 (Thucydides) 的故事，以便更透彻地理解其中的思想。 Sacchini 还断言，Saint Jerome（公元 342-420 年）手写了很多书，“不是因为他的图书馆薄弱，而是出于从中获利的愿望。”254

The New England preacher Richard Steele wrote in 1682: “The very writing of any thing fixes it deeper in the mind.”[255](#footnote-205) 新英格兰传教士理查德 · 斯蒂尔 (Richard Steele) 在 1682 年写道：“任何事物的书写本身都会将它深深地固定在脑海中。”255

At Harvard College in the late seventeenth century, students were taught in the following manner. They were given the assignment to write down textbooks bought in England, by hand.[256](#footnote-204) It may sound like a lazy way of teaching; however, there remains a serious argument for the power of teaching students by making them write out knowledge by hand. We have moved away from the practice in modern times, but it’s something that may warrant revisiting. 在 17 世纪后期的哈佛大学，学生们的教学方式如下。他们的任务是手写在英国购买的教科书。256 这听起来像是一种懒惰的教学方式；然而，对于通过让学生手写知识来教授学生的力量，仍然存在着严肃的争论。我们已经摆脱了现代的做法，但这可能值得重新审视。

**The Antinet’s Effect: Neuro-Associative RecallAntinet 效应：神经联想回忆**

By neuroimprinting thoughts on your mind, via writing by hand, you’re primed to develop the most important muscle for recognizing and installing important thoughts from the books you read. The “muscle” I’m referring to is the neuro-associative recall “muscle” of your brain. The strength of your neuro-associative recall muscle is predicated on the analog principle of the Antinet. It’s also predicated on the index principle of the Antinet. The index principle forces you to imprint a term onto your mind. That term then maps to a specific numeric-alpha address. Without these two principles, you lose the ability to exercise and strengthen the neuro-associative recall muscle. In other words, when using an Antinet you’re training your memory by lengthening the memory span in which to recall a thought. You’re doing so by neuroimprinting a cue (in the form of a keyterm). This cue acts as a way to immediately recall thoughts to your mind. This exercises your neuro-associative recall muscle, which transforms your brain. While reading you’ll suddenly spot an idea or a thought. Instead of thinking of this thought as something new, you’ll immediately think of the keyterm it relates to in the Antinet. This better allows you to classify the idea, associate the idea, and then develop the current knowledge that you have of the thought. All of this, again, is founded on the four key principles of the Antinet. It’s specifically founded on two of those principles working together (analog and index). If it’s not apparent by now, it should start to become more obvious why the four principles are so critical for developing the type of system Luhmann used. When you strip the system of such functionality (which is what digital Zettelkasten do), you prevent such phenomena from happening. 通过手写，在你的脑海中留下神经印记，你准备好发展最重要的肌肉，从你读过的书中识别和植入重要的想法。我指的 “肌肉” 是大脑的神经联想回忆“肌肉”。您的神经联想回忆肌肉的强度取决于 Antinet 的模拟原理。它也是基于 Antinet 的索引原理。索引原则迫使你将一个术语铭记在心。该术语然后映射到特定的数字字母地址。没有这两个原则，您将失去锻炼和增强神经联想回忆肌肉的能力。换句话说，当你使用 Antinet 时，你是在通过延长回忆一个想法的记忆跨度来训练你的记忆力。你是通过给一个提示（以关键词的形式）留下神经印记来做到这一点的。这个提示可以让你立即回忆起你的想法。这会锻炼你的神经联想回忆肌肉，从而改变你的大脑。阅读时你会突然发现一个想法或想法。您不会将此想法视为新事物，而是会立即想到它在 Antinet 中相关的关键词。这更好地允许您对想法进行分类，关联想法，然后发展您对想法的当前知识。同样，所有这一切都建立在 Antinet 的四个关键原则之上。它专门建立在其中两个原则的基础上（模拟和索引）。如果现在还不明显，那么应该开始变得更加明显，为什么这四个原则对于开发卢曼使用的系统类型如此重要。当您剥离系统的此类功能（这是数字 Zettelkasten 所做的）时，您就可以防止此类现象的发生。

When you use a physical thinking tool like the Antinet, you end up exercising your brain and its various “muscles,” and its various pathways. There’s no easy-way out; no lazy search mechanism that enables you to avoid thinking and associating ideas. It may seem outdated at first, but I assure you, a system that requires you to think and exercise your mind beats the latest and greatest digital app every time. Why? Because the best computer you’ll ever have is the one already operating inside your skull. Using an Antinet results in developing this organ; it could be argued that digital tools work in the opposite direction—perhaps they even tend to degrade your thinking. 当你使用像 Antinet 这样的物理思维工具时，你最终会锻炼你的大脑及其各种 “肌肉” 及其各种通路。没有捷径可走；没有使您避免思考和联想想法的惰性搜索机制。一开始它可能看起来过时了，但我向你保证，一个需要你思考和锻炼头脑的系统每次都胜过最新最好的数字应用程序。为什么？因为您将拥有的最好的计算机是已经在您的头骨中运行的计算机。使用 Antinet 会导致该器官发育；可以说数字工具的作用恰恰相反——也许它们甚至会削弱你的思维。

**The Antinet Is Not in the Same Category as “Notetaking Apps”Antinet 与 “笔记应用程序” 不属于同一类别**

Notetaking apps primarily concern themselves with storing information that is mostly developed already. With an Antinet system you’re developing thoughts primarily through the process of writing them down by hand. It is a thinking system because it produces thoughts. It’s not the best tool for storing already thought-about information; though that does indeed have major benefits (neuroimprinting the great ideas and work of others on your mind). Primarily, the Antinet is a tool for developing information into knowledge—knowledge being your own thoughts. 笔记应用程序主要关注自己存储大部分已经开发的信息。使用 Antinet 系统，你主要是通过手写的过程来形成想法。它是一个思维系统，因为它产生思想。它不是存储已经考虑过的信息的最佳工具；尽管这确实有很大的好处（将他人的伟大想法和工作印在你的脑海中）。首先，Antinet 是一种将信息转化为知识的工具——知识就是你自己的想法。

The primary benefit of a digital notetaking app is its storage capacity. People seem to find comfort in digitally storing notes and syncing them across devices. They prefer this, without realizing they are prioritizing storage over the more crucial benefit: developing and evolving thought. It is my belief that a system that develops and evolves thought into developed thought is preferable to a system that merely stores (and links) undeveloped thought. Paradoxically, it seems that digital notetaking apps ultimately do a worse job of storing thoughts. Why? Because information is encountered less frequently, and thus recalled less frequently by the user than the knowledge stored in an Antinet. Why? Because digital information faces the perennial issue of generating a black hole of too much information. 数字笔记应用程序的主要优势在于其存储容量。人们似乎对以数字方式存储笔记并在设备间同步它们感到很舒服。他们更喜欢这个，却没有意识到他们将存储置于更重要的好处之上：发展和进化思想。我相信，一个将思想发展并演化为发达思想的系统比仅存储（和链接）未发展思想的系统更可取。矛盾的是，数字笔记应用程序似乎最终在存储思想方面做得更差。为什么？因为与 Antinet 中存储的知识相比，信息遇到的频率较低，因此用户调用的频率也较低。为什么？因为数字信息面临着产生过多信息黑洞的长期问题。

**Why an Antinet Is Not a “Memory System” 为什么 Antinet 不是 “记忆系统”**

While an Antinet is a thinking system; it’s not only that type of system. It comprises other systems: it is a memory system, but not only a memory system; it’s also a sorting system, and a search system. Markus Krajewski has observed that an Antinet is not just a “memory aid” for recalling thoughts. It’s also, (1) a “sorting aid” (for sorting through thoughts), (2) a “search engine” (by way of index), and (3) a “computer” (in German, Rechenmaschine), “in the strict etymological sense of rechnen as ‘to organize’, ‘to guide’ and ‘to prepare’.”[257](#footnote-203)Antinet 是一个思维系统；不仅是那种类型的系统。它包含其他系统：它是一个记忆系统，但不仅仅是一个记忆系统；它也是一个分类系统和一个搜索系统。 Markus Krajewski 观察到 Antinet 不仅仅是用于回忆思想的 “记忆辅助工具”。它还是，(1) 一个 “分类辅助工具”（用于整理思想），(2) 一个 “搜索引擎”（通过索引），以及 (3) 一个 “计算机”（德语，Rechenmaschine），“在 rechnen 的严格词源意义是‘组织’、‘引导’和‘准备’。”257

Another way of phrasing it is that an Antinet acts as a pre-processing engine allowing your thoughts to become ruminated on, fixed, corrected, recorrected, and matured. All of this happens before even writing the first word of your book, paper, essay, dissertation, blog post, or anything else. The way in which a thought forms and evolves is also different compared to how it would otherwise evolve in digital notetaking apps. 另一种表达方式是，Antinet 充当预处理引擎，让您的思想得到反省、固定、纠正、再纠正和成熟。所有这一切都发生在你写书、论文、论文、论文、博客文章或其他任何东西的第一个词之前。思想形成和演变的方式也不同于它在数字笔记应用程序中的演变方式。

A key reason the Antinet is not a memory system, but more of a thinking system, centers on its proficiency in bringing to the surface parts of your thinking that are, upon further rumination, potentially not entirely correct. The Antinet, thanks to its structure and analog design, allows for proactive interference. It does this in a manner that is different—if not entirely impossible–for digital tools to achieve. What is meant by proactive interference will be covered next.Antinet 不是一个记忆系统，而是一个思维系统的一个关键原因在于它能够熟练地将你的思维中的某些部分浮出水面，这些部分在进一步反思后可能并不完全正确。由于其结构和模拟设计，Antinet 允许主动干扰。它以一种不同的方式（如果不是完全不可能的话）让数字工具实现这一点。接下来将介绍主动干扰的含义。

Human memory is complex, important, and still a mystery.[258](#footnote-202) When Luhmann began building his Antinet, it was in reaction to his “poor memory.”[259](#footnote-201) Yet he discovered the issue to be much more complex, in part because his understanding of memory was incomplete. What he referred to as a “poor memory” when he began building his Antinet in the 1950s related to retroactive interference, the interference caused by losing thoughts you’ve already previously learned. 人类的记忆是复杂的、重要的，而且仍然是个谜。 258 当卢曼开始构建他的 Antinet 时，这是对他 “糟糕的记忆” 的反应。 259 然而他发现这个问题要复杂得多，部分原因是他对记忆的理解是不完整的。当他在 1950 年代开始构建他的 Antinet 时，他称之为“记忆力差”，这与追溯干扰有关，这种干扰是由于失去你之前已经学过的想法而造成的。

Another type of interference in human memory prevents one from thinking clearly. It’s called proactive interference.[260](#footnote-200) You’ve probably heard the expression involving the notion of being your own worst enemy. This expression is founded on the idea that your own false-beliefs and cognitive fallacies can end up harming you more than any other person could. This isn’t an imaginary notion; much of the time it perfectly describes reality. 另一种对人类记忆的干扰会阻止人们清晰地思考。这称为主动干扰。260 您可能听说过 “成为自己最大的敌人” 这个概念。这种表达是基于这样一种观点，即你自己的错误信念和认知谬误最终可能比任何其他人都更能伤害你。这不是一个虚构的概念；很多时候它完美地描述了现实。

Wherever you go in life, you carry something with you. You carry information, facts, knowledge, and beliefs. These are stored in your mind. These things rely on your memory for their encoding, storage, and retrieval. There’s a problem, however: your memory may have filled in gaps or assumptions with an oversimplified representation of reality to support the encoding, storage, and retrieval of thought(s). These parts proceed to go unquestioned; they’re never analyzed or consciously recognized by yourself. The core problem with this is that these memory shortcuts, if you will, end up preventing you from assimilating new, deeper, and more profound ways to think about things. In brief, it is not the inability to recall thoughts that is the problem; rather it’s the inability to learn and evolve current thoughts that becomes a problem. This is what is meant by proactive interference. 无论你走到哪里，你都会随身携带一些东西。你携带着信息、事实、知识和信念。这些都储存在你的脑海里。这些东西依靠你的记忆来编码、存储和检索。然而，存在一个问题：您的记忆可能已经用过于简化的现实表示来填补空白或假设，以支持思想的编码、存储和检索。这些部分继续毫无疑问；他们从未被您分析或有意识地识别。这样做的核心问题是，如果你愿意的话，这些记忆捷径最终会阻止你吸收新的、更深入、更深刻的思考事物的方式。简而言之，问题不在于无法回忆起想法；相反，无法学习和发展当前的想法会成为一个问题。这就是主动干涉的意思。

Why does proactive interference happen? It happens because thoughts remain in a fixed state; not in a state where they can evolve—and just as important—not where the trail of a thought’s evolution can be clearly viewed. This is one of the benefits of analog notecards. When notecards combine with the evolving branching and stemming tree structure component of the Antinet, it is possible to observe knowledge growth. This prevents thoughts from being subject to proactive interference by forcing the thinker to constantly review and recall thoughts they stumble across—this happens more frequently in an Antinet because users are forced to swing from card to card, guided by the index, instead of simply searching the collection by keyword (like in digital notetaking apps). 为什么会发生主动干扰？它发生是因为思想保持在固定状态；不是处于它们可以进化的状态——同样重要的是——不是处于可以清楚地看到思想进化轨迹的状态。这是模拟记事卡的好处之一。当记事卡与 Antinet 不断发展的分支和词干树结构组件结合时，可以观察到知识增长。这可以防止思想受到主动干扰，迫使思考者不断回顾和回忆他们偶然发现的思想——这种情况在 Antinet 中更频繁发生，因为用户被迫在索引的指导下从一张卡片切换到另一张卡片，而不是简单地搜索按关键字收集（如在数字笔记应用程序中）。

Thinking systems that mitigate proactive interference are a critical component to improving the intelligence of one’s work. “Intelligence is traditionally viewed as the ability to think and learn. Yet, in a turbulent world, there’s another set of cognitive skills that might matter more: the ability to rethink and unlearn.”[261](#footnote-199) A system that mitigates proactive interference is a system that helps one rethink and unlearn. This type of system is precisely what the Antinet allows with its third principle, the tree structure. 减少主动干扰的思维系统是提高一个人工作智能的关键组成部分。 “传统上，智力被视为思考和学习的能力。然而，在动荡的世界中，还有另一套认知技能可能更重要：重新思考和忘却学习的能力。”261 减轻主动干扰的系统是帮助人们重新思考和忘却学习的系统。这种类型的系统正是 Antinet 的第三个原则，即树结构所允许的。

In summary, the Antinet is not a memory system, alone. Memory systems imply helping solve for one type of interference in human memory (that is, the interference that causes one to forget something). The Antinet solves for both types of interference in thought development (including the interference caused by thinking you know something that you don’t really know). 总之，Antinet 不是一个单独的记忆系统。记忆系统意味着帮助解决人类记忆中的一种干扰（即导致人们忘记某事的干扰）。 Antinet 解决了思想发展中的两种类型的干扰（包括因认为你知道一些你并不真正知道的事情而引起的干扰）。

**Working with an Antinet Develops Your** Memory Faculties 使用 Antinet 开发您的记忆能力

An Antinet is not an external system that enables you to simply offload theAntinet 不是一个外部系统，它使您能够简单地卸载

energy you’d otherwise rely on for your brain to recall thoughts. It acts as a system that exercises and enhances your brain’s memory faculties. That is, the Antinet enhances your brain’s ability to encode, store, and recall thought(s). The Antinet, with its neuroimprinting process, develops your mind’s capabilities for recollecting and recognizing interesting patterns when you read. This enables you to make connections to material ruminating in your Antinet. In the field of human memory studies, this involves a process called recognition.[262](#footnote-198) Let’s cover this briefly now. 否则您的大脑会依赖能量来回忆想法。它充当一个锻炼和增强大脑记忆能力的系统。也就是说，Antinet 增强了大脑编码、存储和回忆思想的能力。 Antinet 及其神经印记过程可培养您在阅读时回忆和识别有趣模式的思维能力。这使您能够与 Antinet 中的材料反思建立联系。在人类记忆研究领域，这涉及一个称为识别的过程。262 现在让我们简要介绍一下。

In the field of human memory studies, when you recognize a concept, two processes occur in the mind: 在人类记忆研究领域，当你识别一个概念时，大脑中会发生两个过程：

1.Familiarity: this process involves placing a confidence value on how familiar you are with the content you encounter. This includes what those who study human memory call strength theory.1. 熟悉度：此过程涉及对您对遇到的内容的熟悉程度设置置信度。这包括那些研究人类记忆的人所说的强度理论。

2.Recollection: this process involves the recall of contextual information related to the content you encounter while reading.2. 回忆：这个过程涉及回忆与阅读时遇到的内容相关的上下文信息。

It’s critical to recognize a concept while reading because it provides for two things: (1) it enables you to create information via comparison, and (2) it allows you to relate this information to a selective set of other relations. This is a necessary precursor for creating knowledge, and ultimately, achieving wisdom. The concept of selective relations will be discussed at length later in this book. 在阅读时识别概念至关重要，因为它提供了两件事：(1) 它使您能够通过比较创建信息，以及 (2) 它使您能够将此信息与一组有选择的其他关系相关联。这是创造知识并最终获得智慧的必要前提。选择关系的概念将在本书后面详细讨论。

Let’s jump back to the two processes occurring in the mind during recognition: familiarity and recollection. The question becomes How does the Antinet serve to enhance these two processes? 让我们回到认知过程中大脑中发生的两个过程：熟悉和回忆。问题变成了 Antinet 如何增强这两个过程？

The Antinet enhances the process of familiarity (familiarity with a concept) through the practice of two of its principles: (1) its analog principle, which spawns neuroimprinting, and (2) its index component, which results in consistent reviewing of information while searching for previously-noted thoughts.Antinet 通过实践其两个原则来增强熟悉过程（对概念的熟悉）：(1) 产生神经印记的模拟原则，以及 (2) 其索引组件，这导致在搜索时对信息进行一致的审查对于先前提到的想法。

The Antinet also enhances the process of recollection through forcing users to develop thoughts within contexts. This emerges via the third principle of the Antinet, its tree structure. Users create different contexts by organizing their knowledge around branches, or stems of thought in their Antinet.Antinet 还通过强迫用户在上下文中发展思想来增强回忆过程。这是通过 Antinet 的第三个原则，它的树结构出现的。用户通过围绕分支或 Antinet 中的思想干组织他们的知识来创建不同的上下文。

As scholars have observed, both variables (familiarity and recollection) paradoxically transform a notetaking system from something designed to replace human memory into a system that both replaces and enhances human memory. Alberto Cevolini points out that handwritten notetaking, due to the repetition that helps the mind retain passages, and the respective construction of a card index, serve as both a substitute for personal memory and a memory aid.[263](#footnote-197) 正如学者们观察到的那样，这两个变量（熟悉度和回忆）自相矛盾地将笔记系统从旨在取代人类记忆的系统转变为既能取代人类记忆又能增强人类记忆的系统。阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 指出，手写笔记由于帮助大脑记住段落的重复，以及卡片索引的相应构建，可以作为个人记忆的替代品和记忆辅助工具。 263

The Antinet structures itself in a way that enhances the familiarity and recollection processes involved in recognition. This allows you to recognize thoughts from readings, and better encode and store those thoughts for later recall. In short, the Antinet achieves this from doing one thing: developing your mind and its memory.Antinet 以一种增强识别所涉及的熟悉度和回忆过程的方式构建自己。这使您可以从阅读中识别想法，并更好地编码和存储这些想法以供日后回忆。简而言之，Antinet 通过做一件事来实现这一点：开发您的思维和记忆。

**An Antinet Is Primarily a Thinking SystemAntinet 主要是一个思维系统**

By now it should be apparent that an Antinet is not a notetaking app centered on the convenient storage of and access to thoughts. Its primary concern is in the developing and evolving of thought. An Antinet is not a notetaking system. What an Antinet really is, is quite apparent: it’s a thinking system. If you want a memory system, there are tools like Anki.[264](#footnote-196) If you want a notetaking system, perhaps one of the digital notetaking apps (or supposed digital Zettelkasten) would be of value. The Antinet, on the other hand, is a thinking system. It’s a thought development system, as well. It falls under the all-encompassing concept of a knowledge development system. It naturally improves your memory, but it does more: (1) it strengthens your neuro-associative recall ability, which was touched upon previously, and (2) the Antinet improves your ability to learn faster, and at a deeper level. 现在应该很明显，Antinet 并不是一个以方便存储和访问思想为中心的笔记应用程序。它主要关注的是思想的发展和演变。 Antinet 不是笔记系统。 Antinet 的真正含义非常明显：它是一个思维系统。如果你想要一个记忆系统，可以使用像 Anki.264 这样的工具。如果你想要一个笔记系统，也许数字笔记应用程序之一（或假定的数字 Zettelkasten）会很有价值。另一方面，Antinet 是一个思维系统。这也是一个思想发展系统。它属于知识开发系统的包罗万象的概念。它自然会提高您的记忆力，但它的作用更多：(1) 它增强了您之前提到的神经联想回忆能力，以及 (2) Antinet 提高了您更快、更深入地学习的能力。

Specifically, in human memory, there are several critical processes we’ve discussed already: (1) recognition, (2) recall, and (3) familiarity. However, there’s another process that is just as critical. That process is known as association.[265](#footnote-195) This concept will be further explored later in the book. 具体来说，在人类记忆中，有几个我们已经讨论过的关键过程：(1) 识别，(2) 回忆，和 (3) 熟悉。然而，还有另一个同样重要的过程。这个过程被称为联想。265 这个概念将在本书后面进一步探讨。

In brief, a traditional notetaking system is more like a personal information storage system. Again, an Antinet is a thinking system. It’s also a thought development system. It’s something that develops thought in both the short term and the long term because of what memory is. Sure, human memory’s raw material consists of memories, which are representations of thought; however, the process of memory itself is an active process, an “active operation.”[266](#footnote-194) 简而言之，传统的笔记系统更像是个人信息存储系统。同样，Antinet 是一种思维系统。这也是一个思想发展系统。由于记忆是什么，它可以在短期和长期内发展思想。当然，人类记忆的原材料由记忆组成，记忆是思想的表现；然而，记忆过程本身就是一个主动过程，一个 “主动操作”。 266
