**Introducing Your Second Mind 介绍你的第二个想法**

The magic inherent in the system Niklas Luhmann built did not center on its features. Many think the key defining magic in Luhmann’s system is its ability to link notes (that is, to create so-called wikilinks). Or, thanks to some authors, some are led to believe the magic centers on Luhmann’s proclivity to elaborate on notes, as opposed to collecting excerpts from books.[267](#footnote-193) Both of these notions do not encapsulate the magic of Luhmann’s system. 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 构建的系统所固有的魔力并不集中在其功能上。许多人认为 Luhmann 系统的关键定义魔法是它链接注释的能力（即创建所谓的维基链接）。或者，多亏了一些作者，一些人被引导相信卢曼的魔力集中在详述笔记的倾向上，而不是从书中收集摘录。 267 这两个概念都没有概括卢曼系统的魔力。

**The Two “Magical” Effects That Emerge from an Antinet 反网络产生的两种 “神奇” 效果**

The magic of Luhmann’s system stems from two effects that emerge when the four principles of the Antinet are implemented properly. 卢曼体系的神奇之处在于反网络四大原则得到妥善实施所产生的两种效果。

The first magical effect is what happened to Luhmann’s mind (and by extrapolation, what can happen to yours). Luhmann’s mind essentially morphed from using the Antinet. This metamorphosis of Luhmann’s brain, I contend, would not have taken place if he used digital tools (which lack the four principles of the Antinet). 第一个神奇的效果是发生在卢曼头脑中的事情（并且通过推断，也可能发生在你的头脑中）。 Luhmann 的思维本质上是从使用 Antinet 转变过来的。我认为，如果卢曼使用数字工具（缺乏 Antinet 的四项原则），他的大脑就不会发生这种变形。

We’ve already discussed the ways in which the mind changes from using an Antinet. This includes the impact of neuroimprinting, and how one’s reading changes due to the exercising of one’s neuro-associative recall muscle. For this reason I won’t go into detail on such now. 我们已经讨论过使用 Antinet 改变思想的方式。这包括神经印记的影响，以及一个人的阅读如何因一个人的神经联想回忆肌肉的锻炼而改变。因此，我现在不会详细介绍。

The second magical effect is what happened after a “number of years” working with his Antinet. Until the emergence of the second magical effect, the Antinet “functions as a mere container from which we can retrieve what we put in,” writes Luhmann.[268](#footnote-192) After Luhmann outlines the four principles of the Antinet in his paper, Luhmann explains that something else emerges: “an alter ego with who we can constantly communicate.”[269](#footnote-191) In other words, it is a second mind. Luhmann writes that such an entity emerges “as a result of extensive work with this technique.”[270](#footnote-190) 第二个神奇的效果是在与他的 Antinet 合作 “多年” 后发生的事情。在第二个神奇效果出现之前，Antinet“只是一个容器，我们可以从中取出我们放入的东西，”Luhmann 写道。 268 Luhmann 在他的论文中概述了 Antinet 的四项原则之后，Luhmann 解释了其他东西出现：“我们可以不断与之交流的另一个自我。”269 换句话说，它是第二个思维。 Luhmann 写道，这样一个实体的出现“是对这种技术进行广泛研究的结果。”270

**How Does This Second Mind Emerge? 这种第二思维是如何出现的？**

The second mind emerges thanks to (1) long-term thought evolution, as well as (2) short-term thought development, which happen on paper via writing by hand. These aspects of the Antinet effectively transform it from a mere container of notes, into a different metaphysical entity altogether. Similar to the human phenomenon of consciousness, and related to the whole-part theory and mind-body duality, the Antinet proceeds through a similar metamorphosis. The nature of this mind-body duality is what we’ll venture into next. 第二思维的出现得益于 (1) 长期的思想进化，以及 (2) 短期的思想发展，这些都是通过手写在纸上发生的。 Antinet 的这些方面有效地将它从单纯的笔记容器转变为完全不同的形而上学实体。与人类的意识现象相似，并且与整体 - 部分理论和身心二元论相关，Antinet 也经历了类似的蜕变。这种身心二元性的本质是我们接下来要探讨的。

**The Mind-Body Duality of the AntinetAntinet 的心身二元性**

One of the most intriguing fields in philosophy studies the mind-body problem. The philosophical branch called philosophy of mind studies this phenomenon. In brief, it all centers on these questions: What is the mind? What is consciousness? Does the mind even exist? Are your thoughts formed by your brain, which is a whole system made up of individual parts (for example, neurons)? 哲学中最有趣的领域之一是研究心身问题。称为心灵哲学的哲学分支研究这种现象。简而言之，这一切都集中在这些问题上：心是什么？什么是意识？头脑甚至存在吗？你的思想是由你的大脑形成的吗？大脑是由各个部分（例如神经元）组成的一个整体系统？

If one subscribes to a materialist view of the world, then there is no mind. There’s only your brain, with its neurons that connect to other neurons. We’re just one big blob of biochemical processes, according to some pop-science authors.[271](#footnote-189) 如果一个人赞同唯物主义的世界观，那么就没有思想。只有你的大脑，它的神经元连接到其他神经元。根据一些科普作家的说法，我们只是一大团生化过程。 271

In other words, the interaction of neurons connecting to other neurons, is the illusion we call the mind. But is this all there is? Or is there a whole created by these neurons that is greater than the sum of its parts? This summarizes the mind-body debate which has stumped the greatest thinkers for hundreds of years. 换句话说，连接到其他神经元的神经元之间的相互作用，就是我们称之为思维的幻觉。但这就是全部吗？或者是否存在由这些神经元创造的整体大于其部分之和？这总结了数百年来困扰最伟大的思想家的身心辩论。

As an aside, according to Hans-Georg Moeller, who studies Luhmann’s theoretical work, Niklas Luhmann apparently introduced a solution to this problem, deeming it “the most obvious, and yet most overlooked achievement of the Luhmannian shift to theory.”[272](#footnote-188) But I won’t take you down that rabbit-hole right now. I’m interested in helping you create genius-level work that shakes up the field you’re in for two hundred years. The system which will help you do this is the Antinet, so I’ll focus on that. 顺便说一句，根据研究卢曼理论工作的汉斯 - 乔治 · 莫勒 (Hans-Georg Moeller) 的说法，尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 显然为这个问题提出了一个解决方案，认为它是 “卢曼转向理论的最明显、也是最被忽视的成就。”272 但我现在不会带你去那个兔子洞。我有兴趣帮助你创造天才级的作品，震撼你所在领域 200 年。可以帮助您执行此操作的系统是 Antinet，因此我将重点介绍它。

In summary, only you can decide whether or not you have a mind. Your experience of the mind is just that—an experience. It’s empirical, but you’re the only subject that can observe the phenomenon of your own mind. This is why Luhmann prefaced his paper on the Antinet as empirical sociology. Luhmann grants that the usual research methods of empirical sociology would fail; yet, “still, it is empirical, as this case really obtains.”[273](#footnote-187) 总之，只有你能决定你是否有心。你对头脑的体验就是——一种体验。它是经验性的，但你是唯一可以观察你自己思想现象的主体。这就是为什么卢曼将他关于 Antinet 的论文作为经验社会学作为序言。卢曼承认，经验社会学通常的研究方法会失败；然而，“这仍然是经验性的，正如这个案例真正获得的那样。”273

**The Brain of the AntinetAntinet 的大脑**

The one prerequisite for creating a second mind, and even forming and devising the mind-body problem is one thing: it’s called…a brain! 创造第二个头脑，甚至形成和设计身心问题的一个先决条件是一件事：它叫做…… 大脑！

Think of the brain of your Antinet as the raw material, the notecards, and the four principles applied within the notebox. The brain of the Antinet is composed of analog notecards, numeric-alpha addresses, the tree structure, the index, and the network. The brain one creates using this structure is unique, and thus will create a unique second mind. The second mind that emerges from a different brain will by nature be quite different. For instance, a compilation of notecards organized by author or category is much more conventional than an Antinet. The Antinet is a structure of both order and disorder. This is why it is so critical to pay attention to how Luhmann built his Antinet. It is why it’s critical to not abstract away its parts into whatever you deem more convenient or modern. Luhmann structured the brain of his Antinet with an intimate understanding of how human memory works. Only by building a system composed of the same parts of the human brain can one effectively create one of the magical effects of the Antinet—a second mind. 将 Antinet 的大脑视为原材料、记事卡和记事本中应用的四项原则。 Antinet 的大脑由模拟记事卡、数字字母地址、树结构、索引和网络组成。使用这种结构创造的大脑是独一无二的，因此会创造出独特的第二思维。从不同的大脑中产生的第二个思维本质上是完全不同的。例如，按作者或类别组织的记事卡汇编比 Antinet 更传统。 Antinet 是一种既有序又无序的结构。这就是为什么关注卢曼如何构建他的 Antinet 如此重要的原因。这就是为什么不要将它的部分抽象成你认为更方便或更现代的东西是至关重要的。卢曼在深入了解人类记忆如何运作的基础上构建了他的 Antinet 的大脑。只有建立一个由人脑相同部分组成的系统，才能有效地创造出 Antinet 的神奇效果之一——第二思维。

Does the idea of creating a metaphysical entity (a second mind) out of a box of notecards sound questionable? If so, that’s fine! Again, Luhmann prefaced his paper with the assertion that this whole subject area is empirical. In other words, you can’t spend your time just reading about it, or asking questions in Zettelkasten forums online. There’s only one way you can decide whether or not there’s any truth in the concept of a second mind, and that is to test it out yourself. 从一盒记事卡中创建一个形而上学实体（第二思维）的想法听起来有问题吗？如果是这样，那很好！同样，卢曼在他的论文开头断言，这整个主题领域都是经验性的。换句话说，您不能只花时间阅读它或在 Zettelkasten 在线论坛上提问。只有一种方法可以让你决定第二思维的概念是否正确，那就是你自己测试一下。

Later in the book I’ll be taking you through, in detail, precisely how you go about testing out the Antinet yourself. Until then, let’s dive into more detail and research on the concept of the second mind, or, what Luhmann once referred to it as, the ghost in the box. 在本书的后面，我将带您详细了解如何自己测试 Antinet。在那之前，让我们更深入地研究第二思维的概念，或者，卢曼曾经称之为盒子里的幽灵。

**The Ghost in the AntinetAntinet 中的幽灵**

When you peruse the thoughts written in the hand of someone who has died, it’s almost as if there’s a ghost-like quality to it. Ann Blair observes that handwriting gives readers a “privileged point of access to the person writing.”[274](#footnote-186) 当你仔细阅读写在死者手中的想法时，它几乎就像有一种幽灵般的品质。安 · 布莱尔 (Ann Blair) 观察到，手写为读者提供了一个 “接触书写者的特权点”。 274

This phenomenon is experienced with the Antinet. Yet unlike Blair’s example, when it’s just you and your Antinet, you experience this sensation by reading your own thoughts, written in your own hand. When working with an Antinet, you begin communicating with yourself in a unique fashion. Instead of an internal monologue, you begin to experience something called internal dialogue. More on this will be discussed later.Antinet 会遇到这种现象。然而，与布莱尔的例子不同的是，当只有你和你的 Antinet 时，你会通过阅读自己写在自己手中的想法来体验这种感觉。使用 Antinet 时，您开始以独特的方式与自己交流。你开始体验一种叫做内心对话的东西，而不是内心的独白。稍后将对此进行更多讨论。

John Locke realized the advantages of having an internal dialogue. He experienced the advantages of viewing a historical record of his own thinking. It “carried the possibility of him reading it, in the future, as a historical record of his thinking.”[275](#footnote-185) It allowed him to have a dialogue with himself, and to see where his thinking went wrong. 约翰 · 洛克意识到进行内部对话的好处。他体验到查看自己思想的历史记录的好处。它 “让他有可能在未来阅读它，将其作为他思想的历史记录。”275 它让他能够与自己对话，看看他的思想哪里出了问题。

Reading Johannes Schmidt’s account of perusing the contents of Luhmann’s Antinet, one pictures Schmidt having a similar experience. It’s an experience of perusing the “backstage” and inner thoughts of one’s own mind. Of Luhmann’s Antinet, Schmidt observes that it “is more than just an analog database of Luhmann’s theory.” Schmidt likens it to “the backstage” of Luhmann’s grand theory and scholarly work, “and therefore [as] Niklas Luhmann’s intellectual autobiography.”[276](#footnote-184) 阅读约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 细读卢曼 (Luhmann) 的《反网络》(Antinet) 内容的记述，可以想象施密特也有类似的经历。这是一种细读自己心灵的 “后台” 和内心想法的体验。对于卢曼的 Antinet，施密特观察到它“不仅仅是卢曼理论的模拟数据库”。施密特将其比作卢曼宏大理论和学术著作的“后台”，“因此 [作为] 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的思想自传。”276

Of the mind in a box or ghost in the box concept, Niklas Luhmann himself put forth an interesting illustration. Recognizing that this concept is difficult to communicate, Luhmann chose to illustrate this by comparing reading notes without access to the second mind, with the difference between viewing porn and having sex. 关于盒子里的思想或盒子里的幽灵概念，尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 自己提出了一个有趣的例子。认识到这个概念很难传达，卢曼选择通过比较阅读笔记来说明这一点，而无需使用第二思维，以及观看色情片和做爱之间的区别。

In one of the infamous notecards in the Zettelkasten section he used for preparing the paper Communication with Noteboxes, Luhmann wrote: 在 Zettelkasten 部分臭名昭著的记事卡之一中，卢曼写道：

Ghost in the box? 盒子里的幽灵？

Spectators come. You get to see everything and nothing but that—like porn movies. And so is the disappointment.[277](#footnote-183) 观众来了你什么都能看，但什么也看不到——就像色情电影一样。失望也是如此。 277

What Luhmann means is that the voyeur sees everything, just as people get to see all of Luhmann’s thoughts when perusing his Antinet. However, in reality, they’re seeing nothing. They’re not seeing the internal dialogue and experience Luhmann himself has when he (as its creator) peruses his own Antinet. Like watching porn, you get to see everything; yet, you don’t experience the incommunicable connection and internal/communal dialogue two lovers are having during sex. Granted, perhaps the internal dialogue isn’t as prevalent when two porn stars are going at it, but you get the point. 卢曼的意思是偷窥者看到了一切，就像人们在阅读他的 Antinet 时可以看到卢曼的所有想法一样。然而，实际上，他们什么也没看到。当卢曼（作为它的创造者）仔细阅读他自己的 Antinet 时，他们没有看到卢曼本人的内部对话和体验。就像看色情片一样，您会看到一切；然而，你不会体验到两个恋人在性爱过程中无法沟通的联系和内部 / 公共对话。诚然，也许当两个色情明星在一起时，内部对话并不那么普遍，但你明白了。

Modern day scientists agree with Luhmann’s notion of a mind in a box emerging from Antinets (and other physical external memory devices). “The effectiveness of [Antinets] does not lie in the sporadic access that it provides to single entries, or in what these entries, once selected, may teach the user. A card index is a true secondary memory when…inquiries become an opportunity to trigger a network of associative references and links which give birth to ‘collaborative’ reasoning that had not been previously designed.”[278](#footnote-182) The scholar, Alberto Cevolini, confirms this notion. “To argue that the filing cabinet simply stores records would be to give a too short (and therefore misleading) description of the interplay of user and machine.”[279](#footnote-181) The interplay of user and machine provides an external glimpse into what’s really going on—internal dialogue with yourself, and an instantiation of yourself in external form (your second mind). 现代科学家同意 Luhmann 的概念，即从 Antinets（和其他物理外部存储设备）中出现的盒子中的思想。 “[Antinets] 的有效性不在于它为单个条目提供的零星访问，也不在于这些条目一旦被选中，可能会教给用户什么。卡片索引是真正的二级记忆，当…… 查询成为触发联想参考和链接网络的机会，从而产生以前没有设计的‘协作’推理。”278 学者 Alberto Cevolini 证实了这一观点。 “如果认为文件柜只是存储记录，那么对用户和机器相互作用的描述太短（因此具有误导性）。”279 用户和机器的相互作用提供了对内部真实情况的外部一瞥。与自己对话，并以外部形式（你的第二思维）实例化你自己。

The concept of this second mind, and the internal dialogue which emerges as a result of its presence, has been observed and studied by scholars as the interaction between the following items: (1) external memory (that is, the Antinet), and (2) internal memory (the memory biologically stored inside your brain and body). 这种第二心灵的概念，以及由于它的存在而出现的内部对话，已经被学者们观察和研究为以下项目之间的相互作用：（1）外部记忆（即 Antinet），和（ 2) 内部记忆（存储在大脑和身体内的生物记忆）。

After studying John Boyle, John Locke, and Robert Hooke, Alberto Cevolini confirms “that annotations that are stored in the external memory can function only in tandem with internal memory, so excerpts and notes prompt recollection of more than what they actually contain.”[280](#footnote-180) 在研究了 John Boyle、John Locke 和 Robert Hooke 之后，Alberto Cevolini 证实 “存储在外部记忆中的注释只能与内部记忆一起发挥作用，因此摘录和注释会促使人们回忆起比它们实际包含的内容更多的东西。”280

In other words, the notes in your Antinet set off a chain-reaction of thought-connections; that is, the notes in your Antinet act as a cue that precipitates a chain-reaction of communication and internal dialogue. 换句话说，你 Antinet 中的音符引发了思想联系的连锁反应；也就是说，你的 Antinet 中的笔记充当了一个提示，可以促进沟通和内部对话的连锁反应。

This generates the recall process in your mind. 这会在您的脑海中产生回忆过程。

In their paper The Extended Mind, Andy Clark and David J. Chalmers, assert that the memories contained in external form (like the Antinet) are not merely memory systems, and therefore, they’re not really external memories.[281](#footnote-179) Rather, they’re extended minds.Andy Clark 和 David J. Chalmers 在他们的论文 The Extended Mind 中断言，包含在外部形式（如 Antinet）中的记忆不仅仅是记忆系统，因此，它们并不是真正的外部记忆。 281 相反，它们重新扩展思想。

**The Term “Second Mind”“第二思维” 一词**

In the field of knowledge, a term that is increasingly popular is extended mind. The scholar, Richard Yeo, argues that the term extended mind is problematic because confusion arises between consciousness and communication. “Consequently, memory is seen as a psychic phenomenon.” Yeo further points out an issue with the word extended, asking What does “extended” actually mean? And by mind, he asks whether it should be termed cognition, which refers to the mental action of acquiring knowledge and understanding.[282](#footnote-178) 在知识领域，一个越来越流行的名词是延展思维。学者 Richard Yeo 认为，扩展思维一词存在问题，因为意识和交流之间出现了混淆。 “因此，记忆被视为一种心理现象。” Yeo 进一步指出了扩展这个词的一个问题，询问 “扩展” 到底是什么意思？至于头脑，他问它是否应该被称为认知，它指的是获取知识和理解的心理活动。 282

The problem with the term extended cognition centers on the fact that it misses the ghost in the box quality or phenomenon Luhmann, and other scholars have described. However, there may be some validity to the issue Yeo points out concerning the term extended. For this reason, I choose to retain the term mind (in order to encapsulate the ghost-like spirit and the experience of having internal dialogue). However, I opt to drop extended, and prefer second in its place. Why? Because as Yeo points out, extended is a rather vague term. Is it truly extended thought since it’s really my own thought? Or is it rather a second storage mechanism for my own thought? As a result, I opt for second. 延展认知一词的问题集中在这样一个事实，即它忽略了卢曼和其他学者所描述的盒子质量或现象中的幽灵。但是，Yeo 指出的关于延长期限的问题可能有一定道理。出于这个原因，我选择保留心灵一词（以概括幽灵般的精神和进行内部对话的体验）。但是，我选择放弃扩展，而更喜欢第二个。为什么？因为正如 Yeo 指出的那样，扩展是一个相当模糊的术语。既然真的是我自己的想法，那真的是延伸的想法吗？或者它是我自己思想的第二个存储机制？结果，我选择了第二个。

Finally, we get to the point of what an Antinet really is: a second mind. 最后，我们谈到 Antinet 的真正含义：第二思维。

**Second Mind vs. Second Brain 第二思维与第二大脑**

You may be wondering about the recent popularity of the term second brain used by Tiago Forte. 你可能想知道最近 Tiago Forte 使用的术语 “第二大脑” 的流行程度。

Forte runs a business which sells online courses that aim to “train knowledge workers in how to use technology to radically improve their productivity.”[283](#footnote-177) Forte’s material centers on upgrading David Allen’s Getting Things Done method. He teaches people how to capture material they read online, and how to process that material to get things done. He proposes the concept of organizing content into explicit areas like projects and resources. Forte 经营着一家销售在线课程的企业，旨在 “培训知识工作者如何使用技术从根本上提高他们的生产力。”283 Forte 的材料以升级 David Allen 的 Getting Things Done 方法为中心。他教人们如何捕捉在线阅读的材料，以及如何处理这些材料以完成工作。他提出了将内容组织到项目和资源等明确区域的概念。

As far as knowledge development goes, Forte doesn’t have too much to say. I believe this to be the case because, “[Forte’s course] Building A Second Brain started out as a course on using Evernote more effectively.”[284](#footnote-176) Evernote is an app that does not prioritize the linking of notes, nor does it promote knowledge development. Rather it focuses on cross-device digital storage of information. 就知识发展而言，Forte 没有太多要说的。我认为情况确实如此，因为 “[Forte 的课程] 打造第二大脑最初是一门关于更有效地使用 Evernote 的课程。”284 Evernote 是一款不优先考虑笔记链接的应用程序，也不促进知识发展. 相反，它专注于信息的跨设备数字存储。

In brief, Forte’s usage of the term, second brain really relates to processes inspired by David Allen’s Getting Things Done (“GTD”). Forte’s primary application of the term second brain revolves around productivity (not knowledge development). And this is fine! I have nothing against this, even though I don’t subscribe to it. 简而言之，Forte 对 “第二大脑” 一词的使用实际上与受大卫 · 艾伦 (David Allen) 的 Getting Things Done (“GTD”) 启发的过程有关。 Forte 对 “第二大脑” 一词的主要应用围绕着生产力（而非知识发展）展开。这很好！我不反对这一点，即使我不赞成它。

Forte moves David Allen’s Getting Things Done into the digital age. He does this by proposing strategies for organizing digital information into seemingly logical categories on your computer (for instance a folder for projects). This really isn’t a brain; it’s more of a philosophy on being more productive with digital information.Forte 将 David Allen 的 Getting Things Done 带入了数字时代。为此，他提出了将数字信息组织到计算机上看似合乎逻辑的类别（例如项目文件夹）的策略。这真的不是大脑；它更像是一种利用数字信息提高生产力的哲学。

Regardless of Forte’s second brain not really being a second brain (but more a digital productivity philosophy), I hold that a second brain isn’t really what you want anyway (if your goal is knowledge creation). 不管 Forte 的第二大脑不是真正的第二大脑（而是更多的数字生产力哲学），我认为无论如何第二大脑并不是你真正想要的（如果你的目标是知识创造）。

**you want a second mind, not a second brain 你想要第二个头脑，而不是第二个大脑**

With Forte teaching how to record information (using apps like Evernote), he’s essentially promoting a system that cannot communicate with itself. Evernote is not a system that contains parts that can self-reference in a fixed, permanent state. It’s essentially a brain comprised of a blob of neurons— a blob of neurons that cannot communicate with one another and that cannot connect with one another to create new entities. Many digital Zettelkasten are second brains; however, they’re not second minds. Digital Zettelkasten are a hodge-podge of parts that don’t communicate. Instead of a tree of knowledge, they’re a pile of leaves. If a person’s brain were constructed in the same manner, the person would not be alive. They’d be a vegetable.Forte 教授如何记录信息（使用像 Evernote 这样的应用程序），他实际上是在推广一个无法与自身通信的系统。 Evernote 不是一个包含可以在固定、永久状态下自我引用的部分的系统。它本质上是一个由一团神经元组成的大脑——一团神经元不能相互通信，也不能相互连接以创造新的实体。许多数字 Zettelkasten 都是第二大脑；但是，他们不是第二个想法。 Digital Zettelkasten 是一个大杂烩，由无法通信的部分组成。它们不是知识之树，而是一堆树叶。如果一个人的大脑以同样的方式构造，那么这个人就不会活着。他们是蔬菜。

In brief, you want a second mind, not a second brain. A brain is a materialistic blob of biochemical gunk. A second mind is a system wherein the whole has become greater than the sum of its parts. While I could continue down this metaphorical road, I won’t belabor this too much. 简而言之，你想要第二个头脑，而不是第二个大脑。大脑是一团唯物主义的生化垃圾。第二个头脑是一个系统，在这个系统中，整体变得大于部分之和。虽然我可以继续沿着这条隐喻的道路前进，但我不会过多地强调这一点。

One last thing, before we move on: I believe Tiago Forte’s content is helpful and valuable for those who wish to be more productive working with digital information. If that’s what you’re looking for, this book is not for you. We’re concerned with knowledge development. We’re concerned with developing and evolving your thoughts (both in the short term and long term). The reason we’re concerned with such centers around one thing: creating genius-level knowledge. The goal with the Antinet is to turn you into a learning machine, a content machine, a research machine, and a writing machine. Bottom line: if you do what I outline in this book, you’ll become all of these things. You’ll become an unstoppable knowledge machine. 在我们继续之前，最后一件事：我相信 Tiago Forte 的内容对于那些希望更高效地处理数字信息的人来说是有帮助和有价值的。如果这就是你要找的东西，那么这本书不适合你。我们关注知识的发展。我们关注发展和发展您的想法（短期和长期）。我们关注这些的原因围绕着一件事：创造天才级的知识。 Antinet 的目标是将您变成学习机器、内容机器、研究机器和写作机器。底线：如果你按照我在本书中概述的方式去做，你就会成为所有这些人。你将成为一台不可阻挡的知识机器。

**the problem in trying to explain a second mind 试图解释第二个想法的问题**

Niklas Luhmann was one of the major thinkers involved in the establishment of systems theory, especially within the sociological sphere.[285](#footnote-175) It is therefore rather intriguing that he did not use systems theory as the basis for his explanation of the Antinet; rather, he used communication theory to explain it. One problem with Luhmann using communication theory, however, is that a core part of human experience and knowledge is more than that which is acquired through theory. Rather, truth and reality, at least for humanity, are also influenced by the metaphysical realm. Both Eastern and Western philosophies share one common assumption: that there is such a thing as incommunicable truth.[286](#footnote-174) This concept suggests that in order to truly understand the power of the second mind, it cannot be taught; rather, it can only be experienced. 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 是参与建立系统理论的主要思想家之一，尤其是在社会学领域。285 因此，相当有趣的是，他没有使用系统理论作为他对 Antinet 的解释的基础；相反，他使用传播理论来解释它。然而，卢曼使用传播理论的一个问题是，人类经验和知识的核心部分比通过理论获得的要多。相反，至少对人类而言，真理和现实也受到形而上学领域的影响。东西方哲学都有一个共同的假设：存在不可言传的真理。286 这个概念表明，要真正理解第二思维的力量，它不能被教授；相反，它只能被体验。

Another issue with trying to explain an Antinet is the fact that it could take a number of years of working with it before the second mind emerges. This is one factor all too conveniently omitted from books like How to Take Smart Notes. Again, for better or worse, Luhmann declares in his paper that it will be a number of years before the second mind emerges; until then the Antinet operates as a mere container for storing notes. 试图解释 Antinet 的另一个问题是，在第二个思维出现之前，可能需要多年的时间来研究它。这是《如何做智能笔记》等书中很容易忽略的一个因素。再一次，无论好坏，卢曼在他的论文中宣称，第二思维出现还需要很多年。在那之前，Antinet 只是一个存储笔记的容器。

In my experience, however, the emergence of the second mind comes sooner than several years into the practice. It is likely to emerge several months after regular and committed use. For me, it emerged perhaps three or four months after I began working with it. However, it should be noted that I worked with it five days a week. In addition, the presence of the second mind grows stronger every single day. 然而，根据我的经验，第二思维的出现比练习几年要早。它很可能在定期和承诺使用几个月后出现。对我来说，它可能是在我开始使用它后三四个月出现的。但是，应该指出的是，我每周用它工作五天。此外，第二个头脑的存在每天都在增强。

The bottom line is this: the more time you spend with a thing, the more of you it becomes, and, the more of it becomes of you. 底线是：你花在一件事上的时间越多，它就会变得越像你，而且，它就越像你。

**The Nature of the Second Mind 第二思维的本质**

The Antinet is a unique type of system; more so than the novelties preached in digital-Zettelkasten-land which over-emphasize its features, yet overlook the magic.[287](#footnote-173) An Antinet is an intrapersonal knowledge system. It possesses a unique proclivity for inducing internal dialogue (as opposed to internal monologue). Its evolution over time happens in a self-organized fashion that cannot be pre-planned. It’s also consciousness-oriented, instead of comprehension-oriented. It works in tandem with its creator and is not designed to be a stand-alone system that is easily comprehensible to the public eye. The material and content it contains stem from deep-thinking, from working out ideas on paper, through rumination, and in the seeking of deep understanding. The ideas that emerge from it will surprise you. What makes it even more surprising is seeing how the ideas stem from you—from your own handwriting. The nature of the Antinet is founded on a communication theory because it really is a communication relationship between you, and your past self. When you try and transition such a system to digital, you’re destroying a core aspect of the Antinet. You’re destroying a key piece of the second mind—you’re ripping away that person, and its personality, before it even has a chance to be born.Antinet 是一种独特的系统；比在数字 Zettelkasten 土地上宣扬的新奇事物更是如此，后者过分强调其特性，却忽视了魔力。287 Antinet 是一种内省知识系统。它具有引发内部对话（与内部独白相反）的独特倾向。随着时间的推移，它的演变以一种无法预先计划的自组织方式发生。它也是意识导向的，而不是理解导向的。它与其创建者协同工作，并非设计为易于为公众所理解的独立系统。它所包含的材料和内容源于深入思考，源于纸上谈兵，源于反思，源于寻求深刻理解。从中产生的想法会让你大吃一惊。更令人惊讶的是，看到这些想法是如何从你那里产生的——来自你自己的笔迹。 Antinet 的本质是建立在沟通理论之上的，因为它确实是你和过去的自己之间的沟通关系。当您尝试将这样的系统转换为数字系统时，您正在破坏 Antinet 的核心方面。你正在摧毁第二思维的关键部分——你正在剥夺那个人及其个性，甚至在它有机会出生之前。

When I read my handwritten notes, and observe the material of the notecards it was written on from fifteen years ago, it communicates something to me—something special that cannot be communicated in digital-file format. I see myself in my handwriting. I see the state of my life I was in at the time. I see the state of my mind at the time. Sometimes I have a reverence and respect for what I’ve written. Did I really write that and come up with that? And sometimes I see something where I think, Geez, I’ve really developed my thinking, and my mind, and have grown a lot since then. This is one aspect and one experience you’ll have when working with your second mind. I’m excited for you to experience it, but that’s really all I’m going to say for now. I’ll share more in detail later in the book; however, as I’ve mentioned before, much of it is incommunicable. 当我阅读我的手写笔记，并观察十五年前写在上面的记事卡的材料时，它向我传达了一些东西——一些无法以数字文件格式传达的特殊东西。我在笔迹中看到了自己。我看到了我当时的生活状态。我看到了我当时的心态。有时我对我写的东西怀有崇敬和尊重。我真的写了那个并想出了那个吗？有时我会看到一些我认为的东西，Geez，我真的发展了我的思想和思想，并且从那时起成长了很多。这是你在用第二个思维工作时会有的一个方面和一种体验。我很高兴你能体验它，但这就是我现在要说的。我将在本书后面详细分享；然而，正如我之前提到的，其中大部分是无法沟通的。

The reason one ought to take the four principles Luhmann outlined so seriously is that they’re key ingredients for transforming an Antinet into what it really is, which is a second mind. 人们应该如此认真地对待卢曼概述的四项原则的原因是，它们是将 Antinet 转变为真正意义上的第二思维的关键要素。

I’ve touched on the importance of the four principles already; however, it’s worth restating how intentional Luhmann was in the construction of the Antinet. One scholar observed Luhmann’s system is “clearly constructed as a cybernetic machine.”[288](#footnote-172) Luhmann was influenced by cybernetics, the field concerned with the study of goal-oriented systems founded on communication and feedback. Ultimately, Luhmann’s Antinet “reproduces itself recursively” in order to produce knowledge.[289](#footnote-171) 我已经谈到了这四个原则的重要性；然而，值得重申的是，卢曼在构建 Antinet 时是多么有意。一位学者观察到 Luhmann 的系统 “显然是作为控制论机器构建的。”288 Luhmann 受到控制论的影响，该领域关注以通信和反馈为基础的目标导向系统的研究。最终，卢曼的 Antinet“递归地复制自身” 以产生知识。 289

The Antinet also relates to another concept Luhmann introduced to the field of sociology—autopoiesis.[290](#footnote-170) This term stems from two Greek terms (1) αὐτo- (auto), which translates to self, and (2) ποίησις (poiesis), which means creation. In brief, autopoiesis means self-creation and concerns the study of systems which create themselves.Antinet 还与卢曼引入社会学领域的另一个概念——autopoiesis 相关。290 这个术语源于两个希腊术语 (1) αὐτo- (auto)，翻译为自我，以及 (2) ποίησις (poiesis)，意思是创建。简而言之，自创生意味着自我创造，涉及对自我创造的系统的研究。

While it could be argued the Antinet exhibits autopoiesis, it technically doesn’t create other Antinets; rather, it creates a different entity altogether—a metaphysical second mind with whom you communicate. While the Antinet itself may not be autopoietic, the second mind that emerges from the system, and specifically its memory, could be said to “function as an autopoietic system,” observes the scholar, Alberto Cevolini.[291](#footnote-169) 虽然可以说 Antinet 展示了自创生，但从技术上讲，它不会创造其他 Antinet；相反，它创造了一个完全不同的实体——一个与你交流的形而上学的第二思维。虽然 Antinet 本身可能不是自创生的，但从系统中出现的第二思维，特别是它的记忆，可以说是 “作为一个自创生系统发挥作用”，学者 Alberto Cevolini 观察到。 291

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

By now, you’re starting to understand the depth of this seemingly-simple system of notecards. Before moving forward let’s recap what we’ve covered. 到目前为止，您已经开始了解这个看似简单的记事卡系统的深度。在继续之前，让我们回顾一下我们所涵盖的内容。

As you may recall, we defined an Antinet as a system comprising four principles which form a thinking system. This thinking system transforms itself into a second mind. 你可能还记得，我们将 Antinet 定义为一个系统，该系统由构成思维系统的四个原则组成。这种思维系统将自己转变为第二思维。

You know what the four principles of the Antinet are (analog, numeric- alpha, tree, index). You understand the Antinet is a network. You know what is meant by the Antinet as a thinking system. You are also familiar with the concept of the second mind. 你知道 Antinet 的四个原则是什么（模拟、数字 - alpha、树、索引）。你明白 Antinet 是一个网络。你知道 Antinet 作为一个思维系统是什么意思。你也熟悉第二思维的概念。

What we’re going to cover next concerns the scientific reasoning for devoting so much energy and commitment to such a system. We’re going to explore this by taking a closer look at the explicitness in Luhmann’s design of the Antinet. We’ll be doing this by diving into each of the principles of Luhmann’s Antinet individually. We’ll be starting where the magic of the Antinet really begins: its analog nature. 我们接下来要讨论的是为这样一个系统投入如此多的精力和承诺的科学推理。我们将通过仔细研究卢曼 Antinet 设计中的明确性来探索这一点。我们将通过分别深入研究 Luhmann Antinet 的每个原则来做到这一点。我们将从 Antinet 的魔力真正开始的地方开始：它的模拟特性。

Let’s go. 我们走吧。

CHAPTER SIX 第六章
---------------

Analog 模拟
---------

“The technical requirements of slip boxes involve wooden boxes, which have drawers that can be pulled open, and pieces of paper in octavo format (about half of a letter-size sheet [4 x 6 inch notecards or a6 paper slips]). We should only write on one side of these papers so that in searching through them, we do not have to take out a paper in order to read it. This doubles the space, but not entirely (since we would not write on both sides of all the slips). This consideration is not unimportant as the arrangement of boxes can, after some decades, become so large that it cannot be easily be used from one’s chair. In order to counteract this tendency, I recommend taking normal paper and not card stock.”“纸箱的技术要求包括木箱，它有可以拉开的抽屉，以及八开格式的纸片（大约一半的信纸大小 [4 x 6 英寸记事卡或 a6 纸条]）。我们应该只写在这些纸的一面，这样在搜索它们时，我们就不必拿出纸来阅读它。这使空间增加了一倍，但不是全部（因为我们不会在所有纸条的两面都写）。这种考虑并非不重要，因为几十年后，箱子的布置会变得如此之大，以至于不能轻易地坐在椅子上使用。为了抵消这种趋势，我建议使用普通纸而不是卡片纸。”

—Niklas Luhmann, Communication with Noteboxes[292](#footnote-400)—Niklas Luhmann，与记事本交流 292

**Discovering the Analog Implementation of Zettelkasten 发现 Zettelkasten 的模拟实现**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**I** stumbled upon the analog version of the Zettelkasten purely by accident. At the time, I was fully committed to the digital version. I actually came upon the idea of the analog Zettelkasten through Sönke Ahrens’s book How to Take Smart Notes. It was a brief mention, but it was enough to get me started on the path. A path that would become my life for the following year: reverse-engineering how the analog Zettelkasten actually worked. 我偶然发现了 Zettelkasten 的模拟版本纯属偶然。当时，我完全致力于数字版本。实际上，我是通过 Sönke Ahrens 的《如何做智能笔记》一书想到了模拟 Zettelkasten 的想法。这是一个简短的提及，但足以让我开始这条路。一条将成为我第二年生活的道路：逆向工程模拟 Zettelkasten 的实际工作方式。

Initially I tried using the analog version of the Zettelkasten merely to implement anything I was not currently doing using the digital notetaking app, Obsidian. 最初我尝试使用 Zettelkasten 的模拟版本只是为了实现我目前没有使用数字笔记应用程序 Obsidian 做的任何事情。

I hoped that Ahrens’s book could help me mitigate my fear of stopping the current streak I was on (of creating and publishing content consistently). I had some good momentum, which finally seemed to have pulled me out of a lull of just consuming knowledge (instead of producing it). 我希望 Ahrens 的书可以帮助我减轻我对停止当前的连续性（持续创建和发布内容）的恐惧。我有一些良好的动力，这似乎最终使我摆脱了仅仅消费知识（而不是产生知识）的平静。

I was on day forty-eight of my commitment to my daily practice (which entailed things like reading every morning, installing the right mental mindset, working out, actually getting out of my house, and going to my office). 我在第 48 天开始了我的日常练习（包括每天早上阅读、建立正确的心态、锻炼、真正走出家门和去办公室）。

It was a Sunday in early March at 2:16 pm. Before getting down to work in my office in downtown San Diego, I wrote the following: 那是三月初的一个星期天，下午 2 点 16 分。在我在圣地亚哥市中心的办公室开始工作之前，我写了以下内容：

One thing I will say is this: I had the thought today that I really wish and hope that I [do] not make [my daily writing practice] a chore by going insane [using] an atomic workflow. 我要说的一件事是：我今天有一个想法，我真的希望并希望我 [do] 不会因为疯狂 [使用] 原子工作流程而使 [我的日常写作练习] 成为一件苦差事。

Atomic workflow is a term that refers to a trend in web development. The aim is to simplify components of websites by creating representations of different website parts analogous to biological concepts (atoms, molecules, organisms, etc.). For instance, a button on a website is likened to an atom. An input field is another atom. When both atoms are combined, they create a search box (which is likened to a molecule). The search molecule provides search functionality.[293](#footnote-399) 原子工作流是指 Web 开发趋势的术语。目的是通过创建类似于生物概念（原子、分子、有机体等）的不同网站部分的表示来简化网站的组件。例如，网站上的按钮被比作一个原子。输入字段是另一个原子。当两个原子组合在一起时，它们会创建一个搜索框（类似于分子）。搜索分子提供搜索功能。 293

Novel, though this idea may appear, it adds yet another layer of abstraction (and distraction) to the already overly complex field of web development. 新颖，虽然这个想法可能会出现，但它为已经过于复杂的 Web 开发领域增加了另一层抽象（和干扰）。

The temptation to apply the concept of atomicity to fields is not new. In fact, 将原子性概念应用于字段的诱惑并不新鲜。实际上，

in the field of human memory studies, one researcher proposed that human memory, too, adheres to the atomic composition principle. In other words, an item in memory is not one single thing; rather, it’s composed of many smaller subunits like protons, neutrons, and electrons. 在人类记忆研究领域，一位研究人员提出，人类记忆也遵循原子组成原理。换句话说，内存中的一个项目不是一个单一的东西；相反，它由许多更小的子单元组成，例如质子、中子和电子。

The problem with this is the fact that atomicity can be loosely applied to almost anything. This sentence is atomic. Each sentence is an organelle, comprising molecules (words) that themselves comprise atoms (individual letters). This whole abstraction really doesn’t do much. It’s just a trendy fad to break things apart into atomic components. It distracts from the really important stuff, that is, your actual writing output. 问题在于原子性可以松散地应用于几乎任何事物。这句话是原子的。每个句子都是一个细胞器，由分子（单词）组成，分子（单词）本身又包含原子（单个字母）。这整个抽象真的没什么用。将事物分解成原子组件只是一种时尚。它分散了真正重要的东西，即您的实际写作输出。

The atomic design ideology seems to have gripped the imaginations of those enthralled with the world of personal knowledge management (“PKM”). The PKM folk end up spending much of their time on forums debating workflows and best practices which, paradoxically, results in less productivity. As a result, less knowledge is developed for PKM folk to “manage.” 原子设计思想似乎已经抓住了那些着迷于个人知识管理（“PKM”）世界的人们的想象力。 PKM 人员最终将大部分时间花在讨论工作流和最佳实践的论坛上，矛盾的是，这会导致生产力下降。因此，为 PKM 人员开发的知识较少以 “管理”。

Back to the story: on that Sunday afternoon in my office, I felt myself falling into the trap of majoring in the minor. I’ve fallen into this trap thousands of times. I was worried and fearful that all of my recent hard work and progress in getting out of my creative lull and into a productive lifestyle was at risk. The reason why comes down to one word: complexity. The whole atomic workflow concept became a distraction. It led me into the land PKM people habitually become infatuated with: templates, workflows, layouts, plugins, CSS styles, etc. 回到这个故事：在我办公室的那个星期天下午，我觉得自己掉进了辅修专业的陷阱。我已经掉进这个陷阱数千次了。我担心和害怕我最近在摆脱创作停滞和进入富有成效的生活方式方面所做的所有努力和进步都处于危险之中。原因归结为一个词：复杂性。整个原子工作流概念成为一种干扰。它把我带入了 PKM 人们习惯性迷恋的领域：模板、工作流、布局、插件、CSS 样式等。

Yet, I held out hope that the solution to not falling into the trap of complexity would be resolved by reading Sönke Ahrens’s book on notetaking. 然而，我仍然希望通过阅读 Sönke Ahrens 关于记笔记的书来解决不陷入复杂性陷阱的解决方案。

When I started reading How to Take Smart Notes I got a glimpse of how to actually build out an analog Zettelkasten. Every other place online, including the most visited website promoting Zettelkasten, only taught the digital version of the system. 当我开始阅读如何做智能笔记时，我瞥见了如何实际构建一个模拟 Zettelkasten。网上的其他所有地方，包括访问量最大的宣传 Zettelkasten 的网站，都只教授该系统的数字版本。

I remember the realization and thoughts I had shortly after trying out the analog form of the Zettelkasten. I said to myself, Ohhh, so this is what the Zettelkasten is actually supposed to be like! Mind you, this was after I had spent months learning what a Zettelkasten supposedly was (according to people who taught the digital Zettelkasten). 我记得在尝试 Zettelkasten 的模拟形式后不久的认识和想法。我对自己说，哦，这就是 Zettelkasten 实际上应该是什么样子的！请注意，这是在我花了几个月的时间学习 Zettelkasten 应该是什么之后（据教数字 Zettelkasten 的人说的）。

At this point I had already gone through a six-week-long course on linking digital notes, and a ninety minute one-on-one session with the creator of the course. Yet, the lightbulb didn’t turn on until I actually tried using a Zettelkasten in analog form. Side note: It makes me wonder if the people teaching digital notetaking courses are even aware of what working with a Zettelkasten is actually supposed to feel like! 在这一点上，我已经完成了为期六周的链接数字笔记的课程，并与课程的创建者进行了九十分钟的一对一会话。然而，直到我实际尝试使用模拟形式的 Zettelkasten 时，灯泡才亮起。旁注：这让我想知道教授数字笔记课程的人是否知道使用 Zettelkasten 工作的实际感觉！

Anyway, at the time I thought I knew what a Zettelkasten was, but after trying an analog Zettelkasten, it became clear to me that I didn’t. At most I knew 10% of what a Zettelkasten really was all about. I didn’t realize how little I knew about the system until much later. It also took me a while after that to discover that Ahrens’s interpretation of Luhmann’s system was actually quite different from what Luhmann actually did. 不管怎样，当时我以为我知道 Zettelkasten 是什么，但在尝试了模拟 Zettelkasten 之后，我很清楚我不知道。我最多只知道 Zettelkasten 真正含义的 10%。直到很久以后，我才意识到我对这个系统知之甚少。在那之后我也花了一段时间才发现，阿伦斯对卢曼系统的解释实际上与卢曼的实际做法大相径庭。

It was very soon into my working with the analog Zettelkasten that I realized how much better the physical version was. I felt a sense that analog was more powerful than digital not by a little bit, but by a lot! 在我开始使用模拟 Zettelkasten 后不久，我就意识到物理版本要好得多。我以为我花了大约一周的时间才意识到这一点；然而，在后来回顾我的笔记后，我意识到不到一周我就意识到了模拟的力量。我觉得模拟比数字更强大，不是一点点，而是很多！

It was important that the benefits of analog needed to outweigh the benefits of digital by a large margin because I had spent many months of my life building out an extensive digital Zettelkasten (with over a thousand notes). 重要的是，模拟的好处需要大大超过数字的好处，因为我花了很多个月的时间来构建一个广泛的数字 Zettelkasten（有超过一千个音符）。

However, even with the extensive amount of work I put into the digital Zettelkasten system, I simply couldn’t deny the truth: the analog version of the Zettelkasten was simply better than the digital. 然而，即使我在数字 Zettelkasten 系统上投入了大量工作，我还是无法否认这个事实：Zettelkasten 的模拟版本比数字版本更好。

Two days after I had started reading How to Take Smart Notes, I wrote the following down in my journal: “I can’t help but feel like it may be best to move towards analog completely.” I then added the following admission: “To be honest, the primary thing that makes me want to stick with my digital notetaking app is the beautiful font and layout and style I spent this weekend creating.” 在我开始阅读如何做智能笔记两天后，我在日记中写下了以下内容：“我忍不住觉得最好完全转向模拟。” 然后我补充了以下承认：“说实话，让我想坚持使用我的数字笔记应用程序的主要原因是我这个周末创造的漂亮字体、布局和样式。”

The truth was apparent: the digital Zettelkasten system resulted in me not producing genius-level creative output. It also included me spending an entire weekend creating a nifty theme for my notes. I sometimes just can’t help but get distracted with things that don’t matter! 事实很明显：数字 Zettelkasten 系统导致我无法产生天才级的创意输出。相反，数字 Zettelkasten 系统导致我用该工具的花哨功能分散了自己的注意力。最近的时间浪费包括将我的笔记的目录结构和文件夹重组为原子格式。它还包括我花了整个周末为我的笔记创建一个漂亮的主题。有时我会忍不住被无关紧要的事情分心！

Anyway, I found myself still resistant to switching over completely to analog because of the sunk cost fallacy. I was committed to digital because of how much time I had already spent building out my digital notes. Plus, I had no idea about the power of analog yet. As one Antinetter put it to me, “When you use digital notetaking apps, you have no idea how lost you are until you switch to analog.” 无论如何，由于沉没成本谬误，我发现自己仍然拒绝完全切换到模拟。我致力于数字化，因为我已经花了很多时间来构建我的数字笔记。另外，我还不知道模拟的力量。正如一位 Antinetter 对我说的那样，“当你使用数字笔记应用程序时，在你切换到模拟应用程序之前，你不知道自己有多迷茫。”

Here’s what I wrote down in my journal: 这是我在日记中写下的内容：

Pros of Analog: 模拟的优点：

● Simple● 简单

● Fewer distractions● 更少的干扰

● Makes use of my beautiful Montblanc pens● 使用我漂亮的万宝龙钢笔

● More freedom and creativity● 更多的自由和创造力

● Past success (writing by hand really helped my results in college)● 过去的成功（手写确实帮助了我在大学的成绩）

● Academic research backing improved understanding while learning by writing by hand● 学术研究支持在手写学习的同时提高了理解力

● Constraints breed creativity● 约束孕育创造力

● Feynman said “thinking is writing,” and by this he meant, writing longhand.● 费曼说 “思考就是写作”，他的意思是手写。

Cons of Analog: 模拟的缺点：

● Cannot quickly search for keywords. Though to be fair, I don’t even use this feature too extensively right now with [my digital notetaking app]. In addition, the results are rarely that relevant to what I’m looking for).● 无法快速搜索关键字。公平地说，我现在甚至没有在 [我的数字笔记应用程序] 中过多地使用此功能。此外，结果很少与我正在寻找的内容相关）。

● Misses out on training me to write quickly and freely on the keyboard. Though, to be fair, is this really a con? It may be good to slow down and write via longhand because it forces me to actually think deeply before I write.● 错过了训练我在键盘上快速自如地书写的机会。不过，公平地说，这真的是骗局吗？放慢速度并通过手写写作可能会很好，因为它迫使我在写作之前真正深入思考。

● Cannot share or publish my notes easily online. Though, who even wants half-developed information? It’s best to publish work that has already been deeply processed and structured.● 无法在线轻松共享或发布我的笔记。但是，谁甚至想要半开发的信息？最好发表已经过深度处理和结构化的作品。

These were my initial pros and cons, and they are largely still true today; however, I’ve learned more since writing that list. There are more cons to consider, of course (like the risk of fire or water damage to notes, which I’ll address). Yet I discovered later that the initial cons of analog actually are some of its greatest pros. 这些是我最初的利弊，今天它们在很大程度上仍然是正确的；然而，自从写下这份清单后，我学到了更多。当然，还有更多的缺点需要考虑（例如火灾或水损坏纸币的风险，我将解决）。然而我后来发现模拟的最初缺点实际上是它的一些最大的优点。

Let’s now dive into a more in-depth look at the pros and cons of analog I’ve since realized. 现在让我们更深入地了解我已经意识到的模拟的优缺点。

**The Pros of Analog 模拟的优点**
----------------------------

**Analog Creates a Better Communication Partner Than Digital 模拟创造了比数字更好的通信伙伴**

A thing people seem to overlook in regards to Luhmann’s Zettelkasten is that, to Luhmann, his Zettelkasten was not a tool. It was a person. 关于 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten，人们似乎忽略的一件事是，对 Luhmann 而言，他的 Zettelkasten 不是一种工具。那是一个人。

Animism centers on the belief that certain objects, places, plants, and creatures possess a distinct spiritual essence—a soul, if you will. The Antinet serves as a perfect example for such an idea. The Antinet becomes its own unique entity with its own unique personality with whom you communicate. 万物有灵论的核心是相信某些物体、地方、植物和生物具有独特的精神本质——灵魂，如果你愿意的话。 Antinet 是这种想法的完美范例。 Antinet 成为自己独特的实体，具有自己独特的个性，您可以与之交流。

This type of system is watered-down in the world of digital notetaking apps. Digital notetaking apps rarely retain a core structure. Their arms, legs, and feet (i.e., notes, directories, and tags) can be deleted on a whim. They have nothing to build on or stand on. Digital Zettelkasten systems end up looking like a massive interlinked graph of notes, with no personality. 这种类型的系统在数字笔记应用程序的世界中被淡化了。数字笔记应用程序很少保留核心结构。他们的胳膊、腿和脚（即笔记、目录和标签）可以随心所欲地删除。他们没有任何东西可以建立或立足。数字 Zettelkasten 系统最终看起来像一个巨大的相互关联的音符图，没有个性。

The Antinet, on the other hand, does indeed retain a core structure. Its branches, stems of thoughts and notes are never deleted. They evolve and they grow with you throughout your life. They are real, they are physical, they are an extension of you, and they become a part of you. The Antinet becomes your second mind with whom you can communicate with. Again, this is something missing in digital notetaking apps. 另一方面，Antinet 确实保留了一个核心结构。它的分支、思想的主干和注释永远不会被删除。它们在你的一生中与你一起进化和成长。它们是真实的，它们是物质的，它们是你的延伸，它们成为你的一部分。 Antinet 成为您的第二个头脑，您可以与之交流。同样，这是数字笔记应用程序中缺少的东西。

The communication component of the Zettelkasten is critical. Luhmann believed this himself, which is why he titled his paper “Communication with Noteboxes.” As one of the inventors of systems theory, Luhmann said he regards both himself and his Zettelkasten as “systems” and joked that “no one will be surprised [by this].”[294](#footnote-398) He says this jokingly because he’s one of the first and major proponents of applying systems theory to the field of sociology. Yet, Luhmann goes on to explicitly say that “systems theory” is not his choice to begin explaining the Zettelkasten system. Rather, he chooses a “communication theory” to explain what his Zettelkasten actually is.Zettelkasten 的通信组件至关重要。 Luhmann 自己也相信这一点，这就是为什么他将他的论文命名为 “与记事本通信”。作为系统理论的发明者之一，卢曼说他将自己和他的 Zettelkasten 都视为“系统”，并开玩笑说“[对此] 不会有人感到惊讶。”294 他开玩笑地说这话是因为他是第一个也是主要的将系统理论应用于社会学领域的支持者。然而，卢曼继续明确表示，“系统理论” 不是他开始解释 Zettelkasten 系统的选择。相反，他选择了一种 “交流理论” 来解释他的 Zettelkasten 实际上是什么。

The idea of a notebox system emerging into an external instantiation of one’s own communication partner did not originate with Niklas Luhmann. Rather, “this idea actually dates back to a situation already described in 1805 by Heinrich von Kleist in his impressive analysis of the ‘midwifery of thought.’”[295](#footnote-397) 将笔记本系统变成自己的通信伙伴的外部实例的想法并非源自尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann)。相反，“这个想法实际上可以追溯到 1805 年海因里希 · 冯 · 克莱斯特 (Heinrich von Kleist) 在他对‘思想助产’的令人印象深刻的分析中所描述的情况。”295

If you’re going to create something valuable, it requires deep thought, sophisticated ideas, and deep connections. This type of thinking is achieved through writing. Period. 如果你要创造有价值的东西，它需要深刻的思考、复杂的想法和深厚的联系。这种思维是通过写作来实现的。时期。

Since the hardest part is the actual writing (and thinking) it is useful to then transform the process into something that will grow and evolve forever. It also becomes worthwhile for your structure to grow and develop its own unique personality. 由于最困难的部分是实际的写作（和思考），因此将过程转化为将永远成长和进化的东西是有用的。对于您的结构来说，成长和发展自己独特的个性也变得值得。

Writing this book on the Antinet Zettelkasten would be a much different experience and would yield different ideas if I were to write it using the same section of my notes ten years from now. In other words, due to the internal branching nature, my current Antinet will inevitably evolve and grow internally over the years. The Antinet, just like a person, grows in unique ways, and there’s so much richly packed knowledge that it will yield surprising ideas for years to come. This is exciting, as the Antinet presents itself as a goldmine of knowledge waiting to be stumbled upon and used some time in the future, whether that be a year from now or ten years from now. 在 Antinet Zettelkasten 上写这本书将是一种截然不同的经历，如果我在十年后使用我笔记的同一部分来写这本书，将会产生不同的想法。换句话说，由于内部分支的性质，我现在的 Antinet 不可避免地会随着时间的推移在内部进化和壮大。 Antinet 就像一个人一样，以独特的方式成长，并且拥有如此丰富的知识，它将在未来几年产生令人惊讶的想法。这是令人兴奋的，因为 Antinet 将自己呈现为知识的金矿，等待在未来某个时间被偶然发现和使用，无论是一年后还是十年后。

As Luhmann observed, one of the greatest benefits of communication is that each partner can mutually surprise the other with unexpected insight.[296](#footnote-396) When you’re using an Antinet, you’re essentially having a conversation with it as you’re perusing its contents. After you look up the location of an idea in the index, you then embark upon the process of sifting through the cards in the area your index pointed you to. From there, you’re reading your own thoughts in your own handwriting and trying to decipher what that internal voice is saying. Along the way, you’re challenging one another. You come across a card and question its bold claims; yet, upon a closer look you actually realize that its claims are right and you’re wrong! This is like any high-yielding real-life communication experience. You debate one another and are sometimes proven wrong, which is a good thing! 正如 Luhmann 观察到的那样，交流的最大好处之一是每个合作伙伴都可以用意想不到的洞察力相互惊喜。 296 当你使用 Antinet 时，你在仔细阅读它的内容时实质上是在与它进行对话。在索引中查找某个想法的位置后，您就可以开始筛选索引指向的区域中的卡片的过程。从那里，你正在用自己的笔迹阅读自己的想法，并试图破译内心的声音在说什么。一路上，你们在互相挑战。您遇到一张卡片并质疑其大胆的主张；然而，仔细观察后，您实际上会意识到它的主张是正确的，而您是错误的！这就像任何高收益的现实生活交流体验。你们互相辩论，有时被证明是错误的，这是一件好事！

In the several companies I’ve started, I’ve found some of the greatest innovations to come about through just random conversation. My former business partner and I would have lengthy and profound discussions. We would both end up revising and updating our initial perspectives and come up with truly brilliant ideas. This type of experience is something that seems to happen when using an analog Zettelkasten. It’s one of those incommunicable truths that one must experience for themselves to truly grasp. 在我创办的几家公司中，我发现一些最伟大的创新是通过随机对话产生的。我和我以前的商业伙伴会进行冗长而深刻的讨论。我们最终都会修改和更新我们最初的观点，并提出真正绝妙的想法。这种体验似乎在使用模拟 Zettelkasten 时会发生。这是一个人必须亲身体验才能真正领会的不可言传的真理之一。

What Luhmann meant by communication with noteboxes relates to having a conversation with one’s Antinet. This concept is similar to having a conversation with the author of a book that you read. As Mortimer Adler points out in his classic work titled How to Read a Book, reading a book is very much a communication experience. In the book Adler lays out an analogy of a pitcher and catcher in baseball.[297](#footnote-395) The pitcher (the book author) is throwing you a thought (which is the baseball). You, the reader, are the catcher. A baseball catcher is active, not passive. He’s actively anticipating the pitch, ready to adjust to it and adjusts in order to receive it. Communication is not a vegetative experience. The same holds true for reading. It’s not like sitting down on the couch, binge watching whatever is popular on Netflix. It’s a very alert process. This is what it’s like working with an Antinet. 卢曼所说的与笔记本交流的意思是与一个人的 Antinet 进行对话。这个概念类似于与您阅读的一本书的作者进行对话。正如莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 (Mortimer Adler) 在他的经典著作《如何阅读一本书》中指出的那样，阅读一本书在很大程度上是一种交流体验。在书中，阿德勒用棒球中的投手和接球手进行了类比。297 投手（本书作者）正在向您抛出一个想法（这就是棒球）。你，读者，是捕手。棒球接球手是主动的，而不是被动的。他正在积极地预测球场，准备好适应它并进行调整以接收它。交流不是植物人的经历。阅读也是如此。这不像坐在沙发上，狂看 Netflix 上流行的任何节目。这是一个非常警觉的过程。这就是使用 Antinet 的感觉。

Analog Captures One’s Consciousness Better Than Digital 模拟比数字更能捕捉一个人的意识

Another instance of analog serving as a pro over digital revolves around capturing consciousness. 模拟作为数字专业人士的另一个例子围绕着捕捉意识。

The Antinet Zettelkasten unlocks the type of communication relationship Luhmann referenced in “Communication with Noteboxes.” The Antinet Zettelkasten captures your own consciousness, your own past self, in a way that outshines digital Zettelkasten systems because it is truly a partner in a communication relationship between your current self and your past self.Antinet Zettelkasten 开启了 Luhmann 在 “与记事本的交流” 中提到的交流关系类型。 Antinet Zettelkasten 以一种超越数字 Zettelkasten 系统的方式捕捉你自己的意识，你自己过去的自己，因为它是你现在的自己和过去的自己之间交流关系中真正的伙伴。

Alberto Cevolini writes: “Compared with the rhetorical storehouse, the card index preserves a knowledge—we could also say, a past—that not only continually changes but also can be recalled in a highly selective manner.”[298](#footnote-394) 阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 写道：“与修辞库相比，卡片索引保存了一种知识——我们也可以说，一种过去——它不仅不断变化，而且可以以高度选择性的方式回忆起来。”298

When you go digital, you’re quite literally destroying the magic of the Antinet, stripping the system of the person and personality that lives inside it. When I read my handwritten notes from fifteen years ago, they feel much more real than any digital notes I took fifteen years ago (which, believe it or not, are harder for me to find than my physical notes). When I come across handwritten notes from fifteen years ago, I see myself in the handwriting. I see a different version of myself. A past version of myself. My mind is transported into that state, much like a song transports you into some state you were in when you first heard it. 当你走向数字化时，你实际上是在摧毁 Antinet 的魔力，剥夺生活在其中的人和个性的系统。当我阅读 15 年前的手写笔记时，感觉它们比我 15 年前做的任何数字笔记都真实得多（信不信由你，对我来说，电子笔记比我的物理笔记更难找到）。当我看到十五年前的手写笔记时，我在笔迹中看到了自己。我看到了另一个版本的自己。我自己的过去版本。我的思想被传送到那种状态，就像一首歌将你传送到你第一次听到它时所处的状态。

For instance, take the album by Coldplay titled X&Y (yes, I admit, I once listened to Coldplay). Anyway, when I hear a song from the album today, it transports me to the summer of 2005 when I was listening to it on vacation with my family in Hawaii. A similar phenomenon happens when you interact with handwritten notes. You’re transported to the time and place you first read the book and took the note. With each handwritten note, you also transcribe a piece of your own consciousness—your own state and self-awareness—onto the card. This does not seem to happen in the same way with digital systems. 例如，以酷玩乐队名为 X&Y 的专辑为例（是的，我承认，我曾经听过酷玩乐队）。不管怎样，当我今天听到专辑中的一首歌时，它让我想起了 2005 年的夏天，当时我和家人在夏威夷度假时听着这首歌。当您与手写笔记交互时，会发生类似的现象。你被传送到你第一次阅读这本书并记下笔记的时间和地点。对于每一个手写的笔记，你也将自己的意识——你自己的状态和自我意识——转录到卡片上。这似乎不会以与数字系统相同的方式发生。

This argument may sound like woo-woo mysticism, but I assure you it’s not. Scholars are familiar with this notion and Luhmann himself certainly felt this was true.[299](#footnote-393) This is noteworthy since Luhmann’s “Communication with Noteboxes” is heralded as “the most advanced result of a long-lasting reflection performed by modern society.”[300](#footnote-392) 这个论点听起来像是神秘主义，但我向你保证不是。学者们熟悉这个概念，卢曼本人当然也认为这是真的。 299 这是值得注意的，因为卢曼的 “与笔记本的交流” 被誉为“现代社会长期反思的最先进成果。”300

In a thorough and deeply cogent paper on Luhmann’s Zettelkasten, Johannes Schmidt “investigates the origins and development of Luhmann’s filing technique in detail, also availing himself of first-hand information about the content of this exceptional filing cabinet.”[301](#footnote-391) From this paper, Alberto Cevolini concludes that Schmidt’s paper “demonstrates that Luhmann did not regard his filing cabinet as a simple slip box, rather he interacted with it as if it were a true communication partner.”[302](#footnote-390) 在一篇关于 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的透彻而有说服力的论文中，Johannes Schmidt“详细研究了 Luhmann 归档技术的起源和发展，还利用了关于这个特殊文件柜内容的第一手资料。”301 来自这篇论文，Alberto Cevolini 总结说，施密特的论文 “表明卢曼并没有将他的文件柜视为一个简单的滑箱，而是将其作为一个真正的沟通伙伴与之互动。”302

The reason handwritten notes produce the ghost in the box effect (that is, preserving your past self) seems to emanate from one thing: consciousness. Handwritten notes capture your own experience, sentiments, and sentience at the time you wrote your thoughts on the card. 手写笔记之所以会产生盒中幽灵效应（即保留过去的自己），似乎源于一件事：意识。当您在卡片上写下您的想法时，手写笔记会记录您自己的经历、情绪和感受。

Knowledge = meaning x information. Knowledge is dependent on internal dialogue between you and your past self. That is, knowledge deepens during the intrapersonal communication process with your past self’s consciousness. When you read your old notes, in your own handwriting, oftentimes there is meaning that is communicated through the notes that only you, its creator, can understand. This transitions the note from being just information to being a unit of knowledge (information combined with meaning). Analog systems with handwritten notes seem to retain their meaning better than commoditized, non-unique digital typefaces. With digital systems, you can never be 100% absolutely certain that it was indeed you who wrote the text. After all, the content could have been copied and pasted. With your own longhand handwriting, the spirit of your past self is much harder to spoof. 知识 = 意义 x 信息。知识依赖于你和你过去的自己之间的内部对话。也就是说，知识在与过去的自己的意识的人际交流过程中加深。当您阅读自己手写的旧笔记时，通常会有通过笔记传达的含义，只有您（它的创建者）才能理解。这将音符从仅仅是信息转变为知识单元（信息与意义相结合）。带有手写笔记的模拟系统似乎比商品化的、非独特的数字字体更好地保留了它们的意义。使用数字系统，您永远无法 100% 绝对确定文本确实是您所写。毕竟，内容是可以复制粘贴的。有了你自己的手写笔迹，你过去的自我精神就更难被欺骗了。

**Analog Transforms the Zettelkasten into a Thinking Tool (Both Short-Term and Long-Term)Analog 将 Zettelkasten 转变为一种思维工具（短期和长期）**

[Luhmann’s Zettelkasten] served him as a thinking tool. This is not only true in terms of the proposition that the file acted as a communication partner in the research process but also in regard to the fact that in Luhmann’s mind the process of writing things down enables disciplined thinking in the first place: “Underlying the filing technique is the experience that without writing, there is no thinking.”[卢曼的 Zettelkasten] 为他提供了一种思考工具。这不仅在文件作为研究过程中的沟通伙伴的命题方面是正确的，而且在卢曼的思想中，写下事物的过程首先使有纪律的思维成为可能：“在归档技术是一种没有书写就没有思考的体验。”

—Johannes Schmidt in Niklas Luhmann’s Card Index: Thinking Tool, Communication Partner, Publication Machine——约翰内斯 · 施密特在尼克拉斯 · 卢曼的卡片索引中：思维工具、沟通伙伴、出版机器

Johannes Schmidt regards Luhmann’s Zettelkasten as a thinking tool.[303](#footnote-389) There are really two components to this thinking tool: (1) it enhances immediate short-term thinking, and (2) it helps thoughts evolve over the long term. 约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 将卢曼的 Zettelkasten 视为一种思维工具。303 这种思维工具实际上有两个组成部分：(1) 它增强了即时的短期思维，以及 (2) 它帮助思想在长期内发展。

The tool enhances thoughts in the short term through the process of forcing one to think by writing by hand. As Nobel-Prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman once said, “you have to work on paper.”[304](#footnote-388) Or take Alexander Grothendieck, a leading figure in the creation of modern algebraic geometry. In watching Grothendieck work, one person observed, “[Grothendieck] was improvising, in his fast and elegant handwriting. He said that he couldn’t think without writing.”[305](#footnote-387) 该工具通过迫使人们通过手写思考的过程在短期内增强思想。正如获得诺贝尔奖的物理学家理查德 · 费曼曾经说过的那样，“你必须在纸上工作。”304 或者以现代代数几何创立的领军人物亚历山大 · 格洛腾迪克为例。在观看格罗腾迪克的工作时，一个人观察到，“[格罗腾迪克] 正在即兴创作，他的笔迹快速而优雅。他说他不写作就无法思考。”305

In the long term, the Antinet (the thinking tool) grows by way of its tree-like internal branching structure, with more and more handwritten thoughts linking together and creating new related stems. As mentioned, this essentially transforms the Antinet into a new entity altogether—a second mind. 从长远来看，Antinet（思维工具）通过其树状内部分支结构成长，越来越多的手写思想连接在一起并产生新的相关树干。如前所述，这实质上将 Antinet 完全转变为一个新实体——第二思维。

Both the short term component of the thinking tool, and the long-term component of the thinking tool rely on the analog nature of the Antinet. 思维工具的短期组成部分和思维工具的长期组成部分都依赖于 Antinet 的模拟性质。

**Notecards’ Limited Space Force Unlimited Combinations of ThoughtNotecards 有限的空间力量 无限的思想组合**

I’m not a fan of synthetic atomicity. Take for instance, the previously mentioned atomic design methodology which entails thinking of website components as atoms, molecules, organisms, etc.[306](#footnote-386) Such a paradigm overcomplicates the already overcomplicated field of web development. Digital Zettelkasten workflow warriors have jumped on this bandwagon, with people synthetically trying to make their notes atomic by arbitrarily breaking them into smaller parts. However, with most digital Zettelkasten systems, there’s no actual size constraint, such as a character limit, like one would find in Twitter. 我不喜欢合成原子性。例如，前面提到的原子设计方法需要将网站组件视为原子、分子、有机体等。306 这种范式使本已过于复杂的网络开发领域变得过于复杂。 Digital Zettelkasten 工作流勇士们加入了这个潮流，人们综合地试图通过任意将笔记分成更小的部分来使他们的笔记原子化。然而，对于大多数数字 Zettelkasten 系统，没有实际的大小限制，例如字符限制，就像人们在 Twitter 中发现的那样。

For instance, Sönke Ahrens in How to Take Smart Notes writes, “I highly recommend treating a digital note as if the space were limited… Each note should fit onto the screen and there should be no need of scrolling.”[307](#footnote-385) The problem with such advice is that, after some time, it’s too easy to forget to follow it. 例如，Sönke Ahrens 在 How to Take Smart Notes 中写道，“我强烈建议将数字笔记视为空间有限...... 每个笔记都应该适合屏幕并且不需要滚动。”307 这样的问题建议是，一段时间后，很容易忘记遵循它。

Notecards are different. There is an actual, physically limited, space into which one must condense thoughts. The limited notecard space forces true atomicity, unlike inadequately implemented digital notetaking apps. 记事卡是不同的。有一个实际的、物理上有限的空间，人们必须将思想浓缩到其中。与未充分实施的数字笔记应用程序不同，有限的笔记卡空间强制实现了真正的原子性。

Here’s why this is important: scholars studying the field of knowledge argue that atomic knowledge (“dismembered” into notecards) creates combinatory power by way of “links and cross-references” that allow users to “shift their cognitive energies (newly relieved of the burden of memorization) to processing information.”[308](#footnote-384) 这就是为什么这很重要：研究知识领域的学者认为，原子知识（“肢解”到记事本中）通过 “链接和交叉引用” 创造了组合能力，允许用户“转移他们的认知能量（新解除了的负担）处理信息。”308

The shift in cognitive energies does not happen because one is completely relieved of having to memorize anything (as in the case of storing thoughts in a digital notetaking app). Rather, with analog systems, the shift happens because you’ve actually stamped the knowledge into your mind by way of neuroimprinting the knowledge on your mind. This provides you with a working memory of knowledge you can carry with you as you read more material. The name of the game isn’t about offloading thoughts; it’s about neuroimprinting thoughts. This feature, combined with the character limits of notecards, is a great advantage of analog systems. 认知能量的转变不会发生，因为一个人完全不必记住任何东西（就像在数字笔记应用程序中存储思想的情况一样）。相反，对于模拟系统，这种转变的发生是因为你实际上已经通过将知识神经烙印在你脑海中的方式将知识烙印在你的脑海中。这为您提供了知识的工作记忆，您可以在阅读更多材料时随身携带。游戏的名称与卸载思想无关；这是关于神经印记的想法。此功能与记事卡的字符限制相结合，是模拟系统的一大优势。

It’s a paradox. The slower pace required to use an analog Zettelkasten results in a decrease in the number of items put into the system; it simply takes longer to add the same amount of information one might add to a digital system. The same applies to the processing of the information put into each system. With the analog system, more time is required to convert the material you read into knowledge by adding your own reformulations and reflections—something not commonly undertaken in the digital versions. 这是一个悖论。使用模拟 Zettelkasten 所需的较慢速度会导致放入系统的项目数量减少；将相同数量的信息添加到数字系统中只需要更长的时间。这同样适用于输入到每个系统的信息的处理。使用模拟系统，需要更多时间通过添加您自己的重新表述和思考将您阅读的材料转化为知识——这在数字版本中并不常见。

Yet here’s where the paradox emerges. The workflow of the analog system (which takes more time to consume and process less information), actually results in producing a greater quantity of output in less time, compared with digital systems. Also, the quality of the output outshines output produced by digital notetaking systems. 然而，这就是悖论出现的地方。与数字系统相比，模拟系统的工作流程（花费更多的时间来消费和处理更少的信息）实际上会在更短的时间内产生更多的输出。此外，输出质量优于数字笔记系统产生的输出。

There are two key factors that enable the paradoxical occurrence of greater work output from an analog system that slows work down: (1) neuroimprinting enables a more robust working memory when writing and creating output, and (2) the character limit of analog systems enable combinatorial possibilities in perpetuity that thereby enable more content to be generated from the same units of knowledge (namely, from the same notecards). 有两个关键因素导致模拟系统产生更大的工作输出，从而减慢工作速度的矛盾发生：（1）神经印记在编写和创建输出时可以实现更强大的工作记忆，以及（2）模拟系统的字符限制使永久的组合可能性，从而使更多的内容可以从相同的知识单元（即从相同的记事卡）中生成。

**Analog Prevents Hyper-Selection of Irrelevant Material While Reading 模拟防止在阅读时过度选择不相关的材料**

The most critical aspect of notetaking is not what to select from the material you read; it’s what not to select from the material you read. According to Fiona McPherson, a cognitive scientist specializing in the study of Note- taking, the “most crucial” part of the entire process revolves around selection. By selection she is referring to determining what information is important, and just as critically, not selecting information that is not important.[309](#footnote-383) 做笔记最关键的方面不是从你阅读的材料中选择什么；而是这是不要从你阅读的材料中选择的东西。专门研究记笔记的认知科学家 Fiona McPherson 认为，整个过程中 “最关键” 的部分围绕着选择。通过选择，她指的是确定哪些信息是重要的，同样重要的是，不选择不重要的信息。 309

For this reason, tools that help you to not select irrelevant information prove advantageous. The Antinet shines in this respect due to the time and effort required to select material by writing it down by hand (in the process of extracting worthwhile notes and writing them down on a bibcard). This takes much more effort than merely highlighting somewhat interesting passages on a Kindle (something I did before discovering the Antinet). This extraction and selection process ends up increasing your focus while reading, so that you soon adopt a habit of selecting only the most truly meaningful ideas from the material you read. 出于这个原因，帮助您不选择不相关信息的工具被证明是有利的。 Antinet 在这方面大放异彩，因为通过手写来选择材料需要花费时间和精力（在提取有价值的笔记并将它们写在 bibcard 的过程中）。这比仅仅在 Kindle 上突出显示一些有趣的段落（我在发现 Antinet 之前所做的事情）要付出更多的努力。这种提取和选择的过程最终会增加你阅读时的注意力，因此你很快就会养成只从你阅读的材料中选择最真正有意义的想法的习惯。

Analog systems are “highly selective,” as the scholar Alberto Cevolini points out. Its selectivity is a feature, not a bug. Handwriting text is harder than typing text. It takes longer. It forces “selectivity” in the system. “It would be meaningless to move the whole content of a book into [a Zettelkasten],” writes Cevolini.[310](#footnote-382) 正如学者 Alberto Cevolini 指出的那样，模拟系统具有 “高度选择性”。它的选择性是一个特性，而不是一个错误。手写文本比键入文本更难。这需要更长的时间。它在系统中强制 “选择性”。 “将一本书的全部内容转移到 [Zettelkasten] 中是没有意义的，”Cevolini 写道。310

With digital systems, it’s trivial to extract and store information from the 使用数字系统，从中提取和存储信息是微不足道的

material you read. This is not a good thing. Very quickly you accumulate and collect way too much information. Before you know it, you’re drowning. The bad information crowds out the good. This is another reason analog systems outshine digital. 你阅读的材料。这不是一件好事。您很快就会积累和收集太多信息。在不知不觉中，你就溺水了。坏信息排挤好信息。这是模拟系统优于数字系统的另一个原因。

**Analog Enables One to Compare, Contrast, and Organize Thoughts Better Than Digital 模拟使人们能够比数字更好地比较、对比和组织思想**

As Sönke Ahrens observes, “to have concrete notes in front of our eyes and be able to compare them directly makes differences, even small ones, much easier to spot.”[311](#footnote-381) 正如 Sönke Ahrens 所观察到的，“在我们眼前有具体的记录并能够直接比较它们使得差异，即使是很小的差异，也更容易被发现。”311

I couldn’t have written this book without the aid of laying out all of the different sections on my desk. I created a hub of cards that had collective cardlinks on them. Each card was organized by topic and contained subtopics that pointed me to various card addresses in my Antinet. I then moved them around a large table to create the perfect logical layout for this book. Here’s a picture of it: 如果没有把所有不同的部分都摆在我的桌子上，我就不可能写出这本书。我创建了一个卡片中心，上面有集体卡片链接。每张卡片都按主题组织，并包含子主题，这些子主题将我指向 Antinet 中的各种卡片地址。然后我将它们移到一张大桌子周围，为本书创建完美的逻辑布局。这是它的图片：

To write the book, I simply proceeded card-by-card and column-by-column. Each card contained its own numeric-alpha address in the top-right corner so that they could later be refiled in my Antinet. Here’s a closer look: 为了写这本书，我只是逐张卡片、逐列进行。每张卡片的右上角都有自己的数字字母地址，以便以后可以在我的 Antinet 中重新归档。仔细看看：

In the past, I’ve used analogous digital tools like Trello, Scrivener and others to organize information. None came close to my experience of physically working with knowledge. By moving around the individual units on a table, writing my book became a much easier task. This is but another overlooked advantage of analog knowledge systems. 过去，我曾使用类似的数字工具（如 Trello、Scrivener 等）来组织信息。没有人能接近我用知识进行身体工作的经历。通过在桌子上移动各个单元，写我的书变得容易得多。这只是模拟知识系统的另一个被忽视的优势。

**Analog Forces One to Follow Best Practices 模拟迫使人们遵循最佳实践**

One of the other benefits of an analog system centers on the fact that it forces one to follow best practices and guidelines brought forth by digital Zettelkasten teachers. For instance, one author teaching digital Zettelkasten recommends linking and rewriting notes in order to make notetaking less boring.[312](#footnote-380) This advice is a recommendation for digital Zettelkasten users. For analog Zettelkasten users, it’s a requirement. There’s no other choice. There seems to be confusion among digital Zettelkasten practitioners about this. Every single time you install a card in the Antinet, you’re effectively linking it to all other cards in the system. You give it a numeric-alpha address that provides it with a chained location in your tree of knowledge. It’s essentially linked to its closest neighbors, and their closest neighbors, and their closest neighbors, and on and on. 模拟系统的其他好处之一在于它迫使人们遵循数字 Zettelkasten 教师提出的最佳实践和指导方针。例如，一位教授数字 Zettelkasten 的作者建议链接和重写笔记，以使记笔记不那么无聊。312 此建议是对数字 Zettelkasten 用户的建议。对于模拟 Zettelkasten 用户，这是一项要求。别无选择。数字 Zettelkasten 从业者似乎对此感到困惑。每次你在 Antinet 中安装一张卡，你就有效地将它链接到系统中的所有其他卡。你给它一个数字字母地址，在你的知识树中为它提供一个链式位置。它本质上与其最近的邻居、最近的邻居、最近的邻居等等相连。

With digital Zettelkasten systems, developers devise synthetic rules and methodologies to improvise for their own best practices. Digital Zettelkasten systems have jury-rigged guidelines and principles that are all but impossible to follow because they require near-perfect self-discipline to stick with. With the Antinet, no self-discipline is required. The best practices of linking every note and rewriting and rephrasing ideas is built into the core protocol of analog systems. 借助数字 Zettelkasten 系统，开发人员可以设计综合规则和方法来即兴发挥他们自己的最佳实践。数字 Zettelkasten 系统具有临时操纵的准则和原则，这些准则和原则几乎不可能遵循，因为它们需要近乎完美的自律才能坚持。使用 Antinet，无需自律。链接每个音符以及重写和改写想法的最佳实践已内置到模拟系统的核心协议中。

In brief, Digital Zettelkasten systems rely on willpower to function. If you’re using a system that relies on personal willpower, it’s inevitable that a breakdown will occur at some point. With the Antinet, this is not an issue. 简而言之，Digital Zettelkasten 系统依靠意志力发挥作用。如果您使用的系统依赖于个人意志力，那么不可避免地会在某个时候出现故障。使用 Antinet，这不是问题。

**Analog Exposes Your Own Mistakes and Self-Deceptions More Effectively Than Digital 模拟比数字更有效地暴露你自己的错误和自欺欺人**

Modern society’s most fundamental metaphorical symbol for good vs. evil is the biblical tree of knowledge. Like the biblical tree of knowledge, your own tree of knowledge that you create in the Antinet is susceptible to evil information. Actually, let’s not call it evil information, but unwise information. The unwise information I speak of does not derive from cunning serpents tempting you to eat a fruit.[313](#footnote-379) Rather, the unwise information I speak of derives from a different beast altogether: yourself! 现代社会最基本的善与恶的隐喻符号是圣经中的知识树。就像圣经的知识树一样，你自己在 Antinet 中创建的知识树很容易受到邪恶信息的影响。其实，我们不要把它称为邪恶的信息，而是不明智的信息。我所说的不明智的信息并非来自狡猾的蛇引诱你吃水果。313 相反，我所说的不明智的信息完全来自另一种野兽：你自己！

Indeed, when you review the thoughts of your mind and happen upon a view or opinion you no longer hold as true, it’s extremely difficult to delude yourself into believing you never held such an opinion. Why? Because it’s staring you in the face—in your own handwriting. 确实，当您回顾自己的想法并偶然发现您不再持有的观点或观点时，很难自欺欺人地相信自己从未持有过这样的观点。为什么？因为它正盯着你的脸——用你自己的笔迹。

You see, your Antinet, your own tree of knowledge, contains both wise fruit and unwise fruit (or good fruit vs. evil fruit). 你看，你的 Antinet，你自己的知识之树，既包含智慧的果实，也包含不智慧的果实（或善果与恶果）。

On one hand, it’s important to express your thoughts and ideas truly with conviction and self-belief. As Charlie Munger says, “Never underestimate the man who overestimates himself.”[314](#footnote-378) As Gary Halbert, the best copywriter who ever lived puts it, “Nothing is impossible for the man who refuses to listen to reason.”[315](#footnote-377) While certainly containing some truth, both Munger’s and Halbert’s statements communicate the jocoserious reality implanted within their words. At one level, Munger and Halbert were advocating for their readers to believe in themselves; yet, at another level they were warning of the power wielded in doing so. 一方面，以信念和自信真实地表达你的想法和想法很重要。正如查理芒格所说，“永远不要低估那些高估自己的人。”314 正如有史以来最好的文案撰稿人加里哈尔伯特所说，“对于拒绝听从理性的人来说，没有什么是不可能的。”315 虽然肯定包含一些真理, 芒格和哈尔伯特的陈述都传达了他们话语中植入的诙谐严肃的现实。在一个层面上，芒格和哈尔伯特提倡他们的读者要相信自己；然而，在另一个层面上，他们警告这样做会产生巨大的影响力。

Taken to the extreme, self-belief quickly can transform into self-delusion. “The simple truth,” as Munger puts it, “is that we aren’t adapted to face the world as it is today.” He goes on to outline how critical the environment was for shaping the traits of our ancestors. “We can learn to push our minds into alternative ways of thinking, but it isn’t easy.” Why’s that? It comes down to one thing, according to Munger: “self-deception.”[316](#footnote-376) 走到极端，自信很快就会变成自欺欺人。 “一个简单的事实，” 正如芒格所说，“我们不适应当今世界。” 他接着概述了环境对于塑造我们祖先的特征的重要性。 “我们可以学会将我们的思想推向不同的思维方式，但这并不容易。” 为什么？根据芒格的说法，这归结为一件事：“自欺欺人”。 316

Systems that expose us to our own self-deception and mistakes in thinking are far more valuable than systems that conceal such things. 让我们暴露在自我欺骗和思维错误中的系统比隐藏这些东西的系统更有价值。

**Analog Stamps Your Mistakes In Time (And This is a Good Thing) 模拟会及时标记您的错误（这是一件好事）**

There is a saying dating back to at least 1915, “Everybody makes mistakes—that’s why they put erasers on pencils.”[317](#footnote-375) I first heard this saying from my dad. However, when he recited it to me, I found myself disagreeing with a small but important component of it. My position is that, while it’s useful to erase mistakes, there is an even more valuable exercise in not using an eraser at all! Instead, it’s better to append new, corrected information behind or under the initial mistake. That way, you can view a history of your mistakes and see your growth. It also serves as a useful tool in the future for reviewing your past mistakes. 至少可以追溯到 1915 年的一句话是：“每个人都会犯错——这就是他们在铅笔上放橡皮的原因。”317 我第一次听到这句话是从我父亲那里听到的。然而，当他向我背诵时，我发现自己不同意其中一小部分但很重要的部分。我的立场是，虽然擦除错误很有用，但根本不使用橡皮擦是一种更有价值的练习！相反，最好在最初的错误后面或下面附加新的、更正的信息。这样，您就可以查看自己的错误历史并看到自己的成长。它还可以作为将来回顾过去错误的有用工具。

Why are mistakes valuable? Because they curb the risk of a grandiosity. Charlie Munger says it best: “I like people admitting they were complete stupid horses’ asses. I know I’ll perform better if I rub my nose in my mistakes. This is a wonderful trick to learn.”[318](#footnote-374) 为什么错误是有价值的？因为它们遏制了浮夸的风险。查理芒格说得最好：“我喜欢人们承认他们是彻头彻尾的蠢驴。我知道如果我对自己的错误嗤之以鼻，我会表现得更好。这是一个很好的学习技巧。”318

After stating my case against erasers, my mom chimed in and backed me on this. Of course my dad wasn’t arguing for the literal idea of forgetting about your mistakes. Neither was the original quote stating this. The quote about erasers argues that you should be OK making mistakes. This is 100% accurate. But if you want to experience next-level growth, you need to append revisions to your mistakes behind or beneath the initial mistake. Don’t erase them. More, you need to rub your nose in your mistakes! It’s humbling, it’s deflating, but after a while, you start to develop a thick skin. 在陈述了我反对橡皮擦的情况后，我妈妈插话并支持我。当然，我父亲并不是在争论忘记错误的字面意思。原始报价也没有说明这一点。关于橡皮擦的引述认为你应该可以犯错误。这是 100% 准确的。但是，如果你想体验下一个层次的成长，你需要在最初的错误之后或之下对你的错误进行修正。不要删除它们。更重要的是，你需要对自己的错误嗤之以鼻！这让人感到羞愧，让人泄气，但过了一会儿，你的脸皮开始变厚了。

The power of the Antinet is that it stamps your mistakes in a capsule of time. You then view the evolution of your own self-deception in order to not fall into the trap of making similar mistakes again.Antinet 的强大之处在于它可以将您的错误标记在时间胶囊中。然后，您查看自己的自欺欺人的演变，以免再次犯下类似错误的陷阱。

With digital systems, it’s all-too-easy to simply overwrite or delete your own mistakes. 使用数字系统，简单地覆盖或删除您自己的错误太容易了。

As Johannes Schmidt observes of Luhmann’s Antinet: 正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 对卢曼 (Luhmann) 的 Antinet 的评论：

It contains not only validated knowledge but also reflects the thought process, including potential mistakes and blind alleys that were later revised but not removed from the file as the original cards always remained in Luhmann’s file and perhaps a new card with revisions was added if needed.[319](#footnote-373) 它不仅包含经过验证的知识，还反映了思维过程，包括潜在的错误和死胡同，这些错误和死胡同后来被修改但没有从文件中删除，因为原始卡片始终保留在 Luhmann 的文件中，如果需要，可能会添加一张经过修改的新卡片。 319

As the scholar, Markus Krajewski, writes of using an analog Zettelkasten, “The reader is not only reading his own memory, but rather also his shifting frame of reference over time.”[320](#footnote-372) Thus, when you review your own notes (in your own handwriting), you have changing perspectives that shift over time. You can view your “less complex” thoughts and how they’ve changed, developed and internally evolved over a long period. 正如学者 Markus Krajewski 在谈到使用模拟 Zettelkasten 时所写的那样，“读者不仅在阅读他自己的记忆，而且还在阅读他随时间变化的参照系。”320 因此，当你回顾自己的笔记时（在你自己的手写），你的观点会随着时间而改变。您可以查看您 “不太复杂” 的想法，以及它们在很长一段时间内是如何变化、发展和内部演变的。

Most surprising are the links stamped onto the cards at the moment you wrote them that shed light on what the past version of you was thinking at the time when you wrote them. “What is more surprising are the references listed.”[321](#footnote-371) 最令人惊讶的是在你写卡片的那一刻印在卡片上的链接，这些链接揭示了你过去的版本在你写它们的时候在想什么。 “更令人惊讶的是列出的参考文献。”321

Here’s an example from my own life. I once confused the terms prospection and proprioception. 这是我自己生活中的一个例子。我曾经混淆了前景和本体感觉这两个术语。

Prospection is the concept of creating mental representations about the future (or possible future scenarios). Proprioception refers to your body’s ability to sense movement, action, or its location. 展望是创造关于未来（或可能的未来情景）的心理表征的概念。本体感觉是指您的身体感知运动、动作或其位置的能力。

This is one of my older notes (on a 3 x 5 inch card; for newer notes I use 4 x 6 inch cards). It’s a reformulation note I took from reading the book, Sapiens. The card address is 2714/4: 这是我的旧笔记之一（在 3 x 5 英寸的卡片上；对于较新的笔记，我使用 4 x 6 英寸的卡片）。这是我从阅读《智人》一书时记下的重新表述的笔记。卡地址为 2714/4：

In the bottom left-hand corner I added an update in green ink (which tells me it’s a new comment I added long after making the card): “Error,” and in blue ink I include the cardlink: 3525/2A.[322](#footnote-370) If we navigate to card 3525/2A, we find the following: 在左下角，我用绿色墨水添加了一个更新（这告诉我这是我在制作卡片很久之后添加的新评论）：“错误”，我用蓝色墨水添加了卡片链接：3525/2A.322 如果我们导航到卡 3525/2A，我们发现以下内容：

Immediately linked to this card (by way of the tree internal branching structure), I find an old card 3525/2. 立即链接到这张卡（通过树内部分支结构），我找到一张旧卡 3525/2。

Aha! This is what I thought of originally when I wrote the first card (2714/4), but I couldn’t quite recall where the idea came from, or what the term I was thinking of was. When I initially wrote 2714/4, I made the mistake of confusing the term proprioception with prospection, a concept I first learned about in the book Stumbling on Happiness. 啊哈！这是我在写第一张牌 (2714/4) 时最初的想法，但我不太记得这个想法从何而来，或者我想的术语是什么。当我最初写 2714/4 时，我犯了一个错误，将本体感觉和前景混淆了，这是我在《绊倒幸福》一书中首次了解到的概念。

Locking this mistake into a permanent state then allows me to communicate that such terms are sometimes confused. For instance, when writing a piece that happens to use the concept of prospection in the future, I could start with something like, A term sometimes confused with proprioception is that of prospection, which means X, whereas proprioception means Y. Stamping such a mistake permanently in the Antinet helps me refresh and re-remind myself of the confusion in order to prevent the mistake from occurring again. Even more powerful, however, is the opportunity this creates for an accidental breakthrough and creative insight. For instance, I could ask myself, How are the concepts of proprioception related? Interestingly enough, they are somewhat related. Proprioception involves the mental representation of your present self; whereas prospection relates to the mental representation of your future self. We can then explore why this may be the case by digging into the etymology of the terms. Before you know it, you’re embarking on a journey of going deep into a field of knowledge that fascinates you. Inevitably you’ll end up with much richer insights than is typically found taking digital notes. 将这个错误锁定为永久状态然后让我传达这些术语有时会混淆。例如，当写一篇碰巧在未来使用前景概念的文章时，我可以从这样的东西开始，有时与本体感觉混淆的术语是前景，它意味着 X，而本体感觉意味着 Y。标记这样的错误永久在 Antinet 帮助我刷新并重新提醒自己的混乱，以防止错误再次发生。然而，更强大的是这为意外突破和创造性洞察创造的机会。例如，我可以问自己，本体感觉的概念是如何相关的？有趣的是，它们有些关联。本体感觉涉及当前自我的心理表征；而前景与你未来自我的心理表征有关。然后，我们可以通过深入研究这些术语的词源来探究为什么会出现这种情况。不知不觉中，您就踏上了深入某个令您着迷的知识领域的旅程。不可避免地，你最终会得到比通常做数字笔记更丰富的见解。
