There are ways to jury-rig such a system in digital form (using Git, for instance). However, I find that such solutions are an afterthought. They may expose the “change history” of a note or a document; however the feature is usually placed to the side of the screen of the main note. Even then, it requires manual digging and clicking to reveal the commit history (or change history0 of the note. With an Antinet, such a feature is baked into the core protocol of the system. 有一些方法可以以数字形式临时装配这样的系统（例如使用 Git）。但是，我发现这样的解决方案是事后才想到的。他们可能会公开注释或文档的 “更改历史记录”；但是，该功能通常位于主笔记屏幕的一侧。即便如此，它也需要手动挖掘和点击来揭示提交历史（或笔记的更改历史）。有了 Antinet，这样的功能被融入到系统的核心协议中。

**Analog Enables You to Gain Better Familiarity with Your Knowledge 模拟使您能够更好地熟悉您的知识**

Another key property of the Antinet is revealed by Luhmann’s familiarity with his own tree of knowledge. Luhmann knew his Zettelkasten like the back of his hand. His knowledge was permanently stamped onto his mind. One critical aspect of becoming a “publication machine” is how well you know your way around your knowledge. Johannes Schmidt does not overlook this factor, observing Luhmann “engaged in an ongoing process of tending to his file.”[323](#footnote-369) The extensive time he spent doing this resulted in him gaining a deep understanding of his knowledge. For a thirty-plus year repository of information, one would think there would be a detailed table of contents to help him navigate; however, “Luhmann never created a detailed table of contents.”[324](#footnote-368)Antinet 的另一个关键属性是卢曼对他自己的知识树的熟悉程度。 Luhmann 对他的 Zettelkasten 了如指掌。他的知识永久地印在了他的脑海中。成为 “出版机器” 的一个关键方面是您对知识的了解程度。约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 并没有忽视这一因素，他观察到卢曼“一直在处理他的档案。”323 他在这方面花费的大量时间使他对自己的知识有了深刻的理解。对于一个三十多年的信息库，人们会认为会有一个详细的目录来帮助他导航；然而，“卢曼从未创建过详细的目录。”324

Luhmann benefitted greatly by being essentially forced to work with his knowledge as it accumulated (due to the Zettelkasten’s analog nature, and there being no search feature). This critical property allowed him to store deeply interconnected and complex information. It helped him integrate new ideas, all while gracefully navigating his mind and memory (past and present). He would insert newly acquired information into the appropriate place which resulted in deeply evolved thoughts.Luhmann 从本质上被迫使用他积累的知识（由于 Zettelkasten 的模拟性质，并且没有搜索功能）而受益匪浅。这一关键特性使他能够存储相互关联且复杂的信息。它帮助他整合新想法，同时优雅地引导他的思想和记忆（过去和现在）。他会将新获得的信息插入适当的位置，从而产生深刻的思想。

How did Luhmann achieve such a deeply imprinted “groove” of his thoughts? There’s several ways. First, his ideas were neuroimprinted on his mind due to the analog nature of the system. Second, he developed rapid recall of information from the deep web-like network embedded in the analog system. He developed this faculty by engaging in the ongoing process of tending to his Antinet.[325](#footnote-367) When you partake in this process, it’s very much distinct from the process of reviewing digital files. Reviewing digital files can cause your eyes to glaze over. You forget what you’re searching for and soon become distracted by other things. 卢曼是如何在他的思想中留下如此深刻烙印的？有几种方法。首先，由于系统的模拟性质，他的想法在他的脑海中留下了神经烙印。其次，他从嵌入模拟系统的类似深层网络的网络中开发出快速的信息召回能力。他通过参与持续照料他的 Antinet 的过程来培养这种能力。325 当你参与这个过程时，它与审查数字文件的过程有很大不同。查看数字文件可能会使您的眼睛呆滞。你会忘记你在寻找什么，很快就会被其他事情分心。

With the Antinet, searching for notes becomes a fun, active process, during which you think about and have a conversation with the material. You often find yourself challenging your notes, or, trying to understand the context that led you to write a particular thought. Most important, the process builds your memory in such a way that you and all of your thoughts and learnings reverberate in your mind. You effectively prime your mind for compounding growth, which emerges in your output. 使用 Antinet，搜索笔记成为一个有趣、积极的过程，在此过程中您可以思考并与材料进行对话。你经常发现自己在挑战你的笔记，或者试图理解导致你写下特定想法的背景。最重要的是，这个过程会以这样一种方式建立你的记忆，让你和你所有的想法和学习在你的脑海中回荡。你有效地为复合增长做好了准备，这会出现在你的产出中。

For me, this was an unexpected hidden benefit of analog. In retrospect, however, it’s pretty obvious. You build out your brain’s memory constantly without feeling like it’s a chore. 对我来说，这是模拟的一个意想不到的隐藏好处。然而，回想起来，这很明显。你不断地建立你的大脑记忆而不觉得这是一件苦差事。

In my time using digital notetaking apps, I forced such a practice upon myself using a plugin that opened a random note. This didn’t last long. Opening a random note every day felt like a chore, and I quickly dropped the practice. 在我使用数字笔记应用程序的时候，我使用一个打开随机笔记的插件强迫自己进行这种练习。这并没有持续多久。每天打开一个随机的笔记感觉像是一件苦差事，我很快就放弃了这种做法。

A more effective method, which I’ve stuck with for over a decade, is the practice of reviewing a random chunk notecards. I would randomly sift through my reading notes and allow the concepts I had previously read to reverberate through my mind. 我坚持了十多年的一种更有效的方法是复习随机块记事卡的做法。我会随机筛选我的阅读笔记，让我以前读过的概念在我的脑海中回荡。

Still, it requires self-discipline and seems to wane after some time. However, in working with an Antinet, one reviews thoughts automatically while searching for ideas. It’s a lot more fun. It’s less of a chore, and it always introduces opportunities for surprises. 尽管如此，它仍然需要自律，并且似乎会在一段时间后减弱。然而，在使用 Antinet 时，人们会在搜索想法时自动回顾想法。这更有趣。这不是一件苦差事，而且总是会带来惊喜的机会。

The ability to rapidly learn and later retrieve novel associations, memories, and information is an important ability. In fact, it’s a core part of what makes us human. This is why such a feature is so important in the Antinet. As Michael Kahana states, one’s ability to recall and associate ideas is “an important tool in coping effectively with one’s environment.”[326](#footnote-366) 快速学习并在以后检索新的联想、记忆和信息的能力是一项重要的能力。事实上，它是使我们成为人类的核心部分。这就是为什么这样的功能在安网中如此重要的原因。正如 Michael Kahana 所说，一个人回忆和联想想法的能力是 “有效应对环境的重要工具。”326

Yet in our era of rapidly expanding digital technology, with regard to human memory, people seem to throw logic and rationality out the window. That same Kahana also points out that having a good memory may not be all that important for the ultimate survival of the species due to our “present era of personal-data assistants and Google’s vast searchable databases.”[327](#footnote-365) 然而在我们这个数字技术迅速发展的时代，关于人类的记忆，人们似乎把逻辑和理性抛到了窗外。同一个 Kahana 还指出，由于我们 “现在的个人数据助理时代和谷歌庞大的可搜索数据库”，拥有良好的记忆力对于物种的最终生存可能并不那么重要。 327

This logical jump misses one thing: actual logic. Developing your memory and your ability to recognize patterns when learning new information is critical—and likely will remain critical—at the least for noteworthy success in your field. Analog systems enhance this faculty; digital systems seem less effective in doing so. 这种逻辑跳跃遗漏了一件事：实际逻辑。在学习新信息时培养你的记忆力和识别模式的能力是至关重要的——而且可能仍然是关键——至少对于你所在领域的显着成功而言。模拟系统增强了这种能力；数字系统在这方面似乎不太有效。

**Other Pros of Analog Systems 模拟系统的其他优点**

One concept you’ll learn about in this book is what is termed external context in the field of human memory studies. External context introduces properties that can later help you recall information and knowledge. These things include parts of your sensory system—sounds, tastes, textures, etc.[328](#footnote-364) These properties are found in analog systems; they are not native to digital systems. In a later section I talk about how I retrieve certain memories and ideas based on the external context and cues generated by certain notecards. Digital systems do not possess such features. 您将在本书中了解到的一个概念是人类记忆研究领域中的外部环境。外部上下文引入了以后可以帮助您回忆信息和知识的属性。这些东西包括你的感官系统的一部分——声音、味道、质地等。328 这些属性存在于模拟系统中；它们不是数字系统原生的。在后面的部分中，我将讨论如何根据特定记事卡生成的外部环境和线索来检索特定的记忆和想法。数字系统不具备这样的特性。

**The Science Behind Analog Systems Developing Knowledge 模拟系统发展知识背后的科学**

The premise of analog systems aiding in the development of your mind (compared with digital systems) can be explained by the latest research in the study of human memory. With analog systems, you’re constantly in a state of recognition, reviewing thoughts found in your own system and trying to recognize the core idea behind the concept. When you read new information you’re also trying to recognize the core idea behind the concept. 模拟系统有助于思维发展的前提（与数字系统相比）可以通过人类记忆研究的最新研究来解释。使用模拟系统，你会一直处于识别状态，回顾在你自己的系统中发现的想法，并试图识别概念背后的核心思想。当您阅读新信息时，您也在尝试识别概念背后的核心思想。

When you recognize a concept, thought, or idea, two processes occur within your mind. 当您识别出一个概念、想法或想法时，您的头脑中会发生两个过程。

First, the familiarity process kicks into gear. When you think of the concept or idea, a value of your confidence in the familiarity of the content that arises emerges. It’s essentially a confidence value of how confident you are and how familiar you are with a thought. This concept comprises something called strength theory in human memory. 首先，熟悉过程启动。当你想到这个概念或想法时，你对所出现的内容的熟悉程度的信心值就会出现。它本质上是一个信心值，表示你有多自信以及你对一个想法有多熟悉。这个概念包含了人类记忆中称为强度理论的东西。

The second process is the recollection process. The recollection process involves the recall of contextual information related to the content of the thought. 第二个过程是回忆过程。回忆过程涉及回忆与思想内容相关的上下文信息。

For exceptional knowledge work, it’s critical to exercise your mind’s recognition ability—that is, the faculty for recognizing concepts, thoughts, and ideas. This is critical because it allows you to do two things when reading a text: 对于出色的知识型工作，锻炼大脑的识别能力至关重要——即识别概念、思想和创意的能力。这很关键，因为它可以让你在阅读文本时做两件事：

First, it enables you to create information by way of comparison. As Luh- mann writes: 首先，它使您能够通过比较来创建信息。正如卢曼所写：

Information is an intra-systematic event. It results when one compares one message or entry with regard to other possibilities. Information, accordingly, originates only in systems which possess a comparative schema—even if this amounts only to: “this or something else.”[329](#footnote-363) 信息是系统内的事件。当一个人将一条消息或条目与其他可能性进行比较时，就会产生这种结果。因此，信息仅起源于具有比较图式的系统——即使这仅相当于：“这个或其他东西。”329

By neuroimprinting concepts in your mind, you’re effectively enabling a working memory store of knowledge to compare with new ideas that you come across in your reading. You then set off a process of comparing the idea from your readings with the knowledge already stored in your Antinet. You cannot install a new piece of knowledge in your Antinet without comparing it to your current knowledge. You’re forced to find the most similar location wherein that knowledge should be installed. With digital systems, this is not a requirement. Digital does not force the comparison process into every single note before it’s created. 通过在脑海中留下概念的神经印记，您可以有效地启用知识的工作记忆库，以便与您在阅读中遇到的新想法进行比较。然后你开始将你阅读的想法与你的 Antinet 中已经存储的知识进行比较。如果不与您当前的知识进行比较，您就无法在 Antinet 中安装新知识。您被迫找到应该安装该数据的最相似位置。对于数字系统，这不是必需的。 Digital 不会在创建之前将比较过程强制到每个音符中。

Second, by exercising your ability to recollect concepts, you are forced to relate information to a selective set of other relations (a process necessary to create knowledge, and through action, wisdom). 其次，通过锻炼你回忆概念的能力，你被迫将信息与一组有选择的其他关系联系起来（这是创造知识所必需的过程，并通过行动获得智慧）。

To summarize, the analog nature of the Antinet develops the mind’s faculties for recollecting and recognizing interesting patterns while reading. This allows you to make connections to material ruminating in your second mind. 总而言之，Antinet 的模拟性质开发了大脑在阅读时回忆和识别有趣模式的能力。这使您可以在第二个头脑中与材料反省建立联系。

Familiarity is developed through writing longhand, and it is furthered due to the system not having a search feature. There’s no other choice but to actively review and work with your knowledge. 熟悉是通过手写来培养的，并且由于系统没有搜索功能而得到进一步发展。别无选择，只能积极复习并运用你的知识。

Recollection emerges through developing your thoughts within contexts (i.e., branches, stems and areas within your tree of knowledge). 回忆是通过在情境中发展你的思想而出现的（即，你的知识树中的分支、茎干和区域）。

As some scholars have observed, both of these variables paradoxically transform notetaking from a system designed to store memories into a system that both stores and enhances memories. “[Handwritten] notetaking [due to repetition that helped the mind retain passages] and the respective construction of a card index were considered both a substitute for personal memory and a memory aid.”[330](#footnote-362) 正如一些学者所观察到的，这两个变量自相矛盾地将笔记从一个旨在存储记忆的系统转变为一个既能存储又能增强记忆的系统。 “[手写]记笔记 [由于重复有助于大脑记住段落] 和卡片索引的相应构建被认为既是个人记忆的替代品，也是记忆辅助工具。”330

This phenomenon may not be exclusive to analog systems, however I argue that it’s more common in analog systems because analog systems force the occurrence of familiarity and recollection, even if it’s inconvenient (it’s much more convenient to use the search box of a digital notetaking app). 这种现象可能不是模拟系统所独有的，但我认为它在模拟系统中更常见，因为模拟系统迫使熟悉和回忆的发生，即使它不方便（使用数字笔记应用程序的搜索框要方便得多).

Luhmann talked about generalizing concepts and abstracting them out in such a way as to create containers of insight later on. He highlighted the practice of creating answers to specific questions that he could ask his Antinet. For instance, Luhmann posed the following question: why are museums empty, whereas exhibits of paintings by Monet, Picasso, or Medici are too crowded? The answer seems to revolve around exhibits being short-term events—they’re “temporally limited.” Luhmann then created the following index entry: “preference for what is temporally limited.” This allowed Luhmann to accumulate more cards that exhibit a preference for what is temporally limited.[331](#footnote-361) Later, when more cards accumulated under this entry, Luhmann could compare the different phenomena that correlated with a preference for what is temporally limited. From there he could spot patterns and propose a theory for why certain things occur. 卢曼谈到了概括概念并将它们抽象出来，以便在以后创建洞察力的容器。他强调了为他可以问他的 Antinet 的特定问题创建答案的做法。例如，卢曼提出了以下问题：为什么博物馆空无一人，而莫奈、毕加索或美第奇的画展却人满为患？答案似乎围绕着作为短期事件的展览展开——它们 “在时间上是有限的”。卢曼随后创建了以下索引条目：“对暂时受限的事物的偏好”。这使得 Luhmann 能够积累更多表现出对时间限制的偏好的卡片。331 后来，当更多的卡片在这个条目下积累时，Luhmann 可以比较与对时间限制的偏好相关的不同现象。从那里他可以发现模式并提出一种理论来解释某些事情为什么会发生。

This is a deliberate process. It takes work and effort to create. There’s no magical future to surface such insights. Cutesy bubble graphs of notes won’t magically surface such insights. Neither will the so-called “power of digital search.” 这是一个深思熟虑的过程。创造需要付出努力和努力。没有神奇的未来可以浮出水面。可爱的笔记气泡图不会神奇地浮出水面。所谓的 “数字搜索的力量” 也不会。

Let’s talk briefly about the notion concerning the power of digital search. In reality, the power of digital search is a myth. Due to search functionality, digital notetaking systems possess less impetus to exercise the recognition faculty of one’s mind. With analog, you’re forced to deliberately create patterns in your mind as well as shortcuts for concepts to spot later on. This is yet another advantage of analog systems. 让我们简要谈谈有关数字搜索功能的概念。实际上，数字搜索的力量是一个神话。由于搜索功能，数字笔记系统缺乏锻炼大脑识别能力的动力。使用模拟，您被迫在脑海中刻意创建模式以及稍后发现概念的捷径。这是模拟系统的另一个优势。

These are the pros of working with an analog system. These strengths have emerged from my own experience working with an Antinet for over a year, and from my research into analog thinking systems. There are other positive aspects that are more obvious; however, I won’t bother going into the obvious ones in detail. It’s best to experience them for yourself by testing the Antinet for yourself. That’s the fun part, anyway! 这些是使用模拟系统的优点。这些优势来自于我一年多来使用 Antinet 的经验，以及我对模拟思维系统的研究。还有其他更明显的积极方面；但是，我不会费心去详细讨论那些显而易见的问题。最好通过自己测试 Antinet 来亲自体验它们。无论如何，那是有趣的部分！

Let’s now discuss the cons of analog. 现在让我们讨论模拟的缺点。

**The Cons of Analog 模拟的缺点**
----------------------------

There are no cons of analog. 没有模拟的缺点。

Just kidding! There are a number of negative aspects that arise while working with analog systems. Let’s go through them now. 只是在开玩笑！使用模拟系统时会出现许多消极方面。现在让我们来看看它们。

**Analog Faces The Risk of Destruction Due to Fire, Flood, or Other DisasterAnalog 面临因火灾、洪水或其他灾害而遭受破坏的风险**

At least once a week I get the following type of comment on Reddit or my YouTube channel: Yeah, sounds great Scott, but what about a fire or flood? 我至少每周一次在 Reddit 或我的 YouTube 频道上收到以下类型的评论：是的，听起来不错，斯科特，但是火灾或洪水呢？

It’s a valid question. Many of history’s greatest minds who used analog knowledge systems suffered the downside of losing their archive to fire or flood. For instance, Thomas Jefferson’s personal library and notes were the casualty of a house fire, causing him great despair.[332](#footnote-360) The same happened to Aldous Huxley in his later years when a brushfire broke out at his California home. He rushed in and saved his manuscript of the book he was working on at the time (The Island).[333](#footnote-359) Unfortunately his personal library of four thousand books was engulfed by the flames. 这是一个有效的问题。许多使用模拟知识系统的历史上最伟大的思想家都遭受过在火灾或洪水中丢失档案的不​​利影响。例如，托马斯 · 杰斐逊 (Thomas Jefferson) 的私人图书馆和笔记在一场房屋火灾中化为灰烬，这让他极度绝望。 332 同样的事情也发生在奥尔德斯 · 赫胥黎 (Aldous Huxley) 晚年的加州家中，当时他的家中发生了一场丛林大火。他冲进去救了他当时正在写的书（《岛屿》）的手稿。333 不幸的是，他拥有四千本书的私人图书馆被大火吞没了。

There’s no denying that a downside of analog centers around its risk of destruction (due to fire, flood, or other natural disaster). But is it really enough risk to warrant opting for digital over analog? I think not. 不可否认，模拟的缺点集中在它的破坏风险上（由于火灾、洪水或其他自然灾害）。但是，选择数字而不是模拟真的有足够的风险吗？我想不是。

Here’s one way to think of this: would you rather live a life possessing something extremely valuable that can be lost, or, would you rather possess something that is worth less without risk of loss? Note: I contend that digital notes are not worthless; but they are worth less in that they contain less worth than analog notes. The reason centers on the thought that is poured into notes written by hand. They are worth more. They take more time, they require more attention, and they are created at greater expense than digital notes. 这是一种思考方式：你宁愿过一种拥有可以丢失的极其有价值的东西的生活，还是宁愿拥有一些价值较低但没有丢失风险的东西？注意：我认为数字笔记并非一文不值；但它们的价值较低，因为它们的价值低于模拟纸币。原因集中在手写笔记中的思想上。他们更值钱。它们需要更多的时间，需要更多的关注，而且它们的创建成本比数字笔记更高。

Like any good hero’s journey, after you spend months or years building your own Antinet, you’ll experience the moment of realizing where the value truly resides. The value of the Antinet and its analog notes does not reside in the cabinets in which you store your thoughts. Rather, the value resides in how your brain develops and changes. Working with an analog system like the Antinet transforms the way that you think. In essence, the true value of the Antinet is not its physical material, it’s the metaphysical material that it creates. The value is in what the analog system does to your mind, not the actual contents of the box itself. 就像任何优秀的英雄之旅一样，在您花费数月或数年时间构建自己的 Antinet 之后，您将体验到意识到价值真正所在的时刻。 Antinet 及其模拟笔记的价值不在于您存储思想的柜子。相反，价值在于你的大脑如何发展和变化。使用像 Antinet 这样的模拟系统可以改变您的思维方式。从本质上讲，Antinet 的真正价值不在于它的物理材料，而在于它所创造的形而上学材料。价值在于模拟系统对你的大脑做了什么，而不是盒子本身的实际内容。

This mirrors that moment in the hero’s journey wherein the hero has victory in his or her sights. Yet the hero foregoes crossing the finish line because his friend who had helped him on the journey (and who the hero may be in conflict with) is suddenly in trouble. In this moment, the hero realizes the physical prize is worth less than the fulfillment and love of relationships and connection with others (i.e., the metaphysical prize). In other words, the hero chooses fulfillment over achievement. With this realization, the hero comes to understand that life isn’t about struggling for the external physical item signifying achievement. Rather, life is about the fulfillment of internal metaphysical qualities (such as virtue, growth, challenge and self-respect). 这反映了英雄旅程中英雄在他或她的视野中取得胜利的那一刻。然而英雄放弃了冲过终点线，因为他在旅途中帮助过他的朋友（以及英雄可能与之发生冲突的人）突然遇到了麻烦。在这一刻，英雄意识到物质奖励的价值不及人际关系和与他人联系的满足和热爱（即形而上学的奖励）。换句话说，主人公选择成就而不是成就。有了这种认识，主人公开始明白生活并不是为了获得象征成就的外在物质而奋斗。相反，生活是关于内在形而上学品质（例如美德、成长、挑战和自尊）的实现。

I realize this may sound sappy and ridiculous, especially in the context of reading a book about developing knowledge using notecards, but I assure you there’s truth in this notion. The true value of the Antinet journey is not in the external physical knowledge; it’s what the process of developing the knowledge does to your mind. If my Antinet burned down, I’d do two things: (1) I’d sit down and write furiously to finish the project I was in the middle of, while the knowledge was still fresh, and (2) I’d start a new Antinet. It’s that simple. 我意识到这听起来可能很滑稽和荒谬，尤其是在阅读一本关于使用记事卡发展知识的书的背景下，但我向你保证这个概念是正确的。 Antinet 之旅的真正价值不在于外在的物理知识；这就是发展知识的过程对您的思想的影响。如果我的 Antinet 烧毁了，我会做两件事：(1) 我会坐下来疯狂地写作，以完成我正在进行的项目，同时知识还很新鲜，以及 (2) 我会开始一个新的 Antinet。就这么简单。

That’s a metaphysical solution to analog’s risk of destruction due to disaster. However, there’s also a physical solution. Fireproof and waterproof cabinets exist and they’re quite effective. However, they aren’t cheap. They’re in the same price range as a computer. Still, they are an option. If you live in an area where you greatly fear the risk of damage and destruction, you can certainly go this route. 这是一种形而上学的解决方案，可以解决模拟因灾难而遭受破坏的风险。但是，还有一个物理解决方案。存在防火和防水柜，它们非常有效。但是，它们并不便宜。它们的价格范围与计算机相同。不过，它们是一种选择。如果你住在一个你非常害怕破坏和破坏风险的地区，你当然可以走这条路。

For myself, I have not gone this route. I have thought about looking into fireproof and waterproof cabinets built specifically for the Antinet’s notecards; however I have not done this yet at the time of this writing. For me, I sleep soundly at night knowing my Antinet is stored in a safe office in a nice building. It’s not without risk, yet it doesn’t keep me up at night. 对于我自己，我没有走这条路。我考虑过专门为 Antinet 的 notecards 打造的防火防水柜子；但是在撰写本文时我还没有这样做。对我来说，知道我的 Antinet 存放在一栋漂亮建筑的安全办公室里，我晚上睡得很香。这并非没有风险，但它并没有让我彻夜难眠。

Now, I would like to pose a counter-intuitive idea: the risk of destruction is a good thing. I think there’s a subconscious component to my notes being analog whereby I’m more motivated to turn my notes into a published product. Because my notes stare me in the face (and there is a sizable amount of notes to stare me in the face), I’m more motivated to actually sit down at the computer and type them into my text editor. When my notes are converted into text, it extinguishes the risk of fire (pun intended). The risk of fire or water damage actually forces me to publish my work faster, and to turn it into something useful more immediately. 现在，我想提出一个反直觉的想法：破坏的风险是一件好事。我认为我的笔记中有一个潜意识成分是模拟的，因此我更有动力将我的笔记变成一个已发布的产品。因为我的笔记盯着我的脸（而且有相当多的笔记盯着我的脸），所以我更有动力真正坐在电脑前并将它们输入我的文本编辑器。当我的笔记被转换成文本时，它消除了火灾的风险（双关语）。火灾或水灾的风险实际上迫使我更​​快地发表我的作品，并更快地将它变成有用的东西。

To wrap things up, the risk of damage and destruction of notes due to fire, flood, or other natural disaster is real—yet it’s also not real. It’s real in that it can physically happen; yet it’s not real in that it cannot physically happen unless your mind is destroyed by the fire, flood, or other disaster—and that’s a different problem altogether! That’s a problem digital systems cannot account for either. 总而言之，因火灾、洪水或其他自然灾害造成纸币损坏和毁坏的风险是真实存在的——但也不是真实存在的。它是真实的，因为它可以在物理上发生；然而它是不真实的，除非你的思想被火灾、洪水或其他灾难摧毁，否则它不可能在物理上发生——这完全是一个不同的问题！这是数字系统也无法解决的问题。

**Analog Is Harder Than Digital 模拟比数字更难**

Another con of analog is that it’s harder than digital. It requires more effort, time, and deliberate attention. More, it requires a greater quantity of work to produce less. With digital notetaking systems, knowledge is easier to create. It’s also cheaper to create. However, I contend that the extra effort and the deeper thought processing is worth it. Oftentimes, the hard way is the best way. In fact, it can be argued that it’s the only true way. 模拟的另一个缺点是它比数字更难。它需要更多的努力、时间和刻意的关注。更重要的是，它需要更多的工作量来生产更少的产品。使用数字笔记系统，可以更轻松地创建知识。创建起来也更便宜。然而，我认为额外的努力和更深入的思考过程是值得的。很多时候，困难的方法是最好的方法。事实上，可以说这是唯一正确的方法。

Writing by hand was valued by writers in the early modern period precisely for the reason that it was hard. It sharpened not only their faculties for controlling their attention, but also improved their retention of material. As scholar Anne Blair observes, writers used the process of writing by hand as “a mental and physical discipline that sharpened attention and retention.” [334](#footnote-358) 手写之所以受到近代早期作家的重视，正是因为它难写。它不仅增强了他们控制注意力的能力，还提高了他们对材料的记忆力。正如学者安妮 · 布莱尔 (Anne Blair) 所观察到的那样，作家们将手写的过程视为 “一种提高注意力和记忆力的身心训练”。 334

For myself, using an analog system helps cure my ADHD-tendencies. When I begin writing a main note (i.e., reformulating or reflecting on material), I feel almost sucked into the experience. I cannot pry myself away from my desk until I finish the thought. This practice is certainly not exclusive to analog; however, I find it more prevalent in analog. I also find my thoughts to be better developed and processed when writing by hand. Much of this book was written by hand using my Antinet. This sentence and this section you’re reading right now, however, were not written by hand. I’m thinking by typing on my computer (hypocrite)! While I do not think this is necessarily a bad section, I do think it would have been much better and had a stronger impact if I had taken the time to deliberately write it out by hand first. The reason I have not done so is because the content backing much of what I’m writing here will be covered in another section of this book (a section on the power of writing by hand). So, essentially I have indeed written out the core idea of this section (the power of writing by hand), yet I have not specifically handwritten this section. Still, I have deeply thought through the core idea I’m writing about in this section. How so? Because I developed it elsewhere through writing by hand. 对我自己来说，使用模拟系统有助于治愈我的多动症倾向。当我开始写主要笔记（即重新制定或反思材料）时，我几乎被这种体验所吸引。在我完成这个想法之前，我不能离开我的办公桌。这种做法当然不是模拟所独有的。但是，我发现它在模拟中更为普遍。我还发现手写时可以更好地发展和处理我的想法。这本书的大部分内容都是用我的 Antinet 手写的。然而，您现在正在阅读的这句话和这一部分并不是手写的。我在电脑上打字思考（伪君子）！虽然我不认为这一定是一个糟糕的部分，但我确实认为如果我花时间故意先手写它会更好并且产生更大的影响。我没有这样做的原因是因为支持我在这里写的大部分内容的内容将在本书的另一部分（关于手写的力量的部分）中介绍。所以，本质上我确实已经写出了这一节的核心思想（手写的力量），但我并没有专门手写这一节。尽管如此，我还是对我在本节中所写的核心思想进行了深入思考。为何如此？因为我是通过手写在别处开发的。

Analog is harder than digital not only in terms of the effort it requires, but in other ways as well. With an analog system, you must buy a variety of materials. Blank notecards, boxes, containers, Wite-Out, pens, rulers, and other items. That’s not too difficult, yet it does indeed require more space. 模拟比数字更难，不仅在它需要的努力方面，而且在其他方​​面也是如此。使用模拟系统，您必须购买各种材料。空白记事卡、盒子、容器、Wite-Out、钢笔、尺子和其他物品。这并不太难，但确实需要更多空间。

Analog systems also result in quizzical regard from others who see you using such. They may question your sanity for investing so much time and energy into boxes of physical notecards. If you aren’t strong-minded, you may even end up questioning your own sanity! 模拟系统也会导致其他人看到您使用此类系统时产生疑惑。他们可能会质疑您将如此多的时间和精力投入到实体记事卡盒中的理智。如果你不坚强，你甚至可能会质疑自己的理智！

**Here’s The Truth: The Hard Way Is Better 这是事实：困难的方法更好**

One of the biggest myths about Zettelkasten centers around the tradeoff between ease vs. effort. Here’s the truth: you must be prepared to do things the hard way if you wish to produce great work. The paradox, however, is that the hard way turns out to be the easy way. The up front hard work of writing notes by hand later turns into the greatest benefit of the system. 关于 Zettelkasten 的最大迷思之一围绕着轻松与努力之间的权衡。事实是这样的：如果你想做出伟大的作品，你必须准备好以艰难的方式做事。然而，矛盾的是，困难的方法竟然是简单的方法。前期手写笔记的艰苦工作后来变成了系统的最大好处。

As Mortimer Adler outlines in his classic How to Read a Book, one must be prepared to go about processing books the hard way. “That is the only way,” Adler writes. “Without external help of any sort, you go to work on the book. With nothing but the power of your own mind.”[335](#footnote-357) 正如莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 (Mortimer Adler) 在他的经典著作《如何阅读一本书》(How to Read a Book) 中概述的那样，一个人必须准备好以艰难的方式处理书籍。 “这是唯一的方法，” 阿德勒写道。 “在没有任何形式的外部帮助的情况下，你可以继续写这本书。除了你自己思想的力量之外别无他物。”335

After Ryan Holiday wrote a piece outlining his notebox system, he responded to a question he is frequently asked: “Wouldn’t digital be easier?” Here’s Holiday’s response: 在 Ryan Holiday 写了一篇概述他的笔记本系统的文章后，他回答了一个他经常被问到的问题：“数字化会不会更容易？” 这是假日的回应：

Yes. But I don’t want this to be easy. Writing them [notes] down by hand forces me to take my time and to go over everything again (taking notes on a Kindle is too easy and that’s the problem). Also being able to physically arrange stuff is crucial for getting the structure of your book or project right. I can move cards from one category to another. As I shuffle through the cards, I bump into stuff I had forgotten about, etc.[336](#footnote-356) 是的。但我不希望这很容易。用手写下它们 [笔记] 迫使我花时间重新检查所有内容（在 Kindle 上做笔记太容易了，这就是问题所在）。此外，能够实际安排内容对于正确安排书籍或项目的结构至关重要。我可以将卡片从一个类别移到另一个类别。当我翻牌时，我碰到了我忘记的东西，等等。 336

Holiday makes three important points here. One is the benefit of an analog system enabling him to better develop his thoughts. The other is the benefit of haptic factors utilized in knowledge management (that is, being able to lay the cards out in front of you to physically rearrange). The last benefit Holiday touches on is bumping into stuff he had forgotten about. Here Holiday is describing maintenance rehearsal in human memory.Holiday 在这里提出了三个要点。其中之一是模拟系统的好处，使他能够更好地发展自己的思想。另一个是知识管理中使用的触觉因素的好处（也就是说，能够将卡片放在你面前以进行物理重新排列）。霍乐迪提到的最后一个好处是碰到了他已经忘记的东西。 Holiday 在这里描述了人类记忆中的维护排练。

All of these aspects, admittedly the hard way to do this, end up producing better work. The hard way, paradoxically, becomes the best way. 所有这些方面，无可否认，做到这一点的艰难方式，最终会产生更好的工作。矛盾的是，困难的方法变成了最好的方法。

The bottom line is that analog thinking systems are hard. They take more time and energy investment than digital systems. They’re also less conventional than digital systems, and thus suffer from an implicit bias that digital systems are used by smarter people who are geeky enough to know shortcuts and hotkeys (rubbish). This is a false notion. There are no shortcuts. In fact, the shortcuts end up falling far short of the desired destination: excellence. 底线是模拟思维系统很难。它们比数字系统需要更多的时间和精力投入。它们也不像数字系统那样传统，因此存在一种隐含的偏见，即数字系统被更聪明的人使用，这些人足够怪异，知道快捷方式和热键（垃圾）。这是错误的观念。没有捷径。事实上，捷径最终远远达不到理想的目的地：卓越。

**Analog Is Less Mobile Than Digital (Or Is It?) 模拟不如数字移动（或者是吗？）**

Another con of analog centers around the perceived immobility of the system. Its roots, once again, trace back to Sönke Ahrens. In How to Take Smart Notes, Ahrens says he chose to use a digital Zettelkasten for “mobility.”[337](#footnote-355) His presumption is that a laptop storing his notes is easier to carry than a filing cabinet full of notecards. While this may be true, he’s actually making the wrong comparison. Sure, a laptop carrying notes is more mobile than carrying around filing cabinets full of notecards. However, they are not equivalent. He mistakenly believes that the two are equal when, in reality, they are not. 模拟的另一个缺点围绕着系统的可感知的固定性。它的根源再次追溯到 Sönke Ahrens。在 How to Take Smart Notes 中，Ahrens 说他选择使用数字 Zettelkasten 是为了 “移动性”。337 他的假设是，用于存储他的笔记的笔记本电脑比装满记事本的文件柜更容易携带。虽然这可能是真的，但他实际上是在进行错误的比较。当然，携带笔记的笔记本电脑比携带装满记事本的文件柜更方便携带。但是，它们并不等同。他错误地认为两者是相等的，而实际上它们并不相等。

An analog system like the Antinet contains thoughts and a structure of knowledge that are irreplicable in a digital notetaking system. The knowledge Ahrens carries with him on his laptop is of lesser value and worth than the knowledge contained in a robust analog system. 像 Antinet 这样的模拟系统包含的思想和知识结构在数字笔记系统中是无法复制的。 Ahrens 在他的笔记本电脑上携带的知识的价值和价值低于一个强大的模拟系统中包含的知识。

In addition, the material you carry with you when using an analog system does not just reside in the card boxes. The knowledge resides in your mind. Such knowledge, when digitally managed, would otherwise not be stamped in your mind in such a way. In effect, with the Antinet you carry knowledge with you, wherever you go. Whether you’re in the shower (where breakthroughs in thinking actually happen), or whether you’re on your couch reading, you carry with you knowledge that would otherwise be missing if you used digital systems. In this way, it can be argued that digital systems are less mobile than analog systems. Why? Because with analog systems, you can carry more knowledge, internally, than you can with digital systems. Plus digital notes result in cheaper, less processed knowledge stored in the depths of a notetaking app. 此外，您在使用模拟系统时随身携带的材料不仅仅存在于卡片盒中。知识存在于你的头脑中。这样的知识，如果以数字方式管理，就不会以这种方式印在你的脑海中。实际上，无论您走到哪里，有了 Antinet，您就可以随身携带知识。无论您是在淋浴（思维上的突破实际发生的地方），还是在沙发上看书，您都拥有如果使用数字系统就会丢失的知识。这样，可以说数字系统的移动性不如模拟系统。为什么？因为使用模拟系统，您可以在内部携带比使用数字系统更多的知识。加上数字笔记，可以将更便宜、更少处理的知识存储在笔记应用程序的深处。

**Analog Knowledge Systems vs. Digital Knowledge Systems 模拟知识系统与数字知识系统**
------------------------------------------------------------------------

As the data scientist John Foreman observes, machines can help us measure the correlations and proximities between clusters of groups or individuals who buy a particular item; however, they cannot tell us why people do not buy.[338](#footnote-354) There is an internal experience (a theory of mind) that is invisible to computers. Computers do not know what it’s like to be human. Humans do, and there’s no replacement for this missing feature. I’d like to propose that analog systems retain humanness better than digital systems. They seem to also introduce the understanding of the internal human experience better than digital systems. 正如数据科学家 John Foreman 所观察到的，机器可以帮助我们衡量购买特定商品的群体或个人集群之间的相关性和接近度；但是，它们无法告诉我们人们为什么不购买。338 有一种内在体验（一种心理理论）对计算机来说是不可见的。计算机不知道作为人类是什么感觉。人类有，而且没有替代品可以替代这个缺失的功能。我想建议模拟系统比数字系统更能保留人性。它们似乎也比数字系统更好地引入了对人类内部体验的理解。

Many people inappropriately compare digital and analog Zettelkasten systems. Even learned scholars deeply familiar with knowledge systems make such a mistake. For instance, Markus Krajewski writes: “A critical advantage lies in the fact that software based literary databases are not simply able to remember, but can also be employed as productive assistants in the production of arguments.”[339](#footnote-353) The problem with this scholar’s assertion centers around two things: First, Luhmann himself described his Zettelkasten as a personal productive assistant.[340](#footnote-352) And second, Krajewski does not explain why he holds the view that a digital Zettelkasten can be a productive assistant whereas an analog Zettelkasten cannot.[341](#footnote-351) 许多人不恰当地比较数字和模拟 Zettelkasten 系统。即使是深谙知识体系的博学学者也会犯这样的错误。例如，马库斯 · 克拉耶夫斯基 (Markus Krajewski) 写道：“一个关键优势在于，基于软件的文学数据库不仅能够记忆，而且还可以用作产生论证的生产性助手。”339 这位学者断言的问题集中在围绕两件事：首先，Luhmann 自己将他的 Zettelkasten 描述为个人生产助手。 340 其次，Krajewski 没有解释为什么他认为数字 Zettelkasten 可以成为生产助手而模拟 Zettelkasten 不能。 341

**The Downsides of Digital 数字的缺点**

Many seem to overlook the downsides of digital. We have a vague sense that digital environments are distracting; however research is starting to show us how distracting they actually are. For instance, one study tracked the anonymous digital activity of fifty-thousand users. The results illustrated that half of the users checked communication apps (like Slack and email) “every six minutes or less.”[342](#footnote-350) 许多人似乎忽视了数字化的缺点。我们有一种模糊的感觉，即数字环境会分散注意力；然而，研究开始向我们展示它们实际上有多分散注意力。例如，一项研究追踪了五万名用户的匿名数字活动。结果表明，一半的用户 “每六​​分钟或更短时间” 检查一次通信应用程序（如 Slack 和电子邮件）。 342

When you’re working, even if you have notifications turned off, a distracting app is just a click away. This environment is not optimal for deep work or writing. 当您工作时，即使您关闭了通知，也只需单击一下即可打开分散注意力的应用程序。这种环境不适合深度工作或写作。

Furthermore, the digital work environment has been shown to result in suboptimal health. The International Archives of Occupational and Environment Health published a study that observed long-term trends of nearly five thousand Swedish workers. The results showed a trend of suboptimal health outcomes associated with high information and digital technology usage. Other research shows that email is connected with unhappiness. In other words, every six minutes or so when you’re looped into checking email, you’re also looped into an activity that has been shown to cause unhappiness.[343](#footnote-349) 此外，数字工作环境已被证明会导致健康状况不佳。国际职业与环境卫生档案馆发表了一项研究，观察了近 5000 名瑞典工人的长期趋势。结果显示，与信息和数字技术的大量使用相关的次优健康结果趋势。其他研究表明，电子邮件与不快乐有关。换句话说，每隔六分钟左右，当您陷入检查电子邮件的循环时，您也会陷入一项已被证明会导致不快乐的活动。 343

In brief, the digital environment appears to be more distracting and also leads to less happiness and suboptimal health. Yet the digital work environment is the very thing I find myself having to convince the majority of knowledge workers to escape! 简而言之，数字环境似乎更容易让人分心，也会导致幸福感降低和健康状况不佳。然而，数字工作环境正是我发现自己必须说服大多数知识工作者逃离的东西！

**If Luhmann Were Alive Today 如果卢曼今天还活着**

One might be tempted to think that if Luhmann were alive today, he would opt for a digital notetaking system. I have several reasons why I think he would not. 人们可能会想，如果卢曼今天还活着，他会选择数字笔记系统。我有几个理由认为他不会。

First and foremost, Luhmann lived until 1998. Personal computers were introduced in 1977 and became common in the 1980s.[344](#footnote-348) It’s likely that an academic who was familiar with information science and systems theory would be savvy enough to learn how a personal computer works. Yet Luhmann never seemed to move to the digital medium for managing his knowledge. 首先，卢曼一直活到 1998 年。个人电脑于 1977 年问世，并在 1980 年代变得普遍。344 熟悉信息科学和系统理论的学者很可能足够了解个人电脑的工作原理。然而，卢曼似乎从未转向数字媒体来管理他的知识。

In fact, later in his life (when computers were a more accessible option) Luhmann wrote a piece titled Learning to Read. In it, Luhmann introduced various best practices for reading. He advised the taking of notes (not excerpts, but reformulation notes), and he also advises readers to store those notes in a computer or an analog Zettelkasten.[345](#footnote-347) Even after parting with this advice, Luhmann continued to use his analog Zettelkasten. Therefore, perhaps the question is not whether Luhmann would choose digital if he were alive today—after all, he already had that option. Rather the question becomes, why did Luhmann choose to stick with his analog Zettelkasten? The primary reason centers on what his analog Zettelkasten became for Luhmann: it became his second mind. 事实上，在他生命的后期（当计算机是更容易获得的选择时），卢曼写了一篇题为《学习阅读》的文章。其中，卢曼介绍了阅读的各种最佳实践。他建议做笔记（不是摘录，而是重新制定笔记），他还建议读者将这些笔记存储在计算机或模拟 Zettelkasten 中。345 即使在放弃这个建议后，Luhmann 仍继续使用他的模拟 Zettelkasten。因此，也许问题不在于卢曼如果还活着，会不会选择数字技术——毕竟他已经有了这个选择。相反，问题变成了，为什么卢曼选择坚持使用他的模拟 Zettelkasten？主要原因在于他的模拟 Zettelkasten 对 Luhmann 的影响：它成为了他的第二思维。

There’s a continual fallacy that arises in confusing systems storing information for others vs. systems that store knowledge for oneself. The same scholar who calls digital systems productive assistants also asserts that slipboxes, noteboxes (and Antinets), are for “internal use only.”[346](#footnote-346) 在混淆为他人存储信息的系统与为自己存储知识的系统之间出现了一个持续的谬误。将数字系统称为生产助手的同一位学者还断言，滑箱、记事箱（和 Antinets）仅供 “内部使用”。 346

Luhmann’s goal, quite literally, centered on creating a productive assistant to bounce ideas off of, and guess what…he achieved it with his analog Zettelkasten. When given the choice to discard the second mind he created (and opt for digital instead), Luhmann clearly made the right choice: he chose his Antinet.Luhmann 的目标，从字面上看，集中在创造一个高效的助手来反弹想法，猜猜是什么...... 他用他的模拟 Zettelkasten 实现了它。当让卢曼选择放弃他创造的第二个思维（并选择数字化）时，卢曼显然做出了正确的选择：他选择了他的 Antinet。

The physical, external properties that make such systems like the Antinet more powerful than digital are becoming increasingly recognized by scholars for their powerful features (when they’re not shockingly overlooked). The best advertisement for an analog Zettelkasten is perhaps an article titled “Rank and File,” in which the author professes awe for the intellectual prowess of a professor who inspired him.[347](#footnote-345) It turns out that this revered professor used an analog system of notecards. The author attempted to employ such a notetaking system in digital form, only to realize its shortcomings. It’s rather head-scratching, but the author doesn’t then try an analog Zettelkasten system. Instead, after his failure in making use out of a digital Zettelkasten, the author gives up on the idea completely. It’s unfortunate. The only thing he got wrong in his digital Zettelkasten was the digital part. 使像 Antinet 这样的系统比数字系统更强大的物理、外部属性正因其强大的功能（当它们没有被令人震惊地忽视时）而越来越多地被学者们认可。模拟 Zettelkasten 最好的广告可能是一篇题为 “Rank and File” 的文章，作者在文中表达了对启发他的教授的智慧的敬畏。347 事实证明，这位受人尊敬的教授使用了记事本模拟系统。作者试图以数字形式使用这种笔记系统，却发现了它的缺点。这相当令人头疼，但作者并没有尝试模拟 Zettelkasten 系统。相反，在未能使用数字 Zettelkasten 之后，作者完全放弃了这个想法。很不幸。他在数字 Zettelkasten 中唯一出错的地方是数字部分。

**People of Analog 模拟人**
------------------------

My uncle is an attorney based in Los Angeles, California. He was born to be an attorney. He’s one of the rarer attorneys who is passionate, charming (in his own mind), and most shocking of all, he’s an attorney who is not a complete a-hole! He also has a steel trap for a memory. According to him, it’s not that he has a good memory, it’s just that he can’t seem to forget things! The things he remembers aren’t legal cases and practical stuff. They’re things like football stats, player’s names and numbers, Heisman trophy winners by year, the scores of every Super Bowl ever played, and more. He knows every single winner of the Indianapolis 500, dating back to the year 1911. You simply give him a year, and he’ll instantly tell you the name of the winner and any other contextual details about the event. 我的叔叔是加利福尼亚州洛杉矶的一名律师。他天生就是一名律师。他是为数不多的热情、迷人（在他自己看来）的律师之一，最令人震惊的是，他是一个不完全是个混蛋的律师！他还有一个记忆的钢铁陷阱。按照他的说法，不是他记性好，而是他好像忘不了东西！他记得的东西不是法律案件和实际的东西。它们包括足球统计数据、球员姓名和号码、每年的海斯曼奖杯获得者、每场超级碗比赛的比分等等。他认识印第安纳波利斯 500 的每一位获胜者，可以追溯到 1911 年。你只需给他一年时间，他就会立即告诉你获胜者的名字以及有关该赛事的任何其他背景细节。

On a recent Super Bowl Sunday we decided to watch the football game at my parent’s home. A few hours before the game started, I decided to take a break from being around company, and I found a quiet place in my father’s home office where my father was working as well. At a separate desk, I began making main notes from the bibcard I had created while reading Luhmann’s book Short Cuts. After some time, my uncle walked in to see what me and my dad were up to. 在最近的超级碗周日，我们决定在我父母的家里观看足球比赛。比赛开始前几个小时，我决定离开公司休息一下，我在父亲的家庭办公室找了一个安静的地方，父亲也在工作。在另一张桌子上，我开始根据我在阅读卢曼的《捷径》一书时创建的 bibcard 做主要笔记。过了一会儿，叔叔走进来看我和爸爸在干什么。

My dad was up to his usual stuff: paying bills, returning emails from clients, etc. However, my uncle turned to me and saw six notecards of main notes scattered on my desk. “What the hell are you doing?” he asked. “Whoa, that’s actually pretty good handwriting!” After giving him a surface-level explanation of the notecard system and professing the power of writing by hand, he replied, “That’s been my secret to success. Every opening statement I’ve ever done in my legal career, I’ve written out by hand.” 我爸爸忙着做他平常的事：付账单、回客户的邮件等等。然而，我叔叔转向我，看到我桌上散落着六张主要笔记的记事卡。 “你到底在做什么？” 他问。 “哇，这字还真不错！” 在向他简单介绍了记事卡系统并宣扬手写的力量后，他回答说：“这就是我成功的秘诀。在我的法律职业生涯中，我所做的每一篇开场白都是手写的。”

I wouldn’t be surprised if writing things out by hand also stands key to his steel trap memory. 如果手写东西也是他的钢铁陷阱记忆的关键，我不会感到惊讶。

The more I share the power of analog methods, of notecards, and writing by hand, the more people I discover who use such tools. I get information sent to me from my fellow Antinetters attesting to this. I also keep an eye out while reading. I frequently spot people who reveal their secrets to revolve around analog knowledge tools. When I do, I usually note them down. 我越多地分享模拟方法、记事卡和手写的力量，我发现使用这些工具的人就越多。我从我的 Antinetters 同事那里得到了证明这一点的信息。我在看书的时候也留意一下。我经常发现有人透露他们围绕模拟知识工具的秘密。当我这样做的时候，我通常会把它们记下来。

For instance, take Ted Nelson, the godfather of hypertext documents and hyperlinks who inspired the internet as we know it. One would expect him to arrive at meetings with a laptop. Yet, he uses analog tools like notebooks, notecards, sticky notes, and tape recorders. In a humorous account by Kevin Kelly, the creator of Wired magazine, Kelly shares how Nelson arrived at their meeting to outline the future with such tools.[348](#footnote-344) 例如，以超文本文档和超链接的教父 Ted Nelson 为例，他启发了我们所知的互联网。人们会期望他带着笔记本电脑参加会议。然而，他使用模拟工具，如笔记本、记事卡、便利贴和录音机。在《连线》杂志的创始人凯文凯利的幽默报道中，凯利分享了纳尔逊如何参加他们的会议，用这些工具勾画未来。 348

One of the best marketers of all time is an old curmudgeon named Dan Kennedy. He’s a character who sports a horseshoe mustache and a “No B.S.” attitude (which also serves as the title for his book series). A central point in his book No B.S. Time Management for Entrepreneurs focuses on creating a “success environment” for oneself. This environment is to be stocked with analog tools. He lists off tools including clocks, symbols of wealth, folders, massive Ziploc bags for each project, and, of course, notecards.[349](#footnote-343) 有史以来最好的营销人员之一是一个名叫丹 · 肯尼迪的老脾气。他是一个留着马蹄形小胡子和 “No B.S.” 的角色。态度（这也是他系列丛书的标题）。他的书 No B.S. 中的一个中心点。企业家时间管理着重于为自己创造一个“成功环境”。该环境将配备模拟工具。他列出了工具，包括时钟、财富的象征、文件夹、用于每个项目的大型 Ziploc 袋，当然还有记事卡。 349

On the very first page of The Journals of Abraham Maslow we find Maslow stating the importance of managing his knowledge using analog tools and 3 x 5 inch notecards.[350](#footnote-342) 在亚伯拉罕马斯洛日记的第一页，我们发现马斯洛陈述了使用模拟工具和 3 x 5 英寸记事本管理他的知识的重要性。 350

Indeed, the “soul” of Umberto Eco’s classic book, How to Write a Thesis, is his analog notecard system.[351](#footnote-341) 事实上，Umberto Eco 的经典著作《如何撰写论文》的 “灵魂” 就是他的模拟记事卡系统。 351

And then there’s John August, the screenwriter behind movies like Big Fish, Charlie’s Angels, Titan A.E. and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. What’s the secret to August’s success? Writing his story down on notecards and laying them out on a table. From there he organizes the story and develops the screenplay.[352](#footnote-340) 然后是约翰 · 奥古斯特，他是大鱼、查理的天使、泰坦 A.E. 和查理与巧克力工厂等电影的幕后编剧。奥古斯特成功的秘诀是什么？将他的故事写在记事卡上，然后摊开在桌子上。他从那里组织故事并开发剧本。 352

F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote his novels by hand using paper and super sharp pencils. He didn’t even erase his mistakes, preferring to cross them out.[353](#footnote-339) His personal assistant later in his life observed how Fitzgerald would write by hand every day (presumably even after recovering from his epic gin-induced hangovers)![354](#footnote-338)F. Scott Fitzgerald 用纸和超级锋利的铅笔手工写他的小说。他甚至没有抹去他的错误，宁愿把它们划掉。 353 他的私人助理在他晚年观察到菲茨杰拉德每天如何手写（大概甚至在他从杜松子酒引起的宿醉中恢复过来之后）！ 354

Other people who use analog tools, including notecards, and who write by hand include the following people: comedian Jerry Seinfeld, author Elizabeth Gilbert, author Ryan Holiday, author Robert Greene, novelist Anne Lamott, and writer Robert Caro (whom I talk about elsewhere in this book).[355](#footnote-337) The list goes on and on. 其他使用模拟工具（包括记事卡）和手写的人包括以下人员：喜剧演员杰瑞 · 宋飞、作家伊丽莎白 · 吉尔伯特、作家瑞安 · 霍利迪、作家罗伯特 · 格林、小说家安妮 · 拉莫特和作家罗伯特 · 卡罗（我在其他地方谈到过他）在这本书中）。355 清单还在继续。

**History’s Greatest Minds Used Analog Thinking Systems Like the Antinet 历史上最伟大的思想家使用类似 Antinet 的模拟思维系统**

A great many intellectuals of the past used tools like the Antinet, including the German philosopher and mathematician Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646–1716). Around 1676 he built a so-called excerpt cabinet (scrinium literatum). He was inspired by the Swiss physician and naturalist, Conrad Gessner (1516–1565), who built a “humble paper-slip” system.[356](#footnote-336) Gessner is known as possibly the first person in history who is mentioned using an Antinet-like system.[357](#footnote-335) Other early adopters of an Antinet-like system include Georg Philipp Harsdörffer (1607–1658) and Joachim Jungius (1587–1657). 过去的许多知识分子都使用 Antinet 这样的工具，包括德国哲学家和数学家戈特弗里德 · 威廉 · 莱布尼茨 (Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, 1646–1716)。 1676 年左右，他建造了一个所谓的摘录柜 (scrinium literatum)。他受到瑞士医生和博物学家 Conrad Gessner（1516-1565 年）的启发，后者建立了一个 “简陋的纸条” 系统。356 Gessner 可能是历史上第一个被提及使用类 Antinet 系统的人。 357 类似 Antinet 系统的其他早期采用者包括 Georg Philipp Harsdörffer (1607–1658) 和 Joachim Jungius (1587–1657)。

The first English dictionary, famously built by Samuel Johnson, was assembled using notecards. He sorted the dictionary entries into alphabetical order and then glued them into a master manuscript.[358](#footnote-334) 第一本由塞缪尔 · 约翰逊 (Samuel Johnson) 编写的著名英语词典是使用记事卡组装而成的。他将字典条目按字母顺序排列，然后将它们粘在一份手稿中。 358

I won’t risk boring you with a comprehensive history of people who used Antinet-like systems. The list of people who did is rather robust and can be found in many books dedicated entirely to the scholarship of analog thinking systems. 我不会冒着让你厌烦的风险来介绍使用类 Antinet 系统的人的全面历史。这样做的人的名单相当丰富，可以在许多完全致力于模拟思维系统学术的书籍中找到。

If you’re interested in exploring the history of analog thinking systems, I’ll provide the following list. The list makes no claim of being exhaustive, however the books listed certainly serve as a fine jumping-off point for those interested in the history of knowledge systems. 如果您有兴趣探索模拟思维系统的历史，我将提供以下列表。该清单并未声称详尽无遗，但对于那些对知识系统的历史感兴趣的人来说，所列书籍无疑是一个很好的起点。

**The Power of Writing by Hand 手写的力量**
--------------------------------------

**My Journey Discovering the Power of Writing by Hand 我的旅程发现手写的力量**

One of the secrets to my success in college can be attributed to one thing: writing by hand. 我在大学取得成功的秘诀之一可以归因于一件事：手写。

Many of my other peers brought their laptops to class. When the professor began talking, they’d flip it open and take notes for a while, never looking up to engage with the professor. After some time, they’d open up a new tab, surf the web for news, check email, respond to messages, and be taken away from class. 我的许多其他同龄人都带着他们的笔记本电脑来上课。当教授开始讲话时，他们会把它翻开并做一会儿笔记，从不抬头与教授交流。一段时间后，他们会打开一个新标签，上网浏览新闻，查看电子邮件，回复消息，然后被带离课堂。

I never experienced the temptations that would lead me to fall into this trap. I always had only one thing in front of me. Actually, two: a Five Star spiral notebook, and a pen. 我从未经历过会导致我掉入这个陷阱的诱惑。我面前总是只有一件事。实际上，有两个：一个五星级螺旋笔记本和一支笔。

One reason why I never brought a laptop to class was that it felt disrespectful to the professor. They can’t see what you’re doing, and they have no way of telling if you’re just flat-out ignoring them. There you have a person dedicating their life to teaching you something, and you’re staring into a screen, seemingly ignoring them. It just didn’t sit right with me. 我从不带笔记本电脑上课的一个原因是觉得这对教授不尊重。他们看不到你在做什么，也无法判断你是否完全无视他们。那里有一个人毕生致力于教你一些东西，而你却盯着屏幕，似乎无视他们。它只是不适合我。

That said, the feeling of being disrespectful to the professor wasn’t the only reason I didn’t bring a laptop. I didn’t bring a laptop to class for several other reasons. 也就是说，对教授不尊重的感觉并不是我没有带笔记本电脑的唯一原因。由于其他几个原因，我没有带笔记本电脑上课。

First, by taking notes by hand, you end up understanding the material better (as research now confirms).[360](#footnote-332) When you write by hand, you’re thinking and understanding in a way that is more effective than taking notes using a laptop. 首先，通过手写笔记，您最终会更好地理解材料（正如现在的研究证实的那样）。360 当您手写时，您正在以一种比使用笔记本电脑做笔记更有效的方式思考和理解。

Second, when you write by hand, you end up paying very close attention to the physical cues of the professor or lecturer. You’re better able to filter out what’s truly important. 其次，当你手写时，你最终会非常密切地关注教授或讲师的身体暗示。您可以更好地过滤掉真正重要的内容。

Third, when you write by hand, your selection skills and your ability to select important material improve. Why? Because you’re more constrained by what you can actually write down. Writing by hand is harder, it takes more time. You have to slow down and select only the most important pieces of information, and you must do it in a concise way that captures the concept. 第三，当你手写时，你的选择技巧和选择重要材料的能力会提高。为什么？因为你更受限于你实际可以写下的内容。手写更难，需要更多时间。你必须放慢速度，只选择最重要的信息，而且你必须以能抓住概念的简洁方式进行。

Fourth, when I wrote by hand in class, I was more present. This resulted in two things: first, time flew by. And second, I enjoyed class much more than I would have if my laptop had been open. In fact, research suggests that those who write by hand end up experiencing much more joy than those who type away at their keyboard.[361](#footnote-331) 第四，当我在课堂上手写时，我更加在场。这导致了两件事：第一，时间飞逝。其次，我比笔记本电脑打开时更喜欢上课。事实上，研究表明，那些手写的人最终比那些在键盘上打字的人体验到更多的快乐。 361

Last, when you write by hand, you simply get better results. 最后，当你手写时，你只会得到更好的结果。

In a college environment, one might assume it to be socially acceptable to be perceived as studious or a hard worker by peers. Yet, this wasn’t always the case. I’d often find myself faced with direct questions from my peers. For instance, my friends would say to me, point-blank: The lecture material is posted on the class website. Why are you taking notes? I found myself having to answer this question more often than one would imagine. 在大学环境中，人们可能会认为被同龄人视为好学或勤奋的人在社会上是可以接受的。然而，情况并非总是如此。我经常发现自己面临来自同龄人的直接问题。例如，我的朋友会直截了当地对我说：课程材料已发布在班级网站上。你为什么要记笔记？我发现自己不得不比人们想象的更频繁地回答这个问题。

I recall a fellow student bragging, I don’t need to take notes. He then pointed to his head and said, I keep everything in here. 我记得一个同学吹牛，我不需要做笔记。然后他指着自己的头说，我把所有的东西都放在这儿了。

In these situations I was faced with a choice. Should I stick with taking notes by hand, or should I try to appear smarter by holding it all in my head? I decided to press forward with my practice of taking notes by hand (even though it was hard work and slow). 在这些情况下，我面临着一个选择。我应该坚持用手记笔记，还是应该把它全部记在脑子里来显得更聪明？我决定继续我的手记笔记练习（尽管这很辛苦而且很慢）。

Thankfully I stuck to the hard way, because every single time, in every single class, I outperformed my other classmates who didn’t take notes. I also outperformed everyone who took notes by typing. Oh, and the guy claiming to keep everything in his brain? He almost flunked out. 值得庆幸的是，我坚持了艰难的道路，因为每一次，在每一节课上，我的表现都优于其他不做笔记的同学。我的表现也优于所有通过打字做笔记的人。哦，还有那个声称把一切都记在脑子里的人？他差点没考上。

**The Paradoxical History of Longhand 手写的矛盾历史**

The power of writing by hand isn’t something realized only in modern times; there’s rich history behind the practice of writing by hand. 手写的力量不仅仅在现代才意识到；手写的做法背后有丰富的历史。

Something counterintuitive happened during the Renaissance among learned scholars and thinkers. During this period, the typographic industry exploded in growth (the so-called ars artificialiter scribendi).[362](#footnote-330) Previous to this, scholars relied on “helpers” and scribes to do their writing for them. After the typographic machines came onto the scene, however, scholars read texts via typographic medium by themselves. They also began to write their own thoughts in commonplace books. Soon after, the scholars began parting ways with their scribes and helpers. Instead of dictating their thoughts to them, they “chose to handwrite.”[363](#footnote-329) Why? Because writing by hand developed their thoughts to a far greater degree than simply dictating their thoughts to their helpers. 在文艺复兴时期，博学的学者和思想家之间发生了一些违反直觉的事情。在此期间，印刷业呈爆炸式增长（所谓的 ars artificiter scribendi）。362 在此之前，学者们依靠 “帮手” 和抄写员为他们写作。然而，在印刷机出现之后，学者们通过印刷媒介自己阅读文本。他们也开始把自己的想法写在平淡无奇的书本上。不久之后，学者们开始与他们的抄写员和助手分道扬镳。他们没有向他们口述自己的想法，而是“选择手写”。363 为什么？因为手写比简单地向他们的助手口述他们的想法更能发展他们的思想。

**Writing by Hand Enables a Communication Partner to Emerge in the Antinet 手写让通信合作伙伴在 Antinet 中崭露头角**

At the time of his death, Luhmann’s literary estate contained three thousand of his manuscripts, two hundred of which were previously unpublished. The starting point for these manuscripts was Luhmann’s Antinet, where he developed the foundation through writing by hand. 在他去世时，卢曼的文学遗产包含了他的三千份手稿，其中两百份以前未出版。这些手稿的起点是卢曼的 Antinet，他通过手写奠定了基础。

Writing is not what follows research, learning or studying, it is the medium of all this work.[364](#footnote-328) 写作不是研究、学习或研究之后的结果，它是所有这些工作的媒介。 364

Writing is not the pharmakon of memory; instead, it is a hypomnematic device that encourages scholars to use their mental energies for more abstract—that is, context- detached operations.[365](#footnote-327) 写作不是记忆的良药；相反，它是一种记忆力减退的手段，鼓励学者们将他们的精神能量用于更抽象的——即与上下文无关的操作。 365

Writing does not come after research. It is the very thing that develops the research. Writing is the process by which you actually understand research. And as the scientific literature shows, writing by hand promotes this understanding better than typing on a keyboard.[366](#footnote-326) Sönke Ahrens points this out as well: in terms of understanding what they had been taught, students who write by hand outshine those who write by keyboard.[367](#footnote-325) 写作不是在研究之后出现的。正是它推动了研究的发展。写作是你真正理解研究的过程。正如科学文献所示，手写比键盘打字更能促进这种理解。 366 Sönke Ahrens 也指出了这一点：在理解所教内容方面，手写的学生比键盘打字的学生更出色. 367

This illustrates an important point: developing your thoughts through writing by hand builds the foundation for your thinking and is the starting point from which thoughts can be developed into something even greater. It is not the end itself. If someone believes that an Antinet alone spits out great work, they’re dreaming. This seems to be the belief of digital notetaking bubble graph boiz. For an Antinet to truly bear fruit, the initial thought that is developed with the Antinet must continue to be processed in manuscript form. 这说明了一个重要的观点：通过手写来发展你的思想为你的思想奠定了基础，并且是思想可以发展成更伟大事物的起点。它本身并不是终点。如果有人认为仅 Antinet 就能做出伟大的作品，那他们就是在做梦。这似乎是数字笔记气泡图博伊兹的信念。 Antinet 要真正开花结果，必须以手稿形式继续处理 Antinet 开发的最初想法。

This seems to be less of a likelihood with digital tools. It’s all too easy to copy-and-paste notes and then try developing them from there. When you use an Antinet, there’s no other choice but to rewrite the knowledge from your cards into your text editor (and thereby, you reprocess your already processed thoughts). You’re essentially reprocessing the thoughts you’ve already processed when you originally wrote them down by hand. This is hugely advantageous and should not be overlooked. 这似乎不太可能使用数字工具。复制和粘贴笔记然后尝试从那里开发它们太容易了。当你使用 Antinet 时，别无选择，只能将你卡片中的知识重写到你的文本编辑器中（从而，你重新处理你已经处理过的想法）。当你最初用手写下来时，你实际上是在重新处理你已经处理过的想法。这是非常有利的，不应被忽视。

Luhmann’s Antinet put his thoughts through an intense process so that, by the time they were included in a manuscript or book, the thought was developed to a far deeper degree than just thinking while typing. Luhmann found himself in a fantastic position to develop his thoughts even further. He started with a “leg up” compared to the alternative of thinking on the fly while writing a manuscript.Luhmann 的 Antinet 使他的思想经历了一个紧张的过程，因此，当它们被包含在手稿或书籍中时，思想已经发展到比打字时思考更深入的程度。卢曼发现自己处在一个绝佳的位置，可以进一步发展他的思想。与在撰写手稿时随心所欲地思考的替代方案相比，他从 “优势” 开始。

When writing a manuscript with your Antinet, you have your notecards to guide you, and it begins to feel like a true partnership. 当你用 Antinet 写手稿时，你有你的记事卡来指导你，它开始感觉像是一种真正的伙伴关系。

I’ve experienced this myself by writing this book. The notes from my Antinet have already gone through development in two ways: (1) short-term development through writing by hand, and (2) long-term development by way of engaging new, supporting evidence and further calcifications of an idea (backed by more examples, reflections, reformulations and excerpts). 我在写这本书时亲身经历了这一点。我的 Antinet 中的笔记已经通过两种方式进行了发展：(1) 通过手写进行短期发展，以及 (2) 通过采用新的支持性证据和想法的进一步钙化来进行长期发展（支持通过更多的例子、反思、重新表述和摘录）。

When it comes down to typing the notes into a manuscript, it’s boring to just type things word-for-word from your notes; instead, the experience is a lot more active and fun if thinking is involved while typing and while trying to fully decipher what is being said. You end up developing thoughts to further clarity. Right now, I’m writing this paragraph you’re reading right now with my notecards sitting to the left of my keyboard. Oftentimes, I’ll find myself arguing with what I’ve written on the notecards and sometimes phrase what I’ve written very differently. I question what I’ve written on the notecards and feel compelled to re-check sources. Did the author who I’m quoting, really say that?! I say to myself. I then check, and more often than not, I find that the author did indeed say it. 归结为将笔记输入手稿时，从笔记中逐字逐句输入内容很无聊；相反，如果在打字和尝试完全解读所说内容时进行思考，体验会更加活跃和有趣。您最终会发展思想以进一步清晰。现在，我正在写这段你正在阅读的段落，我的记事卡放在键盘的左边。很多时候，我会发现自己与我在记事卡上写的东西争论不休，有时会用非常不同的方式来表达我写的东西。我质疑我在记事卡上写的内容，并感到有必要重新检查来源。我引用的作者真的这么说了吗？！我对自己说。然后我检查，而且往往是，我发现作者确实说过。

This entire experience enables me to connect with the reader more and communicate the idea properly by sharing with the reader my own initial skepticisms when presented with an idea. For instance, I know what you’re about to read may sound suspect. I realize the concept of ‘communicating with a ghost in a box of notecards’ sounds like woo-woo mysticism. Yet, this is precisely how the greatest social scientist of the 20th century explained the Antinet. 整个经历使我能够与读者建立更多联系，并通过与读者分享我在提出一个想法时最初的怀疑来正确地传达这个想法。例如，我知道您将要阅读的内容可能听起来很可疑。我意识到 “在一盒记事本中与鬼魂交流” 的概念听起来像是神秘主义。然而，这正是 20 世纪最伟大的社会科学家对 Antinet 的解释。

In this respect, the Antinet becomes a true communication partner, a true writing partner. At the foundation of such an emergent experience is the technology of analog notes…written by hand. 在这方面，Antinet 成为一个真正的沟通伙伴，一个真正的写作伙伴。这种突发体验的基础是模拟笔记技术…… 手写。

**Writing by Hand Sparks an Evolutionary Advance That Develops Working Memory Capacity 手写引发了发展工作记忆容量的进化进步**

The deliberate process of writing by hand, observes Harvard University researcher Ann Blair, “produced a somewhat odd effect.” The system, which was supposed to simply replace the cognitive overhead of having to memorize information both, (1) replaced cognitive overhead of memorizing, and unexpectedly, (2) it enhanced one’s ability to retain almost everything learned Renaissance scholars had read. The handwritten notetaking system and “the respective construction of a card index were considered both a substitute for personal memory and a memory aid.”[368](#footnote-324) 哈佛大学研究员安 · 布莱尔 (Ann Blair) 观察到，刻意的手写过程 “产生了一种有点奇怪的效果”。该系统本应简单地取代必须记住信息的认知开销，(1) 取代了记忆的认知开销，并且出乎意料地，(2) 它增强了一个人保留文艺复兴时期学者阅读过的几乎所有知识的能力。手写笔记系统和 “卡片索引的相应构造被认为是个人记忆的替代品和记忆辅助工具。”368

What Blair describes is a contradiction. Contradictions, such as a method that both replaces the cognitive process of memorization and, at the same time, enhances it, serves as a sign of a “transitional” phase towards progress in evolution.[369](#footnote-323) In effect, the practice of writing things down by hand, and thereby building a thinking system that enhances one’s ability to retain information, serves as an evolutionary jump for humans who possess this faculty. This scholar observed the phenomenon of a thinking system (built of hand-written notes and indexes) replacing and enhancing memory, and observed that such a system “may be understood as signs of evolutionary advance.”[370](#footnote-322) 布莱尔描述的是矛盾的。矛盾，例如一种既取代了记忆的认知过程又同时增强了它的方法，是进化过程中 “过渡” 阶段的标志。 369 实际上，通过以下方式记录事物的做法手，从而建立一个思维系统，增强一个人保留信息的能力，作为拥有这种能力的人类的进化跳跃。这位学者观察到思维系统（由手写笔记和索引构建）取代和增强记忆的现象，并观察到这样的系统“可以理解为进化进步的标志。”370

Central to evolutionary advances sits one key concept: contradictory phenomena. Therefore, it’s rather puzzling that the world of notetaking today finds the majority of its practitioners opting for digital systems. These systems have not proven themselves to possess the contradictory phenomenon of analog systems. Indeed, science proves digital systems to be less effective than analog systems for learning and understanding (which will be covered shortly). Digital systems may serve as an adequate memory replacement tool; however, they are not memory enhancement tools. Analog systems are both. The seemingly contradictory nature of being both a memory replacement tool and a memory enhancement tool points to analog systems as the more evolutionarily advanced medium (as absurd as that may seem). 进化进步的核心是一个关键概念：矛盾现象。因此，令人费解的是，当今的笔记世界发现大多数从业者都选择了数字系统。这些系统还没有证明自己具有模拟系统的矛盾现象。事实上，科学证明数字系统在学习和理解方面不如模拟系统有效（稍后将介绍）。数字系统可以作为一种合适的记忆替代工具；但是，它们不是增强记忆力的工具。模拟系统都是。作为内存替换工具和内存增强工具的看似矛盾的本质表明模拟系统是更先进的进化媒介（看起来很荒谬）。

The practice of writing by hand, as pointed out by Ann Blair, results in the enhancement of memory. This is of supreme importance because one of the most critical elements involved in learning is the development of one’s working memory capacity.[371](#footnote-321) 正如 Ann Blair 所指出的那样，手写的练习可以增强记忆力。这是极其重要的，因为学习中最关键的要素之一是一个人的工作记忆能力的发展。 371

Let’s talk briefly about the science of human memory now. 现在让我们简单谈谈人类记忆的科学。

**Working Memory, Short-term Storage, and Long-term Storage 工作记忆、短期存储和长期存储**

Working memory refers to the process in which information is stored in your short-term memory, where it is actively worked on and encoded. After this stage, memories can then be stored in long-term storage for later retrieval. 工作记忆是指信息存储在您的短期记忆中的过程，信息会在短期记忆中积极处理和编码。在这个阶段之后，记忆可以存储在长期存储中以供以后检索。

Luhmann wrote of multiple storage memory systems being around the corner, yet the computing power of his era wasn’t able to produce such a thing.[372](#footnote-320) However, we also know that Luhmann wasn’t convinced that computer memory would replace the need for systems relying on human memory. From Luhmann’s notecard we can see Luhmann was familiar with W. Ross Ashby’s view that “our scientific thinking [of human memory] tends to be grossly misled by the example of the big digital computer.”[373](#footnote-319)Luhmann 写到多个存储内存系统即将到来，但他那个时代的计算能力无法产生这样的东西。 372 然而，我们也知道，Luhmann 不相信计算机内存会取代对系统的需求依靠人类的记忆。从 Luhmann 的记事卡中，我们可以看出 Luhmann 熟悉 W. Ross Ashby 的观点，即 “我们的 [关于人类记忆的] 科学思维往往会被大型数字计算机的例子严重误导。”373

By referencing the concept of multiple storage, Luhmann seems to be more in-tune with how the concept worked in abstract models of human memory (rather than the abstractions of abstractions of human memory, which computer science devised). 通过引用多重存储的概念，卢曼似乎更符合这个概念在人类记忆抽象模型中的工作方式（而不是计算机科学设计的人类记忆抽象的抽象）。

What Luhmann may have been alluding to was something one scientist in human memory refers to as “the most influential computational model of memory.”[374](#footnote-318) The model referred to was proposed by Atkinson and Shiffrin in 1968—during Luhmann’s prime theoretical working days—and was known as dual storage.[375](#footnote-317)Luhmann 可能暗示的是一位研究人类记忆的科学家称之为 “最有影响力的记忆计算模型”。 374 所指的模型由 Atkinson 和 Shiffrin 于 1968 年提出——在 Luhmann 的主要理论工作时期——并且是称为双重存储。 375

The conception of dual storage systems became popular in the 1970s because of its analogy to computer systems that have separate short-term and long-term storage components.[376](#footnote-316) It does not seem coincidental that Luhmann wrote of both in such a close proximity to one another.[377](#footnote-315) In brief, he was likely aware of the dual storage memory model. 双存储系统的概念在 1970 年代开始流行，因为它类似于具有独立的短期和长期存储组件的计算机系统。 376 卢曼将两者写得如此接近，这似乎并非巧合. 377 简而言之，他可能知道双存储内存模型。

Today the dual storage memory model is encompassed under the term Search of Associative Memory, or “SAM”. According to SAM, remembered information is stored in two different types of “containers” within your mind: (1) short-term storage (“STS”), and (2) long-term storage (“LTS”).[378](#footnote-314) 今天，双存储内存模型包含在术语 “关联内存搜索” 或“SAM”下。根据 SAM，记住的信息存储在您脑海中两种不同类型的 “容器” 中：(1) 短期存储 (“STS”)，以及 (2) 长期存储 (“LTS”)。 378

**Short-Term Storage (STS) and The Antinet 短期存储 (STS) 和 Antinet**

Short-term storage is thought of as a “buffer.” In a computing context, 短期存储被认为是一个 “缓冲区”。在计算环境中，

a buffer is a temporary memory-storage area where data is stored before being processed and installed into long-term storage.[379](#footnote-313) 缓冲区是一个临时内存存储区域，数据在被处理并安装到长期存储之前存储在这里。 379

STS has limited capacity for the number of items it can store.STS 可以存储的项目数量有限。

Think of it like writing a bullet point list of ideas on a card and then shortly thereafter elaborating on each of those bullet point ideas on a dedicated card. 可以把它想象成在卡片上写一个要点列表，然后很快在一张专用卡片上详细说明每个要点的想法。

STS is the phase in which you write main notes. You write excerpts, reformulations, or reflections from your readings or source material. It’s the RAM, in computer terms. It’s the working memory, which is developed through writing by hand.STS 是您编写主要笔记的阶段。您从阅读材料或原始资料中摘录、重新表述或反思。用计算机术语来说，就是 RAM。这是工作记忆，是通过手写形成的。

**Long-Term Storage (“LTS”) and the Antinet 长期存储（“LTS”）和 Antinet**

In a later chapter, I’ll be teaching you the core components of the Antinet. The primary box in which knowledge is developed happens in something called “the main box.” Think of long-term storage as the main box of your Antinet, the area where your developed thoughts are then stored for the long term. 在后面的章节中，我将向您介绍 Antinet 的核心组件。开发知识的主要盒子发生在称为 “主盒子” 的东西中。将长期存储想象成你的 Antinet 的主要盒子，你开发的思想然后长期存储的区域。

Memory scientists liken LTS to a variant of associative neuro network models, yet LTS comprises the following features: (1) it stores associations among items, and (2) it stores associations between items and context. 记忆科学家将 LTS 比作联想神经网络模型的一种变体，但 LTS 包含以下特征：(1) 它存储项目之间的关联，以及 (2) 它存储项目和上下文之间的关联。

The Antinet’s tree structure, with proximity-based associations built into its protocol, as well as its context branches, are a perfect instantiation of LTS.Antinet 的树结构及其协议中内置的基于接近度的关联及其上下文分支是 LTS 的完美实例。

Both the architecture of short-term storage and long-term storage are perfectly represented in the Antinet—much more perfectly than a collection of mere bubbles linked together in a digital graph (cough, digital notetaking apps, cough). 短期存储和长期存储的架构在 Antinet 中都得到了完美的体现——比数字图形（咳咳，数字笔记应用程序，咳咳）中连接在一起的单纯气泡的集合要完美得多。

Let’s jump back to working memory. 让我们回到工作记忆。

Before information can be installed into long-term storage (the main box of your Antinet), it must first be encoded and then processed. You encode and process the thoughts by writing by hand.[380](#footnote-312) 在信息可以被安装到长期存储（你的 Antinet 的主盒子）之前，它必须首先被编码然后被处理。你通过手写来编码和处理思想。 380

A popular factoid related to working memory is the idea that it can only hold seven chunks of information in it.[381](#footnote-311) However the latest research argues that working memory can only hold four items during the processing phase.[382](#footnote-310) 一个与工作记忆相关的流行事实是，它只能容纳七个信息块。 381 然而，最新研究认为，工作记忆在处理阶段只能容纳四个项目。 382

When doing knowledge work, and when thinking, it’s advantageous to possess the ability to hold multiple ideas in your mind simultaneously. Often I’ll create a card that states four or five hypotheses.[383](#footnote-309) Each individual one then will get a dedicated card to be built out individually. 在做知识工作和思考时，拥有同时在脑海中容纳多个想法的能力是有利的。通常我会制作一张卡片，上面写着四五个假设。383 然后每个人都会得到一张专门的卡片来单独构建。

We find instances of Luhmann doing this as well. For instance, take the following note from Luhmann’s archived Zettelkasten: 我们也发现了卢曼这样做的例子。例如，从卢曼的存档 Zettelkasten 中获取以下注释：

photo credit: “ZK I: Note 17,11e—Niklas Luhmann Archive,” accessed March 23, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V). 照片来源：“ZK I: Note 17,11e—Niklas Luhmann Archive”，2022 年 3 月 23 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V。

Luhmann lists out five hypotheses to be further developed. Each has a corresponding letter which represents the dedicated card on which the individual hypothesis is to be explored. 卢曼列出了五个有待进一步发展的假设。每个都有一个对应的字母，代表要在其上探索单个假设的专用卡片。

The parent card housing the hypothesis possesses the card address 17,11e. The other cards are explored according to the red letter accompanying them. For instance, 17,11ea, 17,11eD, 17,11eB, 17,11eA, etc. 包含假设的父卡具有卡地址 17,11e。其他牌根据附赠的红字进行探索。例如，17,11ea、17,11eD、17,11eB、17,11eA 等。

The graph view of the tree looks like this: 树的图形视图如下所示：

photo credit: “ZK I: Note 17,11e - Niklas Luhmann Archive,” accessed March 23, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V). 照片来源：“ZK I: Note 17,11e - Niklas Luhmann Archive”，2022 年 3 月 23 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-11e_V。

Being able to hold a handful of hypotheses in your mind at the same time (as opposed to to one or two) becomes advantageous. It is valuable to exercise and build up your working memory capacity because it is critical in developing truly insightful thoughts. 能够同时在脑海中保留几个假设（而不是一个或两个）变得有利。锻炼和建立您的工作记忆能力很有价值，因为它对于发展真正有洞察力的思想至关重要。

In addition, there is an important subcomponent within working memory called “executive control,” which factors into your ability to control your attention.[384](#footnote-308) 此外，工作记忆中还有一个重要的子组件，称为 “执行控制”，它会影响您控制注意力的能力。 384

Writing by hand and working in an analog system generates “less distractions and less competing demands,” compared with the digital environments (where you’re blasted with notifications, for example). Even for those who profess to have self-discipline, are faced with the reality that they’re just one click away from lost time. Even for those who claim to wield total self-discipline, with digital notetaking, you’re just one click away from lost time. And as Benjamin Franklin pointed out, “Lost time is never found again.” 与数字环境（例如，在数字环境中，您会收到大量通知）相比，手写和在模拟系统中工作会产生 “更少的干扰和更少的竞争需求”。即使对于那些自称有自律能力的人来说，也面临这样一个现实，即他们离浪费时间只有一步之遥。即使对于那些声称完全自律的人来说，使用数字笔记，您也只需单击一下即可浪费时间。正如本杰明 · 富兰克林所指出的，“失去的时间再也找不回来了。”

**Writing by Hand Disentangles Thoughts 手写解开思绪**

Dawson Trotman’s statement that thoughts disentangle themselves when they pass through your fingertips certainly rings true for me, and other authors have expressed similar sentiments. For instance, clinical psychologist and bestselling author, Jordan Peterson. Peterson writes his books by coming up with a skeleton framework of his thesis. He places the “skeleton framework” in a Microsoft Word document and creates a mental image of the framework, which he refers to as a memory palace.[385](#footnote-307) Yet even with Peterson’s techniques, he ran into difficulties while finishing his book 12 Rules for Life. What helped Peterson during this time was a certain pen with a light affixed to it that allowed him to write in the dark. The Pen of Light is how he referred to it. Instead of slogging away at his keyboard, he decided to write by hand. He underwent the act of disentangling his thoughts by getting them out on paper with a pen, enabling him to “find the words to properly close [the] book.”[386](#footnote-306) 道森 · 特罗特曼 (Dawson Trotman) 的说法是，当思想通过您的指尖时，它们会自行解开，这对我来说当然是正确的，其他作者也表达了类似的观点。例如，临床心理学家和畅销书作家乔丹 · 彼得森 (Jordan Peterson)。彼得森通过提出他论文的框架来写他的书。他将 “骨架框架” 置于 Microsoft Word 文档中，并在脑海中创建了该框架的图像，他将其称为记忆宫殿。 385 然而，即使使用彼得森的技术，他在完成《人生的 12 条规则》一书时也遇到了困难。这段时间帮助彼得森的是一支带有灯的钢笔，可以让他在黑暗中书写。光之笔是他的称呼。他没有在键盘上苦苦挣扎，而是决定手写。他通过用笔将思绪写在纸上来理清思绪，使他能够“找到合适的词来合上[书]。”386

**Writing By Hand Exercises Neuro-Associative Recall 手写练习神经联想回忆**

In your quest to create genius-level work, you must exercise neuro-associative 在你寻求创造天才级作品的过程中，你必须运用神经联想

recall to uncover unconventional insights. [387](#footnote-305) This entails recognizing a cue (in the form of a keyterm), and recalling a concept, thought or idea that you’ve associated with the cue. 回忆以发现非常规的见解。 387 这需要识别一个提示（以关键词的形式），并回忆起您与该提示相关联的概念、想法或想法。

I refer to this as neuro-associative recall, and I hold that the Antinet develops this ability much more than digital systems do. 我将此称为神经联想回忆，我认为 Antinet 比数字系统更能发展这种能力。

For instance, I’ve employed the neuroimprinting process of writing by hand and creating dedicated keyterms in my index for certain ideas, which has resulted in my being able to instantly recall a concept or set of thoughts. For instance, when presented with the concept of power law, or the pareto principle or the 80/20 principle, I instantly think of the keyterm big impact. The phrase big impact comes from a principle outlined by Nassim Nicholas Taleb in The Black Swan. He discusses the tradeoff between the big picture of things and micro theory. That is, the big events vs. micro events. He advises one to focus on the big picture items that have a big impact.[388](#footnote-304) 例如，我采用了手写的神经印记过程，并在我的索引中为某些想法创建了专门的关键词，这使我能够立即回忆起一个概念或一组想法。例如，当看到幂律、帕累托法则或 80/20 法则的概念时，我会立即想到关键词 big impact。 “大影响” 一词来自纳西姆 · 尼古拉斯 · 塔勒布 (Nassim Nicholas Taleb) 在《黑天鹅》中概述的一条原则。他讨论了事物的大局与微观理论之间的权衡。也就是说，大事件与微事件。他建议人们关注具有重大影响的大局项目。 388

I’ve stamped this concept into my mind so that whenever I read something new, I can instantly recall the thought. I know where in my Antinet to place such similar thoughts that I come across while reading. This involves a strong neuro-associative recall ability. 我已经把这个概念印在脑海里，这样每当我读到新东西时，我都能立即回忆起这个想法。我知道在我的 Antinet 中的什么地方可以放置我在阅读时遇到的类似想法。这涉及强大的神经联想回忆能力。

Neuro-associative recall involves the process of (1) consuming information and inputs, and (2) recalling a concept associated with the new information. 神经联想回忆涉及以下过程：(1) 消费信息和输入，以及 (2) 回忆与新信息相关的概念。

This simple two-part process allows one to compare new information with previous information to learn from and recognize surprising realizations. Thus, it enables the Antinet to truly turn into a surprise-generator (one of its core functions). 这个简单的两部分过程允许人们将新信息与以前的信息进行比较，以从中学习并认识到令人惊讶的认识。因此，它使 Antinet 真正变成了一个惊喜发生器（它的核心功能之一）。

Let’s hone in on the second component of this process: “recall.” 让我们仔细研究这个过程的第二个组成部分：“回忆”。

Memory researchers, when analyzing the critical process between an item’s concept and a thought moving from short-term storage (such as in developing thoughts on main notes) to long-term storage (such as installing the cards into your main box) demonstrate that the manner in which you encode a concept turns out to have a substantial impact on recall.[389](#footnote-303) In other words, speaking thoughts into a voice recorder, as opposed to typing them out or writing them out by hand, has a drastically different result for how well you’ll recall that item. Not only this, it has a drastically different result for how well you will think through the ideas in the first place. 记忆研究人员在分析一个项目的概念和一个想法从短期存储（例如在主要笔记上发展想法）到长期存储（例如将卡片安装到您的主盒子中）之间的关键过程时表明事实证明，您对概念进行编码的方式对回忆有重大影响。 389 换句话说，将想法对着录音机说出来，而不是用手打出来或写出来，对记忆的好坏程度有着截然不同的结果。你会记得那个项目。不仅如此，对于您首先思考这些想法的能力，它也会产生截然不同的结果。

Scientists specializing in human memory have identified two mechanisms for encoding thoughts. These items have an impact on your ability to later recall the thoughts. I go into these concepts in more detail elsewhere in the book, but suffice it to say that these concepts are maintenance rehearsal (refreshing on the notecards by reviewing them), and elaborative rehearsal (thinking through the thoughts by writing them out by hand). 专门研究人类记忆的科学家已经确定了两种编码思想的机制。这些项目会影响您以后回忆这些想法的能力。我在本书的其他地方更详细地探讨了这些概念，但只要说这些概念是维护排练（通过复习记事卡来刷新它们）和精细排练（通过手写来思考想法）就足够了。

Encompassing both of these mechanisms that increase the strength of recall is the following observation: recall critically depends on the amount of time an item has spent being processed in short-term storage.[390](#footnote-302) In other words, the more time you spend processing ideas (as is involved in writing by hand compared to typing digitally), the greater your ability to recall the thought or concept later on. 包含这两种增加回忆强度的机制是以下观察：回忆关键取决于物品在短期存储中被处理的时间量。 390 换句话说，你花在处理想法上的时间越多（如与数字打字相比，涉及手写），您以后回忆想法或概念的能力就越大。

If you still aren’t convinced in the power of writing by hand, I would like to turn to two resources right now who will back me in this: (1) Science, and (2) God. 如果你仍然不相信手写的力量，我现在想求助于两个资源，他们会在这方面支持我：（1）科学，和（2）上帝。

**How Research Supports Writing by Hand 研究如何支持手写**

There have been numerous studies outlining the benefits and power of writing by hand. Let’s go through them now: 有许多研究概述了手写的好处和力量。现在让我们来看看它们：

One group of researchers conducted an experiment that tested subjects’ ability to recognize characters. One segment of subjects copied down the characters by hand; the other segment typed the characters on a keyboard. 一组研究人员进行了一项实验，测试受试者识别字符的能力。一部分被试手抄下文字；另一段在键盘上键入字符。

Results showed that when the characters had been learned by typing, they were more frequently confused with their mirror images than when they had been written by hand. This handwriting advantage did not appear immediately, but mostly [appeared] three weeks after the end of the training.[391](#footnote-301) 结果表明，当通过打字学习汉字时，与手写汉字相比，汉字更容易与镜像混淆。这种笔迹优势并没有立即出现，但大多是在训练结束三周后 [出现]。 391

In another study, a group of researchers studied the process of learning new words. They compared three groups of people: those who wrote by hand with pen, those wrote by hand with a digital pen, and those who typed on a keyboard. 在另一项研究中，一组研究人员研究了学习新单词的过程。他们比较了三组人：用笔手写的人，用数字笔手写的人，以及在键盘上打字的人。

Some interesting results emerged from this study. First, “positive mood during learning was significantly higher during handwriting than during typing.”[392](#footnote-300) 这项研究得出了一些有趣的结果。首先，“学习期间的积极情绪在手写期间明显高于在打字期间。”392

Second, the researchers found that “movements involved in handwriting allow a greater memorization of new words.”[393](#footnote-299) 其次，研究人员发现 “手写动作可以更好地记住新单词。”393

Last, “handwriting with a digital pen and tablet can increase the ability to learn compared with keyboard typing once the individuals are accustomed to it.”[394](#footnote-298) This last finding may prompt one to consider using a digital pen or reMarkable table. I contend, however, that those routes miss the other benefits of analog systems. That is, laying out the cards in front of you, considering the external context associated with sifting through your cards, and the other benefits outlined in this book. Regardless, let’s call a spade a spade: even digital handwriting outshines typing in terms of learning new concepts, words, and stamping such information on your mind. 最后，“一旦个人习惯了，与键盘打字相比，使用数字笔和平板电脑手写可以提高学习能力。”394 最后这一发现可能会促使人们考虑使用数字笔或 reMarkable 桌子。然而，我认为这些路线错过了模拟系统的其他好处。也就是说，将卡片摆在你面前，考虑与筛选卡片相关的外部环境，以及本书中概述的其他好处。无论如何，让我们直言不讳：就学习新概念、单词和将此类信息牢记在心而言，即使是数字手写也胜过打字。

Another study by a group of researchers compared the memory process for subjects who wrote by hand vs. typed. Here’s what they found: 一组研究人员进行的另一项研究比较了手写和打字受试者的记忆过程。这是他们的发现：
