A comparison of recall and recognition for common words demonstrates that memory is better for words when they have been written down rather than when they are typed. This provides additional support for the hypothesis that the additional context provided by the complex task of writing results in better memory. With the recent trend towards electronic note taking, the educational and practical implications of these findings would suggest that performance may be improved by using traditional paper-and-pen notes.[395](#footnote-297) 对常用单词的回忆和识别的比较表明，当单词被写下来而不是被打出来时，它们的记忆力更好。这为以下假设提供了额外的支持，即复杂的写作任务提供的额外上下文会导致更好的记忆。随着最近电子笔记的趋势，这些发现的教育和实践意义表明，使用传统的纸笔笔记可能会提高成绩。 395

Another researcher went deeper in exploring how handwriting seems to positively impact the recognition process of memory. Here’s what she found: 另一位研究人员更深入地探索手写似乎如何对记忆的识别过程产生积极影响。这是她的发现：

My colleagues and I showed that early handwriting practice affects visual symbol recognition because it results in the production of variable visual forms that aid in symbol understanding.[396](#footnote-296) 我和我的同事表明，早期的手写练习会影响视觉符号识别，因为它会产生有助于符号理解的可变视觉形式。 396

One of the more popular studies on handwriting vs. typing using a keyboard is titled, The Pen Is Mightier than the Keyboard: Advantages of Longhand over Laptop Note Taking. Sönke Ahrens himself cites this research paper in his book How to Take Smart Notes; yet puzzlingly enough, he seems to discard such findings and explains to his readers that he opts for a digital Zettelkasten due to mobility. I won’t get into my gripe with this right now. Let’s talk about the study itself. 关于手写与使用键盘打字的比较流行的研究之一是，笔比键盘更强大：手写相对于笔记本电脑记笔记的优势。 Sönke Ahrens 在他的《如何做智能笔记》一书中引用了这篇研究论文；但令人费解的是，他似乎放弃了这些发现，并向他的读者解释说，由于移动性，他选择了数字 Zettelkasten。我现在不会抱怨这个。让我们谈谈研究本身。

The researchers, Pam A. Mueller and Daniel M. Oppenheimer conducted a study involving two groups of students. One group took notes using a laptop; the other group of students took notes by hand. 研究人员 Pam A. Mueller 和 Daniel M. Oppenheimer 进行了一项涉及两组学生的研究。一组使用笔记本电脑做笔记；另一组学生用手记笔记。

What the researchers discovered was that taking notes digitally may be “impairing learning because their use results in shallower processing.”[397](#footnote-295) 研究人员发现，以数字方式记笔记可能 “会损害学习，因为它们的使用会导致较浅的处理过程。”397

Here is what the researchers discovered: 以下是研究人员的发现：

In three studies, we found that students who took notes on laptops performed worse on conceptual questions than students who took notes longhand. We show that whereas taking more notes can be beneficial, laptop note takers’ tendency to transcribe lectures verbatim rather than processing information and reframing it in their own words is detrimental to learning.[398](#footnote-294) 在三项研究中，我们发现在笔记本电脑上做笔记的学生在概念性问题上的表现比手写笔记的学生差。我们表明，虽然做更多笔记可能是有益的，但使用笔记本电脑做笔记的人倾向于逐字记录讲座而不是处理信息并用自己的话重新组织它，这对学习是有害的。 398

While this study from 2014 supports my thesis that writing by hand is more effective than writing digitally, I must share the latest research, which discredits this finding (for sake of intellectual integrity). This brings us to a 2021 study titled, Don’t Ditch the Laptop Just Yet: A Direct Replication of Mueller and Oppenheimer’s (2014) Study 1 Plus Mini Meta-Analyses Across Similar Studies. In this study, researchers replicated Mueller and Oppenheimer’s experiment. However, the results did not “support the idea that longhand note taking improves immediate learning via better encoding of information.”[399](#footnote-293) 虽然 2014 年的这项研究支持我的论点，即手写比数字书写更有效，但我必须分享最新的研究，它否定了这一发现（为了知识的完整性）。这将我们带入了一项 2021 年的研究，该研究的标题是，暂时不要丢弃笔记本电脑：Mueller 和 Oppenheimer (2014) 的研究 1 的直接复制以及类似研究中的迷你元分析。在这项研究中，研究人员复制了 Mueller 和 Oppenheimer 的实验。然而，结果并不 “支持手写笔记通过更好的信息编码来改善即时学习的想法。”399

So, what do we make of this? Which one is mightier: pen or keyboard? On this matter, I will say this: the only right answer is test. Experiment for yourself. For many, the pen is indeed mightier than the keyboard; however, the popularity and cultural stigma of using pen and paper prevents many from adopting longhand. There’s an underlying pressure to use digital tools. There’s an implicit sense that in order to “be smart” (and technically sophisticated), one must embrace the supposed superpower of digital notetaking apps (with their illusive bubble graphs). I think this is incorrect. Many people use digital tools for thinking when, in reality, they should be using analog tools. The most recent research appears to support this conclusion. In a study titled, Make a Note of It: Comparison in Longhand, Keyboard, and Stylus notetaking Techniques, researchers found that “students performed better using their preferred note-taking method.”[400](#footnote-292) The moral of the story? Experiment for yourself. Determine your preferred notetaking method (and don’t be surprised to find that it is, indeed, writing by hand)! 那么，我们对此有何看法？哪一个更强大：笔还是键盘？关于这件事，我会这样说：唯一正确的答案是测试。自己做实验。对于许多人来说，笔确实比键盘更强大；然而，使用笔和纸的流行和文化耻辱阻止了许多人采用手写。使用数字工具存在潜在压力。有一种隐含的感觉，即为了 “变得聪明”（并且在技术上成熟），一个人必须拥抱数字笔记应用程序的所谓超级力量（以及它们虚幻的气泡图）。我认为这是不正确的。许多人使用数字工具来思考，而实际上他们应该使用模拟工具。最近的研究似乎支持这一结论。在一项题为“记下它：手写、键盘和手写笔记笔记技术的比较” 的研究中，研究人员发现“学生使用他们喜欢的记笔记方法表现得更好。”400 这个故事的寓意是什么？自己做实验。确定您喜欢的记笔记方法（不要惊讶地发现它确实是手写）！

Before we conclude this section, let’s briefly turn to a different practice: reading. Not only has writing on a digital device been shown to hamper learning and comprehension, a recent study found that even reading comprehension is reduced when using a digital device.[401](#footnote-291) Even if you hold that writing digitally is better for you, that doesn’t mean reading digitally is better for you. In fact, reading digitally is probably not better for you (at least in terms of comprehension). 在结束本节之前，让我们简要地转向另一种做法：阅读。不仅在数字设备上书写会阻碍学习和理解，最近的一项研究还发现，使用数字设备时甚至阅读理解能力也会降低。 401 即使您认为数字化写作对您更好，但这并不意味着数字阅读更适合您。事实上，数字阅读可能并不适合你（至少在理解方面）。

In sum, the research makes it apparent: not only is the pen mightier than the keyboard, the physical book is, too (at least, for many of us)! 总而言之，这项研究表明：不仅笔比键盘更强大，实体书也是如此（至少对我们许多人而言）！

**How God Supports Writing by Hand 上帝如何支持手写**

If you won’t take my word for it, and if you don’t care about the scientific literature supporting the process of writing by hand, well, then I suppose you can take the word of another entity. He goes by the name of…GOD! 如果你不相信我的话，如果你不关心支持手写过程的科学文献，那么我想你可以相信另一个实体的话。他的名字是…… 上帝！

For the LORD said, “Write the vision; make it plain on tablets” (Habakkuk 2:2 [NRSV]), or Isaiah 8:1 (NRSV): “Then the LORD said to me, take a large tablet and write on it in common characters.” 因为耶和华说：“将异象写下来；写在版上”（哈巴谷书 2:2 [NRSV]），或以赛亚书 8:1 (NRSV)：“耶和华对我说，拿一块大版，用普通的字写在上面。”

There you have it. God espouses the power of writing by hand. 你有它。上帝支持手写的力量。

I lay forth this reason slightly tongue-in-cheek. I’d prefer you adopt the practice of writing by hand by testing it out yourself (or from reading the scientific literature). After all, I may have ever-so-slightly taken these quotes from God out of context. But since these two verses were presented to me while attending church with my family one day, I figured I might as well extract them onto a bibcard and share them with you here. 我开玩笑地提出了这个理由。我希望您通过自己测试（或阅读科学文献）来采用手写的做法。毕竟，我可能已经稍微断章取义了这些来自上帝的引述。但是，由于有一天我和家人一起去教堂时看到了这两节经文，我想我不妨将它们提取到一个 bibcard 上并在这里与您分享。

**Conclusion 结论**

There you have it. I’ve laid out in detail the power of analog, the power of writing by hand, the people who write by hand, and the science behind analog. Heck, I’ve even thrown in God as a reason to take writing by hand seriously. If you’re still not convinced by the power of analog, well then, that means only one thing: even God can’t help you. I’m kidding, of course, but seriously: try the Antinet yourself. Only after that should you determine if it’s truly as powerful as what I (and others) say. 你有它。我已经详细阐述了模拟的力量、手写的力量、手写的人以及模拟背后的科学。哎呀，我什至把上帝作为认真对待手写的理由。如果您仍然不相信模拟的力量，那么，那只意味着一件事：即使上帝也帮不了您。当然，我是在开玩笑，但我是认真的：自己试试 Antinet。只有在那之后，你才能确定它是否真的像我（和其他人）所说的那样强大。

CHAPTER SEVEN 第七章
-----------------

Numeric-Alpha 数字字母
------------------

“Since all notes have fixed numbers, you can add as many references to them as you may want. Central concepts can have many links which show on which other contexts we can find materials relevant for them. Through references, we can, without too much work or paper, solve the problem of multiple storage.”“由于所有笔记都有固定编号，您可以根据需要添加任意数量的参考文献。中心概念可以有许多链接，这些链接显示我们可以在哪些其他上下文中找到与它们相关的材料。通过引用，我们可以在没有太多工作或纸张的情况下解决多重存储的问题。”

—Niklas Luhmann, Communication with Noteboxes[402](#footnote-453)—Niklas Luhmann，与 Noteboxes402 的交流

**Numeric-Alpha Addresses are Arguably the Most Important Component of The Antinet 数字字母地址可以说是 Antinet 最重要的组成部分**
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Alberto cevolini, a scholar who has studied a vast amount of knowledge systems throughout history, observes that Luhmann’s numbering of entries is too important to brush over too quickly. In the scholar’s view, Luhmann’s numeric-alpha scheme represents one of the most interesting evolutionary transitions in the field of knowledge management systems.[403](#footnote-452) 研究过大量历史知识体系的学者阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto cevolini) 观察到，卢曼的条目编号太重要了，不能草率扫过。在这位学者看来，卢曼的数字 - 阿尔法方案代表了知识管理系统领域最有趣的演化转变之一。 403

The most important feature of the Antinet is the one that generates its most important results. To Luhmann the most important result of the Antinet concerns its inner life. Antinet 最重要的特征是产生其最重要结果的特征。对卢曼来说，Antinet 最重要的结果是它的内在生活。

The inner life of the Antinet is brought about by two things. Antinet 的内在生命是由两件事带来的。

First, it revolves around creating a communication partner (a second mind, a ghost in the box, and an alter-ego). 首先，它围绕着创造一个沟通伙伴（第二个头脑，盒子里的幽灵和另一个自我）。

In the beginning of his paper on his Antinet, Luhmann states something rather radical: he says that “it is easy to think of systems theory” as the way to describe the Antinet. After all, “we consider ourselves to be systems.” But he goes on to explain that he chooses “communication theory” to describe his system. “One of us listens to the other.” He continues, “This needs to be explained.”[404](#footnote-451) 在他关于反网络的论文的开头，卢曼说了一些相当激进的话：他说 “很容易想到系统理论” 作为描述反网络的方式。毕竟，“我们认为自己是系统。”但他继续解释说，他选择 “通信理论” 来描述他的系统。 “我们中的一个人倾听另一个人的声音。”他继续说道，“这需要解释一下。”404

The radical notion centers on his usage of the terms us and we. What he’s referring to is the communication and dialogue that takes place between him and his Antinet, yet the way in which he’s referring to it makes him sound more like a schizophrenic than the most important German sociologist of the twentieth century! 激进的概念集中在他对术语 “我们” 和“我们”的使用上。他指的是发生在他和他的 Antinet 之间的交流和对话，但他指代它的方式让他听起来更像是一个精神分裂症患者，而不是 20 世纪最重要的德国社会学家！

But if we decide to take Luhmann’s word for it, perhaps we could learn something from this. Perhaps there really is something to the idea of creating a communication partner out of an analog notebox. 但如果我们决定相信卢曼的话，也许我们可以从中学到一些东西。也许从模拟记事本中创建一个通信伙伴的想法真的很有意义。

How do we go about experiencing such a phenomenon of creating a com- munication partner? 我们如何着手体验这种创造沟通伙伴的现象？

According to Luhmann, it requires giving each card a firm fixed place through use of a numeric-alpha address. “This decision about structure…” according to Luhmann, “makes possible the creation of high complexity in the card file and thus makes possible its ability to communicate in the first place.”[405](#footnote-450) 根据 Luhmann 的说法，它需要通过使用数字字母地址为每张卡提供一个固定的位置。 “这个关于结构的决定……” 根据卢曼的说法，“使得在卡片文件中创建高度复杂的内容成为可能，从而使其首先能够进行交流。”405

The second component of the inner life of the Antinet is its ability to become a surprise-generator through its ability to produce fortunate accidents. “The role of accidents in the theory of science is not disputed,” writes Luhmann. “If you employ evolutionary models, accidents assume a most important role.”[406](#footnote-449) These accidents are really accidental insights that come about by stumbling upon ideas or thoughts while exploring the physical form and nature of your knowledge (by sifting through your cards by hand).Antinet 内在生命的第二个组成部分是它通过产生幸运事故的能力成为惊喜发生器的能力。 “事故在科学理论中的作用是没有争议的，” 卢曼写道。 “如果你采用进化模型，意外事件将扮演最重要的角色。”406 这些意外事件实际上是在探索你的知识的物理形式和本质（通过手工筛选你的卡片）时偶然发现想法或想法而产生的。 .

These two components describe the most important aspect of Luhmann’s system, its “inner life.” As Luhmann writes: 这两个组成部分描述了卢曼系统最重要的方面，即它的 “内心生活”。正如卢曼所写：

For the inner life of the card index, for the arrangement of notes or its mental history, it is most important that we decide against the systematic ordering in accordance with topics and sub-topics and choose instead a firm fixed place (Stellordnung).[407](#footnote-448) 对于卡片索引的内在生命，对于笔记的排列或它的心路历程，最重要的是我们决定不按照主题和子主题进行系统排序，而是选择一个固定的固定位置 (Stellordnung)。 407

The most important component for establishing the inner life of this system, and giving it a firm fixed place, revolves around one thing: numeric-alpha addresses. 建立这个系统的内部生命并赋予它一个稳固的固定位置的最重要的组成部分围绕着一件事：数字字母地址。

This makes it quite puzzling when so-called Zettelkasten experts, productivity experts, PKM experts, and second-brain proselytizers take a nonchalant approach to explaining numeric-alpha addresses. 当所谓的 Zettelkasten 专家、生产力专家、PKM 专家和第二脑倡导者采用一种漫不经心的方式来解释数字字母地址时，这让人感到非常困惑。

**The History of Numeric-Alpha Addresses in Notecard Systems 记事本系统中数字字母地址的历史**
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Niklas Luhmann was not the first person to devise the notion of using numeric-alpha addresses on notecards. Fridericus Sidelius and Paulus Sigismundus recommended notecards (excerpta schedacea) in a booklet they published in 1713. In the booklet they stated “it would be sufficient to preserve index cards in distinguished files and number them consecutively, while leaving a margin [for] later gluing or stitching together all cards belonging to the same entry.”[408](#footnote-447) 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 并不是第一个提出在记事卡上使用数字字母地址的人。 Fridericus Sidelius 和 Paulus Sigismundus 在他们于 1713 年出版的一本小册子中推荐了记事卡 (excerpta schedacea)。在小册子中他们说 “将索引卡保存在不同的文件中并连续编号就足够了，同时为以后的粘合留出空白或将属于同一条目的所有卡片拼接在一起。”408

A novel knowledge development system was devised by Thomas Harrison more than fifty years prior to the publishing of the booklet by Sidelius and Sigismundus. Harrison’s system was called the “Ark of Studies.” Harrison advised that the notecard-like slips of paper in the Ark of Studies could be arranged in alphabetical order, or, could be numbered.[409](#footnote-446) 在 Sidelius 和 Sigismundus 出版小册子之前五十多年，Thomas Harrison 设计了一种新颖的知识开发系统。哈里森的系统被称为 “研究方舟”。哈里森建议，研究方舟中类似记事卡的纸条可以按字母顺序排列，或者可以编号。 409

At the beginning of the eighteenth century, Johann Benedict Metzler recommended numbering notecards because “compared with alphabetical order, numerical order is clearer and avoids the inconvenience of empty spaces.”[410](#footnote-445)18 世纪初，约翰 · 本尼迪克特 · 梅茨勒 (Johann Benedict Metzler) 推荐了编号记事卡，因为 “与字母顺序相比，数字顺序更清晰，避免了空格带来的不便。”410

The history of numeric-alpha notes stands quite rich. Many thinkers stumbled onto the system because it simply makes sense. John Locke even devised his own numeric-alpha system for his notes.[411](#footnote-444) In Antonin Sertillanges’s Antinet, which he outlines in his 1921 book, The Intellectual Life, he advises that each slip should be numbered in the corner or in the middle of the slip.[412](#footnote-443) 数字字母音符的历史相当丰富。许多思想家偶然发现了这个系统，因为它很有意义。 John Locke 甚至为他的笔记设计了他自己的数字字母系统。 411 在 Antonin Sertillanges 的 Antinet 中，他在他 1921 年的著作 The Intellectual Life 中概述了这本书，他建议每张纸条都应该在纸条的角落或中间编号. 412

Luhmann never shared specifically where he got the idea for his Antinet. Nor did he state where the idea for using numeric-alpha addresses came from. However, I believe much of the system’s essence derived from the first job he held during his short legal career. The first job he took after law school was at the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court. His task was to organize a reference system for administrative court decisions. According to Luhmann, “the court should be able to see what higher court decisions were available at any given time.”[413](#footnote-442) It is there, I believe, that Luhmann either developed or learned the reference system that gave birth to the Zettelkasten. He worked at the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court precisely around the time he created his first Zettelkasten system (1952–1953).Luhmann 从未具体透露过他是从哪里得到 Antinet 的想法的。他也没有说明使用数字字母地址的想法从何而来。但是，我相信该系统的大部分本质都源于他在其短暂的法律职业生涯中担任的第一份工作。他从法学院毕业后的第一份工作是在吕讷堡高等行政法院。他的任务是为行政法院判决组织一个参考系统。根据 Luhmann 的说法，“法院应该能够在任何给定时间看到更高级别的法院判决。”413 我相信，正是在那里，Luhmann 发展或学习了催生 Zettelkasten 的参考系统。就在他创建第一个 Zettelkasten 系统（1952-1953 年）前后，他在 Lüneburg 高等行政法院工作。

Recently, a group of researchers gathered on Luhmann’s ninetieth birthday to discuss Luhmann’s time at the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court. Of Luhmann’s work during that time, one scholar noted that there are no longer any physical traces; all traces of it were destroyed in accordance with regulations.[414](#footnote-441) However, from personnel notes about Luhmann at the time, we learn several things, including that Luhmann built out a notebox in the court’s library. 最近，一群研究人员聚集在卢曼九十岁生日之际，讨论卢曼在吕讷堡高等行政法院度过的时光。关于卢曼那段时间的作品，一位学者指出，不再有任何物理痕迹；它的所有痕迹都按照规定销毁了。 414 然而，从当时关于卢曼的人员记录中，我们了解到几件事，包括卢曼在法院图书馆建造了一个笔记本。

The scheme used in the German legal administration system relies on each document having a “file number” (Aktenzeichen).[415](#footnote-440) This number is, separated by a slash (/), is unique (no file can have the same number), and can be combined with alphabetical characters. An example Aktenzeichen is 211321/37a. 德国法律管理系统中使用的方案依赖于每个文件都有一个 “文件编号”（Aktenzeichen）。415 这个编号由斜线（/）分隔，是唯一的（没有文件可以有相同的编号），并且可以与字母字符组合。 Aktenzeichen 的一个例子是 211321/37a。

In brief, Luhmann’s work at Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court greatly shaped the origins of the numeric-alpha address. If Luhmann didn’t learn about Aktenzeichen at the Lüneburg Higher Administrative Court, then at the very least, it derived from his time studying law and using such a reference system. 简而言之，卢曼在吕讷堡高等行政法院的工作极大地塑造了数字字母地址的起源。如果卢曼没有在吕讷堡高等行政法院了解 Aktenzeichen，那么至少，它源于他学习法律和使用这样一个参考系统的时间。

**The Anatomy of Numeric-Alpha Addresses 数字字母地址剖析**
---------------------------------------------------

The anatomy of numeric-alpha addresses is quite simple. Each address starts with a number and can be combined with an alphabetical character that serves as a variant of the idea. From there, the addresses “branch-down,” and allow users to create more cards by adding a forward slash (/) , a period (.), a comma (,), or even by just appending the address with alternating numbers and alphabetical characters. Personally, I prefer forward slashes (/). 数字字母地址的剖析非常简单。每个地址都以数字开头，并且可以与作为想法变体的字母字符组合。从那里，地址 “向下分支”，并允许用户通过添加正斜杠 (/)、句点 (.)、逗号 (,) 或什至只是在地址后附加交替数字和字母字符。就个人而言，我更喜欢正斜杠 (/)。

Let’s use a hypothetical example. Here is an example of an arbitrary set of branches: 让我们使用一个假设的例子。这是一个任意分支集的示例：

Now, let’s say later on you want to add a card for a mule (the offspring of a male donkey and a female horse). 现在，假设稍后您想为骡子（公驴和母马的后代）添加一张卡片。

You’re faced with a few options. In fact, you can really do anything (as long as you link to the Mule card). However let’s say you wish to place the Mule card after Donkey and before Turtles. What do you do? It’s simple. You create a card 3118/2a for Mules. 你面临着几个选择。事实上，你真的可以做任何事情（只要你链接到 Mule 卡）。但是，假设您希望将 Mule 卡放在 Donkey 之后和 Turtles 之前。你做什么工作？这很简单。您为 Mules 创建了一张卡片 3118/2a。

It then looks like this: 然后它看起来像这样：

The 3118/2a is the numeric-alpha address for mules. It never changes. As Luhmann writes, it has a fixed position, which is a core element that gives your Antinet its inner life. It’s such a simple discipline and practice yet, over time, you’ll see that this simple concept turns your Antinet into a communication partner and a brilliant system for generating breakthroughs (by way of accidents).3118/2a 是 mule 的字母数字地址。它永远不会改变。正如 Luhmann 所写，它有一个固定的位置，这是赋予 Antinet 内部生命的核心元素。这是一个如此简单的纪律和实践，但随着时间的推移，你会发现这个简单的概念将你的 Antinet 变成了一个沟通伙伴和一个产生突破（通过意外）的绝妙系统。

**Numeric-Alpha Addresses in Real Life 现实生活中的数字字母地址**
-----------------------------------------------------

When you start looking for them, you’ll start to see numeric-alpha addresses everywhere; for instance, freeway exit numbers. 当你开始寻找它们时，你会开始看到到处都是数字字母地址；例如，高速公路出口号码。

Numeric-alpha addresses in the Antinet operate much like the addresses allotted to freeway exits. Instead of having to remember full names, one can simply look for a numeric-alpha address like 9b. The 9b simply routes you to a location. It does not indicate a hierarchical relationship with exits 9 or 9a; it just indicates that the exit will take you to a different location in the world. This is precisely how such addresses work in the Antinet; they route you to different locations in your tree of knowledge. Antinet 中的数字字母地址与分配给高速公路出口的地址非常相似。不必记住全名，只需查找像 9b 这样的数字字母地址即可。 9b 只是将您引导至某个位置。不表示与出口 9 或 9a 有等级关系；它只是表示出口将带您到世界上的不同位置。这正是此类地址在 Antinet 中的工作方式；他们将您引导到知识树中的不同位置。

**Numeric-Alpha Addresses Unlock the Self-Referential Nature of the Antinet 数字 - Alpha 地址解锁了 Antinet 的自我引用性质**
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The concept of self-reference refers to the notion of a sentence, idea, formula, function, or a system that refers to its self (or itself). For instance, the term “I” in English is a self-reference to oneself. Or take the concept def init(self): in the Python programming language used in computing). It enables a class to create objects that refer to itself and that call itself (reference itself). Self-referential statements are often paradoxical and can be considered recursive. 自我指涉的概念是指一个句子、想法、公式、函数或一个系统的概念，它指代自己（或它自己）。例如，英语中的 “我” 一词是对自己的自我指代。或者采用概念 def init(self): 在用于计算的 Python 编程语言中）。它使一个类能够创建引用自身和调用自身（引用自身）的对象。自引用语句通常是自相矛盾的，可以被认为是递归的。

The scholar Alberto Cevolini observes that an numeric-alpha address “ensures utmost autonomy, i.e. self-referential closure of the machine.”[416](#footnote-439) 学者阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 观察到数字字母地址 “确保了最大程度的自治，即机器的自我引用关闭。”416

The self-referential closure of the machine is a critical piece of the Antinet’s architecture. It’s the key piece that transforms the Antinet into a cybernetic system (a system that achieves a goal through feedback and communication). 机器的自引用关闭是 Antinet 架构的关键部分。它是将 Antinet 转变为控制论系统（通过反馈和通信实现目标的系统）的关键部分。

The numeric-alpha addresses enable the Antinet to refer to itself and its own individual parts. It’s a key piece for creating the personality (the ghost, the alter ego). As a result, observes Cevolini, “interaction” with the Antinet, becomes “a type of communication”—an internal dialogue.[417](#footnote-438) 数字字母地址使 Antinet 能够引用自身及其自身的各个部分。这是创造个性（幽灵，另一个自我）的关键部分。因此，Cevolini 观察到，与 Antinet 的 “互动” 变成了“一种交流”——一种内部对话。 417

Luhmann was intimately familiar with the power of self-referential systems. His magnum opus social theory was largely predicated on society as a self-referential system.[418](#footnote-437) As such, Luhmann designed the Antinet with the capability to refer to itself. Just as a human can refer to its own parts (like the left hand), the Antinet can refer to its own parts (its thoughts identified by its unique numeric-alpha card addresses). 卢曼非常熟悉自我参照系统的力量。他的巨著社会理论主要基于社会作为一个自我参照系统。418 因此，卢曼设计了具有自我参照能力的 Antinet。正如人类可以参考自己的部分（如左手），Antinet 可以参考自己的部分（其思想由其唯一的数字字母卡地址标识）。

Luhmann was also greatly influenced by the idea of self-description. He was inspired by the work of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, a German philosopher who wrote extensively about self-description by way of making the case for philosophy as the apotheosis of science.[419](#footnote-436) Luhmann’s theories attempted to adhere to the idea of self-description. He sought to devise a theory of society that explained itself through itself.[420](#footnote-435) 卢曼也深受自我描述思想的影响。他受到德国哲学家格奥尔格 · 威廉 · 弗里德里希 · 黑格尔 (Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel) 著作的启发，黑格尔通过将哲学作为科学的典范来撰写大量关于自我描述的文章。419 卢曼的理论试图坚持自我描述的理念。他试图设计一种通过自身来解释自身的社会理论。 420

For a fun illustration of self-referential systems, let’s take an example from my own Antinet. I have a card at the very beginning (card address 0). My own Antinet essentially introduces himself and refers to his own parts. 为了有趣地说明自参照系统，让我们以我自己的 Antinet 为例。我一开始就有一张卡（卡地址 0）。我自己的 Antinet 本质上是介绍自己并引用他自己的部分。

This may seem absurd, but Luhmann did similar things in his own Antinet.[421](#footnote-434) It keeps things light and fun! 这可能看起来很荒谬，但 Luhmann 在他自己的 Antinet 中做了类似的事情。421 它让事情变得轻松有趣！

**The Science Behind Numeric-Alpha Addresses 数字字母地址背后的科学**
----------------------------------------------------------

Throughout this book I emphasize over and over that Luhmann’s system was a deliberate creation. It mirrors how human memory works to a surprisingly close degree. 在整本书中，我一再强调卢曼的体系是一种深思熟虑的创造。它以惊人的接近程度反映了人类记忆的工作方式。

The numeric-alpha addresses transform the Antinet’s network into something akin to auto-associations discussed in memory science. An auto-association is built on content-addressable memory, similar to how computes work: “the bits themselves are meaningless, and the bytes made out of them have arbitrary addresses, like houses on a street, which have nothing to do with their contents.”[422](#footnote-433) 数字字母地址将 Antinet 的网络转换为类似于记忆科学中讨论的自动关联的东西。自动关联建立在内容可寻址内存之上，类似于计算的工作方式：“位本身是无意义的，由它们组成的字节具有任意地址，就像街道上的房屋一样，与它们的内容无关”422

This is also how the Antinet works thanks to the numeric-alpha addresses. “Memory locations are accessed by their addresses.”[423](#footnote-432) The way in which you explore these addresses is through the keyterms which are housed in the index, serving as a cue to light up areas of your mind. 由于数字字母地址，这也是 Antinet 的工作方式。 “通过地址访问内存位置。”423 您探索这些地址的方式是通过索引中的关键词，作为点亮您思想领域的线索。

Multi-storage models posited by those who study human memory indicate why numeric-alpha addresses are critical. Johannes Schmidt explains that, “embedding a topic in various contexts gives rise to different lines of information by means of opening up different realms of comparison in each case.”[424](#footnote-431) 研究人类记忆的人提出的多存储模型表明了为什么数字字母地址很重要。 Johannes Schmidt 解释说，“通过在每种情况下打开不同的比较领域，将主题嵌入不同的上下文会产生不同的信息线。”424

**The Concept of Comparison 比较的概念**

Let’s talk about the concept of comparison briefly. Steven Pinker points out an important point relating to the concept of comparison in his book How the Mind Works. Pinker writes that without specifying a goal, “the very idea of intelligence is meaningless.”[425](#footnote-430) 简单说一下比较的概念。 Steven Pinker 在他的著作 How the Mind Works 中指出了与比较概念相关的一个重要观点。平克写道，如果不指定目标，“智力这个概念本身就毫无意义。”425

And what is intelligence? It’s something that comes from information, thus bringing up the question, What is information? According to Pinker, “information is a correlation between two things that is produced by a lawful process.”[426](#footnote-429) For instance, the rings of a tree stump compared with the age of the tree. The Antinet is constructed around this concept. Before you install anything into the Antinet, it forces comparison and correlation. As Luhmann puts it, “Information, accordingly, originates only in systems which possess a comparative schema—even if this amounts only to: ‘this or something else.’”[427](#footnote-428) 什么是智力？它是来自信息的东西，因此提出了一个问题，什么是信息？根据 Pinker 的说法，“信息是通过合法过程产生的两种事物之间的相关性。”426 例如，树桩的年轮与树龄的比较。 Antinet 就是围绕这个概念构建的。在将任何东西安装到 Antinet 之前，它会强制进行比较和关联。正如卢曼所说，“因此，信息仅起源于具有比较图式的系统——即使这仅相当于：‘这个或其他东西’。”427

**The Concept of Relations 关系的概念**

“Life is just one damn relatedness after another.” —Julian Huxley[428](#footnote-427)“生活就是一个又一个该死的关联。” ——朱利安赫胥黎 428

When you install anything in the Antinet, you’re relating the concept on the note to the most similar concept already installed in your Antinet. You’re comparing, contrasting, and correlating the thought with all other thoughts in long-term storage. 当您在 Antinet 中安装任何东西时，您会将注释上的概念与已安装在 Antinet 中的最相似概念相关联。您正在将想法与长期存储中的所有其他想法进行比较、对比和关联。

This introduces us to the concept that the Antinet is really a relation of “(selective) relations,” as Johannes Schmidt puts it.[429](#footnote-426) For instance, when you read, there’s a relation between the book and your mind.[430](#footnote-425) These are what one would call selective relations. You’re selecting information from a book that you relate to another thought in your mind. From here, you relate this information to other thoughts already installed in your Antinet. You do this by assigning them a numeric-alpha address and placing them next to, or under, the most similar card. 这向我们介绍了 Antinet 实际上是一种 “（选择性）关系” 的概念，正如 Johannes Schmidt 所说。 429 例如，当你阅读时，书和你的思想之间存在一种关系。 430 这些是一个会称为选择性关系。您正在从一本书中选择与您脑海中的另一个想法相关的信息。从这里开始，您将此信息与您的 Antinet 中已经安装的其他想法相关联。为此，您可以为它们分配一个数字字母地址，并将它们放在最相似的卡片旁边或下面。

At this point we have a relation of selective relations. 在这一点上，我们有一个选择关系的关系。

However, with remotelinks, which will be detailed later, we can link to other relations of selective relations on other branches of our Antinet. 然而，使用远程链接，稍后将详细介绍，我们可以链接到我们 Antinet 的其他分支上的其他选择性关系。

In effect, we have a relation of relations of selective relations. Basically, the Antinet is a spider-like web of knowledge you’ve selected from your readings. 实际上，我们有一种选择性关系的关系。基本上，Antinet 是您从阅读中选择的蜘蛛状知识网。

If you find this a bit confusing, don’t worry. You’re not the only one. I’ll explain it in a clearer manner later in this book—specifically, in the chapter on selection. 如果您觉得这有点令人困惑，请不要担心。你并不是唯一的一个。我将在本书后面以更清晰的方式解释它——特别是在关于选择的章节中。

In brief, the Antinet and its numeric-alpha address scheme models itself after the science of human memory. Creating a note in a stream of consciousness state mirrors the short-term storage concept in human memory. In turn, this opens up different realms of information when the card is installed in your Antinet (the long-term storage component of human memory). The different realms of information are powered by the core process built into the Antinet: comparing thoughts and deciding what they’re related to (this or something else, as Luhmann says).[431](#footnote-424) 简而言之，Antinet 及其数字字母地址方案模仿人类记忆科学。在意识流状态下创建笔记反映了人类记忆中的短期存储概念。反过来，当将卡安装到您的 Antinet（人类记忆的长期存储组件）中时，这会打开不同的信息领域。不同的信息领域由内置于 Antinet 中的核心过程提供动力：比较思想并确定它们与什么相关（如 Luhmann 所说，这个或其他）。 431

**The Resistance of Numeric-Alpha Addresses 数字字母地址的阻力**
-------------------------------------------------------

For some reason, numeric-alpha addresses never took off within the land of digital Zettelkasten. Why? Probably because it was perceived as unnecessary.[432](#footnote-423) 出于某种原因，数字字母地址从未在数字 Zettelkasten 的土地上起飞。为什么？可能是因为它被认为是不必要的。 432

I’ve brought up Johannes Schmidt’s statement that numeric-alpha addresses serve as an essential prerequisite for creativity in Luhmann’s system.[433](#footnote-422) Yet I’m met with resistance to this assertion. Some object that my reasoning is “an appeal to authority and not a proper argument.”[434](#footnote-421) This objection is puzzling because the entire premise of using a Zettelkasten in the first place comes from an appeal to authority.[435](#footnote-420) Regardless, there’s not much that can be accomplished through theoretical debate on this front. In reality, one must investigate the power of numeric-alpha addresses for oneself. This is only achieved through experimenting with the system and experiencing it first-hand. 我提出了约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 的说法，即数字字母地址是卢曼系统中创造力的必要先决条件。 433 然而，我遇到了对这种说法的抵制。有人反对我的推理是 “对权威的诉求，而不是适当的论证。”434 这种反对意见令人费解，因为首先使用 Zettelkasten 的整个前提来自对权威的诉求。 435 无论如何，没有多少可以通过这方面的理论辩论来完成。实际上，必须亲自研究数字字母地址的功能。这只能通过对系统进行试验并亲身体验来实现。

With that said, I’d like to caution against the common convention used in digital Zettelkasten systems today: human-readable note titles. For instance, in writing a note on the definition of self-reference, many digital Zettelkasten practitioners would name the note or filename Definition of Self-reference, or Self-reference (Definition), or some other scheme. However, in an Antinet, the note would receive a numeric-alpha address like 4214/1A/0. 话虽如此，我想提醒大家注意当今数字 Zettelkasten 系统中使用的通用约定：人类可读的注释标题。例如，在写关于自引用定义的注释时，许多数字 Zettelkasten 从业者会将注释或文件名命名为自引用定义或自引用（定义）或其他一些方案。然而，在 Antinet 中，便条会收到一个数字字母地址，如 4214/1A/0。

Here’s why this is important: 这就是为什么这很重要：

A numeric-alpha card address instantiates a thought. A thought is an incommunicable event that takes place in the mind. You can do your best to represent a thought by communicating it as clearly as possible; however, you cannot “losslessly” export that thought and perfectly install it in the mind of the receiver. 数字字母卡地址实例化了一个想法。思想是发生在头脑中的不可传达的事件。您可以通过尽可能清楚地传达思想来尽力表达思想；但是，您不能 “无损地” 导出该想法并将其完美地安装在接收者的脑海中。

As such, a thought is encompassed by many things, including words, images, and other elements of reality. Giving it a numeric-alpha address is a way of treating it properly. When you try to encapsulate the entire thought in a human-readable note title, you’re watering it down into a mere artificial phrase. The artificial phrase can never encapsulate the true nature of the thought (which includes the associations that also arise when thinking of it). This is why giving the thought a numeric-alpha address is preferred. 因此，思想被许多事物所包围，包括文字、图像和现实的其他元素。给它一个数字字母地址是正确对待它的一种方式。当你试图将整个想法封装在一个人类可读的笔记标题中时，你就是在把它淡化成一个纯粹的人工短语。人为的短语永远无法概括思想的真实本质（包括在思考时也会出现的联想）。这就是为什么给思想一个数字字母地址是首选。

The thought is the thought. It is not, and should not, be watered down by artificial phrases (aka, a note title). 念头就是念头。它不是，也不应该被人为的短语（又名笔记标题）淡化。

In human memory, a thought is a collection of many things; and it’s melded together with links. A thought does not come packed with a pretty human-readable title name, and neither should be the product of your thought, in written form. 在人的记忆中，一个念头是许多事物的集合；它与链接融合在一起。一个想法不会带有一个漂亮的人类可读的标题名称，也不应该是你的想法的书面形式的产物。

**Numeric-Alpha Addresses Enable Links 数字字母地址启用链接**
---------------------------------------------------

“Possibility of linking (Verweisungsmöglichkeiten). Since all notes have fixed numbers, you can add as many references to them as you may want.”“链接的可能性 (Verweisungsmöglichkeiten)。由于所有笔记都有固定编号，因此您可以根据需要添加任意数量的参考。”

– Niklas Luhmann, Communication with Noteboxes[436](#footnote-419)– Niklas Luhmann，与 Noteboxes436 的交流

The numeric-alpha addresses make it possible to do another critical thing: linking. 数字字母地址可以做另一件重要的事情：链接。

**The Two Classes of Links 两类链接**

There are two classes of links in an Antinet:Antinet 中有两类链接：

1. Internal Links1. 内部链接

2. External Links2. 外部链接

You can think of it like this: internal links refer to links within your own mind (i.e., within the Antinet). External links refer to links to another’s mind (i.e., external to your Antinet). 你可以这样想：内链是指你自己脑子里（即 Antinet 里）的链接。外部链接是指指向他人思想的链接（即，在您的 Antinet 外部）。

**I. Internal Links 一、内部链接**

An internal link is a link to an area or card in your Antinet. There are several types of internal links: 内部链接是指向 Antinet 中的区域或卡片的链接。有几种类型的内部链接：

**1. Maincard Links (aka, “Cardlinks”)1. Maincard 链接（又名 “Cardlinks”）**

The majority of internal links in your Antinet are maincard links (aka, cardlinks). These are links to cards in the main box of your Antinet. Such links look like 5425/2a, 1337/1b, etc. Antinet 中的大部分内部链接都是主卡链接（也称为卡片链接）。这些是指向 Antinet 主框中卡片的链接。此类链接看起来像 5425/2a、1337/1b 等。

There are several types of cardlinks: (1) Stemlinks, (2) Branchlinks, and (3) Remotelinks. We’ll briefly cover these now. 有几种类型的卡片链接：(1) Stemlinks，(2) Branchlinks，和 (3) Remotelinks。我们现在将简要介绍这些。

i. stemlinks 我。词干链接

Stemlinks are links that are relative to the current stem of thought that you’re on. For instance, say the current card you’re on is 4214/2e/3a. If you see a link on the card that simply reads /1, this tells you the link is to card 4214/2e/3a/1. The /1 is a stemlink. Stemlinks 是与你当前的想法相关的链接。例如，假设您当前使用的网卡是 4214/2e/3a。如果您在卡上看到一个简单地显示为 /1 的链接，则表明该链接指向卡 4214/2e/3a/1。 /1 是词干链接。

Stemlinks are similar to the concept relative links within the world of web development. Luhmann employed this concept in his own Antinet, which Johannes Schmidt refers as “single references.”[437](#footnote-418)Stemlinks 类似于网络开发世界中的概念相关链接。 Luhmann 在他自己的 Antinet 中采用了这个概念，Johannes Schmidt 称之为 “单一引用”。 437

For instance, on the card 17.1b9, you’ll see the red numbers 1 and 2. 例如，在卡片 17.1b9 上，您会看到红色数字 1 和 2。

photo credit: “ZK I: Zettel 17,1b9—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed July 15, 2021, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-1b9_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-1b9_V). 照片来源：“ZK I：Zettel 17,1b9—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2021 年 7 月 15 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17-1b9_V。

The red 1 and 2 are stemlinks. They are links to the cards 17.1b9.1 and 17.1b9.2. 红色的 1 和 2 是词干链接。它们是卡 17.1b9.1 和 17.1b9.2 的链接。

This is helpful when you’re writing in a stream of consciousness manner. It sends a signal in the form of a reminder that you intend to elaborate on certain sentences by giving them a dedicated card in the following stem of thought. 当您以意识流的方式写作时，这会很有帮助。它以提醒的形式发送信号，表明您打算通过在以下思路中给它们一张专用卡片来详细说明某些句子。

ii. branchlinks 二. 分支链接

Branchlinks are a concept I started using for the sake of saving space. For instance, say I’m writing a note on the card 5218/2a. If I want to link to another card, say 5218/1/1a/2b/1, instead of writing out the 5218, I’ll use the tilde character (~). In computing, the tilde character typically refers to the current user’s home directory. Within the world of the Antinet, it refers to the current card’s branch. Therefore, instead of writing 5218/1/1a/2b/1, I write ~/1/1a/2b/1, which is a link within the current branch I’m in (5218). The ~/1/1a/2b/1 is a branchlink, which is shorthand for 5218/1/1a/2b/1. 分支链接是我为了节省空间而开始使用的概念。例如，假设我正在卡片 5218/2a 上写笔记。如果我想链接到另一张卡，比如 5218/1/1a/2b/1，我不会写出 5218，而是使用波浪字符 (~)。在计算中，波浪字符通常指当前用户的主目录。在 Antinet 世界中，指的是当前卡牌的分支。因此，我没有写 5218/1/1a/2b/1，而是写了 ~/1/1a/2b/1，这是我所在的当前分支 (5218) 中的一个链接。 ~/1/1a/2b/1 是一个分支链接，它是 5218/1/1a/2b/1 的简写。

iii. remotelinks 三. 远程链接

Say you’re writing a note within the card 4214/5a/2 and you create a link to the card 1334/2a/4. What you have just created is a remotelink. You’re linking to a card in a remote area in your tree of knowledge. Remotelinks are essentially the full card address of another card that resides in a relatively remote part of your Antinet. 假设您在卡片 4214/5a/2 中写了一条笔记，并创建了一个指向卡片 1334/2a/4 的链接。您刚刚创建的是一个远程链接。您正在链接到知识树中偏远地区的一张卡片。远程链接本质上是位于 Antinet 相对远程部分的另一张卡的完整卡地址。

Think of remotelinks kind of like vines on a tree. A vine will take you from one branch of a tree, to a more remote branch of the tree. 把远程链接想象成树上的藤蔓。藤蔓会将您从树的一个分支带到树的更远的分支。

**the science of maincard links 主卡链接的科学**

Given that Luhmann was deliberate in the design of the Antinet’s structure, we can begin to see the brilliance in how it mirrors the way human memory works.[438](#footnote-417) In the field of memory science, stemlinks are what are called forward and backward associations.[439](#footnote-416) The branchlinks are items located nearby, and in one’s general neighborhood. Yet, like human memory, the further away and the more items there are in between each memory, the association decreases.[440](#footnote-415) Remotelinks mimic “remote associations” as understood in the study of human memory.[441](#footnote-414) Again, the further away the memories are from one another, the further their association is (unless they’re connected via remotelinks). 鉴于 Luhmann 在 Antinet 结构的设计中有意为之，我们可以开始看到它在反映人类记忆工作方式方面的卓越之处。 438 在记忆科学领域，词干链接就是所谓的前向和后向关联。 439 branchlinks 是位于附近的项目，并且在一个人的一般社区中。然而，就像人类记忆一样，距离越远，每个记忆之间的项目越多，关联就会减少。440 远程链接模仿人类记忆研究中所理解的 “远程关联”。441 同样，记忆距离越远彼此之间，他们的联系越远（除非他们通过远程链接连接）。

**when in doubt, use full cardlinks 如有疑问，请使用完整的卡片链接**

Both stemlinks and branchlinks are shorthand and can save time. When in doubt, the safest bet is to write the full card address. Regardless, it’s nice to have stemlinks and branchlinks at your disposal when creating notes.stemlinks 和 branchlinks 都是速记，可以节省时间。如有疑问，最安全的做法是写下完整的卡地址。无论如何，在创建笔记时可以使用主干链接和分支链接是件好事。

**2. Keyterm Links2. 关键词链接**

Keyterm links are links that point you to a keyterm in the index box. For instance, on some of my notes I’ll have a keyterm written and underlined in green or blue ink. This tells me to refer to the index and look up that term. 关键字链接是指向索引框中关键字的链接。例如，在我的一些笔记上，我会用绿色或蓝色墨水写下一个关键词并加下划线。这告诉我参考索引并查找该术语。

For instance, here’s a collective of links for the section I’m writing about right now (on the concept of links). 例如，这是我现在正在写的部分的一组链接（关于链接的概念）。

You’ll see the following keyterm links in green: Association, Links, and Relate (Relations). This tells me to go look up those keyterms in the index. When I look them up, I can then build out more content for this section from those keyterm cards. 您会看到以下绿色的关键字链接：Association、Links 和 Relate（关系）。这告诉我去索引中查找那些关键字。当我查找它们时，我可以从这些关键字卡片中为这部分构建更多内容。

For instance, here’s the keyterm for Association found in my index box: 例如，这是在我的索引框中找到的 Association 的关键词：

From here, I can then add any sections related to this section on Links as I see fit. 从这里，我可以根据需要在链接上添加与此部分相关的任何部分。

**II. External Links (aka, ExRefs) 二。外部链接（又名 ExRefs）**

External links (aka, ExRefs) are external references to an outside source of knowledge (like a book, YouTube video, podcast, etc.). Also included in the external link is the page number (or timestamp) from the source. 外部链接（又名 ExRefs）是对外部知识来源（如书籍、YouTube 视频、播客等）的外部引用。外部链接中还包括来源的页码（或时间戳）。

My ExRefs are always written in red pen, and they resemble that of a footnote. There are two formats of an ExRef. They either begin with a b. or an r.. We’ll cover both types of ExRefs now. 我的 ExRef 总是用红笔写的，它们类似于脚注。 ExRef 有两种格式。它们要么以 b 开头。或 r.. 我们现在将介绍这两种类型的 ExRef。

**1. Bibliography Box ExRefs1. 参考书目框 ExRefs**

The Antinet’s bibliography box is an analog reference manager. It enables one to organize and manage their bibliography references using “bibcards.” More on bibcards will be covered later. Basically, they’re cards that contain the details of the book you engage with (or podcast, video, website, etc.).Antinet 的书目框是一个模拟参考管理器。它使人们能够使用 “bibcards” 来组织和管理他们的参考书目。稍后将介绍更多关于 bibcard 的内容。基本上，它们是包含您参与的书籍（或播客、视频、网站等）详细信息的卡片。

The first type of ExRef begins with a lowercase-b, followed by a period (b.). Here’s an example from the card 4214/4/1bd/1. 第一种 ExRef 以小写字母 b 开头，后跟句点 (b.)。这是卡片 4214/4/1bd/1 中的示例。

Note the red 1 on the card resembling a footnote. This points to the item circled in red: b.NakladovaJohann, 199. This is an ExRef. It signals that the idea originated from the bibcard, b.NakladovaJohann, and from the page number 199. Think of the b.NakladovaJohann kind of like a tag (in digital speak). It’s a short phrase that enables one to quickly navigate to the reference in the bib box. If we look up b.NakladovaJohann in the bib box, we find the full details of this reference: 请注意卡片上的红色 1，类似于脚注。这指向用红色圈出的项目：b.NakladovaJohann, 199。这是一个 ExRef。它表明这个想法源自 bibcard、b.NakladovaJohann 和第 199 页。将 b.NakladovaJohann 想象成一个标签（在数字语言中）。这是一个简短的短语，可以让人们快速导航到围兜箱中的参考文献。如果我们在围兜框中查找 b.NakladovaJohann，我们会找到此参考资料的完整详细信息：

In brief, this tells us that the idea on the card 4214/4/1BD/1 originated from page 199 in the chapter, “Johann Amos Comenius: Early Modern Metaphysics of Knowledge and Ars Excerpendi,” by Iveta Nakládalová, which is found in the book titled, Forgetting Machines. 简而言之，这告诉我们卡片 4214/4/1BD/1 上的想法源自 Iveta Nakládalová 所著的 “Johann Amos Comenius：知识的早期现代形而上学和 Ars Excerpendi” 一章的第 199 页，可在这本书名为《遗忘机器》。

**2. Digital Reference Manager ExRefs2. 数字参考管理器 ExRefs**

When people talk about a reference manager, they really mean a digital reference manager. This is a digital tool for storing bibliographic references. These encompass books, articles, papers, videos, podcasts, or other media. 当人们谈论参考资料管理器时，他们真正指的是数字参考资料管理器。这是一个用于存储书目参考的数字工具。这些包括书籍、文章、论文、视频、播客或其他媒体。

While I am a major proponent of using the analog medium as a thinking system, I am not a luddite. There are clear advantages in using a digital reference manager, as well. First, digital reference managers allow you to store local copies of web pages. This ensures that you’ll have the source even if the web page is later deleted. And second, digital reference managers are convenient in that they automatically format references in whatever style guide you use (AP Style, Chicago Style, MLA Style, etc.). 虽然我是使用模拟媒体作为思维系统的主要支持者，但我并不是勒德分子。使用数字参考管理器也有明显的优势。首先，数字参考管理器允许您存储网页的本地副本。这样可以确保即使网页后来被删除，您也能获得源代码。其次，数字参考管理器很方便，因为它们会自动按照您使用的任何风格指南（AP 风格、芝加哥风格、MLA 风格等）格式化参考。

There are a number of digital apps to choose from when it comes to a reference manager. I’ve tried a handful of them, yet the one I always go back to is called Zotero.[442](#footnote-413) It’s simple, it’s free and it has all the features you’ll need. 关于参考资料管理器，有许多数字应用程序可供选择。我已经尝试了其中的一些，但我经常回去的那个叫做 Zotero。442 它很简单，它是免费的，并且具有您需要的所有功能。

There are cases in which I’ll read a web page that is brief enough that it’s unnecessary to create a dedicated hand-written bibcard for it. Yet, at the same time, there will be ideas in it that I’ll want to reference in a maincard. In such instances, I first add the article to Zotero using a one-click browser extension. Then, I create a tag for the referenced article that begins with a lowercase-r, followed by a period (r.). Unlike the b., the r. tells me the item is stored in my digital reference manager. 在某些情况下，我会阅读一个足够简短的网页，因此没有必要为其创建专门的手写 bibcard。然而，与此同时，其中会有我想在主卡中引用的想法。在这种情况下，我首先使用一键式浏览器扩展将文章添加到 Zotero。然后，我为引用的文章创建一个标签，该标签以小写字母 r 开头，后跟句点 (r.)。与 b. 不同，r. 告诉我该项目存储在我的数字参考管理器中。

Here’s an example of a digital reference manager ExRef from my own Antinet: 这是来自我自己的 Antinet 的数字参考管理器 ExRef 的示例：

The r.Zetteldan.1 tells me to look this tag up in Zotero. When I do this, I’m pointed to a blog post about the Zettelkasten written by a software developer named Daniel Lüdecke.[443](#footnote-412) The r.Zetteldan.1 is an ExRef stored in Zotero. Such ExRefs are quite useful. Digital reference manager ExRefs are yet another tool you have at your disposal.r.Zetteldan.1 告诉我在 Zotero 中查找此标签。当我这样做时，我被指向了一篇关于 Zettelkasten 的博客文章，作者是一位名叫 Daniel Lüdecke 的软件开发人员。443 r.Zetteldan.1 是存储在 Zotero 中的 ExRef。这样的 ExRef 非常有用。数字参考管理器 ExRefs 是您可以使用的另一种工具。

Now that you know the fundamentals of links in the Antinet, let’s jump back into the land of theory. We’ll cap this chapter off by discussing the real-life memory science of links. 现在您已经了解了 Antinet 中链接的基础知识，让我们回到理论领域。我们将通过讨论现实生活中的链接记忆科学来结束本章。

The Science and Importance of Links 链接的科学性和重要性

“Each note is only an element that derives its quality from the web of references and cross references within the system. A note that is not linked to this web becomes lost in the file; the file forgets it.”“每个音符只是一个元素，它的质量来自系统内的参考和交叉参考网络。未链接到该网站的笔记会丢失在文件中；文件忘了它。”

—Niklas Luhmann[444](#footnote-411)——尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 444

“As discussed by philosophers since ancient times, our memories appear to be organized in terms of associative structures formed between items that are contiguous in space and time. Two items are said to be associated if presentation of one leads to thinking of (or responding with) the other.”“正如自古以来哲学家所讨论的那样，我们的记忆似乎是根据在空间和时间上相邻的项目之间形成的关联结构来组织的。如果一个项目的呈现导致对另一个项目的思考（或回应），则称这两个项目是相关的。”

—Michael J. Kahana, Foundations of Human Memory[445](#footnote-410)—Michael J. Kahana，《人类记忆基础》445

In memory-science terminology, links are associations. When trying to think of a memory, you’re undergoing something called the process of retrieval. The most widely accepted theories of how retrieval works revolve around association.[446](#footnote-409) 在记忆科学术语中，链接是关联。当试图回想一段记忆时，您正在经历一种称为检索过程的过程。最广泛接受的关于检索如何工作的理论围绕着联想。 446

Association is the raw material powering two things: (1) biological learning, and (2) artificial learning (specifically, deep learning).[447](#footnote-408) 联想是推动两件事的原材料：(1) 生物学习，和 (2) 人工学习（特别是深度学习）。 447

The manner in which associations are built within digital notetaking apps look nice and pretty. They create nifty-looking graphs and visualizations. However, such tools are not structured in a way to optimize learning. Antinets, on the other hand, are built entirely around association. You cannot install a note in the Antinet without associating it with the neighboring notes. As a result a chain-reaction takes place in the system. All notes are essentially chain-linked to every other note in the system. This is the concept of associative chaining, which I detail later in this book. 在数字笔记应用程序中建立关联的方式看起来非常漂亮。他们创建漂亮的图表和可视化。但是，此类工具的结构并未优化学习。另一方面，Antinets 完全围绕关联构建。您不能在 Antinet 中安装一个音符而不将它与相邻的音符相关联。结果，系统中发生了连锁反应。所有笔记基本上都链接到系统中的每个其他笔记。这就是关联链的概念，我将在本书后面详细介绍。

It seems like a rather fringe area of focus, yet the study of how association occurs in the brain ended up revolutionizing the world. This field of study sparked the discovery of neural networks in the 1970s.[448](#footnote-407) Artificial neural networks sit at the heart of deep learning, which is a subfield of machine learning.[449](#footnote-406) If you use Facebook, Instagram, Pinterest, Google, Amazon, Netflix—and really almost any large-scale consumer internet product—there’s a high probability you’re interacting with an artificial neural network.[450](#footnote-405) Even if you’re in a car, there’s a chance you’re interacting with a neural network.[451](#footnote-404) All of these technologies are powered by the science that emerged from the question of how linking works in the human brain. This is why I’m bothering to spend time emphasizing the power and importance of links and associations! 这似乎是一个相当边缘的关注领域，但对大脑中联想如何发生的研究最终彻底改变了世界。这一研究领域在 1970 年代引发了神经网络的发现。448 人工神经网络是深度学习的核心，深度学习是机器学习的一个子领域。449 如果您使用 Facebook、Instagram、Pinterest、Google、Amazon、Netflix——以及几乎所有大型消费互联网产品——您很可能正在与人工神经网络进行交互。450 即使您在车里，也有可能与神经网络进行交互。451 所有这些这些技术的动力来自于人类大脑中连接如何工作的问题所产生的科学。这就是为什么我费心花时间强调链接和关联的力量和重要性！

To recap, the raw material of deep learning is a neural network, and the raw material of neural networks are the thing the Antinet is built on: associations. 回顾一下，深度学习的原材料是神经网络，而神经网络的原材料是 Antinet 的基础：关联。

If you’re aiming to build a knowledge development system that increases learning and unconventional insights, then it’s important to understand how associations work (and how they’re structured within the Antinet). The human memory operates with concepts analogous to the types of associations in the Antinet (stemlinks, branchlinks, and remotelinks). Digital notetaking apps are not structured in such a way. The digital notetaking preachers seem to treat such a structure as a matter of personal preference which, I hold, is a grave mistake.[452](#footnote-403) 如果你的目标是建立一个知识发展系统，以增加学习和非常规洞察力，那么了解协会如何运作（以及它们在 Antinet 中的结构）是很重要的。人类记忆使用类似于 Antinet 中的关联类型（主干链接、分支链接和远程链接）的概念进行操作。数字笔记应用程序不是以这种方式构建的。数字笔记传教士似乎将这种结构视为个人喜好问题，我认为这是一个严重的错误。 452

Even though digital notetaking preachers get a lot of things wrong, they do get some things correct. One author gets it correct by emphasizing the importance of association in an abstracted information network, yet he still under-represents the depth of its importance.[453](#footnote-402) 尽管数字笔记传教士犯了很多错误，但他们确实做对了一些事情。一位作者通过强调关联在抽象信息网络中的重要性得到了正确的理解，但他仍然低估了其重要性的深度。 453

You see, associations in a neural network are not opt-in. They’re not just a clever strategy. They’re not some hip, new workflow method. They’re not a best-practice one ought to follow for good knowledge work. Associations are not optional in an Antinet, they are a requirement. Like a neural network, associations are a requirement in an Antinet. Before you can install anything into your Antinet, it must be associated with, and installed near, its most related note. 你看，神经网络中的关联不是选择加入的。它们不仅仅是一个聪明的策略。它们不是一些时髦的新工作流程方法。它们不是进行良好知识工作应遵循的最佳实践。关联在 Antinet 中不是可选的，它们是必需的。与神经网络一样，关联是 Antinet 中的必要条件。在您可以将任何东西安装到您的 Antinet 之前，它必须与其最相关的注释相关联并安装在其附近。

The association composition in an Antinet is not one of mere opinion. It ought to mirror the two properties related to how long-term storage in human memory works. The Antinet stores associations among items, and it stores associations between items and context.Antinet 中的协会组成不仅仅是一种意见。它应该反映与人类记忆中的长期存储如何工作相关的两个属性。 Antinet 存储项目之间的关联，它存储项目和上下文之间的关联。

The Antinet’s tree structure, with proximity-based associations as well as context-based associations (in terms of stems and branches), serves as a perfect model for how human memory works. It’s the model the Antinet is built on.Antinet 的树结构，具有基于接近度的关联以及基于上下文的关联（在茎和分支方面），是人类记忆如何工作的完美模型。这是构建 Antinet 的模型。

The concept the Antinet forces is that of working out your neuro-associative recall “muscle.” It does this by forcing you to think and associate. It requires that you compare information you happen upon in your reading with the knowledge stored in the long-term location within your second mind (your Antinet). Only after this exercise of comparison can you actually install information in your Antinet. Again, this process is not some best-practice principle by which one might manually integrates information (such as in a digital Zettelkasten workflow). Rather, it’s built into the core foundation of the analog system. Every time you develop new knowledge, the Antinet forces a process that models how the human brain works. To tie the Antinet in with physiological neural networks one last time, we can point to the process of comparing new and old information, which is impaired with some patients suffering anterograde amnesia.[454](#footnote-401) Basically those with impaired neuro-associative recall ability are able to create new maincard notes. However, they do not possess the ability to install those new notes. They do not have the ability to exercise neuro-associative recall and delineate where each new idea they encounter should be stored. Basically, they have no index box which enables them to navigate their tree of knowledge.Antinet 力的概念是锻炼你的神经联想回忆 “肌肉”。它通过强迫你思考和联想来做到这一点。它要求你将你在阅读中偶然发现的信息与存储在你的第二头脑（你的 Antinet）中的长期位置的知识进行比较。只有经过这种比较练习，您才能真正在 Antinet 中安装信息。同样，这个过程不是一些最佳实践原则，人们可以根据最佳实践原则手动集成信息（例如在数字 Zettelkasten 工作流程中）。相反，它内置于模拟系统的核心基础中。每次你开发新知识时，Antinet 都会强制执行一个模拟人脑工作方式的过程。最后一次将 Antinet 与生理神经网络联系起来，我们可以指出比较新旧信息的过程，这在一些顺行性遗忘症患者中受损。454 基本上那些神经联想回忆能力受损的人能够创造新的主卡笔记。但是，他们不具备安装这些新笔记的能力。他们没有能力进行神经联想回忆，也没有能力描述他们遇到的每个新想法应该存储在哪里。基本上，他们没有使他们能够浏览知识树的索引框。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

We’ve covered quite a bit in this chapter. We’ve surveyed the history of numeric-alpha addresses. We’ve also explored the science and fundamental components of such. Numeric-alpha addresses unlock a critical aspect of the Antinet: links. We’ve gone into detail on the different types of links, as well as the memory science behind links. 我们在本章中介绍了很多内容。我们调查了数字字母地址的历史。我们还探索了此类的科学和基本组成部分。数字字母地址解锁了 Antinet 的一个关键方面：链接。我们已经详细介绍了不同类型的链接，以及链接背后的记忆科学。

At this point you’re beginning to understand the depth of the Antinet. This isn’t some trivial notebox system. It’s much greater than that. In the next chapter, we’ll dive deeper into the depths of the Antinet. We’ll cover another critical component which makes the Antinet the ultimate system for developing knowledge: its tree structure. 此时你开始了解 Antinet 的深度。这不是一些微不足道的记事本系统。它远不止于此。在下一章中，我们将深入了解 Antinet。我们将介绍另一个使 Antinet 成为开发知识的终极系统的关键组件：它的树结构。

CHAPTER EIGHT 第八章
-----------------

Tree 树
------

“[The Antinet has] the possibility of arbitrary internal branching. We do not need to add notes at the end, but we can connect them anywhere—even to a particular word in the middle of a continuous text.”“[Antinet 具有] 任意内部分支的可能性。我们不需要在末尾添加注释，但我们可以将它们连接到任何地方——甚至是连续文本中间的特定单词。”

–Niklas Luhmann, Communication with Noteboxes[455](#footnote-524)–Niklas Luhmann，与 Noteboxes455 的交流

In this section i detail the structure of the Antinet. In brief, I hold that the best representation of the Antinet’s structure is a tree. The idea of using a tree as a metaphor of Antinet-like knowledge systems is not new. In fact, it’s a rather ancient idea. Early modern scholars referred to their Antinet systems as sylva, which in Latin means “forest.” It was described in this manner due to an Antinet’s characteristic of “arranged chaos.”[456](#footnote-523) 在本节中，我将详细介绍 Antinet 的结构。简而言之，我认为 Antinet 结构的最佳表示是一棵树。用树来比喻 Antinet-like 知识系统的想法并不新鲜。事实上，这是一个相当古老的想法。早期现代学者将他们的 Antinet 系统称为 sylva，在拉丁语中意为 “森林”。由于 Antinet 具有“安排的混乱” 的特征，因此以这种方式进行描述。 456

I contend that the very best systems possess tree-like structures. For instance, Github is built on a tree-like structure called Git. When Github arrived to the version-control arena (i.e., the arena of managing different software versions), Git quickly blew away the other systems. The other systems were rife with horrid version conflicts and syncing issues. 我认为最好的系统都具有树状结构。例如，Github 是建立在称为 Git 的树状结构之上的。当 Github 进入版本控制领域（即管理不同软件版本的领域）时，Git 迅速击败了其他系统。其他系统充斥着可怕的版本冲突和同步问题。

The tree structure of the Antinet creates many of the system’s irreplaceable benefits. Benefits include increasing the likelihood of breakthrough insights by way of surprise, and many more benefits.Antinet 的树形结构创造了系统的许多不可替代的好处。好处包括通过惊喜增加突破性见解的可能性，以及更多好处。

In addition, there’s a metaphysical power to the idea of tree-like structures. Not only do tree structures have applications of the practical sort, trees serve as a very powerful symbol. Indeed, trees stand as the central motif for some of humankind’s most moving belief systems. All of these items, and more, will be explored in detail in this chapter. 此外，树状结构的想法具有形而上学的力量。树结构不仅有实用的应用，树还是一个非常强大的符号。事实上，树木是人类一些最感人的信仰体系的中心主题。本章将详细探讨所有这些项目以及更多内容。

**Types of Knowledge Structures 知识结构的类型**
-----------------------------------------

Before we dive into the structure of the Antinet, let’s survey a few types of knowledge structures. 在我们深入了解 Antinet 的结构之前，让我们先调查一下几种类型的知识结构。

**The “Rigid” Structure“刚性” 结构**

The so-called “rigid” knowledge structure is reflected in systems that are organized by hierarchical taxonomy. This type of structure can be represented in folders and sub-folders in a computer file system. 所谓 “僵化” 的知识结构体现在按等级分类法组织的系统中。这种类型的结构可以在计算机文件系统中的文件夹和子文件夹中表示。

The basic structure looks like this: 基本结构如下所示：

Examples of systems that use this structure include (1) the Dewey Decimal Classification System, (2) the Library of Congress Classification System, and (3) notebox systems organized by topic or category. 使用此结构的系统示例包括 (1) 杜威十进制分类系统，(2) 美国国会图书馆分类系统，以及 (3) 按主题或类别组织的笔记本系统。

It’s become commonplace for personal knowledge management (“PKM”) experts to advise against these rigid structures.[457](#footnote-522) However, it is unfair to write off such structures completely. They’re useful in that they keep things simple and easy to understand. Still, rigid structures lack the features that make the Antinet great: linking thoughts, developing thoughts, and creating a unique personality out of your system that evolves over time. 个人知识管理 (“PKM”) 专家反对这些僵化的结构已成为司空见惯的事。 457 然而，完全取消此类结构是不公平的。它们很有用，因为它们使事情变得简单易懂。尽管如此，僵化的结构缺乏使 Antinet 变得伟大的特征：连接思想、发展思想以及从你的系统中创造出随着时间的推移而演变的独特个性。

**The “Fluid” Structure“流体” 结构**

When rigid structures are introduced by PKM experts, they’re implied as being “bad.” The “good” structure is then introduced: so-called fluid structures. 当 PKM 专家介绍刚性结构时，它们被暗示为 “坏的”。然后引入“好” 结构：所谓的流体结构。

Fluid structures are types of systems built with tags, keyword search, and wikilinks. These structures allow users to create linked bubble graphs that give the illusion of viewing your mind. 流体结构是使用标签、关键字搜索和维基链接构建的系统类型。这些结构允许用户创建链接的气泡图，给人一种看到你的想法的错觉。

For instance, a graph like this: 例如，像这样的图形：

photo credit: Sbae2020, English: Knowledge Graph for Evans-Tibbs Artists, August 2021, August 2021, Own work, [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File):KnowledgeGraph02.png. 照片来源：Sbae2020，英语：Evans-Tibbs 艺术家的知识图谱，2021 年 8 月，2021 年 8 月，自己的作品，https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:KnowledgeGraph02.png。

However, these structures are a mere illusion. They’re pretty to look at; however they are not the best structure for developing and evolving thought. 然而，这些结构仅仅是一种幻觉。它们看起来很漂亮；然而，它们并不是发展和进化思想的最佳结构。

Rather than being a useful representation of your brain, think of such structures as a pile of leaves on the ground with vines that connect them. 与其将其作为大脑的有用表示，不如将这些结构想象成地上的一堆树叶和连接它们的藤蔓。

Digital Zettelkasten systems look much like this structure. You’re left with either a blob of loosely connected spoke-wheel bubbles, or a needlessly long document of notes. This is not the best way for your brain to process information. Nor is it the best way to create knowledge. It’s not representative of how human memory works, either. 数字 Zettelkasten 系统看起来很像这种结构。你留下的要么是一团松散连接的辐条轮气泡，要么是一份不必要的长笔记文档。这不是大脑处理信息的最佳方式。它也不是创造知识的最佳方式。它也不能代表人类记忆的工作方式。

Your memory, and more specifically, each individual memory, is akin to a tree. Yes, a tree. A tree wherein certain leaves, attached via vines, are lit up with a lightning bolt of activity (kind of like Christmas tree lights). 你的记忆，更具体地说，每一个单独的记忆，都类似于一棵树。是的，一棵树。一棵树，其中某些叶子通过藤蔓附着，被活动的闪电照亮（有点像圣诞树灯）。

In the science of human memory, this is known as distributed representation.[458](#footnote-521) The Antinet’s structure is built with distributed representation in its core. Digital Zettelkasten apps do not possess such a structure. They are based on surface-level wikilinks, not on a branched and chain-linked structures of associations (generated by numeric-alpha addresses). This is one of many reasons I hold the Antinet as a superior knowledge system compared to digital notetaking apps (with wikilink capabilities). 在人类记忆科学中，这被称为分布式表示。 458 Antinet 的结构以分布式表示为核心构建。 Digital Zettelkasten 应用程序不具备这样的结构。它们基于表面级别的维基链接，而不是基于分支和链式关联结构（由数字字母地址生成）。与数字笔记应用程序（具有 wikilink 功能）相比，这是我认为 Antinet 是一个更好的知识系统的众多原因之一。

With the Antinet, the structure is different. It’s not a pile of leaves. It’s a rough anti-fragile tree. 有了 Antinet，结构就不同了。这不是一堆树叶。这是一棵粗糙的抗脆弱树。

**The Rough Structure of the AntinetAntinet 的粗略结构**
---------------------------------------------------

The magic of the Antinet is not in how rigid or how fluid it is. The magic is in the roughness of the structure.Antinet 的魔力不在于它的刚性或流动性。神奇之处在于结构的粗糙度。

This seems to run counter to the ideology propped up by PKM practitioners and so-called “Note-taking experts.” Such people propose systems more analogous to what’s currently trendy. The sexy buzzwords of today are things like decentralization, openness, atomicity and dynamic systems. Naturally, every PKM expert seemingly integrates such terms into their gospel of notetaking. 这似乎与 PKM 从业者和所谓的 “笔记专家” 所支持的意识形态背道而驰。这些人提出的系统更类似于当前流行的系统。当今性感的流行语是去中心化、开放性、原子性和动态系统。自然地，每一位 PKM 专家似乎都将这些术语融入了他们的笔记福音中。

Yet Luhmann’s system does not reflect the popular buzzwords of today. It’s not a decentralized, open, atomic, dynamic system. 然而，卢曼的体系并没有反映当今流行的流行语。它不是一个分散的、开放的、原子的、动态的系统。

The Antinet is closer to being the exact opposite, in fact. 事实上，Antinet 更接近于完全相反。

It’s centralized—in that you, its creator, make all of the decisions. 它是中心化的——因为你，它的创造者，做出所有的决定。

It’s closed—in that it’s a cybernetic system wherein each card has its own numeric-alpha address; therefore, the cards containing numeric-alpha addresses are effectively closed inside the system. The system can expand and evolve, yet the expansion and branching happens internally. The roots, stems, and branches of the system grow deeper. 它是封闭的——因为它是一个控制论系统，其中每张卡片都有自己的数字字母地址；因此，包含数字字母地址的卡片在系统内部有效关闭。系统可以扩展和发展，但扩展和分支发生在内部。系统的根、茎、枝越来越深。

It’s molecular more than atomic. Each note can run onto the next note. The whole one idea per note notion is a myth propagated by Sönke Ahrens. The Antinet is made up of many chain-linked structures, and they do not subscribe to the idea of strict atomicity. 它的分子性大于原子性。每个音符都可以运行到下一个音符。每个音符一个想法的概念是 Sönke Ahrens 传播的神话。 Antinet 由许多链式结构组成，他们不认同严格的原子性思想。

It’s not a dynamic system. You can’t find-and-replace-all. You can’t updated and delete your thoughts freely on a whim. You can’t refactor your notes (and thereby procrastinate on actually doing work). The Antinet’s structure, including the notes within it, is more marcescent in nature than dynamic (which we’ll cover shortly). 它不是一个动态系统。你不能找到并替换所有。你不能随心所欲地更新和删除你的想法。你不能重构你的笔记（从而拖延实际工作）。 Antinet 的结构，包括其中的音符，在本质上比动态的（我们将在稍后介绍）更具侵略性。

**The Rough Tree Structure Gives the System Personality 粗糙的树结构赋予系统个性**

“Natural and diagrammatic representations of trees come in many varieties, each with its own charm, virtues, and uses. Some trees are broad and shallow, others are narrow and deep; some trees are balanced with fixed depth, others have varying branching factors and erratic depth.”“树木的自然和图表表现形式多种多样，每一种都有自己的魅力、优点和用途。有的树宽而浅，有的树窄而深；有些树是平衡的，深度固定，有些树有不同的分支因子和不稳定的深度。”

—Ben Shneiderman, The Book of Trees[459](#footnote-520)——本 · 施耐德曼，《树木之书》459

The reason it’s important that the Antinet possesses such rough properties is because it gives the system personality. As previously mentioned, the unique structure enables the system to transform into a second mind. It enables it to develop an alter ego, as Luhmann calls it.[460](#footnote-519)Antinet 具有如此粗糙的属性之所以重要，是因为它赋予了系统个性。如前所述，独特的结构使系统能够转变为第二思维。它使它能够发展出另一个自我，正如卢曼所说的那样。 460

The Antinet’s structure gives it a sense of uniqueness and distinction. It’s a system that cannot be freely reorganized and edited. You cannot rename every file on a whim based on whatever new convention you fall in love with. The digital notetaking apps suffer from this freedom. Unlike digital systems, the Antinet does not allow for refactoring of notes en masse. You cannot waste time dragging and dropping notes into different subfolders at a later date. You cannot dynamically update all of the links in files. You cannot retroactively integrate some new metadata or front-matter scheme that you delude yourself into believing will make you more productive.Antinet 的结构赋予它独特和与众不同的感觉。这是一个无法自由重组和编辑的系统。您不能根据自己喜欢的任何新约定一时兴起重命名每个文件。数字笔记应用程序受到这种自由的影响。与数字系统不同，Antinet 不允许对笔记进行整体重构。您不能在以后浪费时间将笔记拖放到不同的子文件夹中。您不能动态更新文件中的所有链接。您不能追溯性地集成一些您自欺欺人地相信会让您更有效率的新元数据或前端方案。

Rather, the Antinet forces you to do two things: first, to think, and second, to evolve thoughts. If you’re looking for a system that focuses on everything else, then digital notetaking apps serve as a better alternative. 相反，Antinet 迫使你做两件事：首先，思考，其次，发展思想。如果您正在寻找一个专注于其他一切的系统，那么数字笔记应用程序是一个更好的选择。

All of the things the Antinet cannot do are in fact the very elements which contribute to its most important function: to generate breakthrough creative insights.Antinet 无法做到的所有事情实际上正是促成其最重要功能的要素：产生突破性的创造性见解。

These creative insights are generated through the element of surprise, which the Antinet’s structure is uniquely positioned to provide. More on surprises and the surprise-generating functions of the Antinet will be discussed in a later chapter. 这些创造性的见解是通过惊喜元素产生的，Antinet 的结构具有独特的定位。更多关于惊喜和 Antinet 的惊喜生成功能将在后面的章节中讨论。

Suffice it to say, the rough structure of the Antinet forces—or actually, encourages—users to ask questions they otherwise would never ask. A digital system, with fully-indexed file searching, only enables the lazy act of searching for a keyterm the user is thinking of at that precise time. 可以这么说，Antinet 的粗略结构迫使——或者实际上，鼓励——用户提出他们在其他情况下永远不会提出的问题。具有全索引文件搜索功能的数字系统只能实现懒惰的行为，即搜索用户在那个准确时间想到的关键词。

With the Antinet, things aren’t that simple. 有了 Antinet，事情就没那么简单了。

The Antinet forces you to ask: What’s the name of the concept I’m thinking of? And if an answer is not forthcoming, then a process kicks into gear wherein you ask another set of questions: What is the concept I’m thinking of related to? Where else would it make sense for the concept to be? What other variant terms point to the concept? If that’s unsuccessful, you may then wish to create a new stem of thought for the concept. And because it was so hard to find the concept, you are then incentivized to create a keyterm in the index. That way, you’ll be able to find it more quickly in the future.Antinet 迫使你问：我正在考虑的概念的名称是什么？如果没有得到答案，那么一个过程就会开始，你会问另一组问题：我正在考虑的概念与什么相关？这个概念还有什么意义呢？还有哪些其他变体术语指向这个概念？如果不成功，您可能希望为该概念创建一个新的思路。因为很难找到这个概念，所以你会被激励在索引中创建一个关键词。这样，您以后就可以更快地找到它。

What about the original concept you were looking for that you never found? In my experience, any concept, if it’s important enough, always turns up one way or another. Your Antinet is less of a black hole than digital notetaking apps are. Whenever you do stumble across the concept again, you can then create a remotelink to it, thereby connecting the two disparate stems of thought. In turn this creates an even richer structure of knowledge. 您一直在寻找但从未找到的原始概念呢？根据我的经验，任何概念，如果它足够重要，总是以这样或那样的方式出现。与数字笔记应用程序相比，您的 Antinet 更像是一个黑洞。每当你再次偶然发现这个概念时，你就可以创建一个远程链接到它，从而将两个不同的思想联系起来。这反过来又创造了一个更丰富的知识结构。

This entire exercise results in several things taking place in the brain. First, you approach the concept in a fun way, using associative thinking, which actually improves mood.[461](#footnote-518) Second, during this process you stumble upon profound surprises you now recognize as connected. Last, you trigger internal dialogue. Your current mind, with its own active present memory and consciousness, communicates with your past self (your past mind) as revealed on the notecards. This process, like communication, results in surprises. 整个练习会导致大脑中发生几件事。首先，您以一种有趣的方式处理这个概念，使用联想思维，这实际上可以改善情绪。461 其次，在这个过程中，您偶然发现了深刻的惊喜，您现在认为这些惊喜是相互关联的。最后，你触发内部对话。你现在的头脑，带着它自己活跃的当下记忆和意识，与你过去的自我（你过去的头脑）交流，正如记事卡上所揭示的那样。这个过程，就像交流一样，会带来惊喜。

If nothing else, the core process of the Antinet centers on this communication process that allows the Antinet to become a “surprise generator,” as Johannes Schmidt refers to it.[462](#footnote-517) 如果不出意外，Antinet 的核心过程就是让 Antinet 成为 “惊喜发生器” 的通信过程，正如 Johannes Schmidt 所说的那样。 462

**Order vs. Chaos 秩序与混乱**

A critical thing to keep in mind is that pure order is undesirable (as is pure chaos). While the Dewey Decimal Classification System makes sense in theory, it and other such rigid systems also stand problematic. How so? They do not accurately reflect reality. The categories of such systems are static; they do not evolve, morph, or grow. 要牢记的一件重要事情是，纯粹的秩序是不可取的（纯粹的混乱也是如此）。虽然杜威十进分类法在理论上是有道理的，但它和其他此类僵化的分类法也存在问题。为何如此？它们不能准确反映现实。这种系统的类别是静态的；它们不会进化、变形或成长。

Luhmann’s system started with rough categories and then evolved from there. 卢曼的系统从粗略的范畴开始，然后从那里演变而来。

The reason I do not refer to the Antinet as a rigid structure is because the Antinet is more organic in nature. Johannes Schmidt, who is most familiar with Luhmann’s system, also refers to it as “a rough structure.”[463](#footnote-516) Like nature, the Antinet is rough. It’s antifragile, as Nassim Nicholas Taleb would say.[464](#footnote-515) It gets stronger with randomness, volatility and disorder. It follows certain laws and adheres to certain conventions. It’s also a structure subjected to complete accidents, random chance, and surprise. The system, in brief, mirrors reality. It mirrors both order and chaos. 我之所以不将 Antinet 称为刚性结构，是因为 Antinet 在本质上更具有机性。最熟悉卢曼系统的约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 也将其称为 “粗糙结构”。463 与自然界一样，Antinet 也是粗糙的。正如纳西姆 · 尼古拉斯 · 塔勒布 (Nassim Nicholas Taleb) 所说，它是反脆弱的。 464 它随着随机性、波动性和无序性而变得更强大。它遵循某些法律并遵守某些约定。它也是一个遭受完全意外、随机机会和惊喜的结构。简而言之，该系统反映了现实。它反映了秩序和混乱。

Early on in life, Niklas Luhmann realized the world isn’t a simple dualistic affair (good vs. evil). Recall, he learned this particularly from being captured and tortured by the supposed “good guys” at the end of World War II. The world is complex, and so is the human mind. 早年，尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 就意识到世界并不是简单的二元对立（善与恶）。回想一下，他是在第二次世界大战结束时被所谓的 “好人” 俘虏并遭受酷刑时才学到这一点的。世界是复杂的，人的思想也是如此。

The question becomes How can one devise a system built on that which reflects chaos, yet also possess some physical laws of order binding it together, in order to navigate such complexity? 问题变成了如何设计一个建立在反映混乱的系统之上的系统，同时又拥有一些将它结合在一起的物理秩序法则，以便驾驭这种复杂性？

It was with this question in mind that Luhmann crafted the structure of the Antinet. 考虑到这个问题，卢曼精心设计了 Antinet 的结构。

**The Antinet as an Actual TreeAntinet 作为一棵实际的树**

“The distributions and partitions of knowledge are not like several lines that meet in one angle, and so touch but in a point; but are like branches of a tree, that meet in a stem, which hath a dimension and quantity of entireness and continuance, before it comes to discontinue and break itself into arms and boughs.”“知识的分布和划分，不像几条线在一个角上相交，而是在一个点上相交；但就像一棵树的树枝，在树干上相遇，在它停止并分裂成手臂和树枝之前，它具有一定程度和数量的完整性和连续性。”

–Francis Bacon[465](#footnote-514)–弗朗西斯 · 培根 465

While it’s accurate to describe the structure of the Antinet as rough, roughness is a property of the system, and not the actual structure. 虽然将 Antinet 的结构描述为粗糙是准确的，但粗糙度是系统的一个属性，而不是实际结构。

Instead of thinking of the Antinet as a fluid structure, or rigid structure, or even a hybrid of that dichotomy (a rough structure), I hold that the best way to think of the Antinet is as a tree—a real tree. 与其将 Antinet 视为流体结构或刚性结构，甚至是这种二分法的混合体（粗略结构），我认为最好的方式是将 Antinet 视为一棵树——一棵真正的树。

The idea of using a tree to metaphorically represent the structure of human knowledge is not new. The first metaphorical tree used to represent human knowledge dates back to sometime between AD 268 and 270. This first metaphorical tree of knowledge is known as the Porphyrian tree, named after Greek philosopher and logician Porphyry. The Porphyrian tree reframed and developed Aristotle’s classification scheme by presenting it in tree form. 使用树来隐喻地表示人类知识结构的想法并不新鲜。第一棵用于表示人类知识的隐喻树可以追溯到公元 268 年到 270 年之间的某个时间。这第一棵隐喻知识树被称为 Porphyrian 树，以希腊哲学家和逻辑学家 Porphyry 的名字命名。卟啉树通过以树的形式呈现亚里士多德的分类方案，对其进行了重构和发展。

photo credit: Penn Libraries Manuscripts, March 2018, [https://upennmanuscripts.tumblr.com/post/171413737213/ljs-457-loyca-parva-etc-written-in-the-abbey-of](https://upennmanuscripts.tumblr.com/post/171413737213/ljs-457-loyca-parva-etc-written-in-the-abbey-of). 照片来源：宾夕法尼亚图书馆手稿，2018 年 3 月，https://upennmanuscripts.tumblr.com/post/171413737213/ljs-457-loyca-parva-etc-written-in-the-abbey-of。

It’s important to look to nature as our primary source in forming our understanding of reality. “I think that I shall never see a poem as lovely as a tree,” writes Aldous Huxley.[466](#footnote-513) By this Huxley was referring to the concept that platonic abstractions can only do so much. True beauty and reality are best represented by nature itself. It’s best to think of the Antinet as an actual tree, and not merely as a computer science representation of one. 重要的是将自然视为形成我们对现实的理解的主要来源。 “我认为我永远不会看到一首像树一样可爱的诗，”Aldous Huxley 写道。466 赫胥黎指的是柏拉图式的抽象只能做这么多的概念。真正的美和真实最能体现自然本身。最好将 Antinet 视为一棵真正的树，而不仅仅是作为一棵树的计算机科学表示。

Looking first to nature—and specifically trees—results in creating useful abstractions for managing knowledge. It’s important to first look to nature for inspiration, as opposed to looking at some other platonic abstraction for information. Looking to nature first is actually what inspired a useful visual innovation in computer science called rectangular treemaps. Its originator, Ben Shneiderman writes, “The recursive branching structure of trees, which provides a compelling metaphor for organizing knowledge, was at the forefront of my mind as I developed the rectangular treemap as a means to display the nested structure of folders on a computers hard drive.”[467](#footnote-512) The lesson is that actual, real trees, are the best metaphor to think of when devising the structure of your own Antinet. 首先关注自然——尤其是树木——会导致创建有用的抽象来管理知识。重要的是首先要从大自然中寻找灵感，而不是从其他柏拉图式的抽象中寻找信息。首先关注自然实际上激发了计算机科学中一种有用的视觉创新，称为矩形树图。它的创始人 Ben Shneiderman 写道，“当我开发矩形树图作为在计算机上显示文件夹嵌套结构的一种方式时，树的递归分支结构为组织知识提供了一个令人信服的隐喻，它是我的首要考虑硬盘驱动器。”467 这个教训是，在设计自己的 Antinet 结构时，实际的、真正的树是最好的比喻。

Trees are not only useful, but also fundamentally critical in explaining the truth of reality. Charles Darwin writes, “The affinities of all the beings of the same class have sometimes been represented by a great tree. I believe this simile largely speaks the truth.”[468](#footnote-511) In fact, in Darwin’s seminal book On The Origin of Species, the only illustration in the entire book is a tree structure.[469](#footnote-510) 树木不仅有用，而且在解释现实真相方面具有根本性的关键意义。查尔斯 · 达尔文写道：“同一类所有生物的亲缘关系有时用一棵大树来表示。我相信这个比喻在很大程度上说出了真相。”468 事实上，在达尔文的开创性著作《物种起源》中，整本书中唯一的插图是树结构。 469

photo credit: On the Origin of Species (London: Murray, 1859), 116ff. 照片来源：《物种起源》（伦敦：默里出版社，1859 年），116ff。

Darwin used this model, called the tree of life, to explain his theory of evolution. 达尔文使用这种称为生命之树的模型来解释他的进化论。

So critical was this diagram that Darwin wrote the following letter to his publisher a few months before the release of his book: “Enclosed is the Diagram which I wish engraved on Copper on folding out Plate to face latter part of volume. It is an odd looking affair, but is indispensable to show the nature of the very complex affinities of past & present animals. I have given full instructions to Engraver, but must see a Proof.”[470](#footnote-509) 这张图是如此关键，以至于达尔文在他的书出版前几个月写了下面这封信给他的出版商：这是一件看起来很奇怪的事情，但对于展示过去和现在动物非常复杂的亲缘关系的本质来说是必不可少的。我已向雕刻师提供完整说明，但必须查看校样。”470

Many applications have been built around trees as metaphors for representing knowledge. For instance, an interesting tree-like application is that of the Thompson Chain Reference Bible. 许多应用程序都是围绕树构建的，作为表示知识的隐喻。例如，一个有趣的树状应用程序是 Thompson Chain Reference Bible。

photo credit: “Handy Size Thompson Chain Reference Bible KJV (186),” Bible Buying Guide (blog), accessed April 19, 2022, [https://biblebuyingguide.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Handy-Size-Thompson-Chain-Reference-Bible-KJV-186.jpg](https://biblebuyingguide.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Handy-Size-Thompson-Chain-Reference-Bible-KJV-186.jpg). 照片来源：“Handy Size Thompson Chain Reference Bible KJV (186)”，圣经购买指南（博客），2022 年 4 月 19 日访问，https://biblebuyingguide.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Handy-Size -Thompson-Chain-Reference-Bible-KJV-186.jpg。

This version effectively breaks apart the Bible into branches and stems of thought. You essentially follow one branch’s verse. When you get to the verse, in the page margin is a chain-link to another verse somewhere else in the Bible. For instance, if you follow the verse of a prophecy in the Old Testament, the structure then takes you to a verse in the New Testament wherein Jesus references the prophecy. 这个版本有效地将圣经分解成思想的分支和主干。您基本上遵循一个分支的诗句。当你读到这节经文时，在页边空白处有一个链式链接，指向圣经中其他地方的另一节经文。例如，如果你跟随旧约中预言的经文，结构就会将你带到新约中耶稣引用预言的经文。

The Thompson Chain Reference Bible is actually quite similar to the Antinet. However, the leaves of the Antinet aren’t verses, they’re notecards.Thompson Chain Reference Bible 实际上与 Antinet 非常相似。但是，Antinet 的叶子不是诗句，而是记事本。

In sum, using an actual tree as inspiration for knowledge has been proven throughout history to be a powerful metaphor. Luhmann’s Antinet embodied this tree-like structure, and it only makes sense we continue to fully embrace it. 总而言之，使用一棵实际的树作为知识的灵感在历史上已被证明是一个强有力的比喻。 Luhmann 的 Antinet 体现了这种树状结构，只有我们继续完全接受它才有意义。

**Components of the Antinet’s Tree StructureAntinet 树结构的组成部分**

To illustrate how an Antinet reflects a tree structure, think of it like this:[471](#footnote-508) 为了说明 Antinet 如何反映树结构，可以这样想：471

● The tree is the entire Antinet. It is your tree of knowledge.● 树是整个 Antinet。它是你的知识之树。

● The branches are the main top-level sub-sections. For instance: 4000 which represents Formal Sciences, and 4212 which represents Information Science.●The stems are the individual collections and streams of thoughts that usually are created together. For instance: 4214/1a/1, 4214/1a/2, 4214/1a/3. In this case, the stem is 1a.● 分支是主要的顶级子部分。例如：4000 代表形式科学，4212 代表信息科学。例如：4214/1a/1、4214/1a/2、4214/1a/3。在这种情况下，词干是 1a。

● The leaves are the individual notecards. For instance, 4214/1a/1, 4214/1a/2, 4214/1a/3. These three cards represent three individual leaves.● 叶子是单独的记事卡。例如，4214/1a/1、4214/1a/2、4214/1a/3。这三张卡片代表三片叶子。

● The vines are remotelinks that allow you to swing from one area in your tree of knowledge to another. In the field of human memory science, they’re akin to remote associations. For instance, within 4214/1a/2 you can link to a remote area like 2431/2a. When you do this, you’re effectively swinging from a vine on 4214/1a/2 to 2431/2a.● 藤蔓是远程链接，可让您从知识之树的一个区域切换到另一个区域。在人类记忆科学领域，它们类似于远程联想。例如，在 4214/1a/2 内，您可以链接到像 2431/2a 这样的偏远地区。当你这样做时，你实际上是从 4214/1a/2 的藤蔓摇摆到 2431/2a。

**Marcescent Thoughts 马森思**

In the fields of botany and zoology, the term persistence refers to the part of a plant or animal that is of a nature wherein it remains attached to the animal. Yet there are some phenomena in nature where plants or animals keep parts of themselves you’d expect them to shed. For instance, one normally expects trees to shed their dead leaves.
