However, have you ever noticed that certain trees do not do so? This is a phenomenon called marcescence. It’s a rarity among all of the species of trees, yet certain trees—like beech trees— do not shed spent leaves.[472](#footnote-507) 在植物学和动物学领域，持久性一词指的是植物或动物的自然部分，它仍然依附于动物。然而在自然界中有一些现象，植物或动物会保留你希望它们脱落的部分自身。例如，人们通常期望树木脱落枯叶。但是，您是否注意到某些树不会这样做？这是一种称为白化的现象。这在所有树种中都很罕见，但某些树（如山毛榉树）不会脱落枯叶。 472

Like literal trees, each person’s tree of knowledge residing in their mind does not shed leaves, but thoughts. Some leaves, like some thoughts, grow brown and stale before they are shed. Other leaves are useful. For instance, producing food (with chlorophyll) by way of photosynthesis, which helps it survive.[473](#footnote-506) Yet even valuable leaves—like one’s valuable thoughts—are destined to be shed, never to be seen again. 就像文字树一样，每个人心中的知识之树不落叶，而是思想。有些叶子，就像一些思想一样，在它们脱落之前会变成褐色和陈旧。其他叶子是有用的。例如，通过光合作用生产食物（含叶绿素），这有助于它生存。473 然而，即使是有价值的叶子——就像一个人的宝贵思想——也注定要脱落，再也见不到。

Indeed, shedding some types of thoughts are certainly welcomed by many of us! Yet the latest research in cognitive neuroscience shows that the average person experiences about 6,200 thoughts per day.[474](#footnote-505) Many of these thoughts are useful, yet they need some time in the sun to fully sprout and develop. 事实上，摆脱某些类型的想法当然受到我们许多人的欢迎！然而，认知神经科学的最新研究表明，普通人每天经历大约 6,200 个想法。474 其中许多想法很有用，但它们需要一些时间在阳光下才能完全萌芽和发展。

Unfortunately, most of your thoughts never have the time to sprout and develop. They never have the chance to be ruminated on and await their time to shine. 不幸的是，你的大部分想法都没有时间发芽和发展。他们永远没有机会被反思并等待他们发​​光的时间。

Productivity junkies try to address this problem by devising systematized digital workflows. The goal centers around capturing more information, and storing such in a single repository. Yet, this isn’t the solution. Capturing more information is not the solution. Rather, capturing less information, and developing more knowledge is. 生产力爱好者试图通过设计系统化的数字工作流程来解决这个问题。目标围绕捕获更多信息并将其存储在单个存储库中。然而，这不是解决方案。捕获更多信息不是解决方案。相反，获取更少的信息，开发更多的知识才是。

Information overload is the very thing Luhmann figured out how to avoid. By way of metaphor, Luhmann’s system transforms one’s mind into a persistent, supercharged version of itself. Luhmann devised a knowledge structure for his thoughts which transformed his mind into something capable of marcescence, able to retain its key thoughts persistently—forever. 信息过载正是卢曼想出的避免方法。打个比方，卢曼的系统将一个人的思想转变为一个持久的、增压的自我。 Luhmann 为他的思想设计了一种知识结构，将他的思想转变为一种能够消亡的东西，能够持久地——永远地——保留其关键思想。

You see, over the course of the days, weeks, months, years, and even decades, your Antinet transforms. It evolves naturally and slowly thanks to the marcescent phenomenon of never shedding its leaves. Its ultimately indescribable, unforeseeable structure corresponds not just to your mind—but to every instance of your mind’s thoughts. This is made possible by way of the unique combination of its components and structure which, if used together, result in a tree that retains its leaves. Your tree of knowledge does not shed its thoughts, it grows and evolves them, thereby enabling you to evolve with your marcescent mind. By constantly communicating with your Antinet, you natively structure thoughts based on where it makes the most sense at the time. You retain your thoughts and evolve them for as long as you communicate with the system. 你看，在几天、几周、几个月、几年甚至几十年的过程中，你的 Antinet 发生了变化。由于从不脱落叶子的腐烂现象，它自然而缓慢地进化。它最终难以描述、不可预见的结构不仅对应于你的思想——而且对应于你思想的每一个实例。这是通过其组件和结构的独特组合实现的，如果一起使用，就会产生一棵保留叶子的树。你的知识之树不会脱落它的思想，它会生长和进化它们，从而使你能够随着你的顽强的思想而进化。通过不断地与你的 Antinet 交流，你会自然地根据当时最有意义的地方来构建想法。只要你与系统交流，你就会保留你的想法并不断发展它们。

This illustration largely relies on metaphor but it reflects the truth of using an Antinet in practice. You’ll begin to understand the more you use it. 这个例子很大程度上依赖于隐喻，但它反映了在实践中使用 Antinet 的真实情况。使用得越多，您就会开始了解它。

**On Hierarchies 关于层次结构**
-------------------------

Your tree of knowledge is the Antinet. The leaves on the tree of knowledge represent notecards. Each of these notecards is of the same class and status in terms of their theoretical importance. 你的知识树是 Antinet。知识树上的叶子代表记事卡。就理论重要性而言，这些记事卡中的每一个都属于同一类别和地位。

In an Antinet, there is no hierarchical superiority. As Johannes Schmidt says, “the position of special subject or card says nothing of the theoretical importance of the card.”[475](#footnote-504) As far as hierarchy goes, as Schmidt says, “there’s no bottom and there’s no top.”[476](#footnote-503) 在 Antinet 中，没有等级优势。正如 Johannes Schmidt 所说，“特殊主题或卡片的位置并不能说明卡片的理论重要性。”475 就等级而言，正如 Schmidt 所说，“没有底部，也没有顶部。”476

One thing people have difficulty comprehending is how the Antinet does not employ a hierarchical taxonomy. 人们难以理解的一件事是 Antinet 为何不采用分层分类法。

Taxonomy comes from the Greek roots taxis and nomos. Taxis means order, and nomos, means science. Essentially, taxonomy refers to the science of order. However, the Antinet, as Luhmann writes, is a system of both “order and disorder.”[477](#footnote-502) It’s a system not trying to make a science of order. It’s not trying to make order out of chaos. Rather it’s a system that embraces chaos without becoming overwhelmed by it. The mechanisms preventing users from going crazy with too much chaos are the numeric-alpha addresses and the tree structure. 分类学来自希腊词根 taxis 和 nomos。 Taxis 意味着秩序，nomos 意味着科学。本质上，分类学指的是秩序科学。然而，正如 Luhmann 所写，Antinet 是一个既有 “秩序又无序” 的系统。 477 它是一个不试图建立秩序科学的系统。它并不是要拨乱反正。相反，它是一个拥抱混乱而不被其淹没的系统。防止用户因太多混乱而发疯的机制是数字字母地址和树结构。

The numeric-alpha addresses alone are not enough for the system to thrive. That’s where the branch separators come into play. Branch separators are the special characters that fork off a thought into a new branch or stem. They’re characters like forward-slashes, periods, or commas.[478](#footnote-501) 仅数字字母地址不足以让系统蓬勃发展。这就是分支分隔符发挥作用的地方。分支分隔符是将思想分叉成新分支或主干的特殊字符。它们是正斜杠、句点或逗号等字符。 478

Some may interpret that whatever comes after the branch separator is somehow of a lower-status on the perceived hierarchy. In reality, this is not the case. In fact, as Luhmann confirms, “the positioning of a subject within this system of organization reveals nothing about its theoretical importance for there exist no privileged positions in this web of notes.”[479](#footnote-500) 有些人可能会解释，分支分隔符之后的内容在某种程度上在感知层次结构中处于较低的状态。实际上，情况并非如此。事实上，正如卢曼所证实的那样，“一个主体在这个组织系统中的定位丝毫没有揭示其理论重要性，因为在这个笔记网络中不存在任何特权位置。”479

Here’s an illustration showing how there are no privileged positions in the Antinet’s structure: Luhmann’s most important work is his Theory of Society. In his Antinet, Luhmann placed a section for a major project pertaining to his most important work in a very discrete location: 21/3d7fb.[480](#footnote-499) This location falls under several other branches which are seemingly less important. When looking at this, it becomes clear that the rank of the importance of a thought is not reflected in its position within the Antinet. 这是一个说明 Antinet 结构中没有特权位置的例子：卢曼最重要的著作是他的社会理论。在他的 Antinet 中，Luhmann 在一个非常离散的位置放置了一个与他最重要的工作有关的主要项目的部分：21/3d7fb.480 这个位置属于其他几个看起来不太重要的分支。看到这里，很明显一个思想的重要性等级并没有反映在它在 Antinet 中的位置上。

**Notes Are in a Position, Not in a Rank 笔记是在一个位置，而不是在一个等级**

Each numeric-alpha address pertaining to each note lives in a specific location indicated by its fixed address. Similar to a latitude-longitude coordinate, notes in an Antinet reside at a certain address that is not a ranked order of contents. 与每个音符相关的每个数字字母地址都位于由其固定地址指示的特定位置。与经纬度坐标类似，Antinet 中的笔记位于某个地址，该地址不是内容排序。

**Internal Branching 内部分支**

The position-based scheme in the Antinet’s structure allows for internalAntinet 结构中基于位置的方案允许内部

branching. This is important because it allows the system to shift and evolve in unexpected ways. 分枝。这很重要，因为它允许系统以意想不到的方式转变和发展。

The Antinet is composed of thoughts that can be visualized as leaves. Like leaves, some grow stale and some new ones grow between others. They’re always changing. Some leaves turn brown and dry up. Other areas on your tree unexpectedly grow and flourish. As Luhmann himself states, “some things fade away; some notes are never seen again.”[481](#footnote-498) Yet the reason you should allow this to occur centers on the opposite scenario. Ideas you had which were “initially positioned so as to play a minor role [in what you’re working on] come to dominate the system.”[482](#footnote-497)Antinet 由可以想象为树叶的思想组成。就像树叶一样，有些会变老，有些会长出新的。他们总是在变化。一些叶子变成棕色并变干。树上的其他区域出乎意料地生长和繁荣。正如卢曼自己所说，“有些东西会消失；有些笔记再也见不到了。”481 然而，您应该允许这种情况发生的原因集中在相反的场景上。你的想法 “最初被定位为[在你正在做的事情中] 扮演次要角色，但后来却主宰了整个系统。”482

Alternatively, you’ll also have thoughts you initially believed would play a major role in your work. Yet the thoughts end up not evolving or being developed at all. This can happen due to the initial excitement for the idea wearing off. Or, this can happen when thoughts lack additional support from your future readings. Both of these stands as a good thing. You don’t want to continue developing an idea that no longer seems relevant or useful. This is something that happens naturally in an Antinet. 或者，您也会有您最初认为会在您的工作中发挥重要作用的想法。然而，这些想法最终没有进化或根本没有发展。这可能是因为最初对这个想法的兴奋逐渐消退。或者，当您的想法缺乏未来阅读的额外支持时，就会发生这种情况。这两点都是好事。你不想继续开发一个看起来不再相关或有用的想法。这是 Antinet 中自然发生的事情。

This highlights the power of internal branching. 这突出了内部分支的力量。

The power of internal branching was not realized by Luhmann alone. Others scholars observed the power of such as well. One scholar writes, “the card index is open-ended not only in a physical sense—new file cards and new entries can be added to existing ones without limits—but also in a structural sense.”[483](#footnote-496) Yet the numeric-alpha addresses also enclose this open-ended system in a cybernetic network. That is, numeric-alpha addresses create a self-contained border between themselves and the outside world. In essence, the system is open-ended, but only in the sense that it grows more complex inwardly instead of externally. The tree of knowledge gets denser and denser. It becomes filled with more leaves, branches, stems, and vines over time. 内部分支的力量并不是卢曼一个人意识到的。其他学者也观察到了这种力量。一位学者写道，“卡片索引不仅在物理意义上是开放式的——新的文件卡片和新条目可以无限制地添加到现有的卡片上——而且在结构意义上也是如此。”483 然而，数字字母地址也将这个开放式系统封闭在控制论网络中。也就是说，数字字母地址在它们自己和外部世界之间创建了一个独立的边界。从本质上讲，该系统是开放式的，但只是在它向内而不是向外变得更加复杂的意义上。知识之树越来越茂密。随着时间的推移，它会长满更多的叶子、树枝、茎干和藤蔓。

The internal branching is made possible through the Antinet’s structure: its fixed order of positioning each leaf on the tree. 内部分支是通过 Antinet 的结构实现的：它在树上放置每个叶子的固定顺序。

As Johannes Schmidt says, it’s best not to think of the system as “an order of contents,” but as a “fixed order of positioning.”[484](#footnote-495) By fixed order of positioning, he alludes to the spatial implications of a thought. A thought doesn’t exist in the ether, but can be assigned to a certain position in physical space. 正如 Johannes Schmidt 所说，最好不要将系统视为 “内容的顺序”，而应将其视为 “固定的定位顺序”。484 通过固定的定位顺序，他暗指思想的空间含义。思想不存在于以太中，但可以被分配到物理空间中的某个位置。

This mirrors how ancient Greek thinkers implemented mnemonic techniques to aid memorization: “If the recollection of things and words is based on semantic associations triggered by images, then these images must be placed somewhere. This arrangement cannot be chaotic; it must follow an order that in turn may be easily memorized.”[485](#footnote-494) By must be placed somewhere, think of numeric-alpha addresses and installing your notes in long-term storage. By easily memorized, consider the the tree-like structure of the Antinet, as well as the index. One can logically trace the area where the note should be filed after looking up the keyterm in the index. 这反映了古希腊思想家如何运用助记技术来帮助记忆：“如果对事物和单词的回忆是基于图像触发的语义联想，那么这些图像必须放在某个地方。这样的安排不能乱；它必须遵循一个容易记住的顺序。”485 By 必须放在某个地方，想想数字字母地址并将您的笔记放在长期存储中。为了便于记忆，考虑 Antinet 的树状结构，以及索引。在索引中查找关键字后，可以逻辑地跟踪应该将注释归档的区域。

**Links and Reverberation 链接和混响**

Internal branching enables you to be pulled deeper into thoughts that are more developed. Yet, internal branching isn’t the only mechanism in the Antinet that facilitates this. Johannes Schmidt points out that the parts of the Antinet that are poorly linked, or not even linked at all, result in becoming isolated later on, in part because isolated elements lack reverberation.[486](#footnote-493) 内部分支使您能够更深入地进入更发达的思想。然而，内部分支并不是 Antinet 中促进这一点的唯一机制。约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 指出，Antinet 中连接不良或根本没有连接的部分会导致后来变得孤立，部分原因是孤立的元素缺乏混响。 486

Reverberation, a concept that appears throughout this book, relates to “just-experienced associations” setting off a chain reaction of thought. During this period, the concept and the associations are easier to recall.[487](#footnote-492) 混响是贯穿本书的一个概念，它与引发思想连锁反应的 “刚刚经历过的联想” 有关。在此期间，概念和联想更容易回忆起来。 487

After you’ve triggered a reverberation event, over the next several days, the association and connection is given a new lease on life, opening the possibility of those thoughts colliding with new ideas related to your current thoughts and recent discoveries. This enables ideas to evolve. 在你触发了一个回响事件之后，在接下来的几天里，联想和联系被赋予了新的生命，这些想法有可能与你当前的想法和最近的发现相关的新想法发生碰撞。这使想法得以发展。

Reverberation is a necessary ingredient for the evolution of thoughts. Reverberation is attained through creating and re-experiencing linked thoughts. As can be expected, this experience of reverberation, relying exclusively on links as it is, is significantly wiped away with digital keyword search functionality. 混响是思想进化的必要成分。混响是通过创造和重新体验相互关联的思想来实现的。正如可以预料的那样，这种完全依赖于链接的混响体验被数字关键字搜索功能大大消除了。

When you navigate around your Antinet by way of using associations (links), you are building your memory. You’re building memory in the short term by triggering reverberation events, and you’re stamping the potential of re-triggering reverberation events in the long term. 当您通过使用关联（链接）在 Antinet 中导航时，您正在建立您的记忆。您通过触发混响事件在短期内建立记忆，并且在长期内标记重新触发混响事件的潜力。

Reverberation is also super-charged and strengthened over time via the practice of writing by hand. You see, reverberation transitions an idea into “supersonic mode” within your mind for months (if not years and decades) by way of neuroimprinting ideas on your mind. The reason why this is important is because it enables you to recall the idea when faced with a new idea that contradicts the one still reverberating in your mind. Reverberation, in turn, serves as a self-deception filter for your thoughts. 通过手写练习，混响也会随着时间的推移而增强和增强。你看，混响通过在你脑海中留下神经印记的方式，将一个想法转变为你脑海中的 “超音速模式” 数月（如果不是数年和数十年）。这一点之所以重要，是因为它可以让你在面对一个与你脑海中仍在回荡的想法相矛盾的新想法时回忆起这个想法。反过来，混响可以作为您思想的自我欺骗过滤器。

The tree structure of the Antinet (with its internal branching), as well as links made possible by way of numeric-alpha addresses, enables reverberation to be elevated to a whole new level. This, again, is something lacking in digital Zettelkasten systems with their automated linking and specific-term search properties.Antinet 的树结构（及其内部分支）以及通过数字字母地址实现的链接，使混响能够提升到一个全新的水平。这又是数字 Zettelkasten 系统所缺乏的，具有自动链接和特定术语搜索属性。

**Associative Chaining 关联链**

Let’s take a look at two types of structures for organizing knowledge: (1) Associative Bubbles, and (2) Associative Chaining. 让我们来看看组织知识的两种类型的结构：(1) Associative Bubbles，和 (2) Associative Chaining。

**Associative Bubbles 关联气泡**

Associative bubble structures contain one link type with no strength differentiation. Think of these as simple links or wikilinks in a typical notetaking app. 关联气泡结构包含一种没有强度差异的链接类型。将这些视为典型笔记应用程序中的简单链接或维基链接。

These aren’t very sophisticated graphs of knowledge, nor are they reflective of how human memory works. The reason centers around the fact that there are no relations between the core branches. For instance, the relations between A, B, and C, are broken in the associative bubble diagram shown. Yet, for some reason, associative bubbles are the most popular structures used in digital notetaking apps today. 这些不是非常复杂的知识图表，也不能反映人类记忆的工作方式。原因在于核心分支之间没有关系这一事实。例如，A、B 和 C 之间的关系在所示的关联气泡图中被打破。然而，出于某种原因，联想气泡是当今数字笔记应用程序中使用最流行的结构。

**Associative Chaining 关联链**

In comparison, there’s associative chaining, which stems from the science of human memory. It also reflects the structure of the Antinet. 相比之下，联想链源于人类记忆科学。它还反映了 Antinet 的结构。

With associative chaining, every single thought is linked by proximity, and the nearest neighbors have the strongest links. There are both forward links, and backward links. However the backwards links are of a weaker association. 通过关联链，每一个想法都被邻近性联系起来，最近的邻居拥有最强的联系。既有前向链接，也有后向链接。然而，后向链接的关联性较弱。

**Hierarchical Association of the AntinetAntinet 的等级协会**

If you look closely at the diagram of associative chaining, you’ll see that a5 stems into a5/1 and a5/2, which stems into a5/2a. Within the field of memory science, this concept is known as “chunking” or “hierarchical association.”[488](#footnote-491) 如果仔细查看关联链图，您会发现 a5 源于 a5/1 和 a5/2，后者源于 a5/2a。在记忆科学领域，这个概念被称为 “分块” 或“层次关联”。 488

This term hierarchical association illustrates a key point. The Antinet’s structure is not hierarchically ordered, but is rather hierarchically associated—with no implication of any special status granted to the order or rank of the note. Merely, notes are organized in a hierarchical association based on structure alone (not based on content). 这个术语分层关联说明了一个关键点。 Antinet 的结构不是按层次排列的，而是按层次关联的——不暗示任何特殊状态被授予笔记的顺序或等级。只是，笔记是根据结构（而不​​是基于内容）按层次关联组织的。

Hierarchical association models (aka, chunking models) are based on the idea that sequences have natural breakpoints dividing words, numbers, and thoughts. By dividing the sequence of items, they’re organized into smaller components (aka, chunks).[489](#footnote-490) 层次关联模型（又名分块模型）基于序列具有划分单词、数字和思想的自然断点的想法。通过划分项目序列，它们被组织成更小的组件（也称为块）。 489

This is not a hierarchical rank indicating importance, however. Within the science of human memory, items correlated with the stem of a tree structure, comprising chunks of more related items, are thought of as “representing more elementary attributes” of the idea. The branches and items found closer to the trunk of the tree are thought of as “representing more abstract structures.”[490](#footnote-489) 但是，这不是表示重要性的等级等级。在人类记忆科学中，与树结构的主干相关的项目，包括更多相关项目的块，被认为是 “代表更基本的属性” 的想法。靠近树干的树枝和物品被认为是“代表更抽象的结构。”490

By navigating to one section (or chunk) of leaves on your tree of knowledge, you can navigate upstem to other branches, and downstem into other sections of leaves. 通过导航到知识树上叶子的一部分（或一大块），您可以向上导航到其他分支，然后向下导航到叶子的其他部分。

Within the science of human memory this is referred to as retrieving abstract “superordinate” items from memory and accessing more elemental chunks. In turn you may “retrieve the other items associated [with the memory]” (which is similar in nature to associative chaining).[491](#footnote-488) 在人类记忆科学中，这被称为从记忆中检索抽象的 “上级” 项目并访问更多的基本块。反过来，您可以“检索 [与记忆] 相关的其他项目”（这在本质上类似于关联链）。491

Though this concept is referred to as a hierarchical associative model, it’s not a traditional hierarchy, but one built on “abstract structures” and “more elementary attributes.”[492](#footnote-487) It’s a structure more akin to a tree than a hierarchy connoting relative importance. 虽然这个概念被称为层次关联模型，但它不是传统的层次结构，而是建立在 “抽象结构” 和“更基本的属性”之上的层次结构。492 它是一种更类似于树的结构，而不是表示相对重要性的层次结构。

The latest explorations in memory science have begun to use tree structures in their models. 记忆科学的最新探索已经开始在他们的模型中使用树结构。

For instance, the concept of chain-structured long short-term memory (LSTM) has come to dominate the field of machine learning and data mining. LTSM has proven itself effective at solving a wide-range of problems. This includes problems in the field of speech recognition and machine translation. This model (referred to as S-LSTM) is now being extended by using tree structures, and researchers have found that the performance of this tree-structured model yields better results than LSTM alone.[493](#footnote-486) 例如，链式结构长短期记忆（LSTM）的概念已经主导了机器学习和数据挖掘领域。 LTSM 已证明自己可以有效解决范围广泛的问题。这包括语音识别和机器翻译领域的问题。这种模型（称为 S-LSTM）现在正在通过使用树结构进行扩展，研究人员发现这种树结构模型的性能比单独使用 LSTM 产生更好的结果。 493

**Understanding the Anti-Hierarchy of the Antinet Comes from Personal Empirical Experimentation 理解 Antinet 的反等级制度来自于个人的实证实验**

It’s hard to conceive of the Antinet as not being a hierarchical system unless you actually experience it yourself (spending time building out your own Antinet and working with it). Until then, it may be helpful to look at hierarchical systems to comprehend the difference. 除非您亲自体验（花时间构建自己的 Antinet 并使用它），否则很难将 Antinet 想象成不是一个等级制度。在此之前，查看分层系统以理解差异可能会有所帮助。

**Topics, Categories and Fuzzy Categories 主题、类别和模糊类别**
------------------------------------------------------

An easy way to tell an Antinet system apart from a conventional notebox system is that the notebox system is organized by category alone (without any numerical conventions). If it contains groupings such as Courage, Stoicism, etc., then it’s not an Antinet. 区分 Antinet 系统和传统记事本系统的一种简单方法是，记事本系统仅按类别组织（没有任何数字约定）。如果它包含勇气、斯多葛主义等分组，那么它就不是 Antinet。

With this said, labeling an Antinet as a system not organized by category is incorrect. Long story short, the Antinet has an odd relationship with categories. 话虽如此，将 Antinet 标记为不按类别组织的系统是不正确的。长话短说，Antinet 与类别有着奇怪的关系。

Indeed, one does organize the Antinet by categories by assigning keyterms to point to a certain numeric-alpha address. However, the Antinet self-organizes itself by those numeric-alpha addresses. Basically, you organize the Antinet by keyterms and categories, while the Antinet organizes itself by addresses (not by categories). 事实上，人们确实通过分配关键字以指向某个数字字母地址来按类别组织 Antinet。然而，Antinet 通过这些数字字母地址进行自我组织。基本上，您按关键字和类别组织 Antinet，而 Antinet 按地址（而不是按类别）组织自己。

Luhmann organized his second Antinet by creating eleven top-level categories. However, over the years his system organized itself based on the numeric-alpha addresses.Luhmann 通过创建 11 个顶级类别来组织他的第二个 Antinet。然而，多年来，他的系统根据数字字母地址进行自我组织。

So, in effect, Luhmann technically did organize the system by categories and topics; however, over time, and as more cards were added, it self-organized itself using numeric-alpha addresses, with the addresses going far beyond (and deeper into) the categories and topics Luhmann started with. This allowed his Antinet to morph way beyond any notion of preconceived categories. 因此，实际上，卢曼在技术上确实按类别和主题组织了系统；然而，随着时间的推移，随着更多卡片的添加，它使用数字字母地址自我组织，地址远远超出（并深入到）卢曼开始的类别和主题。这使得他的 Antinet 能够超越任何先入为主的类别概念。

That the initial categorizing indicates a hierarchical system is a misconception and myth carried forth and held by many Zettelkasten practitioners. 最初的分类表明等级制度是许多 Zettelkasten 从业者传播和持有的误解和神话。

**The Nature of Category-Based Knowledge Systems 基于类别的知识系统的本质**

I contend that category-based knowledge systems cater to simpler theories and simpler material (i.e., mass-appeal books). This isn’t necessarily a bad thing. I do not wish to impart negative judgment on mass-appeal books; I simply wish to impart a critique that other notebox systems organized by simple and clear topics, end up producing more simplified work. 我认为基于类别的知识系统迎合了更简单的理论和更简单的材料（即大众化书籍）。这不一定是坏事。我不想对大众书做出负面评价；我只是想批评一下，其他由简单明了的主题组织的笔记本系统最终会产生更简化的工作。

It’s easy to discount category-based notecard systems based on their simplicity, compared with an Antinet system; however, I prefer not to discount them totally. 与 Antinet 系统相比，基于类别的记事卡系统很容易因为它们的简单性而打折；但是，我不想完全打折它们。

Category-based systems serve as a more appropriate choice if one wishes to write general books for the general public. For instance, Ryan Holiday, Elizabeth Gilbert, and Robert Greene use topic-organized notebox systems. Their books essentially take simple ideas and concepts and provide useful stories, reflections, and excerpts to support their views. 如果希望为大众编写通用书籍，则基于类别的系统是更合适的选择。例如，Ryan Holiday、Elizabeth Gilbert 和 Robert Greene 使用主题组织的笔记箱系统。他们的书基本上采用简单的想法和概念，并提供有用的故事、反思和摘录来支持他们的观点。

For instance, an author might take a concept like courage, make a category in their notebox, and then add cards with excerpts, stories, and reflections about courage in that category. 例如，作者可能会采用像勇气这样的概念，在他们的笔记本中创建一个类别，然后在该类别中添加带有关于勇气的摘录、故事和反思的卡片。

This helps produce simpler, easier-to-read books organized by very broad topics; however, it also contributes to several downsides: (1) it risks over-simplifying the concept and therefore misinterpreting reality, and (2) it risks steering the author toward saying something that is not groundbreaking or new. 这有助于制作由非常广泛的主题组织的更简单、更易于阅读的书籍；然而，它也带来了几个缺点：（1）它有可能过度简化概念并因此误解现实，以及（2）它有可能引导作者说出一些不具有开创性或新意的东西。

The problem with classification systems built on clear categories and topics is that they do not exist in nature. 建立在明确类别和主题之上的分类系统的问题在于它们在自然界中并不存在。

As the linguist George Lakoff observed, “Pristine categories are fictions.”[494](#footnote-485) Categories are artifacts of the human tendency to seek clear definitions of a phenomenon—even if it’s too complex to be assigned a clear definition. This tendency was inherited from Aristotle, and we must shed this habit.[495](#footnote-484) 正如语言学家 George Lakoff 所观察到的，“原始类别是虚构的。”494 类别是人类寻求现象明确定义的倾向的产物——即使它太复杂而无法指定明确的定义。这种倾向是从亚里士多德那里继承来的，我们必须摆脱这种习惯。 495

Fuzzy Categories 模糊分类

As Steven Pinker points out, when you use a microscope to zoom in on anything, that thing’s boundaries turn fuzzy. This introduces a concept Pinker refers to as fuzzy categories, a concept that is similar to the idea of the rough structure and rough categories the Antinet is built upon.[496](#footnote-483) 正如史蒂文 · 平克 (Steven Pinker) 指出的那样，当您使用显微镜放大任何事物时，事物的边界就会变得模糊。这引入了 Pinker 称为模糊类别的概念，该概念类似于 Antinet 所基于的粗略结构和粗略类别的概念。 496

You cannot create genius-level work if you’re confined to thinking about whatever category is popular, or even thinkable. 如果你局限于思考流行的类别，甚至是可以想象的类别，你就无法创造出天才级别的作品。

Moreover, categories tend to induce certain OCD tendencies. One begins to major in the minor. This introduces something I call the classifier’s fallacy. 此外，类别往往会诱发某些强迫症倾向。一个人开始主修未成年人。这引入了我称之为分类器谬误的东西。

**The Collector’s Fallacy and the Classifier’s Fallacy 收集器的谬误和分类器的谬误**

The classifier’s fallacy derives its inspiration from something Christian Tietze calls the collector’s fallacy, the tendency to collet information without actually processing and understanding it through elaboration (such as by making main notes that reflect on the content).[497](#footnote-482) The collector’s fallacy is the tendency to collet information without actually processing and understanding it through elaboration (i.e., making notes that reflect on the content). The Catholic intellectual and philosopher Antonin Sertillanges observed the trap of the collector’s fallacy in the early 1920s. “We must beware of a certain craze for collecting which sometimes takes possession of those who makes notes,” writes Sertillanges.[498](#footnote-481) 分类器谬误的灵感来自 Christian Tietze 称之为收集者谬误的东西，即收集信息而不通过详细阐述（例如通过对内容进行反映的主要注释）进行实际处理和理解的倾向。 497 收集者的谬误是倾向于收集信息而不通过详细阐述（即，做反映内容的笔记）实际处理和理解它。天主教知识分子和哲学家 Antonin Sertillanges 在 20 年代初观察到收藏家谬误的陷阱。 Sertillanges 写道：“我们必须提防某种收藏狂热，这种狂热有时会占据那些做笔记的人。”498

Just as harmful as the collector’s fallacy is that of the classifier’s fallacy. With category-based systems, one experiences the tendency to obsess over classifications, notably in deciding which category a note belongs to or over the hierarchical structure of one’s classification system. “Excessive attention to classification interferes with use,” warns Sertillanges.[499](#footnote-480) This is something the Antinet’s structure helps stave off. After some time working with the Antinet, users become comfortable enough with the chaos that arises and are able to face the temptations without falling prey to the time-sucking dithering over classifications 与收集器谬误一样有害的是分类器谬误。在基于类别的系统中，人们会倾向于沉迷于分类，特别是在决定一张纸条属于哪个类别时，或者在一个人的分类系统的层次结构上。 “过度关注分类会干扰使用，”Sertillanges 警告说。499 Antinet 的结构有助于避免这种情况。在使用 Antinet 一段时间后，用户对出现的混乱感到足够自在，并且能够面对诱惑而不会陷入浪费时间的分类犹豫不决中

Here’s the deal. Luhmann did not become “the most important German sociologist in the 20th century” through thinking conventionally.[500](#footnote-479) He came to be known as such by thinking unconventionally. The system Luhmann used promotes unconventional interactions. It is a system of chaos founded on simple rules of order. If an author desires to create best-selling books with simplified ideas (at risk of being simplistic), perhaps he or she should opt for a simpler system of organizing his or her knowledge. And experience the tendency of being conventional (rather than unconventional). 这是交易。卢曼并没有通过传统思维成为 “20 世纪最重要的德国社会学家”。500 他之所以出名，是因为非传统思维。卢曼使用的系统促进了非常规的互动。它是一个建立在简单秩序规则之上的混沌系统。如果作者希望用简化的想法创作畅销书（冒着被简单化的风险），也许他或她应该选择一个更简单的系统来组织他或她的知识。并体验传统的趋势（而不是非常规的）。

The fuzzy categories and structure of the Antinet, on the other hand, prevent it from falling into the trap of oversimplifying reality, leading to deeper, more unconventional, and complex work (for better, or worse). 另一方面，Antinet 的模糊类别和结构防止它陷入过于简单化现实的陷阱，从而导致更深入、更非常规和复杂的工作（无论好坏）。

One of Luhmann’s intellectual rivals held a more conventional framework for his theory of society. The man is named Jürgen Habermas. In Robert Greene’s book, The Laws of Human Nature, its contents are organized by categories like Irrationality, Narcissism, Shortsightedness, Envy, and others. Habermas’s work is conventionally laid out in a similar manner. One finds a table of contents with ideas which were considered conventional within the dominant school of social theory at the time (known as the Frankfurt School). In the mid-1980s Luhmann was asked whether he thought Habermas used an Antinet system like Luhmann himself did. Luhmann’s tart reply is classic: “For [Habermas’s] theory, simple [categories] of order seems to be sufficient.”[501](#footnote-478) 卢曼的一位知识分子对手为他的社会理论持有一个更传统的框架。这个人名叫 Jürgen Habermas。在罗伯特 · 格林 (Robert Greene) 的著作《人性法则》中，其内容按非理性、自恋、短视、嫉妒等类别进行组织。哈贝马斯的作品通常以类似的方式进行布局。人们可以找到一张目录，其中包含当时主流社会理论学派（称为法兰克福学派）中被认为是传统的思想。在 20 世纪 80 年代中期，卢曼被问及他是否认为哈贝马斯使用了像卢曼本人那样的 Antinet 系统。卢曼尖刻的回答是经典的：“对于 [哈贝马斯] 的理论，简单的 [范畴] 秩序似乎就足够了。”501

In brief, conventional systems tend to produce conventional thoughts. The Antinet results in a structure that produces thoughts pulled across many contexts and that dances with complexity. The system is built upon similarity and it links ideas that, at first glance, don’t seem similar at the time when you go back to write about a section. However, upon closer look, the structure yields some fascinating clusters that would have otherwise been impossible to create if one compartmentalizes every thought into conventional containers. 简而言之，传统系统倾向于产生传统思想。 Antinet 产生了一种结构，这种结构产生了跨越许多背景的思想，并与复杂性共舞。该系统建立在相似性之上，它链接了一些想法，乍一看，当你回过头来写一个部分时，这些想法看起来并不相似。然而，仔细观察后，该结构产生了一些迷人的集群，如果将每个想法划分到传统容器中，这些集群是不可能创建的。

**The Downsides of Category-Based Systems 基于类别的系统的缺点**

Now, let’s explore some of the downsides of category-based systems. 现在，让我们探讨一下基于类别的系统的一些缺点。

**Duplicating Cards Leads to Diminishing Neuroimprinting Returns 复制卡片导致神经印记回报减少**

Ryan Holiday uses a notecard system organized by categories (like Life, Anticipation, Death, and Strategy). His cards are not individually addressed. Rather, you’ll find the name of a category in the top-right corner.Ryan Holiday 使用按类别（如生活、预期、死亡和策略）组织的记事卡系统。他的卡片没有单独的地址。相反，您会在右上角找到类别的名称。

When using a category-based system, one often faces the dilemma of a card that can be filed in multiple categories. For instance, a card that fits both into the Anticipation category and the Strategy category. In such a case, Holiday’s advice is simple: “Just make a duplicate card.”[502](#footnote-477) 在使用基于类别的系统时，人们经常面临可以在多个类别中归档的卡片的困境。例如，一张既适合预期类别又适合策略类别的卡片。在这种情况下，Holiday 的建议很简单：“制作一张复制卡即可。”502

While this is not ideal, it’s not terribly bad, either. After all, you gain the benefits of neuroimprinting the idea on your mind. However, writing an idea down multiple times does run up against the law of diminishing returns. There’s simply too much to know, as Ann Blair would say. There’s a risk that the excerpt you write down multiple times will prove useless to your work. Also, the idea of copying out reflection notes (which I’ll detail later), may span across several cards, is rather impractical in the long term. 虽然这并不理想，但也不是很糟糕。毕竟，将想法印在脑海中会为您带来好处。然而，多次写下一个想法确实违反了收益递减法则。正如安 · 布莱尔 (Ann Blair) 所说，要知道的实在是太多了。您多次写下的摘录可能对您的工作毫无用处。此外，抄写反思笔记（我稍后会详细说明）的想法可能会跨越多张卡片，从长远来看是相当不切实际的。

Holiday’s solution to this problem sheds light on one of the several inadequacies of category-based systems. You see, Luhmann faced the same problem of trying to figure out which keyterm best encapsulated an idea. Yet because of the self-referential nature of the Antinet (made possible by numeric-alpha addresses), all Luhmann had to do was simply create a card that said, For more on this concept, see card ‘3411/2A.’ I call this type of card a hoplink card, which will be covered later. Oftentimes, however, Luhmann wouldn’t create a card with only links on it. There was frequently enough space on any given card to just create a cardlink to the related idea.Holiday 对这个问题的解决方案揭示了基于类别的系统的几个不足之一。你看，卢曼面临着同样的问题，即试图找出哪个关键词最能概括一个想法。然而，由于 Antinet 的自我参照性质（通过数字字母地址成为可能），Luhmann 所要做的就是简单地创建一张卡片，上面写着，关于这个概念的更多信息，请参见卡片 “3411/2A”。我打电话这种卡是 hoplink 卡，后面会讲到。然而，Luhmann 通常不会制作一张只有链接的卡片。任何给定的卡片上通常都有足够的空间来创建指向相关想法的卡片链接。

**Duplicating Cards Prevents Feedback Signals in Notetaking Systems 复制卡片可防止笔记系统中的反馈信号**

In addition to the diminishing returns achieved by writing out the same card multiple times, there is something lacking in such a system. 除了通过多次写出同一张卡片实现的收益递减之外，这样的系统还缺少一些东西。

You see, one of the things that has held back notetaking systems is the lack of feedback. Whenever you release a new book or piece of work out into the world, you’re met with feedback. Sometimes there’s an audience for your work, sometimes there’s not, and sometimes it’s worse: people hate it. However, every single one of those outcomes is fantastic. Feedback, even negative feedback, enables you to learn from your efforts. In the field of artificial intelligence, the entire system relies on feedback. The same holds true for cybernetic networks, which is what an Antinet is. It’s a system with a deliberate goal, and it’s a system that learns from feedback. 你看，阻碍笔记系统发展的原因之一是缺乏反馈。每当你向世界发布一本新书或一部作品时，你都会收到反馈。有时你的作品会有观众，有时没有，有时更糟：人们讨厌它。但是，这些结果中的每一个都很棒。反馈，甚至是负面反馈，都能让你从自己的努力中学习。在人工智能领域，整个系统都依赖于反馈。这同样适用于控制论网络，这就是 Antinet。这是一个有深思熟虑的目标的系统，它是一个从反馈中学习的系统。

In notetaking systems, you’re rarely met with feedback because the system is made for your eyes only (as it should be). It’s a system for you to process thoughts, learn thoughts, and reflect on ideas. As such, you do not publish the work, and thus, you don’t gain feedback. However, you should not correct the lack of feedback in your notetaking system by publishing your notes. That’s a waste of time. 在笔记系统中，您很少会收到反馈，因为该系统专为您的眼睛而设计（本应如此）。它是一个让你处理想法、学习想法和反思想法的系统。因此，您不会发布作品，因此您不会获得反馈。但是，您不应该通过发布笔记来纠正笔记系统中缺乏反馈的问题。那是浪费时间。

But what are you to do if you wish to evolve your notetaking system, even if you’ve not yet experienced the feedback signals necessary to evolve it? 但是，如果你想改进你的笔记系统，你该怎么办，即使你还没有体验到改进它所必需的反馈信号？

One way to gain feedback signals relates to duplicate card entries. 获得反馈信号的一种方式涉及重复卡片条目。

When you create a duplicate card in the Antinet, it’s a feedback signal. It’s not something you want to do, nor is it that likely to happen, because even before you write a maincard, you should first peruse your Antinet to figure out where it’s going to fit. Only after that point, do you then begin writing the maincard (which is an excerpt note, a reformulation note, or a reflection note). These will be detailed later. Bottom line: the practice of first figuring out where you’ll install a new note prevents you from duplicating an already created idea. 当你在 Antinet 中创建一张重复的卡片时，它是一个反馈信号。这不是您想做的事情，也不太可能发生，因为即使在您编写主卡之前，您也应该首先仔细阅读 Antinet 以确定它适合的位置。只有在那之后，你才开始写主卡（这是一个摘录笔记、一个重新制定的笔记或一个反思笔记）。这些将在后面详细介绍。底线：首先弄清楚你将在哪里安装新笔记的做法可以防止你复制一个已经创建的想法。

When you do create a duplicate card it tells you that your Antinet knows more than you give it credit for. It sends a feedback signal to you that you should spend more time with your Antinet perusing its contents, creating index entries, and getting familiar with it. 当您确实创建了一张复制卡时，它会告诉您您的 Antinet 知道的比您认为的要多。它向您发送反馈信号，您应该花更多时间使用 Antinet 细读其内容、创建索引条目并熟悉它。

Also, when you create a duplicate card it poses an interesting question: were you going to file the duplicate card in a different location? If you were going to file the card in a different location, it sends another signal. It creates an opportunity to create links across those areas of your Antinet. As a result, it creates an opportunity for accidents or surprises to occur down the road. 此外，当您创建一张复制卡时，它提出了一个有趣的问题：您是否打算将复制卡归档在不同的位置？如果您打算将卡片归档到不同的位置，它会发送另一个信号。它创造了在 Antinet 的这些区域之间创建链接的机会。结果，它为以后发生事故或意外创造了机会。

**The Benefits of Cardlinks Over Writing Out Copies of Duplicate CardsCardlinks 优于写出重复卡片副本的好处**

Creating cardlinks, instead of copying out a duplicate card possesses several advantages: 创建卡片链接，而不是复制一张重复的卡片有几个优点：

First, cardlinks eliminate the wasting of time and the accompanying diminished value of neuroimprinting multiple cards. 首先，卡片链接消除了时间的浪费和神经印记多张卡片随之而来的价值下降。

Second, cardlinks enrich the cybernetic network of the Antinet because you end up creating a system with more connections. Effectively, the neurons in your brain are enhanced through the making of many connections across the network. 其次，卡片链接丰富了 Antinet 的控制论网络，因为你最终创建了一个具有更多连接的系统。实际上，通过在网络中建立许多连接，您大脑中的神经元得到了增强。

Third, cardlinks enable the Antinet to retain the structure necessary for compounding and evolving ideas over the long term. In comparison, category-based systems confine the ideas to silos of information. The cards cannot communicate between silos. At most, they can (merely) reference top-level categories. For instance, they contain references like, For more on this, see the “Death” category. The system cannot reference a subsection of cards or even an individual card within the Death category, which could contain thousands of cards. 第三，卡片链接使 Antinet 能够保留长期复合和发展思想所必需的结构。相比之下，基于类别的系统将想法限制在信息孤岛中。卡片无法在筒仓之间进行通信。最多，他们可以（仅）引用顶级类别。例如，它们包含类似的引用，有关更多信息，请参阅 “死亡” 类别。系统无法引用卡片的一小部分，甚至无法引用死亡类别中的一张卡片，后者可能包含数千张卡片。

Fourth, cardlinks introduce the possibility of surprise, and as a result, the likelihood of inducing breakthrough insights are increased. In an Antinet, when you encounter a remotelink, you’re often taken to a completely different branch in the Antinet. In that branch you review stems of thought and leaves that end up serving as the perfect material for what you need. 第四，卡片链接带来了惊喜的可能性，因此增加了产生突破性见解的可能性。在 Antinet 中，当您遇到 remotelink 时，您通常会被带到 Antinet 中一个完全不同的分支。在那个分支中，你回顾了思想和叶子，它们最终成为你需要的完美材料。

For instance, right now while writing this section, an accidental surprise occurred. In the following card (4214/5/0/1), you’ll see a green snippet of text that says: For instance, Hoplinks: ‘4214/3H/4’比如现在写这一段的时候，意外发生了一件意外的事情。在下面的卡片 (4214/5/0/1) 中，您会看到一段绿色的文字：例如，Hoplinks：‘4214/3H/4’

When I navigated to 4214/3h/4, I actually stumbled upon a very useful surprise in a few cards placed immediately before 4214/3h/4. The cards were 4214/3h/3b and 4214/3h/3b/1. 当我导航到 4214/3h/4 时，我实际上在 4214/3h/4 之前的几张卡片中偶然发现了一个非常有用的惊喜。这些卡是 4214/3h/3b 和 4214/3h/3b/1。

These cards pertain to the downsides of category-based systems. I had forgotten about this set of cards. The second card, 4214/3h/3b/1, reminded me of another downside of category-based systems which formed the section you’re about to read next. This all came by way of a surprise that generated a breakthrough insight. 这些卡片与基于类别的系统的缺点有关。我忘记了这套卡片。第二张卡片 4214/3h/3b/1 让我想起了基于类别的系统的另一个缺点，这构成了您接下来要阅读的部分。这一切都来自于产生突破性洞察力的惊喜。

Yet even if my (re)discovery of the card 4214/3h/3b/1 didn’t come by way of accident (thanks to the tree structure of the Antinet); it would have been discovered by way of linking. 然而，即使我（重新）发现卡 4214/3h/3b/1 并非偶然（感谢 Antinet 的树结构）；它会通过链接被发现。

If I continued further along down the branch from the initial card, (4214/5/0/1), I would have happened upon the card 4214/5/b2/1, which points me to 4214/3h/3b/1. See the following note: 如果我从最初的卡片 (4214/5/0/1) 继续沿着分支向下走，我会偶然发现卡片 4214/5/b2/1，它指向 4214/3h/3b/1。请参阅以下注释：

This provides a glimpse into the nature of working with an Antinet. It’s a web-like system of chaos and order that introduces surprises. This makes it more fun when it comes time to sit down and write the draft or manuscript of whatever project you’re working on. 这提供了对使用 Antinet 的本质的一瞥。这是一个类似网络的混乱和秩序系统，会带来惊喜。当您坐下来写下您正在从事的任何项目的草稿或手稿时，这会变得更加有趣。

**Category-based Systems Lack the Benefits of Association Based on Proximity 基于类别的系统缺乏基于接近度的关联的好处**

Another problem with category-based systems is the fact that they lack the power of proximal association. 基于类别的系统的另一个问题是它们缺乏近端关联的能力。

In the Antinet, the closer the cards are to one another, the more associated they are. This often comes from, (1) temporal-based creation of the notes, and (2) from years of compounding and installing related notes nearby one another. This mirrors how human memory works. The concept is known as forward and backward associations.[503](#footnote-476) Because of the numeric-alpha addresses, one can count on building out a system based on association. In a category-based notecard system, if your cards ever get shuffled or mixed around, it loses the associations that are evolved and compound over years (even decades) based on proximal associations. 在 Antinet 中，卡片之间的距离越近，它们之间的关联度就越高。这通常来自，(1) 基于时间的音符创建，以及 (2) 多年来将相关音符组合在一起并放置在彼此附近。这反映了人类记忆的工作原理。这个概念被称为前向和后向关联。503 由于数字字母地址，人们可以指望建立一个基于关联的系统。在基于类别的记事卡系统中，如果您的卡片被洗牌或混在一起，它会失去基于近端关联多年（甚至几十年）演变和复合的关联。

**Category-based Systems Lack the Compounding Features of The Antinet 基于类别的系统缺乏 Antinet 的复合功能**

The numeric-alpha addresses (compared with category-based systems), ensure that the external mind you’re building models itself after the human brain. The human brain is built around neurons and the connections between them. 数字字母地址（与基于类别的系统相比）确保您正在构建的外部思维模仿人脑。人脑是围绕神经元和它们之间的联系而构建的。

As Alberto Cevolini observes, numbering systems do not “mirror the order of the universe,” yet they’re no more unusual than alphabetically organized systems based on categories.[504](#footnote-475) By adopting numeric-alpha addresses, it’s possible to shed the notion that the entire universe and reality can be consolidated into easily understood categories. The numeric-alpha addresses compel users to develop completely different cognitive capacities.[505](#footnote-474) This cognitive capacity results in “a truly combinatory ability to manage knowledge.”[506](#footnote-473) In other words, numeric-alpha addresses combined with the tree structure of the Antinet, allows knowledge to compound and combine to create breakthrough insights. 正如阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 所观察到的那样，编号系统并不 “反映宇宙的秩序”，但它们并不比基于类别的按字母顺序组织的系统更不寻常。 504 通过采用数字字母地址，有可能摆脱这样一种观念，即整个宇宙和现实可以合并为易于理解的类别。数字字母地址迫使用户发展完全不同的认知能力。505 这种认知能力导致 “管理知识的真正组合能力”。506 换句话说，数字字母地址与 Antinet 的树结构相结合，允许知识复合和结合以创造突破性的见解。

Much of this concept was already covered in an earlier chapter discussing the who and why of the Antinet. In that chapter, I touched upon where the Antinet shines, which is when one is developing knowledge for the long term. Category-based systems can certainly work; however, their real power is experienced over the long term. 这个概念的大部分内容已经在前面讨论 Antinet 的人和原因的章节中讨论过了。在那一章中，我谈到了 Antinet 的闪光点，也就是人们在长期发展知识的时候。基于类别的系统当然可以工作；然而，它们的真正力量是长期存在的。

**Tree Classification Systems 树木分类系统**
--------------------------------------

Luhmann’s first and second Zettelkasten did indeed contain top-level categories, yet they were not category-based systems. Numeric addresses were affixed to the cards, and they were separated by branch separators (like “/”). This enabled his thoughts to branch internally. The top-level branches were more like fuzzy categories. They were good starting points or areas from which knowledge would develop. They retained the rough structure of trees. However, I think it best to think of them as top-level branches instead of top-level categories. Also, instead of calling Luhmann’s Antinet architecture a classification system, I like to think of it as a tree classification system.Luhmann 的第一个和第二个 Zettelkasten 确实包含顶级类别，但它们不是基于类别的系统。数字地址被贴在卡片上，并由分支分隔符（如 “/”）分隔。这使他的思想在内部产生了分支。顶级分支更像是模糊类别。它们是知识发展的良好起点或领域。他们保留了树木的粗略结构。但是，我认为最好将它们视为顶级分支而不是顶级类别。此外，我不喜欢将 Luhmann 的 Antinet 架构称为分类系统，而是将其视为树分类系统。

**The Luhmannian Tree Classification System 卢曼树分类系统**

Luhmann started his fist Antinet in early 1950, when he was in his early twenties. He did this to accumulate knowledge and extract concepts from the books he was reading. He used his first Antinet to learn and understand the ideas he was being introduced to in his readings. He had 108 top-level branches in his first Antinet. The list of those branches can be found in Appendix A.Luhmann 于 1950 年初开始了他的拳头 Antinet，当时他二十出头。他这样做是为了积累知识并从他正在阅读的书中提取概念。他使用他的第一个 Antinet 来学习和理解他在阅读中被介绍的想法。他在他的第一个 Antinet 中拥有 108 个顶级分支。这些分支机构的列表可以在附录 A 中找到。

Luhmann started his second Antinet with a focus on his sociological research project (which he asserted would take thirty years to complete). In his second Antinet, there were eleven top-level branches. The list of those branches can be found in Appendix B. 卢曼开始了他的第二个 Antinet，重点是他的社会学研究项目（他断言需要三十年才能完成）。在他的第二个安帝内特，共有十一个顶级分支。这些分支机构的列表可以在附录 B 中找到。

**The Luhmannian Tree in Practice 实践中的卢曼树**

For an example of the tree structure in practice, let’s turn to Luhmann’s second Antinet, the one that contained eleven top-level branches. 作为实践中树结构的一个例子，让我们看看 Luhmann 的第二个 Antinet，它包含 11 个顶级分支。

Each of the branches contained subsections (which I call sub-branches). As Johannes Schmidt points out, “each of these subsections was assigned a numerical prefix of up to four digits.”[507](#footnote-472) For instance, 3411 for Ideology. 每个分支都包含小节（我称之为子分支）。正如 Johannes Schmidt 指出的那样，“这些小节中的每一个都被分配了一个最多四位数的数字前缀。”507 例如，意识形态为 3411。

Here’s an example: 这是一个例子：

At first glance this structure seems similar to the rigid structures. However there are key differences that make it unique. 乍一看，这种结构似乎类似于刚性结构。但是，有一些关键差异使其独一无二。

First off, each has a numeric address between one and four digits long. As Johannes Schmidt writes, “each of these subsections was assigned a numerical prefix of up to four digits.”[508](#footnote-471) Second, the numeric addresses are arbitrary. They are roughly chosen. They are what are known as fuzzy categories. Third, each of them contain thoughts organized by numeric-alpha addresses which then can branch down infinitely. 首先，每个都有一个长度在一到四位数字之间的数字地址。正如 Johannes Schmidt 所写，“这些小节中的每一个都被分配了一个最多四位数的数字前缀。”508 其次，数字地址是任意的。他们是粗略选择的。它们就是所谓的模糊类别。第三，它们中的每一个都包含由数字字母地址组织的思想，然后可以无限地向下分支。

A practice I implement in my own Antinet centers on always using four-digits. For instance, 3 General decision theory would be 3000 General decision theory. Luhmann essentially omitted using zeros; however, for me, it makes sense to employ them. 我在自己的 Antinet 中实施的一个实践是始终使用四位数。例如，3 General decision theory 将是 3000 General decision theory。 Luhmann 基本上省略了使用零；但是，对我来说，雇用他们是有意义的。

From each of the branches (or sub-branches), you can then begin branching down and creating thoughts on stems under the sub-branches. Each of the thoughts are leaves and represent a note. For instance, you’d create 3414/1. This, in turn, can then be branched down even further (3414/1/1), and on and on. 从每个分支（或子分支）开始，您可以开始向下分支并在子分支下的主干上创建想法。每个想法都是树叶，代表一个音符。例如，您将创建 3414/1。这反过来又可以进一步向下分支 (3414/1/1)，等等。

As one software developer who studied Luhmann’s archive puts it, “the ability to branch was the central principle” in Luhmann’s system.[509](#footnote-470) I wholeheartedly agree with this assessment. The Antinet’s tree structure makes possible its architecture. It enables it to contain relations of relations of selective relations. 正如一位研究过 Luhmann 档案的软件开发人员所说，“分支能力是 Luhmann 系统的核心原则”。 509 我完全同意这一评估。 Antinet 的树结构使其架构成为可能。它使它能够包含选择性关系的关系。

**The Scheperian Tree Classification SystemScheperian 树分类系统**

The Luhmannian Tree Classification System bases its top-level branches on an arbitrary decision. The creator of decides which branches to create based on the project they intend to build with the system. For instance, in Luhmann’s second Antinet, he chose top-level branches relevant to his thirty-year-long undertaking of exploring the theory of society.Luhmannian Tree Classification System 的顶级分支基于任意决策。的创建者根据他们打算用系统构建的项目来决定创建哪些分支。例如，在卢曼的第二个 Antinet 中，他选择了与他长达 30 年的社会理论探索事业相关的顶级分支。

When I built my Antinet, I wanted it to encompass all domains of knowledge so that I could move around wherever my interests went over my lifetime. For this reason, I chose to base my classification system on the academic disciplinary fields. The academic disciplinary fields provide a vast domain for one to install their knowledge. 当我构建我的 Antinet 时，我希望它涵盖所有知识领域，这样我就可以在我的一生中随心所欲地移动。出于这个原因，我选择将我的分类系统基于学科领域。学术学科领域为人们提供了一个广阔的领域来安装他们的知识。

I surveyed various lists of the academic disciplines, including Stanford University’s list of academic fields.[510](#footnote-469) However, the most robust list I found was Wikipedia’s list of academic disciplines.[511](#footnote-468) 我调查了各种学科列表，包括斯坦福大学的学术领域列表。 510 然而，我找到的最可靠的列表是维基百科的学科列表。 511

I base my tree classification system (let’s call it the Scheperian Tree Classification System) on this robust list. 我将我的树分类系统（我们称之为 Scheperian 树分类系统）建立在这个稳健的列表上。

Here are my top-level branches: 这是我的顶级分支：

The branches are quite broad, and there is a wealth of sub-branches available under each of them. The process entails searching the Wikipedia page of the Outline of Academic Disciplines for a given field. From there, you simply choose a number arbitrarily under the parent branch from which to build out a subject area. Material related to life self-development and life philosophy can be added to a section within Applied Arts & Sciences, for instance (5411 – Self-Development). 分支机构非常广泛，每个分支机构下都有丰富的子分支机构。该过程需要搜索学术学科大纲的维基百科页面以查找给定领域。从那里，您只需在父分支下任意选择一个数字，从中构建一个主题区域。与生活自我发展和生活哲学相关的材料可以添加到 Applied Arts & Sciences 的一个部分，例如 (5411 – Self-Development)。

Luhmann’s first Antinet focused on knowledge accumulation. It also focused on generating interesting insights by way of bisociation. His second Antinet, however, was narrower in its focus. The entire thing really could be considered a branch of the sociology branch. It was primarily theory-focused. By using the academic disciplinary fields as detailed previously, the top-level branches can encompass the fields explored in both of Luhmann’s Antinets. If he had started building his Antinet out using the academic disciplinary fields as his classification system, there’s a good chance he wouldn’t have needed to create a second Antinet. 卢曼的第一个 Antinet 专注于知识积累。它还专注于通过分离产生有趣的见解。然而，他的第二个 Antinet 的关注范围较窄。整个事情真的可以被认为是社会学分支的一个分支。它主要以理论为中心。通过使用如前所述的学术学科领域，顶级分支可以包含在卢曼的 Antinets 中探索的领域。如果他开始使用学术学科领域作为他的分类系统来构建他的 Antinet，那么他很有可能不需要创建第二个 Antinet。

**Choosing Your Own Tree Classification 选择你自己的树分类**

According to John Locke, classifications are important for two reasons. First, “it’s a great help to the memory.” Second, it allows us to “avoid confusion in our thoughts.” In other words, it gives us a map of reality, or as Locke calls it, “a map as it were of the mundus intelligibilis.”[512](#footnote-467) Mundus intelligibilis is the Latin term for intelligible world. Classification systems, in other words, create a map of intelligible reality. 根据 John Locke 的说法，分类很重要有两个原因。首先，“这对记忆有很大帮助。” 其次，它让我们 “避免思想混乱”。换句话说，它给了我们一张现实的地图，或者正如洛克所说的那样，“一张可以理解为 mundus intelligibilis 的地图”。512 Mundus intelligibilis 是可理解世界的拉丁语术语。换句话说，分类系统创建了一张可理解的现实地图。

When building out the structure of your own Antinet, you’re left with several options in choosing a classification system. 在构建自己的 Antinet 结构时，您在选择分类系统时有多种选择。

You can go the Luhmannian route and create a rough, arbitrary list of sections based on what you think you’ll need (like Luhmann’s second Antinet containing eleven branches). 你可以走 Luhmannian 路线，根据你认为你需要的内容创建一个粗略的、任意的部分列表（比如 Luhmann 的第二个 Antinet 包含 11 个分支）。

Or you can go the route of keeping things more open ended. This seems to be the route Luhmann took with his first Antinet that contains 108 top-level branches. 或者你可以走让事情更开放的路线。这似乎是卢曼在他的第一个包含 108 个顶级分支的 Antinet 中采用的路线。

Sometimes I’m presented with a question like I’m a data scientist working in the field of machine learning. Why should I adopt the academic disciplinary fields as my classification system? Why do I have to include Arts & Humanities? The simple answer is that you don’t! You don’t have to choose the academic disciplinary field classification system. However, you’re potentially locking yourself in for life to a small branch. You’re betting that you’ll be interested in machine learning for your entire life. I chose the academic disciplines because the system allows me to move around to whatever branch of knowledge I wish to learn about in the future and build out that branch. 有时我会被问到一个问题，比如我是一名在机器学习领域工作的数据科学家。为什么我应该采用学术学科领域作为我的分类系统？为什么我必须包括艺术与人文学科？简单的答案是你不知道！您不必选择学术学科领域分类系统。但是，您可能会将自己终生锁定在一个小分支上。您敢打赌，您会终生对机器学习感兴趣。我之所以选择学术学科，是因为该系统允许我转向我将来希望学习的任何知识分支并建立该分支。

The choice is yours. There are many different classifications systems you can gain inspiration from. 这是你的选择。您可以从许多不同的分类系统中获得灵感。

You can adopt John Locke’s structure: “Physica, for medical and scientific subjects, or Ethica for moral, philosophical, and political topics.”[513](#footnote-466) 您可以采用 John Locke 的结构：“Physica，用于医学和科学主题，或 Ethica 用于道德、哲学和政治主题。”513

There are numerous other classification systems to choose from. 还有许多其他分类系统可供选择。

Aristotle had his own classification system that categorized every aspect of human understanding into ten categories: substance, quantity, quality, relation, place, time, position, state, action, and affection.[514](#footnote-465) Francis Bacon had his own classification system that was divided into (1) divine learning, which encompassed the timeless truth of scriptures, and (2) human learning, which encompassed history, poetry, philosophy, and other fields.[515](#footnote-464) There’s also the classification system of Charles Cutter—whose work at the Harvard College library paved the way for the Library of Congress Classification System.[516](#footnote-463) There’s even classification schemes organized by space, time, and objects.[517](#footnote-462) 亚里士多德有他自己的分类系统，将人类理解的各个方面分为十类：物质、数量、质量、关系、地点、时间、位置、状态、行动和情感。 514 弗朗西斯 · 培根有他自己的分类系统，分为 (1) 神学，包括经文的永恒真理；(2) 人学，包括历史、诗歌、哲学和其他领域。 515 还有查尔斯 · 卡特 (Charles Cutter) 的分类系统——他在哈佛大学图书馆的工作为国会图书馆分类系统铺平了道路。516 甚至还有按空间、时间和对象组织的分类方案。517

There is also, of course, the Dewey Decimal Classification system, which includes ten top-level classes: 当然，还有杜威十进制分类系统，其中包括十个顶级类别：

I’m sometimes asked why I do not recommend the Dewey Decimal System. There’s no really good reason. It’s merely preference. I simply like Wikipedia’s outline of academic disciplines better. I find it broader and also easier to search. If you like the Dewey Decimal Classification System better, that’s fine. Go with what you prefer. Because of the infinite internal branching, it will adjust and evolve to fit your needs. 有时有人问我为什么不推荐杜威十进制系统。没有很好的理由。这只是偏好。我只是更喜欢维基百科的学科大纲。我发现它更广泛，也更容易搜索。如果您更喜欢杜威十进分类法，那很好。随心所欲。由于无限的内部分支，它会调整和发展以适应您的需求。

Remember, these classification systems merely serve as the trunk and broad branches from which your tree of knowledge develops. The true value derives from the many remote stems of thoughts and rich leaves that develop around certain ideas. René Descartes recognized this as well: “It is not from the roots or the trunks of trees that we gather the fruit, but only from the extremities of their branches, so the principal utility of philosophy depends on the separate uses of its parts, which we can only learn last of all.”[518](#footnote-461) 请记住，这些分类系统仅作为您的知识树发展的主干和广泛分支。真正的价值来自于围绕某些想法发展的许多遥远的思想和丰富的叶子。勒内 · 笛卡尔也认识到这一点：“我们不是从树的根部或树干上采摘果实，而只是从树枝的末端采摘，因此哲学的主要效用取决于其各部分的单独用途，这我们只能在最后学习。”518

A more modern classification has emerged called the Johnny Decimal System. It’s geared toward managing digital files. It seems we’re beginning to come full circle in personal knowledge management. “Nobody can find anything any more,” Johnny Decimal’s site declares. “Thousands of emails. Hundreds of files. File structures created on a whim and six layers deep. Duplicated content, lost content. We thought search would save us from this nightmare, but we were wrong.”[519](#footnote-460) 出现了一种更现代的分类，称为约翰尼十进制系统。它适用于管理数字文件。看来我们开始在个人知识管理方面全面发展。 “没有人能再找到任何东西，”Johnny Decimal 的网站宣称。 “数以千计的电子邮件。数百个文件。一时兴起创建的文件结构，深达六层。重复的内容，丢失的内容。我们认为搜索可以将我们从这场噩梦中解救出来，但我们错了。”519

I couldn’t agree more, yet I think the better solution is found in adopting an analog system over digital, of course! 我完全同意，但我认为更好的解决方案当然是采用模拟系统而不是数字系统！

The bottom line is this: you have several classification system options to choose from, though I’ll be teaching Wikipedia’s Outline of Academic Disciplines in this book. However, whatever system you choose, keep in mind that the classification systems are a rough starting point. Because of the tree structure of the Antinet, your system will evolve internally beyond the classification scheme. Classification systems merely assist in creating a rough starting point for a branch. They do not serve to encompass everything. 底线是：你有几个分类系统选项可供选择，尽管我将在本书中教授维基百科的学术学科大纲。但是，无论您选择什么系统，请记住分类系统只是一个粗略的起点。由于 Antinet 的树结构，您的系统将在内部进化，超越分类方案。分类系统仅有助于为分支创建一个粗略的起点。它们并不能包罗万象。

The reason you shouldn’t get too hung up the classification system is because of the other component of the Antinet which will be covered next: the index. 你不应该对分类系统太着迷的原因是因为 Antinet 的另一个组成部分将在接下来介绍：索引。

When building out an Antinet, you’re creating a map for your thoughts, which are representations of reality. Classification systems help you create a map of these representations of reality. Yet the index component of the Antinet is a second layer map of your thoughts which enable you to navigate freely across your Antinet without being held back by the limitations of classification systems. 构建 Antinet 时，您正在为您的思想创建地图，这是现实的表现。分类系统可帮助您创建这些现实表示的地图。然而，Antinet 的索引组件是您思想的第二层地图，它使您能够在 Antinet 中自由导航，而不会受到分类系统限制的阻碍。

**The Metaphysical Power of Trees 树木的形而上学力量**
---------------------------------------------

How we long to achieve the growth the tree fosters in itself, the reach and rootage, the sturdiness and balance between high and low, the way it meets each season, holding its ground, spare or blooming.[520](#footnote-459) 我们多么渴望实现树木自身的生长、伸展和生根、高低之间的坚固和平衡、它在每个季节相遇的方式、坚守阵地、空闲或盛开。 520

**The Mythology of Trees 树的神话**

When you begin using an Antinet, you’ll be sufficiently supplied with practical knowledge of working with tree structures. Before you’re in the thick of this terrain, however, I’d like to supply you with some metaphysical knowledge of tree structures. 当您开始使用 Antinet 时，您将充分掌握使用树结构的实用知识。然而，在您深入了解这个领域之前，我想为您提供一些关于树结构的形而上学知识。

Trees are the core symbol of the most important stories ever told in both Eastern and Western theological and philosophical systems.[521](#footnote-458) 树木是东西方神学和哲学体系中最重要故事的核心象征。 521

In the West, the crucifixion of Jesus serves as perhaps the most widely-told story in history. The story’s motifs, according to the scholar, Joseph Campbell, center on life after death. This can be thought of as being resurrected or creating a legacy out of one’s work. 在西方，耶稣被钉十字架可能是历史上流传最广的故事。根据学者约瑟夫 · 坎贝尔 (Joseph Campbell) 的说法，这个故事的主题以死后的生命为中心。这可以被认为是复活或从一个人的工作中创造遗产。

Within this great story is that of Christ on the holy rood. The holy rood is the cross made out of a tree, referred to as the tree of redemption.[522](#footnote-457) 在这个伟大的故事中有基督在圣十字架上的故事。圣十字架是由一棵树制成的十字架，称为救赎之树。 522

From The Book of Genesis there’s the tree of life and the tree of knowledge. If you ever wondered why there’s evil in the world, here’s the answer: It’s because of some damn woman named Eve! What did Eve do? She ate from the tree of knowledge. 创世记中有生命树和知识树。如果你想知道为什么世界上有邪恶，答案是：这是因为一个名叫夏娃的该死的女人！夏娃做了什么？她吃了知识树上的果子。

In the West, the metaphorical importance of trees is not exclusively unique to Christianity. The metaphorical significance of trees actually stems from Jewish, Assyrian, and Sumerian traditions.[523](#footnote-456) 在西方，树木的隐喻意义并非基督教所独有。树木的隐喻意义实际上源于犹太人、亚述人和苏美尔人的传统。 523

In the East, we have the foundational story of The Buddha’s enlightenment. The motifs of this story center on the once-spoiled aristocrat-turned-ascetic named Siddhartha Gautama. One day, when sitting beneath a bodhi tree (for forty-nine days straight), young Siddhartha became enlightened. The tree, in turn, became known as the tree of enlightenment. The bodhi tree forms the term and figure we know as Buddha.[524](#footnote-455) 在东方，我们有佛陀成道的基本故事。这个故事的主题集中在曾经被宠坏的贵族变苦行者名叫悉达多 · 乔达摩 (Siddhartha Gautama) 身上。有一天，当坐在一棵菩提树下（连续四十九天）时，年轻的悉达多开悟了。反过来，这棵树被称为启蒙之树。菩提树构成了我们所知的佛陀这个词和形象。 524

Not only do we find trees as symbols in the most widely shared Eastern and Western stories, we also see them in our modern mythic stories. Harry Potter used his wand as a source of power. The Ents were the tree-people in The Lord of The Rings, and in The Game of Thrones, we find the heart tree, the core symbol of Winterfell, as well as the Three-Eyed Raven, an old man who is enfolded in a tree.[525](#footnote-454) 我们不仅在最广泛传播的东西方故事中发现树作为象征，我们还在现代神话故事中看到它们。哈利波特使用他的魔杖作为力量的来源。树人是指环王中的树人，而在权力的游戏中，我们找到心树，即临冬城的核心标志，以及三眼乌鸦，一个被包裹在树中的老人树. 525

**More Resources on Trees 更多关于树木的资源**

It may seem rather absurd to be reading about trees in a book about a knowledge system built entirely of notecards. However, there is more to trees than meets the eye. 在一本关于完全由记事卡构建的知识系统的书中阅读有关树木的内容，这似乎相当荒谬。然而，树木远不止这些。

As I’ve shown you throughout this chapter, there’s applicable power within tree structures and they serve as a fundamental component for how and why the Antinet works so well. 正如我在本章中向您展示的那样，树结构具有适用的力量，它们是 Antinet 如何以及为什么如此运作的基本组成部分。

I won’t go deeper into tree structures any more than I already have. However, I’d like to leave you with a few resources that may be of interest: 我不会再深入研究树结构了。但是，我想为您提供一些您可能感兴趣的资源：

1. Ascoli, Giorgio A. Trees of the Brain, Roots of the Mind. Cambridge, MA, USA: MIT Press, 2015: This is a fascinating book detailing the tree structures that form the basis of our brain (and mind). The author suggests that the human brain is perhaps the most complex object in the universe. It’s comprised of tiny tree-like structures which make up its massive network. Each nerve cell, when enlarged a thousand-fold looks like a tree. It thus follows that regions of the nervous system, when enlarged, resembles a gigantic forest. This book takes a deep dive into the tree-like structures of the brain and explores stunning visualizations of tree networks. 1. Ascoli, Giorgio A. 大脑之树，心灵之根。美国马萨诸塞州剑桥市：麻省理工学院出版社，2015 年：这是一本引人入胜的书，详细介绍了构成我们大脑（和思维）基础的树状结构。作者认为人脑可能是宇宙中最复杂的物体。它由构成其庞大网络的微小树状结构组成。每个神经细胞放大一千倍后都像一棵树。因此，神经系统的区域在扩大时就像一片巨大的森林。这本书深入研究了大脑的树状结构，并探索了令人惊叹的树状网络可视化。

2. Lima, Manuel. The Book of Trees: Visualizing Branches of Knowledge. Illustrated edition. New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 2014: This book takes you through the rich history of the metaphorical visualizations of trees. There are a countless number of beautiful photos in this book which show the many different types of tree visualizations. It’s not only informative, it’s also a wonderful coffee table book!2. 利马，曼努埃尔。树之书：可视化知识分支。图解版。纽约：普林斯顿建筑出版社，2014 年：这本书带您了解树木隐喻可视化的丰富历史。本书中有无数美丽的照片，展示了许多不同类型的树可视化。它不仅内容丰富，还是一本很棒的咖啡桌书！

3. Wohlleben, Peter, Tim Flannery, and Suzanne Simard. The Hidden Life of Trees: What They Feel, How They Communicate—Discoveries from A Secret World. Vancouver, BC, Canada: Greystone Books, 2016: This book shows that trees are a lot more intelligent than we give them credit for. The author shows how forests are a large social network, including how tree parents live together with their children, communicate with them, support them, how they share nutrients with other trees who are sick or struggling, and even warn nearby trees of impending danger.3. Wohlleben、Peter、Tim Flannery 和 Suzanne Simard。树木隐藏的生命：它们的感受，它们如何交流——来自秘密世界的发现。加拿大不列颠哥伦比亚省温哥华：Greystone Books，2016 年：这本书表明树木比我们认为的要聪明得多。作者展示了森林如何成为一个庞大的社交网络，包括树父母如何与孩子一起生活、与他们交流、支持他们，他们如何与其他生病或挣扎的树木分享养分，甚至警告附近的树木即将发生危险。

These resources are more than enough to appease your basic curiosity about tree structures. However, don’t get distracted by them now. We’ve still got another key component of the Antinet to explore: the index! 这些资源足以满足您对树结构的基本好奇心。但是，现在不要被他们分心。我们还有 Antinet 的另一个关键组件需要探索：索引！

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

We’ve covered a lot in this chapter. You’ve learned about the rough tree structure of the Antinet. You’ve been introduced to the deep theoretical implications of the tree structure. We touched on the concepts of order and chaos. We’ve explored the concept of hierarchy, and how the Antinet is not a traditional hierarchical structure (but is rather built on association and proximity). I’ve taken you into the depths of classification systems. And finally, I capped off this chapter with the mythological magic of trees. 我们在本章中介绍了很多内容。您已经了解了 Antinet 的粗略树结构。您已经了解了树结构的深层理论含义。我们谈到了秩序和混乱的概念。我们已经探讨了层次结构的概念，以及 Antinet 为何不是传统的层次结构（而是建立在关联和接近的基础上）。我已带您深入分类系统。最后，我以树木的神话魔法结束了这一章。

This was a lot to cover. Thanks for sticking with me; I promise you’ll be rewarded. You now have a deep theoretical knowledge of the Antinet. This will come in handy in the long term. You’ll find yourself more confident in the system because you know the rich depth in which its theory relies. You won’t risk yet another instance in your life of getting excited about a new system, only to find yourself quitting (and shifting to whatever the next shiny, new object happens to be). The Antinet is it. It’s the very best tool for developing deep thought. It’s the best system for those who wish to become a learning machine, an online content machine, a book-writing machine, and an academic research machine. Keep going. 这涉及很多内容。谢谢你和我在一起；我保证你会得到回报。您现在对 Antinet 有了深入的理论知识。从长远来看，这将派上用场。你会发现自己对这个系统更有信心，因为你知道它的理论所依赖的丰富深度。你不会再冒生命中又一次对新系统感到兴奋的风险，结果却发现自己放弃了（并转移到下一个闪亮的新对象恰好是什么）。 Antinet 就是它。它是培养深度思考的最佳工具。对于那些希望成为学习机器、在线内容机器、写书机器和学术研究机器的人来说，这是最好的系统。继续前进。

In the next chapter, we’ll be diving into a more “practical” area of the Antinet: the index. Press on. 在下一章中，我们将深入 Antinet 的一个更 “实用” 的领域：索引。按下。

CHAPTER NINE 第九章
----------------

Index 指数
--------

“Considering the absence of a systematic order, we must regulate the process of rediscovery of notes, for we cannot rely on our memory of numbers. The alternation of numbers and alphabetic characters in numbering the notecards helps memory and is an optical aid when we search for them, but it is insufficient. Therefore we need a [index] of keywords that we constantly update.”“考虑到没有系统的秩序，我们必须规范重新发现笔记的过程，因为我们不能依赖我们对数字的记忆。记事卡编号时数字和字母字符的交替有助于记忆，并且在我们搜索它们时是一种视觉辅助，但这还不够。因此，我们需要一个我们不断更新的关键字 [索引]。”

–Niklas Luhmann, Communication with Noteboxes[526](#footnote-553)–Niklas Luhmann，与 Noteboxes 的通信 526

**What the Index Is 什么是指数**
---------------------------

In the previous chapter, I touched on how classification systems provide utility in that they create a map of intelligible reality. The tree, with its organized branches of knowledge, proves useful for managing and perusing your knowledge. Yet classification systems have their limits. They confine information into silos and can be rather broad. Thankfully, the tree structure mitigates some of these downsides. Trees enable thoughts to flow and they create stems into more specific areas for thoughts to evolve (over the long term). 在上一章中，我谈到了分类系统如何提供实用性，因为它们可以创建可理解的现实地图。这棵树及其组织的知识分支证明对管理和细读您的知识很有用。然而，分类系统有其局限性。它们将信息限制在孤岛中，而且范围可能相当广泛。值得庆幸的是，树结构减轻了其中的一些缺点。树木使思想流动，它们将茎干形成更具体的区域，以便思想进化（从长远来看）。

However, the tree structure is not enough. The tool that serves as a second-layer map is the index. The index enables one to jump around freely from branch-to-branch, stem-to-stem, and leaf-to-leaf in one’s tree of knowledge. The index transforms the system into something that looks like this: 然而，树结构是不够的。作为第二层地图的工具是索引。该索引使人们能够在自己的知识树中自由地从一个分支到另一个分支、从一个茎到另一个茎、从一个叶子到另一个叶子跳来跳去。索引将系统转换成如下所示：

The index is composed of a special type of notecard containing two things: (1) a keyterm, and (2) a location. 索引由一种特殊类型的记事卡组成，其中包含两件事：(1) 关键字词和 (2) 位置。

As mentioned earlier, a good way to think of the location component of the index is to compare it to latitude and longitude coordinates (e.g., 37.2431°n, 115.7930°w). These can be thought of as the place’s global address.[527](#footnote-552) This is why numeric-alpha addresses are addresses, opposed to being IDs. But we humans don’t think in coordinates, we think in keyterms. 如前所述，考虑索引的位置部分的一个好方法是将其与纬度和经度坐标（例如 37.2431°n，115.7930°w）进行比较。这些可以被认为是该地点的全球地址。 527 这就是为什么数字字母地址是地址，而不是 ID。但我们人类不以坐标思考，我们以关键词思考。

**The Keyterm 关键词**

We humans don’t spend our time thinking and communicating in the equivalent of latitude/longitude coordinates (“lat/long”). As Luhmann put it, “we cannot rely on our memory of numbers.”[528](#footnote-551) We need a human-friendly name to be associated with the lat/long coordinates. We need a key in other words, of a term to associate with the coordinates. This human-friendly key and term is what we call the keyterm. 我们人类不会花时间在相当于纬度 / 经度坐标（“纬度 / 经度”）的地方思考和交流。正如 Luhmann 所说，“我们不能依赖于我们对数字的记忆。”528 我们需要一个人性化的名称来与纬度 / 经度坐标相关联。换句话说，我们需要一个键来与坐标相关联。这个人性化的键和术语就是我们所说的关键字。

The keyterm is simply the name of anything your brain naturally uses to describe the location of something. It can be anything. It can be a person, place, thing, metaphorical concept, idea, or whatever—as long as it can be noted down.[529](#footnote-550) 关键词只是您的大脑自然用来描述某物位置的任何名称。它可以是任何东西。它可以是人、地点、事物、隐喻概念、想法或任何东西——只要能记下来即可。 529

Why the keyterm? Well, I mean, we could try and remember the location of something by memorizing 37.2431°n, 115.7930°w… or we could remember it by associating it with its more human-friendly name: Area 51. I think it’s pretty obvious that the keyterm Area 51 is easier to remember. 为什么是关键词？好吧，我的意思是，我们可以尝试通过记住 37.2431°n、115.7930°w 来记住某物的位置…… 或者我们可以通过将它与更人性化的名称相关联来记住它：51 区。我认为很明显 keyterm Area 51 更容易记住。

With the keyterm, Area 51, we can pair it with a value. We do this by placing a colon (:) between the keyterm and value. The format looks like this: keyterm: ‘value’. For instance, Area 51: ‘37.2431°n, 115.7930°w’. Within the Antinet, the value is not a lat/long coordinate, but a numeric-alpha address (i.e., Area 51: ‘2563/27a’). 使用关键字 Area 51，我们可以将其与值配对。我们通过在关键字和值之间放置一个冒号 (:) 来做到这一点。格式如下所示：keyterm: ‘value’。例如，51 区：‘37.2431°n，115.7930°w’。在 Antinet 中，该值不是纬度 / 经度坐标，而是数字字母地址（即 Area 51：‘2563/27a’）。

In computer science terminology, this is a type of data structure. It’s a key-value pair. It’s known more familiarly as a map or an associative array. 在计算机科学术语中，这是一种数据结构。这是一个键值对。它被更熟悉地称为映射或关联数组。

I like the term associative array, so let’s roll with that. A thesaurus is similar to an associative array. Like a thesaurus, which contains multiple synonyms for a word, you can have multiple values for a keyterm. For instance, Area 51: ‘2563/27a’, ‘5472/3’, ‘3572/22/1/4). In computer-science geek-speak, this is known as a multimap, multihash, or multidict. 我喜欢关联数组这个术语，所以让我们开始吧。词库类似于关联数组。就像包含一个词的多个同义词的词库一样，您可以为一个关键字词设置多个值。例如，51 区：“2563/27a”、“5472/3”、“3572/22/1/4”）。用计算机科学极客的话说，这称为多重映射、多重哈希或多重字典。

**The Purpose of the Index 索引的目的**
----------------------------------

A system relying on complete random chance (with no index and no tree structure) is an undesirable system. It costs more (effort) than it produces. Yet a system of too much order is lifeless and yields a lower probability of generating breakthrough insights. The perfect middle ground is to have a system that employs an organic tree structure that allows both order and chaos to emerge. The perfect mediator to navigate between order and chaos is the index. This is its single, simple purpose.[530](#footnote-549) It’s there to provide you with at least one point of entry into your tree of knowledge related to any given keyterm.[531](#footnote-548) This allows you to begin stumbling upon other leaves of thought, as well as other stems and branches that have since formed around the term. 依赖完全随机机会（没有索引也没有树结构）的系统是不受欢迎的系统。它花费的（努力）比它产生的多。然而，一个过于有序的系统是没有生命力的，并且产生突破性见解的可能性较低。完美的中间立场是拥有一个采用有机树结构的系统，允许秩序和混乱出现。在秩序和混乱之间导航的完美中介是索引。这是它单一、简单的目的。530 它至少为您提供一个进入与任何给定关键词相关的知识树的入口。531 这使您可以开始绊倒思想的其他叶子以及其他茎干以及围绕这个词形成的分支。

Luhmann did not create an exhaustive list of cardlinks for each keyterm. Just because card 5248/3 mentions complexity, doesn’t mean the indexed keyterm for complexity gets a cardlink pointing to 5248/3. Why? Because mentions don’t matter. What matters is that the card address to which the complexity keyterm points actually significantly pertains to the concept itself. Mentions don’t matter much. This makes the index more useful than search. When you search your notes digitally, all sorts of irrelevant mentions show up for the search term. This is not so with the index.Luhmann 没有为每个关键词创建一个详尽的卡片链接列表。仅仅因为卡片 5248/3 提到了复杂性，并不意味着复杂性的索引关键字获得指向 5248/3 的卡片链接。为什么？因为提及并不重要。重要的是复杂性关键字指向的卡片地址实际上与概念本身有很大关系。提及并不重要。这使得索引比搜索更有用。当您以数字方式搜索笔记时，搜索词会出现各种不相关的提及。索引不是这样。

The reason Luhmann did not create cardlinks for every single card mentioning a keyterm is not because it is technically unfeasible (I mean it is, but it’s something that Luhmann wouldn’t have preferred even if he possessed the capability). Rather, the reason Luhmann only included a few cardlinks per keyterm can be distilled down to two reasons:Luhmann 没有为每张提到关键字的卡片创建卡片链接的原因并不是因为它在技术上不可行（我的意思是它是，但即使他拥有这种能力，Luhmann 也不会更喜欢这种东西）。相反，Luhmann 只在每个关键词中包含几个卡片链接的原因可以归结为两个原因：

1. The tree structure of the Antinet allows you to follow the stems of thought the notecard rests on. This then takes you on a journey that reveals more cards related to the concept. It then may take you to a collective card. This is a card containing a collection of cardlinks to other areas of your Antinet (you’ll learn more about collectives later).1. Antinet 的树状结构让您可以跟随记事卡所依据的思路。然后，这将带您踏上一段旅程，揭示更多与该概念相关的卡片。然后它可能会带你到一张集体卡。这是一张卡片，其中包含指向 Antinet 其他区域的卡片链接集合（稍后您将了解有关集合的更多信息）。

2. By creating only a general list of a few cardlinks, it affirms the rough tree structure of the Antinet. It re-emphasizes the expectation that the location provides you with a rough area of your Antinet. It enables your present conscious mind to interact and communicate with your Antinet. You encounter nearby stems of thoughts in the area that surprise you. When such a communication takes place, breakthrough insights occur which have come about by complete accident. The power of this communication experience will be detailed later in the book.2. 通过仅创建几个卡片链接的一般列表，它确认了 Antinet 的粗略树结构。它再次强调了该位置为您提供 Antinet 的粗略区域的期望。它使你当前的意识思维能够与你的 Antinet 互动和交流。您会在附近的区域遇到让您感到惊讶的想法。当这样的交流发生时，突破性的见解就会出现，而这完全是偶然的。这种沟通体验的力量将在本书后面详细介绍。

The reason there are but a few cardlinks for each keyterm entry is that it sets you on a path of exploration. It enables you to explore your tree of knowledge. This also highlights another downside of digital systems. Lacking the nested tree-like structures of the Antinet, digital systems are just a flat-level view of connected bubbles. This knowledge work, however, is not just about storing information and creating cool bubble graphs; it’s about exploration. The tree structure of the Antinet enables meaningful exploration. As Alberto Cevolini writes, “secondary memories themselves have an inner order that allows for exploration.”[532](#footnote-547) 每个关键字条目只有几个卡片链接的原因是它会让您走上探索之路。它使您能够探索您的知识树。这也突出了数字系统的另一个缺点。缺少 Antinet 的嵌套树状结构，数字系统只是连接气泡的平面视图。然而，这种知识工作不仅仅是存储信息和创建炫酷的气泡图；这是关于探索。 Antinet 的树结构使有意义的探索成为可能。正如阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 所写，“次级记忆本身具有允许探索的内在秩序。”532

The Antinet is a long-term storage container of your short-term store of thoughts. In itself, it’s a single storage of your mind’s thoughts. It transforms your short-term memory and long-term memory into one holistic entity (a second mind). The index is a secondary storage container which allows you to navigate your second mind.Antinet 是您短期思想存储的长期存储容器。就其本身而言，它是您思想的单一存储。它将您的短期记忆和长期记忆转化为一个整体实体（第二思维）。该索引是一个辅助存储容器，可让您导航您的第二个想法。

It took a long time for humans to realize that you could create a secondary container (that is, a secondary map) for exploring your own knowledge. It wasn’t until the latter half of the sixteenth century that scholars realized the index could be used as a secondary data storage for navigating the main memory store.[533](#footnote-546) 人类花了很长时间才意识到可以创建一个二级容器（即二级地图）来探索自己的知识。直到 16 世纪下半叶，学者们才意识到索引可以用作辅助数据存储来导航主内存存储。 533

Luhmann was sage in not overlooking the rather new technology of the index. Inspired by The Royal Society of London, Luhmann created his own index, which he called a register. In specific notes in his Antinet, Luhmann mentions having paid attention to how the Royal Society developed their register of knowledge.[534](#footnote-545) Like Johannes Schmidt, though, I prefer the term index to refer to Luhmann’s register. You’re welcome to use whichever terminology you prefer. Heck, in the beginning I used to refer to it as the map. Yet the name that’s stuck for me is index, and that’s what I shall use from here on.Luhmann 明智地没有忽视指数这一相当新的技术。受到伦敦皇家学会的启发，卢曼创建了自己的索引，他称之为寄存器。在他的 Antinet 中的特定注释中，卢曼提到了他对皇家学会如何发展他们的知识登记册的关注。 534 不过，像约翰内斯施密特一样，我更喜欢术语索引来指代卢曼的登记册。欢迎您使用您喜欢的任何术语。哎呀，一开始我习惯把它称为地图。然而，为我保留的名称是索引，这就是我从这里开始使用的名称。

**The Power of the Index 指数的力量**
--------------------------------

As the scholar who has studied Luhmann’s Antinet most closely, Johannes Schmidt, deems the index “a central key to the system.”[535](#footnote-544) The elimination of a fixed classification system and the lack of table of contents turn the index into a “key tool” for using the file. As Schmidt puts it, “how else should one be able to find certain notes again and thus gain access to the system of references?”[536](#footnote-543) In brief, the index is a critical component in using an Antinet. 约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 是对卢曼的 Antinet 研究得最深入的学者，他认为索引是 “系统的中心钥匙”。535 固定分类系统的消除和目录的缺失使索引成为“关键工具” 用于使用该文件。正如 Schmidt 所说，“人们还应该如何才能再次找到某些笔记，从而获得对参考系统的访问权？”536 简而言之，索引是使用 Antinet 的关键组成部分。

The index is the conduit by which your brain “structurally couples” itself to the thoughts compiled into an inanimate box. It is the component that breathes life into the Antinet, thereby creating a second mind, an alter ego with which you can communicate. 索引是你的大脑将自己 “结构性地耦合” 到一个无生命盒子中的思想的管道。它是为 Antinet 注入生命的组成部分，从而创造出第二个思想，一个可以与之交流的另一个自我。

This isn’t woo-woo fuzzy jargon; it’s backed by knowledge science. “Memory lies not in the machine,” says the scholar, Alberto Cevolini, “but the structural coupling of users and machines, that is, in the indexing system.”[537](#footnote-542) Indeed, the index stands as the core property which transitions the Antinet from merely a container of others’ thoughts, into “an actual writing generator,” observes the scholar Élisabeth Décultot.[538](#footnote-541) 这不是模糊的行话；它得到知识科学的支持。 “记忆不在机器中，” 学者 Alberto Cevolini 说，“而是用户和机器的结构耦合，即在索引系统中。”537 事实上，索引是 Antinet 从 Antinet 过渡的核心属性。学者 Élisabeth Décultot 观察到，仅仅是其他人思想的容器，变成了 “一个真正的写作生成器”。 538

**Cued Recall 提示召回**

Cued recall is the modern cognitive scientific term for the no-longer-favored term recollection. It occurs when a stimulus (for example a word, sound, or image) elicits a memory of another item with which it is linked.[539](#footnote-540) Basically, cued recall works by invoking a memory when presented with a keyterm as the prompt.Cued recall 是现代认知科学术语，指的是不再受欢迎的术语 recollection。它发生在刺激（例如一个词、声音或图像）引起与其相关联的另一个项目的记忆时。539 基本上，提示回忆通过以关键词作为提示呈现时调用记忆来工作。

When you create a deliberate, hand-written keyterm entry in your index, you are neuroimprinting a cue into your mind. 当你在你的索引中创建一个有意的、手写的关键词条目时，你正在将一个提示植入你的脑海。

Let’s take an example. Say you’ve read Cal Newport’s book, So Good They Can’t Ignore You. A key idea in that book revolves around something called deliberate practice. Deliberate practice is setting aside a deliberately planned time to practice a skill—regardless of whether the activity is enjoyable (oftentimes, it isn’t).[540](#footnote-539) In the context of the Antinet, if you’re interested in this particular concept, you would undertake a time-intensive process. First you would write down the idea on the bibcard related to Newport’s book. After that, you would create a maincard for the idea. On the maincard you would either excerpt the idea (by writing down a quote by hand), reformulate the idea (by summarizing it in your own words), or reflect on the idea (by adding your own take, experience, and thoughts on the idea).
