After this phase, you would then create a keyterm of the idea, consolidating it into a brief word or phrase. 让我们举个例子。假设您读过 Cal Newport 的书，他们无法忽视您。那本书的一个关键思想围绕着一种叫做刻意练习的东西。刻意练习是留出刻意计划的时间来练习一项技能——不管这项活动是否令人愉快（通常不是）。540 在 Antinet 的背景下，如果你对这个特定概念感兴趣，你会进行一个耗时的过程。首先，你会在与 Newport 的书相关的 bibcard 上写下这个想法。之后，您将为该想法创建一张主卡。在主卡上，您可以摘录这个想法（通过手写引述）、重新表述这个想法（通过用您自己的话总结），或者反思这个想法（通过在上面添加您自己的看法、经验和想法）主意）。在此阶段之后，您将创建该想法的关键词，将其合并为一个简短的单词或短语。

Whenever you begin reading a new book and you come across an idea that relates to deliberate practice, you can recall that you already have a keyterm in your Antinet that elaborates on this area. From there, you may either, (1) recall what you already know about deliberate practice (thanks to neuroimprinting you can remember what you already know), and (2) you can simply write down the term deliberate practice and the page number on the new bibcard. From there you can refer to your Antinet and explore the branches and stems of what you already know about deliberate practice. At that point you can develop the thought further by creating a dedicated maincard for it. If you don’t feel it is necessary to develop a maincard, you can simply write down the external reference of the book and page number (thereby letting the idea ruminate). 每当您开始阅读一本新书并遇到与刻意练习相关的想法时，您都可以回想起您的 Antinet 中已经有一个关键术语详细说明了这一领域。从那里，你可以，(1) 回忆你已经知道的关于刻意练习的知识（多亏了神经印记，你可以记住你已经知道的东西），以及 (2) 你可以简单地写下刻意练习这个术语和页码新的比卡。从那里你可以参考你的 Antinet 并探索你已经知道的关于刻意练习的分支和主干。到那时，您可以通过为其创建专用的主卡来进一步发展思想。如果你觉得没有必要开发主卡，你可以简单地写下本书的外部参考和页码（从而让想法反省）。

In brief, because you’ve been intentional in creating a keyterm for an idea, you begin to read differently. While reading, when you come across ideas and concepts related to deliberate practice, you develop a greater capability to do several things: 简而言之，因为你一直有意为一个想法创造一个关键词，你开始阅读不同的东西。在阅读时，当你遇到与刻意练习相关的想法和概念时，你会发展出更强的能力来做几件事：

1. While reading, the concept you recall may be deemed important enough that you decide to extract a new relevant bit of information. As mentioned previously, you may either (1) excerpt it, (2) reformulate it, or (3) elaborate on it. 1. 阅读时，你回忆起的概念可能被认为足够重要，以至于你决定提取一些新的相关信息。如前所述，您可以 (1) 摘录它，(2) 重新表述它，或者 (3) 详细说明它。

2. You’ve deliberately primed your mind, and have selected the idea of deliberate practice as important. Because you’ve intentionally created a keyterm for the idea, and since you have installed the concept in your Antinet, you may recall the concepts related to it. This is made possible, thanks to the tree structure. You can begin to piece together concepts related to it.2. 你已经刻意地启动了你的思维，并选择了刻意练习的想法作为重要的。因为你有意为这个想法创建了一个关键词，并且因为你已经在你的 Antinet 中安装了这个概念，所以你可能会回忆起与之相关的概念。多亏了树结构，这才成为可能。您可以开始拼凑与之相关的概念。

3. Another benefit is that since you know you’ve written something valuable about the keyterm already, you are more motivated to review what you’ve already written about the concept in your Antinet. I often find myself surprised when I review keyterms. I recall key ideas I’ve long forgotten about.3. 另一个好处是，因为你知道你已经写了一些关于关键词的有价值的东西，你更有动力去回顾你已经在 Antinet 中写的关于这个概念的东西。当我复习关键词时，我常常发现自己很惊讶。我想起了我早已忘记的关键思想。

**Deliberate Indexing is Different from Tagging 故意索引不同于标记**

As others have observed, so-called “rigid folders” have fallen out of fashion in the modern personal-knowledge-management field. The new popular practice revolves around creating tags (that is, tagging notes).[541](#footnote-538) 正如其他人所观察到的，所谓的 “死板文件夹” 在现代个人知识管理领域已经过时了。新的流行做法围绕创建标签（即标记笔记）展开。 541

Digital Zettelkasten practitioners may learn of Luhmann’s index and deliberate keyterms, and then liken the process to that of tagging notes. They may then proceed to tag every single one of their notes. 数字 Zettelkasten 从业者可能会学习 Luhmann 的索引和故意的关键词，然后将这个过程比作标记笔记的过程。然后他们可以继续标记他们的每一个笔记。

There’s a difference, however, in how Luhmann used his Antinet. His keyterms served as an entry point into his tree of knowledge (and its branches and stems of thought). Keyterms were used sparingly to get you started on the path of exploring your notes organically by way of exploration. However, as has been observed, tagging is not so central and it’s not intensely necessary that every note needs to be tagged.[542](#footnote-537) 然而，卢曼使用 Antinet 的方式有所不同。他的关键词是进入他的知识之树（及其思想的分支和主干）的切入点。关键词语被谨慎使用，让您开始通过探索的方式有机地探索您的笔记。然而，正如已经观察到的那样，标记并不是那么重要，并不是每个音符都需要标记。 542

Furthermore, when you tag your notes using digital Zettelkasten tools, it’s possible to over-tag notes. It naturally follows that it thereby “cheapens” the individual tag. A note with a powerful idea about truth is lumped together with other notes tagged with truth—even ideas vaguely relating to the concept of truth. With digital systems that enable easy and low-cost information collection, the bad ends up drowning out the good. 此外，当您使用数字 Zettelkasten 工具标记笔记时，可能会过度标记笔记。自然而然地，它因此使单个标签 “便宜”。一个关于真理的强烈想法的笔记与其他标记为真理的笔记混为一谈——甚至是与真理概念模糊相关的想法。数字系统可以轻松、低成本地收集信息，坏事最终会淹没好事。

To understand the different nature of the index system vs. digital tagging, the following diagram helps illustrate the nature of the two: 要了解索引系统与数字标签的不同性质，下图有助于说明两者的性质：

Tagging misses out on the unique branching structure of notes. It results in flat, weak relations and bubble graphs. Because of the tendency to tag anything and everything, a bunch of weak connections and useless material also becomes linked together. Essentially, the tendency to tag every note creates an information swamp. Tagging embodies the typical structure of digital Zettelkasten systems. It creates a pile of leaves on the ground with vines connecting weakly-associated leaves together. 标记错过了音符的独特分支结构。它会导致平坦、弱的关系和气泡图。由于倾向于标记任何东西，一堆薄弱的联系和无用的材料也会联系在一起。从本质上讲，标记每个笔记的趋势会造成信息沼泽。标记体现了数字 Zettelkasten 系统的典型结构。它在地面上创造了一堆叶子，藤蔓将弱关联的叶子连接在一起。

**A Guide to the Index 索引指南**
-----------------------------

There are three boxes in the Antinet: (1) the bibliography box (the “bib box”), (2) the main box of the Antinet storing thoughts by concept in the numeric-alpha tree structure (the “main box”), and (3) the index box containing keyterms that point one to locations in the Antinet (the “index box”).Antinet 中有三个框：(1) bibliography 框（“bib 框”），(2) Antinet 的主框，在数字 - alpha 树结构中按概念存储思想（“主框”）， (3) 包含指向 Antinet 中位置的关键字的索引框（“索引框”）。

The index box contains a list of alphabetized cards. There are two types of cards in the index: (1) List Indexcards, and (2) Keyterm Indexcards. Let’s cover these now. 索引框包含按字母顺序排列的卡片列表。索引中有两种类型的卡片：(1) List Indexcards，和 (2) Keyterm Indexcards。现在让我们介绍这些。

**List Indexcards 列表索引卡**

List indexcards are cards filed alphabetically, each pertaining to one letter of 列表索引卡是按字母顺序归档的卡片，每张卡片对应一个字母

the alphabet (A, B, C, etc.). Under the assigned alphabetical character is a list of keyterms that begin with the letter affixed to the card. 字母表（A、B、C 等）。在分配的字母字符下方是一系列以贴在卡片上的字母开头的关键词。

These cards serve as an associative array of key-value pairs. The key is the keyterm, and the value is the address of a card in the main box of the Antinet. 这些卡片用作键值对的关联数组。 key 是 keyterm，value 是 Antinet 主机箱中一张卡的地址。

When you first start out building your Antinet, you should begin by creating 26 list indexcards (one for each letter in the alphabet). 当您第一次开始构建 Antinet 时，您应该首先创建 26 个列表索引卡（一个对应字母表中的每个字母）。

**Examples of List Indexcards 列表索引卡示例**

The following list indexcard is from Luhmann (it’s a Luhmannian list indexcard): 以下列表索引卡来自 Luhmann（这是一个 Luhmannian 列表索引卡）：

photo credit: “ZK I: Note in the Subject Index (002-A)—Niklas Luhmann Archive,” accessed April 1, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_SW1_002_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_SW1_002_V). 照片来源：“ZK I：主题索引 (002-A) 中的注释——Niklas Luhmann 档案”，2022 年 4 月 1 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_SW1_002_V。

You’ll notice a few things from the card. First, there is a red letter A in the top left corner. This signifies that these are keyterms beginning with A. The second thing you’ll notice is that the keyterms in the list are not alphabetical. For instance, Argument comes before Aggressivität. The list of keyterms accumulates over time, organically, and in an emergent fashion. The words are organized temporally (by time). The only requirement is that they begin with the letter A. 你会从卡片上注意到一些事情。首先，左上角有一个红色的字母 A。这表示这些是以 A 开头的关键字。您会注意到的第二件事是列表中的关键字不是按字母顺序排列的。例如，Argument 出现在 Aggressivität 之前。关键词列表会随着时间的推移、有机地、以紧急方式积累。这些词是按时间（按时间）组织的。唯一的要求是它们以字母 A 开头。

Here is a list indexcard from my own Antinet (a Scheperian list indexcard): 这是我自己的 Antinet 中的列表索引卡（Scheperian 列表索引卡）：

You’ll notice a few differences in my own version. First, you’ll see there’s a convention with arrows. For instance Contradictions → Polarity. This tells me to navigate to the Polarity keyterm in my index box. The second thing you’ll notice are conventions like SA: ‘1805/9’. SA means See Also. Third, you’ll see that the top of the card reads C (2). This tells me that it’s the second list indexcard for the letter C. Fourth, you’ll notice that I cross out certain keyterm entries. For instance Change (Formula For)…is crossed out. This tells me to go see the dedicated keyterm indexcard, which you’ll learn about next. 你会注意到我自己的版本有一些不同。首先，你会看到有一个带箭头的约定。例如矛盾→极性。这告诉我导航到索引框中的 Polarity 关键字。您会注意到的第二件事是像 SA 这样的约定：‘1805/9’。 SA 表示另见。第三，你会看到卡片的顶部写着 C (2)。这告诉我这是字母 C 的第二张列表索引卡。第四，你会注意到我划掉了某些关键词条目。例如 Change (Formula For)… 被划掉了。这告诉我去看看专用的关键字索引卡，你将在接下来了解它。

**Keyterm Indexcards 关键字索引卡**

A keyterm indexcard, as opposed to a list indexcard, is a dedicated card 与列表索引卡相反，关键字索引卡是专用卡

listing multiple links or external references for a given keyterm. Whenever a keyterm entry in a list indexcard accumulates multiple cardlinks, you’ll want to create a dedicated keyterm indexcard for it. 列出给定关键字的多个链接或外部引用。每当列表索引卡中的关键字条目累积多个卡片链接时，您需要为其创建一个专用的关键字索引卡。

Here’s an example of a keyterm indexcard: 这是一个关键字索引卡的示例：

This keyterm indexcard is for the keyterm Change. It displays the crossed-out entries from the list, such as Formula For: ‘5409/0’, which becomes Formula for Change; and the listed keyterm and Business; ‘5100/1’ becomes Change and Business. The entry State  ‘State’ refers to changing state (as in changing one’s state of mind), and the arrow prompts me to go see the dedicated keyterm indexcard ‘State.’此关键字索引卡用于关键字更改。它显示列表中被划掉的条目，例如 Formula For: ‘5409/0’，它变成 Formula for Change；以及列出的关键字和业务； “5100/1” 成为变革和商业。条目状态“状态” 指的是改变状态（如改变一个人的心态），箭头提示我去查看专用关键字索引卡 “状态”。

**The Index Box 索引框**

Within the index box, the indexcards should be organized alphabetically. The list indexcards are placed immediately after the letter-dividers, followed by the keyterm indexcards. Each of the following keyterm indexcards starting with the same letter should then be organized alphabetically relative to each other. 在索引框中，索引卡应按字母顺序排列。列表索引卡紧跟在字母分隔符之后，然后是关键字索引卡。以下每个以相同字母开头的关键字索引卡应按字母顺序相对于彼此组织。

To illustrate, on the following page is a picture of my index box. Behind the A divider, you’ll first encounter the A (1) list indexcard (note that the yellow A (4) card is visible in this photo). 为了说明，下一页是我的索引框的图片。在 A 分隔线后面，您首先会遇到 A (1) 列表索引卡（请注意，黄色 A (4) 卡在此照片中可见）。

Here is another photo. Likewise, the C (1) list indexcard follows the letter C divider; here there are several more list indexcards, which ends with C (4).Immediately behind C (4) the sequence of my keyterm indexcards begins. The first keyterm indexcard is Candor (Candidness). 这是另一张照片。同样，C (1) 列表索引卡跟在字母 C 分隔符之后；这里还有几个列表索引卡，以 C (4) 结尾。紧接在 C (4) 之后，我的关键字索引卡序列开始。第一个关键字索引卡是 Candor（坦诚）。

Following this card, is the next card in the alphabetical list: Categorization. 在这张卡片之后，是按字母顺序排列的列表中的下一张卡片：分类。

This gives you a good practical taste of the components involved in building out an index. 这使您对构建索引所涉及的组件有一个很好的实际体验。

**Search is a Bug, Not a Feature 搜索是一个错误，而不是一个功能**
--------------------------------------------------

When you use the index component of the Antinet to search, you’re exploring. When you search notes digitally, the internal dialogue is different. You’re not so much exploring as you are filtering. In essence, you are simply trying to recognize and sift through signals. Oftentimes, you spend a great deal of time sifting through keywords that show up in the search results. 当你使用 Antinet 的索引组件进行搜索时，你就是在探索。当您以数字方式搜索笔记时，内部对话是不同的。与其说你在探索，不如说你在过滤。本质上，您只是在尝试识别和筛选信号。通常，您会花费大量时间筛选出现在搜索结果中的关键字。

Many people who have written about (digital) Zettelkasten miss the fact that search is a bug, and not a feature. Why? Perhaps it stems from the perennial human tendency of not recognizing and questioning inaccurate assumptions. 许多写过（数字）Zettelkasten 的人都忽略了一个事实，即搜索是一个错误，而不是一个功能。为什么？也许这源于人类长期不承认和质疑不准确假设的倾向。

A significant portion of the book Thinkertoys, a book focused on improving thinking, centers on challenging assumptions.[543](#footnote-536) It’s simply difficult and hard work to invert and challenge all of your assumptions all the time. It’s exhausting. It’s no surprise that many digital Zettelkasten practitioners have never stopped to actually question the value of search since we live in the GAMA era: Google, Apple, Meta (Facebook), and Amazon. In this GAMA era, we have a collective bias and acceptance of digital search being a desired feature in all cases.Thinkertoys 这本书的重要部分，一本专注于提高思维的书，以挑战假设为中心。 543 一直推翻和挑战你所有的假设是一件非常困难和艰苦的工作。这很累人。毫不奇怪，自从我们生活在 GAMA 时代以来，许多数字 Zettelkasten 从业者从未停止过真正质疑搜索的价值：谷歌、苹果、Meta (Facebook) 和亚马逊。在这个 GAMA 时代，我们有一种集体偏见，并且接受数字搜索是所有情况下都需要的功能。

The assumption that the search function is a universally desirable feature is what plagues digital Zettelkasten systems. For instance, one author declares digital systems to be better because they “allow you to search whole databases.”[544](#footnote-535) Yet digital search possesses a wealth of insidious negative effects that are difficult to spot with the naked eye. The downsides of such a system become apparent only after investing significant time and energy creating a large enough note database in the first place. 认为搜索功能是普遍需要的功能的假设困扰着数字 Zettelkasten 系统。例如，一位作者宣称数字系统更好，因为它们 “允许您搜索整个数据库”。544 然而，数字搜索具有大量难以用肉眼发现的潜在负面影响。只有在首先投入大量时间和精力创建足够大的笔记数据库之后，这种系统的缺点才会变得明显。

As Alberto Cevolini points out, digital search is disappointing for at least two reasons. 正如 Alberto Cevolini 指出的那样，数字搜索至少有两个原因令人失望。

The first reason is that search results are “too large.”[545](#footnote-534) With a digital notetaking app this quickly becomes obvious, and it only gets worse over time. Unfortunately, by the time things get unbearable, you’re faced with a massive number of notes. The sunk-cost dilemma (sticking with a system that is ineffective just because you’ve invested so much time and energy in building that system) is a real problem. 第一个原因是搜索结果 “太大”。545 使用数字笔记应用程序，这很快就会变得很明显，而且随着时间的推移只会变得更糟。不幸的是，当事情变得难以忍受时，您将面临大量音符。沉没成本困境（坚持一个无效的系统只是因为你在构建该系统上投入了太多时间和精力）是一个真正的问题。

Having an app that indexes every single word of your thoughts ends up drowning out the attention you would otherwise spend creating deliberate and carefully selected keyterms. 拥有一个可以为您的想法中的每个单词编制索引的应用程序最终会淹没您的注意力，否则您会花在创建经过深思熟虑和精心挑选的关键词上。

The second reason digital search is disappointing echoes this issue. “The complete number of results,” Cevolini writes, “is never a reliable panorama of what is actually stored in secondary memory and it is not necessarily informative.”[546](#footnote-533) 数字搜索令人失望的第二个原因与这个问题相呼应。 “结果的完整数量，”Cevolini 写道，“从来都不是二级记忆中实际存储内容的可靠全景图，而且不一定提供信息。”546

The cognitive psychologist and bestselling author Steven Pinker, provides an observation backing this notion. In an “optimally designed” information and knowledge system like the Antinet, search results should only yield items where “the relevance of the item outweighs the cost of retrieving it.”[547](#footnote-532) The problem with digital systems, however, is that the cost of retrieval is so low that it yields information and knowledge that is of low relevance and low value. I contend that the Antinet does not suffer the same effect. 认知心理学家和畅销书作家史蒂文平克提供了支持这一观点的观察。在像 Antinet 这样的 “优化设计” 的信息和知识系统中，搜索结果应该只产生 “项目的相关性超过检索它的成本” 的项目。 547 然而，数字系统的问题是检索成本如此之低，以至于它产生的信息和知识的相关性和价值都很低。我认为 Antinet 不会受到同样的影响。

Although it seems counter-intuitive, human-domain experts outperform search algorithms even today. Take this illustration from Pinker: 尽管这似乎违反直觉，但即使在今天，人类领域专家的表现也优于搜索算法。以 Pinker 的插图为例：

Anyone who has used a computerized library retrieval system quickly comes to rue the avalanche of titles spilling across the screen. A human expert, despite our allegedly feeble powers of retrieval, vastly outperforms any computer in locating a piece of information from its content. When I need to find articles in a topic in an unfamiliar field, I don’t use the library computer; I send an email to a pal in the field.[548](#footnote-531) 任何使用过计算机化图书馆检索系统的人都会很快对屏幕上溢出的大量书名感到懊悔。人类专家，尽管据称我们的检索能力微弱，但在从内容中定位信息方面远远优于任何计算机。当我需要在一个不熟悉的领域中查找某个主题的文章时，我不会使用图书馆的计算机；我给现场的朋友发了一封电子邮件。548

This is something also observed by computer science professor and bestselling author, Cal Newport. He advises his readers to talk to reference librarians. “I’m amazed by how often this resource is overlooked,” Newport writes. “Ask the librarian for research help and she will guide you to some amazing sources you would have never found on your own. These extra discoveries make the difference between an average paper and one that shines.”[549](#footnote-530) 计算机科学教授兼畅销书作家卡尔纽波特也观察到了这一点。他建议他的读者与参考图书馆员交谈。 “我对这种资源被忽视的频率感到惊讶，” 纽波特写道。 “向图书管理员寻求研究帮助，她会引导你找到一些你自己永远找不到的惊人资源。这些额外的发现使普通论文与出色论文之间存在差异。”549

**Antinet Search Equals Exploration; Digital Search Equals Filtering Irrelevant Information 反网搜索等于探索；数字搜索等于过滤无关信息**

When you are trying to find something in your Antinet, think of it like Tarzan swinging through trees. He swings from branch to branch and then along stems and leaves of thought. Every time you swing to a different branch by way of vines (links), you trigger a reverberation event. You’re reminding yourself not just of the idea, but of the area and stems of thought around the idea. This experience is lost via digital search. You’re presented with a plethora of useless information. With the Antinet, you’re engaged in the experience of jumping from branch to branch through your knowledge. With digital search, you’re not even in the jungle. You’re in a dim office somewhere reading about the jungle through a computer screen. 当你试图在你的 Antinet 中找到一些东西时，把它想象成泰山在树间摇摆。他从一个分支到另一个分支，然后沿着思想的茎叶摇摆。每次通过藤蔓（链接）摆动到不同的分支时，都会触发混响事件。你不仅要提醒自己这个想法，还要提醒自己围绕这个想法的领域和思路。这种体验通过数字搜索丢失了。您会收到大量无用的信息。使用 Antinet，您将体验到通过您的知识从一个分支跳到另一个分支的体验。使用数字搜索，您甚至不在丛林中。你在一间昏暗的办公室里，通过电脑屏幕阅读有关丛林的信息。

The Antinet allows you to experience the power of exploration. It promotes a way of exploring that is curious, deliberate, and that operates within a general and rough context. This is akin to the experience of being in a library and exploring shelved books. Oftentimes, you happen upon profoundly valuable books by way of accidental discovery just by walking down a row in the library that interests you—even if it’s somewhat unrelated to your current project. In doing this, you may stumble upon a book that becomes a critical component of the project or book you’re working on. Digitally searching your notes eliminates this magical experience.Antinet 让您体验探索的力量。它提倡一种探索的方式，这种探索方式是好奇的、深思熟虑的，并且在一般和粗略的背景下运作。这类似于在图书馆探索书架上的书籍的体验。很多时候，你只是在图书馆里走一排你感兴趣的东西，偶然发现了一些非常有价值的书——即使它与你当前的项目有些无关。在这样做的过程中，您可能会偶然发现一本书成为您正在处理的项目或书籍的重要组成部分。数字化搜索您的笔记消除了这种神奇的体验。

The digital Zettelkasten proselytizers oftentimes think that linking is the core component of Zettelkasten systems. This couldn’t be further from the truth. An entire industry of apps and courses revolve around the idea of linking notes. Yet linking does is not the core component of Zettelkasten systems. It is but one property, along with indexing and others, that makes the system work. 数字 Zettelkasten 的传播者通常认为链接是 Zettelkasten 系统的核心组成部分。这与事实相去甚远。整个应用程序和课程行业都围绕着链接笔记的想法展开。然而，链接并不是 Zettelkasten 系统的核心组成部分。使系统工作的只是一个属性，连同索引和其他属性。

For instance, the analog nature of the Antinet makes full-text search impossible. It forces users to explicitly create very selective links between thoughts. Why? Because you know there’s no full-text search that possesses the illusion of saving you later on. When you’re writing out a note by hand, and you think of a related note, you must create the link right then and there. There’s no safety net. Laziness, in other words, is not an option. 例如，Antinet 的模拟特性使得全文搜索变得不可能。它迫使用户明确地在思想之间建立非常有选择性的联系。为什么？因为您知道没有全文搜索具有稍后拯救您的幻觉。当你手写笔记时，你想到了相关的笔记，你必须当场创建链接。没有安全网。换句话说，懒惰不是一种选择。

As a result, you invest more energy in creating very selective links. You end up hardcoding cardlinks into your notes with the result that you end up taking them more seriously than you would cheaply created digital wikilinks. After investing that energy, it’s more likely that you will follow the cardlinks and explore your notes, which then takes you to new places in your Antinet where you might stumble upon other information that would lead to more accidental breakthrough insights. 结果，您投入了更多精力来创建非常有选择性的链接。你最终将卡片链接硬编码到你的笔记中，结果你最终会比廉价创建数字 wiki 链接更认真地对待它们。投入精力后，您更有可能跟随卡片链接并探索您的笔记，然后将您带到 Antinet 中的新位置，在那里您可能会偶然发现其他信息，从而导致更多意外的突破性见解。

**The Bugs of Digital Search 数字搜索的错误**

**Digital Search Robs You of Maintenance Rehearsal Learning and Association 数字搜索剥夺了您的维护排练学习和协会**

Manually flipping through your old notes and reviewing them strengths your 手动翻阅旧笔记并复习它们可以增强你的能力

long-term memory; it gives more opportunities for maintenance rehearsal (talked about in detail in this book). 长期记忆; 它为维护演练提供了更多机会（在本书中详细讨论）。

Searching your Antinet relates to the process of reviewing flash cards for an exam. Yet it’s not painfully boring like rote learning usually is. Rote learning is a memorization technique based on repetition—it’s essentially maintenance rehearsal that allows you to keep an idea fresh in your mind, then refresh it when your memory lags. Yet, with the Antinet, it’s a different flavor of maintenance rehearsal. While you’re reviewing your old ideas, you’re oftentimes holding a new card idea in your mind. Why? Because you’re on a quest to install a new idea that you’re probably excited about into your Antinet. The name of the game is similarity. You’re on a quest, looking for the most similar idea to install this card next to. This entire quest is a fun process, it even improves mood, which I’ll detail shortly. In brief, digital search lacks such a process. 搜索您的 Antinet 与复习用于考试的闪存卡的过程有关。然而，它并不像通常的死记硬背那样枯燥乏味。死记硬背是一种基于重复的记忆技巧——它本质上是一种维护性排练，让你的脑海中保持新鲜的想法，然后在记忆滞后时刷新它。然而，对于 Antinet，这是一种不同风格的维护排练。当你回顾你的旧想法时，你的脑海中经常会有一个新的卡片想法。为什么？因为您正在寻求将您可能会兴奋的新想法安装到您的 Antinet 中。游戏的名称是相似性。您正在寻找最相似的想法来将这张卡安装在旁边。整个任务是一个有趣的过程，它甚至可以改善心情，我将在稍后详细介绍。简而言之，数字搜索缺乏这样一个过程。

By using a digital Zettelkasten, you thwart the richness of the process of inducing maintenance rehearsal while searching for the most-closely associated idea in the Antinet. 通过使用数字 Zettelkasten，您可以在 Antinet 中搜索最密切相关的想法时阻止诱导维护排练过程的丰富性。

**Digital Search Kills the Magic of Structured Accidents 数字搜索扼杀了结构性事故的魔力**

When perusing a library, structured accidents often occur. The accidental discovery of an incredible book is not a completely random accident, it’s a structured accident. After all, the book is contained within a structured contextual area of the library. It’s not completely random. 在阅读图书馆时，经常会发生结构化事故。偶然发现一本不可思议的书并不是完全随机的，而是有组织的。毕竟，这本书包含在图书馆的结构化上下文区域中。这不是完全随机的。

The magic of the Antinet is not only in how it fosters your thinking of and associating the new concept from the book you’ve read with what it relates to (that’s a conventional interaction). Rather, the magic of the Antinet comes from discoveries “which were never planned, never preconceived, or conceived.”[550](#footnote-529) Important discoveries come about not so much by way of your current thinking; they come about by realizing the magical connections you first missed in your old way of thinking. They also come about by way of structured accidents.Antinet 的魔力不仅在于它如何促进你思考并将你读过的书中的新概念与它相关的东西联系起来（这是一种传统的互动）。相反，Antinet 的魔力来自于 “从未计划、从未先入为主或构想过的发现”。550 重要的发现并不是通过你当前的思维方式产生的；它们是通过意识到您在旧思维方式中最初错过的神奇联系而产生的。它们也通过结构性事故发生。

The power of accidents will be covered later in this book, however, let’s take a look at a few examples. 事故的力量将在本书后面介绍，但是，让我们看几个例子。

The following is an example of a more conventional interaction that reveals somewhat interesting insights. 以下是一个更传统的交互示例，它揭示了一些有趣的见解。

Because association is at the core of the fallacy, the keyterm points me to this area of my Antinet. 那里有一个奇怪的条目，写为 Fallacy of: (Persian Messenger): ‘2432/4’。这与波斯信使谬误有关，通常被称为射杀携带坏消息并因此与坏消息相关联的信使。因为联想是谬误的核心，所以关键词将我指向 Antinet 的这个区域。

This type of thing often occurs in digital search. This, however, is not an unconventional insight. Nor is it something that necessarily produces breakthrough creative insights. 这种事情经常发生在数字搜索中。然而，这并不是一个非常规的见解。它也不一定会产生突破性的创造性见解。

Breakthrough insights come about by way of unconventional interactions. They come about by way of structured accidents. This is why it’s critical, in Luhmann’s words, that your “selection and comparisons are not identical with the schema of searching for them.”[551](#footnote-528) Simply searching for a keyword robs the potential for innovation to occur. You are only presented with information you feel is related at the time. Ingenious insights come from unconventional discoveries you make along the way. The breakthrough ideas that come from flipping through your related past thoughts, in a structured way, are what unlock truly unconventional interactions. The tree structure of the Antinet induces these structured accidents. 突破性的见解来自非常规的互动。它们是通过结构化事故产生的。这就是为什么用卢曼的话来说，你的 “选择和比较与搜索它们的模式不同” 是至关重要的。 551 简单地搜索关键字会剥夺创新发生的可能性。您只会看到当时您认为相关的信息。巧妙的见解来自您一路上做出的非常规发现。以结构化的方式翻阅你过去相关的想法所产生的突破性想法，才是开启真正非常规互动的钥匙。 Antinet 的树结构诱发了这些结构化事故。

While the Persian messenger association fallacy introduces an interesting interaction, the more compelling ones come about by exploring the items around the area where the concept resides (in this case, exploring around 2432/4). The truly unconventional interactions come about when navigating through and around the tree structure of the Antinet. 虽然波斯信使联想谬误引入了一种有趣的互动，但更引人注目的是探索概念所在区域周围的项目（在本例中，探索 2432/4 附近）。当在 Antinet 的树结构中和周围导航时，就会出现真正非常规的交互。

Structured accidents are critical for procuring breakthrough insights. The random pieces of information you encounter in your quest of exploring the Antinet create valuable opportunities to experience incidental learning (by way of structured accidents).[552](#footnote-527) Digital search mitigates such phenomena from occurring. 结构化事故对于获得突破性见解至关重要。您在探索 Antinet 的过程中遇到的随机信息片段为体验偶然学习（通过结构化事故）创造了宝贵的机会。552 数字搜索减轻了此类现象的发生。

**Digital Search Robs You of Developing a Unique Structure for Evolving Your Mind 数字搜索剥夺了你发展独特结构的能力**

The Antinet’s structure allowed Luhmann to store deeply complex and inter- Antinet 的结构让 Luhmann 能够存储非常复杂和相互关联的信息。

connected information, thanks to its tree structure. It allowed him to gracefully navigate his mind and his memory (past and present). 连接信息，这要归功于它的树结构。它让他能够优雅地浏览他的思想和他的记忆（过去和现在）。

As has been mentioned before, developing his mind and memory came about from two processes. It occurred first by neuroimprinting thoughts by writing by hand. Second, by engaging in an ongoing process of tending to his file, Luhmann engaged in constant maintenance rehearsal, eventually developing the ability to recall thoughts without effort.[553](#footnote-526) 如前所述，发展他的思维和记忆来自两个过程。它首先通过手写的神经印记思想发生。其次，通过持续照料他的档案，卢曼进行了持续的维护排练，最终培养了不费力地回忆思想的能力。 553

When you instead review your own thoughts, written in your own handwriting, the process is often very fun. It’s also very humbling. You see your thoughts and brilliant ideas written on cards from years ago. It also helps mitigate the sense that you haven’t written something. When you see your own handwriting with your own brilliant ideas, you experience a sense of being impressed by your old self! More pertinent, this process builds your memory. It builds it in such a way wherein your thoughts are primed to compound. 相反，当你回顾自己的想法时，用你自己的笔迹写下来，这个过程通常很有趣。这也很谦虚。你会看到你多年前写在卡片上的想法和绝妙的想法。它还有助于减轻您没有写东西的感觉。当你看到自己的笔迹和自己的绝妙想法时，你会体验到一种被旧人折服的感觉！更切题的是，这个过程会建立你的记忆。它以这样一种方式构建它，在这种方式中，你的想法已经准备好复合。

With digital search, you’re constantly searching for and through documents without any life or personality. They contain your thoughts, yes. But they’re in some system-standardized font; the files are not living. They’re constantly changing, being deleted, and overwritten. You have no chance to view the changes in your thinking because all traces are erased. 通过数字搜索，您可以不断搜索和浏览没有任何生命或个性的文档。它们包含你的想法，是的。但是它们使用的是某种系统标准化的字体；这些文件不是活的。它们不断变化、被删除和覆盖。你没有机会看到你思维的变化，因为所有的痕迹都被抹去了。

Finally! A simple, easy way to cure depression scientifically proven to cure ass- backward thoughts—INSTANTLY, 100% FREE, DOUBLE-YOUR-MONEY- BACK GUARANTEED! 最后！一种简单易行的治疗抑郁症的方法，经科学证明可以治愈落后的想法——即刻、100% 免费、双倍退款保证！

The Antinet improves mood, whereas digital search eradicates much of the magic inherent in associative processing. Finally! We have proof. Digital search robs you of a good mood. CHAPTER TEN 第十章
---------------

Network 网络
----------

In 1956, on a gray evening in the padded cell of a mental hospital, W. Ross Ashby sat at his desk. He was putting the finishing touches on his manuscript Introduction to Cybernetics. Ashby was not a patient of the mental hospital, however. He was a trained psychiatrist, research pathologist, and at the time, was serving as the Director of Research at Barnwood House Hospital in Gloucester, England.[555](#footnote-562) He simply found the padded cells of his patients to be the perfect environment to focus. In this padded cell he published a paper which would greatly influence some of the brightest thinkers in information theory, mathematics, and technology for decades to come.1956 年，在一个灰蒙蒙的夜晚，在一间精神病院的软垫牢房里，W. Ross Ashby 坐在他的办公桌前。他正在对他的手稿《控制论导论》进行最后润色。然而，阿什比并不是精神病院的病人。他是一名训练有素的精神病学家、研究病理学家，当时担任英国格洛斯特 Barnwood House 医院的研究主任。555 他只是发现患者的软垫细胞是集中注意力的完美环境。在这个带衬垫的牢房里，他发表了一篇论文，该论文将在未来几十年对信息论、数学和技术领域的一些最聪明的思想家产生重大影响。

Ashby was always up to some odd research project. A few years prior, he built what may be the first device in history capable of adapting itself to its environment: the homeostat. For that work, Ashby’s wife proffered their kitchen table as the workbench for his experiments that, in the homeostat’s case, included Royal Air Force bomb parts.[556](#footnote-561) 阿什比总是忙于一些奇怪的研究项目。几年前，他制造了可能是历史上第一台能够自我适应环境的设备：稳态器。对于这项工作，阿什比的妻子提供了他们的厨房桌子作为他实验的工作台，在稳态器的例子中，包括皇家空军炸弹部件。 556

From this experience Ashby devised his theory of cybernetics. 从这次经历阿什比设计了他的控制论。

**The Cybernetic Network of The AntinetAntinet 的控制论网络**
-------------------------------------------------------

On the very first notecard Niklas Luhmann wrote down in preparation for describing the Antinet Zettelkasten, he wrote that it’s a cybernetic system.[557](#footnote-560) We also know that Luhmann was familiar with the work of W. Ross Ashby because we find Luhmann writing of Ashby’s work a few cards later.[558](#footnote-559) We also know that Luhmann was deeply familiar with a subfield of cybernetics called autopoiesis (which is the concept of a system producing and maintaining itself by creating itself). 在 Niklas Luhmann 为准备描述 Antinet Zettelkasten 而写下的第一个记事卡上，他写道这是一个控制论系统。 557 我们也知道 Luhmann 熟悉 W. Ross Ashby 的作品，因为我们发现 Luhmann 写下了 Ashby 的作品几张卡片之后。558 我们还知道，卢曼非常熟悉控制论的一个子领域，称为自创生（这是一个系统通过创造自身来生产和维持自身的概念）。

Cybernetics derives from kybernetes (Greek), meaning “steersman,” and refers to having a goal and achieving the goal through steering in the proper direction by way of the communication of feedback. W. Ross Ashby defines it as “the art of steersmanship.”[559](#footnote-558) One of the pioneers of cybernetics, Norbert Wiener, characterizes it as “control and communication in animal and machine.”[560](#footnote-557) It arose as a disciplinary field involving information theory, engineering, and computer science, and continues to have a wide-spanning range across many different disciplinary fields.Cyber​​netics 源自 kybernetes（希腊语），意思是 “舵手”，指的是有一个目标，并通过反馈的交流，将舵转向正确的方向，从而实现目标。 W. Ross Ashby 将其定义为 “掌舵的艺术”。559 控制论的先驱之一诺伯特 · 维纳 (Norbert Wiener) 将其描述为 “动物和机器的控制和通信”。560 它作为一个学科领域出现，涉及信息论、工程学和计算机科学，并继续在许多不同的学科领域拥有广泛的范围。

Luhmann’s reference to the structure of his Antinet as a cybernetic one makes sense. This field of study centers on communication. It’s no accident that Luhmann titled his paper on the Antinet, Communication with Noteboxes. The communication process arises out of the cybernetic nature of the Antinet, utilizing control (by way of a fixed goal), and feedback. Cybernetic systems are modeled in both machines and living organisms. In the former, such systems are closely related to machine learning, specifically Q-learning (which artificial intelligence systems use to learn by way of reinforcement).Luhmann 将他的 Antinet 结构称为控制论结构是有道理的。该研究领域以通信为中心。 Luhmann 将他关于 Antinet 的论文命名为 Communication with Noteboxes 绝非偶然。通信过程源于 Antinet 的控制论性质，利用控制（通过固定目标）和反馈。控制论系统在机器和生物体中都被建模。在前者中，此类系统与机器学习密切相关，特别是 Q-learning（人工智能系统使用它通过强化学习）。

**The Nature of the Antinet’s Cybernetic NetworkAntinet 控制论网络的本质**
------------------------------------------------------------------

The cybernetic network structure of the Antinet resembles that of associationism.[561](#footnote-556) This involves the association of nodes in a network based on contiguity (the continuous flow of thought), and on the similarity of thoughts causing them to be grouped or linked to one another. These two components (contiguity and similarity) are what govern thought. They’re also what comprise the structure of the cybernetic network of the Antinet. In essence, the Antinet is built on associations that are linked together by way of contiguity, in that continuously flowing ideas that overflow across cards are naturally grouped together.Antinet 的控制论网络结构类似于联想论。561 这涉及网络中基于连续性（思想的连续流动）和思想相似性的节点关联，导致它们被分组或相互链接。这两个组成部分（连续性和相似性）是支配思想的因素。它们也是 Antinet 控制论网络结构的组成部分。从本质上讲，Antinet 是建立在通过连续性连接在一起的关联之上的，因为不断流动的想法会自然地组合在一起。

Additionally, the Antinet groups ideas in the long term by way of similarity. The most similar thoughts are naturally grouped together, near one another. The reason for this is that, again, the name of the game is to install notecards closest to their nearest neighbors. This means either an individual notecard, or a new stream of thought that encompasses several notecards which elaborate on an idea. 此外，Antinet 通过相似性从长远来看对想法进行分组。最相似的想法自然而然地聚在一起，彼此靠近。这样做的原因是，同样，游戏的名称是将记事卡安装在离最近邻居最近的地方。这意味着要么是一个单独的记事卡，要么是包含多个详细说明一个想法的记事卡的新思想流。

The cards’ numeric-alpha addresses transform the Antinet’s network into something akin to auto-associators in human memory science. This is something I go into in the chapter on how the Antinet mirrors human memory. In brief, an auto-associator is built on content-addressable memory.[562](#footnote-555) That is, every single memory has an address “affixed” to it. 卡片的数字字母地址将 Antinet 的网络转变为类似于人类记忆科学中的自动联想器的东西。这是我在关于 Antinet 如何反映人类记忆的章节中讨论的内容。简而言之，自动关联器建立在内容可寻址内存之上。562 也就是说，每个内存都有一个 “固定” 的地址。

The Antinet’s network is essentially composed of individual units of content-addressable memory (thanks to numeric-alpha addresses). How one navigates the network comes by way of the index and tree structure of the Antinet. These two components enrich the network in a powerful way that is absent in digital Zettelkasten systems.Antinet 的网络本质上是由内容可寻址内存的各个单元组成的（多亏了数字字母地址）。一个人如何浏览网络是通过 Antinet 的索引和树结构来实现的。这两个组件以数字 Zettelkasten 系统中不存在的强大方式丰富了网络。

**What Creates the Cybernetic Network of the Antinet 是什么创造了 Antinet 的控制论网络**

As already discussed, the Antinet’s numeric-alpha addresses “ensure utmost autonomy, i.e. self-referential closure of the machine.”[563](#footnote-554) The self-referential closure of the machine is critical because it serves as the precondition for creating a cybernetic network. In brief, the numeric-alpha addresses create the cybernetic network of the Antinet. 正如已经讨论过的，Antinet 的 numeric-alpha 地址 “确保最大程度的自治，即机器的自我参照关闭。”563 机器的自我参照关闭是至关重要的，因为它是创建控制论网络的先决条件。简而言之，数字字母地址创建了 Antinet 的控制论网络。

This is important because the cybernetic nature of the Antinet is what helps convert it into a network that provides feedback. The problem with digital Zettelkasten and many notetaking systems is that they lack feedback mechanisms. With an Antinet, however, the system is enclosed in feedback loops. For example, in your mind you might be looking for an idea or concept. You follow a train of thought, and if you can’t find what you’re looking for, that is a piece of feedback. The feedback is even more valuable if you’re sure that you have the idea stored somewhere in the Antinet. You’re forced to have a conversation and to communicate with the Antinet. You ask yourself, Where else could I have stored the thought I’m looking for? What else is it related to? In searching for the idea, you’re provided with more feedback and you make accidental discoveries. The whole system is a feedback-generating mechanism that brings unexpected new insights to the surface along the way. 这很重要，因为 Antinet 的控制论性质有助于将其转换为提供反馈的网络。数字 Zettelkasten 和许多笔记系统的问题在于它们缺乏反馈机制。然而，使用 Antinet 时，系统被封闭在反馈回路中。例如，在您的脑海中，您可能正在寻找一个想法或概念。你遵循一个思路，如果你找不到你要找的东西，那就是一个反馈。如果你确定你的想法存储在 Antinet 的某个地方，那么反馈就更有价值了。你被迫与 Antinet 进行对话和交流。你问自己，我还能在哪里储存我正在寻找的想法？它还与什么有关？在寻找想法的过程中，你会得到更多的反馈，并且会有意外的发现。整个系统是一个反馈生成机制，在整个过程中带来意想不到的新见解。
