Now we turn to a chapter of more practical nature. In the next chapter you’ll be guided through the wild world of building your own Antinet. The first part of the chapter serves as mental preparation in approaching the journey. Then, halfway through the next chapter, you’ll be asked to follow a set of guided instructions. Follow them precisely as I outline. Good luck, and Godspeed. 现在我们转向更实际的一章。在下一章中，您将被引导穿越构建您自己的 Antinet 的狂野世界。本章的第一部分作为接近旅程的心理准备。然后，在下一章进行到一半时，系统会要求您遵循一组指导说明。严格按照我的概述进行操作。祝你好运，万事如意。

CHAPTER ELEVEN 第十一章
-------------------

The Hitchhiker’s Guide To The AntinetAntinet 漫游指南
-------------------------------------------------

At this point you have more than enough theoretical Antinet knowledge. It’s time to roll up your sleeves and build out your own Antinet. For all of the theoretical material you’ve ingested, you’ll be surprised to find its nature to be quite simple. 至此，您对 Antinet 的理论知识已经绰绰有余。是时候卷起袖子建立自己的 Antinet 了。对于您吸收的所有理论材料，您会惊讶地发现它的本质非常简单。

**The Obstacles You’ll Face Building an Antinet 构建 Antinet 时您将面临的障碍**
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Before we dive into the instructions, it’s critical for you to understand what to expect. I’ve found that the biggest thing preventing anyone from building out an Antinet is the false belief in what to expect. We’re going to dive into this area now. 在我们深入了解说明之前，了解预期内容对您来说至关重要。我发现阻止任何人构建 Antinet 的最大因素是对预期结果的错误信念。我们现在要深入到这个领域。

**How to Even Begin 如何开始**

The biggest obstacle you’ll face in building an Antinet is grasping how to even begin in the first place. At this phase you might think that how you set up your Antinet is critically important to its success. You might have the feeling that if you make a single mistake in the beginning, the whole system is doomed. Forever. Unfortunately, this is the case. Just kidding! 你在构建 Antinet 时将面临的最大障碍是掌握如何从一开始就开始。在此阶段，您可能会认为如何设置 Antinet 对其成功至关重要。你可能会有这样的感觉，如果你一开始犯了一个错误，整个系统就完蛋了。永远。不幸的是，情况就是这样。只是在开玩笑！

I’ve seen advice in online forums dedicated to digital Zettelkasten telling people to just begin blindly, even randomly. You’ll also get advice from the bestselling books that the Zettelkasten just emerges without planning—without trying to create some semblance of organization using categories. 我在专门针对数字 Zettelkasten 的在线论坛上看到过一些建议，告诉人们要盲目地开始，甚至是随机地开始。您还会从畅销书中得到建议，即 Zettelkasten 是在没有计划的情况下出现的——无需尝试使用类别来创建某种组织形式。

For instance, you’ll find authors stating things like: “The trick is that [Luhmann] did not organize his notes by topic, but in a rather abstract way of giving them fixed numbers.”[564](#footnote-594) Yet, as you learn throughout this book, this notion is false. Luhmann never declared that anyone should start building an Antinet with no idea at all of where they want to go. Luhmann’s second Zettelkasten was planned with eleven fuzzy categories. Luhmann’s first Zettelkasten included 108 top-level categories. Both are included in the appendix of this book. 例如，你会发现作者这样说：“诀窍在于 [Luhmann] 没有按主题组织他的笔记，而是以一种相当抽象的方式为它们提供固定的数字。”564 然而，正如你在本书中了解到的那样，这个观念是错误的。 Luhmann 从未宣称任何人都应该在完全不知道他们想去哪里的情况下开始构建 Antinet。 Luhmann 的第二个 Zettelkasten 计划有 11 个模糊类别。 Luhmann 的第一个 Zettelkasten 包括 108 个顶级类别。两者都包含在本书的附录中。

Luhmann’s Antinet categories weren’t undetermined; rather, many were predetermined. As Johannes Schmidt observes, “The pattern that we see here is very much one of exploring and reflecting on largely predetermined, fairly detailed fields of knowledge.”[565](#footnote-593)Luhmann 的 Antinet 类别并非未确定；相反，许多是预先确定的。正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 所观察到的，“我们在这里看到的模式在很大程度上是一种探索和反思很大程度上预先确定的、相当详细的知识领域的模式。”565

In brief, you don’t want to start with zero idea of how you’d like to structure your Antinet. Ideally, you want to start with a rough idea of where you want to take it. You want a fuzzy idea of what you want to build. With that said, the system I’m about to teach you makes use of well-developed disciplinary fields, so even if you don’t have a clue about what you want to use your Antinet for, it will still work for you in the long term. The expansive disciplinary fields, plus the internal branching structure of the Antinet, enable the system to evolve in whatever direction your mind wishes to take it. 简而言之，您不想从零开始就想如何构建 Antinet。理想情况下，您首先要大致了解要将其带到哪里。您想要对要构建的内容有一个模糊的想法。话虽如此，我将要教给你的系统利用了发达的学科领域，所以即使你不知道你想用你的 Antinet 做什么，它仍然会为你工作长期。广阔的学科领域，加上 Antinet 的内部分支结构，使该系统能够朝着你的思想希望采取的任何方向发展。

I realize all this sounds rather abstract and ambiguous; however, once you complete the instructions I’m about to provide, you’ll begin to see what I’m talking about. Once you spend a few weeks using the system, you’ll get a lot more comfortable with it, and you will be less likely to wonder if you’ve done something wrong. 我意识到这一切听起来相当抽象和模棱两可；但是，一旦您完成了我即将提供的说明，您就会开始明白我在说什么。一旦你花了几周时间使用这个系统，你就会更加适应它，并且你将不太可能怀疑自己是否做错了什么。

**Avoid Perfectionism (Always Evolve, Never Delete) 避免完美主义（永远进化，永不删除）**

At the core of what I’ve just talked about is the tendency of perfectionism. In the beginning of building your Antinet, you must abandon your desire for perfection. One of the most valuable parts of the Antinet is…mistakes! Specifically, your mistakes, your own thinking mistakes, and even imperfections in your own numbering conventions of the Antinet. 我刚才讲的核心是完美主义倾向。在开始构建您的 Antinet 时，您必须放弃对完美的渴望。 Antinet 最有价值的部分之一是…… 错误！具体来说，你的错误，你自己的思维错误，甚至是你自己的 Antinet 编号规则的不完善。

For instance, in the card I’m using to compose the section you’re reading right now, I created what could be called an imperfection in its numbering convention. 例如，在我用来组成你现在正在阅读的部分的卡片中，我在其编号约定中创建了一个可以称为缺陷的部分。

As you can see from this card, the card address is 4214/5aca/1. You’ll notice that the end part is in green (a/1), whereas the beginning of the card address is in blue. This is because at the time I created the card I hadn’t yet figured out where I was going to put it. Therefore, in the beginning I would just write a/1 in green, and once I figured out where to install it, I’d prepend the address with the actual location in blue. Notice that the stem of the cards before 4214/5aca is 4214/5ac and 4214/5a. 从这张卡可以看出，卡地址是 4214/5aca/1。你会注意到结尾部分是绿色的 (a/1)，而卡片地址的开头是蓝色的。这是因为在我创建卡片时，我还没有弄清楚我要把它放在哪里。因此，一开始我只是将 a/1 写成绿色，一旦我弄清楚安装位置，我就会在地址前面加上蓝色的实际位置。请注意，4214/5aca 之前的牌干是 4214/5ac 和 4214/5a。

In brief, the structure looks like this: 简而言之，结构如下所示：

Note that there’s no 4214/5ab. I for some reason, just skip right to using 5ac because I created c before I even knew where I would install the card. 请注意，没有 4214/5ab。出于某种原因，我直接跳到使用 5ac，因为我什至在不知道将卡安装在哪里之前就创建了 c。

In brief, this isn’t the convention I use these days. In my workflow today, I would first figure out where I wanted to install the card before I wrote the note. The structure would be something like this instead: 简而言之，这不是我最近使用的惯例。在我今天的工作流程中，在写笔记之前，我会先弄清楚我想把卡安装在哪里。结构将是这样的：

In spite of the difference, both conventions are fine. The imperfections work just as well. It’s just that my new conventional way of doing things has changed over time. I find my current convention makes more sense (to me), and it appears cleaner and more logical (again, to me). For instance, today I wouldn’t go from 4214/5a to 4214/5ac (thus skipping 4214/5ab). In addition, I also like a more nested structure, which uses slashes (/). For instance, I prefer ‘branching down’ and creating 4214/5a/1 (opposed to appending letters onto letters, like 4214/5ab). 尽管存在差异，但两种约定都很好。缺陷也同样有效。只是随着时间的推移，我新的传统做事方式发生了变化。我发现我目前的惯例（对我来说）更有意义，而且看起来更清晰、更合乎逻辑（再次对我来说）。例如，今天我不会从 4214/5a 转到 4214/5ac（因此跳过 4214/5ab）。此外，我还喜欢一种更嵌套的结构，它使用斜杠（/）。例如，我更喜欢 “向下分支” 并创建 4214/5a/1（反对将字母附加到字母上，如 4214/5ab）。

What counts, though, is the actual thought being developed. I never have the temptation to refactor the addresses of my notes. There’s no temptation to make my new notes perfectly backward compatible with my old schemes for numbering. Why? I don’t need to. The system just works. 然而，重要的是正在形成的实际想法。我从来没有想重构我笔记的地址。没有人想让我的新笔记完全向后兼容我的旧编号方案。为什么？我不需要。该系统正常工作。

In brief, don’t delete your mistakes or imperfections. The reason for this is that there is value in re-reviewing your thoughts or re-reviewing your previous mistakes to see how much you’ve grown. Or even to see how your previous corrections of initially perceived mistakes turned out to also be incorrect! All of these occurrences are valuable. 简而言之，不要删除你的错误或不完美之处。这样做的原因是重新审视你的想法或重新审视你以前的错误是有价值的，看看你已经成长了多少。甚至查看您之前对最初认为的错误的更正结果也是不正确的！所有这些事件都是有价值的。

Here’s a secret: even Luhmann didn’t get it right the first time. First, Luhmann’s thoughts themselves contained mistakes. Yet he never removed them from his Antinet. For instance, Johannes Schmidt writes: 这是一个秘密：即使是卢曼也不是第一次就做对了。首先，卢曼的思想本身就有错误。然而他从未将它们从他的 Antinet 中移除。例如，约翰内斯施密特写道：

It [Luhmann’s Antinet] contains not only validated knowledge but also reflects the thought process, including potential mistakes and blind alleys that were later revised but not removed from the file as the original cards always remained in Luhmann’s file and perhaps a new card with revisions was added if needed.[566](#footnote-592) 它 [Luhmann's Antinet] 不仅包含经过验证的知识，还反映了思维过程，包括潜在的错误和死胡同，这些错误和死胡同后来被修改但没有从文件中删除，因为原始卡片始终保留在 Luhmann 的文件中，也许经过修改的新卡片是如果需要添加。 566

Second, Luhmann’s conventions, and the components of his Antinet, were never deleted. He never deleted his old indexes, for instance, but continually created more organized versions. After a certain point, his index became messy.[567](#footnote-591) Instead of replacing the index with his new one, he simply placed the new index after the old one. In total, his second Antinet contains four versions of the index.[568](#footnote-590) 其次，卢曼的惯例和他的 Antinet 的组成部分从未被删除。例如，他从不删除他的旧索引，而是不断创建更有条理的版本。在某一点之后，他的索引变得混乱。567 他没有用新索引替换索引，而是简单地将新索引放在旧索引之后。他的第二个 Antinet 总共包含四个版本的 index.568

Not only did Luhmann modify the index component of his Antinet, he also experimented in other ways. He created an index that was not organized by concepts’ keyterms, but by people’s names. Luhmann thought that this was a helpful practice because our minds sometimes retrieve ideas by thinking of the name of the author from which they derived.[569](#footnote-589) 卢曼不仅修改了 Antinet 的索引组件，还尝试了其他方式。他创建的索引不是按概念的关键词组织的，而是按人名组织的。 Luhmann 认为这是一种有益的做法，因为我们的大脑有时会通过思考思想来源的作者姓名来检索思想。 569

Yet when Luhmann created a name-based index, he did not attempt to retroactively make it backward compatible. He did not attempt to go through all of his previous notecards and make sure the name-based index comprehensively referenced each of the notes. He did not systematically pursue the strategy of adding items to the name index in every case.[570](#footnote-588) 然而，当 Luhmann 创建一个基于名称的索引时，他并没有试图追溯使其向后兼容。他没有尝试查看他以前的所有笔记卡并确保基于名称的索引全面引用了每个笔记。他并没有系统地追求在每个案例中都将项目添加到名称索引的策略。 570

What we learn from these examples is to extinguish any sense of perfectionism. That’s right. I’m asking you to extinguish the idea that your Antinet is to be a perfectly organized system. There’s far more power in creating paths documenting your various mistakes. The stems of thoughts and ideas documenting your mind changing stands as an invaluable property of the Antinet. In addition, you’re encouraged to launch experiments (like Luhmann’s people-focused index). But at the same time, don’t feel like you’re bound to systematically pursuing such an experiment forever. Old experiments are valuable in and of themselves, and who knows—maybe you’ll pick up where you left off one day and continue developing an experiment you began ages ago. 我们从这些例子中学到的是消除任何完美主义的感觉。这是正确的。我要求你打消你的 Antinet 是一个组织完美的系统的想法。创建记录各种错误的路径的功能要强大得多。记录您的思想变化的思想和想法的根源是 Antinet 的宝贵财产。此外，我们鼓励您开展实验（例如 Luhmann 的以人为本的索引）。但与此同时，不要觉得你一定要系统地永远进行这样的实验。旧实验本身就很有价值，谁知道呢——也许有一天你会从你停下的地方继续做你很久以前就开始的实验。

**Doubting the Power of Analog 怀疑模拟的力量**

When first starting out, you may not realize the sheer power of analog systems. In fact, you may still hold a systemic negative regard for analog systems. Today, society blindly accepts that technology and digital tools are better for everything. However, digital tools are not better for everything. They’re certainly not better for thinking and evolving thought. 刚开始时，您可能没有意识到模拟系统的强大功能。事实上，您可能仍然对模拟系统持有系统性的负面看法。今天，社会盲目地接受技术和数字工具对一切都更好。然而，数字工具并不适合所有情况。他们当然不会更好地思考和发展思想。

When you’re just starting out, you may find yourself doubting this. You may experience false beliefs and doubts about what you’re investing your time and energy into. Please take my word for it until then. In brief, analog is worth it. Developing your mind using analog tools pays off in the long-run; heck, it even pays off in the short-run. 当您刚开始时，您可能会发现自己对此表示怀疑。您可能会对自己投入时间和精力的事情产生错误的信念和怀疑。在那之前请相信我的话。简而言之，模拟是值得的。从长远来看，使用模拟工具开发思维是有回报的；哎呀，它甚至可以在短期内得到回报。

**Don’t Become Distracted by the Zettelkasten Myths out There 不要被 Zettelkasten 神话分散注意力**

Perhaps the biggest distraction you’ll face in building an Antinet is the misinformation and complete inventions you’ll find online about Zettelkasten. If you search Zettelkasten online, there’s a 96% chance you’ll come across a myth that misrepresents the system.[571](#footnote-587) 在构建 Antinet 时，您可能会面临的最大干扰是您会在网上找到有关 Zettelkasten 的错误信息和完整的发明。如果你在网上搜索 Zettelkasten，你有 96% 的机会会遇到一个歪曲该系统的神话。 571

The myths you come across about Zettelkasten seem innocuous and quite rational at first. Yet the smallest thing could prevent your notetaking system from becoming an actual second mind—a communication partner. For instance, if you buy into the whole idea of creating atomic notes (perfectly organized sets of one idea per card), then you’re setting yourself up for failure. The many myths of Zettelkasten will be exposed throughout this book. Until then, just trust me here. Don’t get distracted by the stuff about Zettelkasten you find online. 您遇到的关于 Zettelkasten 的神话起初似乎无害且非常合理。然而，最小的事情可能会阻止您的笔记系统成为真正的第二思维——沟通伙伴。例如，如果你相信创建原子笔记的整个想法（每张卡片完美组织一个想法），那么你就是在为失败做好准备。 Zettelkasten 的许多神话将贯穿全书。在那之前，请相信我。不要被你在网上找到的关于 Zettelkasten 的东西分心。

**You’re Like an Airplane Taking Off 你就像一架起飞的飞机**

Building an Antinet isn’t easy. Especially in the beginning. I’d like to re-emphasize a major point: with the Antinet, you’re doing things the old way, the hard way, the true way. Yet, you’ll be doing so bit-by-bit, card-by-card. Paradoxically, this turns out to be the easy way in the long-run. 构建 Antinet 并不容易。尤其是在开始的时候。我想再次强调一个要点：使用 Antinet，您正在以旧的方式、困难的方式、真正的方式做事。然而，您将逐张、逐张地这样做。矛盾的是，从长远来看，这被证明是最简单的方法。

Yet, the major premise in Sönke Ahrens’s presentation of Zettelkasten is the notion that it will make writing an easy, “seamless” activity.[572](#footnote-586) Ahrens makes it seem like it’s a simple system. He misappropriates Luhmann’s phrase: “I must tell you that I never force anything. I only do what comes easy to me.”[573](#footnote-585) Ahrens leaves out the fact that Luhmann said this immediately after outlining his work routine in detail. In brief, Luhmann worked every day from 8:30am until roughly midnight. 然而，Sönke Ahrens 介绍 Zettelkasten 的主要前提是，它将使写作成为一项简单、“无缝” 的活动。572 Ahrens 使它看起来像是一个简单的系统。他盗用了卢曼的话：“我必须告诉你，我从不强迫任何事情。我只做对我来说容易的事情。”573 阿伦斯没有提到卢曼在详细概述了他的工作程序后立即说了这句话。简而言之，卢曼每天从早上 8 点 30 分一直工作到午夜。

Building out an Antinet requires work and a deliberate investment of energy. However, you don’t need to work from 8:30am until midnight (for reasons I’ll outline shortly). 建立一个 Antinet 需要工作和有意识的精力投入。但是，您不需要从早上 8 点 30 分一直工作到午夜（原因我将在稍后概述）。

When starting out, it’s best to think of yourself as an airplane taking off. In the beginning it will require more energy. You’re about to be introduced to an entirely new way of organizing and evolving your mind, and I’m also introducing you to a new way of reading and developing your thoughts. 开始时，最好将自己想象成一架起飞的飞机。一开始它需要更多的能量。你将被引入一种全新的方式来组织和发展你的思想，我也向你介绍一种阅读和发展你的思想的新方式。

Combined with the overhead expenditure of energy required in learning a new system, you’re also starting from scratch. You’ll face what I call index fatigue. In the beginning, you have a completely barren structure. You’ll therefore need to spend a considerable amount of time creating new keyterm entries in your index. This is something that decreases and becomes less time-consuming after several months. 再加上学习新系统所需的能量开销，您也是从头开始。你将面临我所说的指数疲劳。一开始，你有一个完全贫瘠的结构。因此，您需要花费大量时间在索引中创建新的关键字条目。几个月后，这会减少并且变得不那么耗时。

Don’t get me wrong: you’ll always be creating new keyterm entries in your index. But, in the beginning you’ll be creating keyterms much more frequently. The important thing is that you manage index fatigue well. Don’t get burnt out. Don’t land the plane before giving yourself a chance to hit cruise control. 不要误会我的意思：您将始终在索引中创建新的关键字条目。但是，一开始你会更频繁地创建关键词。重要的是你要很好地管理索引疲劳。不要筋疲力尽。在给自己一个机会进行巡航控制之前，不要降落飞机。

**You Only Need Two Hours a Day for Great Intellectual Work 你每天只需要两个小时就可以进行出色的智力工作**

While I do hold it to be true that the Antinet is for those who accept the time investment required, it’s important to provide a caveat. The caveat is that consistency is the goal. Keep in mind that Luhmann used his Antinet for forty-six years (1951–1997). You should strive for the same. 虽然我确实认为 Antinet 是为那些接受所需时间投资的人准备的，但提供一个警告很重要。需要注意的是，一致性是目标。请记住，卢曼使用他的 Antinet 已有四十六年（1951-1997）。你也应该为此而努力。

When I preach hard work, don’t interpret my advice as requiring you to work twelve hours a day on your Antinet. Rather two hours of work per day consistently over the long term is a good goal. That means reading or writing notes for two hours per day (on average). 当我宣扬努力工作时，请不要将我的建议解释为要求您每天在 Antinet 上工作 12 小时。从长远来看，每天持续工作两个小时是一个不错的目标。这意味着每天（平均）阅读或写笔记两个小时。

The Catholic intellectual Antonin Sertillanges confirms this notion. To do great intellectual work, a person needs only two hours per day of focused study.[574](#footnote-584) If you work full-time, you must carve out two hours a day—either before work or after work (or, even split them up). In my early twenties, when I worked a day job full-time, I carved out two hours of work every morning before I left for the office. Luhmann carved out his deliberate focus time with his Antinet in the evenings.[575](#footnote-583) 天主教知识分子 Antonin Sertillanges 证实了这一观点。要完成出色的智力工作，一个人每天只需要集中学习两个小时。574 如果你全职工作，你必须每天抽出两个小时——工作前或工作后（或者，甚至分开）。在我二十出头的时候，当我全职工作时，我每天早上在去办公室之前抽出两个小时的工作时间。 Luhmann 在晚上用他的 Antinet 刻意安排了他的专注时间。 575

As far as intellectual work goes, the two-hour a day rule seems to be a theme. For instance, the scholar Umberto Eco recommends a similar time commitment in his book, How to Write a Thesis. One can write a quality thesis, according to Eco, even if “they can only dedicate a few hours each day.” Yet Eco hints at an even more important variable: one’s attitude. Those who gain the most in writing a thesis, it seems, are those who pursue it as a means to attain a “certain intellectual satisfaction.”[576](#footnote-582) That is, those who approach the process of intellectual work with an attitude that centers not on fulfilling an external requirement, but their own internal requirement. I agree. 就智力工作而言，每天两小时的规则似乎是一个主题。例如，学者 Umberto Eco 在他的《如何撰写论文》一书中推荐了类似的时间承诺。根据 Eco 的说法，一个人可以写出一篇高质量的论文，即使 “他们每天只能投入几个小时”。然而，艾柯暗示了一个更重要的变量：一个人的态度。那些在撰写论文中获益最多的人似乎是那些将其作为获得“某种智力满足感” 的手段来追求的人。 576 也就是说，那些以不以实现为中心的态度来处理智力工作的过程。一个外在的要求，而是自己的内在要求。我同意。

**On Having a Goal 关于有一个目标**
----------------------------

Richard W. Hamming, an American mathematician who worked at Bell Laboratories and who greatly influenced how computer and telecommunication technology works today once observed how shockingly common it was that his fellow employees were content to work on unimportant problems. They lacked a clear goal or purpose. He noted how it even seemed like they made a deliberate choice to work on unimportant problems. 美国数学家理查德 ·W· 汉明 (Richard W. Hamming) 曾在贝尔实验室工作，他极大地影响了当今计算机和电信技术的工作方式，他曾经观察到，他的同事满足于研究不重要的问题是多么普遍。他们缺乏明确的目标或宗旨。他指出，他们似乎是故意选择处理不重要的问题。

Hamming was a scientist obsessed with truth. He had the tendency of delivering his truth in an unfiltered fashion (often at the expense of other people’s feelings). One day Hamming approached a fellow employee and said abruptly, Why are you even bothering to live if you’re not working on an important problem or goal? The employee, understandably, was quite upset. He scoffed at Hamming’s offensive words and stormed out of the room. 汉明是一位痴迷于真理的科学家。他倾向于以未经过滤的方式传达他的真相（通常以牺牲他人的感受为代价）。一天，海明走近一位同事，突然说，如果你不是在解决一个重要的问题或目标，你为什么还要为生活而烦恼呢？可以理解，该员工非常沮丧。他嘲笑海明无礼的话，冲出房间。

Later the employee wrote a letter to Hamming thanking him. The letter read: Thank you. Your words ended up changing my life.[577](#footnote-581) 后来该员工写信给汉明感谢他。信上写着：谢谢。你的话最终改变了我的生活。 577

This brings us to the crux of the matter: goals. Specifically, your goals in building an Antinet. This matter is so important that you must explore it in detail before setting out to build your Antinet. 这就把我们带到了问题的关键：目标。具体来说，您构建 Antinet 的目标。这件事非常重要，您必须在着手构建 Antinet 之前详细研究它。

It can be argued that people are too fascinated with Luhmann’s Antinet, to the extent that many people overlook the famous declaration Luhmann made. At the beginning of his intellectual career, Luhmann was one of the first professors hired by Bielefeld University. The new administration asked Luhmann what research project he would work on. His response was legendary amongst sociologists: “My project was, and ever since has been, the theory of society; term: thirty years; costs: none.”[578](#footnote-580) 可以说，人们对卢曼的反网络过于着迷，以至于很多人忽视了卢曼的著名宣言。在其学术生涯的初期，卢曼是比勒费尔德大学聘用的首批教授之一。新政府问卢曼他将从事什么研究项目。他的回答在社会学家中具有传奇色彩：“我的项目是，并且从那以后一直是社会理论；任期：三十年；成本：无。”578

The Antinet served as the perfect tool for Luhmann because it helped him with his ambitious goal. His goal was a massive undertaking. It was a thirty year project that required a system that would enable him to develop and evolve his thinking over the course of it.Antinet 是卢曼的完美工具，因为它帮助他实现了雄心勃勃的目标。他的目标是一项艰巨的任务。这是一个三十年的项目，需要一个系统，使他能够在此过程中发展和发展他的思想。

This brings up the question: what is the goal of an Antinet in the first place? 这就提出了一个问题：Antinet 的首要目标是什么？

In a sense, the ultimate goal of an Antinet centers on “maximizing the number of copies of the genes that created it.”[579](#footnote-579) Consider this: the goal of Luhmann’s Antinet was to maximize the proliferation of his ideas. He intended to do this by packing in evidence from all of his readings. He began by extracting knowledge from books onto their bibcards. From there he would develop that knowledge by elaborating on it (primarily by way of reflection notes). These notes would then chain together and create deeply rich knowledge that supported his theory of society. 从某种意义上说，Antinet 的最终目标集中在 “最大限度地增加创建它的基因的拷贝数”。579 考虑一下：Luhmann 的 Antinet 的目标是最大限度地传播他的思想。他打算通过打包他所有阅读材料中的证据来做到这一点。他开始从书中提取知识到他们的名片上。从那里，他将通过详细阐述（主要是通过反思笔记）来发展该知识。然后，这些笔记将链接在一起，创造出非常丰富的知识来支持他的社会理论。

In other words, Luhmann was reproducing and creating a legacy from his thoughts as they developed in his Antinet. 换句话说，卢曼正在从他的思想中复制和创造遗产，因为它们在他的 Antinet 中得到了发展。

The goal of the Antinet, then, is to replicate the thoughts of its creator in the real world. Think of the thoughts as intellectual genetic material encompassed in notecards. Therefore, the goal centers on reproduction—not biological reproduction, but metaphysical reproduction of your thoughts—and metaphysical reproduction of your thinking throughout the world. This is achieved through your thoughts being so well-developed that they end up producing work that reproduces those thoughts and allows them to be spread throughout the world. 因此，Antinet 的目标是在现实世界中复制其创造者的思想。将思想视为记录卡中包含的智力遗传材料。因此，目标集中在繁殖——不是生物繁殖，而是你思想的形而上学繁殖——以及你思想在全世界的形而上学繁殖。这是通过你的思想得到很好的发展来实现的，以至于它们最终产生了复制这些思想的作品，并让它们传播到世界各地。

Luhmann’s Antinet seems to have achieved this. His books are studied by scholars today—or at least studied by the ones with the diligence and motivation to parse his deeply intertwined texts! Yet, ironically, Luhmann’s Antinet seems to have the potential to proliferate and live on longer than even Luhmann’s actual theoretical work will. Or perhaps it’s not so ironic. People are fascinated with how Luhmann became a book-writing academic research machine. The answer? The Antinet.Luhmann 的 Antinet 似乎已经做到了这一点。他的书被今天的学者研究——或者至少被那些勤奋和积极地分析他深刻交织的文本的人研究过！然而，具有讽刺意味的是，卢曼的 Antinet 似乎有可能比卢曼的实际理论工作更广泛地传播和存在。或者也许它并不那么具有讽刺意味。人们对卢曼如何成为写作学术研究机器着迷。答案？反网。

In essence, the goal of the Antinet is to reproduce the thoughts of its creator by making it easier to create written products with the thoughts it stores. 从本质上讲，Antinet 的目标是通过使用它存储的思想更容易地创建书面产品来再现其创造者的思想。

Let’s now turn to the dichotomy of growth vs. contribution. 现在让我们转向增长与贡献的二分法。

**Growth vs. Contribution 增长与贡献**

There are two states one operates in when using the Antinet. One is not necessarily better than the other. In fact, you’ll likely move back and forth between each state regularly. 使用 Antinet 时有两种状态。一个不一定比另一个好。事实上，您可能会定期在每个状态之间来回移动。

The first state is the growth state. This occurs when using an Antinet to grow your own knowledge and understanding. Whenever you’re venturing into a new disciplinary field, you’ll spend the beginning phases learning by reading books in brand new fields and noting down brand new ideas. You’ll mostly be writing reformulation notes in this phase. You’ll be encountering new ideas and reformulating them in your own words. 第一个状态是生长状态。当使用 Antinet 来增长您自己的知识和理解时，就会发生这种情况。每当你进入一个新的学科领域时，你都会在开始阶段通过阅读全新领域的书籍和记下全新的想法来学习。在此阶段，您将主要编写重新制定的说明。你会遇到新的想法，并用你自己的话重新表述它们。

The second state is the contribution state. This occurs when using the Antinet to publish work and the focus is on contributing to others through teaching them material. In this stage your focus will be books that you’re creating. 第二个状态是贡献状态。当使用 Antinet 发布作品时会发生这种情况，并且重点是通过教他们材料来为他人做出贡献。在这个阶段，您的重点将放在您正在创作的书籍上。

You will often oscillate between the two states. However, I find that it’s best to strive and live in the contribution state. In other words, you want to write your notes as if they are part of a project or book that you’ll be publishing so that you can teach others. It’s a paradox because the best way to grow and learn something is by teaching the material, and the best way to do that is through having the mindset of contribution. 你会经常在这两种状态之间摇摆不定。但是，我发现最好在贡献状态下努力和生活。换句话说，你想把你的笔记当作你将要出版的项目或书籍的一部分来写，这样你就可以教别人了。这是一个悖论，因为成长和学习某些东西的最佳方式是通过教授材料，而做到这一点的最佳方式是拥有贡献的心态。

In the beginning of working on your Antinet, you may not be ready to actually commit to a certain project. I certainly wasn’t when I began my journey. However, I would like to nudge you in the direction of moving toward contribution. 在开始使用 Antinet 时，您可能还没有准备好实际投入某个项目。当我开始我的旅程时，我当然不是。然而，我想推动你朝着贡献的方向前进。

If Luhmann had not set out with the ambitious goal of creating a theory of society in thirty years, there’s a good chance we never would have even heard about the Zettelkasten in the first place. In essence, Luhmann’s Antinet wasn’t the only thing that helped him create genius-level work. The other thing that helped him was his massive ambitious goal for his Antinet. 如果卢曼没有在 30 年内立下创建社会理论的雄心勃勃的目标，那么我们很可能一开始就从未听说过 Zettelkasten。从本质上讲，卢曼的 Antinet 并不是唯一帮助他创造出天才级作品的东西。对他有帮助的另一件事是他为 Antinet 制定的雄心勃勃的目标。

The most important step to creating an Antinet that is too easily overlooked is determining what your goal is before writing your first note. It is the overall objective—the why—behind what attracted you to the Antinet that is critically important. 创建一个太容易被忽视的 Antinet 的最重要步骤是在写第一个笔记之前确定你的目标是什么。至关重要的是吸引您使用 Antinet 的总体目标——原因。

You ought to have at least a vague or general direction for what you intend to build with it. 对于您打算用它构建的内容，您至少应该有一个模糊的或大致的方向。

As Steven Pinker points out in his book, How the Mind Works, without specifying a goal “the very idea of intelligence is meaningless.”[580](#footnote-578) 正如史蒂文 · 平克 (Steven Pinker) 在他的著作《思维的运作方式》(How the Mind Works) 中指出的那样，没有具体说明目标，“智力的概念本身就毫无意义。”580

And what is intelligence? It is the phenomenon the Antinet is engineered to create. Intelligence comes from information. Information is a correlation between two things. Before you install anything in your Antinet, you will compare and correlate. You must decide if a concept is “this or something else,” as Luhmann says.[581](#footnote-577) 什么是智力？这是 Antinet 旨在创造的现象。智能来自信息。信息是两个事物之间的相关性。在 Antinet 中安装任何东西之前，您将进行比较和关联。正如卢曼所说，你必须决定一个概念是 “这个还是别的东西”。 581

In brief, it helps to specify a goal. To be fair, however, the system works perfectly even when you’re in a state in which your goal is to learn and grow. 简而言之，它有助于指定一个目标。然而，公平地说，即使您处于以学习和成长为目标的状态，该系统也能完美运行。

Luhmann’s second Zettelkasten was started when he had a clear goal in mind. His first Zettelkasten, however, was started when he didn’t have a clear idea of what his intellectual work would entail in the years he was working for the Higher Administrative Court of Lüneburg. During this time, he spent his nights reading and building his Antinet. He said, “I started my Zettelkasten, because I realized that I had to plan for a life and not for a book.”[582](#footnote-576)Luhmann 的第二个 Zettelkasten 是在他心中有一个明确的目标时开始的。然而，他的第一个 Zettelkasten 是在他不清楚他在 Lüneburg 高等行政法院工作的那些年里他的智力工作会带来什么时开始的。在此期间，他晚上都在阅读和构建他的 Antinet。他说，“我开始了我的 Zettelkasten，因为我意识到我必须为生活而不是一本书做计划。”582

This statement seems to contradict his reason for starting his second Antinet (the Antinet he created in order to work on his thirty-year book project culminating in his Theory of Society). 这种说法似乎与他开始他的第二个 Antinet 的原因相矛盾（他创建 Antinet 是为了从事他长达 30 年的书籍项目，最终在他的社会理论中达到顶峰）。

You might notice, though, that Luhmann did have a goal for his first Zettelkasten: it was to plan for life by learning from many fields of knowledge. 不过，您可能会注意到，Luhmann 确实为他的第一个 Zettelkasten 设定了一个目标：它是通过从许多知识领域学习来规划生活。

In brief, the Antinet can serve both states. It can assist someone who’s in the growth state (without a clear end goal), and it can also assist someone who’s in the contribution state (with a clearly defined book or project). 简而言之，Antinet 可以为两个州服务。它可以帮助处于成长状态的人（没有明确的最终目标），也可以帮助处于贡献状态的人（有明确定义的书籍或项目）。

From my experience, I have found the Antinet to really shine when one is in the contribution state. When you have a specific project and goal in mind, the Antinet really begins to flex its strength. 根据我的经验，我发现当一个人处于贡献状态时，Antinet 真的很闪耀。当您心中有了一个特定的项目和目标时，Antinet 就真正开始发挥它的力量了。

In essence, what we’re talking about here is the explore vs. exploit dilemma. That is, do you approach work as an explorer with an open-mind? Or do you approach your work with a deliberate goal, and exploit an opportunity you see? The explore-exploit tradeoff occurs every single day. It can be as simple as going to your favorite restaurant, or trying out a new one.[583](#footnote-575) 本质上，我们在这里谈论的是探索与利用的困境。也就是说，您是否以开放的心态对待工作？还是您以深思熟虑的目标对待您的工作，并利用您看到的机会？探索与利用的权衡每天都会发生。它可以像去您最喜欢的餐厅或尝试一家新餐厅一样简单。 583

In approaching this dilemma, I like a concept introduced by clinical psychologist and bestselling author Jordan Peterson. One ought to define a deliberate goal to limit the chaos of life. Yet one also ought to adopt a meta goal. The term meta, in Greek, means above or beyond. Therefore, one ought to have a goal which resides above a concrete project in the physical world. An example of a meta goal is to “live in truth.” That is, a meta goal allows one to act diligently toward a defined end in an authentic way that remains in alignment with your soul.[584](#footnote-574) Have a defined goal, yes; however, if your soul authentically shifts, shift with it. 在解决这个难题时，我喜欢临床心理学家和畅销书作家乔丹彼得森提出的一个概念。人们应该定义一个深思熟虑的目标来限制生活的混乱。然而，人们也应该采用一个元目标。在希腊语中，meta 一词的意思是超越或超越。因此，一个人应该有一个高于物质世界中具体项目的目标。元目标的一个例子是 “活在真实中”。也就是说，一个元目标允许一个人以一种与你的灵魂保持一致的真实方式朝着一个明确的目标努力行动。584 有一个明确的目标，是的；然而，如果你的灵魂真的在转变，那就跟着转变。

**Before Writing Your First Note 在写你的第一个笔记之前**

One critical point that rarely gets mentioned may seem rather obvious: it’s helpful to have a project in mind for your Antinet. An Antinet is not necessarily something you ought to do with the idea of completely open-ended reading. As Luhmann states, “I first make a plan of what I am going to write, and then take from the note cabinet what I can use.”[585](#footnote-573) When Luhmann drew from the Antinet the material would use for a new project, that material did not come about through aimless reading. At some point, he made a decision on what project to work on. 一个很少被提及的关键点可能看起来相当明显：为您的 Antinet 考虑一个项目是有帮助的。对于完全开放式阅读的想法，Antinet 不一定是您应该做的事情。正如卢曼所说，“我首先制定我要写的计划，然后从笔记柜中取出我可以使用的东西。”585 当卢曼从 Antinet 中提取将用于新项目的材料时，该材料确实不是通过漫无目的的阅读来的。在某个时候，他决定要从事哪个项目。

The key point is that when you decide to work on a project, it doesn’t necessarily confine you to that project forever. The material you create in one project will unearth material you can use in your next project. 关键是当你决定从事一个项目时，并不一定要把你永远限制在那个项目上。您在一个项目中创建的材料将发掘您可以在下一个项目中使用的材料。

For instance, when I first started building out my Antinet, I didn’t yet realize I was going to write a book on it. I was planning on writing a book that sat at the intersection of copywriting, psychology, and philosophy. My readings included books like The Hero with a Thousand Faces, which is about the hero’s journey and storytelling. It didn’t seem like any of the material would have been relevant to this book; yet, as it turns out, it was relevant! In my section on the tree structure of the Antinet, I used some of the material in discussing the metaphysical power pertaining to the concept of trees. Moreover, reading about the power of trees may have helped spark the light bulb that helped me realize that the Antinet is built on a tree structure. 例如，当我第一次开始构建我的 Antinet 时，我还没有意识到我要写一本书。我正计划写一本位于文案写作、心理学和哲学交叉点的书。我的读物包括像《千面英雄》这样的书，这是关于英雄的旅程和故事的。似乎没有任何材料与本书相关；然而，事实证明，它是相关的！在我关于 Antinet 树结构的部分中，我使用了一些材料来讨论与树概念相关的形而上学力量。此外，阅读有关树木的力量的文章可能有助于点燃灯泡，帮助我意识到 Antinet 是建立在树结构上的。

What I’m trying to say is this: take a goal-oriented approach when building out your Antinet. Do not worry if, later on, you decide to progress to a completely different project. Why? Because it’s likely the material you develop will still contribute to the new project. All domains of knowledge are interdisciplinary. Concepts in mathematics can serve one’s understanding of philosophical concepts. The great mathematician Bertrand Russell also penned one of the best books ever written on philosophy (A History of Western Philosophy, which won him a Nobel Prize in 1950). This is but one of countless examples. 我想说的是：在构建 Antinet 时采用以目标为导向的方法。如果以后您决定进行一个完全不同的项目，请不要担心。为什么？因为您开发的材料很可能仍会为新项目做出贡献。所有知识领域都是跨学科的。数学中的概念可以服务于一个人对哲学概念的理解。伟大的数学家伯特兰 · 罗素 (Bertrand Russell) 也撰写了有史以来最好的哲学著作之一（西方哲学史，这本书为他赢得了 1950 年的诺贝尔奖）。这只是无数例子中的一个。

I’ll keep hammering this idea into you: having a goal or project in mind is critical when developing notes using an Antinet. Even when reading a book, the goal-oriented nature and intention of reading is paramount.[586](#footnote-572) I’ll illustrate this principle more in the chapter on reading workflows. 我会不断地向你灌输这个想法：在使用 Antinet 编写笔记时，心中有一个目标或项目是至关重要的。即使在阅读一本书时，以目标为导向的性质和阅读意图也是最重要的。586 我将在阅读工作流程一章中详细说明这一原则。

The reason I keep emphasizing this is because the magic of the Antinet really started taking off for me once I shifted to contribution. In mid-June 2021, I made a decision to focus on teaching the true Zettelkasten— the Luhmannian version—the Antinet Zettelkasten. Up until that point I was resisting the idea of writing a book about the Antinet. I feared it would just be a distraction or procrastination-fueled detour. It also appeared seemingly absurd at the time. My profession and craft was in marketing, copywriting, and cryptocurrency (which are much more lucrative markets). The PKM and productivity market is as niche as it gets. And within that niche almost everyone focuses on teaching the powerful “method” of whatever the latest and greatest digital app is. 我一直强调这一点的原因是，一旦我转向贡献，Antinet 的魔力就真正开始为我起飞。 2021 年 6 月中旬，我决定专注于教授真正的 Zettelkasten——卢曼版本——Antinet Zettelkasten。在那之前，我一直在抵制写一本关于 Antinet 的书的想法。我担心这只会让我分心或因拖延而绕道而行。这在当时也显得很荒谬。我的职业和手艺是市场营销、文案写作和加密货币（这些市场利润更高）。 PKM 和生产力市场非常小众。在这个利基市场中，几乎每个人都专注于教授最新最好的数字应用程序的强大 “方法”。

Yet, I knew in my heart and soul the truth: analog tools serve as a much more effective system for developing thought. I knew in my heart that people were left with watered down digital Zettelkasten tools. There were no instructions or guides for how to build an analog version—the original version. I couldn’t let it go. So, even with doubts in my mind, I made a commitment. To hell with the copywriting, psychology and philosophy project for now, I said to myself. I’m going all in on the Antinet. 然而，我内心深处知道一个事实：模拟工具是一种更有效的思维发展系统。我心里知道，人们只剩下淡化了的数字 Zettelkasten 工具。没有关于如何构建模拟版本（原始版本）的说明或指南。我不能放手。所以，即使心中有疑虑，我还是做出了承诺。现在让文案写作、心理学和哲学项目见鬼去吧，我对自己说。我要全力投入 Antinet。

This is when things really started to take off. At this point I began to experience the magic of the Antinet. Yet even before this commitment to the Antinet, I made a soft commitment to working on a copywriting, psychology and philosophy project. 这是事情真正开始起飞的时候。至此我开始体会到 Antinet 的神奇之处。然而，甚至在投身于 Antinet 之前，我就软性承诺从事文案、心理学和哲学项目。

Again, commit to an idea or project and don’t fret if you decide to shift into a different project altogether. You can shift back to the original project whenever you’re done with the new project. You can also shift back to different projects if you hit a wall (figuratively speaking). As Luhmann says (after outlining his twelve-plus-hour work days): “I only write when I know immediately how to do it. If it stops for a moment, I put the thing aside and do something else.”[587](#footnote-571) However, don’t let Luhmann’s turn you into someone who switches tasks every other day. Try to start things you’ll finish. Commit to them, but also know they can be revisited if you ever decide to switch to something else after a few months. 再次重申，致力于一个想法或项目，如果您决定完全转向另一个项目，请不要担心。每当您完成新项目时，您都可以切换回原始项目。如果你碰壁了（打个比方），你也可以转回不同的项目。正如卢曼所说（在概述了他每天 12 个多小时的工作之后）：“我只在我立即知道如何去做时才写作。如果它停了一会儿，我就把它放在一边去做其他事情。”587 但是，不要让 Luhmann 把你变成每隔一天就切换一次任务的人。尝试开始你将要完成的事情。对它们做出承诺，但也要知道，如果您在几个月后决定改用其他东西，可以重新访问它们。

Johannes Schmidt writes, “at least in the more mature stage of Luhmann’s theory-building since the 1970s, [Luhmann’s Antinet] did not serve as a pure archive that he would develop independent of specific publication projects.” Luhmann only installed cards in his Antinet that were related to publication requests he took on.[588](#footnote-570) 约翰内斯施密特写道，“至少在 1970 年代以来卢曼理论构建的更成熟阶段，[卢曼的 Antinet] 并没有作为他将独立于特定出版项目开发的纯粹档案。” Luhmann 只在他的 Antinet 中安装了与他接受的出版请求相关的卡片。 588

Yet, as Schmidt points out, the material Luhmann developed during the course of fulfilling publication requests—by writing research papers—ended up serving as the basis for his books. By taking on one project, the new material created unforeseeable developments in his other long-term projects. As Luhmann worked on new publications, “in the process, he would also document the evolution of his thought process,” writes Schmidt. “Over the course of producing these publications,” his theory developments were compounded.[589](#footnote-569) 然而，正如施密特指出的那样，卢曼在满足出版要求的过程中开发的材料——通过撰写研究论文——最终成为了他著作的基础。通过承担一个项目，新材料在他的其他长期项目中创造了不可预见的发展。当卢曼致力于新的出版物时，“在这个过程中，他也会记录他思想过程的演变，” 施密特写道。 “在制作这些出版物的过程中，” 他的理论发展是复杂的。 589

**How to Build an Antinet 如何构建 Antinet**
----------------------------------------

OK, now that you know the obstacles to avoid, we can now get into building your Antinet. Jesus Christ, Scott, it’s about time! 好的，既然您知道要避免的障碍，我们现在可以开始构建您的 Antinet。耶稣基督，斯科特，是时候了！

Here is an overview of the system we will be building: 以下是我们将要构建的系统的概述：

**The Supplies You Need 您需要的用品**

To help perfect the way I teach the Antinet, I conducted a series of 1-on-1 Antinet coaching sessions (the recordings of which you can find on my YouTube channel). 为了帮助完善我教授 Antinet 的方式，我进行了一系列一对一的 Antinet 辅导课程（您可以在我的 YouTube 频道上找到这些课程的录音）。

With each of my Antinet coaching clients, I recommend the following materials for getting started: 对于我的每个 Antinet 教练客户，我推荐以下入门材料：

1. Three noteboxes that can store 4 x 6 inch notecards (or one box, if you wish to save space for now).1. 三个可存放 4 x 6 英寸记事卡的记事盒（或一个盒子，如果您现在想节省空间）。

2. A set of blank double-sided 4 x 6 inch notecards.2. 一套空白双面 4 x 6 英寸记事卡。

3. A set of ruled colored 4 x 6 inch indexcards.3. 一套 4 x 6 英寸彩色索引卡。

4. A set of alphabetical card dividers, wherein each divider label contains a dedicated alphabetical letter (i.e., A, B, C, etc.).4. 一组字母卡分隔器，其中每个分隔器标签包含专用字母（即 A、B、C 等）。

You will also need a badass pen. Use a pen you love to write with. Think of it as an instrument. People apply a ton of creativity to what colors they use. You’re welcome to use whichever set of colors work best for you. I’ve experimented with different colored inks over time. My current ink repertoire is black ink for main notes, green ink for cardlinks, and red ink for ExRefs (i.e., citing books and external sources). 您还需要一支 badass 笔。使用您喜欢书写的笔。把它想象成一种乐器。人们对他们使用的颜色应用了大量的创造力。欢迎您使用最适合您的一组颜色。随着时间的推移，我尝试了不同颜色的墨水。我目前的墨水库是黑色墨水用于主要笔记，绿色墨水用于卡片链接，红色墨水用于 ExRef（即引用书籍和外部资源）。

**Building Out Your Main Box and Index Box 构建您的主框和索引框**

In my experience coaching people through this process, I find that most people don’t have a problem taking notes from the books they read. Taking reading notes is straightforward. Heck, it’s even addicting and fun! Those types of notes are filed in the bib box. I’ll cover that in the next section which involves reading strategies. 根据我在这个过程中指导人们的经验，我发现大多数人对从他们读过的书中做笔记没有问题。做阅读笔记很简单。哎呀，它甚至令人上瘾和有趣！这些类型的笔记被归档在围兜箱中。我将在涉及阅读策略的下一节中介绍这一点。

We’re going to skip the bib box part for now. Instead we’re going to dive right into the heart of the Antinet, the so-called “hard part” of this whole thing. We’re going to build out the main box and index box of your Antinet. Realize that you’re not going to really understand why I’m telling you to do certain things in the beginning; but just follow exactly what I say. Don’t try and understand it yet. Just proceed step-by-step in a deliberate fashion. Follow every detail. Sound good? 我们暂时跳过 bib box 部分。相反，我们将直接进入 Antinet 的核心，即整个事情的所谓 “困难部分”。我们将构建 Antinet 的主框和索引框。意识到你不会真正理解为什么我一开始就告诉你做某些事情；但只要完全按照我说的去做。不要试图去理解它。只需谨慎地逐步进行即可。关注每一个细节。听起来不错？

Let’s go. 我们走吧。

● Take out a pen with black ink.● 拿出一支黑色墨水笔。

● Take out a blank white 4 x 6 inch notecard.[590](#footnote-568)● 取出一张空白的白色 4 x 6 英寸记事卡。590

● In the top-right corner[591](#footnote-567) write 1000.● 在右上角 591 写 1000。

● In the center write Arts & Humanities.● 在中间写上 Arts & Humanities。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● Take out another notecard.● 取出另一张记事卡。

● In the corner write 2000, and in the middle write Social Sciences.● 角落写 2000，中间写社会科学。

● Take out another notecard.● 取出另一张记事卡。

● In the corner write 3000, and in the middle write Natural Sciences.● 角落写 3000，中间写自然科学。

● Take out another notecard.● 取出另一张记事卡。

● In the corner write 4000, and in the middle write Formal Sciences.● 角落写 4000，中间写 Formal Sciences。

● Take out one more notecard.● 再取出一张记事卡。

● In the corner write 5000, and in the middle write Applied Arts & Sciences.● 角落写 5000，中间写 Applied Arts & Sciences。

● Now, stack all five of these cards in sequential order from 1000 to 5000 and place them in the first box.● 现在，将所有五张卡片按顺序从 1000 到 5000 堆叠起来，然后将它们放入第一个盒子中。

This is your main box. 这是你的主盒子。

● On the front of this box create a small label for this box that reads Main.● 在这个盒子的前面为这个盒子创建一个小标签，上面写着 Main。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● Now, pull out 26 ruled indexcards. I like to use colored indexcards for these. Set them in front of you.● 现在，拿出 26 张横格索引卡。我喜欢为这些使用彩色索引卡。把它们摆在你面前。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● With the first indexcard, in the top-left corner, write A.● 在第一张索引卡片的左上角，写上 A。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● Do the same exact thing for the remaining twenty five letters in the alphabet.● 对字母表中剩下的二十五个字母做同样的事情。

● Now, stack the 26 cards in alphabetical order, from A-Z, then place the stack of 26 cards in the second box.● 现在，将 26 张卡片按字母顺序从 A 到 Z 堆叠起来，然后将这叠 26 张卡片放入第二个盒子中。

● On the second box, create a label that reads Index, and place it on the front of the box.● 在第二个盒子上，创建一个标签，上面写着索引，并将其放在盒子的前面。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

The first box is your main box. Your Antinet is a tree of knowledge. The tree contains five main branches (1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, and 5000). From these five branches, many other branches will “branch off.” Stems will form, and leaves of notecards will fill up the tree. Right now, your tree of knowledge is barren. We’ll fix that soon. 第一个框是您的主框。你的 Antinet 是一棵知识树。该树包含五个主要分支（1000、2000、3000、4000 和 5000）。从这五个分支中，会 “分出” 许多其他分支。茎会形成，记事卡的叶子会填满树。现在，你的知识之树是贫瘠的。我们会尽快解决这个问题。

The second box containing 26 cards is your index. Your index is the map you create as you build your tree of knowledge. 第二个包含 26 张卡片的盒子是您的索引。您的索引是您在构建知识树时创建的地图。

Now, pull out another blank notecard. 现在，拿出另一张空白记事卡。

On this notecard, write out the following quote. However, before you write it out, make sure you leave about a centimeter of space at the top of the quote. 在这张记事卡上，写下以下引述。然而，在你把它写出来之前，确保你在报价的顶部留出大约一厘米的空间。

“One of the most basic presuppositions of communication is that the partners can mutually surprise each other. Only in this way can information be produced in the respective other. Information is an intra-systematic event. It results when one compares one message or entry with regard to other possibilities. Information, accordingly, originates only in systems which possess a comparative schema—even if this only amounts to ‘this or something else.’”“沟通的最基本前提之一是合作伙伴可以互相惊喜。只有这样，才能在各自的他者中产生信息。信息是系统内的事件。当一个人将一条消息或条目与其他可能性进行比较时，就会产生这种结果。因此，信息仅起源于具有比较图式的系统——即使这仅相当于 “这个或其他东西”。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

At this point, you’re probably wondering why the heck I made you write down this excerpt. After all, your reason for using an Antinet probably won’t focus on writing about communication theory or information theory. 在这一点上，你可能想知道为什么我让你写下这段摘录。毕竟，您使用 Antinet 的原因可能不会专注于撰写有关通信理论或信息理论的文章。

The reason why I chose to start with this is to show the flexibility of the system we’re about to create. 我选择从这个开始的原因是为了展示我们将要创建的系统的灵活性。

You see, in Luhmann’s first Antinet, he created 108 top-level categories. They were rough starting points. They included many topics he was interested in. Yet when he created his second Antinet, it was focused primarily on his theoretical sociological work. 你看，在卢曼的第一个 Antinet 中，他创建了 108 个顶级类别。它们是粗略的起点。其中包括他感兴趣的许多主题。然而，当他创建他的第二个 Antinet 时，它主要集中在他的理论社会学工作上。

If Luhmann had started out with a broader classification system (instead of his arbitrarily chosen 108 categories), I hold that he would never have needed to create a second Antinet. If he had structured his first Antinet to be all-encompassing, he could have created a branch (or set of branches), which nicely encompassed his theoretical sociological work. 如果 Luhmann 从一个更广泛的分类系统开始（而不是他任意选择的 108 个类别），我认为他永远不需要创建第二个 Antinet。如果他将他的第一个 Antinet 构建为包罗万象，他本可以创建一个分支（或一组分支），它很好地涵盖了他的理论社会学工作。

The goal with your Antinet is to avoid having to make a second, separate Antinet; to reach that goal, you’ll use an all-encompassing structure to house all your knowledge so that you can use the same Antinet for the rest of your life.Antinet 的目标是避免制作第二个独立的 Antinet；为实现该目标，您将使用一个包罗万象的结构来容纳您的所有知识，以便您可以在余生中使用同一个 Antinet。

This will be made possible by using a well-developed and robust classification system. For this reason, I choose to use the academic disciplinary fields provided by Wikipedia. 这将通过使用完善且强大的分类系统来实现。为此，我选择使用维基百科提供的学科领域。

Here is a link to Wikipedia’s Outline of academic disciplines: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_academic_disciplines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_academic_disciplines) 这是维基百科学术学科大纲的链接：https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_academic_disciplines

This classification system will serve as a rough guide for how to structure your Antinet. 该分类系统将作为如何构建 Antinet 的粗略指南。

You will notice that the contents of the academic disciplines have five top-level branches. These five top-level branches map directly to the five branches you already created. The sub-branches of each of these categories can be created and numbered arbitrarily. The choice of the numbers and whether or not to even create the sub-branch is entirely up to you. Here’s a picture: 你会注意到学科的内容有五个顶级分支。这五个顶级分支直接映射到您已经创建的五个分支。每个类别的子分支都可以任意创建和编号。号码的选择以及是否创建支行完全取决于您。这是一张照片：

I will now show you how to use the academic disciplines to help you figure out where to install your notecards. 我现在将向您展示如何使用学术学科来帮助您确定将记事卡安装在何处。

OK, so where should we place the notecard we’ve just created? 好的，那么我们应该把刚刚创建的记事卡放在哪里呢？

The quote I had you write on the notecard is from Niklas Luhmann. He’s writing of the Antinet as his communication partner. He’s observing that information comes about by comparing something to something else. I guess it could be filed in either an information branch, or a communication branch. But which one? In my opinion, the primary idea in this quote revolves around information, so let’s go with that. 我让你写在记事卡上的引语来自尼克拉斯 · 卢曼。他正在撰写 Antinet 作为他的沟通伙伴。他观察到信息是通过将某物与另一物进行比较而产生的。我想它可以提交到信息部门或通信部门。但是哪一个？在我看来，这句话的主要思想围绕着信息，所以让我们继续吧。

Now, let’s open up the Wikipedia’s academic disciplines page, and search the page for the term information. What we find are twenty-one search results for the term information on the page. We also find that the first three seem irrelevant… 现在，让我们打开维基百科的学科页面，并在页面中搜索术语信息。我们找到的是页面上的术语信息的 21 个搜索结果。我们还发现前三个似乎无关紧要……

But, aha! The fourth result seems intriguing…it’s something called Information Theory. What the heck is Information Theory? Let’s find out. 但是，啊哈！第四个结果似乎很有趣…… 这就是所谓的信息论。信息论到底是什么？让我们找出答案。

 Pull out another blank notecard. In the middle write:¦ 拿出另一张空白记事卡。中间写：

Information Theory 信息论

Information Theory studies the transmission, processing, extraction, and utilization of information. 信息论研究信息的传输、处理、提取和利用。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

Still with me? 还在我这儿？

Good. 好的。

You now have two cards in front of you. One with the quote written on it, and the other for Information Theory. If you don’t, retrace your steps (and get your shit together). Kidding, but seriously. 现在你面前有两张牌。一个上面写着引文，另一个是信息论。如果你不这样做，请折回你的步骤（并把你的狗屎放在一起）。开玩笑，但认真。

Let’s keep going. 我们继续吧。

So now we have two cards with handwritten stuff on them. 所以现在我们有两张带有手写内容的卡片。

Where should we file these cards? 我们应该在哪里归档这些卡片？

Let’s start with the second card we wrote. The one that outlines Infor- mation Theory. 让我们从我们写的第二张卡片开始。概述信息论的那个。

By consulting Wikipedia’s academic disciplines, we can see that Information Theory falls under the field of Formal Sciences. It falls specifically within the subfield of Computer Science. 通过查阅维基百科的学科，我们可以看到信息论属于形式科学领域。它特别属于计算机科学的子领域。

● Still with me? Cool. Now pull out another blank card.● 还在我身边吗？凉爽的。现在拿出另一张空白卡片。

● In the top-corner write, 4200 and in the middle write:● 上角写 4200，中间写：

Computer Science 计算机科学

Computer Science is the study of computation, automation, and information. 计算机科学是对计算、自动化和信息的研究。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● Now it’s time to consult the index. In your index box find the list indexcard C and pull it out.● 现在是查询索引的时候了。在您的索引框中找到列表索引卡 C 并将其拉出。

● With the card C, write an entry that reads Computer Science: ‘4200’.● 使用卡片 C，写下一个条目，内容为计算机科学：“4200”。

It should look something like this: 它应该看起来像这样：

I like to put little quotes around cardlinks so they feel more contained. It’s just a personal preference. 我喜欢在卡片链接周围加上小引号，这样它们就更有内涵了。这只是个人喜好。

● Now place the C list indexcard back inside the index box. File the card 4200 behind the card 4000 in the main box.● 现在将 C 列表索引卡放回索引框内。将主箱中的卡片 4000 后面的卡片 4200 归档。

OK, now back to the Information Theory card. 好的，现在回到信息论卡片。

Where should we file the Information Theory card? 我们应该在哪里归档信息论卡？

● Let’s place it within the Computer Science branch. Why? Because according to Wikipedia’s Outline of Academic Disciplines, Information Theory falls under Computer Science. So, let’s arbitrarily choose 4212 for Information Theory.● 让我们把它放在计算机科学分支中。为什么？因为根据维基百科的学科大纲，信息论属于计算机科学。所以，让我们随意选择 4212 作为信息论。

● In the top-corner of the Information Theory card write 4212.● 在信息论卡片的右上角写上 4212。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● Now file this card in your main box behind card 4200.● 现在将这张卡片归档在你的主箱中卡片 4200 后面。

Good job so far! 到目前为止干得好！

Now, there should be one remaining card in front of you—the card with the long-quote on it. Let’s figure out where to file this card. 现在，你面前应该还有一张卡片——上面有长引号的卡片。让我们找出将这张卡片归档的位置。

In the Antinet, the name of the game is similarity. When figuring out where to install a card, you must ask: What is this card most similar to? 在 Antinet 中，游戏的名称是相似性。在确定卡的安装位置时，您必须问：这张卡与什么最相似？

OK, so what is this card in front of us most similar to? That’s easy. It’s most similar to the Information Theory card. Indeed, it even falls within the Information Theory branch.OK，那么我们面前的这张卡片和什么最相似呢？这很容易。它与信息论卡片最相似。实际上，它甚至属于信息论分支。

● In the top-right corner of the card write 4212/1.● 在卡片的右上角写上 4212/1。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

Heck yes! We’re all done, right? Almost, but not quite. 哎呀是的！我们都完成了，对吧？差不多，但不完全是。

There are a few more things we ought to do. 还有几件事我们应该做。

● First, pull out the list indexcard I from your index box.● 首先，从您的索引箱中取出列表索引卡 I。

● Create an entry: Information Theory, and next to that write, 4212● 创建一个条目：Information Theory，然后在旁边写上 4212

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

There’s another thing we ought to do (since we’re pros). 还有一件事我们应该做（因为我们是专业人士）。

● Let’s add an entry under list indexcard C for Communication within the context of Information Theory. Pull out the list indexcard C and write Communication (within Information Theory): ‘4212/1’.● 让我们在信息论上下文中的通信列表索引卡 C 下添加一个条目。拉出列表索引卡 C 并写下通信（在信息论中）：“4212/1”。

It should look like this: 它应该是这样的：

● OK, now file away C by putting it back in your index box.● 好的，现在把 C 放回你的索引箱，把它归档。

In front of you, there should be one notecard: 4212/1. Before you install 4212/1 into your main box, we have one more thing we need to do. 在你面前，应该有一张记事卡：4212/1。在将 4212/1 安装到主机箱之前，我们还需要做一件事。

On 4212/1, what you did was write down a quote. The notion that Luhmann never wrote down excerpts or quotes is a myth. Luhmann did, indeed, write down quotes from the books he read. That said, you want to err on the side of creating more reformulation notes and reflection notes (instead of excerpt notes). I’ll detail those types of notes in a later chapter. For now, it’s helpful to start you off with an excerpt note (which is why I had you write down that quote)! 在 4212/1 上，您所做的只是写下引述。卢曼从未写下摘录或引述的观点是一个神话。事实上，卢曼确实从他读过的书中摘下了引述。也就是说，您宁愿创建更多重新制定的笔记和反思笔记（而不是摘录笔记）。我将在后面的章节中详细介绍这些类型的笔记。现在，以摘录注释开始你会很有帮助（这就是我让你写下那句话的原因）！

When you create an excerpt note, it requires one thing. It must also provide the source from where the quote came from. To answer this, we shall now dive into External Reference Links (“ExRefs”). 当您创建摘录笔记时，它需要一件事。它还必须提供引用的来源。为了回答这个问题，我们现在将深入研究外部参考链接（“ExRefs”）。

Stay with me; we’re almost done. 留在我身边; 我们快完成了。

● On a computer, download the reference manager called Zotero by visit- ing [www.zotero.org](http://www.zotero.org/).● 在计算机上，访问 www.zotero.org 下载名为 Zotero 的参考管理器。

● After you download and install Zotero on your computer, there is one more step. You must download the Zotero connector for your web browser. Visit the following link and download the connector for the browser that you use: [https://www.zotero.org/download/connectors](https://www.zotero.org/download/connectors)● 在您的计算机上下载并安装 Zotero 后，还有一个步骤。您必须为您的 Web 浏览器下载 Zotero 连接器。访问以下链接并下载适用于您使用的浏览器的连接器：https://www.zotero.org/download/connectors

● Next, open up Zotero.● 接下来，打开 Zotero。

● Now, using the browser in which you have the Zotero Connector installed, visit the following URL: [https://daily.scottscheper.com/zettelkasten/](https://daily.scottscheper.com/zettelkasten/)This URL is where the quote originated from. It is an English translation of a paper titled Communication with Noteboxes by Niklas Luhmann.[592](#footnote-566)● 现在，使用安装了 Zotero Connector 的浏览器访问以下 URL：https://daily.scottscheper.com/zettelkasten / 此 URL 是引用的来源。这是一篇名为 Communication with Noteboxes 的论文的英文翻译，作者是 Niklas Luhmann.592

● While viewing this web page, click the Zotero icon which should now be installed in the panel of your browser. It should capture the page and add it as an entry to your Zotero Desktop application.● 查看此网页时，单击现在应安装在浏览器面板中的 Zotero 图标。它应该捕获页面并将其作为条目添加到您的 Zotero 桌面应用程序。

● Now, switch over to the Zotero Desktop application. Click on the new entry. It should look something like this:● 现在，切换到 Zotero Desktop 应用程序。单击新条目。它应该看起来像这样：

After clicking on the entry, you should see four buttons in the right-hand area: Info, Notes, Tags, and Related. 单击条目后，您应该会在右侧区域看到四个按钮：Info、Notes、Tags 和 Related。

● Click Tags.● 单击标记。

● Add a new tag and name it r.TDSSZ.[593](#footnote-565)● 添加一个新标签并将其命名为 r.TDSSZ.593

The “r.” prepended to the reference identifier indicates that we’re referencing an ExRef stored in Zotero.“r”。在引用标识符前面表示我们正在引用存储在 Zotero 中的 ExRef。

Ok, now let’s jump back to the card 4212/1. 好的，现在让我们跳回卡片 4212/1。

● Take out a pen. One with red ink.● 拿出一支笔。一个用红墨水。

● Immediately after the quote ends, add a little footnote in red ink by writing [1] after it. In the bottom-left corner, with red ink as well, write the following: 1. r.TDSSZ. This signals to us where this quote originated from.● 引用结束后，立即用红墨水在其后写上 [1] 添加一个小脚注。在左下角，同样用红色墨水写下以下内容： 1. r.TDSSZ。这向我们表明了这句话的来源。

The card 4212/1 should now look like this: 卡 4212/1 现在应该如下所示：

Now take a look at that beautiful card in front of you. Bask in its glory. 现在看看你面前那张漂亮的卡片。沐浴在它的荣耀中。

● Now file it away behind notecard 4212.● 现在将它归档在记事卡 4212 后面。

That’s it for now. 现在就是这样。

This should give you a taste for what it’s like working with an Antinet. 这应该会让您体验使用 Antinet 的感觉。

You now have your main box and index box built out. 您现在已经构建了主框和索引框。

Eventually, as you build out your Antinet, it will grow significantly. Instead of one main box, you’ll have many main boxes. In fact, you’ll probably end up with a box for each of the five branches you’ve created. A box each for 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, 5000. At that point, your Antinet will have grown to look like this: 最终，当您构建 Antinet 时，它会显着增长。您将拥有许多主箱，而不是一个主箱。事实上，您最终可能会为您创建的五个分支中的每一个创建一个框。 1000、2000、3000、4000、5000 各一个盒子。到那时，你的 Antinet 将长成这样：

One of the things I recommend picking up is a set of alphabetical card dividers. 我推荐的东西之一是一套按字母顺序排列的卡片分隔器。

The card dividers are useful for when your index box expands. They’re also useful for storing bibcards in your bib box (which I’ll outline in the chapter on Extraction). 当您的索引框展开时，卡片分隔器很有用。它们对于将 bibcards 存储在你的 bib box 中也很有用（我将在提取章节中概述）。

Here’s a picture of my index box: 这是我的索引框的图片：

The alphabetical dividers are helpful for sorting through the indexcards quickly. 按字母顺序排列的分隔符有助于快速对索引卡进行排序。

These are mere conveniences. You don’t need them to thrive in the beginning, but they’re things you’ll want to add to your Antinet as it grows. 这些仅仅是方便。你不需要它们在一开始就茁壮成长，但随着它的发展，它们是你想要添加到你的 Antinet 中的东西。

**Frequently Asked Questions 经常问的问题**
-------------------------------------

There’s a chance you’ll have questions come up that I haven’t addressed fully. In such a case, a good resource is the Antinet Reddit Community ([www.reddit.com/r/Antinet](http://www.reddit.com/r/Antinet)). There’s also a good chance the question you may have has been answered there, not just by myself, but by other Antinetters, as well. In addition, I recommend you visit my website as another resource ([www.scottscheper.com](http://www.scottscheper.com/)). On my website, and through my email list, I share a wealth of Antinet resources. 您可能会提出我没有完全解决的问题。在这种情况下，Antinet Reddit 社区 (www.reddit.com/r/Antinet) 是一个很好的资源。还有一个很好的机会，你可能已经在那里回答了问题，不仅仅是我自己，还有其他 Antinetters。此外，我建议您访问我的网站作为另一种资源 (www.scottscheper.com)。在我的网站上，并通过我的电子邮件列表，我共享了丰富的 Antinet 资源。

With that said, I’d like to address a few questions I get asked frequently. 话虽如此，我想回答几个我经常被问到的问题。

**Where Should I Place This Card? 我应该把这张卡放在哪里？**

It seems like the most common area where people get hung up is the numeric-alpha addresses. We imagine that there’s some correct place or area for a card to be filed. That’s one of the downsides of using academic disciplines as a classification system. It implies that there’s some perfect and correct place for a certain card to be placed. 人们挂断电话的最常见区域似乎是数字字母地址。我们想象有一些正确的地方或区域可以归档卡片。这是使用学术学科作为分类系统的缺点之一。这意味着放置某张牌有一些完美和正确的地方。

Let me make it perfectly clear: the correct place for any card is to install it near its most similar neighbor. 让我说得非常清楚：任何卡的正确位置都是将其安装在最相似的邻居附近。

If you want to install a card in a more remote location, under a branch you feel fits better, simply create a cardlink for it. For instance, my main section where I write about the Antinet resides at 4214. However, there are certain sections related to that topic, which live in other locations. 如果你想在更远的地方安装一张卡，在你觉得更合适的分支下，只需为它创建一个卡链接。例如，我写关于 Antinet 的主要部分位于 4214。但是，与该主题相关的某些部分位于其他位置。

For example, I have a section about writing by hand, which is discussed in 4214/3d/3b. However, I also have a section on the power of writing by hand in section 1323. Why? Because the section 1323 resides closer to my section on writing. This isn’t a problem. I just have a card within 4214/3d/3b that says, For more on writing by hand, see also: ‘1323’. 例如，我有一个关于手写的部分，在 4214/3d/3b 中讨论。但是，我在第 1323 节中也有一节是关于手写的力量的。为什么？因为 1323 部分离我的写作部分更近。这不是问题。我只有一张 4214/3d/3b 内的卡片，上面写着，有关手写的更多信息，另请参阅：“1323”。

If you’re struggling to figure out how to make branches for your cards, remember that there’s no correct solution. It’s arbitrary. Each scenario will work. If you’re trying to figure out whether to create a branch at 4212 vs. 4300, let me offer some guidance: if the area will comprise a significant portion of your work with many sub-branches, then I’d opt for 4300. This grants you the ability to organize a structure like this: 如果您正在努力弄清楚如何为您的卡片创建分支，请记住没有正确的解决方案。这是任意的。每个场景都会起作用。如果您想弄清楚是在 4212 还是在 4300 处创建分支机构，请让我提供一些指导：如果该区域将包含您工作的重要部分以及许多子分支机构，那么我会选择 4300。这使您能够组织这样的结构：

However, even if you elected to go with 4212, you’ll be fine. You can organize such a branch like this: 但是，即使您选择使用 4212，也没有问题。您可以像这样组织这样的分支：

These are very clean examples. However, in reality, when you use an Antinet, it’s never perfectly clean. It’s a system of ordered chaos. Embrace it. Stop trying to confine the infinite depths of knowledge to some preconceived set of categories. 这些都是非常干净的例子。然而，实际上，当您使用 Antinet 时，它永远不会完全干净。这是一个有序的混沌系统。拥抱它。不要试图将知识的无限深度限制在某些先入为主的类别中。

Your Antinet, over time, will evolve into a unique structure. This gives it a personality. This is what transforms it into an alter-ego, a second mind, a communication partner. 随着时间的推移，你的 Antinet 将演变成一个独特的结构。这赋予了它个性。这就是将它转变为另一个自我、第二个思维、一个沟通伙伴的原因。

**What If I Already Have a Card There? 如果我已经在那里有卡怎么办？**

Another question I get asked pertains to what you should do if you already have a card installed in the desired location. 我被问到的另一个问题是，如果您已经在所需位置安装了卡，您应该怎么做。

For instance, take the following sequence: 例如，采用以下序列：

Now, say you want to install a card immediately after 4214/1. The only problem is that 4214/1/1 is already there. What are you to do? 现在，假设您想在 4214/1 之后立即安装一张卡。唯一的问题是 4214/1/1 已经存在。你要做什么？

The solution is quite simple. Simply create a card 4214/1/0. 解决方案非常简单。只需创建一张卡片 4214/1/0。

This then naturally brings up a follow-up question. What do you do when you want to install a card before 4214/1/0? 这自然而然地提出了一个后续问题。 4214/1/0 之前要装卡怎么办？

Again, it’s simple, move into the negatives. What comes before zero? Why, negative-one comes before zero! Simply create 4214/1/-1 同样，这很简单，进入底片。零之前是什么？为什么，负一在零之前！只需创建 4214/1/-1

Now, using negative numbers is something Luhmann did not do; however, I’ve found it to work quite well for me. 现在，使用负数是卢曼没有做的事情；但是，我发现它对我来说效果很好。

As a result you’ll have: 结果，您将拥有：

**What If a Card Fits Into Multiple Categories? 如果一张卡片适合多个类别怎么办？**

Let’s go deeper into the question of where to install cards. Again, the game you’re playing with the Antinet is associating the card next to, or under, its most similar neighbor. 让我们更深入地探讨卡在哪里安装的问题。同样，您使用 Antinet 玩的游戏是将卡片与其最相似的邻居相邻或下方关联起来。

This exercises the comparison faculty of your brain. Comparison, again, is a critical process for creating information, a precursor for knowledge. 这会锻炼你大脑的比较能力。同样，比较是创造信息的关键过程，是知识的先驱。

If a card fits into multiple categories, first off, do not get anxiety about it. “Every place is adequate,” as Johannes Schmidt says. “The card only has to connect with the card before it.”[594](#footnote-564) 如果一张卡片适合多个类别，首先，不要为此感到焦虑。正如约翰内斯施密特所说，“每个地方都足够了”。 “该卡只需要与它之前的卡连接。”594

But what happens if you have a card that fits into two different places in your Antinet? 但是，如果您有一张卡可以放入 Antinet 中的两个不同位置，会发生什么情况？

There are three primary ways to handle this: (1) Index Cardlinks, (2) Hoplink Cards, and (3) “See Also” Cardlinks. 处理此问题的主要方法有三种：(1) 索引卡片链接，(2) Hoplink 卡片，以及 (3) “另见” 卡片链接。

**Index Cardlinks 索引卡链接**

In the walkthrough we just went through in building your own Antinet, we encountered a scenario where a card fits into the information branch, as well the communication branch. What we did was simply choose to install it in the information branch. We then created an entry in the list indexcard for C, writing Communication (within Info. Theory): ‘4212/1’. 在我们刚刚完成的构建您自己的 Antinet 的演练中，我们遇到了卡片适合信息分支和通信分支的场景。我们所做的只是选择将其安装在信息分支中。然后，我们在 C 的列表索引卡中创建了一个条目，写作 Communication（在 Info. Theory 中）：‘4212/1’。

This is an index cardlink. Whenever you’re ready to create a branch in the main box of the Antinet for Communication, you’ll also see that you have a card pertaining to Communication within the Information Theory branch. 这是一个索引卡片链接。每当您准备在通信 Antinet 的主框中创建一个分支时，您还会看到您在信息论分支中有一张与通信相关的卡片。

**Hoplink Cards 链接卡**

Another way of handling this would be to create a new card and place it in the Communication branch (whenever it’s created). On the card, it would simply say, For Communication in the context of Information Theory, visit ‘4212/1’. This is what I call a hoplink card. Luhmann created these types of cards, as well. 另一种处理方法是创建一张新卡并将其放置在通信分支中（无论何时创建）。在卡片上，它会简单地说，对于信息论背景下的通信，请访问 “4212/1”。这就是我所说的跳链卡。卢曼也创造了这些类型的卡片。

Here’s an example hoplink card: 这是一个跳转链接卡示例：

More on hoplink cards are explored in the chapter, Creation. 更多关于 hoplink 卡的内容在创建一章中进行了探讨。

**“See Also” Cardlinks“另见” 卡片链接**

In most cases, you don’t need to create a dedicated hoplink card. At the bottom of a card already written about communication, you can simply add a bit of text at the bottom that says: See also: ‘4214/5AE/2’. Here’s an example from my own Antinet: 在大多数情况下，您不需要创建专用的跳链卡。在一张已经写了关于沟通的卡片的底部，你可以简单地在底部添加一些文字：参见：‘4214/5AE/2’。这是我自己的 Antinet 的一个例子：

This is a “see also” cardlink. 这是一个 “另见” 卡片链接。

As you can see (pun intended), numeric-alpha addresses are powerful. They enable a whole wealth of possibilities and ways to link bits of your knowledge together to generate new connections. This is where a system like the Antinet really begins to outshine other systems. 如您所见（双关语），字母数字地址功能强大。它们提供了大量的可能性和方法，可以将您的知识点滴链接在一起，从而产生新的联系。这就是像 Antinet 这样的系统真正开始超越其他系统的地方。

**“See Also” ExRefs“另见”ExRef**

“See also” cardlinks not only pertain to internal cardlinks (which link to cards within your Antinet). They can also be used for ExRefs (external references).“另请参阅” 卡片链接不仅适用于内部卡片链接（链接到您的 Antinet 中的卡片）。它们也可以用于 ExRefs（外部引用）。

For instance, say you read a book that contains a good passage relating to Love. Yet you’re not working actively on a project related to Love. Instead of developing an elaborate main note on love, for sake of time, you can simply create an entry, which reads See also: r.Moeller, 36. Luhmann did this frequently. 例如，假设您读了一本书，其中有一段与爱情有关的好段落。然而你并没有积极地从事与爱情相关的项目。为了节省时间，您可以简单地创建一个条目，而不是开发一个关于爱情的详尽的主要注释，另请参阅：r.Moeller，36。卢曼经常这样做。

**How Do I Create Notes for Cold Hard Facts? 我如何为冷酷的事实创建笔记？**

While writing the section at the beginning of this book, I received the following question: How do I install cold hard facts in my Antinet? 在撰写本书开头的部分时，我收到了以下问题：如何在我的 Antinet 中安装冷酷的事实？

The individual who asked me this question works in the field of French real estate law. He was wondering where to file the following note: “French real estate law requires each condominium to be divided by unit, and each apartment is a unit.” 问我这个问题的人在法国房地产法领域工作。他想知道在哪里提交以下注释：“法国房地产法要求每个公寓按单元划分，每个公寓都是一个单元。”

On this matter, I’ll say a few things. 关于这件事，我说几句。

I have indeed installed cold hard facts in my own Antinet. They are cards like population size by country, revenue figures of businesses, etc. 我确实在我自己的 Antinet 中安装了冷酷的事实。它们是卡片，如按国家 / 地区划分的人口规模、企业收入数据等。

However, I created these cold hard fact cards in the pre-Antinet days.[595](#footnote-563) So that’s one reason they even exist. I have since retroactively gone back and installed many of these cold hard fact cards into my Antinet. In every case, I’ve found the academic disciplinary fields to accommodate them. There’s always a branch for where they can go. And even if there isn’t a clear branch within the academic disciplinary fields, you can just create one (and likely place it in branch 5000). 然而，我在前 Antinet 时代创建了这些冷酷的事实卡片。595 所以这就是它们存在的原因之一。从那以后，我追溯回去并将许多这些冷酷的事实卡片安装到我的 Antinet 中。在每种情况下，我都找到了适合他们的学科领域。他们可以去的地方总有一个分支。即使学术学科领域内没有明确的分支，您也可以创建一个（并且很可能将其放在分支 5000 中）。

I like to place my cold hard fact cards on 3 x 5 inch cards. I like to consult them from time to time in order to unearth accidental insights. 我喜欢将冷酷的事实卡片放在 3 x 5 英寸的卡片上。我喜欢不时地向他们请教，以发掘意外的见解。

Yet, as I touched upon in the beginning of this book, the Antinet is primarily useful for creators. It’s useful for those who wish to elaborate on thoughts and evolve them by reflecting on them. You evolve your thoughts by linking them to more thoughts filed behind them. 然而，正如我在本书开头提到的，Antinet 主要对创作者有用。对于那些希望详细阐述思想并通过反思来发展思想的人来说，这很有用。你通过将它们链接到它们背后的更多想法来发展你的想法。

If you wish to just memorize a bunch of cold hard facts, an Antinet may be overkill. Heck, even digital tools like Anki do the trick for this type of thing. Of course, there is certainly value to be obtained from the act of writing facts down by hand. 如果您只想记住一堆冷酷的事实，那么 Antinet 可能有点矫枉过正。哎呀，即使是像 Anki 这样的数字工具也能解决这类问题。当然，从手写事实的行为中肯定可以获得价值。

Typically, those who benefit most from an Antinet are writers, researchers, and creators who wish to evolve thought. 通常，那些从 Antinet 中获益最多的人是希望发展思想的作家、研究人员和创造者。

After sharing my response with the individual who asked the question about cold hard facts, he provided more clarity. In actuality, his work in French real estate law is for his thesis. In this case, the Antinet will have more use, and provide more value. 在与提出关于冷酷事实的问题的个人分享我的回答后，他提供了更多的清晰度。实际上，他在法国房地产法方面的工作是为了他的论文。在这种情况下，Antinet 将有更多的用途，并提供更多的价值。

To wrap this up, it is possible to use the Antinet to store cold hard facts. For example, you’d place the previously mentioned card in Real Estate Law branch. For instance, 1310. Near that branch, you could create a branch for French Real Estate Law at 1312. Within that branch, you can begin creating cards pertaining to specific laws at 1312/1. Again, these numbers are arbitrary and can be chosen by you based on personal whim. 总而言之，可以使用 Antinet 来存储冷硬的事实。例如，您可以将前面提到的卡片放在房地产法分支中。例如，1310。在该分支附近，您可以在 1312 为法国房地产法创建一个分支。在该分支内，您可以开始创建与 1312/1 的特定法律有关的卡片。同样，这些数字是任意的，您可以根据个人想法选择。

-----------------

We’ve covered a lot in this chapter. We started with important principles involved in building an Antinet. We covered the mindset with which you should approach the beginning phases of building an Antinet. We emphasized that you must not get lost in the trap of perfectionism. We also capped off this preamble with the concept of goals, and growth vs. contribution. 我们在本章中介绍了很多内容。我们从构建 Antinet 所涉及的重要原则开始。我们介绍了在构建 Antinet 的开始阶段应该采用的思维方式。我们强调，您绝不能迷失在完美主义的陷阱中。我们还用目标、增长与贡献的概念结束了这个序言。

We then dove headfirst into building out your own Antinet. If you followed the steps (which I hope you did), you now have a solid base. You have the start of your own Antinet! 然后，我们一头扎进构建您自己的 Antinet。如果您遵循了这些步骤（我希望您做到了），那么您现在就有了坚实的基础。你有你自己的 Antinet 的开始！

Now that you have a solid foundation, it’s time to embark upon the next phase of our journey: Knowledge Development. Get ready. This section of the book is a lot more fun than it sounds. It also serves as the core process for building your knowledge. Let’s go. 现在您已经打下了坚实的基础，是时候开始我们旅程的下一阶段了：知识发展。做好准备。本书的这一部分比听起来有趣得多。它还是构建知识的核心过程。我们走吧。

CHAPTER TWELVE 第十二章
-------------------

Knowledge Development 知识发展
--------------------------

The category zettelkasten finds itself lumped into is called personal knowledge management (PKM). PKM is a disciplinary subfield of knowledge management concerned with the personal collection, organization, storing, and sharing of digital information.zettelkasten 发现自己归入的类别称为个人知识管理 (PKM)。 PKM 是知识管理的一个学科子领域，涉及数字信息的个人收集、组织、存储和共享。

As it applies to the Antinet, I dislike the categorical term PKM for several reasons. First off, notetaking systems do not exclusively contain knowledge; they contain information, which helps one develop knowledge. In addition, the entire point of Luhmann’s Antinet centered on the development of knowledge (not management of knowledge). 由于它适用于 Antinet，我不喜欢 PKM 这个绝对术语有几个原因。首先，笔记系统不仅仅包含知识；它们包含有助于人们发展知识的信息。此外，卢曼的 Antinet 的整个观点都集中在知识的发展（而不是知识的管理）上。

Luhmann’s Antinet is not seen as a memory tool, but a thinking tool. It’s a thinking tool that aims to develop one’s thoughts. It’s a very active system, not something that is properly encompassed by the term management. Because it requires action, a better term for it is development. The goal of the Antinet is to develop one’s thoughts (revealed in the notes you create), as well as your own thinking (revealed in how your brain works to link together ideas). For this reason, I encompass both thoughts and thinking under the umbrella term knowledge. In turn this gives us the label in which I categorize the Antinet: a knowledge development system.Luhmann 的 Antinet 不被视为一种记忆工具，而是一种思维工具。它是一种思维工具，旨在发展一个人的思想。这是一个非常活跃的系统，而不是术语管理所包含的东西。因为它需要行动，所以更好的说法是发展。 Antinet 的目标是发展一个人的思想（体现在您创建的笔记中）以及您自己的思维（体现在您的大脑如何将想法联系在一起）。出于这个原因，我将思想和思维都包含在知识这一总称之下。反过来，这给了我们一个标签，我将 Antinet 归类为：知识开发系统。

**Two Processes of Knowledge De**velopment 知识发展的两个过程
----------------------------------------------------

As Johannes Schmidt observes, there are two processes of the Antinet as 正如 Johannes Schmidt 所观察到的，Antinet 有两个过程：

a knowledge development system. The first process involves developing thought through the practice of writing by hand. The second process involves interacting with the Antinet as a communication partner.[596](#footnote-614) 知识开发系统。第一个过程涉及通过手写练习来发展思想。第二个过程涉及作为通信伙伴与 Antinet 进行交互。 596

**Process I: Short-term Knowledge Development 过程 I：短期知识开发**

In Luhmann’s own Antinet, one finds the following handwritten note: “Underlying the filing technique is the experience that without writing, there is no thinking.”[597](#footnote-613) 在 Luhmann 自己的 Antinet 中，可以找到以下手写的注释：“归档技术的基础是没有书写就没有思考的体验。”597

In the short term, the Antinet enables users to develop thought through the practice of writing by hand. As I’ve illustrated throughout this text, I contend that this practice develops thought better than digital systems because of the deliberate attention required. As Schmidt observes, “writing things down enables disciplined thinking in the first place.”[598](#footnote-612) I also contend that the analog nature of the Antinet develops one’s thinking better because it neuroimprints ideas on the mind far more effectively than digital tools. 在短期内，Antinet 使用户能够通过手写练习来发展思维。正如我在本文中所说明的那样，我认为这种做法比数字系统更能发展思维，因为它需要刻意的关注。正如 Schmidt 所观察到的，“把事情写下来首先可以使思维有纪律。”598 我还认为 Antinet 的模拟性质可以更好地发展一个人的思维，因为它比数字工具更有效地将想法印在脑海中。

**Process II: Long-term Knowledge Development 过程 II：长期知识发展**

As Schmidt highlights, the second process of knowledge development centers on the Antinet emerging as a communication partner during research. This happens by way of the tree structure of the Antinet evolving your thoughts over the long term. 正如 Schmidt 强调的那样，知识发展的第二个过程集中在 Antinet 作为研究过程中的通信伙伴。这是通过 Antinet 的树结构在长期内演变你的想法而发生的。

When you begin exploring your notes as you prepare to write a manuscript, a communication experience emerges. For instance, you first come upon a note written seven years ago. Following this note is a newer note recently added which seemingly contradicts the first note. What happens next illustrates the internal dialogue that takes place: you question why the notes contradict one another, and then you begin investigating the sources of the notes. You begin investigating your chain of thoughts that resulted in coming away with a different understanding from what you now hold as true. 当您在准备撰写手稿时开始浏览笔记时，就会出现交流体验。例如，您首先看到七年前写的一张纸条。在这个注释之后是最近添加的一个新注释，它似乎与第一个注释相矛盾。接下来发生的事情说明了发生的内部对话：你质疑为什么笔记相互矛盾，然后你开始调查笔记的来源。你开始调查你的思想链，这些思想链导致了与你现在所认为的不同的理解。

This is an instance that exemplifies the long-term thought development that takes place while using an Antinet. Thoughts are developed both in the short term as well as the long term. 这是一个例子，说明了使用 Antinet 时发生的长期思想发展。思想的发展既有短期的，也有长期的。

Before we get into the four specific phases of knowledge development, let’s first take a step back into the abstract land of information science. 在我们进入知识发展的四个具体阶段之前，让我们先回到信息科学的抽象领域。

**The Nature of Knowledge and Information 知识和信息的本质**
----------------------------------------------------

In order to better understand knowledge, we need to distinguish it from its close relatives: data, information, and wisdom. This brings us to the DIKW pyramid. 为了更好地理解知识，我们需要将它与它的近亲区分开来：数据、信息和智慧。这将我们带到了 DIKW 金字塔。

**The DIKW PyramidDIKW 金字塔**

A convenient model that emerged within the information science field is called the DIKW pyramid. 信息科学领域内出现的一种便捷模型称为 DIKW 金字塔。

Like all models of reality, the pyramid is fuzzy and imperfect. Every scholar in information science seems to have their own interpretation of the four components of the pyramid. For instance, one paper contains 130 different definitions of data, information and knowledge from 45 different scholars. The paper was created because it recognized that an issue with information science revolves around the lack of clarity on these fundamental concepts.[599](#footnote-611) 像所有现实模型一样，金字塔是模糊和不完美的。每个信息科学领域的学者似乎对金字塔的四个组成部分都有自己的解释。例如，一篇论文包含来自 45 位不同学者的 130 种不同的数据、信息和知识定义。这篇论文的创建是因为它认识到信息科学的一个问题围绕着这些基本概念的不明确。 599

The different components of the DIKW pyramid get so fuzzy that I almost scratched this entire section when I started to second-guess whether or not I was getting things right. I would read one scholar’s explanation and come away with an understanding of information only to find another scholar classifying the same thing as knowledge!DIKW 金字塔的不同组成部分变得如此模糊，以至于当我开始重新猜测我是否做对了事情时，我几乎把整个部分都擦掉了。我会阅读一位学者的解释并理解信息，却发现另一位学者将同样的事情归类为知识！

Regardless, I’ve assembled the following explanations, which are more than sufficient for our purposes. 无论如何，我已经收集了以下解释，这些解释对我们的目的来说绰绰有余。

**Data 数据**

Data is raw, unprocessed stimuli from the universe. The raw material can be physical in nature or metaphysical in nature. Data is raw material, like the universe’s energy waves and particles: light, heat, sound, force, and electromagnetic components. Think of data as sound wave represented in computer symbols like 010110100011011. We cannot understand what this data means at this point. 数据是来自宇宙的原始、未经处理的刺激。原材料可以是物理性质的，也可以是形而上学的。数据是原始材料，就像宇宙的能量波和粒子：光、热、声、力和电磁成分。将数据想象成用计算机符号表示的声波，例如 010110100011011。我们目前无法理解该数据的含义。

**Information 信息**

“To be informed is to know simply that something is the case.”“被告知就是简单地知道事情是这样的。”

–Mortimer Adler[600](#footnote-610)–莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 600

Before data can be converted to information, it undergoes a phase transition. The phase transition is the interpretation phase. This phase involves our sensory system (sight, smell, sound, taste, touch, balance). For example, our ears receive data, and then interpret the data. We then transcribe the data into forms we can comprehend. 在数据可以转换为信息之前，它会经历一个相变。相变是解释阶段。这个阶段涉及我们的感官系统（视觉、嗅觉、声音、味觉、触觉、平衡）。例如，我们的耳朵接收数据，然后解释数据。然后我们将数据转录成我们可以理解的形式。

In brief, information is data we can comprehend. For instance, the sound wave data from the previous example (010110100011011) is interpreted through one’s ears. It is then transitioned into a comprehensible sound: the sound of a train, which is information. 简而言之，信息是我们可以理解的数据。例如，前面示例中的声波数据 (010110100011011) 是通过人的耳朵来解读的。然后它被转换成一种可理解的声音：火车的声音，这是信息。

**Knowledge 知识**
