“To be enlightened is to know, in addition, what it is all about: why it is the case, what its connections are with other facts, in what respects it is the same, in what respects it is different, and so forth.”“此外，要开悟就是要了解它的全部内容：为什么会这样，它与其他事实有什么联系，在哪些方面相同，在哪些方面不同等等。”

–Mortimer Adler[601](#footnote-609)–莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 601

Knowledge is information multiplied by meaning. Knowledge is useful information. I also like to think of knowledge as structured information. Knowledge integrates, correlates, and collects several pieces of information.[602](#footnote-608) Say, for instance, we have the information that the sound we just heard is that of a train. Knowledge assembles and structures other useful pieces of information onto this: the information comprising the who, what, where, and when properties attached to data.[603](#footnote-607) For instance, we know what we heard sounds like a train (what). Yet we piece this information together with other properties: it involves you and the train (who), its general direction (where), and how recently we heard it (when). 知识是信息乘以意义。知识是有用的信息。我也喜欢将知识视为结构化信息。知识整合、关联和收集几条信息。602 比如说，我们有这样的信息，即我们刚刚听到的声音是火车的声音。知识将其他有用的信息组合并构建到此之上：这些信息包括附加到数据的人物、内容、地点和时间属性。603 例如，我们知道我们听到的声音听起来像火车（什么）。然而，我们将此信息与其他属性拼凑在一起：它涉及您和火车（谁）、它的大致方向（在哪里）以及我们最近听到它的时间（何时）。

Knowledge enables us to connect and structure these disparate pieces of information together to create meaning. It tells us, holy crap, I’m on the train tracks right now and I just heard a train. This brings us to wisdom. 知识使我们能够将这些不同的信息片段连接起来并组织起来，从而创造出意义。它告诉我们，天哪，我现在在火车轨道上，我刚刚听到火车声。这给我们带来了智慧。

**Wisdom 智慧**

“Intelligent action depends on knowledge.”“明智的行动取决于知识。”

–Mortimer Adler[604](#footnote-606)–莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 604

Wisdom is knowledge multiplied by action. When you take action after the information phase, that’s intuitive action. However, when you take action after the knowledge phase, you’re taking wise action. You’re making a decision based on multiple pieces of information. This doesn’t mean you’re necessarily taking the right action; however, it does mean you have a higher likelihood of taking the right action. Knowing things only gets one so far; wise action stands as a critical phase. 智慧是知识乘以行动。当你在信息阶段后采取行动时，这就是直觉行动。然而，当你在知识阶段之后采取行动时，你就是在采取明智的行动。您正在根据多条信息做出决定。这并不意味着您必须采取正确的行动；但是，这确实意味着您更有可能采取正确的行动。到目前为止，知道事情只会得到一个；明智的行动是一个关键阶段。

**Formulaic Summary 公式总结**

Here’s a formulaic summary of what we just covered: 这是我们刚刚介绍的内容的公式化摘要：

Data = Raw Stimuli 数据 = 原始刺激

Information = Comprehension x Data 信息 = 理解 x 数据

Knowledge = Information x Meaning 知识 = 信息 x 意义

Wisdom = Knowledge x Action 智慧 = 知识 x 行动

**Knowledge Creation and Sharing is The Goal 知识创造和分享是目标**

With the Antinet, the goal is to create knowledge, not information. Information is a means to an end. We don’t just want to collect facts and material we can comprehend; we want to create knowledge.Antinet 的目标是创造知识，而不是信息。信息是达到目的的手段。我们不只是想收集我们可以理解的事实和材料；我们想创造知识。

This is why I routinely advise against wasting your time with things like publishing your notes. When it comes to sharing publicly, err on the side of publishing knowledge over information. 这就是为什么我经常建议不要在发表笔记等事情上浪费时间。当谈到公开分享时，宁愿发布知识也不要发布信息。

When you possess information, you’re informed. When you possess knowledge, you’re enlightened. The difference between being informed and being enlightened is the difference between being able to recite something vs. being able to teach it.[605](#footnote-605) 当你拥有信息时，你就会被告知。当你拥有知识时，你就开悟了。被告知和被启发之间的区别是能够背诵某事与能够教授它之间的区别。 605

Do not discount the importance of being informed, however, for being informed is a prerequisite for enlightenment.[606](#footnote-604) This is why the practice of taking excerpt notes is helpful. It enables one to better comprehend material. However, excerpt notes are only a precursor for the next phase: turning the information into knowledge by way of reformulation and reflection notes. 然而，不要低估被告知的重要性，因为被告知是开悟的先决条件。606 这就是为什么做摘录笔记的做法是有帮助的。它使人们能够更好地理解材料。然而，摘录笔记只是下一阶段的前奏：通过重新表述和反思笔记将信息转化为知识。

Within your Antinet, you’ll find a mix of knowledge and information. The knowledge it contains isn’t fully processed until it makes its way into your creative output. 在您的 Antinet 中，您会发现各种知识和信息。它包含的知识在进入您的创意输出之前不会得到充分处理。

Again, this emphasizes the point that the Antinet is a means to the end (the end being creative output). The Antinet helps you process and create knowledge; however the most important part is that you actually share it. As the philosopher Hans-Georg Moeller points out, “knowledge only counts if it is exchanged and thus given away or spent.”[607](#footnote-603) 这再次强调了 Antinet 是达到目的的手段（目的是创造性输出）。 Antinet 帮助您处理和创造知识；然而，最重要的部分是您实际分享它。正如哲学家 Hans-Georg Moeller 所指出的，“知识只有在被交换并因此被赠送或花费时才算数。”607

**Meaning and the Intrapersonal Nature of** the AntinetAntinet 的意义和内省性质

As we learned previously, knowledge is information multiplied by meaning. However, we never addressed the concept of meaning. The question is, where does meaning come from? 正如我们之前了解到的，知识是信息乘以意义。但是，我们从未讨论过意义的概念。问题是，意义从何而来？

According to Alberto Cevolini, “The only operations that can reproduce and manage meaning are communication and consciousness.”[608](#footnote-602) The nature of the communication experience (with your own past self’s consciousness) that arises in the course of working with an Antinet helps create meaning. It helps you transform information into knowledge that you can share with the world. 根据阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 的说法，“唯一可以重现和管理意义的操作是交流和意识。”608 在与 Antinet 合作的过程中出现的交流体验（与你过去的自我意识）的本质有助于创造意义。它可以帮助您将信息转化为可以与世界分享的知识。

Knowledge development is a fluid process that transitions through different states. From complex to simple, and back to complex again. The nature of this process is what we’ll cover next. 知识发展是一个流动的过程，在不同的状态之间转换。从复杂到简单，再回到复杂。这个过程的性质是我们接下来要介绍的。

**Complexity to Simplicity to Complexity 从复杂到简单再到复杂**
-----------------------------------------------------

Even though I refer primarily to reading throughout this book, what I’m really referring to is more broad. I’m really referring to any communication experience. Any time you engage with a source of knowledge, you’re undertaking a communication experience. As the scholar, Alberto Cevolini states, “Knowledge is socially managed through communication, although at least one consciousness is required to perpetuate communication.”[609](#footnote-601) The source of the communication experience can be a book, podcast, YouTube video, research paper, lecture, one-on-one meeting, group meeting, or any other communication media. 尽管我在整本书中主要指的是阅读，但我真正指的是更广泛的内容。我真的指的是任何沟通经验。每当您接触知识来源时，您都在进行交流体验。正如学者 Alberto Cevolini 所说，“知识是通过交流进行社会管理的，尽管至少需要一种意识来延续交流。”609 交流体验的来源可以是书籍、播客、YouTube 视频、研究论文、讲座、一对一会议、小组会议或任何其他交流媒体。

When you engage with a source of knowledge, you’re undergoing a process, making a complex entity simple, in order to then convert it back into complexity—your own complexity—your Antinet. 当你接触知识源时，你正在经历一个过程，使一个复杂的实体变得简单，然后将其转换回复杂性——你自己的复杂性——你的 Antinet。

In the first part, there’s the author of a given text. The author has spent time forming thoughts and presenting them to you. The thoughts often make sense in the author’s mind; yet, the knowledge contained may indeed be complex. It pulls from many experiences and refers to material from different areas the author has engaged with throughout his or her life. If the author has done a good job, they package their complex knowledge into a book that presents the complex ideas in a simplified way. The simplified container of complex knowledge is what composes a book. When you read a book, the book communicates with you. 第一部分是给定文本的作者。作者花时间形成想法并将其呈现给您。这些想法在作者的脑海中通常是有意义的；然而，所包含的知识可能确实很复杂。它从许多经验中汲取灵感，指的是作者一生所涉足的不同领域的材料。如果作者做得好，他们会将复杂的知识打包成一本书，以简化的方式呈现复杂的思想。复杂知识的简化容器构成了一本书。当你阅读一本书时，这本书会与你交流。

Under the diagram of the character of you, you’ll find a dotted line with the term communication next to it. The dotted line refers to the communication that takes place in your mind while you are reading. While you’re reading you think of keyterms and thoughts stored in your Antinet. This is the communication experience the dotted line is referring to. 在你的性格图下，你会发现一条虚线，旁边是沟通一词。虚线是指阅读时脑海中发生的交流。当您阅读时，您会想到存储在 Antinet 中的关键词和想法。这就是虚线所指的沟通体验。

Next, there’s a phase that occurs wherein you must simplify the material enough to comprehend it. You then must select from the material the thoughts you find irresistible. With the knowledge that you select you then add your own complexity by transforming it into notes. The Antinet stores an associative chain of this complexity, which you then can communicate with forever. 接下来是一个阶段，您必须将材料简化到足以理解它的程度。然后你必须从材料中选择你觉得不可抗拒的想法。有了你选择的知识，你就可以通过将它转化为笔记来增加你自己的复杂性。 Antinet 存储了一个具有这种复杂性的关联链，然后你就可以永远与之通信。

The communication experience that you have with the Antinet is a bit simpler than reading a book, in part because you’ve written it down by hand. As a result, you process the information in a slower, more deliberate way. You make that information more comprehendible later on. Why? Because you’ve written it out in your own words. 您与 Antinet 的通信体验比阅读一本书要简单一些，部分原因是您已经手写了它。结果，您以更慢、更慎重的方式处理信息。稍后您可以使该信息更容易理解。为什么？因为你已经用自己的话写出来了。

The entire process involves a phase transformation between complexity and simplicity. 整个过程涉及复杂与简单之间的相变。

One scholar observes the following of Luhmann’s system: “The outcome is the reproduction of complexity by means of selection, that is, the paradoxical reproduction of complexity through a reduction of complexity.”[610](#footnote-600) 一位学者观察了卢曼系统的以下内容：“结果是通过选择来复制复杂性，即通过减少复杂性来矛盾地复制复杂性。”610

Essentially, you simplify a book’s contents by selecting and extracting its most irresistible parts. Then, you create knowledge by adding your own reformulations or reflections of that content. In turn, you add your own experiences and ways of viewing the world. You then install that knowledge in the Antinet, thereby creating a complex entity that you can communicate with perennially. 从本质上讲，您可以通过选择和提取最不可抗拒的部分来简化书籍的内容。然后，您通过添加您自己的重新表述或对该内容的反思来创造知识。反过来，您会添加自己的体验和看待世界的方式。然后你将这些知识安装在 Antinet 中，从而创建一个你可以永久通信的复杂实体。

Luhmann confirms this cycle, stating: “In a way, the [Antinet Zettelkasten] is a reduction to build complexity.”[611](#footnote-599)Luhmann 证实了这个循环，并指出：“在某种程度上，[Antinet Zettelkasten] 减少了构建的复杂性。”611

**Robert Boyle’s Knowledge Development Process 罗伯特博伊尔的知识发展过程**

Robert Boyle’s knowledge development process is similar to what I’ve just outlined. Boyle specifies three elementary steps that can be extrapolated to the Antinet.[612](#footnote-598) 罗伯特博伊尔的知识发展过程与我刚才概述的相似。 Boyle 指定了可以外推到 Antinet 的三个基本步骤。 612

The first step is “careful selection of materials.” That is, carefully selecting books worth reading. 第一步是 “仔细选择材料”。即慎选值得一读的书籍。

Second in Boyle’s process: “Repeated reflection on key themes.” In other words, figuring out what to select, and extract onto cards.Boyle 过程中的第二个：“对关键主题的反复反思。” 换句话说，弄清楚要选择什么，然后提取到卡片上。

Third is: “Rehearsal of a skeletal direction of meditation.” By this, Boyle means reviewing and doing maintenance rehearsal on the cards you’ve created. 第三个是：“排练冥想的骨骼方向。” Boyle 的意思是对您创建的卡片进行审查和维护排练。

Boyle’s process is similar to the model we’ll use in this section. Our model has four phases, which I’ll introduce to you shortly. But first, let’s talk analog vs. digital with regards to knowledge development.Boyle 的过程类似于我们将在本节中使用的模型。我们的模型有四个阶段，稍后我将向您介绍。但首先，让我们谈谈知识开发方面的模拟与数字。

**Analog vs. Digital Knowledge Development 模拟与数字知识发展**
------------------------------------------------------

One of the reasons the analog component of the Antinet is so important is because of how it affects knowledge development.Antinet 的模拟部分如此重要的原因之一是它如何影响知识发展。

To put it simply, knowledge development is different for analog systems and digital systems. The very same principles I teach in this book cannot be perfectly copied to digital workflows, in part because of the time investment analog systems require. The time it takes to slow your mind down and record your thoughts is a hidden advantage of analog systems. 简单地说，模拟系统和数字系统的知识发展是不同的。我在本书中教授的原则无法完美地复制到数字工作流程中，部分原因是模拟系统需要投入时间。放慢思维速度并记录想法所需的时间是模拟系统的一个隐藏优势。

To illustrate this, it’s helpful to view knowledge development by revisiting the input-output model (shown previously): 为了说明这一点，通过重新访问输入输出模型（如前所示）来查看知识发展是有帮助的：

In the input phase of an analog workflow, it takes more time to ingest information. With the priming practice I’ll be teaching you, you’ll spend more time actually engaging with the sources you select. However, as a result, you’ll be reading less sporadically. With digital workflows, readers navigate sporadically from article to article. Even with a digital e-reader like a Kindle, one ingests information more rapidly than they do when reading physical materials. With bookmarking tools you simply click a button on any web page you visit to remind yourself to read something later. As a result you end up collecting way more material in less time. As you’ll soon find out, this isn’t a good thing. 在模拟工作流的输入阶段，需要更多时间来摄取信息。通过我将教给你的启动练习，你会花更多的时间实际接触你选择的资源。然而，结果，你会减少阅读的次数。通过数字工作流程，读者可以零星地从一篇文章导航到另一篇文章。即使使用像 Kindle 这样的数字电子阅读器，人们吸收信息的速度也比阅读物理材料时更快。使用书签工具，您只需在访问的任何网页上单击一个按钮，即可提醒自己稍后阅读。因此，您最终会在更短的时间内收集到更多的材料。您很快就会发现，这不是一件好事。

Now, let’s consider the processing phase. “Information processing is the fundamental activity of the brain,” Steven Pinker writes.[613](#footnote-597) When it comes to processing information, the tradeoff of analog vs. digital is very much the same as the input phase. Analog workflows take more time and energy to process inputs. It takes more time to actually write notes by hand. It’s a deliberate process that requires the mind to slow down and think. You think with your pen forming thoughts across the paper. With digital, it’s faster—especially if you know how to type without looking down at the keyboard! As a result, you are able to create significantly more notes. In brief, a greater quantity of notes can be written in less time with digital systems. 现在，让我们考虑处理阶段。 “信息处理是大脑的基本活动，”Steven Pinker 写道。613 在处理信息时，模拟与数字的权衡与输入阶段非常相似。模拟工作流程需要更多的时间和精力来处理输入。实际手写笔记需要更多时间。这是一个深思熟虑的过程，需要头脑放慢速度思考。你用你的笔在纸上形成想法。使用数字技术，速度更快——尤其是如果您知道如何在不低头看键盘的情况下打字！因此，您可以创建更多的笔记。简而言之，使用数字系统可以在更短的时间内写出更多的笔记。

To recap, digital systems allow you to ingest more information and process more information in less time. However, a great paradox occurs. You see, there is another variable we didn’t mention in the previously model. That variable is quality. 回顾一下，数字系统使您能够在更短的时间内吸收更多信息并处理更多信息。然而，一个很大的悖论出现了。你看，还有一个我们在之前的模型中没有提到的变量。这个变量就是质量。

Sure, digital systems enable the ingesting and processing of a greater quantity of information. However they also result in lower quality ingestion and processing of information. Because analog workflows take more time to absorb and comprehend information, you must be much more selective about what you read. In addition, you will be more selective in how you pay attention while you read. The analog workflow also forces you to be selective in what you choose to process. Because analog takes more time, you are less tempted to create useless notes and are more incentivized to say more with fewer words. As a result, a paradox emerges. Analog systems enable users to produce more output in less time. Furthermore, the quality of the output is higher. 当然，数字系统可以吸收和处理更大量的信息。然而，它们也会导致较低质量的信息摄取和处理。由于模拟工作流程需要更多时间来吸收和理解信息，因此您必须更加有选择性地阅读内容。此外，您在阅读时会更有选择性地集中注意力。模拟工作流程还迫使您在选择处理的内容时有所选择。因为模拟需要更多时间，所以您不太想创建无用的笔记，并且更有动力用更少的单词说更多。结果，出现了一个悖论。模拟系统使用户能够在更短的时间内产生更多的输出。此外，输出的质量更高。

This effect derives from several factors. First off, you create less trash in analog systems. Because of the time and energy investment required for ingesting and processing information, there’s less trash as a result. In turn this helps during the creation process. It’s much easier to create more with less. The reason for this is that notes act largely as cues. They stamp knowledge onto your mind, allowing your mind to run with it during the creation process. 这种影响源于几个因素。首先，您在模拟系统中产生的垃圾更少。由于摄取和处理信息所需的时间和精力投入，因此产生的垃圾更少。反过来，这有助于创建过程。用更少的钱创造更多的东西要容易得多。这样做的原因是笔记在很大程度上起到了提示的作用。它们将知识印记在您的脑海中，让您的大脑在创作过程中随心所欲。

For instance, in writing this section right now, the only cue I had was a notecard of the diagram shown previously. Everything else consisted simply of me typing my explanation of the diagram. All I needed was a diagram of this idea to serve as a cue for me to write and explain this model. 例如，在写这一部分时，我唯一的线索就是之前显示的图表的记事卡。其他一切都只是我输入我对图表的解释。我所需要的只是这个想法的图表，作为我编写和解释这个模型的线索。

In addition, stumbling upon the card of the diagram was a structured accident. While writing another section of this book, I stumbled upon the model. When I happened upon it, I set it aside for the knowledge development chapter. 此外，绊倒在图表的卡片上是结构性事故。在编写本书的另一部分时，我偶然发现了这个模型。当我偶然发现它时，我把它留到知识发展章节。

Had I been using a digital workflow, this type of material would have been crowded out by a colossal number of other digital notes. In turn, I might not have even written about this model at all. And even if I had, I would probably have had less time and energy to write about it because more time would have been spent parsing the mountain of digital notes I had. It may seem contradictory, but with analog systems, your energy is stored and saved for the actual process of writing. With analog, you’ve spent more time producing fewer notes such that, when it comes time to write, it’s like being shot out of a cannon. 如果我一直在使用数字工作流程，这种类型的材料就会被大量其他数字笔记挤掉。反过来，我可能根本就没有写过这个模型。即使我有，我也可能没有多少时间和精力来写它，因为更多的时间会花在解析我拥有的堆积如山的数字笔记上。这似乎是矛盾的，但是对于模拟系统，您的能量会被存储并保存起来用于实际的写作过程。使用模拟，你花更多的时间来制作更少的音符，以至于到了写作的时候，就像被大炮射中一样。

The section you’re reading right now is a little over eight hundred words. It took me about a half-hour to write. This serves as an example of the analog workflow: more content written, in less time, and at higher quality. This is why the analog nature of the Antinet is so important. It served as a critical piece that helped Luhmann become “a publication machine.”[614](#footnote-596) 您现在正在阅读的部分有八百多字。写了大概半个小时。这是模拟工作流程的一个例子：在更短的时间内以更高的质量编写更多的内容。这就是 Antinet 的模拟特性如此重要的原因。它是帮助卢曼成为 “出版机器” 的关键作品。 614

**The Four Phases of Knowledge Development 知识发展的四个阶段**
------------------------------------------------------

I like to think of knowledge development as consisting of four phases. 我喜欢将知识发展视为由四个阶段组成。

The first phase is selection. This pertains to selecting irresistible pieces of information found while engaging with external sources (books, podcasts, videos, etc.). Selection takes place in your own mind. It involves the internal voice in your head. You, and only you, can decide which information is worth selecting. It’s an incommunicable process that involves your consciousness and self-awareness. It is indistinguishable from the concept of attention.[615](#footnote-595) It requires being in tune with your own internal experience. 第一阶段是选择。这涉及选择在与外部资源（书籍、播客、视频等）互动时发现的不可抗拒的信息片段。选择发生在你自己的脑海里。它涉及您头脑中的内部声音。您，也只有您，可以决定哪些信息值得选择。这是一个涉及你的意识和自我意识的不可沟通的过程。它与注意力的概念没有区别。615 它需要与您自己的内部体验保持一致。

The second phase is extraction. This encompasses the actual action of writing down the thoughts and observations you have while reading. There are several workflows to choose from in this phase. 第二阶段是提取。这包括写下您在阅读时的想法和观察结果的实际行动。在这个阶段有几个工作流程可供选择。

The third phase is creation. This describes the process of creating notes. This mean either excerpting notes, reformulating notes, or elaborating on the notes by reflecting on ideas. 第三阶段是创造。这描述了创建笔记的过程。这意味着要么摘录笔记、重新组织笔记，要么通过反思想法来详细阐述笔记。

The fourth phase is installation. This describes both where to install the cards you’ve just created, and how to actually install them. This relates to the index keyterms you will assign (if any). 第四阶段是安装。这描述了在何处安装您刚刚创建的卡，以及如何实际安装它们。这与您将分配的索引关键词（如果有）有关。

In the following chapters, we’ll explore each of these phases in detail. Let’s go. 在接下来的章节中，我们将详细探讨每个阶段。我们走吧。

CHAPTER THIRTEEN 第十三章
---------------------

Selection 选择
------------

“We read a lot. I don’t know anyone who’s wise who doesn’t read a lot. But that’s not enough: You have to have a temperament to grab ideas and do sensible things. Most people don’t grab the right ideas or don’t know what to do with them.”“我们读了很多。我不认识任何不读书的人。但这还不够：你必须有一种气质来抓住想法并做明智的事情。大多数人没有抓住正确的想法，或者不知道如何处理它们。”

–Charlie Munger[616](#footnote-649)——查理芒格 616

It could be argued that selection is the most important process when working with an Antinet. 可以说选择是使用 Antinet 时最重要的过程。

Fiona McPherson, a cognitive scientist specializing in the study of notetaking, agrees that the “most crucial” part of notetaking revolves around selection. Specifically this means selecting what information is important, and just as critically, not selecting information that is not important.[617](#footnote-648) 专攻笔记研究的认知科学家菲奥娜 · 麦克弗森 (Fiona McPherson) 同意，笔记的 “最关键” 部分围绕着选择。具体来说，这意味着选择重要的信息，同样重要的是，不要选择不重要的信息。 617

This introduces the tradeoff between selection and exclusion. “To select everything would mean to exclude nothing,” as the scholar Alberto Cevolini puts it. Or, as Jeremias Drexel (1581—1638) puts it, “to read without selecting means to be negligent.”[618](#footnote-647) 这引入了选择和排除之间的权衡。正如学者阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 所说，“选择一切就意味着不排除任何东西”。或者，正如 Jeremias Drexel（1581-1638）所说，“不加选择地阅读意味着疏忽。”618

In brief, the relationship between what to select and what to exclude from what you read is an important skill—a skill which we will discuss in this chapter. 简而言之，选择什么和从阅读中排除什么之间的关系是一项重要的技能——我们将在本章中讨论的一项技能。

**Selection in the Brain 大脑中的选择**
---------------------------------

I like the illustration given by cognitive scientist William K. Estes who posited that human memory can be likened to a computing system. A computing system takes inputs, runs them through a process, and then produces outputs.[619](#footnote-646) Here’s a diagram of how it works: 我喜欢认知科学家 William K. Estes 给出的例子，他假设人类记忆可以比作计算系统。计算系统接受输入，通过一个过程运行它们，然后产生输出。619 这是它如何工作的图表：

External data comes from the environment. It’s essentially the world, the ecosystem we encounter. 外部数据来自环境。它本质上是世界，我们遇到的生态系统。

Our sensory system consists of our senses of sight, hearing, touch, taste, smell, and balance. Our sensory system operates like an interpreter as understood in the context of the computer language Python. The interpreter deciphers the input data and transforms it into information that the computer can understand. With our sensory system, it’s much the same. It deciphers the data and turns it into information our brains can understand. 我们的感官系统包括我们的视觉、听觉、触觉、味觉、嗅觉和平衡感。我们的感觉系统就像在计算机语言 Python 的上下文中理解的解释器一样运行。解释器对输入数据进行解密，并将其转换为计算机可以理解的信息。对于我们的感官系统，情况大同小异。它破译数据并将其转化为我们的大脑可以理解的信息。

From there the brain must make a decision: is the information meaningful or is it not meaningful? If the information is not meaningful we ignore it. We do not pay attention to it. If it is meaningful we select that information. With that information selected we run it through another process. We determine to what degree the item is meaningful. 大脑必须从那里做出决定：信息有意义还是没有意义？如果信息没有意义，我们将忽略它。我们不注意它。如果有意义，我们会选择该信息。选择该信息后，我们将通过另一个流程运行它。我们确定该项目在多大程度上有意义。

The study of this process is actually what ended up motivating the development of the science of information processing models.[620](#footnote-645) This decision between meaningful and non-meaningful information is indistinguishable from the concept of attention.[621](#footnote-644) Brought back to the process of working with an Antinet, when you are reading, it’s an active process that requires full attention. The concept of selection is entrenched in this process. 对这一过程的研究实际上最终推动了信息处理模型科学的发展。620 有意义和无意义信息之间的这种决定与注意力的概念无法区分。621 带回到使用 Antinet 的过程，当你在阅读的时候，它是一个需要全神贯注的主动过程。选择的概念在这个过程中根深蒂固。

**The Trouble of Selection: Feedback 选择的麻烦：反馈**

Here, selection refers to the entire process of thinking that takes place in your mind when you encounter a new idea. It refers to the process involved in determining what thought generated by a text should be (1) extracted onto a card by writing it out by hand to ruminate on or elaborate on; (2) stored in the Antinet by installing it in the position most similar and most closely associated with it; or (3) discarded entirely because it’s not worth the time investment of extracting or storing the thought. 在这里，选择是指当你遇到一个新想法时，你脑海中发生的整个思考过程。它指的是确定文本产生的思想应该（1）通过手写提取到卡片上以进行反思或详述的过程； (2) 通过安装在与其最相似、关联最密切的位置存储在 Antinet 中； (3) 完全丢弃，因为不值得花时间提取或存储思想。

This process occurs very quickly in the mind. It’s also not trivial. Consider what Alberto Cevolini observes: “Troubles arise when one wonders about the criteria according to which one should select, store, or discard.”[622](#footnote-643) 这个过程在头脑中发生得非常快。这也不是微不足道的。想想阿尔贝托 · 切沃里尼 (Alberto Cevolini) 的观察：“当一个人想知道应该根据什么标准进行选择、存储或丢弃时，就会出现问题。”622

The notion of troubles arising with regard to the information one should select or not select while reading is echoed by other scientists. Cognitive scientist, Fiona McPherson, holds selection as the most critical skill you can master. It is the foundation upon which others skills rest. Yet “no-one has yet to come up with an effective way of teaching this skill,” observes McPherson. However, there is some good news: what McPherson meant is that there’s no universal one-size-fits-all way of teaching this. Each person will pick up the skill of selection in a different way. It is a skill that can indeed be taught. However, certain people may require more practice than others.[623](#footnote-642) 关于阅读时应该选择或不选择信息的问题的概念得到了其他科学家的响应。认知科学家菲奥娜 · 麦克弗森 (Fiona McPherson) 认为选择是您可以掌握的最关键的技能。它是其他技能的基础。然而，“还没有人想出一种有效的方法来教授这项技能，” 麦克弗森说。然而，有一些好消息：麦克弗森的意思是没有通用的一刀切的教学方法。每个人都会以不同的方式掌握选择技巧。这是一项确实可以传授的技能。然而，某些人可能需要比其他人更多的练习。 623

Developing the skills of selection requires one thing: feedback. 培养选择技能需要一件事：反馈。

Feedback equals growth. In a classroom setting, you can quickly tell how well your notetaking is working from the feedback you receive in form of test scores. Yet in creative work with long timelines (like one or two years), feedback is a bit more difficult to receive in a timely manner. Sönke Ahrens makes such an observation in his book How to Take Smart Notes. “The linear model of academic writing comes with few feedback opportunities,” Ahrens writes.[624](#footnote-641) Yet he makes an interesting assertion that, by choosing to reformulate or reflect on your reading, you’re essentially testing yourself on whether or not you understand the material well enough to explain it in your own words. You’re testing yourself to see if you even know it well enough to reformulate the material. You’re also testing yourself whenever you attempt to write a reflection note. Do you truly understand it well enough that you’ll be able to reflect on what you’ve selected? 反馈等于成长。在课堂环境中，您可以根据收到的测试分数形式的反馈快速判断您的笔记记录效果如何。然而，在时间线较长（如一两年）的创造性工作中，及时收到反馈有点困难。 Sönke Ahrens 在他的《如何做聪明的笔记》一书中做出了这样的观察。 “学术写作的线性模型几乎没有反馈机会，”Ahrens 写道。624 然而他做出了一个有趣的断言，即通过选择重新表述或反思你的阅读，你实际上是在测试你自己是否理解材料足以用你自己的话来解释它。您正在测试自己，看看您是否足够了解它以重新制定材料。每当您尝试写反思笔记时，您也在测试自己。你真的理解得足够好，以至于你能够反思你的选择吗？

However, receiving feedback is tricky when it comes to selection. Whenever you attempt to write notes on something, you receive feedback on how well you understand the material. Yet, this does not provide feedback on whether or not you should have selected the material in the first place. 然而，在选择方面，接收反馈很棘手。每当您尝试在某事上写笔记时，您都会收到有关您对材料的理解程度的反馈。然而，这并没有提供关于您是否应该首先选择材料的反馈。

The question is: How do we gain feedback from the notes we create? 问题是：我们如何从我们创建的笔记中获得反馈？

One argument is to just publish your notes. In other words, create a so-called ‘digital garden’ or a personal website which shares your notes so that others can provide feedback. Not surprisingly, this is something I do not advise for a number of reasons. In brief, when you publish your notes, you’re publishing information. This is less useful to people than publishing knowledge. With knowledge, you’ve contextualized and further processed that information. As a result your knowledge provides the reader with much more value than unprocessed information. In turn, if you do indeed receive feedback from such notes, the feedback will be misguided. To a large degree, it will be a waste of time, which is why I advise against it. 一种说法是只发表你的笔记。换句话说，创建一个所谓的 “数字花园” 或个人网站来分享您的笔记，以便其他人可以提供反馈。毫不奇怪，出于多种原因我不建议这样做。简而言之，当您发布笔记时，您就是在发布信息。这对人们来说不如发布知识有用。有了知识，您就可以将这些信息置于情境中并进一步处理。因此，与未经处理的信息相比，您的知识为读者提供的价值要大得多。反过来，如果您确实从此类笔记中收到反馈，则反馈将被误导。在很大程度上，这将是浪费时间，这就是我反对它的原因。

In sum, perhaps there are no shortcuts here. The best way to select material is to do so with a clear understanding of why you’re reading the source you’ve selected. It also requires that you have a clear understanding of your audience. 总而言之，也许这里没有捷径可走。选择材料的最佳方法是在清楚地了解为什么要阅读所选资源的情况下这样做。它还要求您清楚地了解您的听众。

I’ll offer a few suggestions for getting better at selection: 我将提供一些建议以更好地进行选择：

First, create a profile of your dream reader. Search photos online and cut out a stock photo of him or her. Paste the image on a notecard and write down a made-up name for the person. They’re your dream reader, your dream avatar whom you wish to serve. Ideally, create a male and female avatar (unless you’re specifically targeting a gender). Write down a one-to-three sentence profile on them, detailing what their interests are, what they like, or dislike, etc. Heck, your avatar could even be your professor if you’re a student. Place the picture(s) on your wall or some place you’ll see regularly. Whenever you’re reading a book, read with your dream reader in mind. This is another reason why it’s helpful to adopt a contribution mindset (as opposed to a personal growth mindset). 首先，创建您理想读者的个人资料。在线搜索照片并剪下他或她的库存照片。将图像粘贴到记事卡上，并为该人写下虚构的名字。他们是您的梦想读者，您希望为之服务的梦想化身。理想情况下，创建男性和女性头像（除非您专门针对性别）。用一到三句话写下他们的简介，详细说明他们的兴趣是什么，喜欢什么或不喜欢什么等等。哎呀，如果你是学生，你的化身甚至可以是你的教授。将图片放在墙上或您经常看到的地方。每当您阅读一本书时，请牢记您的梦想读者。这是采用贡献心态（相对于个人成长心态）有帮助的另一个原因。

Second, I recommend publishing short pieces of your work or material as you’re writing. Instead of publishing under-processed notes, I recommend that you give readers chapter samples and tastes of your writing. Do this by publishing short pieces or blog posts online. This is something I’ve done myself over the course of writing this book. 其次，我建议在您写作时发表您的作品或材料的短片。我建议您不要发布处理不当的笔记，而是向读者提供章节样本和您的写作品味。通过在线发布短文或博客文章来做到这一点。这是我在写这本书的过程中自己做的事情。

Later, I’ll be introducing you to something called priming, which promotes more effective reading. You’ll end up selecting information aligned with why you’ve set out to read a book. 稍后，我将向您介绍一种叫做启动的东西，它可以促进更有效的阅读。你最终会选择与你开始读书的原因相一致的信息。

“Selection is a highly personalized activity,” writes scholar, Alberto Cevolini.[625](#footnote-640) In other words, every person is unique, and everyone will spot unique material that speaks to them. Your job is to channel your internal voice and select the material that uniquely resonates with you, plain and simple.“选择是一项高度个性化的活动，” 学者 Alberto Cevolini 写道。625 换句话说，每个人都是独一无二的，每个人都会发现与他们对话的独特材料。你的工作是传达你内​​心的声音，选择能引起你独特共鸣的材料，简单明了。

Selection doesn’t just mean “gathering,” it means “making a judgement.”[626](#footnote-639) However, what then follows is the question of what you should even make a judgement about! From here, we can rely on the wisdom of early modern literature: select only what is considered to be of future utility.[627](#footnote-638) That is, select what will be of future utility to you, and through you, what will be of future utility to others. 选择不仅意味着 “聚集”，还意味着 “做出判断”。626 但是，接下来的问题是您甚至应该对什么做出判断！从这里开始，我们可以依靠早期现代文学的智慧：只选择被认为对未来有用的东西。 627 也就是说，选择对你未来有用的东西，并通过你，选择对未来有用的东西其他的。

Selection helps form the uniqueness of your second mind. If you fit an entire library into your Antinet, it would demolish the unique personality you’ve injected into it by way of selection. Digital apps like Pocket or Read Later or Evernote do not create a second mind. They are mere repositories of quotes, articles, and material from others. As scholar, Richard Yeo holds, a second mind is selected material (from books, a library, articles, etc.) that you capture through creating notes which then are installed in your Antinet. This entity works in tandem with your internal biological memory to create an internal dialogue, and what results serves as your second mind.[628](#footnote-637) 选择有助于形成你第二个想法的独特性。如果你将整个图书馆放入你的 Antinet，它会破坏你通过选择注入其中的独特个性。 Pocket 或 Read Later 或 Evernote 等数字应用程序不会产生第二思维。它们只是引用、文章和其他人的材料的存储库。作为学者，Richard Yeo 认为，第二思维是您通过创建笔记捕获的精选材料（来自书籍、图书馆、文章等），然后将其安装在您的 Antinet 中。这个实体与你的内部生物记忆协同工作以创建内部对话，而结果将作为你的第二思维。 628

You don’t want your Antinet to embody characteristics of just any library. Rather, you want it to be a personal library. As one scholar observes, one of the most impressive aspects of the process in building an Antinet is that it builds a universal personal library out of a universal library.[629](#footnote-636) “Such re-arising of the world (of learning) inside the world (of learning),” Alberto Cevolini writes, “is possible through selection, and in turn selection is the crucial operation for begetting complexity, that is, an excess of possible combinations, links, or references among meaningful data.”[630](#footnote-635) 您不希望您的 Antinet 体现任何图书馆的特征。相反，您希望它成为个人图书馆。正如一位学者所观察到的，在构建 Antinet 的过程中最令人印象深刻的方面之一是它从通用图书馆构建了一个通用个人图书馆。629“世界（学习）在世界（的学习）”，Alberto Cevolini 写道，“通过选择成为可能，而选择又是产生复杂性的关键操作，即有意义数据之间可能的组合、链接或引用过多。”630

Think of it like this: reality is equal to all data in the cosmos. Science is the study of reality. Yet science proceeds very slowly and selectively in advancing our understanding of reality. We extract only strands of reality and do our best to provide theories and experiments that clearly explain this slice of reality. Luhmann makes mention of science and reality never being whole. They’re never equal. Why? Because science proceeds “selectively, because this is the only way to bring order and comprehensibility.”[631](#footnote-634) 可以这样想：现实等于宇宙中的所有数据。科学是对现实的研究。然而，科学在推进我们对现实的理解方面进展非常缓慢且有选择。我们只提取现实的一部分，并尽最大努力提供能够清楚地解释这部分现实的理论和实验。卢曼提到科学和现实从来都不是完整的。他们永远不平等。为什么？因为科学 “有选择地进行，因为这是带来秩序和可理解性的唯一途径。”631

In brief, you don’t want all the data in the universe in your Antinet. Nor do you want tools that bring you closer to this non-ideal maximum. Digital tools have the tendency to do just that. They have the tendency to create overselection (something I’ll cover shortly). You simply want to select the most important information from the sources you engage. 简而言之，你不希望你的 Antinet 中包含宇宙中的所有数据。您也不想要让您更接近这个非理想最大值的工具。数字工具倾向于做到这一点。他们倾向于创建过度选择（我将很快介绍）。您只想从您使用的来源中选择最重要的信息。

As Fiona McPherson writes, “Anything that helps you select the most important information is good.”[632](#footnote-633) Only you, yourself, can determine what strategy works best for you in selecting material that resonates with you. 正如 Fiona McPherson 所写，“任何能帮助您选择最重要信息的东西都是好的。”632 只有您自己才能确定哪种策略最适合您选择与您产生共鸣的材料。

In the next chapter I’ll teach you some different extraction methods, which will make selecting material easier for you. But until then, let’s continue our journey through The Matrix (that is, selection). 在下一章中，我将教您一些不同的提取方法，这将使您更容易选择材料。但在那之前，让我们继续我们的黑客帝国之旅（即选择）。

**Selection Underlies Communication 选择是沟通的基础**
----------------------------------------------

Communication was a critically important area in Luhmann’s research; likewise, for the Antinet, it also stands as a critical component. We’ll detail the concept of communication later in this book. However, for now, it’s interesting to note one peculiar thing involving Luhmann’s concept of communication: it’s founded on selection. 交流是卢曼研究中一个至关重要的领域。同样，对于 Antinet 来说，它也是一个重要的组成部分。我们将在本书后面详细介绍通信的概念。然而，就目前而言，有趣的是注意到一个涉及卢曼传播概念的奇特之处：它建立在选择之上。

According to Luhmann, communication is an emergent reality that emanates from three different selections: (1) selection of information, (2) selection of the message of this function, and (3) selective understanding (or misunderstanding) of the message and its interpretation.[633](#footnote-632) 根据 Luhmann 的说法，交流是一种涌现的现实，它源于三种不同的选择：（1）信息的选择，（2）具有此功能的信息的选择，以及（3）对信息及其解释的选择性理解（或误解） .633

The concept of selection is critically important pragmatically, as well as theoretically, for the Antinet. For this reason, we shall spend time on both the theoretical and practical matters of selection. 选择的概念对于 Antinet 在实用上和理论上都至关重要。出于这个原因，我们将花时间在选择的理论和实践问题上。

**Knowledge Selection as Natural Selection 作为自然选择的知识选择**
--------------------------------------------------------

In natural selection, the environment essentially selects organisms that have qualities that are best adapted for it to survive and reproduce. The process of selecting information and turning into knowledge is not much different.[634](#footnote-631) 在自然选择中，环境基本上会选择具有最适合其生存和繁殖的品质的生物。选择信息和转化为知识的过程没有太大区别。 634

The first step in knowledge selection is actually information selection. Knowledge is created from information. As found in nature, reproduction (generally) involves an individual selecting a mate with corresponding genetic information. With an Antinet, you select information from sources that you read. The sources are analogous to a mating partner. 知识选择的第一步实际上是信息选择。知识是从信息中创造出来的。正如在自然界中发现的那样，繁殖（通常）涉及个体选择具有相应遗传信息的配偶。使用 Antinet，您可以从阅读的来源中选择信息。来源类似于交配伙伴。

Selected information is then processed into knowledge by reformulating or reflecting on the information, to which you add your own experiences and understanding, anchored by your own unique perspectives (and the context in which you’ve experienced life). When you create a reformulation note or reflection note, you essentially create a new entity altogether: you create knowledge. In evolutionary terms, you give birth to a child—a new, living organism (after exchanging information in the form of genetic code). In knowledge-science terms, you give birth to a book or other creative work (after exchanging information in the form of reading other authors’ works). 然后，通过重新表述或反思信息，将选定的信息处理成知识，您将自己的经验和理解添加到这些信息中，以您自己独特的观点（以及您体验生活的背景）为基础。当您创建重新制定的笔记或反思笔记时，您实际上完全创建了一个新实体：您创造了知识。用进化的术语来说，你生下了一个孩子——一个新的活的有机体（在以遗传密码的形式交换信息之后）。用知识科学的术语来说，你诞生了一本书或其他创造性的作品（在以阅读其他作者的作品的形式交换信息之后）。

Your (intellectual) environment is populated by your audience of readers. If the knowledge you create (your book) resonates with your audience exceptionally well, it will be selected. It will be selected apart from other competing books, to rise in popularity and essentially reproduce. 您的（知识）环境由您的读者群组成。如果您创造的知识（您的书）在您的听众中产生特别好的共鸣，它就会被选中。它将从其他竞争书籍中脱颖而出，以提高知名度并从根本上进行复制。

For your work to survive, it doesn’t necessarily need to be the best ever. It doesn’t necessarily need to be the most optimal piece of work. Rather it must be sufficiently better than the other pieces of work competing for your reader’s attention. In turn, your work will rise in popularity and reproduce itself. 为了让你的作品生存下来，它不一定是有史以来最好的。它不一定需要是最优化的工作。相反，它必须比其他争夺读者注意力的作品要好得多。反过来，你的作品会越来越受欢迎并自我复制。

This highlights some important points: 这突出了一些要点：

1. The success of the knowledge you produce is very much a function of: (a) the source material you select. This means the books, articles, podcasts, lectures, videos, or other media you select; (b) what genes (or ideas) that you select from your mate (or book); and (c) how you then process that information and its genes to produce a new creation (a baby, or a book); and (d) how you then organize that creation (by deciding where to file it, or how to raise it).1. 你产生的知识的成功在很大程度上取决于： (a) 你选择的源材料。这意味着您选择的书籍、文章、播客、讲座、视频或其他媒体； (b) 你从你的配偶（或书籍）中选择了什么基因（或想法）； (c) 然后你如何处理这些信息及其基因以产生新的创造物（一个婴儿或一本书）； (d) 然后您如何组织该创作（通过决定将其归档在何处或如何提出）。

2. The output of this process that is best adapted to its audience of readers (that is, its environment), will survive and reproduce more successfully than less adapted output.2. 最适合其读者受众（即其环境）的此过程的输出将比不太适应的输出更成功地生存和复制。

**The Levels of Selection 选择的层次**
---------------------------------

The Antinet can be thought of as a system containing relations of relations of relations. Encompassed in this model are three levels of selection: (1) selecting what source to engage with (choosing what books to read), and (2) selecting what material to extract, and (3) selecting where in the Antinet to install and link to the selection(s).Antinet 可以被认为是一个包含关系关系的系统。此模型包含三个级别的选择：(1) 选择要使用的资源（选择要阅读的书籍），以及 (2) 选择要提取的材料，以及 (3) 选择 Antinet 中的安装和链接位置到选择。

Let’s explore each of these levels of selection now. 现在让我们探讨这些选择级别中的每一个。

**Source Selection 来源选择**

Before embarking upon the process of determining which material to select from the books you read, there is an even more critical challenge: selecting which books are even worth reading in the first place! 在着手决定从您阅读的书中选择哪些材料之前，还有一个更为关键的挑战：首先选择哪些书籍甚至值得一读！

As the Catholic intellectual, Antonin Sertillanges writes, the process of selection is prepended with an important stage: “to choose books and to choose in books.”[635](#footnote-630) 正如天主教知识分子 Antonin Sertillanges 所写，选择过程之前有一个重要阶段：“选择书籍并在书中选择。”635

Here are some guidelines for selecting which books to read in the first place. These guidelines are not set-in-stone rules. Nor are they comprehensive; yet, I think they’re helpful enough to keep in mind as a guideline for selecting books. 这里有一些指导方针，用于选择首先要阅读的书籍。这些准则不是一成不变的规则。它们也不全面；然而，我认为它们足够有用，可以作为选择书籍的指南牢记在心。

**Guideline #1: Do Not Trust Bestsellers with Catchy Titles 准则 #1：不要相信标题吸引人的畅销书**

“Do not trust interest[ing] advertising and catchy titles.”“不要相信有趣的 [ing] 广告和吸引人的标题。”

–Antonin Sertillanges[636](#footnote-629)–Antonin Sertillanges636

Even non-sponsored books on Amazon are suspect these days. Major publishers with big idea hardbound books produce some of the biggest horse-shit out there. Ghost writers are behind more books than you’ll ever know. Big publishing houses thrive on publishing crap. I’ve been behind the scenes during this process and witnessed how it plays out. The New York Times Best Sellers list is really a list of synthetically engineered crap. 如今，即使是亚马逊上的非赞助书籍也令人怀疑。拥有大创意精装书的主要出版商生产了一些最大的马屎。鬼作家背后的书比你知道的要多。大出版社靠出版废话兴旺发达。在这个过程中，我一直在幕后，见证了它是如何发挥作用的。 《纽约时报》畅销书排行榜实际上是一份综合设计的废话清单。

**Guideline #2: Do Not Trust Popular Channels That Books are Advertised Through 准则 #2：不要相信宣传书籍的热门渠道**

If you heard about a book because the author was featured on a popular podcast, be suspicious. Such authors are backed by a publishing house. They’re backed by a public relations circuit that swaps in their latest figurehead. I know this because (again) I’ve been behind the scenes and have seen it firsthand. In some cases, there’s a lot of pressure for show-hosts to accept guests, regardless of their quality. Why? First, shows need content. Second, the publishing house probably did the show-host “a solid” recently. For instance, a publishing house may have gotten a movie star on their show recently during the star’s book tour of their memoir. The show-host may then feel a sense of obligation to return the favor. How do they return the favor? By saying yes to whichever guest the publishing house proposes to feature on their next show (regardless of guest quality). The guest then proceeds to hype-up whatever new (rehashed) book they’re launching. 如果您听说一本书是因为作者出现在热门播客中，请保持警惕。这些作者得到出版社的支持。他们得到了一个公共关系电路的支持，该电路交换了他们最新的傀儡。我知道这一点是因为（再次）我一直在幕后，并且亲眼目睹了它。在某些情况下，节目主持人承受着很大的压力来接受客人，无论他们的素质如何。为什么？首先，节目需要内容。其次，出版社最近可能对节目主持人进行了 “实实在在” 的处理。例如，一家出版社最近可能在明星的回忆录巡回售书期间邀请了一位电影明星参加他们的节目。节目主持人可能会觉得有义务回报他的帮助。他们如何报答？通过对出版社提议在他们的下一个节目中展示的任何一位客人说“是”（无论客人质量如何）。然后，客人继续大肆宣传他们推出的任何新书（改版）。

**Guideline #3: Go to The Original Source 准则 #3：转到原始来源**

“The majority of writers only edit and publish other writers’ thoughts,” Sertillanges writes. “Read only those books in which leading ideas are expressed at first hand.”[637](#footnote-628)“大多数作家只编辑和发表其他作家的想法，”Sertillanges 写道。 “只读那些直接表达了领先思想的书。”637

When you read this book, you are reading the first-hand account of the Antinet. You are reading of my experiences building an analog knowledge machine—a second mind—using the principles of Niklas Luhmann’s Antinet. My primary source is the primary source (Communication with Noteboxes). Yet I’m not just regurgitating his paper. I’m sharing my knowledge and my first-hand experiences in developing knowledge with such a system. You’re reading about my experiences from thousands of hours of using the system. You’re learning my nuances and ways of teaching the system. You’re reading the primary source of the Antinet. 当你阅读本书时，你正在阅读安提网的第一手资料。您正在阅读我使用尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的 Antinet 原理构建模拟知识机器（第二思维）的经历。我的主要来源是主要来源（与记事本通信）。然而，我不仅仅是在反驳他的论文。我正在分享我的知识和我在使用这样一个系统开发知识方面的第一手经验。您正在阅读我数千小时使用该系统的经验。你正在学习我的细微差别和教授系统的方法。您正在阅读 Antinet 的主要来源。

Many books are secondary sources. They’re merely edited curations of the primary source. This includes books like The Complete Idiots Guides. Don’t read these books. Read a Wikipedia article instead. Do your own research. Soon, you’ll spot recurring themes and sources that are regularly cited. These are the original sources, the primary sources. Go to these sources. They’re a must. 许多书都是二手资料。它们只是对主要来源的编辑精选。这包括像 The Complete Idiots Guides 这样的书。不要读这些书。改为阅读维基百科文章。做你自己的研究。很快，您就会发现经常被引用的反复出现的主题和来源。这些是原始来源，主要来源。转到这些来源。他们是必须的。

Of course, secondary sources can be helpful as well. Specifically, they can be helpful in spotting how the secondary sources got certain things right and certain things wrong. In addition, the secondary sources may point out the things you missed when reviewing the primary source(s). 当然，二手资料也有帮助。具体来说，它们有助于发现二手资料是如何把某些事情做对和做错的。此外，二手资料可能会指出您在查看主要资料时遗漏的内容。

Secondary sources are also useful in helping you compile a repository of frequently cited works or authors. 二手资料在帮助您编译经常被引用的作品或作者的资料库方面也很有用。

In my readings, there are certain thinkers who are mentioned over and over and over. These people include Immanuel Kant, Voltaire, René Descartes, John Locke, Francis Bacon, Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz, and more. 在我的阅读中，有一些思想家被一遍又一遍地提到。这些人包括伊曼纽尔 · 康德、伏尔泰、勒内 · 笛卡尔、约翰 · 洛克、弗朗西斯 · 培根、戈特弗里德 · 威廉 · 冯 · 莱布尼茨等。

The main take-away from this guideline is this: primary sources are a requirement, secondary sources are not. 该指南的主要内容是：主要来源是必需的，次要来源不是。

**Link Selection 链接选择**

Another level of selection within the Antinet is selecting where to connect the idea (i.e., where to install the card within the Antinet).Antinet 中的另一个选择级别是选择连接想法的位置（即，在 Antinet 中的何处安装卡）。

**Selective Relations 选择关系**

“The communication with the second mind becomes fruitful only at a high level of generalization, namely that of establishing communicative relations of relations.”“与第二思维的交流只有在高度概括的情况下才会富有成果，即建立关系的交流关系。”

–Niklas Luhmann[638](#footnote-627)——尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 638

It’s not the relations between notes that make the Antinet a powerful system; rather it’s the selective relations that do so. 使 Antinet 成为强大系统的并不是音符之间的关系；而是音符之间的关系。相反，这是选择性关系。

Johannes Schmidt specifically calls attention to the importance of selective relations near the end of his paper, where he points out that the specific readings and the material one selects from the readings are important to the Antinet. However, what is also critical is found in Luhmann’s case with “(selective) relations established between his notes by means of his referencing technique.”[639](#footnote-626) That is, you must also be selective in linking your selections to certain cards and ideas. 约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 在他的论文末尾特别提请注意选择性关系的重要性，他指出特定的阅读材料和从阅读材料中选择的材料对 Antinet 很重要。然而，在 Luhmann 的案例中发现同样重要的是 “通过他的引用技术在他的笔记之间建立（选择性的）关系。”639 也就是说，你也必须有选择性地将你的选择与某些卡片和想法联系起来。

Note how Schmidt encloses the word selective in parentheses in the passage. He did this to call out the implicit truth that Luhmann’s links were selective in nature. When Luhmann used the phrase communicative relations of relations, there was no need for him to specify that he meant selective relations. 请注意 Schmidt 如何在文章中将 “选择性” 一词括在括号中。他这样做是为了揭示一个隐含的事实，即卢曼的链接本质上是选择性的。当卢曼使用关系的交际关系这个短语时，他没有必要特别说明他指的是选择性关系。

For Luhmann, relations (or links) between notes were, by nature, selective. They were not trivial to create. They could not be bulk-applied to digital files using templates, regular expressions (regex), and tags. Links were hard-coded into one’s Antinet, and as previously indicated, they were neuroimprinted onto one’s mind. This network of highly selective links is a result of the analog nature of the system, the benefit of which we touched on in the analog chapter of this book. 对卢曼来说，音符之间的关系（或链接）本质上是有选择性的。创建它们并非易事。它们无法使用模板、正则表达式 (regex) 和标签批量应用于数字文件。链接被硬编码到一个人的 Antinet 中，并且如前所述，它们被神经烙印到一个人的脑海中。这种高度选择性链接的网络是系统模拟性质的结果，我们在本书的模拟章节中谈到了它的好处。

In other words, the magic of the Antinet doesn’t revolve around links. Rather it involves being very selective in what you link cards to. Whenever you install a card in the Antinet, you link by (1) chaining or connecting the card behind another card, and (2) using remotelinks. Due to the analog nature of the Antinet, you are forced to be very selective about what you link to, and to think hard about where a card ought to go, before installing it. With digital notetaking apps, it’s simple. You simply start typing in words for tags or wikilinks. The tool then begins auto-populating terms you can link to. Before you know it, you have numerous things you’re linking to which you otherwise wouldn’t have. With the Antinet, you’re usually choosing one, or maybe two cards to link to. This creates selective relations instead of an overabundance of hyper relations. This element serves as a critical factor in transitioning your Antinet into a second mind, as well as allowing for structured accidents, which I’ll detail later in the book. 换句话说，Antinet 的魔力并不在于链接。相反，它涉及非常有选择性地将卡链接到什么。每当您在 Antinet 中安装一张卡时，您都会通过 (1) 将卡链接或连接到另一张卡后面，以及 (2) 使用远程链接来链接。由于 Antinet 的模拟性质，您不得不非常有选择性地选择您链接的内容，并在安装之前认真考虑卡应该去哪里。使用数字笔记应用程序，这很简单。您只需开始为标签或维基链接输入文字。然后该工具开始自动填充您可以链接到的术语。在不知不觉中，您已经链接到许多原本不会拥有的东西。使用 Antinet，您通常会选择一张或两张卡进行链接。这会创建选择性关系，而不是过多的超级关系。这个元素是将你的 Antinet 转变为第二思维的关键因素，也是允许结构化事故发生的关键因素，我将在本书后面详细介绍。

**A Link is Not a Link (If It’s a Hyperlink) 链接不是链接（如果它是超链接）**

A notecard link is hard. It’s hard-earned. It’s deliberate. It’s selective. It’s a hard link. This is part of what inspired the term I use for linking cards. They’re cardlinks (because it rhymes with hard links). 记事卡链接很难。来之不易。这是故意的。它是有选择性的。这是一个硬链接。这是我用来链接卡片的术语的部分灵感来源。它们是卡片链接（因为它与硬链接押韵）。

Cardlinks are not the equivalent of hyperlinks. Hyperlinks are not selective. The Antinet is based around being selective. Antinet users are selective about (1) the books they read, (2) the material they extract from those books, and (3) the selective links they create within the Antinet. 卡片链接不等同于超链接。超链接没有选择性。 Antinet 基于选择性。 Antinet 用户可以选择 (1) 他们阅读的书籍，(2) 他们从这些书中提取的材料，以及 (3) 他们在 Antinet 中创建的选择性链接。

Cardlinks are of superior impact compared to wikilinks and hyperlinks. Digital links are whittled down by synthetic features like auto-complete, regex, or retroactive search. Cardlinks are superior to digital links not only because they are not diluted by bloatware. In addition, the power of cardlinks are unleashed when you begin taking advantage of the tree structure of the Antinet. When you follow a cardlink in the Antinet, you’re taken down a journey of stems, leaves and other branches of thought that are also linked together. 与维基链接和超链接相比，卡片链接具有更好的影响力。自动完成、正则表达式或追溯搜索等合成功能削弱了数字链接。 Cardlinks 优于数字链接，不仅因为它们不会被英国媒体报道软件稀释。此外，当您开始利用 Antinet 的树结构时，卡片链接的力量就会得到释放。当你在 Antinet 中点击一个卡片链接时，你将踏上一段茎叶和其他思想分支的旅程，这些分支也被链接在一起。

This results in structured accidents and surprises (like walking down the row of a section in the library that interests you). This accidental discovery happens in a way that is almost incommunicable. Why? Because you follow the path that is made possible thanks to the Antinet’s tree structure. 这会导致结构化的意外和惊喜（比如沿着图书馆中您感兴趣的部分的行走）。这一意外发现以一种几乎无法交流的方式发生。为什么？因为您遵循的是 Antinet 的树结构使之成为可能的路径。

This is a glimpse into the magic of the Antinet as a thinking tool and a second mind. The magic does not stem from just one thing alone, and it doesn’t come about through creating trivial easy links (aka, wikilinks). It’s a combination of the four principles of the Antinet that creates its magic: 这是对 Antinet 作为思维工具和第二思维的魔力的一瞥。魔力不仅仅源于一件事，也不是通过创建琐碎的简单链接（又名维基链接）来实现的。它结合了 Antinet 的四个原则，创造了它的魔力：

The “special filing technique,” refers to the tree structure which unlocks infinite internal branching. The “(selective) relations” between notes (made possible through numeric-alpha addresses).[640](#footnote-625) These, combined with the index which neuroimprints keyterms on the mind. These are tied together with the analog component of the Antinet, which forces higher quality selections. All of these combined creates the emergent magic of the Antinet.“特殊归档技术” 指的是解锁无限内部分支的树结构。音符之间的 “（选择性）关系”（通过数字字母地址成为可能）。640 这些，与神经在脑海中留下关键术语的索引相结合。这些与 Antinet 的模拟组件捆绑在一起，从而强制进行更高质量的选择。所有这些结合在一起创造了 Antinet 的新兴魔法。

As Johannes Schmidt points out, this structure demonstrates how quickly the Antinet sets users on a path away from what one would normally deem ordered and taxonomically sound. Although the Antinet’s inner logic might appear nonsensical to an outsider, to the creator—that is, to you, the person creating the system—the Antinet is perfectly natural and understandable.[641](#footnote-624) 正如 Johannes Schmidt 指出的那样，这种结构展示了 Antinet 以多快的速度让用户走上一条远离人们通常认为有序和分类合理的道路。尽管 Antinet 的内在逻辑对于局外人来说可能显得荒谬，但对于创建者（即您，即创建系统的人）来说，Antinet 是完全自然且可以理解的。 641

Through exploration of your Antinet, you are led away from the original topic and to a variety of other subjects—ones that you would not have initially associated with one another. This, in turn, results in unconventional interactions, surprises, and breakthrough insights that otherwise would not have occurred. 通过探索你的 Antinet，你会离开原来的主题，转向各种其他主题——你最初不会将它们彼此联系起来的主题。反过来，这会导致非常规的互动、惊喜和突破性的见解，否则这些是不会发生的。

This entire process is made possible thanks to linking not being too easy. It’s thanks to the nature of hard links. It’s thanks to the nature of cardlinks. 由于链接不太容易，因此整个过程成为可能。这要归功于硬链接的性质。这要归功于卡片链接的性质。

**Digital Creates Overselection 数字创造过度选择**

As I’ve previously illustrated, it’s not just about what material to select. It’s also about what material not to select. 正如我之前所说明的，这不仅仅是关于选择什么材料。这也是关于不选择什么材料。

For this reason, tools that help you not select as much information (due to the considerable time and effort required in extracting them), end up increasing your focus. It increases one’s proficiency in selecting valuable and irresistible material. 出于这个原因，帮助您减少选择太多信息的工具（由于提取它们需要大量时间和精力）最终会增加您的注意力。它提高了一个人选择有价值和不可抗拒的材料的熟练程度。

With digital tools, selection is trivial. It’s all-too-easy to capture, copy, paste, write, and accumulate an abundance of digital information. This is a downside, not a strength. This is yet another reason why analog outperforms digital. Digital collection results in over-saturation, both in terms of material and the information the material includes. 使用数字工具，选择变得微不足道。捕获、复制、粘贴、编写和积累大量数字信息实在是太容易了。这是缺点，而不是优点。这是模拟优于数字的另一个原因。数字馆藏会导致材料和材料所含信息的过度饱和。

**Material Selection 选材**

Thus far we’ve talked about source selection (i.e., what books to select for reading). We also discussed link selection (where in your Antinet to install ideas). The last level of selection concerns what material within a book one should select. 到目前为止，我们已经讨论了资源选择（即选择阅读哪些书籍）。我们还讨论了链接选择（在您的 Antinet 中安装想法）。最后一级选择涉及应选择书中的哪些材料。

**The Four Quadrants of Ideas 想法的四个象限**

I think it’s helpful to think of ideas falling into four quadrants. This concept is inspired by a model introduced to me by Stephen Covey. 我认为将想法分为四个象限是有帮助的。这个概念的灵感来自斯蒂芬柯维向我介绍的一个模型。

Covey proposes four quadrants for managing time by looking at the intersection of four variables: important, not important, urgent, and not urgent.[642](#footnote-623) 柯维通过查看四个变量的交集提出了管理时间的四个象限：重要、不重要、紧急和不紧急。 642

With regards to selecting material from the books you read, I propose this model helps tremendously. One is left with selecting Bad Ideas, Good Ideas, Excellent Ideas, and Irresistible Ideas. 关于从你读过的书中选择材料，我认为这个模型有很大帮助。剩下的就是选择坏主意、好主意、好主意和不可抗拒的主意。

Here’s a diagram of the model: 下面是模型图：

Let’s go through each of these now. 现在让我们逐一分析。

**Bad Ideas 坏主意**

Don’t select bad ideas or pay attention to them. It’s pretty simple. If the idea is irrelevant to what you’re working on and if the idea isn’t even that important, then don’t think twice about it. Even if you’re unsure, err on the side of the idea being a waste of time. We need to move fast. Time is short. Have the confidence that truly valuable ideas will take hold of you later on. 不要选择坏主意或关注它们。这很简单。如果这个想法与你正在做的事情无关，或者这个想法甚至没有那么重要，那么就不要三思而后行。即使您不确定，也不要认为这个想法是在浪费时间。我们需要快速行动。时间很短。相信真正有价值的想法会在以后抓住你。

**Good Ideas 好主意**

These are ideas that could very well be timely and applicable to what you’re working on, yet they don’t add much value. If the idea doesn’t add much value to your project, or if the information is redundant, then forego selecting them for your project. 这些想法很可能是及时的并且适用于你正在做的事情，但它们并没有增加太多价值。如果这个想法没有为您的项目增加太多价值，或者如果信息是多余的，那么请放弃为您的项目选择它们。

For instance, I could bog myself down for a year reading scholarly literature on the history of notetaking systems. I could fill your mind with mountains of seemingly relevant details pertaining to early notebox systems. I could tell you about how there’s a debate as to whether the Josephinian catalog of the late 1700s was the first card catalog in library history or if Konrad Gessner’s of the 1500s actually was.[643](#footnote-622) 例如，我可以花一年时间阅读有关笔记系统历史的学术文献。我可以用大量与早期记事本系统相关的看似相关的细节填满你的脑海。我可以告诉你关于 1700 年代后期的约瑟芬目录是否是图书馆历史上第一个卡片目录，或者 1500 年代康拉德格斯纳的目录是否真的是这样的争论。 643

But in reality, that information isn’t that important. The matter at hand is this: (1) you want to know why the Antinet is the best knowledge development system out there; (2) you want to know the theory behind why it’s better than digital; (3) you want to know how you can build an Antinet; and (4) you want to know what positive effects you can expect by committing to the Antinet (surprise, creative insights, breakthroughs, etc.). You do not need to know every single detail about the history of notetaking. That’s for a different book. 但实际上，这些信息并不那么重要。现在的问题是：(1) 你想知道为什么 Antinet 是最好的知识开发系统； (2) 你想知道为什么它比数字更好的背后的理论； (3) 您想知道如何构建 Antinet； (4) 您想知道投身于 Antinet 可以期待什么积极效果（惊喜、创造性见解、突破等）。您无需了解有关记笔记历史的每一个细节。那是另一本书。

In brief, don’t feel the need to select material that is related to what you’re doing, but is not that important. Avoid selecting good ideas. It’s OK to note them in your mind and find them interesting and amusing, but that’s all they deserve. A grunt of amusement. 简而言之，不要觉得有必要选择与你正在做的事情相关但并不那么重要的材料。避免选择好的想法。在脑海中记下它们并发现它们有趣有趣是可以的，但这就是它们应得的。愉悦的咕哝声。

**Excellent Ideas 绝妙的点子**

Deciding whether to select or ignore excellent ideas is tricky. These ideas are important, yet they are not relevant to the project or goal you’re working on. 决定是选择还是忽略优秀的想法是很棘手的。这些想法很重要，但它们与您正在从事的项目或目标无关。

I realize it may be difficult, but you want to err on the side of skipping these ideas. Granted, there’s a spectrum to the degree of importance. If the idea ranks at least 96 out of 100 on the importance spectrum, it’s OK to select the idea.[644](#footnote-621) However, you should only extract the idea onto your bibcard (which you’ll learn more about soon). You do not want to spend time processing these ideas by converting them into maincards (by way of excerpt, reformulation, or reflection notes). You’ll want to create an ExRef for excellent ideas, but that’s all. 我知道这可能很困难，但你宁愿跳过这些想法也会犯错。当然，重要程度有一个范围。如果该想法在重要性范围内至少排名 96（满分 100），则可以选择该想法。644 但是，您应该只将该想法提取到您的 bibcard 上（您很快就会了解更多）。您不想花时间将这些想法转换成主卡（通过摘录、重新表述或反思笔记）来处理这些想法。你会想要为优秀的想法创建一个 ExRef，但仅此而已。

**Irresistible Ideas 不可抗拒的想法**

You want to spend almost all of your time living for the irresistible ideas. These are ideas that are both timely and important. Think of these as ideas that truly resonate with you. When you encounter one of these ideas, you simply just know. These ideas can be something that you (and only you) can see. These ideas are influenced by your own perspectives and unique experiences in life (both good and bad). These ideas collide with truths you’ve been contemplating that are reverberating in your mind. These are usually things that only you can see and connect. 你想把几乎所有的时间都花在为不可抗拒的想法而活。这些想法既及时又重要。将这些视为真正引起您共鸣的想法。当您遇到这些想法之一时，您就知道了。这些想法可以是您（并且只有您）可以看到的东西。这些想法受到您自己的观点和独特的生活经历（无论好坏）的影响。这些想法与您一直在思考的真理相冲突，这些真理在您的脑海中回荡。这些通常是只有您才能看到和联系的东西。

Time is scarce. This is why you shouldn’t care to bother with any of the other quadrants. You want to reserve as much time as possible to select and develop irresistible ideas. 时间紧迫。这就是为什么你不应该关心任何其他象限的原因。你想保留尽可能多的时间来选择和发展不可抗拒的想法。

Do not feel obligated to write down excellent ideas. A good chunk of them will be relegated to good ideas in a month. The ideas you want to write down are the irresistible ideas. 不要觉得有义务写下优秀的想法。他们中的很大一部分将在一个月内降级为好主意。您想写下的想法是不可抗拒的想法。

**Make Ideas Prove Themselves 让想法证明自己**

Oftentimes, I’ll make an idea prove itself. I’ll make it prove that it’s irresistible. For instance, I’ll read something I feel is irresistible on page 100. But I won’t decide immediately whether to select it. I won’t extract it immediately onto a bibcard. I’ll simply say to myself, Hmm! That’s really interesting! I note it in my mind and let it ruminate for some time. And then I continue reading. By the time I get to page 150—even if it’s several days later—if I still find the idea irresistible, I’ll extract it by writing it down on my bibcard. 通常，我会让一个想法证明自己。我会让它证明它是不可抗拒的。例如，我会在第 100 页阅读一些我觉得无法抗拒的内容。但我不会立即决定是否选择它。我不会立即将其提取到 bibcard 上。我只会对自己说，嗯！这真的很有趣！我在脑海中记下它，让它反省了一段时间。然后我继续阅读。当我读到第 150 页时——即使是几天之后——如果我仍然觉得这个想法无法抗拒，我会把它写在我的名片上。

**What Should and Shouldn’t You Select? 你应该和不应该选择什么？**

One author, who, to a large degree, regurgitates Sönke Ahrens’s material, puts forth a good question that Ahrens never answers clearly. The question is, What should, and shouldn’t, be noted down? 一位作者在很大程度上重复了 Sönke Ahrens 的材料，提出了一个很好的问题，但 Ahrens 从未清楚地回答过。问题是，什么应该记下来，什么不应该记下来？

Ahrens is rather vague in answering this question, but he at least advises the reader what not to do. This other author advises: don’t write down anything you already know by heart. Yet, he qualifies this maxim by saying it’s OK to write down something you already know—if, that is—you intend to connect it to related thoughts.[645](#footnote-620) Such advice is problematic, however, because everything is related to something in the cosmos. Even nothing can be related by describing it. How does one describe nothing? By stating it’s not nothing, and linking it to not nothing in your Antinet. Everything can be connected to related thoughts by way of inversion. 阿伦斯在回答这个问题时相当含糊，但他至少建议读者不要做什么。另一位作者建议：不要写下任何你已经记住的东西。然而，他通过说写下你已经知道的东西是可以的——如果，也就是说——你打算将它与相关的想法联系起来，从而对这条格言进行了限定。645 然而，这样的建议是有问题的，因为一切都与宇宙中的某些东西有关。甚至没有什么可以通过描述来关联。怎么形容什么都没有？通过声明它不是什么，并将它链接到您的 Antinet 中的 not nothing。一切都可以通过倒置的方式与相关的思想联系起来。

In brief the advice that you shouldn’t write down anything you know by heart—unless you wish to relate it to something else—is rather vague. I also believe it’s too simplistic. 简而言之，关于你不应该写下任何你记住的东西——除非你想把它与其他东西联系起来——的建议是相当模糊的。我也认为它太简单了。

The question remains, What types of things should you write down? 问题仍然存在，你应该写下什么类型的东西？

A better way of asking this is, What types of material should you select while reading? Here’s why this is an improved question: the material you select doesn’t necessitate that you’ll extract that knowledge. You’re selecting material to determine if it’s appropriate to actually extract. 一个更好的问法是，你在阅读时应该选择什么类型的材料？这就是为什么这是一个改进的问题：您选择的材料并不需要您提取该知识。您正在选择材料以确定它是否适合实际提取。

So back to the question, What types of material should you select while reading? 回到问题，阅读时应该选择什么类型的材料？

Here’s my take: 这是我的看法：

1. Adhere to the rule of selecting only irresistible things from your readings. Irresistible things are those things that only you can determine. Irresistible encompasses those things you find to be genius, or that you find you simply just resonate with in a way that’s difficult to explain in words. It must be true. Only you can determine if something is truly irresistible.1. 坚持只从你的阅读中选择不可抗拒的东西的规则。不可抗拒的事情是那些只有你才能决定的事情。不可抗拒包括那些你认为是天才的东西，或者你发现你只是以一种难以用语言解释的方式与之产生共鸣。这一定是真的。只有您才能确定某件事是否真的无法抗拒。

2. Select irresistible patterns that you’ve noticed from reading across different disciplines. Also select patterns you’ve noticed from your unique life experiences.2. 选择你从不同学科的阅读中注意到的不可抗拒的模式。还要选择您从独特的生活经历中注意到的模式。

3. Select irresistible ideas that are brand new to you. Granted, if you’re reading in a new field, many of the ideas you encounter will be brand new. That’s fine. Write them down, especially if they resonate with you.3. 选择对你来说全新的不可抗拒的想法。诚然，如果你在一个新领域阅读，你遇到的许多想法都是全新的。没关系。把它们写下来，尤其是当它们引起你​​的共鸣时。

4. Select hard or challenging ideas that you find irresistible. Say you encounter an idea that you find irresistible. Say it resonates with you. Yet, say you find it hard or challenging to decipher. Select that material with the expectation that you’ll be creating an excerpt note of it, or a reformulation note of it in order to better understand it.4. 选择你觉得难以抗拒的困难或具有挑战性的想法。假设您遇到一个无法抗拒的想法。说它引起你的共鸣。然而，假设您发现破译困难或具有挑战性。选择该材料时期望您将创建它的摘录注释或重新制定注释以便更好地理解它。

5. Select as if you’ll be teaching the material. Even if you’re in a state of mind where you’re focused on growing your knowledge, adopt the mindset of a teacher. Operate as if you’re selecting the material in order to teach the material. This is the contribution state of mind. The great paradox is that if you adopt the mindset of contribution, you’ll experience more growth. When you select material as if you’ll be teaching it, you’ll focus on extracting the truly helpful and insightful pieces of knowledge.5. 选择好像你要教授的材料。即使您处于专注于增长知识的心态，也要采用老师的心态。就好像您正在选择材料以教授材料一样进行操作。这就是贡献的心态。最大的悖论是，如果你采用贡献的心态，你会经历更多的成长。当您选择材料时就好像您将要教授它一样，您将专注于提取真正有用和有洞察力的知识片段。

6. Select material that deeply affects you. There may be certain passages or compositions of prose that move you. Remember that emotions can actually be felt in the body (so pay attention to your responses to the material you read). Fundamentally, emotions can be rolled up into five categories.[646](#footnote-619) The five emotions are: anger, sadness, fear, joy, and creative feelings. Material which generates deep experiences involving these emotions ought to be selected.6. 选择对你影响深远的材料。可能会有某些段落或散文作品打动您。请记住，情绪实际上可以在身体中感受到（因此请注意您对阅读材料的反应）。从根本上说，情绪可以分为五类。646 这五种情绪是：愤怒、悲伤、恐惧、快乐和创造性的感受。应该选择能够产生涉及这些情绪的深刻体验的材料。

Now that you know what to select, let’s address the material you should definitely not select while reading. 现在您知道要选择什么了，让我们来谈谈您在阅读时绝对不应该选择的材料。

This question is simpler. There are two types of material you should not select: 这个问题比较简单。您不应选择两种类型的材料：

1. Do not select information that is not irresistible. Do not select material that is bad, good, or even excellent. If it’s not irresistible, don’t waste your time. You’ll have barely enough time to elaborate on and develop irresistible material. Why waste your life energy trying to develop less than irresistible material? The correct answer is: you shouldn’t!1、不要选择非不可抗拒的信息。不要选择不好的、好的，甚至是极好的材料。如果它不是不可抗拒的，不要浪费你的时间。你将几乎没有足够的时间来详细阐述和开发不可抗拒的材料。为什么要浪费你的生命精力去开发不那么令人无法抗拒的材料呢？正确答案是：你不应该！

2. Do not write something down that you’ve already written down. In the knowledge creation phase I’ll introduce a process that helps ensure you don’t waste your time developing content you’ve already written down by hand. In brief, it involves reviewing your Antinet before you commit to creating a new note. The directive of not writing down something you’ve already written down applies mainly to excerpt notes. Say you come across Robert Frost’s famous poem, The Road Not Taken (“Two roads diverged in a yellow wood…”). If you find that poem irresistible, yet you’ve already written it down, then don’t write it down again! Don’t select the material again. If you make a mistake and forget that you’ve already written it down—and if you end up creating an excerpt note for it—make sure you install the note in your Antinet anyway. That way, you’ll have a record of your mistake. Remember: don’t erase mistakes! Don’t delete material in your Antinet.2. 不要写下你已经写下的东西。在知识创造阶段，我将介绍一个流程，帮助确保您不会浪费时间开发您已经手写的内容。简而言之，它涉及在您承诺创建新笔记之前检查您的 Antinet。不要写下你已经写下的东西的指令主要适用于摘录笔记。假设您遇到了罗伯特 · 弗罗斯特 (Robert Frost) 的著名诗歌《未选择的路》（“两条路在黄树林中分叉……”）。如果你觉得那首诗无法抗拒，但你已经把它写下来了，那就不要再写了！不要再次选择材料。如果你犯了一个错误而忘记了你已经把它写下来了——如果你最终为它创建了一个摘录笔记——无论如何都要确保你把笔记安装在你的 Antinet 中。这样，你就会有错误的记录。记住：不要抹去错误！不要删除 Antinet 中的资料。

Now that we have a good grasp of what material to select while reading a book, let’s talk about one final concept before moving on: the concept of priming. 现在我们已经很好地掌握了阅读一本书时选择什么材料，让我们在继续之前谈谈最后一个概念：启动的概念。

**Priming 启动**

The process you must complete before reading even the first page of any book is called the priming phase.[647](#footnote-618) 在阅读任何一本书的第一页之前您必须完成的过程称为启动阶段。 647

The priming phase entails reading related material, relevant background material, even dissecting the book’s table of contents, and other techniques (for instance, designing a quiz about the book for yourself). 启动阶段需要阅读相关材料、相关背景材料，甚至剖析本书的目录，以及其他技巧（例如，为自己设计一个关于本书的测验）。

According to one cognitive psychologist, priming “really does help, especially when the subject matter is difficult or unfamiliar.”[648](#footnote-617) 根据一位认知心理学家的说法，启动 “确实有帮助，尤其是当主题很困难或不熟悉时。”648

I have a specific process that I encourage you to do before reading any book. It works best with a certain knowledge extraction strategy called the Luhmannian bibcard method. I’ll detail that method in the next section. For this, however, all you’ll need is a 4 x 6 inch blank white notecard. 我有一个特定的过程，我鼓励你在阅读任何一本书之前完成。它最适合与称为 Luhmannian bibcard 方法的特定知识提取策略一起使用。我将在下一节中详细介绍该方法。然而，为此，您只需要一张 4 x 6 英寸的空白白色记事卡。

On the front-side of the bibcard you will write three items: (1) the bibliographic details of the source, (2) your goal in engaging the source, and (3) an overview of the source if available (i.e., a brief overview of its table of contents). 在 bibcard 的正面，您将写下三个项目：(1) 来源的书目详细信息，(2) 您参与来源的目标，以及 (3) 来源的概述（如果可用）（即，简要说明其目录概述）。

This becomes your bookmark as you read the book. 当您阅读本书时，这将成为您的书签。

Here’s a picture of one of my bibcards. The front can be thought of as the priming area: 这是我的一张 bibcards 的照片。前面可以被认为是启动区域：

**Creating an Overview 创建概览**

Note that the overview section isn’t a word-for-word copy of the table of contents. It’s brief. It forces you to take the deliberate time to read the table of contents and get a general idea of what you’re about to read. 请注意，概述部分不是目录的逐字复制。很简短。它迫使你花时间仔细阅读目录，并对你将要阅读的内容有一个大概的了解。

This practice was inspired by Mortimer Adler’s classic book titled How to Read a Book. In this book he introduces the practice he calls X-raying a book. He uses this analogy to illustrate that one ought to get a sense of a book’s skeleton—its structure—before reading it. 这种做法的灵感来自莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 (Mortimer Adler) 的经典著作《如何阅读一本书》。在这本书中，他介绍了他称之为 X 光检查的做法一本书。他用这个类比来说明，在阅读一本书之前，应该了解一本书的骨架——它的结构。

This practice is also supported by a cognitive scientist who specializes in notetaking. She advises that one ought to analyze a book’s table of contents as an important first step before reading any book.[649](#footnote-616) 这种做法也得到一位专门做笔记的认知科学家的支持。她建议，在阅读任何一本书之前，应该先分析一本书的目录，这是重要的第一步。 649

**Setting a Goal 设定目标**

Being intentional with your reading is a game-changer, plain and simple. Luhmann always had an intentional goal with his readings. He used short-term projects (research papers) that enabled him to immediately apply many of his ideas, and if those ideas weren’t immediately useful, to place ExRefs in their appropriate place to ruminate on and be used when the time came. 有意识地阅读可以改变游戏规则，简单明了。卢曼的阅读总是有目的的。他使用短期项目（研究论文）使他能够立即应用他的许多想法，如果这些想法不是立即有用，则将 ExRef 放在适当的位置进行反思并在时机成熟时使用。

Luhmann published 550 research papers during his academic career. Two hundred more papers were found among his belongings after he passed away. This comes out to 750 papers. Let’s not even take into consideration the seventy books he also published during this period. If we just look at the papers, he was working on roughly two papers per month. Luhmann, ultimately, was always reading with a specific project in mind. 卢曼在其学术生涯中发表了 550 篇研究论文。他去世后，在他的随身物品中发现了两百多份文件。总共有 750 篇论文。我们甚至不考虑他在此期间还出版的 70 本书。如果我们只看论文，他每个月大约要写两篇论文。最终，卢曼总是带着一个特定的项目来阅读。

As Antonin Sertillanges advises, your reading should be influenced by a definite idea—a clear goal and purpose. “Let it take account not only of your vocation and your personality, but of their immediate application.”[650](#footnote-615) 正如 Antonin Sertillanges 建议的那样，你的阅读应该受到明确想法的影响——明确的目标和目的。 “让它不仅要考虑你的职业和个性，还要考虑它们的直接应用。”650

In other words, read specifically with an eye for immediately applying the knowledge you encounter. 换句话说，专门阅读以立即应用您遇到的知识。

For the knowledge you encounter that is irresistible yet not immediately applicable, simply create an ExRef for the material in your Antinet. In brief, your time creating main notes—specifically reflection notes—should be for material that is immediately applicable. 对于您遇到的无法抗拒但又不能立即应用的知识，只需在您的 Antinet 中为该材料创建一个 ExRef。简而言之，您创建主要笔记（特别是反思笔记）的时间应该用于立即适用的材料。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

We covered a lot of important material in this section. We outlined the importance of taking selection seriously. That is, the importance of selecting books carefully, selecting the material in them carefully, and selecting where to install those ideas within the Antinet carefully. 我们在本节中介绍了很多重要材料。我们概述了认真对待选择的重要性。也就是说，仔细选择书籍的重要性，仔细选择其中的材料，并仔细选择在 Antinet 中安装这些想法的位置。

Selection is a vague and fuzzy area of knowledge development. If things are still a bit unclear, rest assured that your selection skills will improve with practice. Thankfully, analog knowledge development helps in this regard. You’ll quickly learn that you’re selecting way too much material when it takes you seemingly forever to get through a book! 选择是知识发展的一个模糊和模糊的领域。如果事情仍然有点不清楚，请放心，您的选择技巧会随着练习而提高。值得庆幸的是，模拟知识的发展在这方面有所帮助。您很快就会发现，当您似乎要花很长时间才能读完一本书时，您选择的材料太多了！

If you only take one thing from this chapter, let it be this: select only the most irresistibly important books, and the most irresistibly important ideas within those books, which are immediately applicable to your project or goal. 如果你只从本章中吸取一件事，那就是：只选择最重要的书籍，以及这些书中最重要的思想，这些思想可以立即适用于你的项目或目标。

Now that you know about selection, it’s time to embark upon the next phase of knowledge development: Extraction. 现在您了解了选择，是时候开始知识开发的下一阶段了：提取。

CHAPTER FOURTEEN 第十四章
---------------------

Extraction 萃取
-------------

The extraction phase of knowledge development concerns itself with the actual action of pulling out material from the sources with which you engage. Selection entails the internal experience of taking notice of certain thoughts or ideas, after which you face a yes-or-no question. Are you going to extract the material by writing it down? 知识开发的提取阶段关注的是从你接触的资源中提取材料的实际行动。选择需要注意某些想法或想法的内部体验，之后您将面临是或否的问题。你打算通过写下来提取材料吗？

If you determine that yes, you’re going to convert the material into a note, you then proceed into the extraction phase. The extraction phase is a process that exists before you actually create the main note. But in this phase you actually take deliberate action by marking the material to be extracted. Within this phase, there are several methods you can use to extract material. Before we dive into the explicit methods, let’s first survey the different types of strategies involved in reading a book (or engaging with a knowledge source). 如果确定是，则将材料转换为笔记，然后进入提取阶段。提取阶段是在您实际创建主笔记之前存在的过程。但在这个阶段，您实际上是通过标记要提取的材料来采取有意识的行动。在此阶段中，您可以使用多种方法来提取材料。在我们深入研究显式方法之前，让我们首先调查一下阅读一本书（或与知识源互动）所涉及的不同类型的策略。

**Intentional vs. Exploratory Strategies 有意与探索性策略**
---------------------------------------------------

Some books may require a more intentional extraction strategy and others a more exploratory strategy. 有些书可能需要更有意识的提取策略，而另一些则需要更具探索性的策略。

As Antonin Sertillanges advises, “One will have recourse to other books for information, not for formation.”[651](#footnote-688) In other words, when you are new to material and you’re in the exploratory phase, you’re reading for formation. Your primary extraction strategy should consist of comprehending the material you’re reading. Your content should consist of reformulating the material in your own words. 正如 Antonin Sertillanges 建议的那样，“一个人会求助于其他书籍来获取信息，而不是为了形成。”651 换句话说，当你对材料不熟悉并且处于探索阶段时，你正在阅读以形成。你的主要提取策略应该包括理解你正在阅读的材料。你的内容应该包括用你自己的话重新表述材料。

Once you have developed the foundation of knowledge in a field, you can begin reading intentionally. You can begin looking for information to evolve ideas. You begin looking for information that supports your current theories, which are incubating in your Antinet. You begin reading for the purpose of finding material that yields more granular distinctions relative to your theories. You further elucidate these new thoughts by way of reflection notes. 一旦你在某个领域建立了知识基础，你就可以开始有意识地阅读。您可以开始寻找信息来发展想法。你开始寻找支持你当前理论的信息，这些理论正在你的 Antinet 中孵化。你开始阅读的目的是为了找到与你的理论相关的更精细的区别的材料。您通过反思笔记进一步阐明了这些新想法。

Let’s consider both intentional extraction and exploratory extraction in detail. 让我们详细考虑有意提取和探索性提取。

**Intentional Extraction 有意提取**

An intentional extraction strategy should be employed when you’re already familiar with the material you’re reading. If you’re pressed for time, or if you are working with a singular project in mind, you’ll also want an intentional extraction strategy. 当你已经熟悉你正在阅读的材料时，应该采用有意识的提取策略。如果你时间紧迫，或者如果你正在考虑一个单一的项目，你还需要一个有意的提取策略。

When reading intentionally, you’ll be reading for material to enrich your project. The important thing here is that you do not get “bogged down,” as Luhmann would say.[652](#footnote-687) You want to spend less time writing down excerpt and reformulation notes, and more time writing reflection notes. 有意阅读时，您将阅读材料来丰富您的项目。这里重要的是你不会像卢曼所说的那样 “陷入困境”。652 你想花更少的时间写摘录和重新制定的笔记，而花更多的时间写反思笔记。

The two extraction methods best for this are the 2-step marginalia method, and the 2-step Luhmannian bibcard method. These enable you to quickly identify material you find irresistible; but, instead of getting bogged down, and developing them right then and there, you delay the processing. After you’re done reading, you can determine how to efficiently process the material. This gives you more time to elaborate on the most important irresistible ideas. 最适合此的两种提取方法是两步旁注法和两步卢曼比卡法。这些使您能够快速识别您觉得不可抗拒的材料；但是，与其陷入困境并立即开发它们，不如延迟处理。阅读完后，您可以确定如何有效地处理材料。这使您有更多时间来阐述最重要的不可抗拒的想法。

In the next section, we’ll cover the specific extraction methods just outlined in more detail. Before that, however, let’s quickly cover the concept of exploratory extraction. 在下一节中，我们将更详细地介绍刚刚概述的特定提取方法。然而，在此之前，让我们快速介绍一下探索性提取的概念。

**Exploratory Extraction 探索性提取**

An exploratory extraction strategy should be employed for books that are more difficult to parse. Much of the time this applies to books in fields that are new to you. As Mortimer Adler writes, 对于更难解析的书籍，应该采用探索性提取策略。大多数情况下，这适用于您不熟悉的领域的书籍。正如莫蒂默阿德勒所写，

If you are reading in order to become a better reader, you cannot read just any book or article. You will not improve as a reader if all you read are books that are well within your capacity. You must tackle books that are beyond you, or, as we have said, books that are over your head. Only books of that sort will make you stretch your mind. And unless you stretch, you will not learn.[653](#footnote-686) 如果您阅读是为了成为更好的读者，那么您不能只阅读任何一本书或一篇文章。如果你读的都是你能力范围内的书，你作为一个读者是不会进步的。你必须处理那些超出你能力范围的书，或者，正如我们所说的，那些你无法理解的书。只有那种书才能让你舒展一下头脑。除非你伸展，否则你不会学习。 653

Let’s take an example from my own experience. Sometime back I was reading a book called Book of Proof. It’s an introduction to the world of mathematical proofs (think a bunch of Greek symbols, equations, and numbers. This field was completely new to me. I was attracted to it because of the challenge. In order to understand the text, I had to take diligent notes. Taking notes in margins wasn’t effective, as there was not enough space. Taking bullet point notes on a bibcard wasn’t the best option either. On average, each of the notes would take up an entire card anyway. It didn’t make sense to constrain myself, or have them run across several bibcards. 让我们以我自己的经历为例。前段时间我在读一本书，叫做《证据之书》。这是对数学证明世界的介绍（想想一堆希腊符号、方程式和数字。这个领域对我来说是全新的。我是因为挑战而被它吸引的。为了理解文本，我不得不认真做笔记。在空白处做笔记是无效的，因为没有足够的空间。在 bibcard 上做要点笔记也不是最好的选择。平均而言，每个笔记都会占用整张卡片。限制自己或让他们跑过几个 bibcards 是没有意义的。

The method I employed for this book was the 1-step book-to-maincard method.
