This method entails stopping while reading, pulling out a notecard and writing down the note immediately (I prefer 3 x 5 inch because the constraints breed focus). The notes you write in this method are either excerpts or reformulations. The purpose of writing these notes is to better understand the new material. If you proceed through challenging books without first understanding the elementary material that came first, you’re in for a difficult ride. You need to understand the elementary, fundamental concepts before you understand the more complex concepts. 我在本书中采用的方法是从书到主卡的一步法。这种方法需要在阅读时停下来，拿出记事卡并立即写下笔记（我更喜欢 3 x 5 英寸，因为限制会产生焦点）。你用这种方法写的笔记要么是摘录，要么是重新表述。写这些笔记的目的是为了更好地理解新材料。如果您在没有首先理解最先出现的基础材料的情况下继续阅读具有挑战性的书籍，那么您将遇到困难。在理解更复杂的概念之前，您需要先理解基本的基本概念。

The book-to-maincard method enables you to proceed through difficult texts, though the downside, of course, is getting bogged down. It’s counter-intuitive, but reading using an exploratory 1-step strategy ends up taking more time than 2-step intentional strategies. 从书到主卡的方法使您能够继续阅读困难的文本，当然，缺点是会陷入困境。这是违反直觉的，但使用探索性第一步策略阅读最终会比两步有意策略花费更多时间。

Let’s cover the extraction methods in detail now. 现在让我们详细介绍提取方法。

**Knowledge Extraction Methods 知识抽取方法**
---------------------------------------

With notetaking and reading, the method you use to extract knowledge is of paramount importance. 对于记笔记和阅读，您用来提取知识的方法至关重要。

Certain extraction methods work for reading new books with unfamiliar ideas, whereas they fail for other types of books. For this reason you must “understand why and how and when” to use different extraction methods.[654](#footnote-685) 某些提取方法适用于阅读思想不熟悉的新书，而适用于其他类型的书籍。为此，您必须 “了解为什么、如何以及何时” 使用不同的提取方法。 654

When choosing an extraction method, it’s important that you not simply choose the one you’re “most comfortable with.”[655](#footnote-684) That is, don’t merely choose a strategy that is most compatible with how you’re feeling that day. Oftentimes, the best strategy is not the one you’re initially comfortable with. Research supports this, as well. [656](#footnote-683) 选择提取方法时，重要的是您不能简单地选择您 “最舒服” 的方法。655 也就是说，不要只选择最适合您当天感受的策略。通常，最好的策略并不是您最初喜欢的策略。研究也支持这一点。 656

You also should not feel obligated to be married to an extraction method forever. You must have, at your disposal, several extraction methods to choose from. As cognitive scientist Fiona McPherson observes, there’s “no one ‘best’ strategy for taking notes.”[657](#footnote-682) 您也不应该觉得有义务永远采用提取方法。您必须有多种提取方法可供选择。正如认知科学家菲奥娜 · 麦克弗森 (Fiona McPherson) 所观察到的，“没有一种‘最好’的记笔记策略。”657

In my own case, I employ the 2-step Luhmannian bibcard method the majority of the time (think 96%). However, for books in fields that are completely new to me, or ones that are challenging, I sometimes use the 1-step book-to-maincard method. 在我自己的案例中，我大部分时间（认为是 96%）都采用两步 Luhmannian bibcard 方法。然而，对于那些对我来说是全新领域的书籍，或者那些具有挑战性的书籍，我有时会使用 1-step book-to-maincard 方法。

**The 1-Step Book-to-Maincard Method1 步书到 Maincard 方法**

The book-to-maincard method is quite simple. There’s a good chance you already do this. You simply read a book with pen and notecards at hand. When you come across a key concept or passage, you stop reading and make a note for it on a dedicated card. Typically the note is either an excerpt (i.e., a word-for-word copy of the quote), or a reformulation of the concept in your own words. It can also be a reflection note; however I find this kind of note to be briefer than the reflection notes I create using the Luhmannian bibcard method. Why? Because you don’t have enough time to let the idea ruminate on a staging card (i.e., a bibcard). When writing reflection notes using the book-to-maincard method, they seem to embody briefer (and less deep) ideas. I like to think of these as observations (which are similar to the concept of bibnotes, which you’ll learn soon). 从书到主卡的方法非常简单。您很有可能已经这样做了。您只需用手边的笔和记事卡阅读一本书。当你遇到一个关键概念或段落时，你会停止阅读并在专用卡片上做笔记。通常，注释要么是摘录（即引用的逐字复制），要么是用您自己的话对概念的重新表述。它也可以是反思笔记；然而，我发现这种笔记比我使用 Luhmannian bibcard 方法创建的反思笔记更简短。为什么？因为你没有足够的时间让这个想法在临时卡（即 bibcard）上反复思考。当使用从书到主卡的方法写反思笔记时，它们似乎体现了更简短（和不那么深刻）的想法。我喜欢将这些视为观察（类似于 bibnotes 的概念，您很快就会学到）。

**Book-to-Maincard Notes in Practice 实践中的 Book-to-Maincard 注释**

I like to place my book-to-maincard notes on 3 x 5 inch cards. This prevents me from getting bogged down. Typically my book-to-maincard notes are excerpts. Limiting myself to the 3 x 5 inch space prevents me from excerpting quotes or ideas that are too large. In addition, when using 4 x 6 inch cards I frequently experience an unsettling urge to fill up the entire card. If I use only a few lines, it feels much more like I’m wasting paper. Using 3 x 5 inch cards helps me avoid this feeling, and in turn, it helps me avoid getting bogged down in a book by stopping every few pages to write out long excerpts. 我喜欢将我的 book-to-maincard 笔记放在 3 x 5 英寸的卡片上。这可以防止我陷入困境。通常我的 book-to-maincard 笔记是摘录。将自己限制在 3 x 5 英寸的空间内可以防止我摘录太大的引述或想法。此外，在使用 4 x 6 英寸的卡片时，我经常会感到不安，想要填满整张卡片。如果我只使用几行，感觉更像是在浪费纸张。使用 3 x 5 英寸的卡片帮助我避免这种感觉，反过来，它通过每隔几页停下来写下长篇摘录，帮助我避免陷入书本的泥潭。

On the next page is a picture of a book-to-maincard note I took. 下一页是一张我拍的书到主卡笔记的照片。

**The 2-Step Marginalia Method 两步边际法**

Marginalia refers to making notations or other marks in the margins of the books you read. This is something Niklas Luhmann never did.Marginalia 是指在您阅读的书籍的页边空白处做记号或其他标记。这是尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 从未做过的事情。

One could argue that the reason Luhmann never wrote in books was because he actually mostly read in libraries.[658](#footnote-681) Yet Luhmann did indeed own many books. Among his possessions were 5,000 books, 1,400 journal issues, 300 special journal issues, 1,600 offprints, and other material. Johannes Schmidt observed that they hardly showed any underlining or margin notes. He states, “Luhmann almost always made notes on slips of paper while reading.”[659](#footnote-680) 有人可能会争辩说，卢曼从不写书的原因是因为他实际上主要是在图书馆阅读。658 然而，卢曼确实拥有很多书。他的财产包括 5,000 本书、1,400 期期刊、300 期特刊、1,600 册单行本和其他材料。 Johannes Schmidt 观察到它们几乎没有任何下划线或边注。他说，“卢曼几乎总是在阅读时在纸条上做笔记。”659

Regardless, marginalia remains a popular practice. It’s a practice adhered to by many readers and writers, including Cal Newport, Charlie Munger, David McCullough, Ryan Holiday, and countless others.[660](#footnote-679) 无论如何，旁注仍然是一种流行的做法。这是许多读者和作家坚持的做法，包括 Cal Newport、Charlie Munger、David McCullough、Ryan Holiday 和无数其他人。 660

I’ve employed the marginalia practice, as well. However, I do not think you should follow this practice. 我也采用了旁注练习。但是，我认为您不应该遵循这种做法。

Here’s why: Because marginalia suck. 原因如下：因为旁注很烂。

Yes, marginalia suck. They suck compared to the Luhmannian bibcard practice I’ll teach you next. 是的，旁注很烂。与我接下来要教你的 Luhmannian bibcard 实践相比，它们很糟糕。

That said, I foresee many of you not believing me. You may have some sacred scheme or practice such as making notes and dog-earing pages. 也就是说，我预见到你们中的许多人不相信我。您可能有一些神圣的计划或练习，例如做笔记和折角页面。

I’ve decided to at least outline the marginalia schemes available. That way you can observe the practices I’ve found to be inferior so that you can potentially skip having to learn the hard way yourself. 我决定至少概述可用的旁注方案。这样你就可以观察我发现的较差的做法，这样你就可以跳过必须自己努力学习的过程。

**The CVP Marginalia SchemeCVP 边际计划**

During the short period of time I employed a marginalia method, I used a scheme I found quite convenient. Upon coming across a passage I found irresistible, I would place either a C, V, or a P next to it. The C meant Concept. The V meant vocab. The P meant prose. 在我使用旁注法的短时间内，我使用了一个我觉得很方便的方案。遇到无法抗拒的段落时，我会在其旁边放置 C、V 或 P。 C 表示概念。 V 表示词汇。 P 表示散文。

Whenever I read something with an irresistible concept, vocab word, or great prose, I would note down either C, V, or P in the margin. 每当我读到一些具有不可抗拒的概念、词汇或伟大散文的东西时，我都会在页边空白处记下 C、V 或 P。

In the beginning this was nice. However, I encountered problems with this method. The barrier to selecting material became too low. It was too easy to select any and every thought. It resulted in my selecting way too much material for extraction. This created an over-abundance of homework. 一开始这很好。但是，我在使用这种方法时遇到了问题。选择材料的门槛变得太低了。选择任何一个想法太容易了。这导致我选择了太多的提取材料。这造成了过多的家庭作业。

When reading the book Cataloging the World, I employed this method. As a result, the material I’ve selected from this book remains underdeveloped. I have indeed used material from it; however I’ve had to spend more time developing the material. Additionally, because I never took the time to deliberately process the material by writing it down by hand, I find myself relating it to other parts of the book less frequently. 我在看《世界编目》一书时，就采用了这种方法。因此，我从本书中选择的材料仍然不完善。我确实使用了它的材料；但是我不得不花更多的时间来开发这些材料。此外，因为我从来没有花时间通过手写的方式来刻意处理材料，所以我发现自己很少将其与本书的其他部分联系起来。

Here you can see a picture of one section of the book. Note how I placed way too many C’s in the margin. 在这里你可以看到这本书的一个部分的图片。请注意我是如何在空白处放置太多 C 的。

When you use a marginalia technique like this, you end up selecting way too much material for extraction. That’s my experience, at least. You’re welcome to test yourself, and learn the hard way! 当你使用像这样的旁注技术时，你最终会选择太多的材料来提取。至少这是我的经验。欢迎您测试自己，并通过艰苦的方式学习！

**The Dot Marginalia Scheme 点边距方案**

After some time employing the CVP marginalia scheme, I began using something I call the dot marginalia scheme. In this method you simply read a book, and whenever there’s an irresistible idea, you place a simple dot (·) next to it. When you go back to read through your selections, you can usually tell why you selected that material (i.e., whether it’s a concept, vocab term, or prose). Therefore, in theory, it saves time. 在使用 CVP 旁注方案一段时间后，我开始使用我称之为点旁注方案的东西。在这种方法中，您只需阅读一本书，每当有一个不可抗拒的想法时，您就在它旁边放置一个简单的点 (·)。当你回过头来阅读你的选择时，你通常可以说出你为什么选择那些材料（即，它是一个概念、词汇术语还是散文）。因此，从理论上讲，它可以节省时间。

Again, like the CVP method, it results in an overabundance of selections. You create a ton of homework for yourself. The material you select tends to include many good ideas and excellent ideas instead of exclusively containing irresistible ideas. 同样，与 CVP 方法一样，它会导致选择过多。你为自己布置了大量的作业。你选择的材料往往包括许多好的想法和优秀的想法，而不是仅仅包含不可抗拒的想法。

Here’s an example of the dot marginalia scheme. I used this while reading the book The Hero with a Thousand Faces. 这是点旁注方案的示例。我在看《千面英雄》这本书时用过这个。

Like the CVP marginalia scheme, this one resulted in too many selections. 与 CVP 旁注方案一样，该方案导致选择过多。

**The Note Marginalia Scheme 笔记旁注方案**

One of the more popular marginalia schemes involves writing brief notes in the margins. These notes are typically your own thoughts and observations that relate directly to the passage you’ve read. 一种更流行的旁注方案涉及在空白处写简短的注释。这些笔记通常是您自己的想法和观察结果，与您阅读的文章直接相关。

I used this scheme when reading a book on memory science. Here’s a picture from a section of the book: 我在看一本关于记忆科学的书时使用了这个方案。这是本书的一部分的图片：

There are several problems with this scheme. You end up selecting too much material and you end up leaving less time for the irresistible ideas. Furthermore you experience a tendency wherein you write too much, with the result being that you end up wasting time. What you’ve written down in the book must then be duplicated and written down on a note. This is fine when using a very limited space (such as a single line on a bibcard); however, the space in marginalia often can stretch vertically. This leaves you more space to expand your writing. Often, what you end up writing down in the margin is something you shouldn’t have even wasted energy writing down in the first place. 这个方案有几个问题。你最终选择了太多的材料，你最终留给不可抗拒的想法的时间更少了。此外，你会体验到一种写得太多的倾向，结果是你最终浪费了时间。然后必须将您在书中写下的内容复制并写在便条上。这在使用非常有限的空间（例如 bibcard 上的单行）时很好；然而，边缘的空间通常可以垂直延伸。这给你留下了更多的空间来扩展你的写作。通常，你最终在页边空白处写下的是你一开始就不应该浪费精力写下的东西。

**Your Own Marginalia Scheme 你自己的边际计划**

As noted, I contend that the marginalia method is inferior to the Luhmannian bibcard method. If you still insist on marking up book margins, though, then chances are you’ll use your own marginalia scheme. I’ve observed that a lot of people like placing little sticky notes or post-it tabs in their books. While I don’t recommend any of this, I won’t slam you for adding your own flavor to your knowledge extraction process. Each person is different. 如前所述，我认为旁注方法不如 Luhmannian bibcard 方法。但是，如果您仍然坚持标记书页边距，那么您很可能会使用自己的旁注方案。我观察到很多人喜欢在他们的书中放一些小便利贴或便利贴。虽然我不推荐这些，但我不会抨击你在你的知识提取过程中加入你自己的风格。每个人都是不同的。

Since I do not recommend marginalia notes and I opt for the ultimate strategy that Luhmann used, I’ll introduce it to you shortly. 由于我不推荐旁注，我选择了卢曼使用的终极策略，我将很快向您介绍。

But first, let me cover a few other extraction methods very quickly. 但首先，让我快速介绍一些其他提取方法。

**Other Extraction Methods 其他提取方法**
-----------------------------------

Cognitive scientist, Fiona McPherson, outlines three other extraction methods: (1) highlighting, (2) headings, and (3) summaries.[661](#footnote-678) I’ll cover them now. 认知科学家 Fiona McPherson 概述了其他三种提取方法：(1) 突出显示，(2) 标题，和 (3) 摘要。661 我现在将介绍它们。

Highlighting and headings aren’t really pure, stand-alone, extraction methods. They’re more like pre-extraction methods. They’re essentially selection methods for noting which items you intend to extract. They’re used primarily to help you comprehend information and then convert such information into deeper knowledge. You convert the information into deeper knowledge by creating a note for it and elaborating on the material. 突出显示和标题并不是真正纯粹的、独立的提取方法。它们更像是预提取方法。它们本质上是用于记录您打算提取哪些项目的选择方法。它们主要用于帮助您理解信息，然后将此类信息转化为更深入的知识。通过为信息创建注释并详细说明材料，您可以将信息转化为更深入的知识。

Let’s talk about highlighting first. 让我们先谈谈突出显示。

**Highlighting 突出显示**

Highlighting is not a good method for dense, complex, and challenging information. For that type of material it’s best to employ the 1-step book-to-maincard method. 对于密集、复杂和具有挑战性的信息，突出显示不是一个好方法。对于这种类型的材料，最好采用一步从书到主卡的方法。

While highlighting does not possess the cognitive development power, it is not “completely pointless,” as it does help you actually pay attention to the words on the page.[662](#footnote-677) Generally, I’d advise you to stay away from highlighting. If the material is familiar to you, or even if it’s complicated, highlighting won’t help much. There’s even research indicating highlighting may harm one’s ability to learn and recall information.[663](#footnote-676) Highlighting steals time and energy away from more effective learning practices. 虽然突出显示不具备认知发展能力，但它并非 “完全没有意义”，因为它确实可以帮助您真正注意页面上的文字。662 一般来说，我建议您远离突出显示。如果材料对您来说很熟悉，或者即使它很复杂，突出显示也无济于事。甚至有研究表明，突出显示可能会损害一个人学习和回忆信息的能力。663 突出显示会从更有效的学习实践中窃取时间和精力。

As one cognitive scientist observes, the main value of highlighting does not intrinsically add much value to your understanding of the material; its benefit (if any) stems from its ability to motivate you to spend more time with the material. Yet as we’ve found, writing by hand and spending the time elaborating on material by writing reflection notes is even more motivating and fun—especially if you’re only elaborating on the material you find irresistible. 正如一位认知科学家所观察到的，突出显示的主要价值本质上并没有为您对材料的理解增加太多价值；它的好处（如果有的话）源于它能够激励你花更多的时间在材料上。然而，正如我们发现的那样，手写并花时间通过写反思笔记来阐述材料会更有动力和乐趣——尤其是当你只是在阐述你觉得不可抗拒的材料时。

In brief, I’d recommend you stop the practice of highlighting. 简而言之，我建议您停止突出显示的做法。

**Headings 标题**

Headings that you write are brief sentences outlining what the following paragraph intends to cover. They do not summarize or spoil what is written in the paragraph; rather they help organize its content. 你写的标题是简短的句子，概述了下一段打算涵盖的内容。他们不会总结或破坏段落中的内容；相反，他们帮助组织其内容。

Headings have been shown to produce better summaries, outlines, and reformulation of material. This in turn helps enhance your recall of the material you read.[664](#footnote-675) 标题已被证明可以产生更好的摘要、大纲和材料的重新表述。这反过来又有助于增强您对阅读材料的回忆。 664

Headings are classified as organizational signals, and have demonstrated a tendency to improving a reader’s recall of information (unlike highlighting).[665](#footnote-674) 标题被归类为组织信号，并显示出提高读者对信息的记忆力的趋势（与突出显示不同）。 665

Headings are usually provided in texts whose author is awesome (like me), and who put the work in to organize their material into chunks with a heading attached. 标题通常在作者非常棒（比如我）的文本中提供，他们投入工作将他们的材料组织成带有标题的块。

However, so-called “learned” authors (scientists and scholars, like Luhmann) may forgo such niceties. In such a case it may be a useful practice to create your own headings. I don’t recommend doing this directly in the book (i.e., marginalia). Rather, I recommend using your bibcard for this practice. 然而，所谓的 “博学” 作者（科学家和学者，如卢曼）可能会放弃这些细节。在这种情况下，创建自己的标题可能是一种有用的做法。我不建议直接在书中这样做（即旁注）。相反，我建议使用您的 bibcard 进行此练习。

The third extraction method is that of summaries. This is analogous to creating a reformulation note, which is covered in detail in the next chapter. These are best for tackling difficult material. If tackling difficult material, I recommend creating reformulation notes using the 1-step book-to-maincard method. In brief, you go straight from book to creating an entire notecard dedicated to reformulating the difficult idea you just read. 第三种提取方法是摘要提取方法。这类似于创建一个重新制定的注释，下一章将对此进行详细介绍。这些最适合处理困难的材料。如果处理困难的材料，我建议使用 1 步书到主卡方法创建重新制定的注释。简而言之，您直接从书本开始创建一个完整的记事卡，专门用于重新表述您刚刚阅读的困难想法。

Let’s now turn to the grand-daddy of all the extraction strategies: the two-step Luhmannian bibcard method. 现在让我们转向所有提取策略的鼻祖：两步 Luhmannian bibcard 方法。

**The Two-Step Luhmannian Bibcard Method 两步 Luhmannian Bibcard 方法**

A phase transition took place in the eighteenth century during the enlightenment wherein the reading styles of scholars changed. “An enlightened reader was no longer supposed to collect and memorize ‘factoids’ that he found in the texts of others,” observed scholar, Fabian Krämer.[666](#footnote-673) In the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, when scholars read, their focus centered on collecting bits of knowledge (excerpting). During the enlightenment, scholars began to read by recording their own thoughts (observations).[667](#footnote-672) Essentially, reading and observing became “closely intertwined.”[668](#footnote-671) The observations one made while reading could then be used to process an idea more fully. This could be done by way of (1) creating reflection notes on the material in order to integrate ideas into one’s own theories and creative work, (2) testing an author’s conclusions by way of experiment, and (3) writing critical reviews of books (which became a popular practice during the enlightenment). 十八世纪启蒙运动时期发生了阶段性转变，学者们的阅读方式发生了变化。学者法比安 · 克莱默 (Fabian Krämer) 观察到：“一个开明的读者不再应该收集和记住他在他人文本中发现的‘事实’。”666 在 16 和 17 世纪，当学者们阅读时，他们的重点集中在收集零星的信息上。知识（摘录）。在启蒙运动期间，学者们开始通过记录自己的想法（观察）来阅读。667 从本质上讲，阅读和观察变得 “紧密地交织在一起”。668 阅读时所做的观察可以用来更充分地处理一个想法。这可以通过以下方式完成：(1) 在材料上创建反思笔记，以便将想法整合到自己的理论和创造性作品中，(2) 通过实验检验作者的结论，以及 (3) 撰写书评（这在启蒙运动期间成为一种流行的做法）。

These deeper ways of processing texts begins with recording one’s observations. The container with which one records such observations is that of the bibcard. This is what we’ll be covering in this section. 这些处理文本的更深层次的方法始于记录一个人的观察。记录此类观察结果的容器是 bibcard。这就是我们将在本节中介绍的内容。

In the course of using the Antinet, I’ve tried out all of the methods mentioned previously. I’ve come to conclude that the best method in the majority of cases is what you’re about to learn now: The 2-step bibcard method. 在 Antinet 的使用过程中，我已经尝试了前面提到的所有方法。我得出的结论是，在大多数情况下最好的方法就是您现在要学习的方法：两步 bibcard 方法。

In Luhmann’s first Antinet, he primarily adopted the 1-step book-to-maincard method. As Johannes Schmidt observes, “the early notes from the 1950s and 1960s frequently tended to be more of the running-text kind and more closely reflected the original readings.”[669](#footnote-670) 在卢曼的第一个 Antinet 中，他主要采用了 1-step book-to-maincard 的方法。正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 所观察到的，“1950 年代和 1960 年代的早期笔记通常更倾向于行文类型，更接近地反映了原始阅读。”669

In Luhmann’s second Antinet, his method changed. 在卢曼的第二个 Antinet 中，他的方法发生了变化。

Here’s an overview of this process: 以下是此过程的概述：

This method entails extracting knowledge from external sources by placing it on a bibcard. 这种方法需要通过将其放在 bibcard 上来从外部资源中提取知识。

On the front-side of the bibcard, are three items: (1) the bibliographic details of the source, (2) your goal in engaging the source, and (3) an overview of the source if available (such as a brief overview of its table of contents). This is already covered in the chapter on selection. 在 bibcard 的正面，有三个项目：(1) 来源的书目详细信息，(2) 您参与来源的目标，以及 (3) 来源的概述（如果有的话）（例如简要概述其目录）。这已经在关于选择的章节中进行了介绍。

On the back-side of the bibcard, are the bibnotes. The bibnotes are the observations you have while reading. These are the internal thoughts and ideas you wish to select from the material. With these items, you’ll either: (1) convert them into main notes by excerpting them, reformulating them, or reflecting on them, or (2) forego elaborating on the items by storing them as ExRefs. By foregoing elaboration, you allow the items to ruminate until the time wherein you’re working on a relevant project which will benefit from including the material. 在 bibcard 的背面，是 bibnotes。 bibnotes 是您在阅读时的观察结果。这些是您希望从材料中选择的内部想法和想法。使用这些项目，您可以：(1) 通过摘录、重新组织或反思将它们转换为主要笔记，或者 (2) 通过将它们存储为 ExRef 来放弃对这些项目的详细说明。通过上述说明，您可以反复思考这些项目，直到您从事相关项目，该项目将从包含这些材料中受益。

Here’s a picture of a bibcard: 这是一张 bibcard 的图片：

**How to Read with a Bibcard 如何使用 Bibcard 阅读**

Reading using the bibcard method typically involves three items: (1) a physical book, (2) a pen, and (3) the bibcard. 使用 bibcard 方法阅读通常涉及三个项目：(1) 一本实体书，(2) 一支笔，以及 (3) bibcard。

Ideally I recommend physical books (as opposed to reading digital versions). For almost a decade, I read with a Kindle; however a few years ago I transitioned back to using physical books because I felt a stronger spiritual, even sacred, connection to physical books. Reading physical books also seemed more effective in helping me comprehend what I was reading. Research now backs my observations. Recently, a scientific study found that “reading comprehension is reduced when reading from an electronic device.”[670](#footnote-669) 理想情况下，我推荐实体书（而不是阅读数字版本）。近十年来，我一直用 Kindle 阅读；然而几年前，我又开始使用实体书，因为我觉得与实体书有更强烈的精神联系，甚至是神圣联系。阅读实体书似乎也能更有效地帮助我理解所阅读的内容。现在的研究支持我的观察。最近，一项科学研究发现，“通过电子设备阅读时，阅读理解能力会下降。”670

The bibcard method works better with physical books than digital books. You simply place the bibcard in any location at the back of the book. When you finish your reading session, place it where you left off, using the bibcard as a bookmark.bibcard 方法对实体书比数字书更有效。您只需将 bibcard 放在书后的任何位置。当你完成阅读时，把它放在你离开的地方，使用 bibcard 作为书签。

In addition, you’ll want a pen available at the ready. I like to clip the pen onto the back cover of the book. 此外，您需要随时准备一支笔。我喜欢把笔夹在书的封底上。

Here’s how it looks: 这是它的样子：

Inside the book you’ll see the bibcard, which acts as a bookmark, and clipped onto the book’s back cover is a pen. 在书中，您会看到用作书签的 bibcard，夹在书封底上的是一支笔。

I’ve tried a lot of reading setups. A lot of them have pluses and minuses. Certain ones are fine; however, in unusual situations, like while reading in bed or on a sandy beach, they fail miserably. For instance, reading with a Moleskine notebook while lying in bed isn’t something that works for most people. With the bibcard reading method, one can read in bed on their back right before falling asleep and still have everything they need to extract a key idea. 我尝试了很多阅读设置。他们中的很多人都有优点和缺点。有些还好；然而，在不寻常的情况下，比如在床上或沙滩上阅读时，他们会惨败。例如，躺在床上用 Moleskine 笔记本阅读并不适合大多数人。使用 bibcard 阅读方法，一个人可以在入睡前仰卧在床上阅读，并且仍然拥有提取关键思想所需的一切。

Reading outdoors is also more supported by physical books. Luhmann once said, “I like working in the sun.”[671](#footnote-668) For those who like reading outside, this is also a great setup because it requires minimal supplies and isn’t subject to the limitations some screens have when used in bright direct light. 户外阅读也更多地得到实体书的支持。 Luhmann 曾经说过，“我喜欢在阳光下工作。”671 对于那些喜欢在户外阅读的人来说，这也是一个很好的设置，因为它需要最少的耗材，并且不受某些屏幕在明亮的直射光下使用时的限制。

Here’s a photo of Luhmann reading in the sun using this method. Note what looks like a bibcard sticking out of the book. 这是一张卢曼使用这种方法在阳光下阅读的照片。注意看起来像从书里伸出来的 bibcard。

photo credit: Niklas Luhmann—Theory of Society 4_13 by Schwumbel; philomag, “Niklas Luhmann Und Die Aufrichtigkeit,” Philosophie Magazin, accessed April 26, 2022, [https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit](https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit). 照片来源：Niklas Luhmann—Schwumbel 的社会理论 4_13； philomag，“Niklas Luhmann Und Die Aufrichtigkeit”，Philosophie Magazin，2022 年 4 月 26 日访问，https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit。

**Bibnotes 书本笔记**

A bibnote is what Sönke Ahrens refers to as a literature note, even though it doesn’t make sense to call them literature notes (as that indicates the notes are from literature). For several reasons, I prefer the term bibnote. A bibliography is a collection of the works you cite in your research, it’s not just composed of literature. The notes one takes can certainly be from a medium beyond literature. You can take notes from YouTube videos, lectures, podcasts, you name it. Furthermore, it can be argued that readers should not confine themselves to reading only literature. In the words of John Aubrey, a fellow of the Royal Society, “material gathered should not be confined to that offered in books.”[672](#footnote-667)Bibnote 是 Sönke Ahrens 所说的文学笔记，尽管称它们为文学笔记没有意义（因为这表明笔记来自文学）。出于几个原因，我更喜欢 bibnote 这个术语。参考书目是你在研究中引用的作品的集合，它不仅仅是由文学作品组成的。一个人做的笔记当然可以来自文学以外的媒介。您可以从 YouTube 视频、讲座、播客等中做笔记。此外，可以说读者不应将自己局限于阅读文学作品。用皇家学会会员 John Aubrey 的话来说，“收集的材料不应局限于书中提供的材料。”672

Since the notes you take while engaging with your sources emanate from your “bibliography” (your list of references), I like to refer to these notes as bibnotes. 因为你在与你的来源打交道时做的笔记来自你的 “参考书目”（你的参考文献列表），所以我喜欢将这些笔记称为 bibnotes。

Bibnotes are made in bullet-point format. The briefer they are, the better. They begin with a page number in parentheses, and then list out the thought or observation.Bibnotes 以项目符号格式制作。他们越简短越好。他们以括号中的页码开头，然后列出想法或观察结果。

For instance, here’s a bibcard with bibnotes I took while listening to a podcast. 例如，这是一张带有我在听播客时记下的 bibnotes 的 bibcard。

note: I put timestamps of the ideas in parantheses. I placed them after the bibnote; however I now typically place the timestamp or page number on the left-hand side before the bibnote. 注意：我将想法的时间戳记在括号中。我把它们放在 bibnote 之后；但是我现在通常将时间戳或页码放在 bibnote 之前的左侧。

I like to think of the nature of these individual bibnotes as observations. They’re observations that you have as you engage with a source. By source I mean a book, podcast, lecture, YouTube video, etc. 我喜欢将这些个人 bibnotes 的性质视为观察。它们是您与消息来源互动时的观察结果。我所说的来源是指书籍、播客、讲座、YouTube 视频等。

John Locke’s notes were of kindred nature and were referred to as “observation” notes. The scholar, Richard Yeo, refers to them as “short comments connected with books [Locke] was reading.”[673](#footnote-666) 约翰 · 洛克的笔记性质相似，被称为 “观察” 笔记。学者理查德 · 杨 (Richard Yeo) 将它们称为“与 [洛克] 正在阅读的书籍相关的简短评论。”673

Much of the time your bibnotes don’t even have to be a short comment. They can be condensed even more by simply writing a keyterm. 很多时候你的 bibnotes 甚至不必是简短的评论。它们可以通过简单地编写一个关键字来进一步压缩。

As Johannes Schmidt observes, bibnotes are “not simply excerpts,” and that Luhmann “jotted down only a few keywords in the course of his reading along with the respective page numbers.”[674](#footnote-665) 正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 所观察到的，笔记 “不仅仅是摘录”，卢曼 “在阅读过程中只记下了几个关键词以及相应的页码。”674

I do the same by simply writing a page number down, and then the keyterm. I signal it’s a keyterm by underlining it. For instance, see this bibcard: 我通过简单地写下页码，然后写下关键字来做同样的事情。我通过下划线来表示这是一个关键词。例如，请参阅此 bibcard：

The bibnote (27) Zone of Genius signals to me that on page 27, there is material relating to the concept of sticking within your “Zone of Genius.” In other words, sticking with your core competency and focusing on your gifts. Because Zone of Genius is underlined, it indicates that it’s a keyterm pertaining to a core idea, which already has an entry in my index box.bibnote (27) Zone of Genius 向我发出信号，在第 27 页，有一些材料与坚持你的 “Zone of Genius” 的概念有关。换句话说，坚持你的核心竞争力并专注于你的天赋。因为 Zone of Genius 是带下划线的，它表示它是与核心思想相关的关键词，它已经在我的索引框中有一个条目。

Here is a picture of page 27 in The Intellectual Life: 这是《智性生活》第 27 页的图片：

When I thought of the keyterm Zone of Genius, it was in regards to the idea that one should not “aim at what is beyond their powers, and thus run the risk of falling into error, [and of those] who waste their real capacity in order to acquire some capacity that is illusory…”[675](#footnote-664) 当我想到天才地带这个关键词时，它是关于一个人不应该 “瞄准超出他们能力范围的东西，从而冒着犯错误的风险，[以及那些] 浪费他们真正能力的人的想法为了获得一些虚幻的能力……”675

In this instance, I didn’t have immediately relevant use for this idea, and therefore I didn’t develop a maincard for it. Instead, I created an ExRef. Here’s a picture of it in the area of my Antinet pertaining to Zone of Genius. Within this area there’s a card of Zone-of-Genius-related ExRefs: 在这种情况下，我并没有直接使用这个想法，因此我没有为它开发主卡。相反，我创建了一个 ExRef。这是我的 Antinet 区域中关于天才地带的一张图片。在这个区域内，有一张与 Zone-of-Genius 相关的 ExRefs 卡片：

The concept of Zone of Genius is important to me; yet I decided it’s not immediately applicable to my current project—that project being the book you’re reading right now. I mean, Zone of Genius technically could be relevant to this book, and I could dedicate a section of the book to it (which I guess, indirectly I’m kind of doing right now). However, you have to draw a line in the sand and focus on the most pertinent material for your task at hand. And right now, we have our hands full enough with the material covered in this book. Simply creating an ExRef allows me to delay processing until I have use for it (which will probably be for a future project).Zone of Genius 的概念对我很重要；但我认为它不能立即适用于我当前的项目——那个项目就是你现在正在阅读的书。我的意思是，从技术上讲，《天才地带》可能与本书相关，我可以用本书的一部分专门介绍它（我想，我现在正在间接地这样做）。但是，您必须谨慎行事，并专注于与您手头的任务最相关的材料。现在，我们已经忙于处理本书中涵盖的材料。简单地创建一个 ExRef 允许我延迟处理，直到我使用它（这可能用于未来的项目）。

This gives you a glimpse into one of my bibcards. Let’s now turn our attention to one of Luhmann’s bibcards: 这使您可以瞥见我的一张 bibcards。现在让我们把注意力转向卢曼的一张名片：

I enlisted the help of the Antinet’s Reddit community to help translate this card.[676](#footnote-663) Luckily, a community member answered the call and provided a translation despite the fact that Luhmann’s handwriting has been called abysmally bad and hideous.[677](#footnote-662) As such, some of the bibnotes are completely indecipherable (designated by […]). Here is the translation: 我寻求 Antinet 的 Reddit 社区的帮助来帮助翻译这张卡片。676 幸运的是，一位社区成员接听了电话并提供了翻译，尽管卢曼的笔迹被称为非常糟糕和丑陋。677 因此，一些 bibnotes 完全无法辨认（由 […] 指定）。这是翻译：

V1. No specific metaphysical theory is necessary. But from this follows not, that no metaphysical theory is necessaryV1。不需要具体的形而上学理论。但由此得出的结论是，不需要任何形而上学理论

1 Ambiguity of the concept or reality1 概念或现实的模糊性

2 reality as function of expectedness [Original in English]2 现实作为预期的函数 [原文为英文]

51 nothing-universe / everything universe, ours somewhere in between […] depends on, that we all must take note of […] 51 无宇宙 / 万物宇宙，我们的宇宙介于两者之间 [...] 取决于，我们都必须注意 [...]

6 Observations as parallel runs[…] between observer & observed [Original in English]6 观察作为平行运行 […] observer & observed [英文原文]

7 The faster we change, the more we can notice [Original in English]7 我们改变得越快，就越能注意到 [英文原文]

10 inferred[…] scientist / historian [Original in English]10 推断 […] 科学家 / 历史学家 [原文为英文]

20 Induction: evaluable for legal argumentation (if the result doesn’t satisfy, one changes the premises)20 归纳法：可用于法律论证（如果结果不满足，则改变前提）

23 Error as […] Coping […]23 错误作为 [...] 应对 [...]

25 Induction as slow operation25 慢速感应

26 W[…] als sec[…] […] prädikas […]26 W[…] als sec[…] […] prädikas […]

27 Paradox of the liar [Original in English]27 说谎者的悖论【英文原文】

31 Observation as primitive concept of science [Original in English]31 观察作为科学的原始概念 [原文为英文]

35 randomness [Original in English]35 随机数【英文原文】

40 Chance is definitively compatible with causality [Underlined]40 偶然性与因果性绝对相容 [下划线]

44 Chance: not connection to [or: relation with] other events44 Chance: not connection to [or: relation with] 其他事件

46 randomness [Original in English]46 随机数【英文原文】

65 The Experimental paradox 107p [Original in English]65 实验悖论 107p [英文原文]

There are several patterns we can glean from this translation. First, note how Luhmann simply jotted down keyterms like randomness. Second, he also wrote down terms in the following way {keyterm} as {supporting context}. In essence, Luhmann stated the keyterm first, and then inserted the phrase as. After as Luhmann would provide a snippet of detail that would contextualize the keyterm. For instance, we see the phrase reality as function of expectedness. This method of creating bibnotes stands as both a way of thinking and a practice one should experiment with. It results in building knowledge around the keyterm (not around the supporting context, which sits in a subordinate position to the main idea of the keyterm). 我们可以从这个翻译中收集到几种模式。首先，请注意卢曼是如何简单地记下随机性等关键词的。其次，他还用以下方式写下术语 {keyterm} 作为 {supporting context}。本质上，卢曼首先陈述了关键词，然后插入了短语 as。之后，Luhmann 会提供一段细节，将关键词语境化。例如，我们将现实这个短语视为预期的函数。这种创建 bibnotes 的方法既是一种思维方式，也是一种应该尝试的实践。它导致围绕关键术语构建知识（而不是围绕支持上下文，它位于关键术语主要思想的从属位置）。

**The Bib Box 围兜箱**

Luhmann’s bibliography box (aka, the bib box) was a critical component of his Antinet. The cards in this section show Luhmann’s thoughts before they were processed fully into main notes. Luhmann’s second Antinet contained 67,000 cards, with 15,000 (roughly 22%) of them bibcards. Luhmann 的参考书目框（又名围兜框）是他的 Antinet 的重要组成部分。本节中的卡片显示了卢曼在完全处理成主要笔记之前的想法。 Luhmann 的第二个 Antinet 包含 67,000 张卡片，其中 15,000 张（大约 22%）是 bibcards。

Given how large a portion of Luhmann’s second Antinet was devoted to bibcards, you would think these would be outlined in Sönke Ahrens’s book How to Take Smart Notes. Yet this component of Luhmann’s system is almost completely omitted in Ahrens’s tutorial. His instructions for how to create this critical component of the Antinet is basically: “I strongly recommend using a free program like Zotero.”[678](#footnote-661) 考虑到 Luhmann 的第二个 Antinet 有很大一部分专门用于 bibcards，你会认为这些会在 Sönke Ahrens 的书如何做智能笔记中概述。然而，阿伦斯的教程几乎完全省略了卢曼系统的这一组成部分。他对如何创建 Antinet 的这个关键组件的说明基本上是：“我强烈建议使用像 Zotero 这样的免费程序。”678

The bib box stores your bibcards in alphabetical order. It’s where you place your bibcards after you finish the book. 围兜箱按字母顺序存储您的围兜卡。这是您读完本书后放置卡片的地方。

**One Reads Differently with an Antinet 一个人用 Antinet 阅读不同**
-----------------------------------------------------------

Written on a card in Luhmann’s own Antinet we find a card on how one “reads differently” when using an Antinet.[679](#footnote-660) Johannes Schmidt notes that Luhmann read “with an eye to the notes already contained in his file.”[680](#footnote-659) 在卢曼自己的 Antinet 的一张卡片上，我们发现了一张卡片，上面写着一个人在使用 Antinet 时如何 “阅读不同”。679 约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 指出，卢曼阅读时 “着眼于他的文件中已经包含的注释。”680

This phenomenon is something other scholars have confirmed: “it is indisputable that in books [he read], Luhmann searched for information or ideas that could be linked to the content of his own card index.”[681](#footnote-658) 这种现象已被其他学者证实：“无可争辩的是，卢曼在 [他读过的] 书中寻找可以与他自己的卡片索引内容相关联的信息或想法。”681

With enough practice with an Antinet, there is a phase transition that occurs whereby you begin to read in such a way that you no longer get “bogged down” by writing out full-excerpts.[682](#footnote-657) 对 Antinet 进行足够多的练习后，会发生一个阶段性转变，你开始以这样一种方式阅读，不再因写出完整的摘录而 “陷入困境”。 682

If we look at Luhmann’s second Antinet and its 15,000 bibcards, most of which referenced books, we can make some calculations (without accounting for titles which span multiple bibcards, which indeed occurred, but not too frequently). Luhmann worked with his second Antinet from roughly 1963 to 1997, which comes out to thirty four years. We can make some calculations (without accounting for titles which span multiple bibcards, which indeed occurred, but wasn’t too frequent). If we divide 15,000 bibcards by thirty four years, this gives us 441 titles per year; 37 titles per month; or roughly one title per day. 如果我们看一下 Luhmann 的第二个 Antinet 和它的 15,000 个 bibcards，其中大部分是参考书，我们可以做一些计算（不考虑跨越多个 bibcards 的标题，这确实发生过，但不是太频繁）。大约从 1963 年到 1997 年，卢曼与他的第二个 Antinet 一起工作，总共有 34 年。我们可以进行一些计算（不考虑跨越多个 bibcards 的标题，这种情况确实发生过，但不是太频繁）。如果我们将 15,000 个 bibcards 除以 34 年，则每年有 441 个标题；每月 37 个标题；或者每天大约一个标题。

In other words, on average Luhmann read roughly one book or journal article per day… for thirty four years. 换句话说，卢曼平均每天大约阅读一本书或一篇期刊文章…… 三十四年。

There’s no way to do this by reading the way normal people read (slowly, sounding out every word in their head). The nature in which Luhmann read was selective. I call it selective reading. You ingest books at a phenomenal rate, like a reading machine, thanks to the priming step we covered in the previous chapter. I suggest this is a hybrid between skimming and reading every sentence. Instead of reading every word, you read every paragraph of the book. You don’t try to comprehend each individual word, or each sentence even. Your goal is to comprehend the paragraph quickly, and move on. When you spot an intriguing idea you slow down. At that point your brain undertakes a communication experience in order to draw up concepts from your Antinet. You then run the new material through a filter: is this idea bad, good, excellent, or irresistible? If it’s irresistible, you extract it onto your bibcard. 没有办法通过阅读正常人的阅读方式来做到这一点（慢慢地，读出他们脑海中的每个单词）。卢曼阅读的本质是有选择性的。我称之为选择性阅读。得益于我们在上一章介绍的启动步骤，您可以像阅读机一样以惊人的速度摄取书籍。我建议这是略读和阅读每个句子的混合体。您不是阅读每个单词，而是阅读本书的每个段落。你不要试图理解每个单词，甚至每个句子。你的目标是快速理解段落，然后继续。当你发现一个有趣的想法时，你会放慢速度。那时你的大脑进行交流体验，以便从你的 Antinet 中提取概念。然后你通过过滤器运行新材料：这个想法是坏的、好的、优秀的还是不可抗拒的？如果无法抗拒，就把它提取到你的 bibcard 上。

As Mortimer Adler advises, reading should not be thought of as a passive activity.[683](#footnote-656) It’s an active process. When employing the bibcard extraction method it’s an even faster, more alert process. 正如 Mortimer Adler 建议的那样，不应将阅读视为一种被动活动。683 这是一个主动过程。当使用 bibcard 提取方法时，它是一个更快、更警觉的过程。

**Slowly Chewing on Books 慢慢咀嚼书本**

There will be books that are worth chewing on (reading them slowly and deliberately). Typically, these will be the books you read when you’re in exploratory mode; when you have yet to develop a rough skeleton to serve as the foundation of your project. In this mode, you ought to employ the book-to-maincard method. You also must shift your mindset. You must slow down your thinking and not worry about processing books efficiently. 会有值得细嚼慢咽的书（慢慢地、有意识地读）。通常，这些是您处于探索模式时阅读的书籍；当你还没有形成一个粗略的骨架来作为你项目的基础时。在这种模式下，您应该使用从书到主卡的方法。你还必须转变你的心态。你必须放慢你的思维，不要担心高效地处理书籍。

In this mode you ought to adopt the advice of people like David Deutsch, a great copywriter. Deutsch famously emphasized that it was better to read one great book ten times, instead of ten good books one time.[684](#footnote-655) In this mode you should opt to be well-read, not widely read. As Mortimer Adler puts it: 在这种模式下，您应该采纳伟大的撰稿人 David Deutsch 等人的建议。 Deutsch 有一句名言：最好将一本好书读十遍，而不是一次读十本好书。684 在这种模式下，您应该选择博览群书，而不是广泛阅读。正如莫蒂默阿德勒所说：

There have always been literate ignoramuses who have read too widely and not well. The Greeks had a name for such a mixture of learning and folly which might be applied to the bookish but poorly read of all ages. They are all sophomores.[685](#footnote-654) 总是有识字的无知者，他们阅读的范围太广，但阅读的并不好。希腊人给这种学问和愚蠢的混合体取了一个名字，这个名字可以用在所有年龄段的书呆子但不识字的人身上。他们都是二年级学生。 685

**Syntopical Reading 主题阅读**

If you already have a base-level structure for what you’re working on, then it’s safer to adopt swifter extraction methods. There are certain books that are so dense, widely-cited, and profound that you just know they deserve a slower read. And there are certain books that are suited for swift selective reading. 如果您已经为正在处理的内容建立了基本结构，那么采用更快速的提取方法会更安全。有些书内容丰富、被广泛引用且意义深远，你只知道它们值得慢慢阅读。还有一些书适合快速选择性阅读。

One of the more enjoyable ways to partake in selective reading is to employ a process called syntopical reading.[686](#footnote-653) With syntopical reading, you read several books on the same subject, at the same time. This is something Luhmann did, as well. In a short piece Luhmann wrote on reading, he states: “Another possibility is to read texts [across] certain topics.”[687](#footnote-652) 参与选择性阅读的一种更有趣的方式是采用称为主题阅读的过程。686 通过主题阅读，您可以同时阅读几本关于同一主题的书。这也是卢曼所做的。在一篇关于阅读的短文中，卢曼写道：“另一种可能性是阅读 [跨] 特定主题的文本。”687

In order to read syntopically, Luhmann writes, “You have to be able to read highly selectively and pull out widely interconnected references.”[688](#footnote-651) Basically you must train your mind to spot certain patterns. This is something neuroimprinting keyterms on your mind helps with (by way of the index). 为了按主题阅读，卢曼写道，“你必须能够高度选择性地阅读并提取广泛相互关联的参考文献。”688 基本上你必须训练你的思维来发现某些模式。这是你脑海中的神经印记关键词帮助的东西（通过索引）。

Here, Luhmann’s referring to storing ideas in long-term memory in the Antinet, such that they evolve and you do not waste your time relearning what you already know. 在这里，Luhmann 指的是将想法存储在 Antinet 的长期记忆中，这样它们就会进化，你就不会浪费时间重新学习你已经知道的东西。

According to Luhmann, the key to reading scientific texts revolves around this act. You must read selectively, and not waste time relearning what you already know. The key piece in this process relates to long-term memory and the necessity to distinguish the “essential from the non-essential and the new from the merely repetitive.”[689](#footnote-650) In other words, you want a system where you can refresh your recollection of your notes and evolve your current ideas with new ideas; you don’t want to waste time relearning things you already know. 根据卢曼的说法，阅读科学文本的关键在于这一行为。你必须有选择地阅读，而不是浪费时间重新学习你已经知道的东西。这个过程中的关键部分与长期记忆以及区分 “基本与非基本、新事物与仅仅重复的事物” 的必要性有关。689 换句话说，您需要一个可以刷新您的记忆的系统您的笔记并用新想法发展您当前的想法；你不想浪费时间重新学习你已经知道的东西。

I like to do this in the following manner: I carve out two hours of back-to-back reading. For the first hour I read one book within one topic. In the next hour I read a different book within that same topic. For example, several years ago I read two books predicting what the future would look like and the technologies that would shape it. The first book I read was The Industries of the Future; the book I read was The Inevitable. By reading syntopically, I spotted interesting patterns—things that they both agreed upon and the contradictions between them. In addition, I noticed that each of them omitted something which served as an important piece of the other’s book. 我喜欢以下列方式做到这一点：我抽出两个小时的背靠背阅读。第一个小时，我读了一个主题的一本书。在接下来的一个小时里，我读了同一主题的另一本书。例如，几年前我读了两本书，预测未来会是什么样子以及塑造未来的技术。我读的第一本书是《未来的产业》。我读的书是不可避免的。通过主题阅读，我发现了有趣的模式——他们都同意的事情以及他们之间的矛盾。此外，我注意到他们每个人都遗漏了一些对对方的书来说很重要的东西。

Again, reading this way usually comes after the exploratory phase. It comes after you’ve gained a sense for what you actually wish to create. However, when you’re ready for this type of reading style, the bibcard extraction method, as well as the Antinet as a whole, takes the experience to a whole new level. 同样，这种阅读方式通常发生在探索阶段之后。它出现在你对你真正想要创造的东西有了感觉之后。然而，当您准备好接受这种类型的阅读风格时，bibcard 提取方法以及整个 Antinet 会将体验提升到一个全新的水平。

In brief, you’ll read differently with an Antinet because you’ve been training and exercising your neuro-associative recall muscle. You see, even before reading the first page of a book, you’ll have primed your mind to detect certain keyterms and ideas by way of creating index entries of keyterms. The Antinet, with its neuroimprinting process of writing by hand, develops your neuro-associative recall ability. When reading, you’ll find yourself thinking of keyterms in your index. This is hugely beneficial because it saves you time. You can simply jot keyterms down on a bibcard, instead of having to write out lengthier notes. 简而言之，你会用 Antinet 阅读不同的内容，因为你一直在训练和锻炼你的神经联想回忆肌肉。你看，甚至在阅读一本书的第一页之前，你就已经准备好通过创建关键术语的索引条目来检测某些关键术语和想法。 Antinet 具有手写的神经印记过程，可培养您的神经联想回忆能力。阅读时，您会发现自己会想到索引中的关键词。这非常有益，因为它可以节省您的时间。你可以简单地在 bibcard 上记下关键词，而不必写出更长的笔记。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

Now you have an idea for the process of extracting material from the sources you engage with. We outlined several strategies (the best one being the 2-step bibcard method). We now turn to the next critical phase of knowledge development: Creation. 现在您对从您接触的资源中提取材料的过程有了一个想法。我们概述了几种策略（最好的一种是两步 bibcard 方法）。我们现在转向知识发展的下一个关键阶段：创造。

CHAPTER FIFTEEN 第十五章
--------------------

Creation 创建
-----------

The creation phase of knowledge development is where the magic really starts to happen. In this phase you begin adding your own meaning to the information you extract from the sources you choose to communicate with. In this phase, you begin injecting your own personality into the information. As a result, you create knowledge with your own unique perspective with the potential of making an impact on the world. 知识发展的创造阶段是魔法真正开始发生的地方。在这个阶段，您开始将自己的含义添加到从您选择与之通信的来源中提取的信息中。在这个阶段，您开始将自己的个性注入信息中。因此，您可以用自己独特的视角创造知识，并有可能对世界产生影响。

We’re going to survey a large swath of material in this section. The best place to start is exploring the nature of notes. 我们将在本节中调查大量材料。最好的起点是探索音符的本质。

**The Nature of the Notes 票据的性质**
---------------------------------

What are notes? I think there are several ways to answer this question. One helpful way to understand the nature of notes is to use some metaphors. In this section I’ll present three illustrations: (1) notes as thoughts, (2) notes as leaves, and (3) notes as neurons. 什么是笔记？我认为有几种方法可以回答这个问题。理解音符本质的一种有用方法是使用一些比喻。在本节中，我将展示三个示例：(1) 笔记作为思想，(2) 笔记作为树叶，以及 (3) 笔记作为神经元。

**Notes as Thoughts 笔记作为想法**

At this point it’s helpful to refresh our memory of what a thought actually is. 在这一点上，刷新我们对思想实际是什么的记忆是有帮助的。

A thought is a metaphysical representation of reality. This reality can be external reality (such as things you see), or internal reality (such as your internal experience, intuition or feelings). The reality can be true in nature or true in fiction (as Hemingway emphasized, each novelist should write the truth). A thought is also shaped by several dimensions, which are represented in the following diagram: 思想是现实的形而上学表征。这种现实可以是外在的现实（比如你看到的东西），也可以是内在的现实（比如你的内心体验、直觉或感受）。现实可以是真实的，也可以是小说中的真实（正如海明威强调的，每个小说家都应该写出真实）。思想也由几个维度塑造，如下图所示：

A thought is shaped by one’s self. You have your own concept of a self (ego, persona or identity). You think of yourself in a certain way that shapes your thoughts. Your experiences, stories, trials, tribulations, and past serve as a background context for your self. Your self shapes your thoughts. Your self also embodies the unique ways your brain works based on its biochemical arrangement. Based on your DNA, based on how you’re wired. 思想是由一个人的自我塑造的。你有自己的自我概念（自我、角色或身份）。您以某种方式思考自己，从而塑造您的想法。你的经历、故事、考验、磨难和过去是你自己的背景。你的自我塑造了你的想法。你的自我也体现了你的大脑基于其生化排列的独特工作方式。基于你的 DNA，基于你的连接方式。

A thought is also shaped by space: where you are in space, your latitude, longitude, and altitude. You’ve heard the phrase, you are your environment. It’s really: your thoughts are your environment—or at least, your thoughts are shaped by your environment. Your thoughts would be different if you lived in Bangladesh (assuming you’re not already living in Bangladesh). In brief, where you reside right now in space shapes your thoughts. 思想也受到空间的影响：你在空间中的位置、你的纬度、经度和高度。你听过这句话，你就是你的环境。确实如此：你的思想就是你的环境——或者至少，你的思想是由你的环境塑造的。如果您住在孟加拉国（假设您尚未居住在孟加拉国），您的想法就会有所不同。简而言之，您现在在太空中所处的位置会影响您的想法。

A thought is also shaped by time. How you think of something today is drastically different from how you’d have thought of it ten years prior. It’s also drastically different from how you’ll think of the same thing ten years from now. We’re always changing, and our thoughts change with us. Yet it’s not only our selves changing that shapes thoughts. It’s also the world around us. The thoughts you have today would be drastically different if you were suddenly transported two thousand years into the past or future—even if you were to remain the same age, in the same physical body, and at the same physical location. Your own place in time, as well as your own world’s place in time, has a significant impact on which thoughts you experience. 思想也是由时间塑造的。你今天对某事的看法与你十年前的看法截然不同。这也与你十年后对同一件事的看法截然不同。我们总是在变化，我们的想法也会随着我们而变化。然而，塑造思想的不仅仅是我们自己的改变。这也是我们周围的世界。如果你突然穿越到过去或未来 2000 年，你今天的想法会截然不同——即使你保持相同的年龄、相同的身体和相同的物理位置。你自己的时间位置，以及你自己的世界的时间位置，对你体验到哪些想法有重大影响。

A thought is also shaped by memory (or reverberation). This is closely related to the concept of self, but it’s more specific. It’s related to our short-term concept of self. We have a memory that fades over time. Our recent actions and things we’ve read—say in the past month—are still reverberating through our minds. Our recent behavior, our recent purchases, the books, TV shows and movies we’ve seen recently shape our thoughts. After some point, however, these memories fade. Every single day we enter a new state wherein some thoughts will arise, and other thoughts simply will not. This is shaped by our memory which is almost like a rolling wave of reverberation. 思想也由记忆（或混响）塑造。这与自我的概念密切相关，但更具体。这与我们短期的自我概念有关。我们的记忆会随着时间的流逝而消失。我们最近的行为和我们读到的东西——比如说在过去一个月里——仍然在我们的脑海中回荡。我们最近的行为、我们最近的购买、我们最近看过的书籍、电视节目和电影都会影响我们的想法。然而，过了某个时间点，这些记忆就会消失。每一天我们都会进入一个新的状态，其中一些想法会出现，而另一些想法根本不会出现。这是由我们的记忆塑造的，它几乎就像一个滚动的回响波。

A thought is also shaped by content. The current content that has our attention and what we’re consuming shapes our thoughts. The TV show you’re watching or book you’re reading shapes thoughts. While you’re ingesting the sources of content, you’re relating the concepts to what you already know. You’re trying to comprehend the concepts and either accepting or rejecting them. When you’re consuming content, you’re selecting which information resonates with you. After reading this book, you’re hopefully learning to select only irresistible material. As you continue with your Antinet, whenever you engage with content, you’re writing down your observational thoughts (onto bibcards). 思想也由内容塑造。当前引起我们注意的内容和我们正在消费的内容会影响我们的想法。您正在观看的电视节目或正在阅读的书会影响您的想法。当您摄取内容来源时，您会将这些概念与您已经知道的联系起来。您正在尝试理解这些概念并接受或拒绝它们。当您消费内容时，您正在选择哪些信息会引起您的共鸣。读完本书后，您有望学会只选择不可抗拒的材料。当您继续使用 Antinet 时，无论何时与内容互动，您都在写下您的观察想法（到 bibcards 上）。

All of these dimensions (self, space, time, memory, content) shape the phenomena that is a thought. The thoughts can be voluntary or involuntary. Regardless, the metaphysical phenomenon that is a thought is then the raw unit captured and immortalized by way of being written down on paper in the form of a notecard. A note, then, is essentially a container of thought. Or, more succinctly, a thought container. 所有这些维度（自我、空间、时间、记忆、内容）塑造了思想的现象。这些想法可以是自愿的，也可以是非自愿的。无论如何，作为思想的形而上学现象是原始单位，通过以记事卡的形式写在纸上而被捕获和永生。那么，笔记本质上是思想的容器。或者，更简洁地说，一个思想容器。

**Thought Containers 思想容器**

I think it’s helpful to think of notes as a mechanism, or a container of thought. The scholar, Markus Krajewski, likens notes to “Denk-zettel,” which is a German term translating roughly to “thought-notes.”[690](#footnote-751) These are the “units” that stand as the raw material of the Antinet. 我认为将笔记视为一种机制或思想的容器是有帮助的。学者 Markus Krajewski 将笔记比作 “Denk-zettel”，这是一个德语术语，大致翻译为 “思想笔记”。690 这些是作为 Antinet 原材料的 “单位”。

There are four components of notes as thought containers. First, notes are containers that develop one’s short-term thoughts. They are a mechanism for thought that enables one to reflect and actually instantiate the phenomenon going on internally in one’s mind. 作为思想容器的笔记有四个组成部分。首先，笔记是培养短期思想的容器。它们是一种思维机制，可以让一个人反思并实际实例化一个人内心深处发生的现象。

Second, notes are containers for developing one’s long-term thoughts. If structured properly, notes can serve as a container to collect and evolve thoughts over the long term. This is thanks to the nested tree structure of the Antinet. 其次，笔记是培养一个人长远思想的容器。如果结构合理，笔记可以作为长期收集和发展思想的容器。这要归功于 Antinet 的嵌套树结构。

Third, notes serve as prompts to help the mind recollect knowledge.[691](#footnote-750) In digital Zettelkasten systems, many people have a tendency to view notes as an all-encompassing document. In digital systems, users regularly tend to their notes, constantly updating and deleting text. Yet truly powerful note systems are not like this. They simply serve as a cue or a prompt to trigger neurons in your brain to fire and connect. As a result you end up grasping an idea that is often incommunicable. You then use your manuscript or project to make the incommunicable knowledge lucid and clear. The notes within the Antinet are a means to the end (the end being your creative output). This is something that will continually arise throughout this section. 第三，笔记作为帮助大脑回忆知识的提示。691 在数字 Zettelkasten 系统中，许多人倾向于将笔记视为包罗万象的文档。在数字系统中，用户会定期查看他们的笔记，不断更新和删除文本。然而真正强大的音符系统并不是这样的。它们只是作为提示或提示来触发大脑中的神经元激发和连接。结果，您最终掌握了一个通常无法传达的想法。然后，您可以使用您的手稿或项目使不可传达的知识清晰明了。 Antinet 中的注释是达到目的的一种手段（目的是您的创意输出）。这将在本节中不断出现。

Fourth, notes are a container encompassing different types of thoughts. As one scholar puts it, notes are “free-floating staging posts of thought, which record all manner of remarkable things, excerpts and quotes in the permanence of script.”[692](#footnote-749) Notes serve as a container for observing what the material you’re reading relates to. Notes serve as a container for thoughts which encapsulate what an author is saying (excerpt notes), as a container for learning material by summarizing concepts in your own words (reformulation notes), and as a container for reflecting on what material means to you, particularly within the context of a current project you’re working on. 第四，笔记是一个包含不同类型思想的容器。正如一位学者所说，笔记是 “思想的自由漂浮的临时驿站，它记录了各种非凡的事情、摘录和永久性的引述。”692 笔记是观察你正在阅读的材料的容器涉及到。笔记作为思想的容器，封装了作者所说的内容（摘录笔记），作为通过用自己的话总结概念的学习材料的容器（重新表述笔记），以及作为反思材料对你意味着什么的容器，特别是在您正在从事的当前项目的背景下。

**Notes as Memories 作为回忆的笔记**

Given that a note can be thought of as a thought (pun intended), it can also be thought of as a memory. Why? Because a memory is a stored representation of a thought. 鉴于一个音符可以被认为是一种思想（双关语意），它也可以被认为是一种记忆。为什么？因为记忆是思想的存储表示。

Think of a note as a thought, an abstraction, and as a memory. The problem with digital notes is that they are unidimensional rather than multidimensional. They are virtual; they live in a man-made dimension. Physical thoughts present in space and time have more dimensionality than purely metaphysical systems. This is something digital will have to overcome if it wishes to have the potency of analog knowledge systems. 将音符视为思想、抽象和记忆。数字笔记的问题在于它们是一维的而不是多维的。它们是虚拟的；他们生活在人造维度中。存在于空间和时间中的物理思想比纯粹的形而上学系统具有更多的维度。如果数字化希望拥有模拟知识系统的潜力，这是它必须克服的问题。

A thought gets stored and represented as a memory. It’s therefore important to note—again, pun intended—that how human memory works is not unidimensional. Rather, human memory is like a matrix. A memory is a combination of multiple attributes and contexts. A well-developed hypothesis posits that individual memories are distributed over multiple attributes, features, elements, or dimensions.[693](#footnote-748) 一个想法被存储并表示为记忆。因此，重要的是要注意——再一次，双关语——人类记忆的工作方式不是一维的。相反，人类的记忆就像一个矩阵。记忆是多个属性和上下文的组合。一个完善的假设假设个人记忆分布在多个属性、特征、元素或维度上。 693

Let’s translate this into something practical: the notecard that I’ve written on the topic of love is easy to spot. Why? Because I decided to write it on an actual leaf! 让我们将其转化为实际的东西：我写的关于爱情主题的记事卡很容易被发现。为什么？因为我决定把它写在一张真正的叶子上！

The words on the leaf are the lyrics of All You Need Is Love by the Beatles. 叶子上的文字是甲壳虫乐队的《All You Need Is Love》的歌词。

This is an example of the multi-dimensionality of notes. 这是笔记多维性的一个例子。

You see, early on into a relationship with my now fiancé, I asked her to pick out a leaf for me when she was with our daughter on a hike. This card is packed not only with intriguing features, but with an entire background story as well. The character of this note is also represented by the style of my handwriting, as well as its content. 你看，在与我现在的未婚夫建立关系的早期，当她和我们的女儿一起远足时，我让她为我挑选一片叶子。这张卡片不仅包含有趣的功能，还包含完整的背景故事。这篇笔记的特点也体现在我的笔迹风格和内容上。

Human memories function much like this. They are multidimensional objects and not merely digital texts or even digital pictures or diagrams. 人类记忆的功能与此非常相似。它们是多维对象，而不仅仅是数字文本，甚至是数字图片或图表。

**The Antinet as a Perfect System of Thought 反网络作为一个完美的思想体系**

The Antinet is constructed in a way that emphasizes the two laws that govern thought. The concept that thought is governed by two laws derives from British philosophers John Locke, David Hume, George Berkeley, David Hartley and John Stuart Mill who suggested that thoughts are governed by two components. [694](#footnote-747)Antinet 的构建方式强调支配思想的两条法则。思想受两个定律支配的概念源自英国哲学家约翰 · 洛克、大卫 · 休谟、乔治 · 伯克利、大卫 · 哈特利和约翰 · 斯图尔特 · 穆勒，他们认为思想受两个组成部分支配。 694

1. Contiguity: the notion that ideas that are frequently experienced together become closely associated in one’s mind. In the Antinet, the sequence of notes results in closely associated streams of thoughts. These streams of thought are thereby organized closely together in a sequence. This is made possible by the numeric-alpha card addresses and tree structure.1. 邻近性：经常一起经历的想法在一个人的脑海中变得紧密相关的概念。在 Antinet 中，音符的顺序导致了紧密相关的思想流。这些思想流因此按顺序紧密地组织在一起。这是通过数字字母卡地址和树结构实现的。

2. Similarity (resemblance): when two ideas are similar, whatever has been closely associated with the first idea (thereby starting the flow of thought) automatically also becomes associated with the following thoughts. The following thoughts are those that then branch downward from the initial thought.2. 相似性（相似性）：当两个想法相似时，与第一个想法密切相关（从而开始思想流动）的任何东西也会自动与以下想法相关联。以下想法是从最初的想法向下分支的想法。

**Notes as Leaves 作为叶子的笔记**

Another helpful metaphor is to think of notes as leaves. The tree metaphor for the Antinet serves as a perfect illustration due to its branching nature. A core component of this metaphor is the leaves on a tree. 另一个有用的比喻是把笔记想象成树叶。 Antinet 的树比喻由于其分支性质而成为一个完美的例证。这个比喻的核心组成部分是树上的叶子。

The leaves on a tree are (relatively) uniform, yet there’s variation between leaves, as well. Some leaves are withered, some have holes in them, and some grow old and dry up. This also happens with notes in the Antinet. Some have holes of logic in them, and some grow old because they’re unlinked. 树上的叶子（相对）一致，但叶子之间也存在差异。树叶有的枯萎了，有的破了洞，有的老了干涸了。 Antinet 中的注释也会发生这种情况。有些里面有逻辑漏洞，有些因为没有联系而变老。

In addition to this, a note-as-a-leaf cannot be simply encapsulated by a short, condensed title. You must view the entire leaf to understand it. When viewing a notecard, you must view the note in its entirety to understand it. On the other hand, with digital notetaking apps, one is forced to squeeze the material of each note into a brief title. This dilutes the material found in the note. For instance, a note that contains profound ideas on the concept of a thought is titled Definition of a Thought. However, this is not the nature of particular leaves. There’s no title for each leaf. To understand the nature of any given leaf you must view the entirety of the leaf. This is the same for notes. 除此之外，笔记不能简单地用简短的标题来概括。您必须查看整片叶子才能理解它。查看记事卡时，您必须完整查看记事才能理解它。另一方面，使用数字笔记应用程序，人们被迫将每条笔记的材料压缩成一个简短的标题。这会稀释纸币中的材料。例如，包含关于思想概念的深刻思想的笔记标题为 “思想的定义”。然而，这不是特定叶子的性质。每片叶子都没有标题。要了解任何给定叶子的性质，您必须查看整个叶子。这对于笔记也是一样的。

The practical lesson is this: Do not weaken your notes by assigning a human-readable title to them. Respect your thoughts by having the thought contain itself (instead of being contained in a catchy title). 实际的教训是：不要通过给笔记分配一个人类可读的标题来削弱你的笔记。通过让思想包含自己（而不是包含在一个朗朗上口的标题中）来尊重你的想法。

**Notes as Neurons 作为神经元的笔记**

Another way to think of notes is to liken them to neurons in the human brain. 另一种理解笔记的方法是将它们比作人脑中的神经元。

As I detail in a later section on human memory, the neural networks we think of today as legitimate are, in reality, merely artificial abstractions, with the result being that the models researchers use to study human memory “bear only a faint resemblance to real biological neurons: they are highly simplified computational ‘units’ that integrate and transmit information.”[695](#footnote-746) This description seems to perfectly encapsulate what a note is. Most of what people think of when they hear the term neural network isn’t actually a real thing—it’s artificial. It’s an abstraction. Yet this abstraction nonetheless made it a very useful system in the real world. The same holds true for the Antinet. 正如我在后面关于人类记忆的章节中详述的那样，我们今天认为合理的神经网络实际上只是人为的抽象，结果是研究人员用来研究人类记忆的模型 “与真实的记忆只有微弱的相似之处” 生物神经元：它们是高度简化的计算“单元”，可以整合和传输信息。”695 这种描述似乎完美地概括了音符是什么。当人们听到神经网络这个术语时，他们想到的大部分内容实际上并不是真实的东西——它是人造的。这是一个抽象。然而，这种抽象仍然使它成为现实世界中非常有用的系统。 Antinet 也是如此。

Neurons are the perfect stand-in for the concept of notes. Notes fit the definition of “highly simplified computational ‘units’ that integrate and transmit information,” which is one reason why the Antinet works so well—or at least better than information stored in silos of commonplace books. 神经元是音符概念的完美替代品。笔记符合 “集成和传输信息的高度简化的计算‘单元’” 的定义，这也是 Antinet 运行良好的原因之一——或者至少比存储在普通书籍中的信息更好。

Niklas Luhmann was familiar with how human memory worked and also deliberate in his design of the Antinet. It’s no coincidence that he built his system based on the idea of connections (inspired by connections of neurons in the human brain). 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 熟悉人类记忆的工作原理，并且在他设计 Antinet 时也深思熟虑。他基于连接的想法（受人脑神经元连接的启发）构建了自己的系统，这并非巧合。

Luhmann pointed out how human memory does not function as a sum of point-by-point access locations (such as sequentially moving through notes).[696](#footnote-745) Rather your brain utilizes internal links and connections. It’s helpful when thinking about a note to view it as a raw unit, as a neuron. The neuron gains its value when it is connected to other notes by way of installing the note under or behind its most similar idea. The neuron is further enriched by connecting to other neurons in your tree of knowledge. This is done by creating remotelinks to other cards on more distant branches of your Antinet.Luhmann 指出人类记忆如何不能作为逐点访问位置的总和（例如按顺序移动笔记）。696 相反，您的大脑利用内部链接和连接。在思考一个音符时，将其视为一个原始单元、一个神经元会很有帮助。当神经元通过将音符安装在其最相似想法的下方或后面而连接到其他音符时，它就会获得其价值。通过连接到知识树中的其他神经元，神经元会进一步丰富。这是通过在 Antinet 更远的分支上创建到其他卡的远程链接来完成的。

The latest research in human memory also supports this, revealing evidence for something termed the distributed representation of memory.[697](#footnote-744) This idea holds that a memory is represented by not merely one notecard (or one neuron), but by an interaction between a large set of neurons. 人类记忆的最新研究也支持这一点，揭示了称为记忆分布式表征的证据。 697 这一观点认为，记忆不仅由一个记事卡（或一个神经元）代表，而且由一大组神经元之间的相互作用代表。神经元。

**The Problems with the Current Definitions of Notes within Zettelkasten LiteratureZettelkasten 文献中当前注释定义的问题**
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**The Problem with the Term ZettelZettel 一词的问题**

The German term Zettel translates into “note” in American English. However, in European English it has been translated into “slip,” and denotes a slip of paper of a6-size as defined by ISO standards (roughly the size of 4 x 6 inch notecards). Regardless of the slight difference in terms (note vs. slip), it’s become conventional for so-called followers of Zettelkasten to throw around the term Zettel. For instance, they ask for critiques on the Zettels they’ve created. 德语术语 Zettel 在美式英语中翻译为 “音符”。然而，在欧洲英语中，它被翻译成 “slip”，表示一张按照 ISO 标准定义的 a6 尺寸的纸条（大约是 4 x 6 英寸记事卡的尺寸）。尽管术语上存在细微差别（注意与单据），但对于所谓的 Zettelkasten 追随者来说，抛出 Zettel 这个词已经成为惯例。例如，他们要求对他们创造的 Zettel 进行批评。

There’s one issue, however. Many Zettelkasten enthusiasts use the term Zettel as the equivalent of a reflection note. They think of Zettels as some type of evergreen, atomic, permanent note. However, roughly seventeen thousand out of Luhmann’s ninety thousand notes were not so-called “Zettels” as these enthusiasts would define it. They were observation notes written down on Luhmann’s bibcards. Of the remaining notes, there were many that were just hub notes containing links to other cards (Collectives), or external references (ExRefs). For this reason, I’ve decided to ditch the whole convention of calling notes Zettels because the term implies that Luhmann had one main type of note. In reality, his so-called “permanent notes” contained several different types of notes. Using the inaccurate and vague term Zettel isn’t helpful. It doesn’t make sense to obfuscate this system even more than it already has been. For this reason, I hereby sentence the term Zettel to death! 但是，有一个问题。许多 Zettelkasten 爱好者使用术语 Zettel 等同于反思笔记。他们认为 Zettels 是某种常青、原子、永久的音符。然而，在卢曼的 9 万条笔记中，大约有 1.7 万条并不是这些狂热者所定义的所谓 “Zettels”。它们是写在卢曼名片上的观察笔记。在剩下的笔记中，有许多只是中心笔记，包含指向其他卡片（集体）或外部参考（ExRefs）的链接。出于这个原因，我决定放弃将音符称为 Zettels 的整个惯例，因为该术语暗示卢曼有一种主要音符类型。实际上，他所谓的“永久笔记” 包含了几种不同类型的笔记。使用不准确和模糊的术语 Zettel 没有帮助。比现在更混淆这个系统是没有意义的。为此，本人特此判处泽特尔一词死刑！

Unfortunately Zettel isn’t the only term that’s unhelpful in the currently confused land of Zettelkasten. Let’s go through the other unhelpful terms now. 不幸的是，在目前混乱的 Zettelkasten 地区，Zettel 并不是唯一没有帮助的术语。现在让我们来看看其他无用的术语。

**The Problem with Fleeting Notes 转瞬即逝的笔记的问题**

Fleeting notes is a term coined by Sönke Ahrens in his book, How to Take Smart Notes. Ahrens calls fleeting notes those notes that “are only reminders of information [that] can be written in any kind of way and will end up in the trash within a day or two.”[698](#footnote-743) 转瞬即逝的笔记是 Sönke Ahrens 在他的书《如何做聪明的笔记》中创造的一个术语。阿伦斯将这些笔记称为转瞬即逝的笔记，这些笔记 “只是信息的提醒，[可以] 以任何方式书写，并会在一两天内被扔进垃圾桶。”698

The problem with such a concept is that we have zero evidence of Luhmann actually using such a technique. Why? Because they would end up in the trash within a day or two. Quite frankly, I’m not sure why Ahrens includes the concept. My best guess is that this practice is something Ahrens himself uses and decided to prescribe for his readers. 这种概念的问题在于，我们对卢曼实际使用这种技术的证据为零。为什么？因为它们会在一两天内进入垃圾桶。坦率地说，我不确定阿伦斯为什么要包含这个概念。我最好的猜测是，这种做法是 Ahrens 自己使用的，并决定为他的读者开出的处方。

I personally don’t have a need to use fleeting notes. I take notes on my bibcards and then spend my energy processing them by creating main notes. I’m very disciplined and strict about this process. My bib notes and main notes are all I need. If I have a thought that continually arises, I’ll wait until I get to my office with my Antinet. If the thought is truly important I’ll explore my Antinet and review the stems that the new thought relates to. If the thought is truly important, I’ll develop it into a main note. 我个人不需要使用转瞬即逝的笔记。我在我的 bibcard 上做笔记，然后通过创建主要笔记来花费我的精力来处理它们。我对这个过程非常有纪律和严格。我的围兜笔记和主要笔记是我所需要的。如果我有一个不断出现的想法，我会等到我带着我的 Antinet 到我的办公室。如果这个想法真的很重要，我会探索我的 Antinet 并回顾与新想法相关的词干。如果这个想法真的很重要，我会把它发展成一个主要的笔记。

I think the concept of fleeting notes stems from a place of fear—the fear of a good idea escaping you, never to return. However, I’ve found that the analog nature of the Antinet has trained my mind and memory to be more disciplined and less sporadic. According to some, we have over six thousand thoughts per day.[699](#footnote-742) You have to trust the truly important ones will recur again and again. When they do, don’t waste time creating fleeting notes; just create a main note for it, if it’s truly relevant. 我认为转瞬即逝的音符的概念源于一种恐惧——害怕一个好主意从你身边溜走，再也回不来了。然而，我发现 Antinet 的模拟特性训练了我的思维和记忆力，使其更有纪律，更少零星。据一些人说，我们每天有超过六千个想法。699 你必须相信真正重要的想法会一次又一次地出现。当他们这样做时，不要浪费时间创建转瞬即逝的笔记；如果它真的相关，只需为其创建一个主要注释。

Luhmann himself was pressed for time and I wouldn’t be surprised to learn that he never took fleeting notes, either. He was very disciplined and deliberate in his thinking, and it’s probable that his bib notes acted as his fleeting notes—as a place to jot down ideas as they first occurred to him while he was reading. Therefore, it makes the whole concept of fleeting notes redundant and unhelpful.Luhmann 本人时间紧迫，如果得知他从不做短暂的笔记，我也不会感到惊讶。他的思维非常有纪律和深思熟虑，他的围兜笔记很可能是他转瞬即逝的笔记——作为一个地方，可以记下他在阅读时第一次想到的想法。因此，它使整个转瞬即逝的音符概念变得多余且无益。

With that said, I do not discount the idea of fleeting notes being valuable for some people. I will grant that the idea of writing down thoughts as they come up is a potentially useful practice. Indeed, writing fleeting thoughts down has been a practice used by some of our greatest thinkers. Nietzsche observed that some of the best ideas are born out in the open (on hikes in nature). Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz always carried paper with him, as well.[700](#footnote-741) 话虽如此，我并不认为转瞬即逝的笔记对某些人来说很有价值。我会承认，在想法出现时将其写下来的想法可能是一种有用的做法。确实，将转瞬即逝的想法写下来一直是我们一些最伟大的思想家所采用的做法。尼采观察到，一些最好的想法是在公开场合（在自然界中远足）诞生的。戈特弗里德 · 威廉 · 莱布尼茨 (Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz) 也总是随身携带纸张。 700

However, I don’t think fleeting notes are something that need to be elaborated on too much in the context of knowledge development. It’s an obvious practice if you want to function as an adult. It’s kind of like keeping track of reminders and appointments. In the rare case I need to capture a fleeting note, I use a weekly paper planner placed in my fanny pack (yes, I rock a fanny pack). I’ve found a pen and paper planner to be more useful and less distracting than using a to-do app, note app, or calendar app on my phone. There are rare occasions where I’ll want to remind myself of a fleeting thought, and in that case I’ll write it down in my weekly planner. However, I’ve noticed a pattern whenever I do this. When it comes time to create a main note for the thought, I usually find that the idea isn’t really even valuable or useful. 但是，我认为在知识发展的背景下，转瞬即逝的笔记是不需要过多阐述的。如果您想像成年人一样工作，这是显而易见的做法。这有点像跟踪提醒和约会。在极少数情况下，我需要捕捉一闪而过的笔记，我会使用放在腰包中的每周纸质计划（是的，我喜欢腰包）。我发现笔和纸计划器比在我的手机上使用待办事项应用程序、笔记应用程序或日历应用程序更有用，也更不容易分心。在极少数情况下，我会想提醒自己一个转瞬即逝的想法，在这种情况下，我会把它写在我的每周计划中。但是，每当我这样做时，我都会注意到一种模式。当需要为想法创建一个主要注释时，我通常会发现这个想法实际上什至没有价值或用处。

Again, the whole concept of fleeting notes isn’t that important in the workflow of using an Antinet. The important pieces are the bib notes and main notes. For all of these reasons, I opt to drop the whole concept of fleeting notes altogether. 同样，转瞬即逝的音符的整个概念在使用 Antinet 的工作流程中并不是那么重要。重要的部分是围兜笔记和主要笔记。出于所有这些原因，我选择完全放弃转瞬即逝的音符的整个概念。

**The Problem with Project Notes 项目笔记的问题**

Another term Sönke Ahrens introduced is that of project notes. Ahrens explains these are notes which are “kept within a project-specific folder and can be discarded or archived after the project is finished.”[701](#footnote-740) This whole concept is another Ahrensian invention. One of the most powerful aspects of the Antinet is that the projects you work on will compound. Why? Because they’re installed in the Antinet. This enables the project you work on for one paper to be potentially used later on in a completely different project. As Johannes Schmidt writes of Luhmann’s Antinet, “The bulk of the collections (approximately 75,000 cards) consists of notes documenting the results of Luhmann’s readings, his own thoughts, and ideas for publication projects.”[702](#footnote-739) In brief, Luhmann stored the material he worked on for projects inside his own Antinet, not in folders. This can be observed in the notes he created for his paper Communication with Noteboxes, as well.[703](#footnote-738)Sönke Ahrens 介绍的另一个术语是项目笔记。阿伦斯解释说，这些笔记 “保存在项目特定的文件夹中，可以在项目完成后丢弃或存档。”701 这整个概念是阿伦斯的另一项发明。 Antinet 最强大的方面之一是您从事的项目将会复合。为什么？因为它们安装在 Antinet 中。这使您为一篇论文所从事的项目有可能在以后用于完全不同的项目。正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 对卢曼的 Antinet 所写的那样，“大部分收藏（大约 75,000 张卡片）包括记录卢曼阅读结果的笔记、他自己的想法以及出版项目的想法。”702 简而言之，卢曼存储了他工作的材料在他自己的 Antinet 中的项目上，而不是在文件夹中。这也可以在他为论文 Communication with Noteboxes 创建的笔记中观察到。 703

In brief, do not store notes you create for a project in some folder outside the Antinet. Store them in your Antinet so that they can be developed and used for another project in the long term. You’ll be surprised how much you end up using from previous material. You may end up stumbling upon the material by accident at the perfect time when you’ll need it most. 简而言之，不要将您为项目创建的笔记存储在 Antinet 之外的某个文件夹中。将它们存储在您的 Antinet 中，以便它们可以长期开发并用于另一个项目。你会惊讶于你最终使用了多少以前的材料。您可能会在最需要的最佳时间偶然发现这些材料。

**The Problem with Literature Notes 文献笔记的问题**

Literature note is another term introduced by Ahrens. He writes, “Whenever you read something, make notes about the content.”[704](#footnote-737) These notes are what he calls literature notes. 文学笔记是阿伦斯引入的另一个术语。他写道，“每当你读到一些东西时，就对内容做笔记。”704 这些笔记就是他所说的文学笔记。

Yet there’s a problem with the term literature notes. First off, it’s vague. What are literature notes? They’re brief observations of what you have read. They also are placed on a bibcard. For this reason, I prefer the term bib notes (or observation notes). Second, as mentioned elsewhere, the term literature notes implies one takes these notes from the literature one reads. However, this is not the case. These types of notes can and should be drawn from many sources (podcasts, videos, lectures, and more). In the words of John Aubrey, a fellow of the Royal Society, “material gathered should not be confined to that offered in books.”[705](#footnote-736) 然而，文学笔记一词存在问题。首先，它是模糊的。什么是文学笔记？它们是对您所读内容的简要观察。它们也被放置在 bibcard 上。出于这个原因，我更喜欢术语 bib notes（或观察笔记）。其次，正如其他地方提到的，文学笔记一词意味着人们从阅读的文学作品中获取这些笔记。然而，这种情况并非如此。这些类型的笔记可以而且应该来自许多来源（播客、视频、讲座等）。用皇家学会会员 John Aubrey 的话来说，“收集的材料不应局限于书中提供的材料。”705

For these reasons, I suggest dropping the term literature notes and instead using bib notes (short for bibliography notes). In cases in which you’re using a 1-step book-to-maincard method, then it’s more appropriate to refer to them as observation notes. 出于这些原因，我建议放弃术语文献注释，而是使用书目注释（参考书目注释的缩写）。如果您使用一步从书到主卡的方法，那么将它们称为观察笔记更合适。

**The Problem with Permanent Notes 永久性笔记的问题**

Permanent note is yet another Ahrensian term that has become part of the Zettelkasten canon. Ahrens defines permanent notes as those “which will never be thrown away and [that] contain the necessary information in a permanently understandable way.”[706](#footnote-735) 永久音符是另一个 Ahrensian 术语，已成为 Zettelkasten 经典的一部分。阿伦斯将永久性笔记定义为 “永远不会被丢弃并且 [that] 以永久可理解的方式包含必要信息的笔记。”706

There are several problems with this term. 这个词有几个问题。

First off, the term permanent is redundant. Every note you install in the Antinet is permanent. The cards you place in the main box of your Antinet are permanent, and so are the cards you install in the bibliography and index box. Calling a note permanent doesn’t differentiate it from the many different types of permanent notes that Luhmann, for example, created. 首先，永久一词是多余的。您在 Antinet 中安装的每个音符都是永久性的。您放置在 Antinet 主盒中的卡片是永久性的，您安装在书目和索引盒中的卡片也是如此。将音符称为永久音符并不能将其与卢曼等人创造的许多不同类型的永久音符区分开来。

What’s even more perplexing is that the idea of permanent notes seems primarily geared toward digital Zettelkasten practitioners. The idea behind permanent notes is that they permanently define a concept and are then referenced (without being deleted or updated). However, this is problematic for digital notetaking apps. Why? Because digital notes are anything but permanent! Their contents are constantly being refactored, updated, deleted and rearranged. For this reason a new term was invented called evergreen notes. According to the inventor of the term, evergreen notes are “written and organized to evolve, contribute, and accumulate over time, across projects.”[707](#footnote-734) The coiner of this term differentiates it from another coined term: transient notes. The idea of these notes centers around the idea of notes just being stored in containers and never evolving. 更令人困惑的是，永久笔记的想法似乎主要针对数字 Zettelkasten 从业者。永久注释背后的想法是，它们永久定义一个概念，然后被引用（不被删除或更新）。然而，这对于数字笔记应用程序来说是有问题的。为什么？因为数字笔记绝非永久性的！它们的内容不断被重构、更新、删除和重新排列。为此，发明了一个新术语，称为长青笔记。根据该术语的发明者，常青笔记是 “编写和组织的，以随着时间的推移，跨项目发展、贡献和积累。”707 这个术语的创造者将它与另一个创造的术语：瞬态笔记区分开来。这些笔记的想法围绕着笔记只是存储在容器中并且永远不会进化的想法。

All of this stuff is just confusing gibberish. It’s a case of people trying to invent terms to encompass what Luhmann’s Antinet really was. Luhmann’s notes were indeed permanent. They were not edited. Using such a system, one’s thinking is thereby stamped in history. Yet the notes also evolved thanks to the tree structure of the Antinet. This concept isn’t really captured in the terms permanent notes or evergreen notes. 所有这些东西只是令人困惑的胡言乱语。这是一个人们试图发明术语来涵盖卢曼的 Antinet 真正含义的例子。卢曼的笔记确实是永久性的。他们没有被编辑。使用这样一个系统，一个人的思想就会在历史上留下烙印。然而，由于 Antinet 的树结构，音符也得到了发展。这个概念并没有真正体现在永久票据或常青票据的术语中。

For these reason I drop the term permanent notes altogether (same goes for evergreen notes). A better way of thinking about notes is in the terminology I’ll be introducing soon. But before I introduce the four types of notes, let’s first talk about the art of note creation. 出于这些原因，我完全放弃了永久笔记这个词（常青笔记也是如此）。一种更好的理解笔记的方法是使用我即将介绍的术语。不过在介绍四种音符之前，我们先来说说音符创作的艺术。

**The Art of Note Creation 笔记创作的艺术**
------------------------------------

The following section may create endless suffering for computer scientists, engineers, and especially digital notetaking junkies (the ones with one-hundred-point checklists and templates for creating notes). Here’s the truth: the Antinet may not be the right tool for those focused on optimization and strict adherence to protocol. 以下部分可能会给计算机科学家、工程师，尤其是数字笔记迷（那些拥有一百点清单和创建笔记模板的人）带来无穷无尽的痛苦。事实是这样的：对于那些专注于优化和严格遵守协议的人来说，Antinet 可能不是合适的工具。

**Notes are a Means to an End 笔记是达到目的的手段**

The Antinet—and any knowledge development system for that matter—is not the end. It’s not the output. It’s not the destination. Knowledge development should not be beautiful; it should be messy, drenched in sweat, ink, coffee stains and some loops that are never closed. Knowledge development contains notes which are raw products. The materials serve as products of your thinking. This raw product doesn’t happen before or after you think, it happens as you think. The symbols on physical paper represent the truest and closest representation of your thinking.Antinet——以及与此相关的任何知识开发系统——并不是终点。这不是输出。这不是目的地。知识的发展不应该是美丽的；它应该是凌乱的，沾满了汗水、墨水、咖啡渍和一些从未闭合的环。知识开发包含作为原始产品的注释。这些材料是您思想的产物。这种原始产品不会在您思考之前或之后发生，它会按照您的想法发生。实物纸上的符号代表了您思想的最真实和最接近的表示。

The goal is for your creative output, not your notes, to be beautiful and profound. 目标是让你的创意输出，而不是你的笔记，变得美丽而深刻。

In brief, notes are a means to an end, not the end itself. The goal is for the output phase to be deeply developed and ordered. It’s OK for the process phase to be seemingly chaotic. 简而言之，笔记是达到目的的手段，而不是目的本身。目标是深入开发和排序输出阶段。过程阶段看似混乱是可以的。

**Not Every Note Will Be Used 并非每个音符都会被使用**

Another thing to keep in mind is that you should not put pressure on yourself to only produce notes that end up getting used. 另一件要记住的事情是，你不应该给自己施加压力，让自己只写出最终被使用的笔记。

When writing notes, according to Luhmann, “the first thing one does is produce a lot of waste.”[708](#footnote-733) If you don’t anticipate this, you may find yourself discouraged; this is why many people burn out on personal knowledge management systems, and digital Zettelkasten with which it’s all-too-easy to create mountains of information. You hit a certain point where you’ve created so much information such that seemingly none of it will ever be used. This can lead to despair and to people giving up knowledge development altogether.[709](#footnote-732) 根据卢曼的说法，写笔记时，“一个人做的第一件事就是产生大量浪费。”708 如果您没有预料到这一点，您可能会发现自己灰心丧气；这就是为什么许多人对个人知识管理系统和数字 Zettelkasten 精疲力竭的原因，利用它们可以轻松创建大量信息。您达到了某个点，您已经创建了如此多的信息，以至于似乎永远不会使用这些信息。这可能导致绝望，并导致人们完全放弃知识开发。 709

As Luhmann acknowledges, “We are educated to expect something useful from our activities and otherwise quickly lose encouragement.”[710](#footnote-731) However, with the Antinet, I’ve found that since it takes longer to produce material, you’re incentivized to produce less waste. In addition, you produce less overall. This results in more of the material and notes you create being used (in comparison to digital workflows that distract you with the labeling, organizing, and reworking of notes). 正如 Luhmann 承认的那样，“我们被教育要从我们的活动中期待一些有用的东西，否则很快就会失去鼓励。”710 然而，有了 Antinet，我发现由于生产材料需要更长的时间，你会被激励去减少浪费. 此外，您的总体产量较低。这导致您创建的更多材料和笔记被使用（与数字工作流程相比，数字工作流程会分散您对笔记的标签、组织和修改的注意力）。

The good news about the Antinet, and one of its invaluable features, is that it forces users to “prepare their notes in such a way that they are available for later access.”[711](#footnote-730) If not easily findable, every note you take is a candidate for an unexpected and invaluable insight if you happen to stumble upon it. Even if you don’t stumble upon a particular card, it creates what Luhmann deems, “a consoling illusion” that mitigates against the risk of discouragement during the knowledge development process.[712](#footnote-729) 关于 Antinet 及其宝贵功能之一的好消息是，它会强制用户 “以这样一种方式准备他们的笔记，以便以后可以访问。”711 如果不容易找到，你做的每一个笔记都是一个候选如果您偶然发现它，可以获得意想不到的宝贵见解。即使你没有偶然发现一张特定的卡片，它也会创造出 Luhmann 所认为的 “一种安慰幻觉”，从而减轻知识发展过程中灰心丧气的风险。 712

In brief, think of knowledge development with the Antinet like exercising the mind. Exercise is good for you. Creating notes and installing them into the Antinet is good for you. It’s a process. It’s a workout for your mind. You’ll start seeing results in the short term, yes. However, it’s something you ought to strive to keep up as a long-term practice. 简而言之，将 Antinet 的知识发展想象成锻炼思维。运动对你有好处。创建注释并将它们安装到 Antinet 中对您有好处。这是一个过程。这是锻炼你的头脑。你会在短期内开始看到结果，是的。然而，这是你应该努力保持的长期实践。

**Press On 按下**
