When using an Antinet for knowledge development, you must remind yourself to do one thing: press on. Prepare yourself to take notes by hand. You must train yourself to slow down and pause to think. Reformulating the author’s words with your own voice is very hard work. 在使用 Antinet 进行知识开发时，您必须提醒自己做一件事：继续前进。准备自己用手做笔记。你必须训练自己放慢脚步，停下来思考。用自己的声音重新表述作者的话是一项非常艰巨的工作。

Luhmann’s advice on how to read scientific literature echoes this advice. He says it’s best to take reformulation notes—and continue to do so—even if it means you must “postpone the hope of scientific productivity for a while.”[713](#footnote-728) For challenging texts, this is how you level up in your reading. It’s how you level up your intellect. Slowing down is how you get to the point where you can take reflection notes on advanced texts. 卢曼关于如何阅读科学文献的建议呼应了这一建议。他说最好重新记录笔记——并继续这样做——即使这意味着你必须 “暂时推迟科学生产力的希望。”713 对于具有挑战性的文本，这就是你提高阅读水平的方式。这就是你如何提升你的智力。放慢速度是你如何达到可以对高级文本进行反思的程度。

**The Process is More Important than the Result 过程比结果更重要**

As Richard Feynman explained, his notes were not a record of his thinking; they were his thinking. “They are my thinking process,” Feynman says.[714](#footnote-727) 正如理查德 · 费曼解释的那样，他的笔记并不是他思想的记录，而是他的思想记录。他们是他的想法。 “它们是我的思考过程，” 费曼说。 714

The goal of creating notes is not to provide you with a written record of information. Rather, it’s to develop your mind—it’s to develop your thoughts.[715](#footnote-726) This is one reason why I don’t lose sleep at night. I don’t fear the prospect of my Antinet catching on fire. The transformation within one’s brain (using an Antinet) is more valuable than undeveloped information stored on a computer (which doesn’t face the same risk of destruction in terms of fire or flood). 创建笔记的目的不是为您提供信息的书面记录。相反，它是为了发展你的思想——它是为了发展你的思想。715 这就是我晚上不失眠的原因之一。我不担心我的 Antinet 会着火。大脑内部的转换（使用 Antinet）比存储在计算机上的未开发信息更有价值（就火灾或洪水而言，计算机不会面临同样的破坏风险）。

As one cognitive scientist puts it, “research reveals the main value of note- taking is through its effect on how you encode the information in your brain.” In other words, she continues, “the act of note-taking is more important than the result.”[716](#footnote-725) I agree. 正如一位认知科学家所说，“研究表明，记笔记的主要价值在于它对大脑中信息编码方式的影响。” 换句话说，她继续说道，“记笔记的行为比结果更重要。”716 我同意。

**The Two Classes of Notes 两类票据**

There are two types of note creation: Notetaking and notemaking.[717](#footnote-724) 有两种类型的笔记创建：Notetaking 和 notemaking.717

**Notetaking 做笔记**

Notetaking refers to the process of recording your own observations that you have while engaging with a source such as a book. For instance, let’s talk about what occurs when you use the 2-step Luhmannian bibcard method. When you record individual bibnotes on a bibcard, the nature of the notes are observations. You’re recording the thoughts you have while reading the text. In essence, you’re taking notes directly influenced by the source. 记笔记是指记录您在与书本等来源互动时的观察结果的过程。例如，让我们谈谈使用两步卢曼比卡法时会发生什么。当您在 bibcard 上记录单个 bibnotes 时，笔记的性质是观察。您正在记录阅读文本时的想法。本质上，您是在直接受源头影响的情况下做笔记。

**Notemaking 做笔记**

With notemaking, you’re a step beyond notetaking and are actually creating a standalone note from the observations you’ve made while reading. You make a main note from the observations you’ve recorded on your bibcard. The main notes are either excerpts, reformulations, or reflections of the material. The difference between notetaking and notemaking is a little fuzzy— especially with regards to excerpt notes (as they’re a direct copy of the source material). Yet, because excerpt notes are installed and applied to a specific area or line of thought within the branches or stems of your Antinet, it’s defensible that they be classified as part of the notemaking process. When you cut the umbilical cord of the material that directly connects to a book, and instead connect the material to a chain of concepts in your Antinet, you’re partaking in notemaking. 有了笔记，你就超越了做笔记，实际上是根据你在阅读时所做的观察来创建一个独立的笔记。您根据记录在 bibcard 上的观察结果做一个主要记录。主要注释要么是摘录、重新表述，要么是对材料的反思。 notetaking 和 notemaking 之间的区别有点模糊——特别是关于摘录笔记（因为它们是源材料的直接副本）。然而，由于摘录笔记被安装并应用于 Antinet 的分支或主干中的特定区域或思路，因此将它们归类为笔记制作过程的一部分是有道理的。当你切断直接连接到一本书的材料的脐带，而是将材料连接到你的 Antinet 中的一系列概念时，你就参与了笔记制作。

**Notetaking vs. Notemaking 做笔记与做笔记**

In summary, notetaking is a process enacted through creating bibcards which contain observations during your readings. Notemaking is a process enacted through main notes which contain excerpt notes, reformulation notes, and reflection notes. The differences will start to make sense where it truly matters: in practice. Let’s now talk about the four main types of notes in practice. 总而言之，记笔记是一个通过创建包含阅读期间观察结果的卡片来实现的过程。笔记制作是通过主要笔记制定的过程，主要笔记包括摘录笔记、重新制定笔记和反思笔记。这些差异将在真正重要的地方开始变得有意义：在实践中。现在让我们谈谈实践中的四种主要笔记类型。

**Your Note-Creation Repertoire 你的笔记创作曲目**
------------------------------------------

You must have multiple note-creation strategies in your repertoire when creating knowledge. There’s “no one ‘best’ strategy for taking notes,” states one cognitive scientist.[718](#footnote-723) 在创造知识时，你的曲目中必须有多种笔记创造策略。一位认知科学家表示，“没有‘最好的’记笔记策略”。 718

The strategy you choose for creating knowledge depends on several factors.[719](#footnote-722) What type of note you decide to create depends on your working memory capacity. As you use the Antinet over time, your working memory capacity will improve. Yet sometimes you don’t have enough bandwidth to simply reflect on notes. Sometimes you need to first create a full excerpt note in order to construct several cards to express your thoughts. This is one factor that has an impact on which type of note you create during knowledge development. 您选择创建知识的策略取决于几个因素。719 您决定创建哪种类型的笔记取决于您的工作记忆容量。当您使用 Antinet 随着时间的推移，您的工作记忆容量将会提高。然而，有时你没有足够的带宽来简单地反思笔记。有时您需要先创建一个完整的摘录笔记，以便构建多张卡片来表达您的想法。这是影响您在知识开发过程中创建哪种类型的笔记的一个因素。

Another factor that affects note creation is external distraction. We already know how distracting the digital environment can be. Research shows us how often people are distracted and pulled into checking communication apps. For 50% of people, it’s every six minutes![720](#footnote-721) Yet even following an analog workflow, your environment may provide distractions. If you’re crammed onto a plane, it’s a lot easier to use the 2-step Luhmannian bibcard method, for instance, than it would be trying to manage fifteen different notecards on your tray table. 影响笔记创建的另一个因素是外部干扰。我们已经知道数字环境会让人分心。研究向我们展示了人们分心并被拉入检查通信应用程序的频率。对于 50% 的人来说，每六分钟一次！720 然而，即使遵循模拟工作流程，您的环境也可能会让人分心。如果你挤在飞机上，使用两步卢曼 bibcard 方法比在你的小桌上尝试管理 15 个不同的记事卡要容易得多。

Not only do external distractions affect your workflow, but internal distractions do so as well. When you practice the 1-step book-to-maincard method, it requires a lot of focus. You must be in a very present state of mind to have the self-awareness to know when you’re getting unnecessarily bogged down in material. If your internal life is in a state of distress and you’re facing many internal distractions, your note creation method should accommodate that state. 不仅外部干扰会影响您的工作流程，内部干扰也会影响您的工作流程。当你练习 1-step book-to-maincard 方法时，它需要非常集中注意力。你必须处于一种非常当下的心态，才能有自我意识，知道什么时候你会不必要地陷入物质的泥潭。如果你的内心生活处于一种痛苦的状态，并且你面临着许多内心的干扰，你的笔记创建方法应该适应这种状态。

The last factor that affects how you should create notes is the difficulty of the material. If you’re tackling a challenging text, understanding the material is a prerequisite for reflecting on the material. How well you understand what you’re reading shapes how you should go about creating notes. In many cases you must first either excerpt or reformulate the material. 最后一个影响你应该如何创建笔记的因素是材料的难度。如果你正在处理一篇具有挑战性的文章，理解材料是反思材料的先决条件。你对所读内容的理解程度决定了你应该如何创建笔记。在许多情况下，您必须首先摘录或重新组织材料。

It’s important to know about these factors when deciding what type of note to create, and how to create them. However don’t worry yourself about trying to hold the types in mind during the note creation process. The understanding of these factors, and what process works best for you will come with time and practice. 在决定创建哪种类型的笔记以及如何创建它们时，了解这些因素很重要。但是，不要担心在笔记创建过程中要牢记类型。随着时间的推移和实践，对这些因素的理解以及最适合您的过程将会到来。

Let’s now get into the four types of notes. 现在让我们进入四种类型的笔记。

**The Four Types of Notes 四种笔记**
--------------------------------

There are four types of notes: 有四种类型的注释：

1. Observation notes 一、观察笔记

2. Excerpt notes2. 摘录笔记

3. Reformulation notes3. 重新制定说明

4. Reflection notes4. 反思笔记

Observation notes are traditionally recorded on bibcards (vertical 4 x 6 inch notecards used while reading or engaging with a source), whereas the other three notes (excerpt, reformulation, and reflection notes) are created on maincards (which are horizontal 4 x 6 inch notecards). 观察笔记传统上记录在 bibcard 上（阅读或与来源互动时使用的垂直 4 x 6 英寸笔记卡），而其他三个笔记（摘录、重新表述和反思笔记）是在主卡（水平 4 x 6 英寸）上创建的记事本）。

Let’s go through each of these in detail now. 现在让我们详细了解其中的每一个。

**Observation Notes 观察笔记**

John Aubrey, a fellow of the Royal Society, once likened the taking of notes to being a traveller. You don’t want to merely copy down a diagram of the map, he said. Rather, you want to explore the land or territory and record your own observations.[721](#footnote-720) In other words, you want to record your own thoughts. These types of notes are observation notes. John Locke took these types of notes, as well. One scholar referred to Locke’s notes as “observations and thoughts.”[722](#footnote-719) Another scholar refers to observation notes as “one’s own comments or annotations on individual textual passages.”[723](#footnote-718) 英国皇家学会会员约翰 · 奥布里 (John Aubrey) 曾将做笔记比作旅行家。他说，你不想仅仅抄下地图的图表。相反，您想探索这片土地或领土并记录您自己的观察结果。721 换句话说，您想记录您自己的想法。这些类型的笔记是观察笔记。约翰 · 洛克也做了这些类型的笔记。一位学者将洛克的笔记称为 “观察和思想”。722 另一位学者将观察笔记称为 “个人对个别文本段落的评论或注释。”723

**Where Observation Notes Live 观察笔记所在的地方**

I teach Antinetters to employ the 2-step Luhmannian bibcard method, with the notes written down on the bibcard being observation notes. While I hold that bibcards are the best medium for capturing observation notes, they’re not the only place observation notes can live. As previously mentioned, some users jot down observation notes in book margins. Some may even extract observation notes onto individual (non-bibcard) notecards while reading a text. In fact, I’ve done such on 3 x 5 inch notecards before. 我教 Antinetters 使用两步 Luhmannian bibcard 方法，在 bibcard 上写下的笔记是观察笔记。虽然我认为 bibcards 是记录观察笔记的最佳媒介，但它们并不是观察笔记唯一可以存在的地方。如前所述，一些用户在书页边空白处记下观察笔记。有些人甚至可能在阅读文本时将观察笔记提取到个人（非 bibcard）记事卡上。事实上，我以前在 3 x 5 英寸的记事卡上做过这样的事情。

**Observation Notes vs. Reflection Notes 观察笔记与反思笔记**

The main characteristic that differentiates an observation note from a reflection note is that observation notes are very short. They’re brief pieces of text that represent the brief thought you have immediately in the moment of reading a text. 区分观察笔记和反思笔记的主要特征是观察笔记非常短。它们是简短的文本片段，代表您在阅读文本时立即产生的简短想法。

**Excerpt Notes 摘录笔记**

Excerpt notes are notes in that you copy down word-for-word from a text as a direct quote. Here’s an example: 摘录注释是您从文本中逐字逐句抄录下来作为直接引述的注释。这是一个例子：

According to one scholar, excerpts do the following things: (1) they capture a text’s “train of thought”; (2) they capture the structure of a text’s argument; and (3) they contain the worthwhile details of a text and its references to secondary literature.[724](#footnote-717) These serve as a few reasons why one should opt to excerpt texts. 根据一位学者的说法，摘录做了以下事情：（1）他们抓住了文本的 “思路”； (2) 它们捕捉文本论点的结构； (3) 它们包含文本的有价值的细节及其对二手文献的参考。724 这些是人们应该选择摘录文本的几个原因。

However, I think there are other reasons to employ excerpt notes. First, sometimes the prose of a text is so commanding that it’s worthwhile to excerpt the entire quote. It’s worth excerpting in order to use the quote in your creative output. It’s also worth excerpting in order to neuroimprint the prose onto your mind so that you can refine and develop your own writing skills. 但是，我认为使用摘录笔记还有其他原因。首先，有时一篇文章的散文是如此引人注目，以至于值得摘录整个引文。为了在您的创意输出中使用报价，值得摘录。为了使散文在您的脑海中留下神经印记，以便您可以完善和发展自己的写作技巧，也值得摘录。

“Sometimes a mere recital of facts can itself lead to a greater understanding,” Mortimer Adler writes.[725](#footnote-716) In other words, the practice of writing down an important snippet of text that you don’t quite understand can actually lead to more understanding. Elsewhere in this book I mentioned that in the late seventeenth century at Harvard College, students were taught from textbooks bought in England. How were they taught specifically? By having students write down the material contained in the texts by hand.[726](#footnote-715) Harvard implemented this practice because it worked. It may not be the most engaging way to teach; however the solitude and time spent rehearsing the words in one’s mind, by excerpting them down on paper, ends up leading to greater understanding of the material. 莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 (Mortimer Adler) 写道：“有时候，仅仅叙述事实本身就可以加深理解。”725 换句话说，写下您不太理解的重要文本片段的做法实际上可以加深理解。在本书的其他地方，我曾提到在 17 世纪晚期的哈佛大学，学生们使用从英国购买的教科书进行教学。具体是怎么教的？让学生手写课文中包含的材料。726 哈佛之所以实施这种做法，是因为它奏效了。这可能不是最吸引人的教学方式；然而，孤独和花时间在脑海中排练单词，将它们摘录在纸上，最终会导致对材料有更好的理解。

I advise the use of excerpt notes when you’re trying to really stretch your mind. When you’re tackling a challenging text and you encounter a critical part, it may be wise to excerpt the section or concepts. When engaging with a challenging text, it’s also recommended to employ the 1-step book-to-maincard method. 当你试图真正扩展你的思维时，我建议使用摘录笔记。当您处理具有挑战性的文本并遇到关键部分时，摘录该部分或概念可能是明智的。在阅读具有挑战性的文本时，还建议采用 1 步从书到主卡的方法。

If you’re engaging with a not-so-challenging text, there are still several instances in which you ought to excerpt material. For instance, if you wish to use the excerpt to support your argument, it’s often useful to quote the author directly. It’s also advisable to use a direct quote when your goal is to refute an argument. 如果你正在阅读一篇不那么具有挑战性的文章，仍然有几个例子你应该摘录材料。例如，如果你想用摘录来支持你的论点，直接引用作者的话通常很有用。当你的目标是反驳一个论点时，也建议使用直接引用。

**Reformulation Notes 重新制定说明**

Luhmann was adamant in his views that one should not get bogged down with excerpt notes. Yet he seemed to follow the do as I say, not as I do principle in this regard. We know this because he took extensive excerpt notes. Regardless, Luhmann does instruct us in the taking of a special type of note called reformulations. “Perhaps the best method is to take notes— not excerpts, but condensed reformulations of what has been read.”[727](#footnote-714) 卢曼坚持他的观点，即人们不应该被摘录笔记所困。然而他似乎遵循的是我说的就做，而不是我做这方面的原则。我们知道这一点，因为他做了大量的摘录笔记。无论如何，卢曼确实指导我们记下一种特殊类型的笔记，称为重新表述。 “也许最好的方法是做笔记——不是摘录，而是对所读内容的重新表述。”727

Reformulation notes entail summarizing and creating a form of the idea in your own words so that, as Luhmann put it, you are creating a “re-description of what has already been described.”[728](#footnote-713) 重新表述笔记需要用你自己的话总结和创造一种形式的想法，这样，正如卢曼所说，你正在创造 “对已经描述过的东西的重新描述。”728

**Why Reformulations? 为什么要重新制定？**

According to Luhmann, reformulation notes automatically train one’s mind in such a way that it creates a lens or “frame of mind” for spotting patterns.[729](#footnote-712) This process operates in the same way the index does. Reformulation notes enable you to neuroimprint ideas so that you can observe and read literature differently. 根据 Luhmann 的说法，重新制定的笔记会自动训练一个人的思维，从而创建一个镜头或 “思维框架” 来发现模式。 729 这个过程的运作方式与索引的运作方式相同。重新制定的笔记使您能够对想法进行神经烙印，以便您可以以不同的方式观察和阅读文学作品。

Reformulation notes force you to question why the author uses certain words. You’re able to pay attention to vocabulary and usage. How? Because you’re investing the additional time necessary in understanding a text well enough to re-describe the concept; you’re forced to spot “conditions that lead to the text offering certain descriptions and not others,” Luhmann says.[730](#footnote-711) 重新表述的注释迫使你质疑作者为什么使用某些词。您可以注意词汇和用法。如何？因为你投入了额外的时间来充分理解文本以重新描述这个概念；你被迫发现 “导致文本提供某些描述而不是其他描述的条件，”Luhmann 说。 730

Reformulating an author’s ideas in your own words forces you to slow down and chew on the material. This practice forces you to think. 用你自己的话重新表述作者的想法会迫使你放慢速度并仔细研究材料。这种做法迫使你思考。

Fiona McPherson, who specializes in the field of notetaking, echoes Luhmann’s advice. She asserts, “Note-taking is effective to the extent that you paraphrase, organize and make sense of information while taking notes.”[731](#footnote-710) Essentially, one of the most effective forms of notetaking is that of reformulation notes. 专注于笔记领域的菲奥娜 · 麦克弗森 (Fiona McPherson) 赞同卢曼的建议。她断言，“如果您在记笔记时释义、组织和理解信息，那么记笔记是有效的。”731 从本质上讲，最有效的记笔记形式之一是重新组织笔记。

Like Luhmann, McPherson goes on to warn against excerpt notes. She refers to excerpt notes as “verbatim notes,” asserting they’re of “minimum value” unless they are used as a staging post, or as “stepping stones” to later paraphrase and then turn into reformulation notes. With this, I partly agree, however I urge one to not overlook the power of excerpt notes in neuroimprinting valuable ideas onto your mind. 像卢曼一样，麦克弗森继续警告不要摘录笔记。她将摘录笔记称为 “逐字记录”，声称它们具有“最低价值”，除非它们被用作中转站，或作为“垫脚石” 以供日后释义然后变成重新制定的笔记。对此，我部分同意，但我敦促人们不要忽视摘录笔记在将有价值的想法神经烙印到您的脑海中的力量。

McPherson holds a very strong opinion on the importance of reformulation notes, stating that reformulations are “the most important” NotetakingMcPherson 对重新制定笔记的重要性持有非常强烈的意见，指出重新制定是 “最重要的” 笔记

skill.[732](#footnote-709) While I think this may be an overstatement (each type of note has its utility), I won’t disagree with her on the potency of reformulations.skill.732 虽然我认为这可能言过其实（每种类型的音符都有其用途），但我不会不同意她对重新表述的效力的看法。

Good reformulations extract the meaning of what the author says. The goal centers on creating reformulations that are short, relevant, and in your own words.[733](#footnote-708) 好的重构提炼出作者所说的意思。目标集中在创建简短、相关且用您自己的话的重新表述。 733

**Types of Reformulation Notes 重新制定说明的类型**

There are several types of reformulation notes. The following collection is by no means comprehensive, and the lines get fuzzy when you zoom in with a microscope around their borders; the types of reformulations listed will certainly give you some idea and a feel for their nature. Let’s go through them now. 有几种类型的重新制定说明。下面的合集绝不是全面的，当你用显微镜放大它们的边界时，线条会变得模糊；列出的重新制定的类型肯定会让您对它们的性质有所了解和感受。现在让我们来看看它们。

**Topical Reformulations 局部重新制定**

Topical reformulations are text-based summaries of content. The goal here is quite simple. Instead of excerpting an entire passage, you want to explain the idea in your own words. Topical reformulations “summarize the main points without adding any new information or offering a new perspective.”[734](#footnote-707) 主题重构是基于文本的内容摘要。这里的目标很简单。您不想摘录整段文章，而是想用自己的话来解释这个想法。专题重新表述 “在不添加任何新信息或提供新观点的情况下总结要点。”734

Here’s an example of a topical reformulation: 这是一个局部重构的例子：

**Outline Reformulations 大纲重新制定**

Outline reformulations refer to the process of breaking down material into a series of steps. For instance, if faced with a daunting wall of text, it’s helpful to break apart the material into steps. Here’s an example of this: 重新制定大纲是指将材料分解为一系列步骤的过程。例如，如果面对令人望而生畏的文字墙，将材料分解成多个步骤会很有帮助。这是一个例子：

This outline reformulation will look familiar to you. It’s what I used to assemble the section several pages back on having a note creation repertoire. 这个重新制定的大纲对你来说看起来很熟悉。这就是我用来组装几页前关于创建音符曲目的部分的内容。

There are several scenarios in which outline reformulations prove to be the best reformulation strategy. Here are such instances: 在几种情况下，大纲重新制定被证明是最好的重新制定策略。下面是这样的例子：

1. If the text is simple and based primarily on facts, it’s a good idea to use outline reformulations.1. 如果文本很简单并且主要基于事实，那么使用大纲重新表述是个好主意。

2. If you’re limited on time, then it’s a good idea to use outline reformulations (instead of diagram reformulations, which will be explained shortly).2. 如果你的时间有限，那么使用大纲重构是个好主意（而不是图表重构，稍后会解释）。

3. If the material will not represent a major framework in what you intend to teach, then it’s a good idea to opt for an outline reformulation (instead of a diagram reformulation).3. 如果材料不能代表您打算教授的内容的主要框架，那么最好选择重新制定大纲（而不是重新制定图表）。

4. If the information is more hierarchical in nature, then it’s a good idea to employ an outline reformulation. Where outline reformulations really shine is in conjunction with texts presenting hierarchical material. Indeed, perhaps “they’re only good for displaying hierarchical information.”[735](#footnote-706)4. 如果信息在本质上更具层次性，那么采用大纲重新表述是个好主意。大纲重新表述真正闪耀的地方是与呈现分层材料的文本相结合。确实，也许 “它们只适合显示层次信息。”735

**Diagram Reformulations 图表重构**

Diagram reformulations are doodles, graphics, illustrations or drawings that represent an idea. You’ve seen such diagram illustrations throughout this text. The pretty drawn illustrations in this text were made by my lovely fiancé. However they initially began as notecards drawn by myself. 图表重构是代表一个想法的涂鸦、图形、插图或绘图。您已经在整篇文章中看到了这样的图表插图。本书中精美的插图出自我可爱的未婚夫之手。然而，它们最初是作为我自己绘制的记事卡开始的。

For instance here’s one of my diagram reformulations: 例如，这是我的图表重构之一：

After my fiancé drew it up, it turned out like this: 未婚夫画好之后，变成了这样：

These are diagram reformulations, and I believe they contain the most untapped potential for the Antinet. It’s truly remarkable how much understanding and knowledge can be communicated through simple diagrams. It’s a practice I’ve never seen Luhmann himself do, yet it’s something I highly recommend integrating into your own repertoire. 这些是重新制定的图表，我相信它们包含 Antinet 尚未开发的潜力。通过简单的图表可以传达多少理解和知识，这真是了不起。这是我从未见过 Luhmann 本人做过的练习，但我强烈建议将其融入你自己的曲目中。

The earliest human communication through time, using physical representation, was expressed not in words, but in pictures—using pictographs and cave paintings.[736](#footnote-705) 最早的人类穿越时间的交流，使用物理表示，不是用文字，而是用图片来表达——使用象形文字和洞穴壁画。 736

According to some research, diagram reformulations are more effective in procuring long-term recall of material, and they have been shown to greatly facilitate many forms of learning.[737](#footnote-704) The biggest limiting factor of diagram reformulations is the time they require to make.[738](#footnote-703) 根据一些研究，图表重构更有效地获得材料的长期回忆，并且它们已被证明极大地促进了多种形式的学习。 737 图表重构的最大限制因素是它们需要制作的时间。 738

Not only do Diagram reformulations require more time to create, often, they also require more time to comprehend. With complex diagrams, it’s almost easier to comprehend something by simply ingesting a page of text. This is why it’s helpful to adhere to a few best practices and guidelines when creating diagrams. 重新制定图表不仅需要更多时间来创建，而且通常还需要更多时间来理解。对于复杂的图表，通过简单地摄取一页文本几乎更容易理解某些东西。这就是为什么在创建图表时遵循一些最佳实践和指南会很有帮助。

**best practices for diagram reformulations 图表重构的最佳实践**

Research holds that the best diagrams “portray a series of steps, in a cause-and-effect chain, with explanatory text that is integrated with the illustrations.” Research studies also suggest diagrams are “more effective than a purely verbal summary.”[739](#footnote-702) However, again it’s important to note the importance of creating cause-and-effect chains in your diagrams because cause-and-effect chains are more effective representations than a mere listing of facts. 研究认为，最好的图表 “描绘了因果链中的一系列步骤，并附有与插图相结合的解释性文字。” 研究还表明，图表“比纯粹的口头总结更有效。”739 然而，再次强调在图表中创建因果链的重要性很重要，因为因果链比简单的描述更有效。仅仅列出事实。

The best diagrams have two traits. They are concise and coherent.[740](#footnote-701) In exhibiting concision, they are simple illustrations with labels one to four words in length. Coherence is manifested when the elements are relevant and connected and show a simple cause-and-effect chain. The label corresponds congruently with the illustration or graphic it’s paired with. 最好的图表有两个特点。它们简洁而连贯。740 为了表现简洁，它们是简单的插图，标签长度为 1 到 4 个词。当元素相关且相互关联并显示出简单的因果链时，就会体现出连贯性。标签与其配对的插图或图形一致对应。

**Reflection Notes 反思笔记**

In teaching about the types of notes used in an Antinet, I’ve tried my best to simplify things as much as possible. If I wanted to simplify the four types of notes even further, I’d find myself tempted to figure out a way to combine observation notes into reflection notes. However, this simply does not reflect reality. Observation notes and reflection notes are two distinct types of notes. 在教授 Antinet 中使用的音符类型时，我已尽最大努力尽可能简化事情。如果我想进一步简化这四种类型的笔记，我会发现自己很想找出一种将观察笔记组合成反思笔记的方法。然而，这根本不反映现实。观察笔记和反思笔记是两种截然不同的笔记类型。

Antonin Sertillanges points out, “Reading itself should awaken reflection.”[741](#footnote-700) Yet readers cannot expect to simply stop every time they have a thought and reflect deeply on it. Reflection requires some time to ruminate and think about material. Reflection first requires a thought or observation about the material being read, and then it requires some time to ruminate and think about it. This is why it’s helpful to first extract observations onto bibcards during reading. This enables you to let the thought ruminate and then to allocate time later to reflect on it.Antonin Sertillanges 指出，“阅读本身应该唤醒反思。”741 然而，读者不能指望每次有想法时就停下来并对其进行深刻反思。反思需要一些时间来反思和思考材料。反思首先需要对正在阅读的材料进行思考或观察，然后需要一些时间来反思和思考它。这就是为什么在阅读过程中首先将观察结果提取到 bibcard 上是有帮助的。这使您能够让想法反复思考，然后分配时间来反思它。

Robert Boyle seems to support this notion, as well. Boyle argued that while reading, our thoughts must be analyzed so “our reflections on what we have observ’d, improves it into consequences new Axioms and Uses.”[742](#footnote-699) Boyle points to the process of turning your observation notes into well-developed reflection notes later on. 罗伯特博伊尔似乎也支持这一观点。博伊尔认为，在阅读时，我们的思想必须得到分析，这样 “我们对所观察到的东西的反思，将其改进为新的公理和用途的结果。”742 博伊尔指出了将你的观察笔记变成完善的反思笔记的过程稍后的。

So what are reflections? 那么什么是反射？

Reflections are notes in which you apply your own experiences, meaning, interpretations, opinions, conclusions, and decisions to material. It’s where you begin to inject your own theory into units of knowledge. The Antinet process is founded on taking complex sources of knowledge, and simplifying them into understandable units. From there you begin assembling more complexity into those units of knowledge again. This is done by way of creating reflection notes. 反思是您将自己的经历、意义、解释、观点、结论和决定应用于材料的笔记。这是你开始将自己的理论注入知识单元的地方。 Antinet 过程的基础是获取复杂的知识来源，并将它们简化为可理解的单元。从那里你开始再次将更多的复杂性组装到这些知识单元中。这是通过创建反思笔记来完成的。

One of the areas where Ahrens and I seem to agree is in the area of elaborative rehearsal. This involves thinking about the meaning of an idea and explaining the concept in your own words.[743](#footnote-698) This type of process encapsulates what takes place within reflection notes. Awareness of the power of elaborative rehearsal is not new. It’s an ancient notion expressed by classical scholars in the motto notae propriae, notae optimae, meaning “your own notes are the best notes.”[744](#footnote-697)Ahrens 和我似乎同意的领域之一是精心排练。这涉及思考一个想法的含义并用您自己的话解释这个概念。743 这种类型的过程封装了反思笔记中发生的事情。对精心排练的力量的认识并不新鲜。这是古典学者在座右铭 notae propriae notae optimae 中表达的一个古老概念，意思是 “你自己的笔记是最好的笔记。”744

So what do reflection notes look like? They are longer in nature than observation notes, typically filling up an entire 4 x 6 inch notecard. Think of reflection notes as medium-sized paragraphs. 那么反思笔记是什么样的呢？它们在本质上比观察笔记更长，通常会填满一整张 4 x 6 英寸的记事卡。将反思笔记视为中等大小的段落。

Here is an example of a reflection note: 这是一个反思笔记的例子：

In this note I am reflecting on an observation I made while listening to a podcast on Luhmann’s Antinet.[745](#footnote-696) At roughly the twenty-four minute and thirty second mark in the video, Johannes Schmidt shared something I found irresistible. I decided to select this observation as important and then extract the observation onto my bibcard. The observation was simply that three thousand manuscripts were found in Luhmann’s literary estate after he passed away. I found this to be a shockingly large amount of material. Imagine what three thousand drafts of papers you’re working on would look like! I then decided to reflect on this idea, which made me realize that Luhmann’s thinking did not exclusively take place in his Antinet alone. It may have originated in the Antinet. However, at least some of his thinking was extended by writing out his ideas in the manuscripts. 在这篇笔记中，我反思了我在 Luhmann 的 Antinet 上收听播客时所做的观察。745 在视频的大约 24 分 30 秒处，Johannes Schmidt 分享了一些我觉得无法抗拒的东西。我决定将此观察结果选为重要的，然后将其提取到我的 bibcard 上。观察只是在卢曼去世后在他的文学遗产中发现了三千份手稿。我发现这是一个惊人的大量材料。想象一下您正在处理的三千份论文草稿会是什么样子！于是我决定反思这个想法，这让我意识到卢曼的思考并不仅仅发生在他的反网络中。它可能起源于 Antinet。然而，至少他的一些想法通过在手稿中写下他的想法得到了扩展。

Here’s the important part: this reflection did not happen in my mind before I wrote the reflection note. Rather it happened as I wrote the reflection note. This reflection note is my thinking. This reflection note is where the idea came from. It did not happen as a pre-conceived step that occurred in my mind before I actually sat down to write it. This, my friend, shows the true power of the Antinet. It expresses the power of writing by hand. The act of writing by hand enables you to reflect more effectively than you would by typing on a keyboard like a hyperactive monkey (one that deludes itself into thinking it forms thoughts exclusively in the mind). Thinking can certainly happen by way of keyboard; however, I contend the best ideas emerge by way of reflection with only pen and paper at hand. After which, keyboards should serve as the place to revise, edit and clarify your thoughts. 这是重要的部分：在我写反思笔记之前，这种反思并没有发生在我的脑海中。相反，它发生在我写反思笔记的时候。这篇反思笔记是我的想法。这个反思笔记就是这个想法的来源。在我真正坐下来写它之前，它并没有作为我脑海中出现的先入为主的步骤发生。我的朋友，这显示了 Antinet 的真正力量。它表达了手写的力量。手写的行为比你像一只过度活跃的猴子（自欺欺人地认为它只在头脑中形成思想）在键盘上打字更有效地反思。思考当然可以通过键盘发生；然而，我认为最好的想法是通过手头只有笔和纸的反思产生的。之后，键盘应该成为修改、编辑和澄清你的想法的地方。

Here is an example of Luhmann’s reflection notes: 这是卢曼反思笔记的一个例子：

photo credit: “ZK I: Zettel 12,16k—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed April 21, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_12-16k_V)/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_12-16k_V. 照片来源：“ZK I：Zettel 12,16k—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2022 年 4 月 21 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_12-16k_V。

Here’s the English translation of the note: 这是注释的英文翻译：

12.16k In modern thinking, the question of the horizon of law is posed as a question of justification, as a question of the justification of law.12.16k 在现代思维中，法律范围的问题被作为正当化问题提出，作为法律正当化问题。

This probably has something to do with the possibility of disposing of the legal system as a whole. 这大概与整个法制的处置可能性有关。

The possibilities of justification are varied; Eg measurement based on the purpose of social performance, i.e. on the extra-legal. Or justification based on a mentally worked out idea of justice; or a basic logical norm (justification as methodical deduction). 辩护的可能性是多种多样的；例如，基于社会绩效目的的衡量，即法外的衡量。或基于头脑中形成的正义观念的辩护；或基本的逻辑规范（作为有条不紊的推论的理由）。

One has to ask oneself whether this way of posing the horizon question in legal matters has become unavoidable due to the fact of positivity or sovereignty in law. 人们不得不问自己，这种在法律事务中提出地平线问题的方式是否由于法律的实证性或主权的事实而变得不可避免。

Note how Luhmann makes a statement or observation (“In modern thinking…”). Yet he then begins reflecting on this observation (“This probably has something to do with…”). 注意卢曼是如何发表声明或观察的（“在现代思维中……”）。然而，他随后开始反思这一观察（“这可能与…… 有关”）。

This gives you a glimpse into the nature of reflection notes. The lines between different note types get blurry when you zoom in: sometimes your reflection notes will need to contain an excerpt, or you may use an excerpt before you begin to reflect on the author’s point. You may also desire to use an excerpt in your reflection note to prove your point or to first reformulate material before you reflect on it. Again, every category gets fuzzy when you zoom in close enough. The main characteristic that differentiates a reflection note from the others, however, is that you write the note as if it will be used as a paragraph or section in the project you’re actively working on. 这使您可以瞥见反思笔记的本质。当您放大时，不同笔记类型之间的界限变得模糊：有时您的反思笔记需要包含摘录，或者您可以在开始反思作者的观点之前使用摘录。您可能还希望在反思笔记中使用摘录来证明您的观点，或者在反思之前首先重新组织材料。同样，当您放大得足够近时，每个类别都会变得模糊。然而，将反思笔记与其他笔记区分开来的主要特征是，您在撰写笔记时就好像它将用作您正在积极从事的项目中的段落或部分一样。

This brings us back to the whole notion of growth vs. contribution. In brief, focus on contribution so that you can grow more. 这让我们回到增长与贡献的整个概念。简而言之，专注于贡献，这样你才能成长得更多。

**Write Reflection Notes as If You’re Teaching 像教学一样写反思笔记**

One individual who has taught me a lot in regards to entrepreneurship and marketing is Russell Brunson. I don’t relate to Brunson on all levels (as I’m not a Mormon with five children, nor do I look like a fifteen year-old boy); still, I greatly admire his enthusiasm and knowledge when it comes to marketing and entrepreneurship. 拉塞尔 · 布伦森 (Russell Brunson) 在创业和营销方面教会了我很多东西。我在各个层面上都与布伦森不相关（因为我不是有五个孩子的摩门教徒，我看起来也不像一个十五岁的男孩）；尽管如此，我还是非常钦佩他在营销和创业方面的热情和知识。

Brunson has built a multi-hundred million dollar company with over five hundred employees. What’s more, he runs it while regularly putting out great content for entrepreneurs. One of Brunson’s practices centers on the idea of getting an immediate return on investment (ROI) out of every one of his activities. 布伦森建立了一家价值数亿美元的公司，拥有超过 500 名员工。更重要的是，他在运营它的同时定期为企业家发布精彩内容。 Brunson 的一项实践以从他的每一项活动中获得即时投资回报 (ROI) 的想法为中心。

During one period, Brunson got sucked into reading the 1,168 page book, Atlas Shrugged. He had decided to read it because he had heard it mentioned over and over throughout his life. Now, this is a very long book that took him many months to read; it took him away from the time he would have otherwise allocated to his company and his family. Atlas Shrugged has many deep philosophical lessons that can serve as important frameworks to holds in one’s mind for life; yet its ideas are not immediately practical. 有一段时间，布伦森沉迷于阅读 1,168 页的书《阿特拉斯耸耸肩》(Atlas Shrugged)。他决定读一读它，因为他一生都听过一遍又一遍地提到它。现在，这是一本很长的书，他花了好几个月才读完；这让他失去了原本可以分配给公司和家人的时间。阿特拉斯耸耸肩有许多深刻的哲学教训，可以作为重要的框架，让人们终生铭记于心；但它的想法并不立即实用。

Therefore, because the book has a long-term ROI, instead of a short-term, immediate ROI, what Brunson decided to do was turn the experience of reading the book into a three-part series on his popular podcast. In effect he was able to get an immediate ROI out of reading a behemoth- sized book. 因此，因为这本书有长期的投资回报率，而不是短期的、即时的投资回报率，布伦森决定做的是将阅读这本书的经历变成他受欢迎的播客上的三部分系列。实际上，他能够通过阅读一本巨著而立即获得投资回报。

Because he focuses on sharing what he learns while he’s still growing, he was then able to teach the book Atlas Shrugged to his audience, leading him to attain a richer understanding by teaching it. “If you really want to learn something, write a book on it,” Brunson says.[746](#footnote-695) In turn, he got an immediate ROI out of the book by providing his audience with valuable content, keeping his community engaged and growing. 因为他在成长过程中专注于分享他所学到的东西，所以他能够将《阿特拉斯耸耸肩》这本书教给他的听众，通过教学使他获得更丰富的理解。 “如果你真的想学习一些东西，就写一本书，” 布伦森说。746 反过来，他通过向读者提供有价值的内容、保持他的社区参与和发展，从书中立即获得了投资回报。

The lesson here is that the process is not about constant, never-ending growth; it’s about constant, never-ending contribution. 这里的教训是，这个过程不是关于持续的、永无止境的增长；而是关于不断增长的。这是关于持续不断的贡献。

Write your reflection notes as if you’re teaching an audience. Through teaching, we gain a deeper understanding of material. Strive to make the material something you could share with your audience as quickly as is feasible. Even if you don’t end up sharing the content, when you stumble upon the note several years later, you’ll find the material easier to understand. 写下你的反思笔记，就好像你在教观众一样。通过教学，我们对材料有了更深刻的理解。努力使材料成为您可以尽快与听众分享的东西。即使您最终没有分享这些内容，当您在几年后偶然发现该笔记时，您也会发现这些材料更容易理解。

**Reformulation vs. Reflection 重新制定与反思**

Sometimes people get confused about the difference between reformulation notes and reflection notes. One of the best ways to think of this relates to differences in the nature of comprehension vs. understanding. 有时人们会对重新制定笔记和反思笔记之间的区别感到困惑。思考这个问题的最佳方式之一涉及理解与理解的本质差异。

Comprehension is the process of grasping the meaning of something. The particular emphasis of comprehension focuses on the phase transition from not understanding something at all to having a basic-level understanding of what something is. 理解是理解事物意义的过程。理解力的特别强调侧重于从根本不理解某事到对某事有基本理解的阶段转变。

Understanding, on the other hand, is the process of grasping something fully via both comprehension and also experience. When you understand a concept you possess deeper-level knowledge of the material. You both comprehend the material theoretically, but you also understand the deep meaning of the material because you’ve experience it—you’ve lived it. 另一方面，理解是通过理解和经验充分掌握事物的过程。当您理解一个概念时，您就拥有了对材料的更深层次的知识。你们都从理论上理解了材料，但你们也理解了材料的深层含义，因为你已经体验过它——你已经体验过它。

When you employ reformulation notes, you’re aiming for comprehension. You’re aiming to grasp a basic-level comprehension of a concept. Your goal is to capture the essence of the concept in your own way. 当你使用重新制定的笔记时，你的目标是理解。您的目标是掌握对概念的基本理解。你的目标是以你自己的方式抓住概念的本质。

When you employ reflection notes, you’re aiming for understanding. You’re aiming to add your own experiences to the material. With reflection notes you add your own perspective, experiments, conclusions, opinions, and decisions on the material. Your goal with reflection notes is to achieve not comprehension, but understanding. 当你使用反思笔记时，你的目标是理解。您的目标是将自己的经验添加到材料中。通过反思笔记，您可以在材料上添加自己的观点、实验、结论、意见和决定。反思笔记的目标不是理解，而是理解。

**Guidelines for Main Notes 主要笔记指南**
------------------------------------

I lump the notes written on maincards (excerpts, reformulations, and reflections) under the category of main notes. We’ll now cover some very important guidelines to follow before creating main notes. 我将写在主卡上的笔记（摘录、重新表述和反思）归为主要笔记类别。我们现在将介绍在创建主要笔记之前要遵循的一些非常重要的指南。

**Before You Begin Writing a Main Note 在开始写主要笔记之前**

Before you even create a main note, you must complete an important step. You must first review your Antinet and determine where you want the maincard (that you’re about to create) to go. This forces you to review previous lines of thinking and, more importantly, it helps you avoid wasting life energy in re-writing something you’ve already written. 在创建主笔记之前，您必须完成一个重要步骤。您必须首先检查您的 Antinet 并确定您希望主卡（您将要创建的）去哪里。这会迫使你回顾以前的思路，更重要的是，它可以帮助你避免浪费生命精力重写你已经写过的东西。

After reading and creating bibnotes, Luhmann states: “After finishing the book I go through my notes and think how these notes might be relevant for already written notes in the [Antinet].”[747](#footnote-694) 在阅读和创建 bibnotes 之后，Luhmann 说：“读完这本书后，我浏览了我的笔记，并思考这些笔记如何与 [Antinet] 中已经写好的笔记相关。”747

What Luhmann highlights is that before actually writing the main note, he goes through his Antinet and figures out where the note will be placed. At this point he still has not even turned the observation note into a main note.Luhmann 强调的是，在真正写下主要笔记之前，他会仔细检查他的 Antinet 并弄清楚笔记将被放置在哪里。此时他连观察笔记都还没有变成主笔记。

**Don’t Create a Maincard for Every Idea** on Your Bibcard 不要为 Bibcard 上的每个想法创建主卡

Luhmann didn’t develop every idea into a main note. He would let some ruminate and prove themselves useful. They would prove themselves useful if he ever decided to work on a book or paper publication relevant to the material.[748](#footnote-693) 卢曼并没有把每一个想法都发展成一个主要的笔记。他会让一些人深思熟虑并证明自己有用。如果他决定从事与该材料相关的书籍或纸质出版物，它们将证明自己有用。 748

For instance, let’s say Luhmann already had a note that outlined the difference between knowledge and information. If he came across a discussion of knowledge vs. information and, if he wasn’t sure he would use the card, he would not create a new dedicated main note for it. He wouldn’t spend the time creating an excerpt note, reformulation note, or reflection note. Rather, he would simply create an external reference (ExRef) for it. For instance, here’s one of Luhmann’s notes on the concept of function (the idea that each part of society has a specific role or function). 例如，假设卢曼已经有一张笔记概述了知识和信息之间的区别。如果他遇到关于知识与信息的讨论，并且如果他不确定自己是否会使用该卡片，他就不会为其创建新的专用主笔记。他不会花时间创建摘录笔记、重新制定的笔记或反思笔记。相反，他会简单地为它创建一个外部引用 (ExRef)。例如，这是卢曼关于功能概念的笔记之一（社会的每一部分都有特定的角色或功能）。

photo credit: “ZK II: Zettel 21 (1) - Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed April 22, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21_1_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21_1_V). 照片来源：“ZK II：Zettel 21 (1) - Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2022 年 4 月 22 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21_1_V。

On this card are a list of ExRefs to pages in books. Luhmann lists the authors’ last name, the year the book was published, and the page numbers. 这张卡片上是书籍页面的 ExRef 列表。卢曼列出了作者的姓氏、出版年份和页码。

If the page ends in ff this connotes the Latin term folio which means “and the following pages”. Therefore, Merton 19ff translates to page 19 and the following pages in the book by Merton. 如果页面以 ff 结尾，这意味着拉丁术语 folio，意思是 “和以下页面”。因此，Merton 19ff 翻译为 Merton 的书中的第 19 页和以下页面。

In Luhmann’s second Antinet, he had sixty-seven thousand maincards (mostly of reformulations and reflections of what he had read).[749](#footnote-692) He had fifteen thousand bibcards which were filled with brief observations he had made while reading different works (with corresponding page numbers). These bibcards usually contained ten to thirty observations notes. 在卢曼的第二部 Antinet 中，他有六万七千张主要卡片（主要是对他所读内容的重新表述和反思）。749 他有一万五千张卡片，上面写满了他在阅读不同作品时所做的简短观察（带有相应的页码） . 这些卡片通常包含十到三十个观察笔记。

So let’s recap: Luhmann’s second Antinet contained sixty-seven thousand maincards and fifteen thousand bibcards. This means that for every bibcard, there were four or five maincards. In effect, this means Luhmann did not turn every observation note on a bibcard into a maincard. Much of the time he would just create ExRefs for the idea. 让我们回顾一下：卢曼的第二个 Antinet 包含六万七千张主卡和一万五千张双卡。这意味着对于每个 bibcard，有四或五个主卡。实际上，这意味着卢曼并没有将 bibcard 上的每条观察记录都变成主卡。大多数时候，他只是为这个想法创建 ExRef。

**Other Types of Notes 其他类型的笔记**
--------------------------------

What you have just learned about are the four main types of notes in an Antinet. I wish it was as simple as that—actually, I wish it was even simpler than that! However, there are a few other types of notes that are useful in the system. 您刚刚了解的是 Antinet 中的四种主要类型的音符。我希望就这么简单——实际上，我希望它比这更简单！但是，还有一些其他类型的注释在系统中很有用。

**Collectives 集体**

In Johannes Schmidt’s categorization of the types of links in Luhmann’s Antinet, there is one type that he calls “collective references.”[750](#footnote-691) In network-theory terms, this kind of linked “array” is referred to as a hub. In some Zettelkasten circles, these are called hub notes.[751](#footnote-690) Personally, I like referring to these cards as collectives. 在 Johannes Schmidt 对 Luhmann Antinet 中链接类型的分类中，有一种类型被他称为 “集体引用”。750 在网络理论术语中，这种链接的“阵列” 被称为集线器。在一些 Zettelkasten 圈子中，这些被称为中心笔记。751 就个人而言，我喜欢将这些卡片称为集体。

Collectives are types of notes that contain a collection of items. 集合是包含项目集合的笔记类型。

There are several different types of collectives. Let’s briefly go through each of them now. 有几种不同类型的集体。现在让我们简要介绍一下它们中的每一个。

**Cardlink CollectivesCardlink 集体**

Cardlink collectives are simply notes that contain a list of links to other cards. These help group cards together based on a specific idea.Cardlink 集合只是包含指向其他卡片的链接列表的注释。这些有助于根据特定想法将卡片组合在一起。

Here’s an example of a cardlink collective from Luhmann: 这是 Luhmann 的 cardlink 集合示例：

You can see a few keyterms on the left-hand side, followed by some cardlinks (like 3414/11g9). 您可以在左侧看到一些关键词，然后是一些卡片链接（例如 3414/11g9）。

Here’s an example from my own Antinet: 这是我自己的 Antinet 的一个例子：

These cardlinks point to notes that support my assertion that Luhmann modeled his Antinet after human memory. Over time, the collective grew as I came upon more examples to support my claim. The green checkmarks under each cardlink indicate that I’ve integrated the material into this book. 这些卡片链接指向的注释支持我的断言，即卢曼根据人类记忆模拟了他的 Antinet。随着时间的推移，随着我找到更多的例子来支持我的主张，这个集体也在壮大。每个卡片链接下的绿色复选标记表示我已将这些材料整合到本书中。

**ExRef CollectivesExRef 集体**

An ExRef collective is a collection of references to external sources. In other words, ExRef collectives reference certain books and their specific page number(s).ExRef 集合是对外部资源的引用的集合。换句话说，ExRef 集合引用某些书籍及其特定页码。

photo credit: “ZK I: Zettel 17 (1)—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed April 22, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_1_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_1_V). 照片来源：“ZK I：Zettel 17 (1)—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2022 年 4 月 22 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_1_V。

In this, titled Ideology Literature (underlined in red), there is a list of books with the bibliographic information and page numbers. This is a collective of external references related to ideology. Luhmann typically placed his ExRef collectives near the beginning of his section for the topic to which it related. For instance, this is the second card found in the section on ideology. 在这个标题为 “意识形态文学”（红色下划线）的目录中，有一个带有书目信息和页码的书籍列表。这是与意识形态相关的外部参考资料的集合。 Luhmann 通常将他的 ExRef 集合放在与其相关主题相关的部分的开头附近。例如，这是意识形态部分中的第二张卡片。

**Branch Collectives 支部集体**

In the beginning branch of each of Luhmann’s main section, he included a collective of cardlinks. These collectives were specifically designed to provide links to other areas of interest related to the branch. I call these types of collectives, branch collectives. As an example, upon navigating to Luhmann’s branch on ideology, one is presented with this branch collective: 在 Luhmann 的每个主要部分的开始分支中，他都包含了一组卡片链接。这些集合专门用于提供与该分支相关的其他感兴趣领域的链接。我称这些类型的集体为分支集体。例如，在导航到卢曼的意识形态分支时，会出现这个分支集体：

photo credit: “ZK I: Note 17 (2)—Niklas Luhmann Archive,” accessed July 13, 2021, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_2_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_2_V). 照片来源：“ZK I：注释 17 (2)—Niklas Luhmann 档案”，2021 年 7 月 13 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_1_NB_17_2_V。

Here’s the translation: 这是翻译：

17 ideology17 意识形态

Links: 7 , especially 7.9 ; 7.7g7 ; 7.7g6d 13.5o ; 83.2c5f 链接：7，尤其是 7.9； 7.7g7; 7.7g6d 13.5o ; 83.2c5f

60.4l1860.4l18

ideology and legitimacy 54.2 意识形态和合法性 54.2

ideology / division of labor 44.1b ; 44.5(e) 意识形态 / 分工 44.1b ; 44.5(e)

formal / informal ideology 70.6 正式 / 非正式意识形态 70.6

ideology / responsibility 71.2g 思想 / 责任 71.2g

systematic connection 28.10l5a (rationality of the org. ) 系统联系 28.10l5a（组织的合理性）

ideology / hierarchy 49.20 意识形态 / 等级制度 49.20

ideology / authority 45.1k2 意识形态 / 权威 45.1k2

ideology / honor 45.8c4 意识形态 / 荣誉 45.8c4

Here is a picture of one of my own branch collectives: 这是我自己的一个分支集体的照片：

This branch collective is for my content related to Zettelkasten. At the time it was created I was still referring to the system as Zettelkasten because I hadn’t yet conceived of the term Antinet! This goes to show how knowledge evolves in the Antinet. My own Antinet developed the term Antinet. It doesn’t get more meta than that! 这个分支集体是为了我与 Zettelkasten 相关的内容。在创建它时，我仍然将该系统称为 Zettelkasten，因为我还没有想到 Antinet 这个词！这表明知识是如何在 Antinet 中演变的。我自己的 Antinet 开发了术语 Antinet。没有比这更多的元数据了！

**Outline Collectives 大纲集体**

There’s one more type of collective it’s important to introduce: I like to refer to these as outline collectives. 还有一种重要的集体需要介绍：我喜欢将它们称为大纲集体。

The book you’re reading right now was organized using outline collectives. Think of these as a table of contents for a book or project you’re working on. 您正在阅读的这本书是使用大纲集合组织的。将这些视为您正在从事的书籍或项目的目录。

Each card is dedicated to a certain topic or idea. Accommodating the idea is a list of cardlinks where you can find the material pertaining to the idea. 每张卡片都专门针对某个主题或想法。容纳这个想法的是一个卡片链接列表，您可以在其中找到与该想法相关的材料。

Unlike cardlink collectives or branch collectives, these types of collectives are more likely to be prearranged and planned. Whereas branch collectives are typically grown over a longer timeframe, outline collectives are created in a short time window in order to outline a project. 与 cardlink 集体或分支集体不同，这些类型的集体更有可能是预先安排和计划的。分支集体通常在较长的时间范围内成长，而大纲集体则在较短的时间窗口内创建以概述项目。

The best way to explain this is to see pictures of my outline collective for this book: 解释这一点的最好方法是查看我为本书编写的大纲集体图片：

This shows an outline of the main sections of this book. 这显示了本书主要部分的大纲。

Here’s a closer look at outline collectives: 下面是大纲集合的详细介绍：

My outline collectives not only include cardlinks, they contain ExRefs as well. See the pink card containing ExRefs pointing to sources I needed to research when writing the section: 我的大纲集合不仅包含卡片链接，还包含 ExRef。请参阅包含 ExRef 的粉红色卡片，指向我在编写该部分时需要研究的来源：

In brief, outline collectives are quite useful when using an Antinet. I recommend using branch collectives to allow your research to build itself from the bottom-up. When it comes time to working on your project or book, then it’s time to create outline collectives. At that phase you simply review the material that has been growing in your branch collectives and then build out some logical groups for the content. 简而言之，大纲集合在使用 Antinet 时非常有用。我建议使用分支集体让你的研究自下而上地建立起来。当需要处理您的项目或书籍时，就该创建大纲集体了。在那个阶段，您只需回顾在您的分支集体中增长的材料，然后为这些内容构建一些逻辑组。

Building out projects using outline collectives is where the analog nature of the Antinet truly begins to shine. You lay out each outline collective card on a table and rearrange them until it forms the perfect outline for your project or book. 使用大纲集合构建项目是 Antinet 的模拟性质真正开始闪耀的地方。您将每张大纲集体卡片放在桌子上并重新排列它们，直到它形成您的项目或书籍的完美大纲。

From there, you fire up a word editor and begin typing out each section. Contrary to what you might think, it’s not a boring process to type each note out word-for-word. Rather it’s engaging because it’s collaborative in nature. And here’s the best part: most of the hard work has already been done for you. This is precisely what Luhmann meant when he said his books wrote themselves.[752](#footnote-689) 从那里，你启动一个文字编辑器并开始输入每个部分。与您的想法相反，逐字逐句地打出每个笔记并不是一个无聊的过程。相反，它之所以吸引人，是因为它本质上是协作的。这是最好的部分：大部分艰苦的工作已经为您完成。这正是卢曼所说的他的书自己写的意思。 752

**Keyterm Indexcards vs. Collectives 关键词索引卡与集体**

In a way, keyterm indexcards are also a type of collective. For instance, here’s a picture of a keyterm indexcard: 在某种程度上，关键词索引卡也是一种集体。例如，这是一张关键字索引卡的图片：

However, there are some distinctions between collectives and keyterm indexcards. The more obvious difference is that collective cards are contained in the main box (and keyterm indexcards are contained in the index box). Keyterm indexcards are organized by keyterm, whereas collectives have a numeric-alpha address. 但是，集合和关键字索引卡之间存在一些区别。更明显的区别是集合卡包含在主框中（而关键字索引卡包含在索引框中）。关键字索引卡按关键字组织，而集合具有数字字母地址。

Both types of cards have their own distinct uses. Keyterm indexcards are often quicker to look up (as you only have to think of the keyterm). However, cardlink collectives inside the main box of your Antinet are useful as well. While surfing through a stem of thought, cardlink collectives connect you to a bunch of other vines and areas in your tree of knowledge. This oftentimes proves useful when you’re in a more exploratory mode (sifting through cards). 两种类型的卡片都有其独特的用途。关键字索引卡通常可以更快地查找（因为您只需要考虑关键字）。但是，Antinet 主框中的 cardlink 集合也很有用。在浏览思想干时，cardlink 集体将您连接到您知识树中的一堆其他藤蔓和区域。当您处于更具探索性的模式（筛选卡片）时，这通常会被证明是有用的。

**Hoplink Cards 链接卡**

The last type of note is what I call a hoplink card. These are very straightforward, essentially containing a brief snippet of text that says For more on x concept, see cardlink ‘xxxx/xx/x’. 最后一种类型的笔记就是我所说的跳链卡。这些非常简单，基本上包含一小段文字，上面写着有关 x 概念的更多信息，请参阅卡片链接 “xxxx/xx/x”。

Here’s an example hoplink card: 这是一个跳转链接卡示例：

Here’s one from Luhmann’s Antinet: 这是 Luhmann 的 Antinet 中的一个：

photo credit: “ZK II: Zettel 21/8o3b - Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed April 22, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-8o3b_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-8o3b_V). 照片来源：“ZK II：Zettel 21/8o3b - Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2022 年 4 月 22 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-8o3b_V。

Hoplinks are useful for breaking up certain stems of thought by linking to another relevant area in the Antinet.Hoplinks 对于通过链接到 Antinet 中的另一个相关区域来分解某些想法很有用。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

The creation phase is perhaps the most enjoyable, yet one of the hardest phases of knowledge development. In this phase you’re actually forced to think deeply. This isn’t easy work, though for some reason the nature of writing by hand makes this difficult process more enjoyable. 创造阶段也许是最令人愉快的，但却是知识发展中最困难的阶段之一。在这个阶段，你实际上被迫深入思考。这不是一件容易的事，尽管出于某种原因，手写的性质使这个困难的过程变得更加愉快。

We’ve covered a lot in this chapter. My advice is to not get overwhelmed. Don’t worry about the other notes for the time being. Just focus on the four big boys: observations, excerpts, reformulations, and reflections. 我们在本章中介绍了很多内容。我的建议是不要不知所措。其他笔记暂时不用管。只关注四个大男孩：观察、摘录、重新表述和反思。

The best style is no style, as Bruce Lee would say. What you’ve been introduced to in this chapter serves as a framework to get you started. Do not be afraid to add your own creativity and tweaks to the system. The most important thing is that you start. Start creating and building. How do you eat an elephant? One bite at a time. How do you create something great? One note at a time. 正如李小龙所说，最好的风格就是没有风格。本章向您介绍的内容可作为您入门的框架。不要害怕为系统添加您自己的创造力和调整。最重要的是你开始了。开始创建和构建。你怎么吃大象？一次咬一口。你如何创造伟大的东西？一次一个音符。

CHAPTER SIXTEEN 第十六章
--------------------

Installation 安装
---------------

Compared to the other chapters in this section on knowledge development, this chapter will be brief. 与本节关于知识发展的其他章节相比，本章将是简短的。

As you may recall from the previous chapter, I advise you to first review your Antinet to determine where to install a card before you begin writing a main note. This is an important step. This step prevents you from rewriting knowledge you’ve already written. It also enables you to evolve your thinking from where you last left off. In essence, you’re evolving the branch or stems of thought in your tree of knowledge. 你可能还记得上一章，我建议你在开始写主笔记之前先检查一下你的 Antinet 以确定卡的安装位置。这是重要的一步。这一步可以防止你重写你已经写过的知识。它还使您能够从上次中断的地方发展您的思维。从本质上讲，您正在发展知识树中的思想分支或思想干。

Due to this prerequisite, figuring out where to install your cards becomes a more manageable endeavor. 由于这个先决条件，找出卡的安装位置变得更容易管理。

In the beginning stages of working with my Antinet, I found myself creating fifteen or so maincards without first figuring out where they should go. This left me with a pile of maincards which made things challenging. It became difficult to go back through my Antinet and figure out where they should go. Moreover, this ended up feeling like tedious homework. It left me wanting to get through the pile as quickly as possible. As a result, I was left with less time and energy to make sure I installed the cards in the best place possible. 在使用我的 Antinet 的开始阶段，我发现自己创建了十五张左右的主卡，但没有先弄清楚它们应该放在哪里。这给我留下了一堆让事情充满挑战的主牌。很难通过我的 Antinet 返回并弄清楚它们应该去哪里。而且，这最终感觉像是繁琐的作业。这让我想尽快通过这堆东西。结果，我没有多少时间和精力来确保将卡安装在尽可能最好的位置。

Reviewing your Antinet and determining where you’ll install the card before you write your main notes results in two things: First, the process of creating and installing notes becomes a lot more fun. And second, the cards end up being installed in more fitting places. 在编写主要笔记之前检查您的 Antinet 并确定您将安装卡的位置有两个结果：首先，创建和安装笔记的过程变得更加有趣。其次，卡片最终被安装在更合适的地方。

One more important reminder: the name of the game is similarity. Your goal is to install the card (or sequence of cards) under or behind its most similar neighbor. 一个更重要的提醒：游戏的名称是相似性。您的目标是将卡片（或卡片序列）安装在其最相似邻居的下方或后面。

When you’re reviewing your Antinet before writing the main note, think of the most similar idea already in the Antinet that it relates to. 当你在写主要笔记之前回顾你的 Antinet 时，想想它相关的 Antinet 中已有的最相似的想法。

Finding the most similar idea, of course, is dependent on one more critical factor: the index. Let’s talk a bit about that now. 当然，找到最相似的想法取决于一个更关键的因素：索引。现在让我们谈谈这个。

**Determining How and When to Index 确定索引的方式和时间**
------------------------------------------------

When you’re installing a note into a sequence of cards within the Antinet, the best case scenario is that you already have the stem of thought indexed. 当你在 Antinet 中将笔记添加到一系列卡片中时，最好的情况是你已经将思想的主干编入索引。

For instance, say in my research I happen upon an idea relating to randomness. The idea discusses how randomness serves as an important function within evolution. Let’s also say I already have a keyterm created in my index for randomness. This makes installing this new idea easy. All I have to do is look up “randomness” in my index. I then navigate to the cardlink it points me to and begin exploring the cards. I then spot the one that’s closest to my new idea and add it under or behind the most similar card. 例如，假设在我的研究中我偶然发现了一个与随机性有关的想法。这个想法讨论了随机性如何在进化中发挥重要作用。假设我已经在我的索引中为随机性创建了一个关键字。这使得安装这个新想法变得容易。我所要做的就是在我的索引中查找 “随机性”。然后我导航到它指向我的卡片链接并开始浏览卡片。然后，我找出最接近我的新想法的一张，并将其添加到最相似的卡片下方或后面。

However what if randomness was not already a keyterm in my index? What would I do then? The first thing I would do is start thinking of what randomness is most similar to. I would think of other concepts such as accidents, change, chaos, entropy, impermanence. Chances are I’d have a keyterm already created for such concepts. 但是，如果随机性在我的索引中还不是关键字怎么办？那我怎么办？我要做的第一件事就是开始思考随机性与什么最相似。我会想到其他概念，例如意外、变化、混沌、熵、无常。很可能我已经为这些概念创建了一个关键词。

In the case I didn’t have keyterms created for closely related concepts, I would create a new stem or a new branch. 如果我没有为密切相关的概念创建关键词，我会创建一个新的主干或一个新的分支。

Now, here’s where we have a decision to make. Here’s where things get interesting. 现在，这是我们要做出决定的地方。这就是事情变得有趣的地方。

There are two scenarios: 有两种情况：

The first scenario is that I’m creating a new maincard on randomness within the context of relating it to how Luhmann’s Zettelkasten works. My branch on the Zettelkasten and Antinet material is 4214. In this scenario, I would either find the most similar stem of cards within 4214, or just create a new stem for it. For instance, I would create the stem 4214/15 and in my index, I would create the entry: Randomness (Zettelkasten): 4214/15. 第一种情况是，我在将随机性与 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten 的工作原理相关联的背景下创建一个新的随机性主卡。我在 Zettelkasten 和 Antinet 材料上的分支是 4214。在这种情况下，我要么在 4214 中找到最相似的卡片主干，要么为它创建一个新的主干。例如，我将创建词干 4214/15，并在我的索引中创建条目：Randomness (Zettelkasten): 4214/15。

The second scenario is that I’m creating a new maincard for randomness within the context of evolution. In this case, I would consult Wikipedia’s Outline of Academic Disciplines. I would then search the keyterm evolution and place it under the branch of evolution. For instance, I would create a branch for Evolutionary Biology and assign it to the branch 3511. I would then create an entry in the index: Randomness (Evolutionary Bio): 3511/1. 第二种情况是我正在为进化的背景下的随机性创建一个新的主卡。在这种情况下，我会参考维基百科的学科大纲。然后，我将搜索关键字 evolution 并将其放在 evolution 的分支下。例如，我会为进化生物学创建一个分支并将其分配给分支 3511。然后我会在索引中创建一个条目：Randomness (Evolutionary Bio): 3511/1。

Chances are, I would choose the first scenario because I find the Antinet works best if I’m actively using it for a project. That is I find it best if I adopt a contribution approach to using it (instead of a personal growth approach to using it). 很有可能，我会选择第一种情况，因为我发现如果我在项目中积极使用 Antinet，它的效果最好。也就是说，我发现最好采用贡献方法来使用它（而不是个人成长方法来使用它）。

In the beginning, you will find yourself needing to create a lot of index keyterm entries. I must caution you not to burn yourself out! In the very beginning, you risk index fatigue. Do not create too many index entries. If you ever have issues finding a maincard, then you know to create an index entry for it (whenever you find it). That way, you won’t waste time having to explore the entirety of your Antinet next time. 一开始，您会发现自己需要创建大量索引关键字条目。我必须警告你不要把自己烧坏！一开始，您可能会面临指数疲劳的风险。不要创建太多索引条目。如果您在查找主卡时遇到问题，那么您就会知道为它创建一个索引条目（无论何时找到它）。这样，下次您就不会浪费时间探索整个 Antinet。

That’s really all there is to discuss on the installation phase of knowledge development. If you follow my advice laid out in the creation phase, the installation phase will be a breeze (or at least easier than it otherwise would)! 这就是知识开发的安装阶段要讨论的全部内容。如果您遵循我在创建阶段提出的建议，安装阶段将变得轻而易举（或者至少比其他方式更容易）！

CHAPTER SEVENTEEN 第十七章
----------------------

Mindset 心态
----------

In this section we’re going to be covering some of the “softer skills” in regard to working with an Antinet. We’ll be covering different work routines, and we’ll cover the mindset one ought to adopt when working with an Antinet. A variety of such lessons are already dispersed throughout this book in relevant sections; yet I think it’s helpful to discuss these lessons in a dedicated place. That’s what this chapter is for. 在本节中，我们将介绍一些与使用 Antinet 有关的 “软技能”。我们将介绍不同的工作程序，我们将介绍在使用 Antinet 时应该采用的思维方式。本书相关章节中已经散布了各种此类课程；但我认为在专门的地方讨论这些课程很有帮助。这就是本章的目的。

**Antinet Work Routine 防网工作例程**
-------------------------------

**The Three States of Antinet Work 反网工作的三种状态**

Deep work sessions are a prerequisite for creating knowledge using an Antinet. Using an Antinet requires a focused environment. However there are three distinct working states involved in this work: (1) an emergence state, and (2) an evolutionary state, and (3) a producing state. 深度工作会议是使用 Antinet 创造知识的先决条件。使用 Antinet 需要一个集中的环境。然而，这项工作涉及三种不同的工作状态：(1) 出现状态，(2) 进化状态，以及 (3) 生产状态。

I call these states (instead of phases or stages) for a reason. A state is something you switch back and forth between. One hour you may be in an emergence state of mind. The next hour you may be in a producing state of mind. The next, you may be in an evolutionary state. This is fine. It’s a natural part of how knowledge development works. It’s not so much a process of sequential phases as it is a dance. Creating knowledge is an asynchronous process where different thoughts are developed concurrently. If you get stuck in one spot, you can easily switch to a different project (or branch of knowledge) and begin developing other thoughts from there. Remember what Luhmann said, “I only write when I know immediately how to do it. If it stops for a moment, I put the thing aside and do something else.”[753](#footnote-766) 我称这些状态（而不是阶段或阶段）是有原因的。状态是您在其中来回切换的东西。一个小时你可能会处于一种紧急状态。接下来的一个小时，您可能会处于生产状态。接下来，您可能处于进化状态。这可以。这是知识开发运作方式的自然组成部分。与其说它是一个连续阶段的过程，不如说它是一种舞蹈。创造知识是一个异步过程，不同的想法是同时发展的。如果你被困在一个地方，你可以轻松地切换到另一个项目（或知识分支）并从那里开始发展其他想法。记住卢曼的话，“我只在我立即知道如何去做时才写作。如果它停了一会儿，我就把它放在一边去做其他事情。”753

**Emergence State 紧急状态**

“Traveler, there is no path, the path must be forged as you walk.”“旅者，本无路，路要边走边开。”

–Antonio Machado[754](#footnote-765)–安东尼奥 · 马查多 754

When in an emergence state, your work is more exploratory. You’re looking for your theories to emerge from the sources you engage with. You’re in research mode. Reading is your primary intellectual activity. In this state, you’re taking many reformulation and excerpt notes. You’re employing the book-to-maincard extraction method. That is, you’re stopping at challenging sections in books and creating a maincard immediately for it. You do this in order to comprehend the material so that you can continue reading the text and understand the rest of the book. 在出现状态时，您的工作更具探索性。您正在寻找从您接触的资源中产生的理论。您处于研究模式。阅读是您的主要智力活动。在这种状态下，你会做很多重新表述和摘录的笔记。您正在使用 book-to-maincard 提取方法。也就是说，您将在书中具有挑战性的部分停下来，并立即为其创建一张主卡。你这样做是为了理解材料，这样你就可以继续阅读文本并理解本书的其余部分。

From this state, theories start to emerge. This is what Brené Brown refers to as emergence and grounded theory research. Brown explains, “Initially I set out, on what I thought was a well-traveled path, to find empirical evidence of what I knew to be true.” Brown then shifted to employing the grounded theory methodology. She shifted to an exploratory way of researching— an emergent way of researching. In this state, she writes, “there is no path and, certainly, there is no way of knowing what you will find.”[755](#footnote-764) 从这种状态开始，理论开始出现。这就是 Brené Brown 所说的涌现和扎根理论研究。 Brown 解释说：“最初，我走的是一条我认为已经走遍的道路，目的是寻找经验证据来证明我所知道的是真实的。” 布朗随后转向采用扎根理论方法。她转向了一种探索性的研究方式——一种新兴的研究方式。在这种状态下，她写道，“没有路径，当然，也没有办法知道你会找到什么。”755

Taking a bottom-up approach to research takes courage. It takes courage to trust that the Antinet will somehow bring theories to the surface. It requires courage to let go and let the readings spark ideas you never predicted. It takes courage to let go of your preconceived notions. 采用自下而上的研究方法需要勇气。相信 Antinet 会以某种方式将理论浮出水面需要勇气。放手需要勇气，让阅读激发您从未预料到的想法。放弃先入为主的观念需要勇气。

When you use an Antinet, you let your readings create your theories from the bottom-up rather than predetermining them in a top-down approach. You don’t go into your research with an already finished theory. You go in with a general intuition and sense, and then let your research make the discoveries for you. This type of research is what the Antinet is built for. 当你使用 Antinet 时，你让你的阅读自下而上地创建你的理论，而不是用自上而下的方法预先确定它们。你不会带着已经完成的理论进入你的研究。你带着一般的直觉和感觉进入，然后让你的研究为你做出发现。 Antinet 就是为这类研究而构建的。

To cultivate the emergence state, I like to allocate two hours in the mornings to reading. I do this as the very first thing I do when I get to the office. I use a block timer that has a one-hour countdown. After the one-hour timer runs out, I reset the timer for another hour. Sometimes, of course, I’ll take a fifteen or so minute break in between the hours. 为了培养涌现状态，我喜欢在早上分配两个小时阅读。当我到达办公室时，我做的第一件事就是这样做。我使用具有一小时倒计时的块计时器。一小时计时器用完后，我将计时器重置为另一个小时。当然，有时我会在工作时间之间休息十五分钟左右。

After these two hours of reading, I’ll typically allocate the rest of the day to further development and installing the material from these readings. 在这两个小时的阅读之后，我通常会分配一天的剩余时间来进一步开发和安装这些阅读材料中的材料。

I like to install the material from the readings into my Antinet that same day. Otherwise I find that notes pile up and installing becomes almost like homework (or something I dread doing). 我喜欢在同一天将阅读材料中的材料安装到我的 Antinet 中。否则我发现笔记堆积如山，安装几乎就像家庭作业（或者我害怕做的事情）。

**Evolutionary State 进化状态**

In the evolutionary state, you’re looking to evolve the ideas that have emerged during your research. You’ll be evolving the ideas by finding material that supports or challenges your emerging theories. 在进化状态下，您正在寻求发展研究过程中出现的想法。您将通过寻找支持或挑战您的新兴理论的材料来发展这些想法。

For instance, in my experience researching Luhmann’s Antinet, one theme that I noticed was the importance of the function of surprises and accidents. In creating any piece of work, surprises and accidents are actually hugely beneficial. Luhmann spoke of this, and it was emphasized in Johannes Schmidt’s writings.[756](#footnote-763) I was not anticipating this concept when I began researching Luhmann’s Antinet. After I extracted this theory onto maincards, I then created a keyterm entry for the concepts (surprises and accidents). I then continued reading more books on knowledge science and human memory. Frequently I would come upon additional material on surprises and accidents. I would then evolve the concepts by adding my reformulations and reflections of the new material. In essence, the ideas that emerged through research continued to then evolve by additional research of other literature. 例如，在我研究 Luhmann 的 Antinet 的过程中，我注意到的一个主题是意外和事故功能的重要性。在创作任何作品时，惊喜和意外实际上是非常有益的。 Luhmann 谈到了这一点，并且在 Johannes Schmidt 的著作中得到了强调。 756 当我开始研究 Luhmann 的 Antinet 时，我并没有预料到这个概念。在我将这个理论提取到主卡上之后，我为概念（惊喜和意外）创建了一个关键词条目。然后我继续阅读更多关于知识科学和人类记忆的书籍。我经常会遇到关于惊喜和事故的额外材料。然后我会通过添加我对新材料的重新表述和思考来发展这些概念。本质上，通过研究出现的想法通过对其他文献的额外研究继续发展。

Let’s once again talk about Brené Brown and grounded theory. At the end of her book Daring Greatly, Brown dedicates an entire section to discussing her research method. She highlights the idea of two different states involved in research. The first state “allows the research problem to emerge from the data.” The second state conducts “a full review of the significant literature.” The literature review served to support the theories she discovered during the emergence phase.[757](#footnote-762) 让我们再次谈谈 Brené Brown 和扎根理论。在她的书 Daring Greatly 的结尾，Brown 用一整节来讨论她的研究方法。她强调了参与研究的两个不同国家的想法。第一种状态 “允许研究问题从数据中浮现”。第二种状态是 “对重要文献进行全面审查”。文献综述有助于支持她在出现阶段发现的理论。 757

I like to think of the second stage as the evolutionary stage. It seems better than the literature review stage. One reason being that sometimes research isn’t actually literature. 我喜欢将第二阶段视为进化阶段。好像比文献综述阶段好。原因之一是有时研究实际上并不是文学。

Anyway, after you’ve extracted a working set of theories and concepts during the emergent phase of your research, your reading style changes (as Luhmann himself pointed out).[758](#footnote-761) In the evolutionary phase you’re capable of quickly spotting, selecting and extracting ideas that are related to the theories you’ve already unearthed. At this point, you’ve already neuroimprinted keyterms on your mind. You are capable of reading differently because any time you spot a related idea, all you need to do is write down the page number and keyterm of the idea on your bibcard. 无论如何，在你的研究的新兴阶段提取了一套有效的理论和概念之后，你的阅读风格会发生变化（正如卢曼自己指出的那样）。758 在进化阶段，你能够快速发现、选择和提取与您已经发现的理论相关的想法。在这一点上，你已经在脑海中留下了关键术语的神经烙印。你能够以不同的方式阅读，因为每当你发现一个相关的想法时，你需要做的就是在你的 bibcard 上写下这个想法的页码和关键词。

As a result of doing this, you begin accumulating material that supports the theories and concepts that were unearthed during the emergent state. In brief, you begin evolving your ideas. 这样做的结果是，您开始积累支持在紧急状态期间发现的理论和概念的材料。简而言之，您开始发展您的想法。

**Producing State 生产国**

Once I’ve done a sufficient amount of research and the material has evolved, I’ll enter the producing state of work. Producing can be creating a podcast episode, a YouTube video, an online course, a song, software, a book, or whatever your craft is. For myself, it’s writing. And the most applicable output for most, is writing. So I’ll talk primarily about that. If I’m writing a book, I’ll aim for an entire drawer full of notecards. If I’m writing a paper, I’d want at least a one-inch pinch of notecards. The material may come from a variety of branches in the Antinet. 一旦我完成了足够多的研究并且材料已经进化，我将进入工作的生产状态。制作可以是制作播客剧集、YouTube 视频、在线课程、歌曲、软件、书籍或您的任何手艺。对我自己来说，就是写作。对于大多数人来说，最适用的输出是写作。所以我主要谈谈这个。如果我正在写一本书，我的目标是让整个抽屉都装满记事卡。如果我正在写一篇论文，我想要至少一英寸的记事卡。这些材料可能来自 Antinet 中的各种分支。

When I’m in producing state, I get to the office in the morning and I write until three or four in the afternoon. Basically, I write all day. I use my notecards to write, and I type in what’s on the notecards. Again, I don’t type the material on the notecards word-for-word. I start typing word-for-word (which kills writer’s block), yet I then expand and clarify the idea I’m trying to convey. I elaborate on the notecard and also add new ideas I’ve since realized. 当我处于生产状态时，我早上到办公室，一直写到下午三四点。基本上，我整天都在写作。我用记事卡写字，然后输入记事卡上的内容。同样，我不会逐字逐句地在记事卡上键入材料。我开始逐字逐句地打字（这消除了作者的障碍），但随后我扩展并阐明了我试图传达的想法。我对记事卡进行了详细说明，并添加了我后来意识到的新想法。

This process is of course broken up by several trips to Starbucks located in the lobby of my building. 这个过程当然会被几次去我大楼大厅的星巴克打断。

**My Work Environment 我的工作环境**

My work environment is primarily analog. I have a private office where I cannot be disturbed. I put my phone on Do Not Disturb Mode and leave it across the room on the floor where it charges. In addition to this, I place lime green earplugs in my ears to block out external noise (lime green is my favorite color). 我的工作环境主要是模拟的。我有一个私人办公室，在那里我不会被打扰。我将手机置于 “请勿打扰” 模式，然后将它放在整个房间的充电地板上。除此之外，我还在耳朵里放了柠檬绿耳塞来阻挡外界噪音（柠檬绿是我最喜欢的颜色）。

I have an analog dictionary and analog thesauri. There’s no excuse for me to use a computer unless I’m writing. When in this state, I use the Ulysses app for writing (Mac only). 我有一本模拟词典和模拟词库。除非我在写作，否则我没有理由使用电脑。在这种状态下，我使用 Ulysses 应用程序进行写作（仅限 Mac）。

**Niklas Luhmann’s Antinet Routine 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的 Antinet 套路**
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Luhmann’s Antinet was actually located at his home. Luhmann lived in Oerlinghausen, which is about a half-hour drive from Bielefeld University where he worked. 卢曼的 Antinet 实际上就在他家里。卢曼住在厄林豪森，距离他工作的比勒费尔德大学约半小时车程。

Luhmann loved to read outdoors in the sun. He also loved to read at libraries. He would give conferences at various universities on the basis of there being a good library on campus.[759](#footnote-760) Perhaps Luhmann would read at Bielefeld’s library during the day. In the evenings he would bring home the bibcards from his readings and transform them into main notes. After this he would file the main notes and bibcard in his Antinet in his home office. 卢曼喜欢在户外晒太阳读书。他还喜欢在图书馆读书。他会在校园里有一个很好的图书馆的基础上在各个大学举行会议。759 也许卢曼白天会在比勒费尔德的图书馆读书。晚上，他会把阅读中的 bibcards 带回家，并将它们转化为主要笔记。在此之后，他会将主要笔记和 bibcard 归档在他家庭办公室的 Antinet 中。

Here’s a photo of Luhmann reading in the sun (with a bibcard hanging out of the book): 这是一张卢曼在阳光下读书的照片（书外挂着一张名片）：

photo credit: Niklas Luhmann—Theory of Society 4\_13 by Schwumbel; philomag, “Niklas Luhmann Und Die Aufrichtigkeit,” Philosophie Magazin, accessed April 26, 2022, [https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit](https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit). 照片来源：Niklas Luhmann—Schwumbel 的社会理论 4\_13； philomag，“Niklas Luhmann Und Die Aufrichtigkeit”，Philosophie Magazin，2022 年 4 月 26 日访问，https://www.philomag.de/artikel/niklas-luhmann-und-die-aufrichtigkeit。

In a biographical interview, Luhmann detailed his routine. We can presume this took place on days where he works from home (which were most days, according to Luhmann’s son, Clemens):[760](#footnote-759) 在一次传记采访中，卢曼详细介绍了他的日常生活。我们可以假设这发生在他在家工作的日子里（根据卢曼的儿子克莱门斯的说法，这是大多数日子）：760

If I have nothing else to do, then I write all day: in the morning from 8:30 a.m. to lunchtime, then I go for a short walk with my dog, then I have time again in the afternoon from 2:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., then it’s the dog’s turn again. Sometimes I also lie down for a quarter of an hour, I have gotten into the habit of resting in a very concentrated way, so that I can get back to work after a short time. Yes, and then I usually write in the evening until around 11:00 p.m. At 11:00 p.m. I usually lie in bed and read a few more things that I can still digest at that time.[761](#footnote-758) 如果我没有别的事可做，那么我会写一整天：早上 8:30 到午餐时间，然后我和我的狗出去散散步，然后下午 2:00 又有时间。到下午 4:00，然后又轮到狗了。有时我也会躺下一刻钟，我已经养成了非常专注地休息的习惯，这样我可以在短时间后重新开始工作。是的，然后我通常在晚上写作，直到晚上 11:00 左右。晚上 11:00 我通常躺在床上，多读一些我当时还能消化的东西。 761

Here are some photos of Luhmann’s office. These photos are taken from a video tour of Luhmann’s office in 1989.[762](#footnote-757) 这是卢曼办公室的一些照片。这些照片取自 1989.762 卢曼办公室的视频之旅

Luhmann’s literary collection, comprising approximately eleven thousand titles. There were rarely any marks or marginalia notes in the books. He took his notes on bibcards. Note the chaise lounge chair. This was Luhmann’s favorite spot, where he both read and took fifteen minute power naps! 卢曼的文学收藏，包括大约一万一千本书。书中很少有任何标记或旁注。他把笔记记在卡片上。注意躺椅。这是 Luhmann 最喜欢的地方，他在这里阅读并小睡 15 分钟！

The floor in front of one of 其中一个前面的地板

Luhmann’s bookshelves. Knowledge 卢曼的书架。知识

work isn’t the most orderly process—工作不是最有序的过程——

even for organized Germans. 即使对于有组织的德国人也是如此。

Luhmann works at his desk. Note the massive red typewriter, and the tea kettle. On the right-hand side of the photo, resting on the floor, is Luhmann’s Zettelkasten (not pictured). 卢曼在他的办公桌前工作。注意巨大的红色打字机和茶壶。照片右侧的地板上放着 Luhmann 的 Zettelkasten（未显示）。

Luhmann reviews some of his main notes. At the top of the photo is Luhmann’s Antinet Zettelkasten with a pile of papers resting on top. 卢曼回顾了他的一些主要笔记。照片的顶部是卢曼的 Antinet Zettelkasten，上面放着一堆文件。

Luhmann reviews his maincards. Resting on the desk is a bibcard from his most recent reading. 卢曼回顾了他的主要名片。桌上放着一张他最近阅读的卡片。

Luhmann navigates his Antinet. He's exploring the contents and refreshing his memory of the material (creating reverberation in his mind). 卢曼在他的 Antinet 中导航。他正在探索内容并刷新他对材料的记忆（在他的脑海中产生回响）。

One other thing of note: Luhmann did not have labels on the outside of his Antinet. He knew his way around the Antinet so well, that he had various branches memorized. The following photo shows Luhmann’s Antinet, which resided on the floor to the left of his desk. **The Antinet Mindset 反网络心态**
-----------------------------

“That is the only way. Without external help of any sort, you go to work  on the book. With nothing but the power of your own mind…”“这是唯一的办法。在没有任何形式的外部帮助的情况下，您可以继续写这本书。只凭自己的意念之力……”

–Mortimer Adler[763](#footnote-756)–莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 763

I’ve said it elsewhere, and I’ll say it here again: getting started with an Antinet isn’t the easiest process. You’ll have to create a lot of keyterms in the index and you have to write a lot of cards. Later on, you won’t have to create as many keyterms, though you’ll still be adding cards to your Antinet. At the beginning, you’re like an airplane taking off. At some point you’ll hit cruise control mode, but it’ll take some effort to get to that point. 我在别处说过，我会在这里再说一遍：开始使用 Antinet 并不是最简单的过程。你必须在索引中创建很多关键词，并且你必须写很多卡片。稍后，您将不必创建那么多关键字，但您仍会向 Antinet 添加卡片。一开始，你就像一架起飞的飞机。在某个时候你会进入巡航控制模式，但要达到那个点需要一些努力。

Luhmann held that it will take a number of years before the payoffs become clear. Until then the Antinet will function merely as a container you put cards into.[764](#footnote-755) I don’t think it will take a number of years. It could be only a few months before you begin to see the value. However you should go into this with a long-term mindset.Luhmann 认为，在回报变得清晰之前，还需要很多年。在那之前，Antinet 将仅充当您将卡片放入其中的容器。764 我认为这不会花很多年。可能只需要几个月的时间，您就会开始看到其价值。但是，您应该以长期的心态来考虑这一点。

**Consistency over the Long Term 长期一致性**

Focus on consistency instead of working away all day like a maniac. Even though I advise this, I’ll admit that when I got my Antinet up and running, I spent a lot of time working away like a maniac. In the beginning, I spent months integrating my previous notes and journals into the Antinet. I even spent many nights printing out my notes from the digital notetaking app I was using for a time. I would print out, and the cut out those digital notes into 4 x 6 inch size cards. As of now, I have maybe a third of my legacy notes installed in the Antinet. However, I stopped after a while because it was taking too much time and the value wasn’t clear. I instead shifted my focus to developing knowledge for my current undertaking and haven’t looked back since. That said, I’ve seen the value of the notes I installed—in fact, I’ve used a bit of the legacy material for this book! 专注于一致性，而不是像疯子一样整天工作。尽管我建议这样做，但我承认，当我启动并运行 Antinet 时，我花了很多时间像疯子一样工作。一开始，我花了几个月的时间将我以前的笔记和日记整合到 Antinet 中。我什至花了很多个晚上从我使用过一段时间的数字笔记应用程序中打印出我的笔记。我会打印出来，然后将这些数字笔记剪成 4 x 6 英寸大小的卡片。截至目前，我可能有三分之一的遗留笔记安装在 Antinet 中。然而，我在一段时间后就停止了，因为它花费了太多时间并且价值不明确。相反，我将注意力转移到为当前的事业发展知识上，此后就再也没有回头。也就是说，我已经看到了我安装的笔记的价值——事实上，我已经为本书使用了一些遗留材料！

The bottom line: focus mainly on the future. Don’t get too hung up on trying to integrate your old (digital) notes into the Antinet. I have thousands of digital notes. It doesn’t matter that they’re not in my Antinet. They’re underdeveloped compared to notes you write by hand. You shouldn’t lose sleep over your digital notes being ported to your Antinet. However, if you do really want to retain your old notes, you can always set aside an hour a day for printing out notes and filing them. Be sure to try and make your life suck less while you’re doing it. When I was doing this, I would blast Pink Floyd and sip a nice glass of wine. 底线：主要关注未来。不要太执着于尝试将您的旧（数字）笔记集成到 Antinet 中。我有成千上万的数字笔记。他们不在我的 Antinet 里也没关系。与您手写的笔记相比，它们不发达。你不应该因为你的数字笔记被移植到你的 Antinet 上而失眠。然而，如果你真的想保留你的旧笔记，你总是可以每天留出一个小时来打印笔记并归档。当你这样做的时候，一定要试着让你的生活少一些糟糕。当我这样做时，我会吹嘘 Pink Floyd 并啜饮一杯美酒。

Again, consistency over the long term is the goal. As I’ve mentioned before, two hours per day is enough to produce great intellectual work. Don’t take my word for it, take the word of the revered intellectual, Antonin Sertillanges.[765](#footnote-754) If you work full-time, aim to carve out two hours every day before work. When I worked full-time I would sit down with a cup of coffee every day and go through challenging texts. I read while sitting on a cushion on the floor (as it helps me focus better). 同样，长期的一致性是目标。正如我之前提到的，每天两个小时足以产生出色的智力工作。不要相信我的话，请听取受人尊敬的知识分子 Antonin Sertillanges 的话。765 如果你是全职工作，目标是每天工作前抽出两个小时。当我全职工作时，我每天都会坐下来喝杯咖啡，阅读具有挑战性的课文。我坐在地板上的垫子上阅读（因为它可以帮助我更好地集中注意力）。

**If It Ain’t Easy, It Ain’t Fun 如果这不容易，那就不好玩**

Luhmann worked roughly twelve hours a day. To him, his vocation was his vacation. He didn’t really perceive his work as work. 卢曼每天大约工作十二个小时。对他来说，他的职业就是他的假期。他并不真正将自己的工作视为工作。

In an interview discussing the beginning of his career, an interviewer asked about Luhmann’s early life. This was during the period where he worked as a legal clerk for the German Ministry of Culture. It was absolutely boring and Luhmann hated his job. When asked what he did after work, he did not respond with something like I blow off steam at the local Biergarten. Instead, he told the interviewer that as soon as the clock struck five, he would race home and “read a lot.” He wasn’t a drinker, anyway. As he points out, he had just recently started his Zettelkasten at that point in his life.[766](#footnote-753) 在一次讨论其职业生涯初期的采访中，一位采访者询问了卢曼的早年生活。这是他在德国文化部担任法律文员期间。这绝对是无聊的，卢曼讨厌他的工作。当被问及他下班后做了什么时，他没有说我在当地的啤酒花园发泄情绪之类的话。相反，他告诉采访者，时钟一敲五点，他就会跑回家 “读很多书”。无论如何，他不是个酒鬼。正如他指出的那样，他刚刚在他生命中的那个时刻开始了他的 Zettelkasten。 766
