The same interviewer seemed puzzled when talking to Luhmann. He was trying to figure out what motivated this great intellectual mind; yet he wasn’t getting a clear answer. Luhmann asserted that he found it difficult to have wishes or “desires.” The only thing, Luhmann said, that he daydreamed about was having more time—like thirty hours in a day, instead of twenty-four. With thirty hours a day, how would he spend it? It’s simple, Luhmann said, he would spend it working with his Antinet more, and “study other things, for example mathematics and economics.”[767](#footnote-752) 与卢曼交谈时，同一位采访者似乎感到困惑。他试图弄清楚是什么激发了这位伟大的知识分子；但他没有得到明确的答案。卢曼断言，他发现很难有愿望或 “欲望”。卢曼说，他做白日梦的唯一一件事就是拥有更多的时间——比如一天三十小时，而不是二十四小时。一天三十个小时，他要怎么度过？ Luhmann 说，这很简单，他会花更多时间与他的 Antinet 一起工作，并 “学习其他东西，例如数学和经济学。”767

In brief, it’s helpful to view the Antinet as a vacation, not as a vocation. Using the Antinet won’t always be easy, but it will be worth it. The number one thing that will help your chances in making the Antinet a part of your life (long term) is this: make sure it’s fun. 简而言之，将 Antinet 视为假期而不是职业是有帮助的。使用 Antinet 并不总是那么容易，但它是值得的。有助于让 Antinet 成为您生活的一部分（长期）的第一件事是：确保它很有趣。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

In this chapter we covered a nice amount of material with regards to working with an Antinet. We discussed the three states one operates in during knowledge development. We also got a glimpse into Luhmann’s work routine with his Antinet. Last, we capped off this chapter with some philosophical advice centering around making the Antinet fun. Consistency over the long term is key. In the next chapter, we’ll dive into one of the most important metaphysical aspects of the Antinet: the Antinet as a second mind. Get ready. 在本章中，我们介绍了大量关于使用 Antinet 的材料。我们讨论了一个人在知识发展过程中所处的三种状态。我们还通过 Antinet 了解了卢曼的日常工作。最后，我们以一些围绕让 Antinet 变得有趣为中心的哲学建议结束了本章。长期的一致性是关键。在下一章中，我们将深入探讨 Antinet 最重要的形而上学方面之一：作为第二思维的 Antinet。做好准备。

CHAPTER EIGHTEEN 第十八章
---------------------

Communication With Your Second Mind 与你的第二个头脑沟通
----------------------------------------------

“Ghost in the box?“箱子里有鬼？

Spectators come. You get to see everything and nothing but that —like porn movies. And so is the disappointment.” 观众来了你可以看到一切，但什么也看不到——就像色情电影一样。失望也是如此。”

–Niklas Luhmann, on communicating with his Zettelkasten[768](#footnote-823)–Niklas Luhmann，关于与他的 Zettelkasten768 的交流

Communication with the Antinet is the most important aspect of the system. There’s a reason Luhmann titled his paper Communication with Noteboxes. It stands as the key descriptor of what it’s like to write and collaborate with an Antinet. Yet, for some reason, this phenomenon is completely omitted when reading about Zettelkasten today. When you research what a Zettelkasten is online, you’ll find every descriptor besides communication partner. Zettelkasten is described as a system of linking notes, and there are the Ahrensian terms like fleeting notes, literature notes, and permanent notes.[769](#footnote-822) Yet we find no mention of the Zettelkasten as a communication partner. You would have to do a lot of digging to discover how Luhmann actually viewed his Zettelkasten: as a second mind, a ghost in the box, or an alter ego with whom he communicated. 与 Antinet 的通信是该系统最重要的方面。 Luhmann 将他的论文命名为 Communication with Noteboxes 是有原因的。它代表了与 Antinet 编写和协作的感觉的关键描述符。然而，出于某种原因，今天阅读 Zettelkasten 时完全忽略了这种现象。当您研究在线 Zettelkasten 时，您会发现除了通讯伙伴之外的所有描述符。 Zettelkasten 被描述为一个连接笔记的系统，并且有 Ahrensian 术语，如短暂的笔记、文学笔记和永久笔记。769 然而，我们没有发现 Zettelkasten 是一个沟通伙伴。你必须做大量的挖掘才能发现卢曼实际上是如何看待他的 Zettelkasten 的：作为第二个头脑，盒子里的幽灵，或者与他交流的另一个自我。

In this chapter, we’ll discuss this most powerful part of the Antinet, and explore the concept of communication with one’s past self—that is, communication with one’s second mind. 在本章中，我们将讨论 Antinet 中这个最强大的部分，并探索与过去的自己交流的概念——即与第二个头脑交流。

**The Origins of Communication with a Second Mind 与第二思维交流的起源**
--------------------------------------------------------------

One interesting parallel with the origins of this idea involves the origins of the Zettelkasten itself.Zettelkasten 本身的起源与这个想法的起源有一个有趣的相似之处。

According to Clemens Luhmann (the youngest child of Niklas Luhmann), the Zettelkasten originated through a communication experience with Luhmann’s best friend, Friedrich Rudolf Hohl (1916–1979), whom Luhmann and the rest of the family called Bruder (meaning brother). Bruder was Luhmann’s closest friend. They shared a love of art, philosophy and other intellectual matters. They were seen almost as if they were the same person. Clemens referred to Hohl as his father’s “alter ego.”[770](#footnote-821) 根据克莱门斯 · 卢曼（尼克拉斯 · 卢曼最小的孩子）的说法，Zettelkasten 起源于与卢曼最好的朋友弗里德里希 · 鲁道夫 · 霍尔（Friedrich Rudolf Hohl，1916-1979 年）的一次交流经历，卢曼和家人称他为布鲁德（意为兄弟）。布鲁德是卢曼最亲密的朋友。他们都热爱艺术、哲学和其他智力问题。他们几乎被视为同一个人。克莱门斯称霍尔为他父亲的 “另一个自我”。 770

The origins of the Zettelkasten came by way of letters and notecards exchanged between Hohl and Luhmann. Luhmann would write letters to Hohl about his readings and include his own notecards in the envelope. The letters would elaborate on the ideas contained in the notes. They would discuss various interpretations. Hohl would do the very same thing in his replies.Zettelkasten 的起源是通过 Hohl 和 Luhmann 之间交换的信件和记事卡。卢曼会写信给霍尔，讲述他的阅读情况，并在信封里放上他自己的记事卡。这些信件将详细说明笔记中包含的想法。他们会讨论各种解释。 Hohl 也会在他的回复中做同样的事情。

This was a communication experience between two close friends. It was a communication experience with Luhmann’s real-life alter ego. 这是两个好朋友之间的一次交流经历。这是一次与卢曼现实生活中的另一个自我的交流经历。

Unfortunately, Luhmann’s best friend and “alter ego” Friedrich Rudolf Hohl passed away only two years after Luhmann’s wife Ursula. They were the only two people who ever got dedications in Luhmann’s books: Ursula and Friedrich Rudolf Hohl (in Love as Passion). 不幸的是，卢曼最好的朋友兼 “另一个自我” 弗里德里希 · 鲁道夫 · 霍尔 (Friedrich Rudolf Hohl) 在卢曼的妻子厄休拉去世仅两年后就去世了。他们是仅有的两个在卢曼的书中获得题词的人：厄休拉和弗里德里希 · 鲁道夫 · 霍尔（《热情如火》）。

A few years later, in 1981, Luhmann published his paper Kommunikation mit Zettelkästen (“Communication with Noteboxes”), in which he talked about a second mind arising from his Zettelkasten; he described it as “an alter ego with whom we can constantly communicate.”[771](#footnote-820) 几年后，在 1981 年，卢曼发表了他的论文 Kommunikation mit Zettelkästen（“与记事本的交流”），其中他谈到了从他的 Zettelkasten 中产生的第二个头脑；他将其描述为 “我们可以不断与之交流的另一个自我。”771

There exists a parallel between the communication experience of Luhmann and his real-life alter ego, Friedrich Rudolf Hohl, and Luhmann and his metaphysical alter ego: his Antinet Zettelkasten. 卢曼和他现实生活中的另一个自我弗里德里希 · 鲁道夫 · 霍尔 (Friedrich Rudolf Hohl) 的交流经历与卢曼和他形而上学的另一个自我：他的 Antinet Zettelkasten 之间存在着相似之处。

**Luhmann’s Theoretical View of Communication 卢曼的传播学理论**
--------------------------------------------------------

“Humans cannot communicate; not even their brains can communicate; not even their conscious minds can communicate. Only communication can communicate.”“人类无法交流；甚至他们的大脑也无法交流；甚至他们的意识也无法交流。只有沟通才能沟通。”

–Niklas Luhmann[772](#footnote-819)——尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 772

There are a few major concepts that at the cornerstone of Luhmann’s theoretical work. The first is general systems theory, which involves the concepts of cybernetics and self-referential systems, and autopoiesis (wherein a system recreates itself).[773](#footnote-818) The other concept that is critical to Luhmann’s theoretical work is communication. In fact, Luhmann uses a communication theory as the starting point for describing his Antinet.[774](#footnote-817) 有几个主要概念是卢曼理论工作的基石。第一个是一般系统理论，它涉及控制论和自我参照系统的概念，以及自创生（其中系统自我重建）。773 对卢曼的理论工作至关重要的另一个概念是交流。事实上，卢曼使用通信理论作为描述他的 Antinet 的起点。 774

According to Luhmann, communication is an emergent reality that emanates from three different selections.[775](#footnote-816) 根据 Luhmann 的说法，交流是一种新兴的现实，源于三种不同的选择。 775

1. The “selection of information”1.“信息选择”

2. The “selection of the message of this function”[776](#footnote-815)2.“本功能消息的选择”776

3. The “selective understanding or misunderstanding of the message and its interpretation”3.“对消息及其解释的选择性理解或误解”

Luhmann holds that none of these components can occur on their own. Only when they are combined together can communication occur.Luhmann 认为这些组成部分都不能单独发生。只有当它们结合在一起时，才能发生交流。

Let’s break down what Luhmann means by these three concepts in relation to working with an Antinet. 让我们分解一下卢曼在使用 Antinet 时所说的这三个概念的含义。

First, Luhmann is referring to the process of how we select information, including choosing the sources we wish to engage with in order to ingest information. In other words: what books, articles, podcasts, YouTube videos, or other media we select information from. 首先，卢曼指的是我们如何选择信息的过程，包括选择我们希望接触的来源以摄取信息。换句话说：我们从哪些书籍、文章、播客、YouTube 视频或其他媒体中选择信息。

The second component Luhmann is referring to is the message. This is the material within a source (such as a book) that we select and decide to interpret. 卢曼提到的第二个组成部分是信息。这是我们选择并决定解释的资源（例如书籍）中的材料。

The third component is the understanding or misunderstanding of the message. Luhmann makes a good point in that we have a choice of whether to understand (or misunderstand) the message we receive. For example, we humans have a phenomenal ability to delude ourselves by way of confirmation bias. That is, we may choose to interpret information in such a way to confirm our already-held preexisting beliefs (and filter our messages which conflict with these beliefs). 第三个组成部分是对消息的理解或误解。卢曼提出了一个很好的观点，即我们可以选择是否理解（或误解）我们收到的信息。例如，我们人类具有通过确认偏差来欺骗自己的非凡能力。也就是说，我们可能会选择以这样一种方式来解释信息，以确认我们已经持有的先前存在的信念（并过滤掉与这些信念相冲突的信息）。

All three components are required for communication. 所有这三个组件都是通信所必需的。

Interestingly enough, all three components serve as critical aspects of the knowledge development process of the Antinet. 有趣的是，所有这三个组成部分都是 Antinet 知识发展过程的关键方面。

Again, communication was a core tenet of Luhmann’s theoretical work. In fact, he proposed a solution to the classic philosophical mind-body problem by converting it to a triad: mind-body-communication.[777](#footnote-814) In Luhmann’s view, communication serves as the missing link for solving this most ancient philosophical puzzle. If you want to understand what it’s like working with an Antinet, you must remind yourself that it’s a communication experience. 同样，交流是卢曼理论工作的核心原则。事实上，他提出了一个解决经典哲学身心问题的方法，将其转化为三元组：身心交流。777 在卢曼看来，交流是解决这个最古老的哲学难题的缺失环节。如果您想了解使用 Antinet 是什么感觉，您必须提醒自己这是一种交流体验。

**Communication is The Secret Ingredient for Generating Surprises 沟通是产生惊喜的秘诀**
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

One of the key functions of the Antinet is its ability to surprise. Johannes Schmidt describes the Zettelkasten as a “surprise generator.”[778](#footnote-813) The precursor for generating surprises is communication.Antinet 的关键功能之一是其出其不意的能力。 Johannes Schmidt 将 Zettelkasten 描述为 “惊喜发生器”。778 产生惊喜的先决条件是沟通。

As Luhmann writes, “One of the most basic presuppositions of communication is that the partners can mutually surprise each other.”[779](#footnote-812) 正如卢曼所写，“沟通的最基本前提之一是合作伙伴可以互相惊喜。”779

On a more general level, communication surprises. For instance, for the past several years I’ve been working primarily by myself. However, in the process of writing this book, I’ve published and shared a lot of material on my social media channels.[780](#footnote-811) In doing so I’ve opened up many more channels of communication with people so that it’s no longer just me communicating with my Antinet. I’ve gained a lot of knowledge by communicating with others, but on top of that, I constantly receive links and ideas that surprise me and generate breakthrough ideas for my research. 在更一般的层面上，沟通令人惊讶。例如，在过去的几年里，我主要是一个人工作。然而，在写这本书的过程中，我已经在我的社交媒体渠道上发布和分享了很多材料。780 这样做，我打开了更多与人交流的渠道，不再只是我在交流与我的 Antinet。通过与他人交流，我获得了很多知识，但除此之外，我不断收到令我惊讶的链接和想法，并为我的研究产生突破性的想法。

Likewise, when you work with an Antinet as a communication partner, you’re having a conversation. A conversation emerges in your own mind wherein you’re trying to re-understand your own thoughts. You’re essentially having a conversation with your old self (that is, your past self). 同样，当您与作为通信伙伴的 Antinet 一起工作时，您就是在进行对话。一段对话出现在您自己的脑海中，您正在尝试重新理解自己的想法。您本质上是在与过去的自己（即过去的自己）进行对话。

This communication experience relates to that described in Mortimer Adler’s How to Read a Book, in which Adler describes the experience of reading a book as an active process that he compares to the game of baseball.[781](#footnote-810) There’s the pitcher (the author of a book), who throws a baseball (the message, material, or an idea contained within the book), and the catcher (you, the reader). The position of catcher is not passive. A catcher is not a lazy inanimate object who does nothing. The catcher is moving, shifting, and anticipating both the pitcher (author) and the pitch (message). It’s a communication experience—a very active communication experience. 这种沟通体验与莫蒂默 · 阿德勒 (Mortimer Adler) 的《如何阅读一本书》(How to Read a Book) 中描述的体验相关，阿德勒在其中将阅读体验描述为一个积极的过程，他将其比作棒球比赛。 781 有投手（一本书的作者） ，谁扔棒球（书中包含的信息、材料或想法），以及接球手（你，读者）。捕手的位置不是被动的。捕手不是什么都不做的懒惰的无生命物体。接球手正在移动、移动和预测投手（作者）和投球（消息）。这是一种交流体验——一种非常活跃的交流体验。

This type of communication experience mirrors what it’s like working with your Antinet. It’s an active, creative, collaborative communication experience. One that generates many surprises. 这种类型的通信体验反映了使用 Antinet 的感觉。这是一种积极的、创造性的、协作的沟通体验。一个产生许多惊喜的人。

This communication experience is also significantly deeper than you might realize. When you are communicating with an author through reading their book, you’re not just reading the words written by that one author. As Kate Turabian puts it, when you read a book, “you silently converse with its authors—and through them with everyone else they have read.”[782](#footnote-809) With your Antinet, you’re creating a deeply evolved and deeply linked communication partner with whom you communicate. 这种交流体验也比您可能意识到的要深刻得多。当您通过阅读他们的书与作者交流时，您不仅仅是在阅读该作者所写的文字。正如凯特 · 图拉比安 (Kate Turabian) 所说，当您阅读一本书时，“您会默默地与作者交谈——并通过他们与他们阅读过的其他人交谈。”782 有了 Antinet，您正在创建一个深度进化且紧密联系的沟通伙伴你沟通。

**An Example of the Antinet Communication ExperienceAntinet 通信体验的一个例子**

As previously discussed, with the Antinet, there is no full-text search. There is no safety net, and this fact underlies the entire experience of using an Antinet. When you begin searching for something, you begin a journey. You undertake an exploration of your mind. During this exploration you’re undertaking a communication process with your past self. 如前所述，对于 Antinet，没有全文搜索。没有安全网，这一事实构成了使用 Antinet 的整个体验的基础。当你开始寻找某样东西时，你就开始了一段旅程。你开始探索你的思想。在此探索过程中，您正在与过去的自己进行交流。

During the journey of finding thoughts in your Antinet, all you have is your index and cardlinks. The index sets you out on the journey, and the cardlinks swing you along across different branches and stems of thought in your tree of knowledge. 在你的 Antinet 中寻找想法的过程中，你所拥有的只是你的索引和卡片链接。索引让你踏上旅程，卡片链接让你跨越知识树中不同的分支和思想主干。

Creating cardlinks is not easy. They are created at the time you create the notecard, or shortly thereafter when you stumble upon the notecard (and have a related idea reverberating in your mind). Cardlinks are hard to create (unlike digital wikilinks). They cannot be mass-created on a whim and they require life energy to create. It’s a deliberate act that requires you to think of truly related ideas. 创建卡片链接并不容易。它们是在您创建记事卡时创建的，或者在您偶然发现记事卡后不久创建的（并且有一个相关的想法在您的脑海中回荡）。卡片链接很难创建（与数字维基链接不同）。它们不能随心所欲地大量创造，它们需要生命能量来创造。这是一种深思熟虑的行为，需要你思考真正相关的想法。

As a result of cardlinks being harder to create, they also require you to be more selective. Since there are fewer cardlinks in analog systems, you have more energy to follow them and you end up taking them more seriously. In contrast, when you encounter links and tags in a digital system, there may be five, ten, or fifteen links associated with a single note. Not to mention that there are backlinks that you can feasibly follow. In effect this dilutes the power of the relations because there are so many of them. 由于卡片链接更难创建，它们还要求您更具选择性。由于模拟系统中的卡片链接较少，你有更多的精力去关注它们，最终你会更加认真地对待它们。相反，当您在数字系统中遇到链接和标签时，可能有五个、十个或十五个链接与单个注释相关联。更不用说还有您可以切实遵循的反向链接。实际上，这削弱了关系的力量，因为关系太多了。

Within an analog system you’re dealing with selective relations. The entire system is relations of relations of selective relations. Whenever you come across a selective relation, you’re more motivated to take it seriously and actually follow the cardlink. If you’re on a tree with fifteen vines, it’s less likely you’ll explore all fifteen. If you’re on a tree with one vine, you’ll hop on and continue your exploration with vigor. 在模拟系统中，您处理的是选择性关系。整个系统是选择性关系的关系。每当您遇到选择性关系时，您都会更有动力认真对待它并实际遵循卡片链接。如果你在一棵有十五根藤蔓的树上，你就不太可能探索全部十五根。如果你在一棵只有一根藤蔓的树上，你就会跳上去继续你的探索。

Let’s walk through a more practical example, an example from Luhmann’s Antinet. 让我们来看一个更实际的例子，一个来自 Luhmann 的 Antinet 的例子。

Let’s say in your index, you look up the keyterm risk. When you look up risk, it links you to transformation of risk (which is at card address 21/3d18c60o9).[783](#footnote-808) You think to yourself, Hmm, this is interesting… Risk is within the branch of Systems Theory (21/3d18) and within that, the branch of Complexity (21/3d18c). Suddenly a secondary conversation takes place in your mind. A dreamlike memory emerges that takes you back to the period in your life when you wrote about complexity within systems theory. Perhaps you wrote about it that time you travelled to Paris and spent the time in a great Parisian library reading (which is what Luhmann did once, according to Clemens Luhmann).[784](#footnote-807) You are suddenly transported back to the setting of that time in the library in Paris. You remember how it was a gray November day in that Paris library. You recall reading about complexity, which led you to write about risk. 假设在您的索引中，您查找关键术语风险。当你查找风险时，它会将你链接到风险转换（位于卡地址 21/3d18c60o9）。783 你自己想，嗯，这很有趣…… 风险属于系统理论 (21/3d18) 的分支，并且其中，复杂性的分支 (21/3d18c)。突然，您的脑海中发生了次要对话。一个梦幻般的记忆出现，带你回到你写系统理论中的复杂性的生活时期。也许你在去巴黎旅行并在巴黎一家很棒的图书馆里读书时写下了它（根据克莱门斯 · 卢曼的说法，卢曼曾经做过）。784 你突然回到了那个时候在图书馆的场景在巴黎。你还记得那巴黎图书馆里十一月的一天是多么灰暗。您还记得阅读有关复杂性的文章，这促使您撰写有关风险的文章。

When you begin moving down the stem of risk you’re soon met with a cardlink collective (21/3d18c60o9,1): 当你开始沿着风险的方向前进时，你很快就会遇到一个 cardlink 集体 (21/3d18c60o9,1)：

photo credit: “ZK II: Zettel 21/3d18c60o9,1—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv,” accessed April 28, 2022, [https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-3d18c60o9-1_V](https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-3d18c60o9-1_V). 照片来源：“ZK II：Zettel 21/3d18c60o9,1—Niklas Luhmann-Archiv”，2022 年 4 月 28 日访问，https://niklas-luhmann-archiv.de/bestand/zettelkasten/zettel/ZK_2_NB_21-3d18c60o9-1_V。

It lists out several concepts related to risk. The concepts are as follows:[785](#footnote-806) 它列出了与风险相关的几个概念。概念如下：785

You think to yourself ‘Death as a risk’ what on earth does that have to do with risk? You then realize, death has everything to do with risk. It relates to Certainty/truth/science in that death is the ultimate form of uncertainty that underlies society and drives human behavior. At the core foundation of risk resides the ultimate fear: risk of death. 你认为 “死亡是一种风险”，这与风险到底有什么关系？然后你意识到，死亡与风险息息相关。它与确定性 / 真理 / 科学相关，因为死亡是构成社会基础并驱动人类行为的不确定性的最终形式。风险的核心基础是最终的恐惧：死亡风险。

This illustrates the communication experience in working with the Antinet. There are several dialogues taking place concurrently. First, we have the dialogue of recalling the memory of writing and researching risk (in the Parisian library). Then, we have the dialogue of actually conversing with the Antinet: What does the concept of death have to do with risk? 这说明了使用 Antinet 的通信体验。有几个对话同时进行。首先，我们有回忆写作记忆和研究风险的对话（在巴黎图书馆）。然后，我们就有了和安妮特实际对话的对话：死亡这个概念跟风险有什么关系？

This example shows how the dots begin to connect over time. When you first wrote about risk, you did not write about death. Over time, the concept of death emerged and was added to the branch collective for risk (21/3d18c60o9,1). These concepts and links needed time to synthesize and grow. Continuing the metaphor of the Antinet as a tree, photosynthesis needed to take place. This area of your tree needed sunlight to synthesize. The structure grew organically over time in a natural way. It creates an antifragile structure (compared to a dynamic digital structure with hyperactive edits and bulk edits). 这个例子展示了这些点是如何随着时间的推移开始连接起来的。当你第一次写风险时，你没有写死亡。随着时间的推移，死亡的概念出现并被添加到风险的分支集体中 (21/3d18c60o9,1)。这些概念和联系需要时间来综合和成长。继续将 Antinet 比喻成一棵树，需要进行光合作用。树的这个区域需要阳光来合成。随着时间的推移，该结构以自然的方式有机地生长。它创建了一个反脆弱结构（与具有超活跃编辑和批量编辑的动态数字结构相比）。

This example gives you a glimpse into the communication experience that is an outcome of working with the Antinet. It shows you the internal dialogue that takes place. It also shows you how a system of both order and chaos works. 此示例让您瞥见作为使用 Antinet 的结果的通信体验。它向您展示了发生的内部对话。它还向您展示了一个既有序又混乱的系统是如何工作的。

You started by looking up risk, and then are taken on a journey that brings forth concepts related to Certainty/truth/science, Uncertainty, and more. This communication experience takes you on a journey that generates breakthrough surprises, leading “to a variety of other subjects that the user initially would not have associated with the first one,” as Johannes Schmidt observes. “It also shows how potential relationships between these topics may not have come to mind in the absence of such a chain of references.”[786](#footnote-805) 您从寻找风险开始，然后踏上一段旅程，带来与确定性 / 真相 / 科学、不确定性等相关的概念。这种交流体验会带您踏上一段会产生突破性惊喜的旅程，正如约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 观察到的那样，它会导致 “用户最初不会与第一个主题相关联的各种其他主题”。 “它还表明，如果没有这样的参考链，这些主题之间的潜在关系可能不会浮现在脑海中。”786

When you use an Antinet, you’re forced to create abstractions of ideas. You’re forced to generalize ideas and relate them to one another. “Communication,” Luhmann says, “becomes fruitful only at a high level of generalization, namely that of establishing communicative relations of relations.”[787](#footnote-804) 当你使用 Antinet 时，你被迫创建思想的抽象。你被迫概括想法并将它们相互联系起来。 “交流，” 卢曼说，“只有在高度概括的情况下才会富有成果，即建立关系的交流关系。”787

Luhmann gives an example wherein he observes, “Why on the one hand museums are [generally] empty, while on the other hand exhibitions of paintings by Monet, Picasso, or Medici are too crowded.”[788](#footnote-803) Instead of creating the keyterms Monet, Picasso, or Medici, he instead does something else. He generalizes and abstracts the idea to get at the core essence. The reason why Monet, Picasso, and Medici exhibits are so crowded is because they’re temporally limited. That is, they are only available to be viewed at a certain place and for only a short period of time. In this instance, Luhmann created the index keyterm or branch collective card with the following concept: “preference for what is temporally limited.”[789](#footnote-802) From there he linked to the card that talks about Monet, Picasso, or Medici exhibits being overcrowded. Over time, more and more examples of preferences for temporally limited items were added to the collective.Luhmann 举了一个例子，他观察到，“为什么一方面博物馆 [通常] 是空的，而另一方面莫奈、毕加索或美第奇的画展又太拥挤了。”788 毕加索没有创造关键词莫奈，而是，或美第奇，他反而做了别的事情。他对想法进行概括和抽象，以获得核心本质。莫奈、毕加索和美第奇的展品之所以人满为患，是因为时间有限。也就是说，它们只能在特定地点观看，而且只能观看很短的时间。在这种情况下，Luhmann 使用以下概念创建了索引关键词或分支集体卡片：“对时间有限的东西的偏好。”789 从那里他链接到谈论莫奈、毕加索或美第奇展品过于拥挤的卡片。随着时间的推移，越来越多的时间限制项目的偏好示例被添加到集合中。

In effect, Luhmann has created a high-level generalization. He points out that communication with the Antinet becomes more valuable when you create such generalizations (instead of merely creating a keyterm for the mention of Picasso). Yet there’s one final piece of this communication experience: the “moment of evaluation.”[790](#footnote-801) 实际上，卢曼创造了一种高级概括。他指出，当你创建这样的概括时，与 Antinet 的交流变得更有价值（而不是仅仅创建一个提及毕加索的关键词）。然而，这种沟通体验还有最后一个环节：“评估时刻”。 790

Luhmann writes that communicating with the Antinet “becomes productive only at the moment of evaluation, and is thus bound to a certain time and is to a high degree accidental.”[791](#footnote-800)Luhmann 写道，与 Antinet 的交流 “只有在评估的那一刻才变得富有成效，因此受限于某个时间，并且在很大程度上是偶然的。”791

In other words, when it comes time to writing, you end up stumbling upon valuable cards. Let’s say you stumble upon the branch collective of items for preferences for temporally limited. As a result of this, you are reminded that art exhibits serve as an example of people tending to prefer something that is temporally limited. In a card nearby, you then stumble upon a cardlink pointing to the concept of scarcity. This opens up a whole new stem of thought, and an idea sparks in your mind. Humans are not just driven by things that are temporally scarce, but by anything that is scarce. You can then write about how museums leverage the tendency of humans to be motivated by scarcity (whether that be time-based scarcity or space-based scarcity), as do retailers, with phrases such as Only 2 items left! (when shopping online). 换句话说，到了写作的时候，你最终会偶然发现有价值的卡片。假设您偶然发现了项目的分支集合，以获取暂时受限的偏好。因此，提醒您艺术展览是人们倾向于喜欢时间有限的东西的一个例子。然后，在附近的一张卡片中，您偶然发现了一个指向稀缺性概念的卡片链接。这开辟了一个全新的思路，一个想法在你的脑海中迸发出火花。人类不仅会被暂时稀缺的事物所驱使，还会被任何稀缺的事物所驱使。然后，您可以写下博物馆如何利用人类被稀缺性（无论是基于时间的稀缺性还是基于空间的稀缺性）所激发的倾向，就像零售商一样，使用诸如仅剩 2 件物品之类的短语！ （在线购物时）。

These connections are not made at the time they’re created, Luhmann points out, but are made at the time of evaluation—at the time you sit down to actually write about them. In effect, you’re working with your Antinet as a communication partner during the time of writing, and doing so helps you generate breakthrough insights and ideas.Luhmann 指出，这些联系并不是在创建时就建立起来的，而是在评估时建立的——在你坐下来真正写下它们的时候。实际上，在写作期间，您正在与您的 Antinet 作为沟通伙伴合作，这样做有助于您产生突破性的见解和想法。

Welcome to the Antinet. Using it sets off the incommunicable experience of a communicable experience (with a notebox). It’s filled with order, chaos, and surprises. 欢迎来到安特网。使用它会引发可交流体验的不可交流体验（使用记事本）。它充满了秩序、混乱和惊喜。

**Intellectual Evolution Depends on Communication with Externalized Artificial Consciousness 智力进化取决于与外化人工意识的交流**
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Something I discuss early on in this book relates to how intellectual evolution relies on communication with an externalized artificial consciousness. I hold that the Antinet serves as a better container of external artificial consciousness than any digital notetaking app (thus far). 我在本书前面部分讨论的内容涉及智力进化如何依赖于与外化人工意识的交流。我认为 Antinet 比任何数字笔记应用程序（迄今为止）都更能充当外部人工意识的容器。

Akin to the concept of human evolution happening through the use of externalizing tools (like axes and spears), intellectual evolution relies on the “exteriorization” of one’s individual memories. This served as a very successful and intriguing idea in the second half of the twentieth century.[792](#footnote-799) 类似于通过使用外化工具（如斧头和长矛）发生的人类进化的概念，智力进化依赖于个人记忆的 “外化”。这在 20 世纪下半叶是一个非常成功和有趣的想法。 792

To evolve intellectually, we must first externalize our individual memories. Recall, a memory is a representation of a thought. A thought is a representation of reality. Paradoxically, we must externalize our metaphysical thoughts by inserting them into physical reality. When you use an Antinet, you do this by way of writing your thoughts by hand on notecards; in the digital realm, you really aren’t participating in the same process because you’re externalizing metaphysical thoughts by injecting them into metaphysical reality (on a computer screen). 要在智力上进化，我们必须首先外化我们的个人记忆。回想一下，记忆是思想的代表。思想是现实的表现。矛盾的是，我们必须将我们的形而上学思想外化，将它们插入物理现实中。当你使用 Antinet 时，你可以通过在记事卡上手写你的想法来做到这一点；在数字领域，您实际上并没有参与相同的过程，因为您通过将形而上学思想注入形而上学现实（在计算机屏幕上）来将它们外化。

As a result, digital may fail to make a key step in procuring intellectual evolution. Here’s why: intellectual evolution will emerge from shifting from the structural coupling of communication and consciousness to a structural coupling of communication and artificial consciousness. In other words, the most advanced communication today happens with conscious entities. Of course communication occurs with unconscious entities as well. After all, when two computers connect, they communicate, though they are unconscious of themselves. They are deterministic agents in a network operated by conscious entities. The next big intellectual evolution will emerge from the communication between conscious entities and artificially conscious entities. Many quickly jump to thinking of robots as the best candidate for becoming the world’s first artificially conscious entity; however some hold that, “Artificial consciousness is impossible due to the extrinsic nature of programming which is bound to syntax and devoid of meaning.”[793](#footnote-798) 因此，数字化可能无法迈出促进智力进化的关键一步。原因如下：智能进化将从通信和意识的结构耦合转变为通信和人工意识的结构耦合。换句话说，当今最先进的通信发生在有意识的实体之间。当然，与无意识实体的交流也会发生。毕竟，当两台计算机连接时，它们会进行通信，尽管它们自己并没有意识到。它们是由有意识的实体运行的网络中的确定性代理。下一次重大的智力进化将出现在有意识实体和人工意识实体之间的交流中。许多人很快就认为机器人是成为世界上第一个具有人工意识的实体的最佳人选；然而，有些人认为，“由于编程的外在性质，它与句法相关并且没有意义，因此人工意识是不可能的。”793

In brief, are we wasting our time in holding that the next intellectual advancement will arise by way of an impossible idea (artificial consciousness)? I think it’s quite possible we are wasting our time. Yet I don’t think this means we ought to cast aside the idea. Instead I think it wise to explore the next best thing to artificial consciousness: creating our own very close versions of artificial consciousness. This is where the Antinet comes into play. 简而言之，我们认为下一次智力进步将通过一个不可能的想法（人工意识）出现是在浪费时间吗？我认为我们很可能在浪费时间。然而我不认为这意味着我们应该抛弃这个想法。相反，我认为探索人工意识的下一个最好的东西是明智的：创造我们自己的非常接近的人工意识版本。这就是 Antinet 发挥作用的地方。

The best tools for intellectual advancement are those which embody the properties of artificial consciousness: a communication partner that seems to have its own externalized personality. Thus far, computers and digital notetaking apps have outshone analog tools for storing data and information. However, they have not outshone analog tools in one area: storing one’s consciousness; one’s deepest thoughts and ideas; one’s personality. I hold that the analog medium—by way of containing your own handwriting—provides a better mechanism to act like a cue or prompt for generating an internal dialogue in your mind. More on this will be discussed shortly. But for now, know that the analog medium serves as a better vehicle of artificial consciousness than does a computer. 智力进步的最佳工具是那些体现人工意识特性的工具：一个似乎有自己外化个性的交流伙伴。迄今为止，计算机和数字笔记应用程序在存储数据和信息方面的表现优于模拟工具。然而，它们在一个领域并没有超越模拟工具：存储一个人的意识；一个人最深的想法和想法；一个人的个性。我认为模拟媒体——通过包含你自己的笔迹——提供了一种更好的机制，可以像提示或提示一样在你的脑海中产生内部对话。有关这方面的更多信息将在稍后讨论。但就目前而言，要知道模拟媒体是比计算机更好的人工意识载体。

Even though the Antinet isn’t actually aware of itself and is not alive (and thus not fully artificially conscious), it is composed of (many iterations of) your past self, which was aware of itself at the time of the note’s creation. Every note you observe in an Antinet is a containerized capsule of your own consciousness. This is why noteboxes have been described as a view into another’s life and mind. This is something Johannes Schmidt touches on when he refers to Luhmann’s Antinet as “the backstage of his theory and therefore as Niklas Luhmann’s intellectual autobiography.”[794](#footnote-797) Our consciousness is indeed captured in external memory devices. Paradoxically, communication with such devices is an incommunicable truth.[795](#footnote-796) It’s impossible to describe to others the internal experience of working with your own artificial consciousness. 尽管 Antinet 实际上并没有意识到自己并且没有生命（因此没有完全人为的意识），但它是由你过去的自我（多次迭代）组成的，它在创建笔记时意识到了自己。你在 Antinet 中观察到的每一个音符都是你自己意识的容器化胶囊。这就是为什么笔记本被描述为观察他人生活和思想的一种方式。约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 将卢曼的 Antinet 称为 “他的理论的后台，因此是尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 的思想自传” 时，他谈到了这一点。 794 我们的意识确实被捕获在外部存储设备中。矛盾的是，与此类设备的交流是无法传达的事实。795 无法向他人描述使用您自己的人工意识工作的内在体验。

**Communication with You and Your Past Self 与你和你过去的自己交流**
---------------------------------------------------------

The Antinet is a true communication relationship with you and your past self. When I read my handwritten notes and papers from fifteen years ago, it’s me I’m interacting with. It’s my thoughts—even if they’re excerpts or reformulations of what I was reading at the time. It signals to me that my past self resonated with whatever idea the note contains. I see myself in my handwriting. I see how much I’ve grown, and also how much I’ve stayed the same. There are feelings of both respect, and also feelings of shame and regret when I review old notes. When I come upon handwritten notes of relationship advice, it makes me a little sad to realize those were written during my first marriage. Yet it also makes me laugh, seeing the irony of relationship advice that wasn’t effective. When I come across other writings from that time, it makes me feel a certain love and reverence and respect for myself during that period.Antinet 是与你和你过去的自己的真正沟通关系。当我阅读十五年前的手写笔记和论文时，与我互动的是我。这是我的想法——即使它们是我当时阅读的内容的摘录或重新表述。它向我发出信号，表明我过去的自己与笔记中包含的任何想法产生了共鸣。我在笔迹中看到了自己。我看到自己成长了多少，也看到了多少保持不变。回顾旧笔记，既有崇敬之情，也有惭愧和遗憾之情。当我看到手写的关系建议笔记时，意识到这些是我第一次婚姻时写的，让我有点难过。然而，这也让我发笑，看到关系建议无效的讽刺意味。当我看到那个时期的其他作品时，让我对那个时期的自己产生了某种爱、敬畏和尊重。

This type of stuff may sound sappy and unscientific; however, I assure you it’s not. The Antinet contains your personality, and this is a very important feature in interacting with your own thoughts. As previously mentioned, scholars, including Luhmann, are aware of the idea of a ghost in the box.[796](#footnote-795) One scholar concludes that “Luhmann did not regard his filing cabinet as a simple slip box, rather he interacted with it as if it were a true communication partner.”[797](#footnote-794) 这种类型的东西可能听起来很无聊而且不科学；但是，我向你保证不是。 Antinet 包含你的个性，这是与你自己的思想互动的一个非常重要的特征。如前所述，包括卢曼在内的学者都知道盒子里有幽灵的想法。 796 一位学者总结道，“卢曼并没有把他的文件柜看作是一个简单的滑箱，而是将它当作一个真正的沟通伙伴。”797

One way the Antinet serves as a communication partner is in the form of asking it questions and “making queries.”[798](#footnote-793) This relates to the concept of asking a book questions, which was nicely outlined by Mortimer Adler. “If you ask a living teacher a question, he will probably answer you… If, however, you ask a book a question, you must answer it yourself. In this respect a book is like nature or the world. When you question it, it answers you only to the extent that you do the work of thinking and analysis yourself.”[799](#footnote-792)Antinet 作为通信伙伴的一种方式是向它提问和 “提出疑问”。798 这与向书本提问的概念有关，Mortimer Adler 对此进行了很好的概述。 “如果你向一位在世的老师提问，他可能会回答你…… 但是，如果你向一本书提问，你必须自己回答。在这方面，一本书就像自然或世界。当你质疑它时，它只会在你自己进行思考和分析工作的范围内回答你。”799

Asking a book a question is similar to communicating with an Antinet, except that the Antinet contains a massive store of knowledge from the many books you’ve read. It’s not like the process of hyperactively searching Google. You must do the work of thinking and analysis yourself—with whatever knowledge you have at your disposal. 向一本书提问类似于与 Antinet 交流，只是 Antinet 包含来自您已阅读的许多书籍的大量知识。这不像过度活跃地搜索谷歌的过程。你必须自己做思考和分析的工作——用你掌握的任何知识。

The Antinet is not some “rhetorical storehouse,” observes one scholar. It’s not a tool for capturing unprocessed information and storing it for a later period of time. You can certainly do this by using ExRefs—however, hyperactive digital tools are much better for collecting unprocessed information. The true value is the Antinet’s ability to turn information into knowledge by injecting your own personality to it. “The card index preserves a knowledge—we could also say, a past—that not only continually changes but also can be recalled in a highly selective manner.”[800](#footnote-791) 一位学者指出，Antinet 不是什么 “修辞库”。它不是用于捕获未处理信息并将其存储以备后用的工具。你当然可以通过使用 ExRefs 来做到这一点——但是，过度活跃的数字工具更适合收集未处理的信息。真正的价值在于 Antinet 能够通过将您自己的个性注入其中，将信息转化为知识。 “卡片索引保留了一种知识——我们也可以说，一种过去——它不仅不断变化，而且可以以高度选择性的方式回忆起来。”800

The ghost in the box factor stems from writing by hand. Handwriting seems to containerize consciousness better than standardized digital fonts. Developing true knowledge, filled with meaningful information, relies on internal dialogue (i.e., intrapersonal communication) with your past self’s consciousness.[801](#footnote-790) Analog systems with handwriting seem to retain this consciousness better than standardized digital schemes. Your own handwriting is unique—especially when you view it yourself. 盒子里的幽灵因素源于手写。手写似乎比标准化数字字体更能体现意识。发展真正的知识，充满有意义的信息，依赖于与你过去的自我意识的内部对话（即内心交流）。801 具有手写的模拟系统似乎比标准化数字方案更好地保留这种意识。您自己的笔迹是独一无二的——尤其是当您亲自查看时。

**The Phase Transition from Antinet to Second Mind 从 Antinet 到 Second Mind 的相变**
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Luhmann’s thinking evolved with his Antinet, as did his process of taking notes. His early notes from the 1950s and 1960s contained more excerpts and long-passages that flowed across several notecards.[802](#footnote-789) At a certain point, Luhmann’s process went through a change that perhaps relates to his statement that the Antinet “needs a number of years in order to reach critical mass. Until then, it functions as a mere container from which we can retrieve what we put in.”[803](#footnote-788) By reaching critical mass, Luhmann was referring to how the Antinet becomes its own mind—an independent entity with whom you can communicate.[804](#footnote-787) 卢曼的思想随着他的 Antinet 的发展而发展，他做笔记的过程也是如此。他在 1950 年代和 1960 年代的早期笔记中包含了更多的摘录和长篇大论，这些摘录和长篇大论横跨多个记事卡。 802 在某个时刻，卢曼的过程经历了一个变化，这可能与他的声明有关，即 Antinet“需要很多年才能完成”。达到临界质量。在那之前，它只是一个容器，我们可以从中取出我们放入的东西。”803 通过达到临界质量，卢曼指的是 Antinet 如何成为它自己的思想——一个你可以与之交流的独立实体。 804

Being that the Antinet is a cybernetic network, I find network science to be an excellent field from which to glean lessons. There’s an emerging area of study within network science called percolation theory, which nicely describes the transition from Antinet to second mind. 由于 Antinet 是一个控制论网络，我发现网络科学是一个很好的学习领域。网络科学中有一个新兴的研究领域称为渗透理论，它很好地描述了从 Antinet 到第二思维的转变。

Percolation theory studies the phenomenon in networks wherein a phase transition takes place. This phase is the result of a very small change in the composition of the network (such as adding a certain number of notes to your Antinet, thus meeting a specific threshold). Think of boiling water on a stove. At 99°C something is happening, but you’re still staring at water. Yet after an increase of one single degree Celsius, a specific threshold is met. Meeting this threshold triggers the entire entity of water to transition into an entirely different substance (gas). This is what is meant by phase transition. 渗透理论研究网络中发生相变的现象。这个阶段是网络的组成发生非常小的变化的结果（比如在你的 Antinet 中添加一定数量的注释，从而达到特定的阈值）。想想炉子上的沸水。在 99°C 时发生了一些事情，但你仍然盯着水看。然而，在增加一摄氏度后，就会达到一个特定的阈值。达到这个阈值会触发整个水实体转变为完全不同的物质（气体）。这就是相变的意思。

The same transformation that occurs during a phase transition when a minimum threshold is met exists within networks, and is studied in a branch of mathematics that studies percolation theory. It is a compelling field because of its utility in studying digital networks on which the success of certain commercial products rely—especially products which rely on mesh networks. Businesses can find significant value in understanding the nature of the networks they have built and what the minimum threshold number of nodes needs to be in order to undergo a phase transition from a disconnected network to a connected one. 当满足最小阈值时相变期间发生的相同转换存在于网络中，并且在研究渗流理论的数学分支中进行了研究。这是一个引人注目的领域，因为它在研究某些商业产品的成功所依赖的数字网络方面的实用性——尤其是依赖网状网络的产品。企业可以在了解他们构建的网络的性质以及为了经历从断开连接的网络到连接网络的相变所需的最小节点数量阈值方面发现重要价值。

As far as the Antinet goes, the matter of importance is to understand the minimum threshold of notes and keyterms needed to undergo a phase transition (from Antinet to second mind). Luhmann never specified this number, other than stating it takes a number of years. 就 Antinet 而言，重要的是了解经历相变（从 Antinet 到 second mind）所需的注释和关键词的最低阈值。 Luhmann 从未具体说明这个数字，只是说它需要很多年。

Whatever this threshold happens to be is of little value to the more interesting occurrence: the fact is that Luhmann did indeed observe a phase transition with his Antinet when, at some point, his Antinet transitioned from an analog brain that simply stores notes, to a completely different entity entirely. Just like water turning into gas when it hits 100°C, the Antinet turns into a second mind after reaching a certain number of notes (say one thousand). 无论这个阈值恰好是什么，对于更有趣的事件来说都没有什么价值：事实是，卢曼确实观察到了他的 Antinet 的相变，在某个时候，他的 Antinet 从一个简单存储音符的模拟大脑转变为一个完全不同的实体。就像水在达到 100°C 时会变成气体一样，Antinet 在达到一定数量的音符（比如一千个）后会变成第二个头脑。

In Luhmann’s notes on the nature of his Antinet, he talks about having an “impression of a mentally muscular overall personality.”[805](#footnote-786) What I hold this to mean is that the Antinet develops its own unique, rough personality after it undergoes this phase transition into a second mind. The entity becomes an alter-ego with whom you can communicate. It becomes a research assistant who you can collaborate with. It becomes a true second mind. 在 Luhmann 关于他的 Antinet 本质的笔记中，他谈到拥有 “一个精神上强壮的整体人格的印象”。805 我认为这意味着 Antinet 在经历了这个阶段转变为第二个想法。该实体成为您可以与之交流的另一个自我。它成为您可以与之合作的研究助理。它成为真正的第二个头脑。

We’ve thus far talked primarily about communication. Understanding this concept is critical in grasping the nature of working with an Antinet. We’ve also touched upon the entity we communicate with when working with an Antinet—the second mind. Let’s now take a deep dive into exploring this entity, the second mind. 到目前为止，我们主要讨论的是沟通。理解这个概念对于掌握使用 Antinet 的本质至关重要。我们还谈到了我们在使用 Antinet 时与之交流的实体——第二思维。现在让我们深入探索这个实体，即第二思维。

**Second Brain vs. Second Mind 第二大脑与第二思维**
------------------------------------------

Second brain is a term that has become popular within productivity and personal knowledge management circles. Also, digital Zettelkasten systems have been linked to this term (pun intended). You’ll find popular software used for digital Zettelkasten systems described as a second brain.[806](#footnote-785) Personally, I find this term lacking. The term second brain has been used primarily to refer to technologies that are for collecting and storing information. The information, however, is essentially a disconnected blob of unprocessed material. 第二大脑是一个在生产力和个人知识管理圈中流行的术语。此外，数字 Zettelkasten 系统已与该术语相关联（双关语）。您会发现用于数字 Zettelkasten 系统的流行软件被描述为第二个大脑。806 就个人而言，我发现这个术语不足。 “第二大脑” 一词主要用于指代收集和存储信息的技术。然而，这些信息本质上是一团不连贯的未经处理的材料。

In reality, you don’t want a second brain; instead you want a second mind. A brain is just biological wetware. It, in itself, is nothing without its other interconnected systems functioning together. A second mind describes the occurrence of the whole becoming greater than the sum of its parts. 实际上，您不需要第二个大脑；相反，你想要第二个想法。大脑只是生物湿件。如果没有其他相互连接的系统一起运作，它本身就什么都不是。第二个头脑描述了整体变得大于其部分之和的发生。

People are intrigued with the Zettelkasten because it’s not just an information storage container. If it were a container, people would opt for simpler notebox systems which merely store thoughts. In contrast, the notecard systems others have shared haven’t created a whole niche within knowledge management. The Zettelkasten has indeed created excitement. Why? Because of its promise to not just be a memory storage system, but a thinking system—it is a true knowledge development system. 人们对 Zettelkasten 很感兴趣，因为它不仅仅是一个信息存储容器。如果它是一个容器，人们会选择更简单的记事本系统，它只存储思想。相比之下，其他人共享的记录卡系统并没有在知识管理中创造一个完整的利基市场。 Zettelkasten 确实令人兴奋。为什么？因为它承诺不仅是一个记忆存储系统，而且是一个思维系统——它是一个真正的知识开发系统。

People are also intrigued with the Zettelkasten because of the results it produced for Luhmann. His prolific work—seventy books and 550 published articles over a thirty year timeframe—was achieved through interacting with his system as if it were a communication partner—a second mind. 人们也对 Zettelkasten 很感兴趣，因为它为卢曼带来了成果。他的多产工作——在 30 年的时间框架内出版了 70 本书和 550 篇文章——是通过与他的系统互动来实现的，就好像它是一个沟通伙伴——第二个头脑。

A second brain is an information store, or information database. 第二个大脑是信息存储或信息数据库。

A second mind is a communication partner that forces you to think, to develop ideas (by hand, the old way, the hard way), and later to argue with your ideas. It forces you to see inconsistencies in your old thoughts and evolve them. 第二个头脑是一个沟通伙伴，它迫使你思考、发展想法（手工、老方法、困难的方法），然后与你的想法争论。它迫使你看到旧思想中的不一致之处并加以改进。

**An Argument for Second Mind over Second Memory 第二记忆优于第二记忆的争论**

Luhmann’s description of the communication relationship he had with his Zettelkasten was summed up as follows: “As a result of prolonged work with this technique, a kind of second memory emerges, an alter ego with which one can constantly communicate.”[807](#footnote-784) 卢曼对他与他的 Zettelkasten 的交流关系的描述总结如下：“由于长期使用这种技术，一种第二记忆出现了，一个可以不断交流的另一个自我。”807

The phrase he used to describe the entity he was communicating with was eine Art Zweitgedächtnis, ein alter Ego. This is a second memory type of entity, or an alter ego. Here, zweit translates to “second,” and Gedächtnis to “memory.” If we look into the word Gedächtnis, we find some interesting origins: its root stems from gedacht, which is the past participle of denken, meaning “to think, call to mind, conceive.”[808](#footnote-783) In other words, a Zweitgedächtnis is a second-memory entity, an alter ego. 他用来描述与他交流的实体的短语是 eine Art Zweitgedächtnis, ein alter Ego。这是实体的第二种记忆类型，或另一个自我。在这里，zweit 翻译为 “秒”，Gedächtnis 翻译为 “记忆”。如果我们研究一下 Gedächtnis 这个词，我们会发现一些有趣的起源：它的词根源于 gedacht，它是 denken 的过去分词，意思是 “思考、想起、构想”。808 换句话说，Zweitgedächtnis 是第二个 - 记忆实体，另一个自我。

The entity Luhmann was referring to involves a communication experience in which you’re calling to mind a second part of yourself (an alter ego). Furthermore, we see Luhmann referring to this entity as a “Geist” in his notes written in preparation for the paper.[809](#footnote-782) I hold that a better term for this entity involves combining Luhmann’s term Geist with the concept of Zweitgedächtnis. As a result we end up with Zweitgeist, which translates to “second mind.” Thus, the term for second mind is born.[810](#footnote-781)Luhmann 所指的实体涉及一种交流体验，在这种交流体验中，你会想起自己的第二部分（另一个自我）。此外，我们看到 Luhmann 在他为准备论文而写的笔记中将这个实体称为 “Geist”。809 我认为对这个实体更好的术语是将 Luhmann 的术语 Geist 与 Zweitgedächtnis 的概念结合起来。结果，我们最终得到了 Zweitgeist，它被翻译成“第二思维”。因此，“第二头脑” 一词诞生了。 810

A similar type of evolution from the term second memory to second mind is something that recently occurred within knowledge science. The term secondary memory is now referred to as “early modern terminology.” The newer and more popular term is extended mind. Proposed by Andy Clark and David Chalmers, the concept of extended mind holds that the mind resides not only in the brain, but also outside of it. One’s mind is stored in the external representations of the human body. While I think there’s truth in their thesis, there are problems with the term extended mind. Several scholars point out that there exists a failure to explain what aspect of the mind is extended. Is it the entire mind that is extended or just cognition? Furthermore, the definition of extended is not made clear.[811](#footnote-780) This is another reason we’ll be sticking to the term second mind. 从术语 “第二记忆” 到“第二思维”的类似演变是最近在知识科学中发生的事情。二级记忆一词现在被称为 “早期现代术语”。更新和更流行的术语是扩展思维。由安迪 · 克拉克和大卫 · 查默斯提出的延展思维概念认为，思维不仅存在于大脑之中，也存在于大脑之外。一个人的思想存储在人体的外部表征中。虽然我认为他们的论点是正确的，但扩展思维一词存在问题。一些学者指出，无法解释思维的哪个方面得到了扩展。延展的是整个心智还是只是认知？此外，扩展的定义并不明确。811 这是我们坚持使用“第二思维” 一词的另一个原因。

So, the entity one communicates with when the Antinet reaches a critical threshold is the second mind. 因此，当 Antinet 达到临界阈值时，与之通信的实体是第二思维。

There’s only one question left. What the hell is a mind?! 只剩下一个问题了。脑洞是什么鬼？！

**What a Mind Is 什么是心灵**

The mind is a metaphysical entity. It has never been identified. As far as we can tell, it may just be a bunch of neurons connecting to other neurons in the brain. A reductionist approach is to just get rid of the concept altogether.[812](#footnote-779) Yet I think this a bit premature. It’s simply that, as cognitive psychologist Steven Pinker points out, “we don’t understand how the mind works.”[813](#footnote-778) For a long period of time humankind didn’t understand gravity; yet we had a sense that there was something to the phenomenon of objects falling. We just couldn’t explain it yet. Aristotle thought it had something to do with elements wishing to return to their natural place.[814](#footnote-777) Just because we didn’t understand gravity, didn’t mean we should have cast aside the concept of something causing the effects we now recognize as being a result of gravity. Just because we don’t understand something fully yet doesn’t mean we should delete the placeholder term and stop asking questions about it. The mind is a metaphysical entity that we don’t fully understand yet. Like human memory, the mind remains one of the last great mysteries in science. 头脑是一个形而上学的实体。它从未被识别。据我们所知，它可能只是一堆连接到大脑中其他神经元的神经元。还原论者的方法是完全摆脱这个概念。812 但我认为这有点为时过早。正如认知心理学家史蒂芬 · 平克 (Steven Pinker) 指出的那样，这很简单，“我们不了解思维是如何工作的。”813 很长一段时间以来，人类并不了解引力；然而我们有一种感觉，物体掉落的现象是有原因的。我们只是还无法解释。亚里士多德认为这与希望返回其自然位置的元素有关。814 仅仅因为我们不了解引力，并不意味着我们应该抛弃导致我们现在认为是结果的影响的事物的概念重力。仅仅因为我们还不完全理解某事并不意味着我们应该删除占位符术语并停止询问有关它的问题。头脑是一个我们还没有完全理解的形而上学实体。就像人类的记忆一样，心灵仍然是科学中最后的伟大谜团之一。

I like to think of the mind as a product of the brain which is a product of evolution.[815](#footnote-776) “The mind is not the brain but what the brain does,” as Pinker puts it.[816](#footnote-775) Again, this is why you want a second mind, not a second brain. You don’t just want an inanimate jumble of wetware. You want an active, holistic system that becomes greater than the sum of its parts. The system itself is inanimate; however when all four components of the Antinet interact, a second mind emerges. 我喜欢将思维视为大脑的产物，大脑是进化的产物。 815 “思维不是大脑，而是大脑所做的事情，” 正如平克所说。 816 同样，这就是为什么你想要第二个头脑，而不是第二个大脑。你不只是想要一堆没有生命的湿件。您需要一个积极的、整体的系统，该系统变得比其各个部分的总和更大。系统本身是无生命的；然而，当 Antinet 的所有四个组成部分相互作用时，就会出现第二个想法。

**The Person Inside the AntinetAntinet 里面的人**
---------------------------------------------

People seem to overlook the fact that the Antinet filled the role of being an actual person for Luhmann. 人们似乎忽略了一个事实，即安提内特为卢曼扮演了一个真实的人。

To Luhmann, the Antinet was not just a thinking tool, it was a person. The concept of viewing the Antinet as a person might be seen as similar to the concept of animism, the way of what we in the modern West call “objects” as possessing person-like qualities. For example, in Japanese Shinto culture, it is believed that a soul lives within all matter; every-day things are thought of as being deities.[817](#footnote-774) This is perhaps why you’ll often find Japanese embracing the idea of robots being companions, nurses and caretaking companions for the elderly.[818](#footnote-773) In a similar vein, this might be one reason the pocket-sized digital pets called Tamagotchi first emerged in Japan, though they quickly spread to Western countries, as well. Several studies have analyzed how the Tamagotchi toys changed human behavior with digital devices. “Tamagotchi convinced consumers to willingly dedicate their time, attention, and emotions to the virtual pet.”[819](#footnote-772) 对卢曼来说，Antinet 不仅仅是一个思维工具，它还是一个人。将 Antinet 视为人的概念可能被视为类似于万物有灵论的概念，即我们在现代西方所说的 “物体” 具有类似人的品质的方式。例如，在日本神道文化中，人们认为灵魂存在于万物之中；每天的事物都被认为是神灵。817 这也许就是为什么你会经常发现日本人认为机器人是老年人的伴侣、护士和照顾伙伴的想法。818 同样，这可能是一个原因名为 Tamagotchi 的口袋大小的数字宠物首先出现在日本，但它们也迅速传播到西方国家。几项研究分析了 Tamagotchi 玩具如何通过数字设备改变人类行为。 “Tamagotchi 说服消费者愿意将他们的时间、注意力和情感投入虚拟宠物。”819

The phenomenon wherein we experience a deep connection when interacting with certain physical objects is widespread. With the Antinet it becomes even easier to experience this because you’re viewing your own thoughts, your own spirit, and your own soul within the handwritten cards of your Antinet. The entire system enables you to communicate with such an entity. 当我们与某些物理对象交互时，我们会体验到一种深层联系的现象很普遍。使用 Antinet，体验这一点变得更加容易，因为您正在 Antinet 的手写卡片中查看自己的思想、自己的精神和自己的灵魂。整个系统使您能够与这样的实体进行通信。

Even though Luhmann was an avid advocate of systems theory, stating, “it is easy to think of systems theory,” in trying to describe the Antinet he went a different direction when he opted for communication theory to explain it; but this was because the system revolves around communication with the second mind.[820](#footnote-771) 尽管卢曼是系统论的狂热拥护者，他说 “很容易想到系统论”，但在试图描述反网络时，他选择了通信理论来解释它，却走向了不同的方向；但这是因为该系统围绕着与第二头脑的交流。 820

The idea of a notebox emerging into an external instantiation of one’s own mind did not originate with Luhmann, but dates back to a situation described by Heinrich Von Kleist in 1805. He remarked upon the phenomenon of something like the second mind emerging in his analysis of the “midwifery of thought.”[821](#footnote-770) 笔记盒出现在一个人自己头脑的外部实例中的想法并非源自卢曼，而是可以追溯到 1805 年海因里希 · 冯 · 克莱斯特 (Heinrich Von Kleist) 描述的一种情况。 “思想的助产士”。821

The reason it was useful for Luhmann to create an actual (metaphysical) person to collaborate with centered around funding difficulties. In brief, Luhmann found that hiring research assistants and employees was too expensive. He needed a communication partner on whom he could rely (for at least thirty years). His Antinet proved to be not only reliable, but also an entity that inspired breakthrough insights in a way that would have been nearly impossible for even the best research assistant to produce. 卢曼创建一个真实的（形而上学的）人来与之合作的原因是围绕资金困难。简而言之，卢曼发现雇用研究助理和员工的费用太高。他需要一个可以信赖（至少三十年）的沟通伙伴。事实证明，他的 Antinet 不仅可靠，而且还是一个能激发突破性见解的实体，即使是最好的研究助理也几乎不可能产生这种见解。

When Luhmann first began building the Antinet it was seen as a memory aid; however in 1981, when he wrote his paper describing the Antinet, he knew it to be much more than just a memory tool. 当卢曼刚开始建造 Antinet 时，它被视为一种记忆辅助工具；然而在 1981 年，当他撰写描述 Antinet 的论文时，他知道它不仅仅是一种记忆工具。

The Antinet is not an analog note database. It’s not necessarily even about notes. Its primary nature concerns itself with the dualistic emergence of the second mind. Again, this dualistic emergence of the second mind relies upon the four principles of the Antinet. I make no claim that the emergence of a second mind is exclusive to the Antinet (perhaps others who have analog noteboxes also experience this phenomenon). However the type of second mind Luhmann experienced relies upon adhering to the four principles of the Antinet.Antinet 不是模拟笔记数据库。它甚至不一定与笔记有关。它的主要性质与第二思想的二元性出现有关。同样，第二思维的这种二元性出现依赖于 Antinet 的四个原则。我并不是说第二个头脑的出现是 Antinet 独有的（也许其他拥有模拟记事本的人也经历过这种现象）。然而，卢曼所经历的第二头脑类型依赖于坚持反网络的四个原则。

In brief, what we’re talking about here is truly something special. When I think of the Antinet, I don’t think about some tool in the notetaking app market. It’s not something that can be compared to whatever digital notetaking app is popular by the time you read this. The Antinet is in a different category altogether. It belongs in a class of tools which induce an intrapersonal dialogue that is helpful during creation. 简而言之，我们在这里谈论的确实是一些特别的东西。当我想到 Antinet 时，我不会想到笔记应用程序市场中的某些工具。在您阅读本文时，它无法与任何流行的数字笔记应用程序相提并论。 Antinet 完全属于不同的类别。它属于一类工具，可以引发对创作有帮助的内部对话。

Modern day scientists agree with Luhmann’s notion of a ghost in the box emerging from Antinets. One scholar confirms that it would be misleading to classify the Antinet as something which simply stores notes.[822](#footnote-769) Here’s why: when you peruse and read the thoughts written by someone who has passed—you feel this ghost-like internal presence. You begin to insert yourself in their shoes while they were writing down the thoughts on the card. 现代科学家同意卢曼关于盒子里的幽灵从 Antinets 出现的观点。一位学者证实，将 Antinet 归类为只是存储笔记的东西会产生误导。822 原因如下：当你细读和阅读逝者所写的思想时——你会感受到这种幽灵般的内在存在。当他们在卡片上写下想法时，您开始设身处地为他们着想。

With the Antinet, this ghost in the box factor is experienced in a slightly different manner. You yourself are viewing your own thoughts. You communicate with your own internal ghost and embark upon an internal dialogue that happens during the act of creation. 对于 Antinet，这种盒子里的幽灵因素的体验方式略有不同。你自己正在观察你自己的想法。你与自己内在的幽灵交流，并开始在创造过程中进行的内在对话。

Because the Antinet possesses the properties of both short-term thought development, and long-term thought development, it morphs into a unique metaphysical entity. The entity it becomes is beyond your control. You cannot preconceive how it will look in the future. This is oftentimes what people struggle with in the beginning. We’re so used to molding our knowledge using digital tools. Digital information is very malleable. We can refactor and reorganize our knowledge on a whim. Whatever cool new convention or idea emerges, can set you out on a months-long quest to reorganize your digital knowledge repository. With the Antinet this is not the case. You must submit yourself to the rigid organic structure that emerges over years of building out your knowledge one notecard at a time, one branch at a time. This chaotic and evolving structure of the Antinet makes it more fun to engage with. You’re always in for a surprise when creating with your Antinet. 由于 Antinet 同时具有短期思维发展和长期思维发展的特性，它演变成一个独特的形而上学实体。它变成的实体是你无法控制的。你不能先入为主地设想它在未来会是什么样子。这通常是人们一开始就在努力解决的问题。我们已经习惯于使用数字工具塑造我们的知识。数字信息具有很强的可塑性。我们可以随心所欲地重构和重组我们的知识。无论出现什么很酷的新惯例或想法，都可以让您开始为期数月的重组数字知识库的探索。对于 Antinet，情况并非如此。你必须服从多年来形成的僵硬的有机结构，一次一张记事卡，一次一个分支。 Antinet 的这种混乱和不断发展的结构使其更有趣。使用 Antinet 进行创作时，您总会有惊喜。

One reason why communicating with a second mind is unique centers around the limitations of each individual note. Within digital tools notes can be extensive in nature—seemingly all-encompassing for an idea. 与第二个头脑交流的独特之处之一在于每个音符的局限性。在数字工具中，笔记在本质上可以是广泛的——似乎包罗万象的想法。

With the Antinet, the notes are constrained by the size of each individual notecard. They’re also constrained by the difficulty and time-intensity of writing by hand. As a result of these constraints, the notes are more prompt-like in nature. They are units that prompt one’s internal dialogue to internally fire off the remaining details of the idea. Antinet notes communicate the idea without belaboring and over-communicating the idea. As a result of this under-communication of the idea, the rest of the communication takes place in the mind. 使用 Antinet，笔记受到每个单独记事卡大小的限制。他们还受到手写的难度和时间强度的限制。由于这些限制，笔记在本质上更像提示。它们是促使一个人的内部对话以在内部触发该想法的其余细节的单位。 Antinet notes 传达了这个想法，但没有冗长和过度传达这个想法。由于这种想法的沟通不足，其余的沟通发生在头脑中。

This concept of under-communication triggering an internal dialogue has been observed by scholars. It’s the result of one’s external memory interacting with one’s internal memory. After studying John Boyle, John Locke, and Robert Hooke, one researcher observed how their notes were useful in the way they prompted recollection. The notes weren’t valuable in themselves; they were valuable in the way they triggered an internal dialogue within their creator.[823](#footnote-768) 学者们已经观察到这种引发内部对话的沟通不足的概念。这是一个人的外部记忆与一个人的内部记忆相互作用的结果。在研究了 John Boyle、John Locke 和 Robert Hooke 之后，一位研究人员观察了他们的笔记在促进回忆方面的作用。这些票据本身没有价值；它们在创造者内部引发内部对话的方式很有价值。 823

The notes in your Antinet set off a chain reaction in your mind. Your notes serve as a cue for starting the recall process in your mind. Digital notes, on the other hand, tend to take different form. They tend to include too much detail. They tend to over-communicate the idea. This robs the creation process of much of its magic. Furthermore, the additional detail is unnecessary. It also ends up snowballing and creating an overabundance of information.Antinet 中的音符在您的脑海中引发了连锁反应。你的笔记可以作为在你脑海中开始回忆过程的线索。另一方面，数字笔记往往采用不同的形式。它们往往包含太多细节。他们倾向于过度传达这个想法。这剥夺了创造过程的大部分魔力。此外，额外的细节是不必要的。它还最终会滚雪球并产生过多的信息。

**The Personality of Your Second Mind 你的第二个头脑的个性**
--------------------------------------------------

The power of your second mind relies on its unique personality. There are several ways a unique personality is incorporated into the system. Again, the unique personality of the system relies on the core principles of the Antinet: Analog, Numeric-alpha Addresses, Tree Structure, Index. In particular, the numeric-alpha addresses are critical. They enable the system to become self-referential, and thus develop a “self” in the first-place. 第二个头脑的力量依赖于它独特的个性。有几种方法可以将独特的个性整合到系统中。同样，系统的独特个性依赖于 Antinet 的核心原则：模拟、数字字母地址、树结构、索引。特别是，数字字母地址很关键。它们使系统能够自我参照，从而首先发展出 “自我”。

Another way the system gains a personality involves how you use the index. Specifically, this relates to what unique keyterms you use to describe concepts. Certain terms you use to describe a concept might make complete sense in your mind, but another person might prefer a different term. You add personality to your system by using terms that make sense in your mind. For instance, I have a stem in my Antinet related to the concept of power law and the Pareto principle, the idea that 80% of something comes from 20% of the participants. For instance, 80% of a nation’s wealth comes from 20% of the population. It exemplifies that a small number of people (or objects) can generate a big result. In my index I have created keyterms for power law, as well as the Pareto principle. However the main term that comes to mind when I think of this principle is big impact, due to the idea that a few things can have a big impact on the whole. I’ve built out a section around instances of “big impact” phenomena in the world. Whenever I come across something related to this in my reading, I write Big Impact on the bibcard and underline it. This unique way of terming something is one way I’ve injected personality into my Antinet. 系统获得个性的另一种方式涉及您如何使用索引。具体来说，这与您用来描述概念的独特关键词有关。您用来描述一个概念的某些术语在您的脑海中可能完全有意义，但另一个人可能更喜欢不同的术语。您可以通过使用您认为有意义的术语来为您的系统增添个性。例如，我的 Antinet 中有一个词干与幂律和帕累托原则的概念有关，即 80% 的事物来自 20% 的参与者。例如，一个国家 80% 的财富来自 20% 的人口。它例证了少数人（或物体）可以产生很大的结果。在我的索引中，我为幂律和帕累托原理创建了关键词。然而，当我想到这个原则时，想到的主要术语是大影响，因为一些事情可以对整体产生大影响。我已经围绕世界上 “重大影响” 现象的实例建立了一个部分。每当我在阅读中遇到与此相关的内容时，我都会在 bibcard 上写下 Big Impact 并在其下划线。这种独特的命名方式是我将个性注入我的 Antinet 的一种方式。

It’s not only the unique keyterms you use that give the second mind its personality; it’s also the way in which you structure those keyterms. For instance, Luhmann observed how museums are frequently empty, while short-term art exhibits are completely packed.[824](#footnote-767) I’ve talked about this concept before; however it’s worth bringing up again to show how it affects the personality of one’s second mind. Instead of creating the keyterms Monet, Picasso, or Medici, Luhmann created the keyterm in his index for Preferences (For Temporally Limited Events). In my Antinet I would create a keyterm for this under Scarcity. My keyterm would be: Scarcity (Examples of It Motivating People). It would then link to the card address of the note. 不仅是您使用的独特关键词赋予了第二思维个性；这也是您构建这些关键词的方式。例如，卢曼观察到博物馆经常空无一人，而短期艺术展览却爆满。824 我之前已经谈过这个概念；然而，值得再次提出来展示它如何影响一个人的第二个头脑的个性。 Luhmann 没有创建关键字 Monet、Picasso 或 Medici，而是在他的索引中为 Preferences（For Temporally Limited Events）创建了关键字。在我的 Antinet 中，我会在 Scarcity 下为此创建一个关键词。我的关键词是：稀缺性（它激励人们的例子）。然后它将链接到笔记的卡地址。

This gives a glimpse into how keyterms inject a unique personality into your Antinet. Both the specific keyterms you use, as well as how you structure them adds a unique personality to your second mind. 这让我们得以一窥关键字词如何为您的 Antinet 注入独特的个性。您使用的特定关键词以及您构建它们的方式都为您的第二思维增添了独特的个性。

**Conclusion 结论**
-----------------

In this chapter, we covered a very important aspect of the Antinet. Actually two aspects. Communication, and the concept of the second mind. These concepts are a very real aspect in working with an Antinet. In the next section we’ll dive into the science backing the Antinet, and its relation to concepts from the science of human memory. 在本章中，我们介绍了 Antinet 的一个非常重要的方面。其实是两个方面。沟通和第二思维的概念。这些概念是使用 Antinet 的一个非常真实的方面。在下一节中，我们将深入探讨支持 Antinet 的科学，以及它与人类记忆科学概念的关系。

CHAPTER NINETEEN 第十九章
---------------------

Human Memory And The Antinet 人类记忆与反网络
-------------------------------------

In this chapter we’ll explore how the Antinet mirrors several aspects of human memory, including a look at the neuroscience behind why the Antinet is a helpful structure, and a deep dive into the concept of context within the Antinet. 在本章中，我们将探讨 Antinet 如何反映人类记忆的几个方面，包括研究 Antinet 为何是一个有用结构背后的神经科学，并深入探讨 Antinet 中的上下文概念。

**Human Memory and the Antinet 人类记忆和反网络**
-----------------------------------------

Luhmann was not forced into the structure of the Antinet due to the limitations of technology. He could have chosen a commonplace book, or a categorical notecard system (organized by human-readable subjects). In fact, Luhmann tried several methods for managing his thoughts from readings. His first attempt was to take notes on notecards and stick them into the book once he had finished. However, this caused the bindings of the books to fray and break.[825](#footnote-867) 由于技术的限制，卢曼并没有被迫进入 Antinet 的结构。他本可以选择一本普通的书，或者一个分类记事卡系统（由人类可读的主题组织）。事实上，卢曼尝试了几种通过阅读来管理思想的方法。他的第一个尝试是在记事卡上做笔记，并在完成后将它们贴在书中。然而，这导致书籍的装订磨损和断裂。 825

After that failed experiment, he tried another technique, placing the notecards his readings generated into folders. Yet, as these notes increased, Luhmann complained of no longer being able to find anything in them.[826](#footnote-866) He could have even switched to using a computer later in his life, but he did not choose any of these routes. 在那个失败的实验之后，他尝试了另一种技术，将他的读数生成的记事卡放入文件夹中。然而，随着这些笔记的增加，卢曼抱怨说再也无法在其中找到任何东西。826 他甚至可以在以后的生活中改用计算机，但他没有选择这些途径中的任何一条。

These false starts helped Luhmann design the perfect system that served him for over forty years. 这些错误的开始帮助卢曼设计了为他服务了四十多年的完美系统。

Luhmann could have switched to using a computer later in his life. However, Luhmann did not choose those routes. The structure of the Antinet, according to one scholar, was not haphazard, but was a deliberate choice arising out of Luhmann’s familiarity with how human memory worked.[827](#footnote-865) This familiarity also allowed Luhmann to understand how computer memory would work in the future (which emphasized the benefits of multiple storage).[828](#footnote-864) 卢曼本可以在他生命的晚些时候转而使用计算机。然而，卢曼并没有选择那些路线。根据一位学者的说法，Antinet 的结构并非偶然，而是卢曼对人类记忆如何工作的熟悉而有意选择的。 827 这种熟悉也让卢曼理解了计算机内存在未来的工作方式（强调多重存储的好处）。828

The scholar, Johannes Schmidt, points out that Luhmann’s decision to use hard-coded, non-changing numeric-alpha addresses is the essential pre- requisite for creativity in his system.[829](#footnote-863) 学者约翰内斯 · 施密特 (Johannes Schmidt) 指出，卢曼 (Luhmann) 决定使用硬编码、不变的数字字母地址是在他的系统中发挥创造力的必要先决条件。 829

Luhmann was likely aware of the issue with multiple storage: the fact that the computer science conception of it is grossly misleading due to it being overly abstract (and thus synthetic). Instead of a computer science concept of multiple storage, Luhmann preferred a more organic version based on the science of human memory.Luhmann 很可能意识到多重存储的问题：计算机科学的概念由于过于抽象（因此是综合的）而严重误导。卢曼没有使用计算机科学的多重存储概念，而是更喜欢基于人类记忆科学的更有机的版本。

In a card on the parent stem of Luhmann’s Antinet located two cards before Luhmann mentions “multiple storage,” we find him citing the following reference: “Ashby 1967, p. 103.”[830](#footnote-862) Luhmann references this, implying that it’s noteworthy because it provides a “general structure of memories.” 在 Luhmann 的 Antinet 的父主干上的一张卡片中，在 Luhmann 提到 “多重存储” 之前找到两张卡片，我们发现他引用了以下参考资料：“Ashby 1967，p。 103.”830 卢曼引用了这一点，暗示它值得注意，因为它提供了“记忆的一般结构”。

I did some digging and, after some time, was able to get my hands on the source Luhmann referenced. Here is the pertinent quote: 我进行了一些挖掘，一段时间后，我终于找到了 Luhmann 引用的来源。这是相关的引用：

At the moment, our scientific thinking tends to be grossly misled by the example of the big digital computer. It has a big memory store, kept far from the working parts, which send recordable facts to special places, and then later go back to exactly the same places to regain the information.[831](#footnote-861) 目前，我们的科学思维往往被大型数字计算机的例子严重误导。它有一个很大的记忆库，远离工作部件，将可记录的事实发送到特殊的地方，然后再回到完全相同的地方重新获得信息。 831

“Such a method,” Ashby continues, “can hardly be achieved in biological machinery,” and he points to biological noise in such systems, such as injury, starvation, and infection.[832](#footnote-860) Ashby is reflecting on the mechanistic problems found in digital systems. There’s no reality built into them (like the reality of human memory decaying given any injury, starvation, or infection a person experiences).“这种方法，” 阿什比继续说道，“在生物机器中很难实现”，他指出了此类系统中的生物噪音，例如伤害、饥饿和感染。832 阿什比正在反思数字系统中发现的机械问题. 它们没有内置的现实（比如人类记忆会因人经历的任何伤害、饥饿或感染而衰退的现实）。

Ashby also states something interesting: “More likely is it that most of the brain’s memory traces occur, and are retained, at the site of their action.”[833](#footnote-859) What Ashby means by this is that thoughts are created in the context in which they are developed and are retained within that context. In the case of the Antinet, structured as it is to function akin to human memory, when developing a thought within one branch (like branch 4212, for instance), the memory of that thought is retained in that branch. It’s not something that is freely floating around in a context-free graph (which is reflective of how digital notetaking apps operate). 阿什比还陈述了一些有趣的事情：“更有可能的是，大脑的大部分记忆痕迹都发生在他们行动的地点，并被保留下来。”833 阿什比的意思是，思想是在他们所处的环境中产生的。在这种情况下得到发展和保留。在 Antinet 的情况下，其结构类似于人类记忆，当在一个分支（例如分支 4212）中发展思想时，该思想的记忆将保留在该分支中。它不是在上下文无关的图形中自由浮动的东西（它反映了数字笔记应用程序的运行方式）。

Memories, Ashby observes, are “widely scattered,” yet they also retain the context (in the Antinet, it’s the branch) in which they were originally developed.[834](#footnote-858) 阿什比观察到，记忆 “分布广泛”，但它们也保留了最初开发它们的背景（在 Antinet 中，它是分支）。 834

Each component of a memory contains its own context and branches, and this is reflected in how the Antinet works. In the following illustration, a memory (or thought) that is recorded in the Antinet is composed of two other memories, represented by a sequence of cards that are branched (parts A and B). 记忆的每个组成部分都包含自己的上下文和分支，这反映在 Antinet 的工作方式中。在下图中，记录在 Antinet 中的记忆（或思想）由另外两个记忆组成，由一系列分支的卡片（A 部分和 B 部分）表示。

Ashby likens this to how “animal heat” is understood as having two sub-components, metabolism and oxidation.[835](#footnote-857) 阿什比将此比作 “动物热量” 被理解为具有两个子成分，即新陈代谢和氧化。 835

So to reiterate, Ashby argues that the concept of memory is “grossly misled by the example of the big digital computer” (which stores information in mechanistic, discrete places), because this is not how human memory works, since it is “more likely …that most of the brain’s memory traces occur, and are retained, at the site of their action.”[836](#footnote-856) 因此，重申一下，阿什比认为记忆的概念 “被大型数字计算机的例子严重误导了”（它将信息存储在机械的、离散的地方），因为这不是人类记忆的工作方式，因为它 “更有可能…… 大脑的大部分记忆痕迹都发生在并保留在它们的行动地点。”836

In other words, memory is not some simple, perfectly ordered, deterministic, and consistent system. It’s not built on a clean binary system (of 1s and 0s). Rather it is a distributed system requiring chains of relationships based within their context. 换句话说，记忆不是一些简单的、完美有序的、确定性的和一致的系统。它不是建立在一个干净的二进制系统（1 和 0 的）上。相反，它是一个分布式系统，需要基于上下文的关系链。

Unlike digital computers, the programs we execute are subject to noise. The Antinet, like human memory, is truly a communication system, as Ashby alludes to.[837](#footnote-855) 与数字计算机不同，我们执行的程序会受到噪音的影响。正如 Ashby 所暗示的那样，Antinet 就像人类的记忆一样，是真正的通信系统。 837

Luhmann’s approach to the Antinet structure appeared to opt for the mereological interpretation of human memory. As a social scientist capable of applying systems theory to sociology, it comes as no surprise that he would favor a systems-based view (mereology), rather than a computation-based view. 卢曼对 Antinet 结构的研究似乎选择了对人类记忆的分体学解释。作为一名能够将系统理论应用于社会学的社会科学家，他偏爱基于系统的观点（分体学）而不是基于计算的观点也就不足为奇了。

The mereological approach views memory as a system made up of subsystems. The environment in which memory operates is provided by other systems. The computational approach to human memory views memory as an algorithm, with a focus on mathematical equations and quantitative experiments to study the encoding, storage, and retrieval building blocks of human memory.[838](#footnote-854) 分体学方法将记忆视为由子系统组成的系统。内存运行的环境是由其他系统提供的。人类记忆的计算方法将记忆视为一种算法，侧重于数学方程式和定量实验，以研究人类记忆的编码、存储和检索构建块。 838

Immediately following Luhmann’s reference to Ashby, he states, “you do not have to rely on a vast number of point-by-point accesses.”[839](#footnote-853) What he means is that you don’t need a robust list of keyterms that point to every single card. Rather you may explore and navigate your Antinet given just a general keyterm in your index. Due to the branched tree structure, you will be able to navigate and uncover genius-level insights and surprises along the way. 在 Luhmann 提到 Ashby 之后，他立即说道，“你不必依赖大量的逐点访问。”839 他的意思是你不需要一个强大的关键字列表来指向每个单卡。相反，您可以在您的索引中仅给出一个通用关键词来探索和导航您的 Antinet。由于分支树结构，您将能够一路导航并发现天才级的见解和惊喜。

It’s not a stretch to imagine how Luhmann approached the design and architecture of his Antinet, likely taking a systems-science approach to devising what he initially thought of as his “second memory.”[840](#footnote-852) Later on, of course, this system evolved, thanks to the unique architecture and design of the Antinet, into a second mind. 不难想象卢曼是如何处理他的 Antinet 的设计和架构的，很可能是采用系统科学方法来设计他最初认为是他的 “第二记忆” 的东西。840 当然，后来这个系统得到了发展，谢谢到 Antinet 的独特架构和设计，进入第二个头脑。

Luhmann did this by first breaking apart the components that create human memory. After this, he created abstracted instantiations of the components. 卢曼通过首先分解创造人类记忆的组件来做到这一点。此后，他创建了组件的抽象实例。

You can see such in the architecture of how cardlinks mirror key functional aspects of human memory. 您可以在卡片链接如何反映人类记忆的关键功能方面的架构中看到这一点。

After studying how human memory works, one can begin to see the brilliance in Luhmann’s design of the Antinet. 在研究了人类记忆的工作原理之后，人们可以开始看到卢曼设计的反网络的高明之处。

Take, for instance, an Antinet with the following numeric-alpha addresses: 以具有以下数字字母地址的 Antinet 为例：

The branch is expressed by the four-digits at the beginning of the numeric-alpha address. For instance: 4212, 4214, 5425. 分支由数字字母地址开头的四位数字表示。例如：4212、4214、5425。

The stems are things like: 4214/1, 4214/1a, 4214/2, 4214/3. From this, there are relative stemlinks like 4214/1a/1, 4214/1a/2, 4214/1a/3. These stemlinks are essentially linked to 4214/1a (they’ve “stemmed down” from 4214/1a). These are analogous to forward and backward associations in human memory.[841](#footnote-851) 词干是这样的：4214/1、4214/1a、4214/2、4214/3。由此，有相对的词干链接，如 4214/1a/1、4214/1a/2、4214/1a/3。这些 stemlinks 本质上链接到 4214/1a（它们从 4214/1a“向下”）。这些类似于人类记忆中的前向和后向联想。 841

Because the Antinet is based on similarity by way of proximity, it mirrors human memory in that the further away two memories or thoughts are, and more memories in between them, the more the association decreases.[842](#footnote-850) The closer the items and memories are, their greater the association is. 因为 Antinet 基于接近度的相似性，它反映了人类记忆，因为两个记忆或思想距离越远，它们之间的记忆越多，关联就越减少。 842 项目和记忆越近，他们的协会越大。

Yet, from experience, we know this isn’t necessarily always the case. There are some ideas located in some contextual branches that are very closely related to an idea in a branch or discipline located far away from it. 然而，根据经验，我们知道情况并非总是如此。某些上下文分支中的一些想法与远离它的分支或学科中的想法非常密切相关。

For such instance, remote associations are part of human memory.[843](#footnote-849) These are essentially cardlinks that link to a branch or a card in a remote part of the Antinet. For instance, say the card 4214/1a/2 contains a sentence at the bottom: For more on the subject of the power of writing by hand, see ‘5425/1’. This is an instance of a remote cardlink (i.e., a remote association in the terminology of human memory). 例如，远程关联是人类记忆的一部分。843 这些本质上是链接到 Antinet 远程部分的分支或卡片的卡片链接。例如，假设卡片 4214/1a/2 在底部包含一句话：有关手写力量的更多信息，请参阅 “5425/1”。这是远程卡片链接的一个实例（即，人类记忆术语中的远程关联）。

**The Neuroscience Behind the AntinetAntinet 背后的神经科学**
------------------------------------------------------

Another analogy of the Antinet comes from neuroscience. Think of notecards as neurons, and the cardlinks as connections.Antinet 的另一个类比来自神经科学。将记事卡视为神经元，将卡片链接视为连接。

The idea of likening notecards to neurons may seem farfetched at first. However, it’s really not. The neural networks we think of today as legitimate are artificial abstractions. In fact, they’re perhaps even abstractions of abstractions. The reason why is simple. The models researchers use to study human memory “bear only a faint resemblance to real biological neurons: they are highly simplified computational ‘units’ that integrate and transmit information.”[844](#footnote-848) 乍一看，将记事卡比作神经元的想法似乎有些牵强。然而，事实并非如此。我们今天认为合法的神经网络是人工抽象。事实上，它们甚至可能是抽象的抽象。原因很简单。研究人员用来研究人类记忆的模型 “与真实的生物神经元只有微弱的相似之处：它们是高度简化的计算‘单元’，可以整合和传输信息。”844

Most of what people think of when they think of neural networks aren’t actually real; they’re artificial. 人们在想到神经网络时想到的大部分内容实际上都不是真实的；他们是人造的。

You see, many people think neural networks are part of natural science. They’re abstractions. When people think of neural networks they’re usually thinking of artificial neural networks. However, there are three types of neural networks: (1) biological neural networks, (2) artificial neural networks, and (3) haptic neural networks. 你看，很多人认为神经网络是自然科学的一部分。它们是抽象的。当人们想到神经网络时，他们通常会想到人工神经网络。然而，存在三种类型的神经网络：(1) 生物神经网络，(2) 人工神经网络，以及 (3) 触觉神经网络。

Haptic neural networks are artificial yet not digital; they can be touched and worked with in physical reality. The Antinet is an example of a haptic neural network. 触觉神经网络是人工的，但不是数字的；他们可以在物理现实中被触摸和使用。 Antinet 是触觉神经网络的一个例子。

Notecards serve as a wonderful physical world abstraction for neurons—at least the neurons modeled by psychologists, computer scientists and neuroscientists. 记事卡是神经元的美妙物理世界抽象——至少是心理学家、计算机科学家和神经科学家建模的神经元。

Notecards fit the definition of “highly simplified computational ‘units’ that integrate and transmit information.”[845](#footnote-847) Another good analogy for a neuron is a tweet (perhaps that’s why Twitter, with its character-limited nature, has done so exceptionally well). The simplicity of such containers representing a neuron actually mirrors a natural reality quite well. 记事卡符合 “集成和传输信息的高度简化的计算‘单元’” 的定义。845 神经元的另一个很好的类比是推文（也许这就是为什么 Twitter 具有字符限制的特性，却做得如此出色）。这种表示神经元的容器的简单性实际上很好地反映了自然现实。

There’s one difference between the Antinet and the human brain, and the difference centers around one thing: vastness. The sheer size of neurons and connections in the human brain are staggering. The human brain possesses one hundred billion neurons, and two hundred trillion connections.[846](#footnote-846) If we were to take the neuroscience analogy of the Antinet seriously, you would need to compile one hundred billion notecards and create two hundred trillion cardlinks between them. From the Antinet Niklas Luhmann worked on from 1951 to 1997, he was only able to create a measly seventy-five thousand cards (maincards).[847](#footnote-845) That’s a lot fewer than one hundred billion.Antinet 和人脑之间有一个区别，这个区别集中在一件事上：浩瀚。人脑中神经元和连接的庞大规模是惊人的。人脑拥有 1000 亿个神经元和 200 万亿个连接。846 如果我们认真对待 Antinet 的神经科学类比，您将需要编制 1000 亿个记事卡并在它们之间创建 200 万亿个卡片链接。从 1951 年到 1997 年尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 从事的 Antinet 工作，他只能创造出区区七万五千张卡片（主卡）。847 这比一千亿少了很多。

Yet, I say all of this with a tongue-in-cheek attitude. Of course one shouldn’t intend to create 100 billion notecards, with 200 trillion cardlinks. I chose to illustrate this comparison just to show how powerful this structure can be. With a database of 75,000 notecards one creates a communication partner that proves itself to be quite powerful. 然而，我以半开玩笑的态度说出这一切。当然，人们不应该打算用 200 万亿个卡片链接创建 1000 亿张记事卡。我选择说明这种比较只是为了展示这种结构的强大之处。借助包含 75,000 个记事卡的数据库，您可以创建一个证明自己非常强大的通信伙伴。

Niklas Luhmann was familiar with how the brain was structured. It’s no coincidence that he built his Antinet around the concept of connections. 尼克拉斯 · 卢曼 (Niklas Luhmann) 熟悉大脑的结构。他围绕连接概念构建 Antinet 并非巧合。

Luhmann points out how memory does not function as a sum of point-by-point accesses[848](#footnote-844) (i.e., like sequentially moving through your notes or just navigating wikilinks in a digital notetaking app). Rather, your brain needs just a starting direction of access points. From there the brain uses internal links by way of the sequential notes, and the internal links and connections (made possible by remote cardlinks).Luhmann 指出记忆如何不能作为逐点访问的总和来发挥作用 848（即，就像在笔记中按顺序移动或只是在数字笔记应用程序中导航 wiki 链接）。相反，您的大脑只需要访问点的起始方向。从那里，大脑通过顺序笔记、内部链接和连接（通过远程卡片链接成为可能）使用内部链接。

**An Antinet Representation of How Human Memory Actually Works 人类记忆实际工作原理的反网络表示**
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The latest research on human memory reveals evidence for something termed the distributed representation of memory. The idea holds that memory is represented not merely by one notecard (neuron), but an interaction between a large set of neurons.[849](#footnote-843) 对人类记忆的最新研究揭示了称为记忆分布式表示的证据。这个想法认为，记忆不仅由一个记事卡（神经元）表示，而且由一大组神经元之间的相互作用表示。 849

For instance, in one piece of writing, I used the following distributed representations of memories (representations of thought) to form an article: 2428/1, 2428/1/0, 2428/1/1, 2428/1a, 2428/1b, 3535/2, 4212/2ba, 4214/1a/1a, 4214/2e/1b/1. Combined, these created a distributed representation of a memory. 例如，在一篇文章中，我使用了以下分布式记忆表征（思想表征）来组成一篇文章：2428/1、2428/1/0、2428/1/1、2428/1a、2428/1b , 3535/2, 4212/2ba, 4214/1a/1a, 4214/2e/1b/1。结合起来，这些创建了内存的分布式表示。

**The Contexts of the AntinetAntinet 的上下文**
