-------------------------------------------

Context can be thought of as a base layer protocol in the Antinet. In other words, context is a foundational component for how thoughts are developed in an Antinet. The importance of context cannot be overstated. 上下文可以被认为是 Antinet 中的基础层协议。换句话说，上下文是思想如何在 Antinet 中发展的基础组成部分。语境的重要性怎么强调都不为过。

Think of context as the branch or stem in which an idea or thought is contained. For instance, my branch on information science is 4212. The thoughts that I develop in this branch are developed within the context of information science. 将上下文视为包含想法或想法的分支或主干。例如，我的信息科学分支是 4212。我在这个分支中发展的思想是在信息科学的背景下发展的。

Early memory scientists thought of context as a fixed container (thus, 4212 would always be known as the information science branch). However, more recent findings in the study of human memory have led to this model being revised. Today it is believed that such context gradually evolves over time.[850](#footnote-842) In other words, what starts out as the information science branch can evolve to become the Antinet branch. Paradoxically, the context evolves based on its content, and the content evolves based on its context. This fuzzy occurrence serves as another illustration as to why the Antinet is built on a rough structure with fuzzy categories. Such a system mirrors how human memory works. 早期的记忆科学家将上下文视为一个固定的容器（因此，4212 将始终被称为信息科学分支）。然而，人类记忆研究的最新发现导致该模型被修改。今天，人们相信这种背景会随着时间的推移而逐渐演变。850 换句话说，最初的信息科学分支可以演变为 Antinet 分支。矛盾的是，上下文根据其内容演变，内容根据其上下文演变。这种模糊的现象可以作为另一个说明，说明为什么 Antinet 建立在具有模糊类别的粗略结构上。这样的系统反映了人类记忆的工作方式。

Digital Zettelkasten systems exhibit fewer properties of rough structures and fuzzy categories; they’re locked into the strict binary world of 1s and 0s. 数字 Zettelkasten 系统表现出较少的粗糙结构和模糊类别的特性；他们被锁在 1 和 0 的严格二进制世界中。

One scientist specializing in the field of memory writing about what takes place when learning suggests that one forms associations not only based on the actual content encountered, but actually on three things.[851](#footnote-841) 一位专门研究记忆领域的科学家写了关于学习时发生的事情，这表明人们不仅根据遇到的实际内容，而且实际上根据三件事来形成联想。 851

First, of course, is the actual content. When you read a book, you’re forming associations based on the content of what you read. Content can include other media (music, articles, podcasts, etc.). In other words, when you’re reading a biography about F. Scott Fitzgerald, and you read about The Great Gatsby selling fewer than five hundred copies in the entire decade of the 1930s, you might associate the content (the information) with the principle of failure, or with things taking time to blossom.[852](#footnote-840) The association emerges from the content itself. 首先，当然是实际内容。当您阅读一本书时，您会根据所阅读的内容形成联想。内容可以包括其他媒体（音乐、文章、播客等）。换句话说，当你读到一本关于 F. Scott Fitzgerald 的传记，并且读到《了不起的盖茨比》在 1930 年代的整个十年里销量不到 500 册时，你可能会将内容（信息）与原则联系起来失败，或事物需要时间才能开花结果。852 联想来自内容本身。

Second, associations are formed based on the external context of the item that is encountered (for example, the environment or setting, or the tactile dimension of the material one is learning about). More on this will be discussed shortly. 其次，联想是根据遇到的项目的外部背景形成的（例如，环境或设置，或者正在学习的材料的触觉维度）。有关这方面的更多信息将在稍后讨论。

Third, associations are formed based on the internal context at the time one is processing the content. For instance, the internal thoughts and ideas taking place in your mind while reading an article today vs. those you had while reading the same article ten years prior; the same content results in a drastically different experience depending on the internal context. In other words, the associations you form based on reading the same content at different periods of your life, will yield different ideas. 第三，联想是基于处理内容时的内部上下文形成的。例如，今天阅读一篇文章时您脑海中出现的内部想法和想法与您十年前阅读同一篇文章时的想法和想法；根据内部上下文，相同的内容会产生截然不同的体验。换句话说，你在生活的不同时期阅读相同内容所形成的联想，会产生不同的想法。

**An Illustration of Context vs. Content 上下文与内容的说明**

When you learn an idea in a given context (for example, the concept of asynchronicity while studying web development), the context is web development; the content is the concept of asynchronicity. Within the context of web development, asynchronicity refers to the loading of web assets in a parallel fashion. There are other contexts for the concept of asynchronicity, for instance asynchronous learning. Essentially, this points out the fact that the same content can have different meaning given a different context. Likewise, this is how human memory is structured and (not surprisingly) it’s how the Antinet is structured.[853](#footnote-839) 当你在给定的上下文中学习一个想法时（例如，学习 Web 开发时的异步概念），上下文就是 Web 开发；内容是异步的概念。在 Web 开发的上下文中，异步性是指以并行方式加载 Web 资产。异步性的概念还有其他上下文，例如异步学习。从本质上讲，这指出了一个事实，即在不同的上下文中，相同的内容可能具有不同的含义。同样，这就是人类记忆的结构方式，并且（毫不奇怪）这就是 Antinet 的结构方式。 853

**Internal Context is a Very Powerful Thing 内部上下文是一个非常强大的东西**

Around 2010, I recall a conversation with an investor in one of my past companies who was one of the top-level team members at Google’s advertising technology division. He told me that Google was currently facing a crisis—a threat to their business. Up to that point, its technology had revolved around content. That is, the search term one finds in front of them on the search results page and the ads the user experiences when browsing a web page. The ads and the search terms were based on the content of the page. For instance, if you were on a website about cats, you would get ads about cat food. Google’s ad technology was built around the content the user was currently accessing at the time. 大约在 2010 年，我记得与我过去一家公司的一位投资者的一次谈话，他是谷歌广告技术部门的顶级团队成员之一。他告诉我，谷歌目前正面临一场危机——对他们业务的威胁。到那时为止，它的技术一直围绕着内容。也就是说，用户在搜索结果页面上找到的搜索词以及用户在浏览网页时体验到的广告。广告和搜索词是基于页面的内容。例如，如果您访问有关猫的网站，您会看到有关猫食的广告。谷歌的广告技术是围绕用户当时正在访问的内容构建的。

However, a new technology emerged in ad targeting known as remarketing or retargeting. This technology targeted users based on their recent patterns and habits. This meant, whatever website they recently visited, would be affixed to the profile of that user. The way these profiles were built relied on website cookies (which you’ve probably now heard of, since almost every website prompts you to accept being tracked with cookies). As a result, when you’re viewing a website about cats, you’d start seeing ads for the website of the clothing store you visited yesterday. 然而，广告定位中出现了一种新技术，称为再营销或重新定位。该技术根据用户最近的模式和习惯来定位用户。这意味着，无论他们最近访问过什么网站，都将附加到该用户的个人资料中。这些配置文件的构建方式依赖于网站 cookie（您现在可能已经听说过，因为几乎每个网站都会提示您接受使用 cookie 进行跟踪）。因此，当您浏览有关猫的网站时，您会开始看到昨天访问过的服装店网站的广告。

Google quickly adapted to this new ad technology and implemented it in their own products. They even went a step further and enabled advertisers to not only target users based on recent websites they had visited, but also on the recent keywords they searched on Google.Google 很快适应了这种新的广告技术，并将其应用到自己的产品中。他们甚至更进一步，使广告商不仅可以根据用户最近访问过的网站，还可以根据他们最近在 Google 上搜索的关键字来定位用户。

Remarketing effectively led to a way of targeting people based on their search terms or the websites they had visited recently (the advertiser could define how recently). Users were essentially grouped into buckets based on their internal context. It started with targeting people who visited any given website, but later on became more abstracted. Google enabled audience targeting based on interests, affinity groups, and whether a person was hot and in the market to buy certain products (part of what’s called an in-market audience). For instance, advertisers could target people who were actively shopping for a new car (indicated by their having visited a number of car websites and navigated to the pricing pages). 再营销有效地导致了一种根据人们的搜索词或他们最近访问过的网站（广告商可以定义最近）来定位人们的方式。用户基本上根据他们的内部上下文被分组到桶中。它首先针对访问过任何给定网站的人，但后来变得更加抽象。谷歌根据兴趣、亲和力群体以及一个人是否热门以及是否在市场上购买某些产品（所谓的有购买意向的受众群体的一部分）来启用受众群体定位。例如，广告商可以针对那些积极购买新车的人（通过他们访问过许多汽车网站并导航到定价页面来表示）。

**Internal Context in the AntinetAntinet 中的内部上下文**

Internal context in relation to the Antinet refers to your internal monologue and the internal thoughts that arise while reading a text or engaging with a piece of content.[854](#footnote-838) Your internal context is affected by whether or not thoughts are consciously accessible at the time you’re engaging with content. 与 Antinet 相关的内在语境是指您的内心独白和在阅读文本或参与一段内容时出现的内在想法。854 您的内在语境受到您在阅读时是否有意识地访问想法的影响。与内容互动。

The experience of internal context can be illustrated in an experience you might have had in which you have a completely different opinion of a book you read ten years ago, compared with your opinion after reading it in the present. 内在语境的体验可以用你可能有过的经历来说明，在这种经历中，你对十年前读过的书的看法与现在读完后的看法完全不同。

For instance, I recall being forced to read The Great Gatsby in high school. I found myself bored out of my mind. I didn’t retain much. The only thing I remember was some stupidly named place the book was set in, called West Egg and East Egg. Ten years later I read the same book and was captivated. It became one of my favorite books of all time. My mindset was different when I read it the second time. I was interested and intrigued by the prose and writing style. I also understood more background about its author, and was more fascinated with the book because of this. 例如，我记得在高中时被迫阅读《了不起的盖茨比》。我发现自己无聊透了。我没有保留太多。我唯一记得的是这本书所在的某个名字愚蠢的地方，叫做 West Egg 和 East Egg。十年后，我读了同一本书并被迷住了。它成为我一直以来最喜欢的书之一。当我第二次阅读时，我的心态有所不同。我对散文和写作风格很感兴趣。我也因此更多地了解了作者的背景，也因此对这本书更加着迷。

With non-fiction books the power of different contexts is even more prevalent. For instance, reading the book How the Mind Works by Steven Pinker was an interesting experience. I would have probably found it more impactful if I hadn’t already read the book Sapiens by Yuval Noah Harari. In Pinker’s book, he introduced some very intriguing ideas; however they were ideas I was already familiar with thanks to reading Sapiens. The internal monologue in my mind was like, This is interesting. This reminds me of the section in Sapiens about the cognitive revolution. As a result, while reading How the Mind Works, I would simply write down the keyterm cognitive revolution on my bibcard. I then would create an external reference to the card on cognitive revolution that was already installed in my Antinet. 对于非小说类书籍，不同背景的力量更为普遍。例如，阅读 Steven Pinker 的 How the Mind Works 一书是一次有趣的经历。如果我没有读过 Yuval Noah Harari 的《智人》一书，我可能会发现它更有影响力。在平克的书中，他介绍了一些非常有趣的想法；但是，由于阅读了《智人》，我已经熟悉了这些想法。我脑海中的内心独白就像，这很有趣。这让我想起了《智人》中关于认知革命的部分。因此，在阅读《思维是如何工作的》时，我会简单地在我的名片上写下关键词认知革命。然后，我将创建一个外部引用，指向已安装在我的 Antinet 中的认知革命卡片。

In brief, the internal context in which I read the book was quite different than what it would have been if I hadn’t read Sapiens first. I probably would have been more impressed with Pinker’s book if that had been the case, too! 简而言之，我阅读这本书的内部环境与我没有先读《智人》的情况大不相同。如果是这样的话，我可能会对平克的书印象更深刻，也是！

When presented with a concept (or a thought) today, the concept activates related information internally in your mind. 今天，当提出一个概念（或一个想法）时，该概念会在您的脑海中激活相关信息。

For another simple example, imagine you were tasked with memorizing the following list: house, shoe, pig. Let’s hone in on the item pig. You probably imagine an abstract representation of a pig (like a pig emoji). I, myself, on the other hand have a completely different representation of pig. Why? Because for about a six month period while writing this book, I owned a pet pig named Garth. When I think of the word pig, I think of Garth (and the many times he pissed on my carpet).[855](#footnote-837) 再举一个简单的例子，假设你的任务是记住以下列表：房子、鞋子、猪。让我们来研究一下项目猪。您可能会想象一只猪的抽象表示（如猪表情符号）。另一方面，我本人对猪有完全不同的表现。为什么？因为在写这本书的大约六个月时间里，我养了一只名叫加思的宠物猪。当我想到猪这个词时，我就会想到加思（以及他多次在我的地毯上撒尿）。855

So what does this mean? In brief, even prior to the experiment taking place, I had a different internal context than you when beginning to memorize the list. As you can imagine, having certain internal representations could be quite advantageous for memorizing certain things.[856](#footnote-836) 那么这是什么意思？简而言之，甚至在实验开始之前，我在开始记住列表时的内部背景就与你不同。可以想象，拥有某些内部表征对于记忆某些事物可能非常有利。 856

A thought, which is the raw material of an Antinet, is much like an experience. As scholars have long recognized, an experience cannot be repeated exactly on two separate occasions.[857](#footnote-835) Every thought is experienced in a somewhat different context. Context can include surrounding thoughts you’ve just had (and that are reverberating in your mind), or the setting in which you have the thought (the external context), or the time of occurrence.[858](#footnote-834) 作为 Antinet 的原材料的思想很像一种体验。正如学者们早就认识到的那样，一种体验不能在两个不同的场合完全重复。857 每个想法都是在不同的背景下体验的。背景可以包括您刚刚产生的周围想法（并且在您的脑海中回荡），或者您产生想法的环境（外部环境），或者发生的时间。 858

Let’s revisit the diagram showing the different variables which shape a thought: 让我们重新审视一下显示塑造思想的不同变量的图表：

Every thought is shaped by internal context. The Antinet captures the internal context of one’s mind quite effectively, and it locks it in time. It does this in a more effective way than digital systems. I contend this is because digital systems are always updating themselves. They’re too fluid and they do not show the internal context of your mind at the time you created a note. For instance, in one of the cards I was referring to when I wrote this section, there was a note that explained internal context, and then said, See ‘4214/3d/3b/2’. I have no idea or recollection of making this note, nor did I have any idea what note 4214/3d/3b/2 was. It turned out to be a card about external context. Essentially, when I was creating this card about internal context I mentioned something that had to do with external context and decided to create a cardlink to that card (which at the time was something I was closely familiar with). This communicates to me where my mind was during the time I created the card. When I created the card about internal context, my past self wanted to make sure I differentiated it from external context and I provided a link to external context in order to view the differences between the two. It stamps the state of my mind at that time, in a static place in (remembered) time. 每个想法都是由内部环境塑造的。 Antinet 非常有效地捕获了一个人思想的内部上下文，并及时锁定了它。它以比数字系统更有效的方式做到这一点。我认为这是因为数字系统总是在自我更新。它们太流畅了，无法显示您在创建笔记时的内部背景。例如，在我编写本节时所参考的其中一张卡片中，有一张说明解释内部上下文的注释，然后说，参见 “4214/3d/3b/2”。我不知道或不记得写过这篇笔记，我也不知道笔记 4214/3d/3b/2 是什么。原来是一张关于外在语境的卡片。本质上，当我创建这张关于内部上下文的卡片时，我提到了一些与外部上下文有关的内容，并决定创建一个指向该卡片的卡片链接（这在当时是我非常熟悉的）。这告诉我在创建卡片时我的想法是什么。当我创建关于内部上下文的卡片时，我过去的自己想要确保我将它与外部上下文区分开来，并且我提供了一个到外部上下文的链接以查看两者之间的差异。它在（记忆中的）时间的一个静止位置标记了我当时的思想状态。

With digital notetaking tools, such a note describing a topic would likely be a bullet point list, and would continually grow, only to be edited, rearranged, modified, or deleted. By the time I was ready to actually begin writing the section I would no longer see the original internal context and internal life of that note stamped in time. This is not ideal. You want to see an original track-record and a snapshot of the original state your mind was in when it created the note. Granted, I could update the card and add more links later on; however, to maintain this time connection, I suggest changing ink color for later additions so that you know it was updated later on. 使用数字笔记工具，这样描述主题的笔记可能是一个要点列表，并且会不断增长，只能被编辑、重新排列、修改或删除。当我准备好真正开始写这个部分时，我将不再及时看到那个笔记的原始内部上下文和内部生命。这并不理想。您想要查看原始跟踪记录和创建笔记时您的思维所处原始状态的快照。当然，我可以稍后更新卡片并添加更多链接；但是，为了保持这种时间联系，我建议更改墨水颜色以供以后添加，以便您知道它是稍后更新的。

This may seem like we’re getting into the weeds here; however, it’s something you’ll come to realize and recognize the benefits of when you work with your Antinet in practice. 这看起来像是我们在这里陷入困境；但是，当您在实践中使用 Antinet 时，您会逐渐意识到并认识到它的好处。

For now, that’s enough on internal context. To truly understand how the Antinet locks in internal context better than digital systems, you’ll need to try it out for yourself. 现在，这就足够了内部上下文。要真正了解 Antinet 如何比数字系统更好地锁定内部上下文，您需要亲自尝试一下。

**The Physical Nature of the Antinet Engenders Memory Processes Not Found in Digital SystemsAntinet 的物理性质产生了数字系统中没有的记忆过程**
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The eponymous album by the band Fleet Foxes includes a letter written by lead singer Robin Pecknold that serves as an illustration of the experience of using an Antinet. Pecknold writes:Fleet Foxes 乐队的同名专辑包括主唱 Robin Pecknold 写的一封信，作为使用 Antinet 体验的例证。佩克诺德写道：

My first memory has always been of me and my mom on a cold grey day down at some beach in Washington, along the Puget Sound somewhere near Seattle. I would be around two or three years old and we’re with a friend of mine from the neighborhood and his mom, walking around among the driftwood looking for crabs. Even now, I can remember the smell and temperature of the air, the feeling of the sand and the swaying tall grass. I can even remember looking over at my friend and how his face looked when he smiled back at me. Another memory that I’ll sometimes recall as my first memory is dressing up in the dead of winter as Jack London, with tennis rackets on my feet and wearing my dad’s hiking pack, in the middle of summer after seeing Disney’s (terrible) version of White Fang. Or there’s the memory of stealing my neighbor’s big wheel and riding it halfway down the block before getting caught and having to turn around defeated, or of wearing a fireman’s outfit while washing my parent’s car, or eating an orange popsicle from the ice cream truck. 我的第一个记忆一直是我和我妈妈在一个寒冷的灰色日子里，在华盛顿的某个海滩上，沿着西雅图附近的普吉特海湾。我大约两三岁，我们和我附近的一个朋友以及他的妈妈一起在漂流木中走来走去寻找螃蟹。即使是现在，我还记得空气的气味和温度，沙子的感觉和摇曳的高草。我什至记得看着我的朋友，以及他对我微笑时的表情。另一个我有时会想起的记忆是我的第一个记忆是在严冬里打扮成杰克伦敦，脚上拿着网球拍，穿着我爸爸的徒步旅行包，在仲夏看到迪斯尼的（可怕的）版本后白牙。或者是我偷了我邻居的大轮子，骑着它跑了半个街区，然后被抓住，不得不转身失败，或者穿着消防员的衣服洗我父母的车，或者吃冰淇淋卡车上的橙色冰棒。

These are and have always been some of my most distinct and persistent memories of childhood, so it came as a disappointment to me when one day as a teenager, I opened up a photo album and found pictures of each and every one of those memories. I didn’t have a single memory that didn’t belong to or somehow grow from pictures my parents had taken of me when I was growing up. Even the scenes I remember so clearly in my head are from the same angles as those photographs, and I don’t really know what to make of it. I’m going to guess that I’d seen all these photographs at some point, forgotten they were just photographs, and over time made them into my most tangible memories. That’s scary to me in a way. 这些一直是我童年最独特、最持久的记忆，所以当我十几岁的时候，有一天我打开相册，找到了每一个记忆的照片，这让我很失望。我没有一个记忆不属于我父母在我成长过程中为我拍摄的照片，或者以某种方式从中成长。即使是我脑海中记得如此清楚的场景，也与那些照片的角度相同，我真的不知道该怎么做。我猜想我在某个时候看过所有这些照片，忘记了它们只是照片，并且随着时间的推移让它们成为我最真实的记忆。在某种程度上，这对我来说很可怕。

This leads me to something weird about the power that music has, it’s transportive ability. Any time I hear a song or record that meant a lot to me at a certain moment or I was listening to at a distinct time, I’m instantly taken back to that place in full detail. 这让我对音乐所具有的力量感到奇怪，它是一种传递能力。每当我在某个时刻听到对我来说意义重大的歌曲或唱片，或者我在不同的时间听过，我都会立即回到那个地方的全部细节。

The phenomenon of feeling like you are “instantly taken back to that place in full detail” is something that doesn’t just occur with music: it happens in the Antinet. 感觉就像你 “立即回到那个地方的全部细节” 的现象不仅发生在音乐中：它发生在 Antinet 中。

After I had spent four years developing “critical thinking” skills in college, I determined two things: first, it’d be wise for me to record the very best concepts I learned during my undergraduate studies (so that I could have them for life). And, second, for some reason I determined the best mechanism for storing the best concepts would be 3 x 5 inch lime green notecards. Yes, lime green notecards. 在我花了四年时间在大学里培养 “批判性思维” 技能之后，我决定做两件事：首先，我最好记录下我在本科学习期间学到的最好的概念（这样我就可以终生拥有它们). 其次，出于某种原因，我确定存储最佳概念的最佳机制是 3 x 5 英寸的青柠色记事卡。是的，青柠色记事卡。

Although the bright colors of these lime green notecards render my thoughts barely legible today, when I happen upon such cards, they’re amazingly valuable. 虽然这些石灰绿色记事卡的鲜艳色彩让我今天的想法几乎无法辨认，但当我偶然看到这些卡片时，它们的价值惊人。

You see, the lime green notecards contain not only ideas written on them, but they transport me back in time. For myself, I’m transported back inside the room I lived in at the time. The Antinet, with its reliance on notecards, serves as a powerful mechanism for capturing and reminding one of certain internal contextual experiences. This derives from the different colors of notecards you choose to use. It also derives from the different diagrams, drawings and even the style of your handwriting at that point in time. This is very powerful when it comes time to writing and creating. This experience leads to potentially insightful breakthroughs that may not otherwise come about from digital notetaking systems (which possess weaker faculties for inducing internal contextual memories). 你看，柠檬绿记事卡不仅包含写在上面的想法，而且它们让我回到了过去。就我自己而言，我仿佛回到了当时住的房间。 Antinet 依赖于记事卡，是一种强大的机制，用于捕捉和提醒某些内部上下文体验。这源于您选择使用的不同颜色的记事卡。它还源自不同的图表、绘图，甚至您当时的笔迹风格。这在写作和创作时非常强大。这种经验导致潜在的有见地的突破，而这些突破可能不会来自数字笔记系统（它具有较弱的诱导内部上下文记忆的能力）。

**External Context in the AntinetAntinet 中的外部上下文**

Color is an important attribute of human memory. We can observe this from our own personal experiences (for me, the lime green notecards taking me back in time). We can find such illustrations of this fact in novels.[859](#footnote-833) Or, we can refer to the field of human memory studies, which lumps this into a category called external context.[860](#footnote-832) 颜色是人类记忆的重要属性。我们可以从我们自己的个人经历中观察到这一点（对我来说，青柠色记事卡让我回到了过去）。我们可以在小说中找到这种事实的例证。 859 或者，我们可以参考人类记忆研究领域，将其归为一类，称为外部背景。 860

External context refers to the physical environment and physical traits involved in learning something. This includes location, environment, and personal perspective. Your perspective derives from your position in the setting in the memory. External context also includes other parts of your sensory system—sounds, smells, tastes, textures, and other sensations.[861](#footnote-831) 外部环境是指学习某事所涉及的物理环境和物理特征。这包括位置、环境和个人观点。你的观点来自于你在记忆中的位置。外部环境还包括您感觉系统的其他部分——声音、气味、味道、质地和其他感觉。 861

External context is an important functional memory input, as recent science reveals: what one learns in one environment is better recalled later on in that or a similar environment.[862](#footnote-830) 外部环境是一种重要的功能性记忆输入，正如最近的科学揭示的那样：一个人在一种环境中学到的东西在那个或类似的环境中会更好地回忆起来。 862

In the digital-focused age of today, far too many people overlook the concept of external context, even though this component is critical for building memory and the mind. 在当今这个以数字为中心的时代，太多人忽视了外部环境的概念，尽管这个组成部分对于建立记忆和思维至关重要。

**Positional Coding in the AntinetAntinet 中的位置编码**

Related to the notion that backs up my use of lime green notecards is the usefulness of notes built using other odd formats. As I’ve previously mentioned, in my Antinet I have a notecard about love written on an actual leaf that my fiancé picked out for me. Whenever I come across this note, it cues the unique external context that generated or embeds the note. 与支持我使用柠檬绿记事卡的概念相关的是使用其他奇怪格式构建的笔记的实用性。正如我之前提到的，在我的 Antinet 中，我有一张关于爱情的记事卡，写在我未婚夫为我挑选的真实叶子上。每当我遇到这个笔记时，它都会提示生成或嵌入笔记的独特外部环境。

A note such as this inhabits physical space in the Antinet, and also in one’s mind. The physical location of items that prompt memory is explained in human memory studies by the notion of positional coding. In this case, I know that the position of the leaf notecard is in the middle of the drawer of the 2000 branch of my Antinet. Whenever I wish to navigate to the subject of love, I simply navigate to that area without having to look up the keyterm love in my index. Whenever I’m reading a book, and the concept of love appears, I make a quick observation note of it on my bibcard, and then quickly install the idea near the leaf notecard in my Antinet. 像这样的音符存在于 Antinet 的物理空间中，也存在于一个人的脑海中。提示记忆的项目的物理位置在人类记忆研究中通过位置编码的概念来解释。在这种情况下，我知道叶子记事卡的位置在我的 Antinet 2000 分支的抽屉中间。每当我想导航到爱的主题时，我只需导航到那个区域，而不必在索引中查找关键词 love。每当我读一本书，爱的概念出现时，我都会在我的 bibcard 上快速观察笔记，然后迅速将这个想法安装在我的 Antinet 中的叶子记事卡附近。

With the Antinet, positional coding blends with spatial memory to create spatial encoding. That is, you know where to look for certain pieces of knowledge based on its spatial position. 在 Antinet 中，位置编码与空间记忆相结合以创建空间编码。也就是说，您知道根据其空间位置到哪里寻找某些知识片段。

Spatial memory is sometimes mentioned in self-help books and programs that promise to teach one how to develop a super memory.[863](#footnote-829) The basic premise of spatial coding involves assigning particular words (or concepts) to particular objects in the room you’re currently in. That is, readers are instructed to imagine “the items arrayed before them on a table or perhaps imagining themselves learning each item at a different sequential location along a familiar route.”[864](#footnote-828) 空间记忆有时会在自助书籍和程序中提到，这些书籍和程序承诺教一个人如何开发超级记忆。 863 空间编码的基本前提涉及将特定单词（或概念）分配给您当前所在房间中的特定对象. 也就是说，读者被指示想象 “在他们面前排列在桌子上的项目，或者想象自己沿着熟悉的路线在不同的顺序位置学习每个项目。”864

The earliest reference to this practice was in 88 BC and is referred to as the method of loci. People who used this practice include Aristotle, Cicero, and Quintilian. Cicero referred to it as artificio memoria.[865](#footnote-827) These thinkers assigned to the thoughts that backed their arguments items situated in rooms and gardens in order to facilitate their recall.[866](#footnote-826) 最早提到这种做法是在公元前 88 年，被称为基因座法。使用这种做法的人包括亚里士多德、西塞罗和昆体良。西塞罗将其称为 artificio memoria。 865 这些思想家将支持他们论点的思想分配到房间和花园中，以方便他们回忆。 866

The spatial memory of the method of loci operates differently than the spatial memory of the Antinet. With the Antinet, one isn’t so fixated on assigning thoughts to objects (such as assigning the thought about consciousness to a plant in the room). That said, properties of spatial memory do indeed surface when using an Antinet (like me knowing generally where to find the leaf notecard for love). 基因座方法的空间记忆与 Antinet 的空间记忆运作方式不同。使用 Antinet，人们不会那么专注于将思想分配给对象（例如将关于意识的思想分配给房间里的植物）。也就是说，空间记忆的特性在使用 Antinet 时确实会浮出水面（就像我一般知道在哪里可以找到爱的叶子记事卡）。

The reason for this occurring can be traced to “Neurons in the hippocampus [which] have been shown to be selective to one’s location in space.”[867](#footnote-825) 发生这种情况的原因可以追溯到 “海马体中的神经元 [已被证明对一个人在空间中的位置具有选择性。”867

The importance of external context and external memory, in which various objects in our physical environment is not foreign to scholars.[868](#footnote-824) This may be why many are hesitant to discard physically-dependent knowledge systems that have been actively evolved for over 2,500 years. These important features are not so easily replaced in the latest switch to using digital tools to manage our memory externally. 外部背景和外部记忆的重要性，其中我们物理环境中的各种对象对学者来说并不陌生。868 这可能就是为什么许多人不愿放弃已经积极发展了 2,500 多年的依赖于物理的知识系统的原因。在最近转向使用数字工具从外部管理我们的记忆时，这些重要功能并没有那么容易被取代。

**The Explicit Nature of Luh**mann’s Zettelkasten 卢曼的 Zettelkasten 的明确性质
------------------------------------------------------------------------

It’s important for you to understand these components of the Antinet to gain a sense for why each individual principle of the Antinet is important. The Antinet was not designed with little thought or care. It very much mirrors how human brain and memory work. Furthermore, the importance of context in the Antinet and how thoughts are developed within contexts (branches) is another component that should not be overlooked. 了解 Antinet 的这些组成部分对于了解 Antinet 的每个单独原则为何重要对您来说很重要。 Antinet 的设计并没有经过深思熟虑。它非常反映了人脑和记忆的工作方式。此外，上下文在 Antinet 中的重要性以及思想如何在上下文（分支）中发展是另一个不容忽视的组成部分。

With the conclusion of this chapter you now have more than enough theoretical understanding of the Antinet’s nature to complement your own empirical experiments. As usually, the only right answer is to test the system for yourself, and experience the Antinet’s glory (for yourself)! 随着本章的结束，你现在对 Antinet 的性质有了足够的理论理解，可以补充你自己的经验实验。和往常一样，唯一正确的答案就是亲身体验系统，体验安网的辉煌（为自己）！

CHAPTER TWENTY 第二十章
-------------------

Evolution, Perception, Perspective And Ruminants 进化、知觉、透视和反刍动物
--------------------------------------------------------------

In this chapter we’ll be discussing the concept of long-term evolution in the Antinet. We’ll also be diving into the concepts of perception vs. perspective, and how the Antinet locks these elements into each notecard. We’ll cap this chapter off with the concept of the Antinet as a ruminant. 在本章中，我们将讨论 Antinet 中长期演化的概念。我们还将深入探讨感知与透视的概念，以及 Antinet 如何将这些元素锁定到每个记事卡中。我们将以 Antinet 作为反刍动物的概念来结束本章。

**Evolution 进化**
----------------

In his paper Communication with Noteboxes, Niklas Luhmann talks about the “inner life” of the Antinet. He touches upon its “mental history,” which evolves through time.[869](#footnote-881) The inner life and mental history of the Antinet are brought forth by its unique structure. Specifically, it’s brought forth by the numeric-alpha addresses. Luhmann refers to the fixed positioning of order (Stellordnung), which is created through unique card addresses. This property enables the Antinet to evolve over time in such a way that it’s possible to view the mental history of your thoughts; with the numeric-alpha addresses and the tree structure, you can observe your mind’s evolution.Niklas Luhmann 在他的论文 Communication with Noteboxes 中谈到了 Antinet 的 “内部生活”。他谈到了它随时间演变的 “心理历史”。869 Antinet 的内在生活和心理历史是由其独特的结构带来的。具体来说，它是由数字字母地址产生的。 Luhmann 指的是订单的固定定位（Stellordnung），它是通过唯一的卡地址创建的。此属性使 Antinet 能够随着时间的推移而发展，从而可以查看您思想的心理历史；使用数字字母地址和树结构，您可以观察到您的思想演变。

Viewing the evolutionary history of your thoughts proves useful for certain types of activities. Take, for instance, the activity of reading scientific literature. According to Luhmann, the key to reading scientific texts centers on long-term memory. According to Luhmann, long-term memory is more crucial than short-term memory for reading scientific texts because it is necessary to distinguish the “essential from the non-essential and the new from the merely repetitive.”[870](#footnote-880) In other words, you want a system where you can refresh your memory of your notes and evolve your current ideas with new ideas. You don’t want to waste time relearning what you already know. 查看您思想的进化历史证明对某些类型的活动很有用。以阅读科学文献的活动为例。根据卢曼的说法，阅读科学文本的关键在于长期记忆。根据 Luhmann 的说法，对于阅读科学文本而言，长期记忆比短期记忆更为重要，因为有必要区分 “本质与非本质，新事物与仅仅重复的事物”。870 换句话说，你想要一个系统，您可以在其中刷新您对笔记的记忆并用新想法发展您当前的想法。你不想浪费时间重新学习你已经知道的东西。

The Antinet’s workflow involves noting down observations on a bibcard. Then, before actually developing a main note, you review the Antinet. You figure out where a card will be placed before dedicating the time to reformulate or reflect on the material. This is an important step as it prevents you from spending too much time on writing about the non-essential or repetitive material that you already know.Antinet 的工作流程涉及在 bibcard 上记录观察结果。然后，在实际开发主要注释之前，您会查看 Antinet。在花时间重新制定或反思材料之前，您先弄清楚卡片的放置位置。这是一个重要的步骤，因为它可以防止您花费太多时间来编写您已经知道的非必要或重复的材料。

When you review this material you’re not only reducing the risk of getting bogged down on things you already know; there’s another useful feature. As Markus Krajewski observes, “The reader is not only reading his own memory, but rather also his shifting frame of reference over time.”[871](#footnote-879) In other words, when you review your Antinet, you’re seeing your shifting frame of references over time. You’re seeing your different perspectives and your different interpretations of ideas based on communication with different sources you’ve engaged with. It’s possible to view how your thoughts have developed, changed, and internally evolved over time. 当您复习这些材料时，您不仅可以降低陷入已知事物困境的风险；还有另一个有用的功能。正如 Markus Krajewski 所观察到的，“读者不仅在阅读他自己的记忆，而且还在阅读他随时间变化的参照系。”871 换句话说，当你回顾你的 Antinet 时，你会看到你随时间变化的参照系. 基于与不同来源的交流，你会看到不同的观点和对想法的不同解释。可以查看您的想法是如何随着时间的推移而发展、变化和内部演变的。

Oftentimes, the most surprising finds are the links you stamp onto the cards. These shed light into what the idea reminded you of at the time and shed light on your own internal reverberation of ideas at a given time. The cards that these links point to serve as the source material of your own internal perspectives and context. When viewing Luhmann’s system, this is something Krajewski confirmed as well: “What is more surprising are the references listed.”[872](#footnote-878) 通常，最令人惊讶的发现是您印在卡片上的链接。这些阐明了这个想法当时让您想起了什么，并阐明了您在特定时间内部对想法的反响。这些链接指向的卡片用作您自己的内部观点和背景的源材料。在查看 Luhmann 的系统时，Krajewski 也证实了这一点：“更令人惊讶的是列出的参考文献。”872

This relates to something in human memory called temporal context.[873](#footnote-877) Memories and thoughts that occur around the same time are essentially linked together.[874](#footnote-876) Temporal context can be thought of as a function of time, external context, and internal context. In essence, your thoughts are a function of the period of time in which you had them. They’re shaped by your own internal dialogue at that specific time, as well as the external context in which you have the thought. As a result, you link together a unique set of other ideas at the time of creation. These unique associations of other ideas are represented in the form of cardlinks in your Antinet. 这与人类记忆中称为时间背景的东西有关。873 大约同时发生的记忆和思想本质上是联系在一起的。874 时间背景可以被认为是时间、外部背景和内部背景的函数。从本质上讲，您的想法是您拥有它们的时间段的函数。它们是由您在特定时间的内部对话以及您产生想法的外部环境所塑造的。结果，您在创作时将一组独特的其他想法联系在一起。这些与其他想法的独特关联在您的 Antinet 中以卡片链接的形式表示。

These cardlinks are way more valuable and effective than things like wikilinks in digital systems. The reason is that notecards in the Antinet are updated and changed less frequently than in digital systems. Notes in digital systems are constantly being updated, rearranged, deleted, and added onto. Within the Antinet, notecards are locked in time once they’re created. This then locks in a view of the temporal context of your ideas over time. 这些卡片链接比数字系统中的维基链接更有价值、更有效。原因是 Antinet 中的记事卡更新和更改的频率低于数字系统。数字系统中的笔记不断更新、重新排列、删除和添加。在 Antinet 中，记事卡一旦创建就会及时锁定。然后，随着时间的推移，这会锁定您的想法的时间背景视图。

**Compounding of Ideas 想法的复合**

Albert Einstein considered compound interest to be the eighth wonder of the world. Warren Buffett has said his financial success is simply “a product of compound interest.”[875](#footnote-875) Simple things compound into complex things. Luhmann himself experienced this first hand with his Antinet. The little, simple, everyday commitment to building and evolving your Antinet results in genius-level thought. Over time your ideas evolve and snowball into things you never could have planned. This happens in an organic way, slowly, one notecard at a time. Thought-by-thought, branch-by-branch, stem-by-stem, link-by-link, your Antinet evolves into a complex entity, experiencing the magic of compound interest. Yet it’s not easy. You have to earn it. This is often seen as a negative aspect of the Antinet (writing things by hand is hard); yet it pays off in the end. 爱因斯坦认为复利是世界第八大奇迹。沃伦 · 巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 曾表示，他的财务成功只是 “复利的产物”。875 简单的事物会复合成复杂的事物。卢曼亲身体验了他的 Antinet。建立和发展 Antinet 的小而简单的日常承诺会产生天才级的思想。随着时间的推移，您的想法不断演变，并像滚雪球一样变成您从未计划过的事情。这是以一种有机的方式发生的，慢慢地，一次一张记事卡。逐个思考、逐个分支、逐个干、逐个链接，您的 Antinet 演变成一个复杂的实体，体验复利的魔力。但这并不容易。你必须赢得它。这通常被视为 Antinet 的消极方面（手写东西很难）；但它最终得到了回报。

Markus Krajewski observes, “Whoever sets about ongoing work (or communication) with such a secondary memory can not only count on the fact that the apparatus will faithfully reproduce everything which has been shared with it, they can also trust that, with the information successively provided over time, future knowledge will be enriched.”[876](#footnote-874) In essence, the individual notes you provide to the Antinet will be enriched over time. The individual pieces of information compound and collide with one another to form rich pathways of knowledge. When it comes time to write, your cognitive energy is freed up to collaborate with this entity. You’re left with a very rich, interconnected store of knowledge with which you can creatively reinterpret that knowledge and tie it into the paper or creative work you’re actively building.Markus Krajewski 观察到，“无论谁用这样的辅助记忆开始正在进行的工作（或交流），不仅可以指望该设备将忠实地再现与之共享的所有内容，他们还可以相信，随着信息的连续出现随着时间的推移提供，未来的知识将得到丰富。”876 本质上，您提供给 Antinet 的个人笔记将随着时间的推移而丰富。各个信息片段相互混合并相互碰撞，形成丰富的知识途径。到了写作的时候，你的认知能量就会被释放出来与这个实体合作。你留下了一个非常丰富、相互关联的知识库，你可以创造性地重新解释这些知识，并将其与你正在积极构建的论文或创造性作品联系起来。

The idea of notes becoming a rich store of value is certainly not a new one. John Aubrey (1626–1697), a fellow of the Royal Society, once said that habitual notetaking creates “‘nest eggs’ for the future.”[877](#footnote-873) 纸币成为一种丰富的保值手段的想法当然不是一个新想法。英国皇家学会会员约翰 · 奥布里 (1626-1697) 曾经说过，习惯性记笔记会 “为未来创造‘储备金’。”877

The bottom line is this: The entity you’re creating with the Antinet is a complex one. It’s a product of compounding the interest of your ideas. The result is something magical: it morphs into an entity that you (and only you) can truly understand. 底线是：你用 Antinet 创建的实体是一个复杂的实体。它是将您的想法的兴趣结合起来的产物。结果是神奇的：它变成了一个你（而且只有你）可以真正理解的实体。

**Perception and Perspective 感知和视角**
------------------------------------

Perception and perspective derive from similar etymological roots. These terms are often confused with one another, even though they’re different.Perception 和 Perspective 源自相似的词源。尽管这些术语不同，但它们经常相互混淆。

Perception comes from the Latin term percipere. Let’s break this apart. Per means “fully.” Cipere means “to grasp” or “to take.” Combined, percipere means to fully grasp, understand or interpret the meaning of something. 感知来自拉丁语 percipere。让我们把它分开。 Per 的意思是 “完全”。 Cipere 的意思是“掌握” 或“采取”。结合起来，percipere 意味着完全掌握、理解或解释某事的含义。

Perspective comes from the Latin term perspecere. Per means the same thing as it does in percipere (“fully”). Specere means “to observe” or “to spectate.” Combined, perspecere means to fully observe and to see and spectate. 透视来自拉丁语 perspecere。 Per 的意思与它在 percipere（“完全”）中的意思相同。 Speere 的意思是 “观察” 或“观察”。结合起来，perspecere 意味着充分观察和观察。

Think of perception as applying your own interpretation of some observations. Perception uses interpretation to help us derive meaning out of an observation. The meaning you assign to an observation shapes your thoughts, which shape your reality. 将感知视为应用您自己对某些观察结果的解释。感知使用解释来帮助我们从观察中获得意义。你赋予观察的意义塑造了你的思想，思想塑造了你的现实。

Think of perspective as your point of view. Perspective is your vantage point. It’s a function of space and time. Where you are in the world, and at what time you observe an event shapes your perspective. 将视角视为您的观点。视角是你的有利位置。它是空间和时间的函数。你在世界上的哪个位置，以及你在什么时间观察到一个事件会影响你的观点。

When you use an Antinet your notes contain both your perspective and your perceptions of ideas. When you create reformulation notes, you’re summarizing ideas based on your perspective at the time. You’re shaping your ideas by your current point of view. When you create reflection notes, you’re adding your own interpretations of the ideas you encounter. You’re stamping your own perceptions of ideas onto your notes. These are locked in time. They are not updated, overwritten or edited (like they often are in digital tools). 当您使用 Antinet 时，您的笔记包含您的观点和您对想法的看法。当你创建重新制定的笔记时，你是在根据你当时的观点总结想法。您正在根据当前的观点塑造您的想法。当您创建反思笔记时，您是在添加自己对遇到的想法的解释。您正在将自己对想法的看法印在笔记上。这些都是及时锁定的。它们不会被更新、覆盖或编辑（就像它们通常在数字工具中一样）。

It’s very important that both your perspectives and perceptions be locked in time. This provides the raw material for the communication experience that makes the Antinet so valuable. When you go back and review old notes, you’re having a communication experience. You’re viewing ideas containing your second mind’s perspectives and perceptions. You’re then comparing these with your own present-day perspectives and perceptions. This creates the valuable internal dialogue we’ve touched upon throughout this book. You begin seeing your perspectives and perceptions evolve over time. This proves to be an invaluable interaction during the creation process. 及时锁定您的观点和看法非常重要。这为 Antinet 如此有价值的通信体验提供了原材料。当您返回并查看旧笔记时，您将拥有一种交流体验。您正在查看包含您的第二思维的观点和看法的想法。然后你将这些与你自己现在的观点和看法进行比较。这创造了我们在整本书中提到的有价值的内部对话。你开始看到你的观点和看法随着时间的推移而演变。这被证明是创作过程中非常宝贵的互动。

**Ruminants 反刍动物**
------------------

Ruminants are a type of mammal that acquire nutrients from eating grass. They first ferment the grass in a specialized stomach called a rumen. After the grass is fermented in the rumen, it is then digested. 反刍动物是一种通过吃草获取营养的哺乳动物。他们首先在称为瘤胃的特殊胃中发酵草。草在瘤胃中发酵后，然后被消化。

The word ruminant comes from the Latin term ruminare, which means “to chew slowly.” This is where the term rumination derives from. 反刍动物一词来自拉丁语 ruminare，意思是 “慢慢咀嚼”。这就是反刍一词的来源。

Here’s why I’m even talking about this: in Luhmann’s own Zettelkasten, he describes his system by calling it a ruminant. 这就是为什么我什至要谈论这个：在卢曼自己的 Zettelkasten 中，他通过称其为反刍动物来描述他的系统。

“The Zettelkasten is like the complicated digestive system of a ruminant. All arbitrary ideas, all coincidences of reading, can be included. It is then the internal connectivity that decides.”“Zettelkasten 就像反刍动物复杂的消化系统。所有随意的想法，所有阅读的巧合，都可以包括在内。然后由内部连接决定。”

–Niklas Luhmann, Zettelkasten II: 9/8i[878](#footnote-872)–Niklas Luhmann，Zettelkasten II：9/8i878

By calling it a ruminant, Luhmann is referring to the idea that some pieces of knowledge need time to be digested. The technique of using external references (ExRefs) helps with this. Sometimes you come across interesting material; however you don’t yet know whether the idea is worth fully processing yet. In this case you create ExRefs for the material and thus enable the material to ruminate in the Antinet. If the time comes wherein the material will become useful, you can then digest the material by converting it into a main note. Or, you can digest the material by using it while writing your manuscript. 卢曼称它为反刍动物，指的是一些知识需要时间来消化。使用外部引用 (ExRefs) 的技术对此有所帮助。有时您会遇到有趣的材料；但是您还不知道这个想法是否值得完全处理。在这种情况下，您为材料创建 ExRef，从而使材料能够在 Antinet 中进行反思。如果到了该材料变得有用的时候，您可以通过将其转换为主要注释来消化该材料。或者，您可以在撰写手稿时使用它来消化材料。

The idea of the mind as a ruminant is not a new concept. The French Catholic philosopher Antonin Sertillanges writes: 头脑是反刍动物的想法并不是一个新概念。法国天主教哲学家 Antonin Sertillanges 写道：

Man’s mind is a ruminant. The cow looks away into the distance, chews slowly, bites off here a tuft and there a twig, takes the whole field for her own, and the horizon as well, producing her milk from the field, feeding her dim soul on the horizon.[879](#footnote-871) 人的思想是一只反刍动物。母牛遥望远方，细嚼慢咽，这里咬下一丛，那里咬下一根小树枝，把整片田野都占为己有，把地平线也占为己有，从田野里挤出奶汁，喂养着地平线上朦胧的灵魂。 879

What this involves is reverberation as understood in the study of human memory. I talk about the concept of reverberation throughout this text. The idea involves “just-experienced” ideas and associations reverberating in one’s mind.[880](#footnote-870) Reverberation is most often associated with short-term memory. However, with the Antinet, you can lock in reverberation over a longer period of time. Reverberation over the long term reflects the concept of rumination. 这涉及到人类记忆研究中所理解的混响。我在整篇文章中都谈到了混响的概念。这个想法涉及在一个人的脑海中回荡的 “刚刚经历过的” 想法和联想。880 回响通常与短期记忆有关。但是，使用 Antinet，您可以在更长的时间内锁定混响。长期的混响反映了反刍的概念。

The idea of rumination doesn’t just have important implications in the Antinet. Rather the way you approach books involves rumination as well.

As Francis Bacon once pointed out, “Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.”[881](#footnote-869) Some books are to be read only in parts; others should be skimmed, some few should be read wholly, and others should be read with deliberate attention. Mortimer Adler asserted: “Reading a book analytically is chewing and digesting it.”[882](#footnote-868) 正如弗朗西斯 · 培根 (Francis Bacon) 曾经指出的那样，“有些书要细细品味，有些要吞咽，还有少数要咀嚼和消化。”881 有些书只能部分阅读；有些书只能部分阅读。其他的应该略读，一些应该完整阅读，其他的应该仔细阅读。 Mortimer Adler 断言：“分析地阅读一本书就是咀嚼和消化它。”882

Yet without the Antinet, the knowledge one gains during analytical reading is lost. The Antinet captures the insights from deep analytical reading and stores them for the long term. In the Antinet these deep insights collide with other ideas and compound. 然而，如果没有 Antinet，在分析阅读中获得的知识就会丢失。 Antinet 从深度分析阅读中捕捉洞察力，并长期存储它们。在 Antinet 中，这些深刻的见解与其他想法发生碰撞和复合。

The point in all of this is reflected in the following suggestion: view the Antinet as a ruminant of your mind. Store all of your material there that you wish to evolve. Store both your fully developed thoughts, as well as thoughts that need more time to sprout. 所有这一切的要点都反映在以下建议中：将 Antinet 视为您头脑中的反刍动物。将您希望发展的所有材料存储在那里。存储您充分发展的想法，以及需要更多时间发芽的想法。

CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE 第二十一章
------------------------

Randomness, Surprises And Accidents 随机性、意外和意外
---------------------------------------------

As we’ve learned, one of the more overlooked benefits of the Antinet is its ability to foster randomness, thanks to its tree structure. This structure generates invaluable surprises and accidents, allowing users to encounter ideas they would otherwise not have reviewed had they been using digital systems. When you work with an analog system, you’re exploring and sifting through your previous thoughts. This ignites a reverberation of ideas that circulate in your mind, causing a crucial “collision” of ideas in your mind during the writing process. 正如我们所了解的，Antinet 最容易被忽视的好处之一是它具有促进随机性的能力，这要归功于它的树结构。这种结构会产生无价的惊喜和意外，使用户能够遇到他们在使用数字系统时不会审阅的想法。当您使用模拟系统时，您正在探索和筛选您以前的想法。这点燃了思想的回响，在你的脑海中循环，在写作过程中引起思想在你脑海中的关键 “碰撞”。

**Randomness 随机性**
------------------

Here, randomness is a feature, not a bug. A key property of a living, evolving, anti-fragile system is its unorthodox structure. The perfectly normalized structures we find in digital notetaking systems are synthetic. They’re fragile. They’re overly malleable and they rarely retain a unique character. As one scholar points out, “Evolution always occurs through the selection of accidental differences without a design.”[883](#footnote-908) 在这里，随机性是一个特性，而不是一个错误。一个活的、不断发展的、反脆弱的系统的一个关键特性是它的非正统结构。我们在数字笔记系统中发现的完美标准化结构是合成的。它们很脆弱。他们的可塑性太强，很少能保持独特的性格。正如一位学者所指出的，“进化总是通过选择偶然的差异而发生的，而不是经过设计的。”883

It doesn’t seem intuitive, but here’s the reality: randomness doesn’t come from chaos alone. Randomness actually relies on order. As Luhmann states, “even the creation of random suggestions requires organization.”[884](#footnote-907) 这似乎不符合直觉，但事实是：随机性不仅仅来自混乱。随机性实际上依赖于顺序。正如卢曼所说，“即使是随机建议的产生也需要组织。”884

When I first began using notecards to store my thoughts in 2006, I would simply take notes about a book on 3 x 5 inch cards. Each card contained one idea. These notes were primarily reformulation notes. They summarized individual concepts I learned while reading the book. By the time I finished reading the book, I would have about twenty or thirty new 3 x 5 inch cards. I would then wrap a rubber band around them and throw them in a shoebox. From time to time I would then review the notecards. 当我在 2006 年第一次开始使用记事卡来存储我的想法时，我只是在 3 x 5 英寸的卡片上记下关于一本书的笔记。每张卡片包含一个想法。这些注释主要是重新制定的注释。他们总结了我在阅读本书时学到的各个概念。当我读完这本书时，我将有大约二十或三十张新的 3 x 5 英寸卡片。然后我会用橡皮筋把它们包起来，然后把它们扔进鞋盒里。我会时不时地回顾笔记卡。

However, this isn’t the most ordered structure. It’s seemingly random. The Antinet, on the other hand, introduces an ordered structure (numeric-alpha addresses and the tree-like branching architecture). As a paradoxical result, the structure induces more useful random features. 然而，这不是最有序的结构。看似随意。另一方面，Antinet 引入了有序结构（数字字母地址和树状分支架构）。作为一个自相矛盾的结果，该结构引发了更有用的随机特征。

**Surprises 惊喜**
----------------

The tree structure of the Antinet encourages the asking of unique questions that are less commonly asked when one uses digital systems, since those systems are fully indexed with full text search. Upon encountering a new idea while using an Antinet, you ask yourself questions like What is the name of that concept. You’re then prompted to ask what other terms live near that concept if you can’t find its location. It requires finding alternative ways to think about the concept and to essentially re-imprint the pathways that led you to the idea. This practice is a fun way to approach knowledge. Embarking upon an associative-thinking process brings about fascinating surprises along the way. Your current mind (with its own active memory) has a dialogue with your past self (your second mind), and this dialogue often results in amazing surprises. If nothing else, the core output of the Antinet is one thing: it’s a “surprise generator.”[885](#footnote-906)Antinet 的树结构鼓励提出使用数字系统时不常问到的独特问题，因为这些系统已通过全文搜索完全索引。在使用 Antinet 时遇到新想法时，您会问自己这样的问题：该概念的名称是什么。如果找不到它的位置，系统会提示您询问该概念附近还有哪些其他术语。它需要找到替代方法来思考这个概念，并从根本上重新印记引导你想到这个想法的途径。这种做法是一种获取知识的有趣方式。开始联想思维过程会带来令人着迷的惊喜。你现在的头脑（有它自己的活跃记忆）与你过去的自己（你的第二个头脑）进行对话，而这种对话通常会带来惊人的惊喜。如果不出意外，Antinet 的核心输出是一回事：它是一个 “惊喜发生器”。 885

As one scholar observes of Luhmann’s system: “a true communication process is triggered that exploits the machine’s ability to surprise, i.e., to produce information.”[886](#footnote-905) 正如一位学者对卢曼系统的观察：“一个真正的交流过程被触发，它利用机器的惊喜能力，即产生信息。”886

The same scholar observes how a true secondary memory arises when the questions one asks triggers a network of associative references and links. These links then give birth to “collaborative” reasoning that was not intentionally designed.[887](#footnote-904) The network of associative references refers both to the concept of forward associations and to remote associations. Here we see that the tree structure, with the continuous flow of cards as well as the remote cardlinks, helps create a collaborative communication relationship with the second mind. It also serves as the core component for creating surprises (realizations that are a result that had not been intentionally designed). 同一位学者观察到，当一个人提出的问题触发联想参考和链接网络时，真正的二级记忆是如何产生的。然后，这些链接产生了并非有意设计的 “协作” 推理。887 关联参考网络指的是前向关联和远程关联的概念。在这里，我们看到树状结构、卡片的连续流动以及远程卡片链接，有助于与第二思维建立协作沟通关系。它还是创造惊喜（非故意设计的结果）的核心组成部分。

Again, the network structure of the Antinet is similar to associationism.[888](#footnote-903) The association of nodes in the network is based on contiguity. The continuous flow of notes (containing thoughts) is augmented by insertions of similar material later on. Thoughts grow contiguously from previous branches and are grouped together with similar thoughts over time. These two components (contiguity and similarity) are the very components which govern thought in general, and that is used to the Antinet’s advantage. 同样，Antinet 的网络结构类似于关联主义。888 网络中节点的关联基于连续性。笔记（包含想法）的连续流动通过稍后插入类似材料而得到增强。思想从以前的分支连续增长，并随着时间的推移与相似的思想组合在一起。这两个组成部分（连续性和相似性）正是支配一般思想的组成部分，而这正是 Antinet 的优势所在。

**The Nature of Surprises 惊喜的本质**

Isaac Asimov once observed that great ideas and breakthroughs begin not with Eureka! but with Hmm, that’s funny.[889](#footnote-902) While using the Antinet, you’ll come across many instances where you think to yourself Hmm, that’s funny! Take note of these instances and create links between them. 艾萨克 · 阿西莫夫 (Isaac Asimov) 曾经观察到，伟大的想法和突破并非始于 Eureka！但对于 Hmm，这很有趣。889 在使用 Antinet 时，您会遇到很多情况，您会认为自己 Hmm，这很有趣！记下这些实例并在它们之间创建链接。

Keep in mind, though, that in the spirit of good science, you should not let your guard down. When you say to yourself, that’s funny, that doesn’t mean the idea is true. It could merely mean that the idea is interesting. Ideas have a tendency to survive not necessarily because they’re true, but because they’re interesting.[890](#footnote-901) In the name of good science, you ought to search for surprises that excavate truth. Your goal should not center on excavating stuff that’s merely interesting—that’s pop science gibberish. 但请记住，本着良好科学的精神，您不应该放松警惕。当你对自己说，这很有趣，并不意味着这个想法是正确的。这可能仅仅意味着这个想法很有趣。想法之所以能够流传下来，不一定是因为它们是真实的，而是因为它们很有趣。890 以优秀科学的名义，你应该寻找能够挖掘真相的惊喜。你的目标不应该集中在挖掘仅仅有趣的东西上——那是流行科学的胡言乱语。

In some ways, the Antinet helps mitigate against getting carried away by interesting but unfounded insights. It does this by collecting contradictions. Surrounding the leaves and stems of cards that generate surprises it’s likely that one will find thoughts that contradict the surprise. This is only possible thanks to the principle of not erasing anything in your Antinet. The fact that contradictory ideas remain for you to find helps you filter out ideas which are merely interesting in order to find insights that are both interesting and true. 在某些方面，Antinet 有助于避免被有趣但毫无根据的见解冲昏头脑。它通过收集矛盾来做到这一点。围绕着产生惊喜的卡片的叶子和茎，人们很可能会发现与惊喜相矛盾的想法。这要归功于不删除 Antinet 中任何内容的原则。矛盾的想法仍然需要你去寻找，这一事实有助于你过滤掉仅仅是有趣的想法，以便找到既有趣又真实的见解。

In addition to this anti-self-deception mechanism, the fact that you’re neuroimprinting ideas enables you to call to mind the contradictory ideas by attending to the reverberation achieved through writing by hand and sifting through your notes. In brief, you’re less likely to deceive yourself when working with the Antinet. Why? Because you can think of examples that contradict insights you might otherwise be charmed by. 除了这种反自欺欺人的机制之外，你正在对想法进行神经印记这一事实使你能够通过注意通过手写和筛选笔记所产生的回响来记住相互矛盾的想法。简而言之，您在使用 Antinet 时不太可能欺骗自己。为什么？因为您可以想到与您可能会着迷的见解相矛盾的示例。

**The Antinet is Built for SurprisesAntinet 为惊喜而生**

Thanks to the Antinet’s structure, surprises are achieved by giving the Antinet “autonomy.”[891](#footnote-900) This autonomy is created by the commitment to never change card addresses. Unlike digital files with their dynamically updating links, the Antinet’s card addresses never change. Likewise, aside from editing marks or additions made directly on a card (that leave a trace of the change in thinking), any future changes made to the information on a card can only occur by adding related, child-like nodes underneath it. 由于 Antinet 的结构，通过赋予 Antinet“自主权”891 实现了惊喜。这种自主权是由永不更改卡地址的承诺创造的。与具有动态更新链接的数字文件不同，Antinet 的卡地址永远不会改变。同样，除了直接在卡片上编辑标记或添加（留下思维变化的痕迹）之外，未来对卡片信息所做的任何更改都只能通过在其下方添加相关的、类似子节点的节点来实现。

The commitment to never change card addresses is pretty easy and doesn’t require willpower (unlike the temptation to change card addresses in a digital system). Thanks to the analog nature of the Antinet, it’s just completely impractical to change the addresses of many cards! 永不更改卡地址的承诺非常容易，不需要意志力（不像在数字系统中更改卡地址的诱惑）。由于 Antinet 的模拟特性，更改许多卡的地址是完全不切实际的！

This is a good thing. If constant changing, deleting, or updating of the system were possible, it would rip out the unique personality of that system. Because of this, complementary and contradictory thoughts are gathered in an essentially “locked” system that then generates surprise com- binations. 这是一件好事。如果不断地改变、删除或更新系统是可能的，那么它就会撕掉该系统的独特个性。正因为如此，互补和矛盾的想法被聚集在一个本质上 “锁定” 的系统中，然后产生令人惊讶的组合。

**An Example of a Surprise 一个惊喜的例子**

Something interesting happened a few months into building out my Antinet. I was going through the process of installing my legacy notecards when I came upon a card pertaining to something called cluster analysis. In machine learning, cluster analysis involves using algorithms to classify data patterns into groups or clusters. The clusters are then analyzed to determine which features and properties make the groups alike. 在构建我的 Antinet 几个月后发生了一些有趣的事情。当我遇到一张与称为聚类分析的东西有关的卡片时，我正在经历安装我的遗留记事卡的过程。在机器学习中，集群分析涉及使用算法将数据模式分类为组或集群。然后分析这些集群以确定哪些特征和属性使这些组相似。

When I went to create a keyterm for cluster analysis I was surprised by the fact that I already had a keyterm for the term cluster! What I found was that the keyterm linked to something in the cognitive biases branch of my Antinet (address 2431/18). When I traveled to that card, I found a concept outlining something called clustering illusion. Suddenly I recalled this concept that refers to a cognitive fallacy by which humans see patterns in data—even if the data is completely random. This tendency usually happens when the data is composed of a small random sample. 当我为聚类分析创建一个关键词时，令我惊讶的是我已经有了一个关键词聚类的关键词！我发现关键术语与我的 Antinet（地址 2431/18）的认知偏见分支中的某些内容相关联。当我浏览那张卡片时，我发现了一个概念，它概述了一种叫做聚类错觉的东西。突然间，我想起了这个概念，它指的是一种认知谬误，人类通过这种谬误来看待数据中的模式——即使数据是完全随机的。当数据由小的随机样本组成时，通常会发生这种趋势。

As a result of this, in my section for cluster analysis, I included a disclaimer for my future self: Before beginning any significant time investment in cluster analysis, be wary of falling into the trap of clustering illusion (See ‘2431/18’). In brief, I’ve created a link across two branches of knowledge that have very important implications for each other. 因此，在我的聚类分析部分中，我为未来的自己做了免责声明：在开始对聚类分析进行任何重大时间投资之前，请警惕落入聚类错觉的陷阱（参见 “2431/18”） . 简而言之，我已经建立了一个跨两个知识分支的链接，这两个分支对彼此都有非常重要的影响。

These types of surprises occur frequently in the Antinet because the keyterms and links are created deliberately. When you see a surprising occurrence (like the shared term cluster which points to concepts which may contradict each other), you pay closer attention to them. You appreciate the surprise more and you use the surprise by creating relevant links between the two ideas. 这些类型的意外在 Antinet 中经常发生，因为关键字和链接是故意创建的。当你看到一个令人惊讶的事件（比如指向可能相互矛盾的概念的共享术语集群）时，你会更加关注它们。你更欣赏惊喜，并通过在两个想法之间建立相关联系来利用惊喜。

If I were using a digital system, I believe it would have been less likely that I’d have realized the same relationship between the two ideas. If I had searched the term cluster, I’d likely have found myself bombarded with dozens, if not hundreds, of notes containing the term cluster. My state of mind would have been one of I want to find the file I’m looking for as quickly as possible, which is not an explorer mindset exhibiting curiosity and pattern-seeking). I would have quickly passed over the commonality of these two concepts because they would have been crowded out by too much information. 如果我使用的是数字系统，我相信我不太可能意识到这两个想法之间的相同关系。如果我搜索术语集群，我可能会发现自己被数十个（如果不是数百个）包含术语集群的注释轰炸。我的心态应该是我想尽快找到我正在寻找的文件，这不是一种表现出好奇心和模式寻求的探索者心态）。我会很快忽略这两个概念的共性，因为它们会被太多信息挤掉。

**Heterogenous Relations 异构关系**

Luhmann points out that the most fruitful types of surprises within the Antinet happen by way of relating “heterogeneous things with each other.” He holds that it’s more valuable to associate patterns between ideas that otherwise would not be associated with one another.[892](#footnote-899)Luhmann 指出，Antinet 中最富有成效的惊喜类型是通过将 “异类事物相互关联” 而发生的。他认为，将原本不会相互关联的想法之间的模式联系起来更有价值。 892

One interesting way to facilitate these heterogenous relations is to group ideas around certain polarizing keyterms. 促进这些异质关系的一种有趣方法是围绕某些两极分化的关键词对想法进行分组。

For instance, in my index I’ve created the keyterm Most, and some interesting concepts have grown around it. 例如，在我的索引中，我创建了关键字词 Most，并且围绕它产生了一些有趣的概念。

For example, there’s the idea stemming from life philosophy: Most Important Variable for Success in Life. This keyterm entry points me to card 2460/2/0, which contains an idea from the book How to Get Rich by Felix Dennis. The idea centers on the concept that self-belief is the most important variable for success in life and suggests that we lack self-belief because we do not yet have confidence. One way to develop this confidence is to retrain your mind through the use of self-affirmations, a (positive) form of self-deception. 例如，有一个源于生活哲学的想法：人生成功最重要的变量。这个关键字条目将我指向卡片 2460/2/0，其中包含菲利克斯 · 丹尼斯 (Felix Dennis) 的《如何致富》一书中的一个想法。这个想法以自信是人生成功最重要的变量这一概念为中心，并表明我们缺乏自信是因为我们还没有信心。培养这种信心的一种方法是通过使用自我肯定来重新训练你的思想，这是一种（积极的）自欺欺人的形式。

Now, when I navigate to another keyterm relating to Most, I find the following entry: Most Important Variable for Success in Science. Cardlink 2431/1/1 points out that avoiding self-deception is the key to success in science. Richard Feynman points out that, “The first principle is that you must not fool yourself, and you’re the easiest person to fool.” 现在，当我导航到另一个与 “大多数” 相关的关键词时，我发现了以下条目：科学成功的最重要变量。 Cardlink 2431/1/1 指出避免自欺欺人是科学成功的关键。理查德 · 费曼指出，“首要原则是你不能自欺欺人，而你是最容易被愚弄的人。”

It seems we have an interesting paradox here. The key to success in life is self-belief, which may involve self-deception. Yet the key to success in science is avoiding self-deception. This creates an opportunity to explore this conflict in greater detail to determine how one can cultivate healthy self-belief, without falling prey to the downsides of self-deception. 看来我们这里有一个有趣的悖论。人生成功的关键是自信，这可能涉及自欺欺人。然而，科学成功的关键是避免自欺欺人。这创造了一个更详细地探讨这一冲突的机会，以确定一个人如何培养健康的自信，而不至于陷入自欺欺人的负面影响。

This is just one example of how heterogenous relations can emerge around certain keyterms in an Antinet. 这只是一个例子，说明异质关系如何围绕 Antinet 中的某些关键术语出现。

**Heterogenous Relations by Way of Proximity 通过邻近性的异质关系**

Another example of heterogenous relations happens naturally thanks to the tree structure of the Antinet. 由于 Antinet 的树结构，异构关系的另一个例子自然而然地发生了。

As you’ve learned, associations are a fundamental building block of human memory. Yet, rather than liken associations to simply links between related items, associations have an additional function: they create new entities altogether. Some types of associations collide and create new ideas. In human memory studies this is called a holistic association.[893](#footnote-898) For example, take the following sequence of items: horse and house. When one thinks of those items together, they may think of a new entity altogether: a barn. Essentially the proximity of those two items creates a new holistic entity. 如您所知，联想是人类记忆的基本组成部分。然而，关联并没有将关联比作相关项目之间的简单链接，关联还有一个额外的功能：它们共同创建了新的实体。某些类型的协会会发生碰撞并产生新的想法。在人类记忆研究中，这被称为整体关联。893 例如，采用以下项目序列：马和房子。当人们一起想到这些物品时，他们可能会完全想到一个新实体：谷仓。本质上，这两个项目的接近度创建了一个新的整体实体。

Luhmann would regard these associations as fruitful instances of surprise and accident. They are the result of seemingly heterogenous ideas forming around a certain area that, when viewed together as a whole, create a new entity altogether. Ultimately, these heterogenous relations create a new form of understanding that otherwise would not have existed. 卢曼将这些联想视为意外和意外的富有成果的例子。它们是围绕某个区域形成的看似异质的想法的结果，当把它们作为一个整体来看时，就会完全创造一个新的实体。最终，这些异质关系创造了一种新的理解形式，否则就不会存在。

**Bisociation 分离**

Recall that Luhmann devised the Antinet because, in his words, he “wanted to accumulate knowledge and open up a combination of possibilities.”[894](#footnote-897) Thus, using heterogenous relations to effect bisociation—which refers to the simultaneous mental association of an idea or object across two fields that are not normally regarded as related—Luhmann did in fact create combinations of possibilities.[895](#footnote-896) Furthermore, he did this by first reducing the complexity of books he read by extracting irresistible material. He then added back complexity by way of bisociating the material using links. “In a way,” Luhmann said, “the [Antinet Zettelkasten] is a reduction to build complexity.”[896](#footnote-895) 回想一下，Luhmann 设计了 ​​Antinet，因为用他的话来说，他 “想要积累知识并开辟可能性的组合。”894 因此，使用异质关系来影响 bisociation——指的是一个想法或对象在整个过程中的同时心理关联。两个通常不相关的领域——卢曼实际上创造了可能性的组合。895 此外，他首先通过提取不可抗拒的材料来降低他阅读的书籍的复杂性。然后，他通过使用链接将材料关联起来，增加了复杂性。 “在某种程度上，”Luhmann 说，“[Antinet Zettelkasten] 降低了构建的复杂性。”896

In brief the Antinet is one big network which enables one to create bisociations by way of linking ideas across different branches of knowledge. As you’ve seen, this is something that can happen in several ways using an Antinet, at the core of which is randomness, surprise, and accidents. 简而言之，Antinet 是一个大网络，它使人们能够通过将不同知识分支的思想联系起来来创建 bisociations。如您所见，使用 Antinet 可以通过多种方式发生这种情况，其核心是随机性、意外和事故。

**Accidents 事故**
----------------

Like randomness, accidents are a feature, not a bug. Accidents play a most crucial part in advancing the evolution of organisms. Likewise, they play a most crucial part in advancing thinking. Luhmann understood this as well. “The role of accidents,” he wrote, “in the theory of science is not disputed. If you employ evolutionary models, accidents assume a most important role.”[897](#footnote-894) 与随机性一样，意外是一种特性，而不是错误。事故在推动有机体的进化中起着最关键的作用。同样，它们在推进思维方面发挥着最关键的作用。卢曼也明白这一点。 “事故的作用，” 他写道，“在科学理论中没有争议。如果你采用进化模型，事故将扮演最重要的角色。”897

How does one unleash the power of accidents? First, you must understand what is meant by the term accident. We’re not trying to create needless accidents. We’re trying to create useful accidents. Useful accidents are those which are usually surprising in nature. In the section on surprises we explored the types of accidents that are useful. Accidents that involve interesting heterogenous relations and fascinating bisociations are the accidents we’re aiming for with the Antinet. 如何释放事故的力量？首先，您必须了解事故一词的含义。我们不想制造不必要的事故。我们正在努力制造有用的事故。有用的意外是那些通常在本质上令人惊讶的意外。在惊喜部分，我们探讨了有用的事故类型。涉及有趣的异质关系和令人着迷的分离的事故是我们用 Antinet 瞄准的事故。

One way the Antinet generates the accidents we’re looking for comes from its analog nature: when surfing through the Antinet and shuffling through cards, one increases the probability of useful accidents. Antinet 产生我们正在寻找的事故的一种方式来自于它的模拟性质：当通过 Antinet 冲浪和洗牌时，一个人增加了有用事故的可能性。

Some of the best advice from scholars and researchers focuses on this act. While doing online research is faster, it misses out on the serendipity of physical exploration. An excellent library encompasses such features. It possesses journals, books, and librarians who are shockingly helpful and more knowledgeable than we give them credit for. Accidents emerge from “prowling the stacks” of books related to the field you’re interested in.[898](#footnote-893) 学者和研究人员的一些最佳建议都集中在这一行为上。虽然进行在线研究速度更快，但它错过了物理探索的偶然性。一个优秀的图书馆包含这些功能。它拥有期刊、书籍和图书馆员，他们非常乐于助人，知识渊博，超出我们的想象。与你感兴趣的领域相关的书籍 “在书堆中徘徊” 会引发意外。 898

The power of prowling the stacks of books also applies to notecards. The power of sifting through notecards, and in turn, yielding fruitful accidents, is something scholars have known for quite some time. This powerful feature of card indexes first became recognized by scholars in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Scholars noted that Antinet systems, with their structural decoupling of knowledge into individual notecards, ends up producing “a substantial number of combinations and insights that otherwise might not have existed.”[899](#footnote-892) 在书堆中徘徊的力量也适用于记事卡。筛选记事卡的力量，反过来，产生富有成果的事故，这是学者们已经知道了很长一段时间的事情。卡片索引的这一强大功能在 17 和 18 世纪首先被学者们所认识。学者们指出，Antinet 系统通过将知识结构解耦为单独的记事卡，最终产生了 “大量的组合和见解，否则这些组合和见解可能不存在。”899

**Movement over Meditation 运动胜于冥想**

“I do not believe in coincidence. I believe that if you keep moving, you expose yourself to a better chance of accidents happening, some good and some bad.”“我不相信巧合。我相信，如果你继续前进，你就会更有可能发生事故，有好有坏。”

–Travis McGee, in A Purple Place for Dying[900](#footnote-891)– Travis McGee，在紫色的垂死之地 900

Accidents don’t come solely from the unique tree structure of the Antinet, however. One other thing is required: movement. 然而，事故不仅仅来自 Antinet 独特的树结构。还需要另一件事：运动。

One of my mentors, Sir Gary Halbert, preached movement over meditation. In essence, the more you move, the more success you have. The more you create and learn from mistakes, the luckier you’ll get. Luhmann himself was tirelessly curious. He kept moving, kept reading, and kept uncovering useful accidents. 我的一位导师加里 · 哈尔伯特爵士 (Sir Gary Halbert) 鼓吹运动胜于冥想。从本质上讲，你移动得越多，你就越成功。你创造的越多，从错误中吸取的教训越多，你就会越幸运。卢曼本人也不知疲倦地好奇。他不停地移动，不停地阅读，不断地发现有用的意外。

This flies in the face of the conventional and popular wisdom today. The advice we hear centers on meditating and sitting under a tree. The advice we hear is that stillness is key. Yet on the other end of the spectrum (literally) we have people moving constantly. They’re the ones who are going to put the human race on Mars. 这与当今的传统和流行智慧背道而驰。我们听到的建议集中在冥想和坐在树下。我们听到的建议是静止是关键。然而，在频谱的另一端（字面意思），我们有人在不断地移动。他们是要将人类送上火星的人。

Of course, it’s a balancing act (like everything). However, if you want to create useful accidents with your Antinet, you need to keep moving. You need to keep creating and learning. 当然，这是一种平衡行为（就像所有事情一样）。但是，如果你想用 Antinet 制造有用的事故，你需要继续前进。你需要不断地创造和学习。

Even if the knowledge you create isn’t useful immediately, there’s a good chance it will be useful later on. During the writing of this book, I’ve used material and notecards written from many years ago. I had no idea they would be used for a project when I created them. It’s something you’ll experience as well. 即使您创建的知识不会立即派上用场，但以后很有可能会派上用场。在本书的写作过程中，我使用了很多年前写的材料和记事卡。我在创建它们时并不知道它们会用于项目。这也是你会经历的事情。

When Luhmann was working on a new publication he would document and record how his thought process evolved.[901](#footnote-890) He would take on publication requests and work on articles that would later prove very useful in other areas. Over the course of producing these developments, Luhmann’s theories compounded and evolved. By moving, he created more material which proved useful for other areas of his work. His movement to constantly take on publication projects allowed him to create useful accidents which compounded his actions. It created the rich material that would form his “super theory” of society. 当 Luhmann 致力于新的出版物时，他会记录并记录他的思维过程是如何演变的。901 他会接受出版请求并撰写后来被证明在其他领域非常有用的文章。在产生这些发展的过程中，卢曼的理论得到了复合和发展。通过移动，他创造了更多材料，这些材料被证明对他工作的其他领域有用。他不断承担出版项目的运动使他能够创造有用的意外事件，从而使他的行动更加复杂。它创造了构成他的社会 “超级理论” 的丰富材料。

While accidents, and randomness are the key components we’re speaking of, the question then becomes: in what spirit of mind does one best cultivate useful accidents? That question is what we’ll answer next. 虽然意外和随机性是我们所说的关键组成部分，但问题就变成了：以什么样的精神精神最能培养有用的意外？这个问题是我们接下来要回答的。

**Playfulness, Curiosity, and Tinkering 嬉戏、好奇心和修修补补**
-----------------------------------------------------

Halfway through the month of June in 1749, all of Britain was buzzing with excitement. Things were especially abuzz in Surrey County, which borders London. The excitement revolved around one thing: a matchup between two of Britain’s cricket clubs, the All England and the Surrey Cricket Clubs. The cricket teams were viewed as the titans of those times. “The match excited considerable interest and was attended by a very numerous body of spectators,” wrote one who attended.[902](#footnote-889)1749 年 6 月中旬，整个英国都兴奋不已。在与伦敦接壤的萨里郡，事情尤其热闹。兴奋围绕着一件事：英国的两个板球俱乐部，全英板球俱乐部和萨里板球俱乐部之间的对决。板球队被视为那个时代的巨头。 “这场比赛引起了极大的兴趣，有很多观众观看，” 一位参加比赛的人写道。 902

The match between the two clubs was intense. The score was close; however in a wild upset victory, Surrey came away with the win. The best player in the match, Henry Venn, was exhausted. The other players on the team looked up to Henry. He was bold, disciplined, resolute, passionate, and very (very) intense. 两家具乐部之间的比赛非常激烈。比分很接近；然而，在一场疯狂的爆冷胜利中，萨里队赢得了胜利。比赛中最好的球员亨利 · 维恩筋疲力尽。球队中的其他球员都仰望着亨利。他大胆、自律、果断、热情，而且非常（非常）热情。

After Surrey came away with the victory Henry’s teammates crowded around him. They gathered to celebrate the upset victory. Yet the excitement came to a stop and things quickly settled down. The fans stopped celebrating and fell quiet. 在萨里队取得胜利后，亨利的队友们围在他身边。他们聚在一起庆祝这场意外的胜利。然而兴奋停止了，事情很快就平静下来了。球迷停止庆祝，安静下来。

Everyone was looking at Henry whose face was red, as if he was angry. He threw down his bat and declared, “Whoever wants a bat, then here! Take it. I have no further occasion for it!”[903](#footnote-888) 每个人都看着脸红的亨利，好像他很生气。他扔下球棒并宣布：“谁想要球棒，就来吧！拿去。我没有更多的理由了！”903

His teammates were shocked. Their hero was quitting on the spot! One of his teammates bravely asked Henry why he was quitting, and Henry replied, “Because I am to be ordained on Sunday.” Henry explained he was quitting the game of cricket for God. He feared a member of his church remarking to him, “Nice game yesterday, Reverend!” 他的队友都惊呆了。他们的英雄当场退出！他的一位队友勇敢地问亨利为什么要辞职，亨利回答说：“因为我将在星期天受命。” 亨利解释说他要为上帝放弃板球运动。他害怕他的教会成员对他说：“昨天打得不错，牧师！”

Henry intended to be a man who was taken seriously. To his mind this meant he must take life seriously, and this meant one thing: cutting out all forms of play. 亨利打算成为一个被认真对待的人。在他看来，这意味着他必须认真对待生活，而这意味着一件事：切断所有形式的游戏。

Sadly, what followed was all but fulfillment and respect for Henry. His health quickly declined by “a sudden transition from a course of most violent exercise to a life of comparative inactivity.”[904](#footnote-887) Yet Henry pushed through the health issues and stuck with a strict regimen. He would wake up at five in the morning and preach ceaselessly all day. This continued on until he had a breakdown at age forty-nine. Henry burnt himself out and was relegated to a small country parish where he lived for another twenty six years. 可悲的是，随之而来的是对亨利的满足和尊重。他的健康状况因 “从最剧烈的运动过程突然过渡到相对缺乏活动的生活而迅速下降”。904 然而，亨利克服了健康问题并坚持严格的养生之道。他会在早上五点起床，整天不停地讲道。这种情况一直持续到他四十九岁时精神崩溃。亨利筋疲力尽，流落到一个乡村小教区，又在那里生活了 26 年。

Two generations of protestant missionaries followed in their forebear’s footsteps. Both his son (John) and his grandson (also named Henry) became Anglican clergymen. 两代新教传教士追随他们祖先的脚步。他的儿子（约翰）和孙子（也叫亨利）都成为了圣公会牧师。

Yet Henry’s physical and mental breakdown hung over the family. It was an unspoken yet very present tension, a tension between work for God vs. play (in the form of cricket). 然而，亨利的身心崩溃笼罩着这个家庭。这是一种不言而喻但又非常现实的紧张关系，一种为上帝工作与玩耍（以板球形式）之间的紧张关系。

This tension was present during the upbringing of Henry Venn’s great grandson, John Venn. 这种紧张关系在亨利 · 维恩的曾孙约翰 · 维恩的成长过程中就存在了。

John was a bright young man. Despite his strict Anglican upbringing, he became interested in mathematics and philosophy. In spite of his interests, John gave in to the religious indoctrination and ended up following in his family’s footsteps, becoming ordained as an Anglican priest in 1859. 约翰是个聪明的年轻人。尽管受到严格的英国国教教育，他还是对数学和哲学产生了兴趣。尽管有兴趣，约翰还是屈服于宗教灌输，最终追随家人的脚步，于 1859 年被任命为圣公会牧师。

Unlike his great grandfather, however, John didn’t wish to give up his other interests in his life. He loved cricket and outdoor activities like mountain climbing and he did not want to give his interest up as had his great grandfather.[905](#footnote-886) Instead of giving up his interests in mathematics and philosophy, John continued his studies, and, in 1883, he resigned from the clergy after concluding that his religion was incompatible with his philosophical beliefs. 然而，与他的曾祖父不同，约翰不想放弃他生活中的其他兴趣。他喜欢板球和登山等户外活动，他不想像他的曾祖父那样放弃自己的兴趣。905 约翰没有放弃他对数学和哲学的兴趣，而是继续他的学业，并于 1883 年辞去了他的职务。神职人员断定他的宗教与他的哲学信仰不相容。

John continued to pursue life with a playful spirit. His passions ranged from mathematics, probability theory, and philosophy, to tinkering with inventions and machinery. He would go on to create the first cricket machine in history. It bowled cricket balls and is said to have struck out the leading batsman of the Australian cricket club four times in a row.[906](#footnote-885) 约翰继续以嬉戏的精神追求生活。他的爱好范围从数学、概率论和哲学，到修补发明和机械。他将继续创造历史上第一台板球机。它投板球，据说连续四次三振澳大利亚板球俱乐部的主要击球手。 906

Now, the reason you probably know John Venn stems from the following diagram: 现在，您可能知道 John Venn 的原因源于下图：

The Venn Diagram 维恩图

All of John Venn’s wide-ranging interests ironically led him to create a diagram in symbolic logic. This diagram is widely used and bears his name to this day. 具有讽刺意味的是，John Venn 广泛的兴趣促使他创建了符号逻辑图。此图被广泛使用，至今仍以他的名字命名。

This breakthrough in symbolic logic was not unearthed in the same manner John’s great grandfather operated. It was not unearthed through rigid routine and workaholism. John was playful in spirit, he was a tinkerer, and he was curious. 这种符号逻辑的突破并不是以约翰的曾祖父运作的方式挖掘出来的。它不是通过严格的常规和工作狂挖掘出来的。约翰是个顽皮的人，他是个修补匠，而且他很好奇。

Those who love order and structure may at first have trouble adopting the philosophy of the Antinet. In the land of binary, the world is perfectly ordered. This (0), or not this (1) underlies the language of digital systems. Binary logic makes life quite simple. But that’s not reality. There’s entropy and chaos in reality. 喜欢秩序和结构的人一开始可能难以接受 Antinet 的哲学。在二进制领域，世界是完美有序的。这个 (0) 或不是这个 (1) 是数字系统语言的基础。二进制逻辑使生活变得非常简单。但这不是现实。现实中存在熵和混沌。

You must be willing to submit to randomness. You must be willing to submit to the mess of knowledge development, and to adopt and appreciate the value of randomness, embracing odd structures and surprises along the way. It involves adopting a playful mindset when working with your knowledge. Hopefully this story about John Venn will remind you of this. 你必须愿意服从随机性。你必须乐于接受知识发展的混乱，接受和欣赏随机性的价值，一路拥抱奇怪的结构和惊喜。它涉及在使用您的知识时采用有趣的心态。希望这个关于 John Venn 的故事会让你想起这一点。

To make sure I don’t forget the lesson of John Venn, I purchased a cricket ball online which I keep in my office. Whenever I see it, I’m reminded to adopt the playful tinkering mindset of John Venn. This is the spirit I believe best suited for working with an Antinet. A playful, curious spirit. 为了确保我不会忘记 John Venn 的教训，我在网上买了一个板球，放在办公室里。每当我看到它时，都会提醒我采用约翰 · 维恩 (John Venn) 顽皮的修修补补的心态。这是我认为最适合与 Antinet 合作的精神。一种顽皮、好奇的精神。

In my YouTube videos I teach the Antinet from my office. Using my iPhone camera, I navigate around and teach certain aspects. Some viewers have commented, asking why there’s a cricket ball sitting around. Now you know why. It’s a great reminder. Adopting playfulness, randomness, and curiosity into your knowledge workflow is something one should not forget. 在我的 YouTube 视频中，我在办公室教授 Antinet。我使用我的 iPhone 相机四处导航并教授某些方面的知识。一些观众评论说，为什么周围会有一个板球。现在你知道为什么了。这是一个很好的提醒。在您的知识工作流程中采用好玩、随机和好奇心是一件不应该忘记的事情。

Now, as we end this book, I’d like to invite you to adopt this same spirit. Take it with you into the world. The spirit of playfulness, randomness, and curiosity. 现在，当我们结束本书时，我想邀请你采用同样的精神。带着它走进这个世界。爱玩、随性、好奇的精神。

I had no idea I’d be ending this book with this seemingly random story of John Venn. His story relates to the playful intellectual human spirit. This is but another example of randomness and accidents being brought forth by the Antinet. Quite frankly, it serves as a fitting end for such a book. 我不知道我会以约翰 · 维恩这个看似随意的故事来结束这本书。他的故事与顽皮的知识分子精神有关。这只是 Antinet 带来的随机性和事故的另一个例子。坦率地说，它是这样一本书的合适结尾。

I wish you enjoyment in your journey. The journey of getting in touch with that deep, internal voice inside of you. I wish you luck in your intellectual pursuits and the things you will create (with the help of your Antinet). 祝您旅途愉快。接触你内心深处的内在声音的旅程。祝你在智力追求和你将要创造的事物中好运（在你的 Antinet 的帮助下）。

Please keep in touch and share your own Antinet Zettelkasten journey with me. You can keep in touch by visiting my website: [https://scottscheper.com](https://scottscheper.com/). 请保持联系并与我分享您自己的 Antinet Zettelkasten 之旅。您可以通过访问我的网站保持联系：https://scottscheper.com。

Stay crispy, my friend. 保持酥脆，我的朋友。
